It also comes with a number of high-quality silicone ear tips. You must try them all to determine which set best fits you. Ear tips make or break your experience. If the bass is lacking, it is probably due to poor fit of your ear tips.

As for the sound quality, I really like this IEM. It sounds natural with a slight bump in mid bass. I prefer warm and dark sound. I like how tight the bass is. It is not super punchy but sounds just right. The bass is very clean. It gives you the sense of weight but not overwhelming. Sometimes I do wish it had a bit more bass when listening to Jazz.

The mids are thick and comfortable. I prefer Jazz and female vocals. This IEM sounds so relaxing that I can listen to it for hours. As for the highs, it is slightly on the bright side, but not shouty. The detail is very good. Soundstage is good for IEM, and imaging is great. Instrument separation is surprisingly capable. I have no problem pinpointing the position of different instruments.

Overall, I really like Dunu Titan S. For the price, it is as good as it gets. Highly recommended.

title: A very nice keyboard with many connection options.
text:
Typically I stick to higher end gaming keyboards. Mechanical and optical switches are generally my go to. I had never used a keyboard from this brand before so when I was given the chance to grab one, I figured I would see how it stacks up.

So far I'm fairly impressed. I've used some tournament edition keyboards with the smaller form factor from other brands so I knew what I was getting into when it came to the size of the keyboard. All in all, sizing is fine. They key placement and distance between keys works fine. I do run into issues at times where my fingers get lost on the right side of the keyboard. Getting used to that will come in time though. The key response is quick. They are mechanical switches but they do manage to deaden the sound a bit which is nice. The RGB features are basic at best. You have a few settings you can select from and all of it is done directly on the keyboard itself. It has your normal basic modes. It illuminates well though and you can increase/decrease the brightness. The build quality is nice. For being a 75% keyboard, it has some weight to it. I like the fact the keys are labeled for both Mac and PC. I primarily use it on my PC though. The place where it seems to shine is in the connectivity department. I can connect it by bluetooth to numerous devices or I can have it wired. I generally run wired to my main PC and if I need to use it on my MacBook or other devices, I just unplug it from the PC and connect by BT to the other device. It works out nicely.

From a gaming standpoint (which I do a lot of), I'm not certain that I like it as much yet. Emphasis on the "yet". I know it takes some time to become accustomed to a new keyboard. The response and feel. I'm going to continue gaming on it for a while to see if I become more adapted to it. It just feels different than what I'm used to. It most likely has to do with the key spacing more so than anything else.

This is definitely a nice keyboard and I recommend it. I will most likely continue to use it as my daily keyboard for a while longer to see how it holds up over time.

title: Would only work with optical and the sound isn't as good as my TV
text:
I have an Omni Fire TV which I purchased about 6 months ago. I was excited about this sound bar - especially when I unboxed it. It looks fantastic and I thought for sure it'd be a very nice upgrade to the sound. I tried bluetooth first and it connected without a problem, but there was no sound. I tried everything I could think of but no-go. I've hooked up many speaker systems so I can almost always figure out what the problem is and it's never a big deal to me.

I next tried hdmi - same thing no sound. Next, I tried the optical (which I've never used before) and it worked immediately with no problem. Well, no problem getting sound at least. A few problems came up: My Fire remote wouldn't change the sound so I would have to use the soundbar remote for sound. That's pretty much a no-go for me because that was a typical issue with technology 20 years ago - today, it's highly unusual that I can't get the soundbar to obey the Fire TV commands.

Also, the sound quality wasn't nearly as good as the native speakers on the TV. There was very little bass and the upper ranges sounded... well, what's the word? Tinny and flat? It was definitely not an improvement in sound but a significant downgrade.

This leaves the final problem which out of them all, for me, is a complete deal breaker. The soundbar volume ranges from 1-30. On 2 it was too loud for me, on 1 it was too soft. The difference between those two was huge - no gradation in sound between the numbers.

With all of the issues, I spent a long time trying to remedy them. I definitely didn't give up after 5 mins. Pretty much a whole day was spent trying to make the soundbar produce good, quality sound. I've read the reviews from others and I don't know if I got a dud or what - so many people love theirs. Overall I'm very disappointed. There's no way I'll be using this soundbar, unfortunately.

* This review is for: LARKSOUND All-in-One 2.1 Sound Bar for TV, 36 Inch Soundbar with Build-in Subwoofer, Surround Sound System TV Speaker with Bluetooth/HDMI ARC/Optical/AUX/USB

title: Good budget ANC over-the-ear headphones, but no case and tight headband
text:
I used these recently on a road trip which had two 10hr+ days in the car during my "rest period" as a passenger. I paired these headphones with my iPhone and iPad Pro, listening to music and also watching content from Netflix. Although neither device has a headphone jack, I appreciate that the manufacturer includes the capability to use a cord, since that would come in particularly handy using in-seat entertainment on an airplane. I own a set of wired Bose QuietComfort headphones that are over 10 years old and also more modern 1st gen Air Pods Pro, so that's what I will be comparing the noise cancellation against.

I was pleasantly surprised at the sound quality. I wouldn't say it is better than the Air Pods Pro, but was very good for the price point. Many inexpensive headphones emphasize too much bass or not enough, these seem to be very well balanced. The noise cancellation was also effective at getting rid of the road noise. It is old school noise cancellation focused primarily on the lower range frequencies like road noise, airplane hum, etc. not next-level sophistication like the QC700s, Air Pods Pro 2, or Air Pods Max. But entirely appropriate for the price point, since those models cost several times more than these.

Two things hold me back from giving these headphones five stars. 1) there is no case. I ended up storing them in the cardboard box that they shipped in, but that is not gonna hold up long term. I hoped that they might fit inside my old QuietComfort case but alas that did not work. Looking at the construction materials and also knowing how my QuietComfort held up with a case, I don't think these will last long just thrown loosely into a bag. 2) the tension on the headband is quite tight. I found myself taking these off after 3-4 hours because they were hurting my ears. Perhaps the tension will loosen over time/usage, but I can't imagine wearing these for a whole 8 hour work day.

Another minor problem that I encountered - which possibly may be an issue only with Apple devices: there was a slight lip-sync delay when I was watching a show on Netflix. This delay did not occur when I switched to the Air Pods Pro, so possibly there is an issue with the Bluetooth handshaking between these headphones and Apple products.

title: Good tertiary monitor for multi-monitor setups and TM MFDs
text:
I use mine for a flight sim setup where i put little maps, FPL, Navigraph, MSFS and XP12 detached windows, and Helios button displays for DCS. I also have a detachable TM MFD setup (2) that fits great over the widescreen, allowing me to port both MFD's to the same screen under each MFD bezel. They both just fit with room on either side and in the middle to adjust to the MFD bezel position. Edge is thick enough to hold MFDs with tape if that is what you prefer. The monitor is plug and play, with a quick adjustment in Windows 10 display settings to get it perfect. Oh I left the plastic protective cover on the screen to keep the TM MFDs from damaging the screen.
Display is not great, but tbf, that wasn't my goal. Its a small monitor and you are NOT gonna be watching 1080p movies on it IMHO. I mean you can, but its not that great. Color is a bit diffused, but brightness is excellent. Contrast ratio is not great and there is a distinctive "bright spot" in the lower left hand corner (which I've covered conveniently with a TM MFD bezel plate!) My maps and cockpit repeaters / HUD look fine on it. It is 1920x1080 so the text / icons are very small. But I like that. Menu is a bit fumbled for the monitor settings, with the buttons on the back right side.
HDMI cable provided is not good, but there is a handy extension provided to offset the HDMI plug from the back (convenient as I don't always use it (like swapping in a VR headset instead) and can easily unplug the HDMI without screwing up my setup. The stand is meh. It holds the monitor ok, but you can't use it to hold it when the MFDs are on it, and try to press. It folds back and moves around with any decent pressing pressure. Therefore I mounted it against my main monitor stand to press up against. Works 4.0.
I was surprised to hear it had speakers (which my Win 10 defaulted to when I plugged it in. Not terrible but fairly loud for the size of the monitor. Good backup speaker I guess.
All in all, happy with it. It gets daily use.

title: The best streamer on the market today
text:
This device has dethroned the Nvidia shield 2019 as the premier streaming device.

Amazon finally hit it right with this device. If you can get past the user interface, and that is very subjective because I happen to like the interface,this third generation cube does everything the other devices do, and then some.

It beats the Apple TV 4K because the Alexa integration into the cube gives it the edge. The Apple TV 4K does a better job at frame rate switching, but that is becoming less important since TVs today do a pretty good job of extracting 24p content from 60p signal from the streamer. Virtually all content that is provided by the streaming services is 23.976 frames per second or 24.0 frames per second (i.e. 24p).

The last time I checked, the cube will not output content at 24.0 frames per second or 30.0 frames per second or 60.0 frames per second. Admittedly, there is not much material that is created using those exact frame rates. But if you do come across some content like Amazon's own rings of power that is created at exactly 24.0 frames per second, then you might see an occasional frame jump every 42 seconds. Not everyone is susceptible to that frame jump.

It beats the Nvidia shield 2019 because it bit streams lossless audio from local rips. The super resolution feature of the cube is not as good as the shields AI upscaling, but it is better than the upscaling the other streamers provide.

I have the harmony hub remote control setup. I added the skill for Alexa to control my setup so now I can turn on and off my system with just using my voice.

The lan interface is something that I do not use. So while it is maxed out at 100 megabit, which could mean about 80 to 90 Mbits of real world performance, that is not fast enough when streaming 4K rips from a Plex server or using Kodi. I have Wi-Fi 6 and my internal lan speed is well over 500 megabits per second to the cube. The ethernet port is really only needed if you have horrible Wi-Fi service. This cube has a nice Wi-Fi radio in it with some pretty good range.

I highly recommend the cube.

title: Works great with decent sound & nice cheap solution!
text:
I wasn't looking for anything specific for wirelessly streaming music out of my phone or laptop into my vintage Kenwood and Vector Research AM/FM receivers from the late 70's. So I figured I would initially try this Esinkin Bluetooth adapter device out, as is was under $25. I just wanted to try out the technology, even though there are much higher spec and higher cost receiver adapters out there to choose from. I found out it is really the exact same device as the Logitech version, which costs just a little more. Anyway, the simple illustration type instructions could be better if written out, but easy to decipher. I like that it came with power plug adapter, and a simple 1/8" into RCA plugs cord to get you going immediately. You can also run a dedicated short RCA cord from the Esinkin device into your Aux or Tape Monitor input jacks, but you must supply that RCA cord, which many people have lying around. Note: Do NOT plug it into the Phono input jacks. Instructions indicate you CAN actually power it off by holding down the top pairing button for at least 3 seconds. But it paired very quickly with my android phone, no problem. I have the Esinkin always in "auto on" mode by simply having its power adapter plugged into the "switched" power outlet on back of both my vintage receivers, so it will only power on and attempt to connect to my Bluetooth music devices when actually I power up the receivers themselves. Perfect. From day one since using it works flawlessly and provides nice acceptable sound when streaming Pandora, Spotify, or YouTube audio. Good lows and highs. You can look up the specs, but again will not be up to the same sound quality you may get out of the ones costing hundreds more. I get a more compressed sound quality of say MP3 files, and it will not be a full CD or FLAC/lossless audio quality. But it works great for my needs and not feeling a need to upgrade to anything else at the moment. More than satisfactory for streaming background music too. Also, the signal range was fine to any room in the house I was in with my phone, but I have a smaller home. I'm just glad I found a cool new unobtrusive device that gives me another music source option to run into my vintage home receivers, and enjoy when not listening to AM/FM, phono, or CD player. No complaints so far.
-Ken V.

title: Good headphones for a budget price
text:
I was looking for another pair of headphones/earbuds that I could keep at work. I had purchased a pair of Capoxo D8 headphones a few months ago and really liked them. Keep those at home. Great sound and features for the price. Anyways, since I was already familiar with Capaxo brand, I saw these smaller headphones with similar features.

Key highlights that I like about these headphones/earbuds:
-Extremely comfortable to wear. They don't feel heavy and fit very well. Barely feel them in your ear. I feel they fit better than the higher end headphones I have. Can shake my head and they don't budge unlike some of my past headphones/earbuds that come loose after 20-30mins or you have to adjust them so they fit better in your ear.
-The headphones/earbuds are very compact and light. I like the compact size. As previously mentioned you can barely feel them.
- I like the color of them. Very stylish. Nicer than the white color on the competitor headphones.
-One of the best features is they have wireless charging! This is so convenient compared to my old headphones that you plugged into a USB port. Theres a USB C port but I'd rather do wireless charging.
The case is compact and not bulky. That was one complaint I had with my Capoxo D8 headphones. The case was rather large but this case is very small where its barely noticeable in your pocket.
-Offer an excellent amount of battery life. They charge quickly and lasted me about 4 days running for 8hrs) before having to recharge them. My old headphones/earbuds would only last for about 4-5hours and then I would have to recharge them. I also like that they have a display with the battery life.
-The hinge feels solid and not flimsy. Constructed very well. You can tell its a quality product.
-They have good sound quality. Good amount of treble and bass. Not a lot of bass that it drowns out the music and treble that they are screeching when singing.

Overall I am very happy with these headphones/earbuds and would recommend them to anyone looking for a good pair of headphones/earbuds that won't break the bank. You'll be happy with these headphones/earbuds.

title: Excellent Sound Quality!
text:
OVERALL: great value, compact design, great battery, single-device connection, easy controls

PROS: These earbuds have the best sound quality and BASS of all the wireless Bluetooth devices I own. The Battery arrives charged and ready to go and is unbelievably long-lasting, with extra charges in the charging case. I really like the controls and system of indicators, which are clearly explained in both the full manual as well as a smaller quick guide that I kept on my desk for the first few days. There are no buttons, all controls are just different taps on either L/R. That being said, the controls are very sensitive and I often accidentally change the volume when messing with my hair or glasses. But it's just as easily changed back. Pairing with a device is as easy as taking the earbuds out of the case and selecting the N09-A device in the Bluetooth settings on your phone/computer/TV. After charging, the earbuds connect automatically to the last device they were connected to, assuming that the device has Bluetooth turned on.
I had low expectations for the phone function after experiences with older devices, but the phone functions on these earbuds are EXCELLENT. They work very similarly to modern Bluetooth hearing aids, whereby you accept, decline, and end calls with a tap or hold of either earpiece. Volume and music control works on a left/right system whereby the right earpiece increases volume or skips to the next music track, and the left decreases volume or skips back a track. Pretty easy stuff to learn with a little practice. You don't have to worry about wasting battery if you forget to turn them off: there is no "OFF" function, and they turn themselves off after 5 minutes of no Bluetooth connection (or when you put them into the case).

CON: You can "pair" these earbuds with multiple Bluetooth devices of pretty much any type (transmitter, phone, computer, TV) BUT they will only "connect" with one device at a time. So, for example, I can't use them with my phone and computer at the same time. To switch from my laptop to my phone, for example, I have to turn Bluetooth off on the laptop, and then select the N09-A device on my phone. I have cheaper earbuds that can handle two devices and/or more seamlessly transition from one to the other.

title: Worthless
text:
I bought this to get OTA TV channels, installed it and it cannot even pick up channels that are 30 miles away. Total piece of junk.

I seem to have had the same experience as many other negative reviewers with the seller trying to bribe me.

"Hello!

My name is Michael,
I noticed you had a bad experience with our HDTV Antenna, and you left a negative review on Amazon:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/R23HQJ3SPYBVJ0/ref=cm_cr_getr_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B07FVLXHYV

I am sorry that you are disappointed, and we want to smooth this inconvenience out for you. Therefore, we would like to offer you a $50 Amazon Gift Card in order to make up for this misfortune.

The only thing we ask you is to delete the review. It will only take a few seconds of your time, and you will gain a generous gift for it.

We are a small family company and we strive to ensure that the expectations of each of our customers are satisfied.
Your feedback made us draw conclusions about our mistakes and drawbacks, and now we would like to make up for them and compensate for the troubles we have caused.

Also, we are willing to assist you with any issues related to our antenna, so please do not hesitate to ask for assistance if you still use or want to use our product. We will gladly investigate the issue along with all possible reasons that may have lead to it, and will help you with resolving it!

I am really looking forward to hearing from you!

Kind Regards,
Michael"

I was invited to join Vine because I have reviewed tons of items on Amazon and I always leave a fair review.
If I give an item a bad review and the seller asks to send me a replacement and the replacement works, I will update my review. In the case of this product, I asked for a second one via Amazon, Return/Replace policy, that one too was junk, so I returned both and left a bad review.

title: Played this thing in the sun and the battery died.
text: When I saw this item I was excited.  I like being prepared for emergencies.  This has a solar panel, is supposedly waterproof, has a speaker, flashlight, radio, and for some reason party lights.  So in terms of use lets look at the speaker and bluetooth function.  This device connected easily and the speaker is loud.  The sound quality is good not great, not being full sounding, and slightly garbled on some songs when played at full volume.  The flashlight works and has a strobe function.  The radio works. The party lights work.  It has several inputs on the back and an on off switch none of which looked weather rated and decided not to tempt fate and ruin this thing.  There is no display so you cannot see what radio station you are listening to, volume, mode, nor your battery percentage, etc.  The sound when on the radio function was sub par, but I think of this as more of an emergency feature in this day and age, so I did not judge that too harshly.  The buttons are very confusing overall, and with no printed instructions on the unit you could get very confused trying to operate this without the box that seemed to be the only instruction list included.  I listened to it outside on BT and got about 3 hours with 80% battery (it did show battery % under my bluetooth on the phone) on full volume.  All of this would have gotten it 3 stars from me normally.  So why 1 star?  I used it outside on a sunny day and it died after 3 hours as I said.  If there is some special way to get it to charge using the solar panel I don't know.  There is no special instructions from what I saw, so I should have been able to use this in the sun and it should have charged it, or at least maintained the original battery level instead of letting it drain out.  In an emergency this would be useless since you couldn't maintain the battery with no power supply.  And I couldn't turn off the party lights, and there were no instructions, if there is a way to do so.  In any case I don't know how many flashlight radio emergency situations that call for different colored flashing lights you can't get rid of.  So 1 star, add a display, give me confidence this is weather proof, kill the party lights, and most importantly get your solar panel to work, and I'd be glad to give it 5 stars.

title: Light works better than ring and here's why...
text:
If you are tired of ring reflections on your glasses or an odd halo effect, this light is perfect for you.

I'll start by saying the pictures for this device and the illumination shown are 100% accurate - so much that there is no need for me to include pictures of my face (thank goodness). included are pictures of the set up and the "instruction manual" that come with the light.

The seller notes the run time is 120 min. I found on the bright setting the light will go out after 90 - 120 min ... even though it is plugged in via the USB C compatible charging cable (included). The cable is 1 meter long (about 39 in.). It did not come charged right out of the box, so I had to charge it for two hours first. This is important, as it looks like it doesn't work at first glance - it really needs to be fully charged before using or the light will go off prematurely. Just because it is plugged into a power source, it doesn't work right away as it takes time for the Li-On 1500 m Ah to charge.

The good thing is that it the light rotates side to side and it clamps perfectly on top of a lap top and doesn't obscure the camera. It also doesn't give me the ring reflection on my glasses that those round lights do. This light is definitely better than the overrated ring lights.

The issue is I am on Zoom for hours at a time and even 2 hours is too short if I was to use the lowest light setting. This product is good for short calls or videos and/or a camera if you cannot plug the light into a power source. I will need to use another light to supplement this one (or take a job with less Zoom meetings!!) as it does go out after two hours to recharge. This will work well while on travel and for short meetings. The clamp on this light is superb.

The instructions are funny. "Manul of fill light" is definitely a bad translation and the instructions to "connect the power outlet charging" are 4 steps of rubbish. Still... most could figure out how to attach the included cord from the light to your power block (not included).

This product arrived really fast and the minimal packaging is appreciated. Hope this review helps.

title: Very happy with this case and keyboard
text:
I purchased this for my Surface Go 3 because I wanted the keyboard, I didn't care about the case. But after receiving it, the case is very nice.

As you can see from my pictures, the case has cut outs so you can easily turn on the tablet and adjust the volume. Also, on the side there is a nice cut out so the different openings can be accessed, such as the charging port. The case doesn't block anything that you need access to. The only thing I would like to have seen be different with the case, is some type of protection around the bottom of the tablet. This does have protection that goes around the base of the kickstand, but that will only protect the bottom of the tablet if the kickstand is in the closed position. Once open, there is no protection to the bottom of the tablet.

The keyboard did need to be charged before I could use it. Once charged setting it up to blue tooth was very easy. The included instructions are very easy to understand. It walked me through it step by step.

On the bottom right side of the keyboard is the on/off switch and the charging port for the keyboard. It uses a USB C cable.

I really like that the keyboard is wireless. I don't have to have it attached to my tablet for it to work. I just have to be within 33 feet. That makes it nice when I don't have a lot of room to sit at comfortably, I can have the keyboard separate from the tablet and everything still works. When you do want the keyboard to be attached, it is done magnetically. Just get the keyboard close to the edge of the tablet and it snaps right in place.

When you are done, just close the tablet using the keyboard as the cover and now you have the screen protected. The keyboard does not snap in place once you put it over the tablet itself, but it does keep the screen covered. It would have been nice to have some sort of snap mechanism that the keyboard went into to keep it secured to the front of the screen.

I think this is a fantastic keyboard and case. I had been pricing keyboards and going with this one saved me a lot of money and I got a case in the bargain. This is well worth the price.

title: A “Must Have” for your vehicle.
text:
Usually, I don’t write long reviews. But this product deserves a thorough review. You need this if your car came with “wired” Apple CarPlay. So many times I forgot to unplug and then take my phone with me when leaving the car. This adapter solves the problem, it’s “wireless Bluetooth” connectivity.
First, I checked out the reviews of all the available (and there’s dozens of them) units on Amazon.
This one seemed like the most promising one, at a reasonable cost (under $100).
Second, when you get it, you need to pair it with your vehicle. (I have a Lexus LS500). The pairing was somewhat difficult at first, so I figured out that I had to unpair my iPhone from the vehicle, then it would pair with the CarPlay adapter. Done!
Third, you should shut down your vehicle and restart. You will get a prompt on your screen that says: only one “Bluetooth” connection is required, so you click okay to connect the CarPlay as your choice.
Fourth, now the adapter is acting as the Bluetooth connection for your phone to the vehicle, which makes the “wireless Bluetooth” Apple CarPlay work.
Fifth, it works almost seamlessly most of the time.
Here’s where you might find it annoying.
Sometimes you will get the prompt to say “okay to connect with the Bluetooth adapter”, and sometimes it just connects automatically.
And, once in a while you will get a blank or blank screen with the words “CarPlay” and it might take a few seconds for it to connect. Other times you will have to unplug it from the USB and then plug it in again to restart it. It’s seamless about 90% of the time.
Sixth, because it will connect again with just a little minor effort (unplug and replug takes a couple seconds), I’m satisfied with the quality of the connection. After reading the reviews of other units (and again, there’s dozens of them) the few hiccups that I have experienced seems to be prevalent with most of them. So I’m keeping this.
The look and the use of the actual Apple CarPlay is identical, wired or wireless. So get the wireless adapter!

title: Works well, but no documentation
text:
The card is working well for what I need, which is eSATA ports. (5 stars) However, it did require me to figure out a few things on my own because no documentation came with it. (-1 star)

Package Contents

The packaging was soft (not rigid), but it appears that the card was unharmed in transit. I received the card (wrapped in an anti-static inside the package) as well as a mini CD (80mm diameter) that was not in any kind of protective cover or sleeve. The CD contains several different drivers without a clear indication of which was the correct one for this card.

Installing the Driver

Without the Driver on my new Windows 11 PC, the device did not appear to be recognized by my computer. I had not figured out which device to look for in Device Manager until after I had the driver installed, so it's possible that the extra driver is not required. On the driver CD, I figured out that the driver is the one inside the "ASM1061 Sata6GB" folder. I had to go into the only subfolder (asmedia_106x_3.0.2) and run the "setup.exe" program. The installation was straightforward. Once the driver was installed, I found the "Asmedia 106x SATA Controller" device inside the "Storage controllers" section of Device Manager.

Configuring for eSATA

There are two sets of jumpers on the card. In the default position (all covering the top two pegs), the SATA ports on the top of the card are active and the eSATA ports on the side of the card are inactive. Moving the jumpers to the lower position (all covering the bottom two pegs) turns off the SATA ports and turns on the eSATA ports. It appears possible to have one SATA and one eSATA port active, but I switched both to eSATA for my use, so have not tested this. The jumpers on the left appear to select either the left SATA or the top eSATA port. The jumpers on the right appear to select either the right SATA or the bottom eSATA port.

Hopefully this helps anyone else who might purchase this card.

title: Get this Pre Amp.
text: This pre amp has changed my whole outlook on things ... I have been using many preamps, over the years, NAD, Denon; Onkyo; Little Bear T-8 Pro-Ject MM and the original Mani to name a few. None have been outrageously priced, or too extravagant, I just want good sound at a reasonable price. The original Mani was actually giving me the most satisfaction of the ones I had tried. And was the most recent in my system.... Lately I was thinking of getting a new moving coil cartridge because my current cartridge the Ortofon 2M Bronze being good and having it for years now, still leaves room for improvement...So I thought maybe the New Mani would be a better fit for a new moving coil cartridge like the Hana SL or Sumiko Songbird etc... As the original Mani while good with Moving Magnets falls short with low output Moving coils, or so it's said according to reviews....So anyway, still using the Ortofon 2M Bronze after purchase, I hooked this Mani 2 up to my system and... bam...The Ortofon 2M Bronze opened up like I had never heard it before. Remember how the 2M Bronze is supposed to be analytical and dry? Not any more this thing turned the 2M Bronze into a musical flying instrument. Greater detail that surpasses the good detail I was so fond of before. In addition, more bass, more bounce, cleaner highs and a more focused soundstage where you can focus and pick out individual instruments better, everything sounds more real, like you're listing to a violin instead of a recording of a violin, vocals also sound more real ....Advanced high points adjustable capacitance, subsonic filter. Getting the capacitance right for your Moving Magnet Cartridge is critical to get the most out of it...Some need 100 Pf some need 300 Pf to sound their best. I've set 147 Pf (on the Mani) for the 2m Bronze with Mogami 2964 cables (19pf a foot) so I'm getting about 240 pf total... Subsonic filter...Do you like to play it loud or do you use a subwoofer? If that is the case, you need this feature. I use it and I think it makes things sound better...Moving Coil adjustments? They are needed. Why pay the price if you're not going to get the sonic benefits from your Moving Coil? Either way get this pre amp...

title: Best multi device charger yet
text:
Power bricks shouldn’t brick the way they do. Neither should cables, which omg Amazon sellers have made millions from selling subpar products where we are a lone step on the way to the landfill. Now that USB C is becoming more standardized, hopefully we are moving away from the pandemic and pre pandemic days of lightning cables arriving with the male connection end detached and as far as I have seen there are no more guaranteed cable replacements, which sounded great, but should have been presented as “buy one get one free for twice the shortest life ever” or “we are sending you a second cable for when this one fails”. But I never noticed power bricks bricking until the transition away from lightning cables had begun. You try to find a company label that is consistent, but how do you know who is manufacturing what and why do some of these companies suddenly disappear as others reappear with vaguely similar names?
So far this brick has not bricked despite me giving a at least one really good reason to do so. It’s a solid accessory in terms of build. I’ve had the dual plugin prongs on Anker bricks decide to decouple and do their own things, seemingly tired of always working with a binary partner, which isn’t going to happen with this interface. I like how it plugs into an outlet like any other traditional device, with a three prong plug at the end of a cord. I am also benefiting from being able to plug my little Fender Mustang GT amp into it which greatly improved a cable management issue I was having.
So far the only weird thing has been the difference on power output that is supposedly indicated by your blue ring and an occasional issue I’m having with my iPad Pro dipping on and off from the charge - it gets annoying hearing the digital bell indicator for when you are connected to charge over and over again. But that might well be my iPad since a hard restart has pulled it from cycling off and on like that and back into a regular connect and charge.
5 stars is not common, but until I find something that I can clearly prove is the fault of this brick or until it becomes an actual plastic brick I will give it all 5 stars. At that point, depending on what/why it fails I will determine if customer service is good enough to retain all 5 stars.
So far so good and a nice change in the paradigm of straight to plug in bricks.

title: Where's the management software?
text:
Not recommended unless you absolutely can't afford a more expensive brand.

The price is good. The item itself is working well so far. I've had reasonably good experience with a different model. But the annoying thing is trying to obtain the control/management software.

The user manual says to look in one place, which doesn't exist. The product description says to look another place, which doesn't have a download link.

One version of the management software is available if you open the "User Guide" PDF and then click the "download" button located in that document. Seriously. The download "button" is embedded in a PDF document. The program is PowerMaster Plus (PM+) 1.05, a very powerful management system that can track multiple devices and do all kinds of stuff with them. Unfortunately there isn't any documentation included, and it's a bit confusing to install (local or remote?). And when you run the program it appears to do nothing. In actuality, however, it opens a browser window where you log in and run the program via a network connection to your local machine. I'm not joking. PowerMaster+ seems to be designed for network professionals, not normal home users.

The other version of the management software is PowerPanel Personal Edition (PPP) 1.4.3. Fortunately for me, I'd downloaded and installed it for previous UPS. It worked fine when I switched to the USB cable to the new device. But if that hadn't been the case, I wouldn't have known PPP even existed, much less been able to download it. Some of the reviews and answers have direct links to the download, which still exists, but this isn't an option as far as the product listing is concerned. The listing doesn't mention it nor does it provide any way to download it. Unlike PM+, PPP is a simpler and more user-friendly management program. I recommend using it.

I don't know what's happened in the four years since I purchased my other UPS and downloaded PPP (with no problem), but I find the situation to be a bit ridiculous, especially given all the questions and reviews asking how to find the management software.

For that reason I don't recommend this product if you can afford a different brand with a better customer experience. I give it 3/5 stars for the management software confusion. Not recommended.

title: Review from an Audio Engineer
text:
These little guys are definitely powerful (sort of?)… in the right hands. 3 days in, they fit awesome, haven’t run out of battery, and sound amazing; with some tweaks of course. I’ve rated this 3 stars as a general review for people who are not knowledgeable of frequency’s, EQing, and isolation, they are going to hate these. The buds are pretty much a flatline/gentle incline in frequency’s. After tinkering with the sizing of these buds and my Spotify’s EQ, I managed to get a decent/near-lossless sound from the Dime’s speakers (images attached are my Spotify’s EQ for reference).

I will admit, I was expecting a little bit more quality ‘sound-wise’ when I purchased these, but they were extremely hot in the 2.4khz-15khz areas, and a bit lacking in the lower frequencies. This led to a very ‘tinny’ and piercing sound. I managed to fix that using Spotify’s built-in EQ feature (although you can not really bass-boost these).

Now, after fitting them and adjusting them accordingly, they almost beat the AirPod series (my favorite general-consumer earbuds)… except there is one last thing I haven’t managed to grasp. The clipping. For those wondering, the definition of clipping is pretty much just distortion when too much power is being sent to a speaker that can’t handle that power (easiest way to explain it). Some songs in the genre that I listen to clip in random areas. I assume it’s because of the massive boost in the low-ends that I performed, and you can reduce that, but if you do, every other song besides that one song that clipped will sound off. It would be astonishing to see the sellers make a 3rd edition with a possible solid built-in EQ to prevent the very thing all consumers of this product complain about.

Long story short: these are great if you know what you’re doing and are using a music-player with an EQ feature (like Spotify). For use on platforms like TikTok, YouTube, and Netflix, I would not recommend these.

[Image key: Ver. 2 = “bass boost” Other = general use]

title: Back to the Future!
text:
My iPod that I bought way back in 2006 won't hold a charge long enough for a cross-country plane ride. I could use my phone, but I like to keep my phone charged so that any airport/airline/transportation issues can be addressed with a full battery; my experience with working outlets at my seat has been fair at best.

This little MP3 player is about the same size as my iPod but a lot thicker. It still fits easily into a shirt pocket and will even fit into the case that holds my Sony noise-cancelling headphones. It came with an 8GB microSD card, so I hooked it up to my computer and loaded some music. I was pleasantly surprised at the overall sound quality. It even has a speaker in the back in case you don't want to use headphones. The unit includes a Bluetooth transmitter and connected easily to my headphones. In addition to mp3 files, it will also play FLAC files. I did not test WMA, AAC, WME, and APE files, though the listing says that they are compatible.

You can also play videos. First, you have to copy a program from the player to your computer. This program is used to convert your video files so that they can be played. I don't plan to watch videos on the tiny screen, so I did not test this function.

I did test both the FM rado and the voice recorder. The FM radio worked surprisingly well considering that there is no antenna. The voice recorder also worked fine. For the purpose I am planning, though, I'm not likely to use either feature. The same is true of the ebook function, primarily because I just can't see myself trying to read a book on such a tiny screen.

The only big unknown at this point is battery life. I'm going to swap out the 8GB card for 128GB, load it up with music, charge it back to 100%, and press play. I'll come back and update this review once I've determined the battery life.

If you do a lot of hiking, like to listen to music while working out, or spend a lot of time on airplanes, this little mp3 player might be just what you're looking for, especially if you don't want to load up your phone with music.

title: Best sound I ever heard!
text:
These are most likely the best earphones you can get for less than $100 bucks (US). And they have a lifetime warranty!
The high end is crisp and clear and the bass...well, let me put it this way. The bass in these is better than most of the stereo systems I had as a teenager growing up. Better by far.
I've heard notes in songs I listened to since the 1970s that I never heard before. It's sort of like when CDs first came out. It's pretty unbelievable. I'm not sure I believe it yet....
And it's got a lifetime warranty!
This little set is comfortable too. As one poster put it, they are so comfortable I forgot I was wearing them. I didn't believe her then. I do now. I forgot I was wearing them...for more than an hour.
These do almost everything the other ones do but at one third the cost. See, you don't have to empty your wallet to have something good. Don't pay good money for a name. Put your dollars where they should go. That is, to a company that's willing to put out something with quality without acting like all the other greedy you-know-whats in the business world. I'm sure that some day in the future their prices will increase, but I have a feeling it won't be before they've proven themselves. Good for them! I hope they wind up making millions. With quality like this they deserve it.
And they've got a lifetime warranty!!
All in all, these earphones are a sure winner. They have the sound, the build quality, and everything else you want in something like this. What more could you ask? Whaddya want, a lifetime warranty?
Got it!!! (Did I mention that already?)
Don't get the Orancu headphones. They're overpriced and not as good. Forget about Beats too. Nobody is going to beat these, certainly not at this price. You can (literally) take that to the bank!
And that's all I got to say about that. And don't forget the lifetime warranty.
PS Yes, I did get a free charger for writing this. But--and if I'm lying, I'm dying-- I was going to write the same thing without getting anything. I am THAT impressed. Hope everyone has a great day!

title: Excellent value and feature set
text:
[[VIDEOID:af953c86893bf829f49bb55567db64ca]] First off, let me say that this D4 microphone is a real value at under $100! I really like the stepless gain dial on the back, and the USB out to either digital or analog is next level cool. The included shock mount seems to do a very good job of isolating handling noise and vibration. The dead cat included in this package is very much appreciated. The mic itself seems very well made.

I also like the ability to adjust the mic forward or backward depending on your needs. Push it all the way forward to leave room for your head when looking directly through the viewfinder, or move it back for better balance or to make sure the dead cat isn't in frame. Also with this adjustability, you can attach a small wireless transmitter to the "inverted" cold shoe mount under the mic to make this a wireless mic. That alone is a really nice feature. Also, the ability to use this D4 Mic connected directly to my computer via the USB C cable is another really cool feature.

I did a quick audio test and also compared this D4 mic to a more expensive Rode Video Mic Pro (https://amzn.to/3JFWJDz). As I mention in my video, this isn't really fair since the Rode mic is over twice the price of the Deity D4, but I wanted to see how it would compare. Watch my video to see how it does head to head with the Rode... Spoiler Alert: The Rode has better sound, but that's to be expected. By the way, the audio in the video comparison is raw and untouched. The audio is exactly as it came out of the digital recorders and no gain or other editing has been done.

But for the money, I think the Deity is a great choice. I mean it's a hundred bucks! The audio captured from this microphone can be improved greatly with some audio magic in post, as well. The one thing that bothers me is that no case or protective carry bag was included. This is a personal pet peeve of mine, but I always expect some kind of case included with any microphone purchase and was disappointed this mic didn't include one.

I deducted one star for not including a case, and for having a little less audio quality than I'd hoped.

title: Nice case with a lot of flaws.
text:
I bought this case looking for nice and cheap option for my iPad 12.9 a4th generation. I have to say that the cat fits very good even that I used for a 4th generation and in the description said that it is for the 5th generation. this is good thing. Another good thing is the price, very good for under $15 and the can cover the Apple Pencil if you have one.
So here comes the issues:
1. Color: it states that is rose gold, but in my opinion this is more on the gold side than rose gold, in my opinion should be more rose.
2.-I understand that this is for the 5th gen iPad Pro, but the cut holes for the speakers are smaller and not aligned for the 4th gen iPad, again I understand this case is intended for the 5th gen the the speakers are different size but I think considering both models are almost identical then would be nice to fit perfectly.
3.The hard plastic that cover the back feels thin and cheap. It is nice translucent color but honestly I don't think this will last long. I had experience with speck case that in my opinion are better quality and this hard plastic eventually break in little time.

Because all this things, I won't be able to recommend this case.

Update 2/11/23
Support Team contacted me to make things right and have a product to my entire satisfaction. They offered me a different product in exchange for nothing just to make my experience just better. I got this https://www.amazon.com/ESR-Compatible-Generation-Convenient-Attachment/dp/B08S374BVG/ref=sr_1_3?crid=U1K0PILBHVSF&keywords=esr%2Bipad%2Bpro%2B12.9%2Bcase&qid=1676062778&sprefix=esr%2B%2Caps%2C136&sr=8-3&th=1
I really like it, because it is similar like the apple Magic Keyboard mechanism. The only think is even that the magnet are decent strong, when the iPad is lifted from magnetic clasp, the iPad detached extremely easily, the iPad will fall and most probably damage. just a little flaw, but overall is good case.

title: Best inexpensive laptop I've ever used
text:
I regularly upgrade my inexpensive secondary device so I can spend only a little each year and have the latest hardware. Each time I'm disappointed by some aspect, usually the screen, but as you can imagine there is no complaint here to be had about the
screen.

And the hardware itself is practically flawless, set aside a few minor complaints to come. The case, keyboard and TouchPad feel top notch and it's super small with pretty good battery life (I average between 5 and 6 hours). The wifi card is an Intel AX411 and is super fast, the memory and ssd are upgradable too (which I may do soon to the max 40gb RAM / 4TB NVMe). And of course the obvious positive, the screen. Just wow, super bright and very sharp with a super awesome resolution to size ratio. I keep it 120hz max res all the time and still get great battery life. The fingerprint reader works great a d I love that it has a built in Webcam cover. Enough storage out of the box to do most things, and it is incredibly fast. I never feel lag, it's basically like using my desktop as far as how snappy it is in everyday usage. Also bonus: you get a free accidental one year warranty with this laptop and some nice discounts for other software, well worth checking out.

There are a few minor issues, but know I'm kind of nitpicking here.
-The speakers are decent, very loud and tunable, but they HAVE to be well tuned to get a decent sound out of them. Not the best but Def not the worst.
-If you're doing heavy lifting like video editing or using other pro level software, it'll get hot. The performance is great in these apps but the laptop will get hot quick. Make sure it can breathe any time you're doing heavy lifting.
-The gaming performance just isn't there compared to AMD APUs. If you want to game, get an AMD APU, if you want to do literally anything / everything else besides game on it this is a great option.

Overall I love this laptop as it feels like the desktop replacement portable laptop I've always wanted. Great for video editing and audio production too. And the 5hrs+ battery life I get from it is more than adequate for my needs, luckily it has a 90w charger to charger the battery back up pretty quick too.

title: Not compatible with all machines including DELL 7740. Reads are slower than expected.
text:
Has a NT5CC64M16GP-DI 1 GB DRAM cash on it as of 4/17/2023
Realtek Controller as well. Looks like the controller was released in 2018 rts5762 l322jp2.

Its not using the larger DRAM or controller that it had at launch but it has some.

Still trying to test it out. Using a NVME 10 GB USB external I get 1GB writes but 500-600 MB/s reads only which is.... Odd. I should be getting closure to 1GB same with the writes.

Testing cheaper lower end drives gives me both 1gb reads and writes using the same enclosure so I know its the drive.

Reads just appear to be super slow for some reason.

I am going to test it in a thunderbolt 4 NVME enclosure to see if the reads change.

I also am unable to get a DELL 7740 to boot with this thing in it. I have 3 other NVME, samsung, sk kynix, and an intel that will boot in the same DELL 7740. But when I put this in the machine refuses to boot.
I tried single NVME drive mode and any combination but it will not see the drive.

So I am not sure since the 9980H CPU and chipset is capable of seeing it and using 4tb. But both 4tb drives I got do the same thing. Refuses to be seen by the machine or even let it boot.

If I place the drives into the USB enclosure the machine is able to see it and utilize it.

So as of now 2 DELL 7740's can't boot with this thing in it. And all 4 NVME slots have been tried on both machines.

Testing with a ryzen 5900x and msi x570 mobo allows me to use use the drives internally but the reads are still below 1gb/s with writes well into the 2gb/s range.

Drive did handle 160 GB worth of Writes in 3 files. Sustaining about 1 GB a second when used in an external USB enclosure. Took about 3 minutes to transfer this. Repeatedly for the full 4TB to test capacity.

title: A Host of Features
text:
This radio has versatility to compete with that of a Swiss Army Knife! The radio can use 5 sources of power (Lithium battery, AAA batteries, USB port, solar panel, hand crank) to receive AM, FM (Stereo on headphones), Shortwave (8 bands), NOAA weather radio with an alert standby mode available when not receiving other modes. It also has an LED flashlight and a loud attention getting emergency siren.

When tuning you can step up/down and also scan up/down to the next available signal. Note that in SW mode, you can hold the Mode button for 2 seconds to be able to use Tune buttons to move to the S1-S8 band of your choice. However, once in the band of your choice, either stepping or scanning with the Tune buttons will not wrap around in the same band, but will change to the next band when you reach a band limit.

In section 6.3 of the manual, Solar Power, reference is made to a red LED, said to be identified in Figure 1. Not shown in Figure 1, but item 19 in Figure 2 is identified as “Charging Indicator”, and when I plug a charger into the Input Port, item 18, the LED is red, but never flashed red when aiming the solar panel at the sun. My email to their Email Support address (Troubleshooting Guide, page 18 in the manual) got a prompt and courteous reply thanking me for calling attention to the oversight in the manual, and identifying the Solar Charging indicator (marked “S”) located between the headphone jack and reset button in Figure 2, but not called out in that Figure. As they told me in the email, it is a steady Orange when receiving charge from the solar panel. The photo they included in the email showed also that if you flip open both ends of the rubber cover, you can rotate it 90° to stay open. I did not know that when I took the photo included with this review. I have added, however, a callout for the “S” LED.”

The reception on all bands compares favorably to other radios in this price range, and with 5 ways to power the radio it is great to have at home or when hiking or anywhere away from plug-in power. A fully charged battery will keep the radio playing for a lot of hours! 5 Stars for this radio.

title: Very Capable Small PC!
text:
I’ve had this for about a month, and I am impressed! My purpose for getting this was that I wasn’t sure if I really wanted a Steam Deck or not... I didn’t need the portability, but I just wanted to be able to play occasional fps games in bed and not need a second gaming console. I never thought about a mini PC, and when this CTOne Mini PC popped up on an Amazon screen, I thought that this might be a better solution... it is!

It runs Windows 11 out of the box, so after doing some minor updates and tweaks, I started loading up some games out of my collection (Fallout 4, Control, Dwarf Fortress) and hooked it up to an older 1080p TV via HDMI. I hooked up a small USB hub and a wireless controller, and it works well! I haven’t bothered to measure frame rates, but the Ryzen 5 seems to hold its own. The graphics chip is rated for 4K at 60Hz, but I’m not pushing anywhere close to that. With visual settings at medium with a couple tweaks, I’m seeing great performance for what I’m doing.

I like that the PC has different power settings... fan noise isn’t too distracting so far. I believe you can put up to 64Gb of RAM in the machine, and I may jump to 32Gb in the Spring to run the Halo collection and some of the Borderland games. I have a spare 1Tb SSD somewhere and may add that in so I can add even more Fallout mods as I get comfortable with this machine.

Even though I have a fairly specific use profile for this CTOne PC, I’m overall impressed by the Ryzen 5; most of my heavy computer work is done with the macOS and the new Apple M1 chips. But for simple leisure time gaming, I’ve had no issues and at 1080p I’m perfectly happy for the hour or so of gaming I can do before I crash for the night.

The case is smaller than I expected, and I love the magnetic side panel... no fiddly clips or screws to deal with.

If you are looking for a small form factor PC for occasional gaming like me, or for simple office work, look into this CTOne Mini PC. It has a lot to offer!

title: Impressive portable speaker
text:
I'm a music lover and amateur DJ, so I'm always in the market for a portable speaker to bring my music with me wherever I go. All my housemates have JBL speakers, but some of theirs are failing with age so I decided to put this Monster portable speaker to the test. For a portable speaker without a boombox style handle this is a little on the large / heavy side, but it comes with an optional carrying strap that can be attached to a loop on the corner of the speaker. It's slightly taller and wider than the JBL charge series, and feels much more substantial. Similar to my housemates' speakers, the Monster DNA Max is fully waterproof and dustproof with an IP67 rating, which makes it a worthy travel partner for beach trips or other outdoor activities. It's got wireless charging capabilities and comes with a Qi charging pad fitted to the oval shape of the base, but it also seems to charge effectively with other wireless charging stations. Another bonus feature is that it acts as a power bank in a pinch and can recharge a phone from the onboard battery (which lasts 15+ hours if you're just playing music).

Now on to the important part, the sound...
I'm honestly impressed with the volume this portable speaker produces. Even at max volume the audio quality does not suffer, the highs and mids sound crisp and clear and the bass response is excellent without sounding muddy or rumbly. I wouldn't call it a bass-heavy speaker but found the sound to be very balanced while producing more bass than much of the competition in the portable speaker market. I prefer it to the JBL speakers for listening at home and will only choose a different portable speaker if size or weight is an issue. It doesn't offer different EQ settings and if you're looking to fine-tune your frequencies you'll have to do this from your device, but I don't mind. It's very easy to use, just plug & play. I've had no issues with the Bluetooth connection - it recognizes my phone and other devices quickly and stays connected reliably (which has been an issue with other speakers).

Overall, it's not an audiophile quality speaker (but it's also not marketed as one), and for a consumer level portable party speaker it delivers some serious sound, in a sleek and well-designed package that feels like it will last years to come. Better than much of the competition in and above it's price range.

title: Not very bright and it only has up/down tilt option
text:
This review is for the “Mini Projector, HOMPOW Portable Projector with 100" Screen, Native 720P Outdoor Movie Projector 7500Lux, Home Theater Projector Compatible with HDMI VGA USB TF AV for Home” I ordered. I like the compact size and quiet sound when running this projector. The instructions are easy to follow and setting up the projector is easy too. Both the instructions and projector options have multiple languages available and while the volume goes to 100, the slight incremental change could be better.

I don’t like how long it takes to bring the volume up/down. The volume sounds okay coming from the projector but it is only high treble sounds and no bass at all. This can make a big difference when watching movies or shows. There is a headphone jack so you could hook up a better speaker option.

The picture has several preset options for color, warmth, screen size and the ability to create your own preferences. The projector screen it comes with is okay but there are definitely better options out there. The screen is very thin so even the slightest light from behind is noticeable.

If you’re looking to use this projector with your phone whether it be an iPhone or Android you will need to have or purchase the wiring for it because this projector doesn’t come with that wire.

This projector doesn’t come with the two AA batteries required for the remote. I don’t like that this projector only provides the up/down tilt option and not left/right so you may have to move the projector around to get it to look right on the projector screen.

I don’t like how much play is in the focus knob because it makes fine adjustments difficult. I also don’t like that there is not a Wi-Fi or Bluetooth connection to make connections easier because to update this projector you need to purchase a USB thumb drive, plug it into your computer, figure out how/where to get the update information, then plug the USB thumb drive into the projector and run it.

This isn’t the worst projector I’ve seen or used and it’s certainly not in the top category but I can be a decent option for indoor use in a very dark room. I don’t know how well this would work outside given the low lighting ability.

title: The affordable Tanchjim Oxygen!
text:
Approx $60-80 for a DD of this high acoustic, construction, and comfort qualityis rarely seen in today's market. Picking this set up at such an affordable price is almost criminal.

EA500 is one of the best sounding single DDs I've ever heard since the Tanchjim Oxygen (which is nearly 3-4 times the price). All the audiophile OGs will perk up a bit because Oxygen is a legend in the iem landscape.

Finally found an Oxygen (& Vortex) beater! In fact she easily holds her own (and some) with her older brother the Simgot Pound-4-Pound Sonic Grand Champ (EA2000, more pricey at $320).

E2000 adds some additional impact, texture, and power to the bass while adding some extra special sauce to mid frequencies.

Right OOTB she begins to beguile you with the effortless way she shapes and carves out sound. She cast a spell on you with her pitch, timbre, & tonal perfection. Some may consider her bright but you have the choice to swap sound tube nozzles (red is my preference) to transform the sound.

Tanchjim Oxygen, Penon Vortex, Oriolus Isabellae, Tanchjim Hana 2021, & Tripowin Olina SE were my DD standard bearers but now... Simgot Twins (EA2000 & EA500) lead the way through the ranks of today's DDs.

Crisp, precise, airy, space-shaping, shimmering, clarity, details, spacious with gorgeous vocals; wrapped up with pronounced, speedy, tight, and impactful bass. Bass is tastefully implemented without coming off as overbearing or overwhelming.

EA500 actually provides space around the notes so replay doesn't feel congested or overdone up and down the frequency spectrum.

Funk, rock, pop, rap, r'n'b, alternative, soul, blues, edm, hip-hop, grunge, house, disco, classical, acoustic, ost's... bring it, EA500 can take all that smoke!!

Such a truly wonderful experience to purchase something that actually lives up to and then surpasses your expectations! Well done Simgot!

title: Where's the bass??
text:
On first impression, I thought the design language was very cool. The driver case looks sort of futuristic. However, it does stand out and it’s not all that subtle. I appreciate the white/gray color and the orange accents and orange neckband certainly give them a sporty look. As far as comfort, these are OK. I can feel the drivers on the side and the neckband is a bit rigid. I would’ve liked a softer or adjustable band. This makes resting my head back uncomfortable. Also, it can be cumbersome to wear these if you have glasses (the headset needs to go first). However, the headset does stay in place while doing moderate exercise or movements.

They feature Bluetooth 5.3, and they connected seamlessly to my Android and iOS devices. The connection was solid, even at respectable distances. There were no discernable lag or sync issues. The battery life is decent, and they charge via USB-C.

Honestly, I had high expectations for this headset. I already own both bone and air conduction headphones, and by looking at the marketing material, these looked promising. Unfortunately, I must say that I was let down somewhat. Having 4 driver units, I expected much better bass than other single-driver options. The bass is basically non-existent, making all audio sound tinny and distant. The midrange was there, as well as the treble, but since there is no bass, the highs are overly accentuated at higher volumes, and it became harsh and fatiguing fast. It’s almost like listening to a transistor radio. The sense of openness that open headsets bring was also disappointing. It seemed as if I was listening to elevator music. Even dialogue-based content sounded as if I was listening to a phone speaker. I can deal with that, but I think I should not have to settle. The good thing is that at least you can be aware of your surroundings, sound leakage is kept to a minimum, and that there is no vibrating sensation usually caused by bone inductors (strange that the product’s page references bone-induction as a feature).

It may be obvious by now that I am not all that happy with these headphones. I hope that this is just my unit, and somehow they are defective. While they are inexpensive, I think spending a bit more could perhaps be a better option if you are looking for open true wireless headsets.

title: Very well made and sturdy. High quality for the price.
text:
I will start by saying that I like iWillink products and have had good luck with them in the past. While I typically use actual punch down panels, I am beginning to appreciate the pass through style like this one. Overall, this one is very well made, super sturdy, comes with all 48 coupler inserts that you will need pre-installed, includes the cage nuts and screws for mounting, and cable ties for securing your cables to the back bar. For installations where you are going to need to potentially add more cables later or may need to relocate/rearrange cables, this style patch panel is great, as you can move things around without risking pulling connections loose (which I have had happen before MANY times on punchdown panels). These also work great in "clean up" installations where people had previously terminated all the network cables with RJ45 connectors and plugged them directly into the switch. With one of these you can relocate all those network connectors to a proper panel front! Another thing I like is that the keystone couplers on this panel are removable, which means that I can swap in others of different colors for easy reference, or swap in other standard keystones like USB3 or HDMI for easy connections to a server (which might be inside a locked anti-theft cage and hard to access).

All that said, I do have a couple of very minor issues with this panel. First, while the keystones are removable, they are VERY tight and you will definitely need a screwdriver and a bit of force to get them to release, so plan on putting in the keystones you think you will need before you mount the panel, as it will be a royal pain to change out the jacks themselves later (cables will be easy to swap around, it is just the keystones that are a bit of a tight fit). The other issue is that I really wish the back bar had screws to where you could remove it as it adds about 3" of extra depth to the panel and could preclude some mounting situations (specifically, "cleanup" installs that are located on either very shallow wall mount racks or, in at least a few cases, between 2x4's). Worst case, the back bar can be removed with some metal cutters!

Overall though, I am very pleased with this patch panel and think it is very well made for the price, especially as it already includes 48 keystone couplers with it.

title: Great option to avoid having to climb a ladder to recharge your camera!
text:
I needed a solution to powering my Nest Camera without having to run a super long power cord to an outlet, and this works perfectly.

Thanks to how adjustable the mount is, I was able to mount mine upside down from the soffit of my garage. My garage faces the east and gets hit with the early morning rising sun, up until almost 11 am, so this panel gets plenty of exposure to recharge the battery. Also, thanks to the location under the overhang, it's better protected from severe weather and should survive the crazy hailstorms of southern Colorado.

So far, it's keeping my battery at 100% as Colorado has a lot of sunny days. You may need to have the panel exposed for more of the day to achieve a full charge.

Pros:
-All hardware needed to install the mount is included in the box. Just predrill your holes, and if need install the wall anchors, then mount.
-Includes two security wires to make it a bit more difficult for someone to run off with your camera.
-Mount is easily adjustable
-13ft cable
-4W max output is plenty for second gen Nest cameras

Negatives:
-The cable is hardwired to the solar panel so if it gets damaged, you may be out of luck with a repair. It'd been great to have a screw-together waterproof connection that's found on a lot of outdoor light sets.

Considerations:
-The 13ft cable may get in the way or be hard to hide. Being under my garage's soffit, I simple zip tied the wire to some metal hooks I screwed into the soffit.
-This is not meant to charge a fully dead or almost dead battery! This is by design as the panel is a trickle-charger. You'll need to remove the camera or use an external battery a t a high enough wattage with the correct cable to charge it in place.
-Don't expect this to pay for itself, even at just $43.99 when reviewed.

Overall, I can highly recommend this panel if you need to power a Nest camera in a strange or hard to reach location.

I may get another camera and another of these panels to mount on my shed... hmmm.

title: Perfect enclosure and it is great to restore deleted files unlike a thumb drive.
text:
I recently purchased the SSK Aluminum M.2 to USB NVMe SATA SSD Enclosure Reader from Amazon for $18.99, and I must say that I am quite impressed with the product. The enclosure works beautifully, just as advertised. However, some people complain about the top speed of the device not reaching full potential, but it's important to keep in mind that it states the top speed is 10gb/s, and the drive needs other efficient hardware to reach full potential.
(I just noticed in my pic the particular PC I am using has a USB-C that I am not plugged in to which would speed this drive up, it is nice to have it be able to plug in both types)

While some people have complained about the tiny thumb screw, I believe it's understandable given the size of the drive and enclosure itself. The product is priced reasonably at $16-20, so I don't think people should be whining about it. The USB-A and C cables included with the product worked just fine for me, although they are a bit short.

I purchased this product to expand an additional SSD hard drive in my computer that I installed games on, and it was great. I was able to copy my existing SSD drive onto a new expanded size Drive and then place what was in the enclosure in my computer. I took out the SSD that wasn't my computer and now I have a massively sized external hard drive to play around with. It was definitely worth the money.

One thing to note is that unlike a thumb drive, files that are deleted do not permanently disappear. They are put in a trash can, and you can restore or undelete the file by pressing Ctrl Z.

Overall, I'm quite happy with my purchase of the SSK Aluminum M.2 to USB NVMe SATA SSD Enclosure Reader. It works great, is slim and easy to use, and has a solid drive holder that is not going to slip or come loose. The holding screw is a bit tricky to install, but once it's done, it's great. I would recommend this product to anyone who needs a slim M2 enclosure for their backup or just a huge USB thumb nail type drive with tons of storage.

Make sure to use the "Safely remove hardware" function to unplug this, or turn the PC off before unplugging to prevent corrupting the drive.

title: Improved online meetings and webinars
text:
I was using some earbud headset that came with a phone for online meetings, and I was having difficulty understanding 100% of what presenters were saying, especially colleagues whose native language is not English. This headset has cleared that up.

FORM AND FIT
These are on-ear rather than over-ear. I've never had one like it and was skeptical about comfort. I had to experiment a bit, but since the ear cups swivel front to back I eventually found a sweet spot that stays in place and is comfortable. The microphone boom swivels enough that you can have it one either side, unlike some others I've had. The smaller footprint compared to the over-ear type feels less cluttering in my home office.

COMFORT: It's "good enough" for most situations. So far the longest meeting was just short of 2 hours. I was ready for a break after that, but there was nothing especially irritating, just normal fatigue. Better than I expected for the price. The earphone padding is a thin soft and rubber-like substance. It's better than I expected, but from experience that kind of material doesn't tend to hold up well to a lot of use. Time will tell.

SOUND QUALITY:
My hobby is audio engineering. I didn't expect these to be good for music, and they aren't, though they're better than I expected. The higher frequencies are lacking, but that's because the maker has zeroed in on human voice frequencies. The improvement in clarity in online meetings over what I was using is VERY noticeable. Possibly the noise cancelling feature also helps? The microphone is good as well. Colleagues noticed that I sounded better the first meeting where I used it.

DOWNSIDES:
I could wish that an adapter to USB C was included, but a those are cheap and easy to find. Also, even though the audio plug type is the same as another headset that works with my older MacBook Pro, this headset's mic isn't recognized so I can only use it on the Windows laptop I have for work.

In general, it's made online meetings less fatiguing because I don't have to concentrate so hard to pick up everything speakers are saying. I'm satisfied with the value for the price. Seems to stack up well against famous brands like Logitech.

title: Great earbuds, but not my fav
text:
I had the Sony XM4s and stupidly lost them. I was quite happy with them, but figured I'd try something new and got the Bose QC2s. At its best, the QC2s produce a great sound, really heavy bass, and the noise cancellation is fantastic. But, I think the XM4s are better all-around earbuds. I wear them daily in NYC, and the range of noises constantly being thrown at me make the XM4s better suited.

Noise Cancellation: on planes, the QC2s are unreal - that background hum of the engines just totally disappears. At home, the QCs let me focus when my stupid robot vacuum is circling my desk. But, for some noises, particularly higher pitch noises, they get right through the ANC. At their best, the XM4s don't cancel noise nearly as well as the QCs, but they filter more of it across the spectrum. For low frequencies, the QCs are a 10/10 and the XM4s are like a 7/10. For higher frequencies, the QCs are a 4/10 but the XM4s are still a 7/10 - subway noise, construction noise, and wind cuts right through the QC's ANC, whereas the XM4s are able to block out much of it. For wind noise, the XM4s weren't great, but the QCs are almost unbearable. In high wind conditions (like on a bike) I would just turn the ANC off on my XM4s, but you don't have that ability on the QCs, so you have to just deal.

Sound Quality: for certain types of music (dance, hip hop, techno - bass heavy stuff), the QCs are on top - great, immersive sound. But the XM4s have a much more well-rounded sound that work with every type of music - I feel like I hear sounds I never noticed before.

Fit: QCs are more customizable and feel more comfortable. The XM4s require more frequency fiddling to keep them securely in place with a good seal.

App: The Sony app is so much more customizable and fully featured, but honestly I turned off most of the more advanced features. If you favor simplicity, the Bose is better.

title: Works well, but no documentation
text:
The card is working well for what I need, which is eSATA ports. (5 stars) However, it did require me to figure out a few things on my own because no documentation came with it. (-1 star)

Package Contents

The packaging was soft (not rigid), but it appears that the card was unharmed in transit. I received the card (wrapped in an anti-static inside the package) as well as a mini CD (80mm diameter) that was not in any kind of protective cover or sleeve. The CD contains several different drivers without a clear indication of which was the correct one for this card.

Installing the Driver

Without the Driver on my new Windows 11 PC, the device did not appear to be recognized by my computer. I had not figured out which device to look for in Device Manager until after I had the driver installed, so it's possible that the extra driver is not required. On the driver CD, I figured out that the driver is the one inside the "ASM1061 Sata6GB" folder. I had to go into the only subfolder (asmedia_106x_3.0.2) and run the "setup.exe" program. The installation was straightforward. Once the driver was installed, I found the "Asmedia 106x SATA Controller" device inside the "Storage controllers" section of Device Manager.

Configuring for eSATA

There are two sets of jumpers on the card. In the default position (all covering the top two pegs), the SATA ports on the top of the card are active and the eSATA ports on the side of the card are inactive. Moving the jumpers to the lower position (all covering the bottom two pegs) turns off the SATA ports and turns on the eSATA ports. It appears possible to have one SATA and one eSATA port active, but I switched both to eSATA for my use, so have not tested this. The jumpers on the left appear to select either the left SATA or the top eSATA port. The jumpers on the right appear to select either the right SATA or the bottom eSATA port.

Hopefully this helps anyone else who might purchase this card.

title: Very Compact, But to Wake Alexa You Have to Shout
text:
I'd been using another brand of compact Alexa-enabled clock on my bedside table, but as the digits started to fade the last couple of years, I found the original company no longer offered the clock. I really liked having Alexa to set simple timers (okay, I admit it - I like to take naps). I found this clock as a replacement, and it added new features that my old clock lacked! So let's take a look at those features:

The Clock - It's big enough to see on your night table, even without your glasses. And it has a great range of settings, including one that is automatic. Being an Internet clock, you don't have to reset it twice a year like most clocks. If all you need is a reliable, readable clock, this is for you.
