Day of the Week - As it turns out, the clock eventually comes to figure this out by itself. I expected this to happen right away, but it took my clock overnight to put the day of the week on the display. Also, unfortunately, the font is so small that I can't read it without my classes.

Temperature and Humidity - The clock gets the outdoor temperature and humidity from the Internet. Nice to know information, and the font is large enough to read without my glasses. It takes a little poking around in the Alexa app to get this feature working, but once you have it set up it works fine.

Weather - The clock also gets the weather from the Internet, but the icons are so small I'd need a magnifying glass to see them. So it works, but is hardly useful for me.

Alexa - Alexa is available and it works; the trouble is that the clock is hard of hearing. To get Alexa's attention, you literally need to yell at the clock. I'm not talking about raising your voice; I'm talking about yelling so loud that people if other rooms of the house wonder what's wrong. Now there is an Alexa button on the top of the clock you can press, but that's not near as easy as saying, "Alexa, set an alarm in one hour." There are also buttons that let you raise and lower the volume, and turn Alexa off entirely.

Overall, I'd say the clock is a good value, as long as those little foibles don't get in your way.

title: How to drastically improve VOLUME and BASE
text:
These bone induction headphones are a compromise, they offer the ability to listen to audio without having something jammed in or covering your ear, this provides significantly better comfort, durability, and of course situational awareness. However, the cons are somewhat limited volume and the rich bass tones are severely limited. As others have also mentioned the volume is less than even typical earbuds, even with the volume cranked all the way it is only mildly loud, and they start to vibrate a lot which tickles your ears.
SHOKZ does recommend using ear plugs (when appropriate) to lower background noise. When I tried this it took away some of the high frequencies as well. I just figured I would need to use a second standard headphone set for those times when I really wanted to immerse myself with loud and rich music sound and use the SHOKZ for times when I need and want the added durability, comfort, and situational awareness these provide.
However, I had this pair of swimmer ear plugs (Hearprotek model HP13) that are designed to block water but let most sound in for hearing (they work well for that). When I put these in with the SHOKZ it was a bit of a shock, bass and overall volume increased A LOT. I usually have the volume at 80-100% (to the point that I get a lot of vibration), however with these ear plugs in that high of a volume would blow your ears out. I had to turn it down to 40-50%, and the bass is now like a typical ear bud. So, if that is important to you, here is a solution.
These earplugs do work as advertised, I can hear almost as well with them in as out. However, with the SHOKZ playing it does make it hard to hear anything else. So, using these vastly improves the sound, but now once again you have something jammed in your ear, and your situational awareness is significantly reduced so...
It also does not transform it into a high end set of earphones (I don’t want to oversell it), it just gives back a lot of the bass and volume lost due to open ear bone acoustics. It might be a decent alternative to having to have two different types of earphones. Also, there are several different earplugs that are tuned for listening to loud music, perhaps one of those might work even better? If I try any others I will update.

title: Great gaming processor
text:
Upgraded from an i7-8700k that I've been using since summer of 2018, and the difference in just about every game is noticeable. The biggest one lately was Returnal, which just released for PC and was giving me a lot of stuttering. Even though the in-game benchmark was telling me I was GPU bound, I was also seeing that my GPU utilization was only hitting 98% on every run. I'd been looking to upgrade anyways, but I wanted to wait for the new AMD X3D chips to be released and see how they performed. Since those came out at such a high price point, and they were only marginally better than this chip was for gaming according to most YouTube reviewers who ran comparisons between them all, I decided to stick with Intel for another generation.

When I installed everything and ran Returnal again the stuttering was gone. Between the better overall performance of this chip, as well as the newer platform offering support for resizable bar with my 3080ti, I was seeing about an 8% overall improvement in average FPS and my 1% lows were more than double what they used to be with the 8700k. I fired up a few other games and immediately noticed much smoother frametimes, even if my average FPS wasn't that much better than before, indicating that my CPU was no longer holding back the performance of my GPU and causing random hitches in performance.

Something to keep in mind is that this CPU runs HOT. I upgraded my AIO cooler from a 240mm EVGA to a 360mm Arctic Liquid Freezer II because it uses a thicker radiator and comes highly recommended by people who tend to overclock their computers. I haven't bothered overclocking yet, but I will probably get into that once my system has been broken in a bit more and the thermal paste has been given time to fully cure. Even then, running Cinebench in a case with a lot of airflow, I was seeing temps get up to 85 and 90C on all the performance cores. Considering the CPU package was pulling 233W under full load, it's no surprise that it had a lot of heat to dissipate.

Overall I'm very impressed with this processor. It's met and exceeded all of my expectations, and if you can tame the heat it puts out you'll get all the frames you'll need when you pair it with a powerful GPU.

title: Really good range. Works fine with BT headset. Questionable driver support.
text:
I primarily got this to use on my office desktop to get me better range with my Bluetooth headset, and for that is seems to work great. Compared to my older Bluetooth adapter, I would say the range is easily 2x-3x as good (using it, my headset was now able to connect from anywhere in the house and didn't start dropping out until I went outside and walked to the end of my driveway). I also like that it has a detachable antenna, which means I could potentially put an even bigger one on it for even more range.

Initial setup on my Windows 10 desktop was a bit of a headache though. Before I could get anything to work, I had to go through and remove ALL of my paired Bluetooth devices (with the old adapter still installed), remove the old adapter, and then put this adapter in, let Windows detect it and install the driver, and then re-pair my devices.

For my headset and some external speakers, everything seems to be working great, but with a Bluetooth mouse it seems to lag a bit and has even higher latency than my old adapter did. Based on a bit of quick sleuthing, it seems that this adapter still uses the original Microsoft Bluetooth driver from 2006 and that its support for Bluetooth 5.3 is a bit...lacking. While it works, it seems to be operating in compatibility mode for an earlier standard and not running at full speed. After checking the VID and PID on this adapter and doing some online research, the ATS2851 chipset in this adapter is the same one that is used in other adapters that have a lot of people complaining about latency issues with mice, game controllers, etc and begging for a custom driver to fix the issues. Unfortunately, so far the only drivers that appear to be available for this adapter are the built-in ones from Microsoft, which do not appear to operate it at full speed. I also went back and re-tested this on my laptop (after disabling the internal Bluetooth adapter) and saw the exact same issues.

So...if you are simply looking for long range on a Bluetooth adapter with something like a headset, this seems to work great, but for other devices like hand controllers, mice, etc the latency seems to be higher than it should be and I think they really need to release some custom drivers. I also feel this device is priced a bit higher than it should be, though the external antenna does mitigate the price somewhat.

title: What a great surprise birthday present!
text:
I have to admit I am a self proclaimed audiophile, so my standards for music reproduction are high. I own Wired Sennheiser 650s as well as wired Bose Quiet Comfort noise canceling cans, or the full headphones over the ear units. I am not convinced in any manner that wireless headphones or earbuds can not compete with the full sound that a wire connection can provide. So not even the all mighty Bluetooth 5.0 despite fancy bandwidth numbers can compete with well constructed wired units.

Now on to the review of the JBL quantum one headphones/headset. First let me say that with the USB connection is the only way to maximize the ability of these cans. The 3.5 mm wire connector is absolutely wonderful but the lack of the noise canceling it (depending on how damaged your ears are) hurts the wonderful sound reproduction.

The Quantum software that integrates all of the features of the headset. Such as the 360° audio, the simulated 7.1 surround sound and head orientation option that it offers. Again only applicable with the USB-A to USB-C cable. And the biggest hit is maybe not a hit is not using that USB cable you have no balance control between the game and the headset; the cable has a knob on it that allows you to give more volume to music or the voices you may be talking to via the very easy to remove and replace microphone. So if you're looking for a top notch multimedia headset one with a good mic the USB issue is a non factor for the home office/ multi-player experience.

To finish this off if you have any real knowledge in fine speaker sound reproduction JBL is tied up at the top of the list for quality. If you've got access to hi-fidelity music; meaning lossless compression formats such as DSD or FLAC to name just a few these cans will not disappoint in any connection method to them. (Anyway do you really need your head to light up like the club in RGB colors?) To me that is the most useless function of these headphones and can be deleted to put more of that awesome JBL goodness; I have in my exception to wireless music being top notch the wireless speakers like the charge series by JBL that are awesome but that's another review.

So yes they are expensive a bit but if you want to shut out the wife and kids and enjoy your favorite jams look no further!!!!!!

title: Great for Travel and Versatility
text:
[[VIDEOID:a022503ddac00a49deb784a423506d88]] I travel a lot, not only out of town, but around the city (NYC) and usually bring a power pack with me so that I can charge any devices that are running low. But with many different devices it can also mean having to bring multiple cables with me which adds to the bulk in my bag. So when I saw the LISEN 4 in 1 Multi Charging Cable it caught my attention. I have grown to know and trust LISEN as a brand for their value, innovation and quality though a number of purchases I have done over the past year (Wall chargers and a magnetic phone holder for the car). This product lives up to and honestly even surpasses my expectations.

First you have so much flexibility USB-C to USB-C, USB-C to Lightning, USB-A to USB-C and USB-A to Lightning, What this means is, I only need to put this one cable in my bag to travel with.

The first thing that you’ll notice is that this is a retractable cable. It adjusts to 5 different lengths (according to the specs - 0.65ft-1.3ft-2ft-2.62ft-3.3ft - I took multiple pictures and edited them together to show the difference). The main cable is USB-C on both ends and one end has a lightning adapter while the other end has a USB-A adapter. These are attached to the cable with a sliding attachment so that if you’re not using them you can slide them out of the way. It also will keep the adapters from being lost.

The other great thing about the design is that depending on the connectors that you use it can deliver higher amounts of power to your device. C to C gives 60W max - enough to power my MacBook Air M1, and C to L gives 27W max.

I have used the cord with my Samsung S21 Ultra as well as my iPad Pro and AirPod Pros and it does great. I love that it can give me up to 1 meter of length when I need it, or retract to the minimum length when I don’t want to deal with the cords.

I highly recommend this for anyone that needs to take a charger with them on the go.

title: No chemical off-gassing smell! Yay!
text:
My husband works in a secure facility with frequent 16 hour shifts. He has to put everything he needs during his shift, including his lunch and drinks, in a clear bag. As such, they take a beating and we've been through a lot of bags over the years. This one seems fairly well made and is decently sized.

The front zippered pocket will be good for papers and small things that aren't super thick. The zipper here and on the main compartment moves smoothly and freely.

Having used bags in this style before, one thing I really like about this one is the strap inside the main compartment that attaches to the pocket with velcro. Seems like a simple small thing, right? The last backpack my husband used didn't have one, and after months of use the pocket kind of stayed open and stretched outward and was constantly in the way when trying to put anything in the larger main compartment. This simple little elastic strap with velcro will keep that from happening with this bag.

The little mesh pocket in the main compartment also has velcro closure. I don't know what my husband will use it for, but it'll be good for anyone who needs this for school or work and needs a place to store things that is slightly more discreet. Sure, contents are still visible when inspected or if you look closely, but it's slightly more discreet than the front compartment for storing tampons, pads, medications, etc.

The bag was shipped in a nice little box inside an Amazon box rather than just a plastic bag that likely would have then been put in a plastic mailer. This is a nice touch, though it likely costs the seller more, but it ensures the bag doesn't get ripped or punctured during shipping. The thing I was most happy (and surprised) about was the lack of smell! We've bought bags in the past that had to be left outside or in the garage to off-gas for days before they were usable. Not the case with this bag! You should be able to use it immediately.

My husband's current bag still has some life left, so he's not switching to this one immediately (I like to always have a new one on hand in case the current one gets ripped) so I can't speak to longevity yet, but I'll be sure to come back and update once he puts it into use if it doesn't live up to expectations.

title: Screws too short to be usable.
text:
Unfortunately, this didn't work for what I was hoping to use it for (a Cisco CBS350 switch for which the relevant parts seem to be unavailable at any price). Unfortunately, there were a number of critical dimensions not posted that I needed, so I ended up ordering it and hoping for the best. With these plates, you'd end up drilling the plate slightly for both screws unless you want to mount it at an angle, and it would be set back a lot (similar to the factory mounting bracket. But it could be used.

The reason for my bad rating is that the screws that come with this are worthless. They *barely* stick through the metal plate, sticking out only about 2mm beyond the other side, which is grossly inadequate, and would strip out very easily. The recommended minimum amount of thread contact is 1.5 x the screw diameter. So for an M4 screw, you should have at least 6mm of screw sticking into the machine, not 2mm.

In fact, the 4mm screws didn't even start to grip the threads on my Cisco switch, and that's probably true for almost anything you could screw them into. But even if they did, you could strip out 2mm of threads in one second flat.

I really can't imagine what they were thinking when they made the screws so short.

Other info:

Before I ordered this, I asked a question about the dimensions, and got no answers. Here are the missing critical dimensions that I needed, but were unavailable, just in case it helps somebody else in the future:

1. Maximum distance between screws:

The distance from the outermost point of one slot's curve to the outermost point on the other slot's curve is about 75 mm. Subtract the screw diameter from that number to get the minimum distance from hole to hole. So if you're using an M4 screw, it would be about 71mm.

2. Minimum distance between screws:

The distance from the innermost point to the innermost point is about 6 mm. Add the screw diameter to that number to get the minimum distance from hole to hole. So for an M4 screw, the minimum distance would be about 10mm.

title: looking for the bare minimum, here it is
text:
I was given this projector as a gift from my daughter for Christmas. She has a part-time job so it took her a while to save for this gift along with others for the family. Why do I bring this up, because I think it was not worth the money spent on it.

As with many other electronic products you purchase on-line, many of us have certain expectations, like batteries for the the remote control, or the necessary cables to connect the projector to your laptop, etc. etc. Well, the GPX Mini Projector with Bluetooth, doesn't offer any of that. When I opened the box, I expected everything to be there for me to give it a test run. What I found was a LARGE system, not mini by any stretch of the imagination, and no HDMI or USB cables. Instead I found RCA cables, yes you read that correctly, RCA cables. I have not seen those for about a decade and I can't think of a single system that still uses those cables on modern laptops.

Needles to say I hid my shock from my daughter and grabbed the remote control which did not have batteries. As with may other electronics we purchase I went looking for the batteries when to my surprise, I didn't see any. So, I went out and purchased HDMI cables and triple A batteries to use the projector. The Bluetooth feature is great but it doesn't work very well. There was a delay between the sound and the picture which did nothing but frustrate me even more. Now I will say that the Bluetooth feature must be on steroids because I was getting devices from my neighbors which was very uncomfortable when they asked if we were trying to watch something using Bluetooth. They said their system would turn on and start playing whatever we were trying to watch. VERY UNCOMFORTABLE indeed. Next was the HDMI outlet, which had trouble holding the weight of the HDMI cable. You have to stand there and wiggle it until you get a connection.

In summary
1. the projector is large - not mini
2. no HDMI and USB cables
3. RCA cables included which is outdated technology for laptops
4. no batteries for the remote control
5. HMDI outlet requires wiggling it to make the connection work

In a nutshell - I would NOT, I repeat, NOT recommend this product to anyone.

title: JUNK
text: just got it delivered and doesn't work!!!!wont go past the amazon screen to set the unit up. there is NO product help anywhere online to tell you what to do to get it work. everything says follow the screen prompts but you can do that if the unit does work! you are better then this amazon.... i severely disappointed in this product. Here is the major issue. I purchased this item, the echo show and it didn't work. I did every step of every troubleshooting method available. 5 factory resets and spoke with customer care rep gave all the information for that person to tell me that my serial number isn't right when i typed it out to them could not use the screen at all and was just stuck on one screen and for the rep to tell me that my order id wasn't right sent me links that you couldn't click on to send the pictures to show them the issue and i also did all the same measures on the alexa app and i even looked it up but all of the instructions are the same but when you can't get passed one screen to any thing up every method of trying you can't do because it wont get past the main screen. Never mind the fact the "instruction" manual is only 3 pages with no troubleshooting pages, no information on who to contact or what steps to take to fix the issue.. completely useless.  piss poor execution of what could have been an excellent product but between a manual with zero helpful information,alexa support staff who was not helpful at all,and  getting a defective product.. which i get will happen from time to time because nothing is perfect. but the fact that you "online support" is quoting a google search is ridiculous. any consumer would and should expect more from a massive corporation such as amazon. then receiving several surveys after every attempt to make contact with a real person and asking if it was helpful or they resolved the issue is pointless after submitting one of them.  i will say i use amazon for damn near everything and typically have an ok experience but part of any business is know the harsh truths about products,usability,customer service, consumer options and most importantly quality and professionalism and making sure the consumer has a good easy experience to remain a repeat customer. this does not mean i will never use use amazon again but i feel like things like this are important to know so thank for letting me share this experiance with you and i hope it is helpful to minimize issues in the future

title: Does not hold charge well
text:
Ordered this in a comboination set with the Ring Stick Up Camera. The panel is smaller than my previous Ring panels and only hold 1.9W. My previous panels were 5W and maintained near 100% all day and night. Compared to my 3 other Ring Stick Up Camera panels in the front yard/driveway this panel maintains lower solar power continuously and never gets a full charge in the daytime. At this moment my device health shows my 3 panels are at 95% and its 5 pm while the smaller panel is showing 85%. Im just used to seeing my panels at 100% charged at night compared to this one. It is still a good panel but not as powerful as the higher rated panels.

UPDATE 4/12/2023 - Melissa from Ring Support called me after noting the decrease in solar efficiency as I had mentioned before. It was down to 70% as the it was on battery power and trickling down from on 85% before. So I moved the solar panel to more sun efficiency on my patio roof awning. After 4 hrs still no improvement. Then I manually charged the battery with the USB cord and after it charged up I re-inserted battery into my Ring Stick up camera. I had noticed on my other Ring camera's solar panels the device
health that indicated all my 3 other cameras had the statement (below the solar status) "A Ring solar accessory is connected and able to charge this device", and it showed the word "connected" in green. My patio camera did not have that at all. While it showed the words "connected" it was not in green as the others. So I checked the USB optional cord going into the camera. I pulled it out and re-connected it and saw that the word "connected" was now in green as well as the statement below the solar status. I had inserted the optional USB cord incorrectly into the camera initially, not knowing it was either not seated correctly or inserted correctly. This led to the battery slowly decreasing unaware that I was the problem by not having the USB optional cord correctly seated. Now the device health is where it should be. (My RSI is strong at 44-51 as well). I mentioned the steps I took to alleviate this mistake on my part so other people could trouble shoot as well if you run into similar problem. Thanks again to Melissa @Ring Support.

title: Wonderful addition to the S4 tablet, but there is one BIG flaw.
text:
This is such a nice addition to the S4 tablet. I really love how handy and conveniant it keeps a physical keyboard. I love being able to hope to physical keys for long typing situations when I need to. The keys feel nice, for a membrane type keyboard. A decent bit of travel in such a small form factor. While a bit on the small side, the keyboard is quite easy to type on. Its familiar enough to jump between pc typing and portable typing. It would be a huge improvement to bave a bit of a backlight for the keys. Sometimes, when its dim, you dont want to be blinded by the wonderful screen, just to type on this thing. But normally I try not to type in the dark. One odd thing I run into, sometimes keys seem to be ignored. I am not sure why, and also holding shift and hitting space too quick as you release shift. That will ignore the shift keys normal action and change the keyboard language. If you have multiple languages installed. If not, you will see your selected lanuage pop up in a toast notification at the bottom of the screen constantly.

The magnetic lock keeps the keyboard and tab tightly connected while laying in place. Also it has magnets that keep the fold cover cosed over the screen too. No batteries, YAY! It connects to the tab with pin that interface with recessed pads on the side of the tablet itself. Keep those pins on the side of the tablet clean, else this keyboard will do noting. So those pins supply power, and data from the keyboard to the tablet. No BT or any wireless connections to fuss with. Snap the tablet into the dock, keyboard is active and ready to go, when yer done. Lift the tablet and its disconnected. Done. Tho I have had little trouble with that.

If it had a backlight, would totally be almost perfect, BUT there is one biiiiig flaw. I have noticed the keyboard's tablet dock area will damage your screen. So a screen protector is a MUST to have with the keyboard cover. I have a faint line on my screen that is permanently there. When the screen is on, its not seen. But is noticeable when off. It was hard to take a picture of tho.

With that in mind, I would totally reccomend this keyboard cover. Just do be mindful anything that is in close proximity to the screen could potentially damage it.

title: Easy Installation (Even on Loaded Desk), Holds Outlet Adapter & Cables. Nice.
text:
Installed on a fully loaded desk 1.5" from the wall. Didn't even need to pull the desk out. Win!

I was worried that I'd have unload the desk and and pull it out to install this basket- I didn't. I just slid up each of the clamp/hangers sideways, turned each 90 degrees and tightened them and then hooked the basket to the hangers. Done.

Nice solution. Just make sure your desk has a rear ledge (i.e., doesn't have a flat vertical back).

Pros:
+ Easy installation
+ Holds firm
+ Holds a fair amount of weight (though seem 'con' below for wall-mount)
+ Includes rubber-like pads to be sure the clamps don't mar your desk
+ Well finished basket (no noticeable sharp wire edges)
+ Includes Velcro cable-ties which are useful
+ Includes adhesive cable holders (round things with a notch to hold cables) I don't use those.
+ Can even be wall mounted and includes both screws and drywall anchors but would be weight limited since it won't be able to hit both studs - see 'con' below. (I didn't screw mine to the wall since they worked fine attaching to our desks).

Cons:
- The wall-mount installation would likely not be able to take the same weight as the desk-attached installation. The basket is 14.5" with the clamp/hangers 1/2" each inside of that 14.5". Catching two studs with each end likely wouldn't work. For US construction, making the baskets an 1" to 2" longer would help installation to wall studs for those who want to attach to a wall (I didn't wall mount so this wasn't a negative for me).

Summary: A cable management isn't just for looks - it stops you from kicking wires as well so you don't accidentally turn things off.

If your desk has a bunch of cords and outlet adapters below it, get one of these. I thought I was only going to use one but ended up using both, one each on a different desk. Well worth it.

Recommended!

title: Pencil Holder Opposite from the Charger
text:
I've been using the case for a week. It's sturdy enough, and doesn't add much bulk. The only issue I have with the case is the pencil holder and charging the pencil. Oddly enough, the pencil holder is on the opposite end of the device from the charger. You can place the pencil on the opposite end of the case (which is where the pencil charger is), and it charges fine, but you can't really carry it around like that unless you want to chance the pencil falling off.

It never crossed my mind that charger was on the other end, not even when I was putting the case on the iPad... I figured it out when I tried to use my pencil, and the battery was dead.

They may have had a reason, but UAG (https://www.amazon.com/Designed-Healthcare-Kickstand-Lightweight-Protective/dp/B0BFWXZPX3/ref=sr_1_6?crid=IM4WZD1XQ73W&keywords=Scout%2BSeries%2BiPad%2BMini%2B(6th%2BGen%2C%2B2022)%2Bwith%2BKickstand%2Band%2BHandstrap%2BCase&qid=1676401588&sprefix=scout%2Bseries%2Bipad%2Bmini%2B6th%2Bgen%2C%2B2022%2Bwith%2Bkickstand%2Band%2Bhandstrap%2Bcase%2Caps%2C119&sr=8-6&ufe=app_do%3Aamzn1.fos.18ed3cb5-28d5-4975-8bc7-93deae8f9840&th=1) makes a case with similar capabilities, but it has built in stand, hand strap, and pencil holder. The UAG pencil holder is where it should be to allow charging of the pencil while stored. It is more expensive than this case by itself, but UAG has a built in hand strap and stand. If you add the magnetic stand to this case, it is more expensive than the UAG.

I'm thinking of returning this case in favor of the UAG.

title: Great Dash cam
text:
First thing I want to say is take some time and pre-sort everything before you get out to the car. It was a bit overwhelming at first when I dumped everything on my passenger seat. Once I was able to separate everything on my garage floor, setting it up was very simple.

Install was as simple as plugging a few things in and running wires under the molding to hide them and keep them out of the way. This is powered by a USB-C cable which is supplied and is about 11.5 feet long. It plugs into a cigarette lighter USB adapter that is provided. I have a USB hub in my vehicle so I opted to plug it into that instead of the lighter port.

The front facing camera quality is what you would expect for 1080P and is on par with the many other manufacturers out there. The cab camera and rear camera are actually only 720P, but that is more than enough for the purpose of it. The cameras do a pretty decent job of adjusting to light scenarios, although like most other dash cams on the market, the camera is pretty much blinded by headlights at night. But, at least if something happens at night, it will be enough to show the police so they can write in their report that you were not at fault, or maybe you were... But this will at least give the truth on what happened.

I appreciate the ease of use when it comes to the buttons on the device itself. Other dash cams I have used are all moving to touch screen which makes you navigate through 100 menus. The small screen supplied with this cam is perfect. I have an android deck that has a dash cam built into it with a 9" screen, and never keep the dashcam on screen. The only reason for the screen on the dash cam I would have to say is to make sure it is capturing the area you need it to capture. If you need video, it is as simple as pulling the SD card and either handing it over to the police, (As long as you don't have you driving wild on it.) or pulling the card and pulling the video yourself from a computer.

I did not run into any issues with this dash cam, and for a 3 channel dash cam under $100, this would be perfect for anyone looking for some extra protection, especially when doing ride sharing.

The dash cam came with a 32GB SD card

title: Mixed bag of meh
text:
First, the product does work. But there are several details that cause concern:
- It is really tight, and not as stretchable as other products like MusiCozy. To be fair - this is day one of my experience, so maybe that would change over time.
- Advise in the Q&A as well as the documentation in the box both say to remove the electronics and then it can be washed. Other than cutting into the thread stitches I don't see how this is possible. There are no flaps, buttons, zippers, or any other way to remove and reinsert the electronics without modifying the product.
- The instructions also have pictures that seem to look like other designs (controls on forehead), but what I received has the controls on the other side of the left ear. Maybe when the instructions say to remove the electronics for cleaning they are referring to a different model? I don't know, just not too happy when the instruction don't match the product.
- Playing my own audio sounds decent, definitely within expectations of a low price band. The voice prompts from the system are a garbled mess. It was hard to tell what it was saying the first time I turned it on (spoiler - I think it says "Bluetooth mode", which is intended to mean pairing.
- A common pitfall of electronics these days is not declaring device names. On top of that, someone above stated that the name was "BT Hat", while I found mine was "BT Music". Again, makes me think there are various models of these and not sure what we are getting.
- The instructions also state what the LEDs mean. The one I have does not have any lights that I can see, whether during charging, pairing or normal play.
- These would not be good for sleeping, at least not the model I got. The right side is passable, though it would hurt if that were between my ear and the pillow all night. The left side is both the speaker and the control housing. It is bulky enough that it was uncomfortable the instant it touched the pillow. Also, I while searching for a comfortable spot, the controls had enough pressure against the pillow to shoot the volume to max before i had a chance to get them off my head.
- I guess if I can't wash it without ripping it open, and can't sleep with it, I really don't have a use for this.

title: It Works Great
text:
I've worked on computers for years and if you know anything about computers they attract dust, food crumbs if you eat at your desk, and other debris you really do not want to think about. When cleaning desktops and laptops I would have to turn off the computers and use canned air to blast the dust away. If you know anything about canned air, it creates moisture and can get in there and damage your computers. So after you the compressed air I would have to let it sit for a few minutes to make sure the moisture is gone.

Over the last few months, I've been seeing these little many electric dusters/vacuums and was curious as to how well they work. When Amazon offered one up for review I just had to get one.

The instructions are limited and it took me a couple of minutes to figure out how to set up the duster and the vacuum. Once I figured I had to charge it up. With USB-C fast charge it charges fast. I forgot to check to see how long it takes to charge. I've only had to charge it once it was on the charger at least 2 hours before I took it off and started using it.

I was able to blow out 3 keyboards, fan grills on Alienware Laptop, and several vents on my external hard drives. I use the vacuum with the different attachments to get the dust stuck on my large mouse pad, fan grills, and other pc equipment.

Since I do a lot of traveling and work from the car I tend to eat while on the move or in the parking lot as I do work. So crumbs get everywhere. I try and clean up the car but you can't get all the crumbs cleaned up after eating. So I have to drag out the shop vac and various detailing sprays/rags and do a deep cleaning several times a month.

After all that it still has plenty of charge (I think). It doesn't have an indicator that tells me how much charge is left.

I tried out the vacuum with various attachments to reach into the tight spots in the center console, cup holders, and in between the seats. It works great.

I found the suctions and blowing features to work fine. They could be a little stronger. But with its size, it really doesn't need it.

title: Not a full 360
text:
I was looking forward to this product because of the features of 360 degree view, being able to communicate through the app both ways, and it being able to plug into a light socket. I didn’t know exactly which socket I would spare but was willing to make the sacrifice of a prime light area if the camera worked well enough. Surprisingly, the camera came with an attachment that allowed this to be plugged into a wall rather than a light fixture! I loved that about it but came to realize it was not strong enough to support the weight of the camera, especially if it was moving at all, so it started to slowly fall out of the socket. That was strike one for me.
Strike two was trying to set up the camera (which, to be fair, was a pretty easy setup even though I think it asked for a bit too much information for this type of product), if I used the app to change the camera’s view, it would rotate the camera and would ultimately rotate the image on my screen to an off-kilter image. I guess I expected it to do automatic re-calibration and that is quite a bit to expect so it’s not necessarily the product’s fault for this issue.
Yet my third strike was the thing I was most excited for—360 degree views—not being possible (or at least not as far as I could figure out). One would think the app would be pretty straightforward where you press the up, down, left, and right buttons to direct your camera to those directions but they only went so far. I would say some of the angles I tried would not even go 180 degrees which was disheartening. I tried manually adjusting to see if I had just set up the camera location incorrectly but produced no better results. After troubleshooting for several more attempts, I ultimately recognized this system is not meant to work the way I expected and it was more hassle than it was worth for my purposes.
This could very well work for people who only have 1-2 views they want to see (and a feature I did like was that you could set “favorite” views) and if you’re fine tilting your head to the side to see the image in the right orientation.
I wasn’t impressed enough to test many of the other features but the talking back and forth seemed to work well. It just has a second or two delay before the audio reaches the other end.

title: Would have been GREAT, if it wasn't faulty.
text:
I was going to use this mostly as a mood setting for those long summer nights on the beach, playing today's most popular love songs in a reggae version. However, this unit was so buggy or faulty that I wasn't able to cope with it. I almost decided to keep it just because it sounds so nice, and the bass was off the chain on it. Love the lighting features. However, I rather handle the issue now and face the issues in the future. I decided to not face the issue later and regret it.

I ran into 2 issues with this unit.

1st issue:
The power button will not turn off the unit. As soon as the unit powers off, it will auto power back on. I can't get this to power off at all. I went looking for answer on the internet and found out that there were many others who had the same issue. I tried the workaround, and the problem was you will need a power source to help turn off the unit. That's the reason I got it in the first place, so I don't have to have a power source, it's supposed to be portable.

2nd issue:
This unit when turned on, the volume will turn down by itself right off the bat. As soon as you press play, the volume sounds great then the volume will just jump to 0(zero) and the volume will be turn off. No way around it, the only way to fix this issue was to press the volume button on the Partybox after your start your music, then press the volume up button then press play again. But if you turn the volume up on your phone, the volume gets all messed up again. It was very annoying; you will literally have to set your volume once and can't touch your volume button anymore.

Overall - I think they should have made a power button to basically use as just that, to turn the unit off and the unit on. JBL made the power button the menu button, the selection button and you basically need to use the power button as a source to do other things. This can really put a strain on the power button that I'm afraid that the overuse of it will shorten its functionality in the years to come especially if you use the unit often. Awesome features, just too many bugs and or faulty things on a brand-new unit will not win me over.

title: Durable, sturdy, fits thick case, portable, and looks great.
text: I will go over some specifications of this tablet stand and then share my experience with it. In the box, I received the stand, a mini wrench, and a carry bag for the wrench. This stand is made of a very lightweight alloy. 4 non-slip rubber pads hold your tablet in place. 2 long pads on the back and 2 on the hooks that cradle your tablet. There are 2 little bumper pads on the bottom of the hinged legs to protect it while folded down. The dimensions of the top piece are Width 9 3/8" x Height 7 1/4" or 7 3/4" from the top to the cradle arms. The legs are 5" in length. The base dimensions are length 7 3/16" × width 8 1/2". You can fold the stand flat for storage or travel down to 1" (1 3/8" with cradle arms). You can fold it back or forth 180°. The back of the stand is open to allow airflow. I decided to get this tablet stand to make my tablet more like a laptop. I ordered a docking station I'm going to attach to this stand. I like the silver color because it matches the other stands I already own. I do have a smaller tablet stand that is nice but not as stable as this unit. The legs on this stand get tightened by the included mini wrench. You can tighten them up so they won't budge. You can draw or push on the screen with your finger and it is not going to fall or tip over. The wrench comes with a storage bag but I got a little magnet and stuck the wrench to one of the nuts so I always have it when I need it. My tablet is heavy and thick with my Unicorn Beetle case. Not only will the legs not budge but my tablet fits great on the cradle arms. It will easily hold my 10.5" tab with the case and my 7" tab with the case at the same time. I just ordered another stand like this but bigger for my laptop. The only thing I would have liked to see differently is nonslip pads underneath the base like my smaller units. Luckily I have a bunch of different types of foot pads because I'm a DIYer and always have little things like this. Nowhere in the description does it state it has pads on the bottom so this will not affect my review. It's still my favorite of all my stands. If you want a lightweight and very durable tablet stand give this a try.

title: Wants to be a wired system...but it's not
text:
Through research and experience, I've come to the realization that wireless camera systems will never be adequate for anything except checking on your pets or kids. As a security system, there's no way you're going to get video evidence of a (smart) burgler on your property.
This system, like most others, operates on 2.4GHz ONLY. The reason is because the alternative (5GHz) won't go through walls and has a short range. Problem is, 2.4GHz is what you're using to stream Netflix, play that new Taylor Swift single, and operate basically everything else in your smart home. So if you were to stream 2K video 24/7 from a bunch of cameras, it will completely SATURATE your Wi-Fi network. Also, it will run down the battery in about 4 hours and the solar panel won't keep up. Manufacturers attempt to get around this by only transmitting and recording video when they sense motion. Maybe other systems are better, but this system didn't start recording until the motion was halfway through the frame...and I was walking really slow. When I ran through the frame, I was gone before it triggered.
Range is also an issue. I had to be within 20 ft of the camera for it to pick me up, and that's on highest range and sensitivity. Constant "motion" event recordings that turned out to be nothing were also an issue.
In addition to the poor performance, this brand is also poor quality. Cheap, plastic housings, and two of them I had to send back due to defects. Communication and service with Wansview was very good though.
If you were reluctant before about running a new power circuit to all corners of your attic to install a wired system, bear in mind most wired systems nowadays are PoE so you don't have to run a power cord to each camera, just an ethernet cable.
A wired system can record 24/7 in 4K resolution to a DVR or NVR and you never have to come home to find the place ransacked and worry about whether or not the camera system actually recorded it. Granted, a wired system costs a little more, but consider one of these 5-camera systems will cost you $100 a year for useless storage of moths flying around. Add that to the cost of a wired system instead, and you'll have everything recorded...everything.

title: A genuine OFC cable made to the finest specs...  Only affordable
text:
The title says it all... This is an amazing product made of the finest materials, and that includes oxygen free copper wiring. This is a dual sheilded, OFC cable the likes of which is comparible to other well known brands among audiophiles, such as 'Cable Matters' and those other brands folks are out there paying $100 per cable for on a daily basis.

Don't get me wrong, I appreciate the fact that those Cable Matters cables are made of the best stuff, but I'm not paying that kind of money for a damn cable. Even if I were wealthy, I would certainly find better ways to piss away good money, than to do so purchasing cables that run $100's of bucks a piece.

However, at this price, I'm all in, and glad to be able to own such a product. And I've already had a buddy compliment me on these cables just as much as he did my new Monolith M12 V2 powered subwoofer, and that's saying something, cuz my new subwoofer is BADASS, no 2 ways about it! I am glad that I was able to find cables like this, so that I could get the best signal possible to my newest investment into my home theater though!

And I HAVE actually tested this against my older Amazon Basics cables, and these definitely do provide a better signal to the sub that is noticeably stronger and more clean. As a matter of fact, I have one sub that I had to use one 15ft splitter cable, coupled to one 15ft single LFE cable to connect to, where I used to use an Amazon Basics 30ft cable, and with the same aettings on the AVR, I could not use the Auto Mode on that sub, I would have to switch it to ON when watching in the room with that sub. But with the same length cable, and same settings on the AVR, I can now use Auto Mode on the same sub, and it fuctions beautifully.

If you are looking for quality subwoofer cables at a great price, don't bother continuing your search from here. If you do, you'll only be short changing yourself if you pass this one up! Just buy it, and thank everyone who wrote the reviews saying to do so once you get yours hooked up and hear it working great with your system!

title: Lots of outlets in a compact power-strip
text:
This is a sturdy and compact power-strip with a convenient 20 watt USB charger built-in.

The unit is just under 10 inches long by 2 inches thick, once mounted to the bracket, the top sits just under 3 inches above the mounting surface. There are ten 3-prong grounded power outlets and four USB jacks (3 Type A and one Type C). Five of the power outlets are located on the top of the unit with five additional power outlets on the front where the USB jacks are also located.

The unit comes with a plastic base plate, which has an adhesive bottom for attaching to a desk surface. The power-strip is secured by sliding it onto the plate. (I'm still experimenting with placement of this unit, so I can't yet speak to the holding power of the adhesive.) There are also two key-slots on the back of the unit for mounting via screws if desired. No screws (or instructions of any kind) were included in the package I received.

I like the six foot long flat cord, which has an angled 3-prong grounded plug. I found the outlets on the power-strip to be a bit too close together. If you are just plugging in power cords they are fine, however, they are too close together to accommodate even thin power supplies without giving up an outlet or two. That being said, there are a total of ten outlets, which should cover most situations, especially considering the internal 20 watt USB charger. Speaking of the charger, I tested it with a USB power analyzer. The USB outlets worked as expected, within acceptable tolerances under load. The power strip also has an on/off switch and the listing states it has 1080J of surge protection.

I find these types of power strips to be very helpful in reducing desktop clutter. Having the addition of 4 USB power jacks really cuts down on the space required for power adapters, further reducing desktop clutter.

I'm pleased with this power-strip, it has more than enough outlets to accommodate my needs and the addition of the built-in USB charger is a huge plus. As far as value - at the time of this review, this was priced at $45, which puts it on the high-side of these types of devices, however, it seems well made and so far has performed flawlessly.

title: Budget Android TV box; plays Prime Video only at 480p, max.
text:
I'm comparing this to my current budget Tanix box - Android 9 with 4GB ram and 64GB rom. Picture quality on this Android 11 box is slightly better - fewer artifacts and less noise in picture. Both boxes can have a slight waxy quality to colors. However, this box lags in routine operations like accessing features of apps. If you click the mouse multiple times in succession, operation will stall up to a minute with fairly frequent reboots. So, click once and wait to see if it registered. Annoying.

The deal-breaker for me is that this box plays Prime Video only at 480p maximum resolution. That's typical of most Chinese-branded Android TV boxes. The internet can't agree on why. Speculation includes that almost all of these boxes, including this one, have DRM settings of Widevine L3 (which forces the 480p limit though most other streaming services can play higher than 480p), not the L1 required for 1080p; or, that certification/licensing from Amazon is required; or, that Amazon has to to whitelist the box.

My only other air mouse remote came with a Sony home theater receiver. I hated it. This one isn't half bad. It has multiple keys for most of the functions normally requiring menu access. I still can't get the hang of twisting my wrist to direct the mouse.

To use he remote's voice command, you have to set Google Assistant as the default . You then press and hold the voice button to speak. Similar to using voice on the PlayStore or for search on Android, but with a physical button. Seems poorly integrated - you can open but not close apps. Not clear if you can actually control apps with voice.

When I tried to use voice control of Prime Video, Android said I have to link that to Assistant in settings. BUT, while a number of apps are listed for linking, Prime Video isn't and there doesn't seem to be any way to add it. Not interested in giving Google my login, anyhow. Might investigate further, or maybe contact the vendor later.

Only tried Prime Video and Youtube (which looks fine). Personally, this unit isn't really an upgrade from my Tanix or other older budget boxes, unless you want Android 11, an air mouse with voice, or the ability to use Google Assistant (assuming that you can actually control apps with voice).

title: Caution -- not what it seems
text:
The Canon Selphy 1500 printer has great reviews in the trade press and by purchasers. Unfortunately it has two serious technical defects that reviewers have ignored, and which made it unusable for me.

First, it advertises "matte" printing of photos in addition to the standard "glossy" finish. It is NOT a matte finish, but rather a diamond-shaped grid that overlays the glossy print to "fake" a matte finish. The effect is nothing like a matte finish. The description that it can print matte is false and misleading.

The second, and for me more serious, technical issue is that it requires a direct wifi connection between iPhone and the printer in order to print to the printer from an iPhone. This means that you must change the iPhone wifi setting from your normally connected wifi network to the "private direct wifi network" where the printer becomes the wifi server. In the process, you no longer have a web-connected iPhone, only the "Direct Connection" to the printer. On top of that, when you set the printer to Direct Connection wifi, the Canon Selphy printer cannot be "seen" nor can it be used by any other devices (computers, laptops, tablets, etc.) because it has been disconnected from the existing WiFi network (oh, of course, unless you cut off all web connection by connecting those devices to just the Canon printer!!). Canon might have designed the printer to support both the Direct Connection wifi and concurrently support the existing home WiFi network, but that would only be a band-aid on the problem. The right way would be to build the Canon Selphy app to allow the iPhone to continue its normal home (or office) WiFi network connection and allow printing to the Selphy through that connection. There is another problem with the DirectConnect configuration -- it can only print within the closer range of the Selphy's wifi signal, and cannot use the broader distance that the home or office WiFi network supports.

I gave up on this printer, and bought a "normal" Epson photo printer that prints "real" matte prints, and also understands that it properly lives in the existing WiFi network, and doesn't need to make up a local WiFi network of its own. The experience with the Canon Selphy technical design issues has been very frustrating. Canon should be able to excel in technical performance -- here it failed in basic design.

title: Great product, great reports great features but freaking huge!!!!
text: this is a cautionary tale in case you're looking to get the GPS device with 140 day charge. I have a spark nano with the weather resistant case.  That device is excellent but it only has a 2-week battery life.  I love the brickhouse monitoring app. it's very easy to understand comparative to other monitoring apps, and the reporting function is great. One of the things I love is you can see a location history in normal English and see exactly the time and the location of whatever you're tracking.  I liked it so much, I wanted to upgrade to a device with a longer battery life so I opted for the extended battery device.  it boasted of 140 days holding a charge, based on your monitoring/refesh options.  so I ordered the device and noticed it was freaking huge.  The battery pack that came with it was like a bank of 8 AA batteries.  then the magnetic case that surrounded everything made it look like 3/4 of a brick.  Yes,  I'm talking about a masonry brick that you see in buildings.  I figured what the heck let me try it out anyway. so I charged it up and slapped it on the vehicle, and don't you know,  my kid, who was driving the car, noticed it PDQ.  My car is a 2007 Jetta and my kid drives that car. Jettas, at least the car that I have, has a barrier between the road and the mechanical parts so you can't easily find a place to stick the magnetic device.  I had to pull that barrier away from the underside of the car in order to find some kind of metal to stick the device to.  okay, i got the damn thing positioned, put everything back nice and neat, and my kid takes the vehicle out.  well he goes over a low freaking speed bump or something and pulls the barrier away from the vehicle  - my kid,  being a considerate kid - noticed it and got down on his hands and knees and tried to put the barrier back in place and lo and behold he found the tracking device.  needless to say a very lengthy conversation ensued.  so if you've got a place to put something the size of 3/4 of a brick on the undercarriage of your vehicle, go for it.  I like the app, I like to device, customer service was wonderful, but I wouldn't recommend it if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground .

title: Might work for you depending on your use case...
text:
Build quality and overall score as a backpack is a decent 6 or 7. It feels like a quality item but not mind-blowing. Fairly priced. Comfortable, rides well despite not much adjustability, zippers work well enough, etc. The camera area, on the other hand, is outstanding. I own and love the Tenba BYOB 10. The camera compartment of the Fulton is just as good if not better than the BYOB. Bigger than the BYOB 10, really well padded, and they give you a ton of dividers to play with. It's also deeper than the BYOB by about an inch.

I also like that the laptop goes in front - it always makes me nervous having a laptop pressing against my back.

But there are problems. First of all - the roll-top area. I love the idea of a roll-top that can expand to fit the moment. The problem is, the sliding buckle and strap totally suck. An ordinary plastic buckle or even velcro would have been so much better here. What should be a quick-access area ends up being slow and frustrating.

The water bottle pocket material feels super fragile. Like it'll rip or snag if you look at it too hard.

Also, outside of the camera compartment, there's basically zero organization. Two small slip pockets in front of the laptop and that's it. They could have easily added another zippered pocket to that area, or a pocket or two inside the roll-top.

My biggest problem with this pack is that if you're not maxing out the camera area with camera gear, then you're left with awkward space that's probably not much use. And if you ever need to press it into service as a completely non-camera bag, you've got to remove all the individual dividers and store them...somewhere...

The flexibility is there - you can move all the dividers and, for example, cut the gear area in half and turn that into empty cargo space instead, but not easily. And when you do, it just highlights even moreso the lack of organization throughout the rest of the bag.

So your needs may vary, but me personally, I don't need that much camera kit on my back at all times. If you do, this bag could do the trick for you.

title: Good picture quality but short on features
text:
[[VIDEOID:c69a7722db0717a720340b1d6290d0a8]] Almost any projector looks good in a dark room on a purpose made screen, so to get a real indication of its brightness and picture quality, I deliberately tested this device in a bright room with a window exposed to full midday sun, while projecting onto a light green wall (see video). To be honest, I was very pleased and somewhat surprised by its performance.

Picture quality is very good and it supports a variety of common video and image file formats without having to connect it to a video player. This might make it a good choice for businesses users who need a simple portable projector that can display videos and images on the go.

The controls on the projector are easy to use and straightforward. Likewise, the included wireless remote provides good functionality. Projection quality is surprisingly good for a unit of this size. The picture is bright and even small text is legible. One thing to note is that the keystone feature will cause parts of the screen to go out of focus at its maximum setting.

There is an included drawstring bag that's big enough to carry the projector but it doesn’t really provide any protection, so you may want to keep it in a padded case if you plan to travel with it. There is a tripod mount on the bottom of the projector which you can use to permanently mount the it to a ceiling or cabinet. Also, there is a convenient menu setting that allows you to flip the picture if you need to mount the projector upside down. A folding tripod is included but it isn’t adjustable so it doesn't seem very useful to me.

Although this is advertised as a mobile device compatible projector, connecting it to an iPhone or Android device requires a separate wired or wireless adapter which is not included. Standard VGA, composite video, and HDMI ports are provided as well as USB and microSD ports. Unfortunately, there is no Bluetooth connectivity as you might find on similar products in the same price range.

This is a pretty decent little projector that’s very bright for its size, and it also happens to be very light and portable. I think there are products with better features at the same price point, but I would still recommend this projector as the picture quality and brightness are surprisingly good. Just be aware of the limitations of the device.

title: A Great Idea, but doesn't always go off.
text:
Ok, this guy has some just outstanding features!

-Solar! No digging in the ground to install wires.
-Range! Phenomenal! We got an almost 1/4 mile long driveway, and it does pick up from that far away, even from within the house.!
-Love that you don't need to run it through your home router or use WIFI. This really opens up the usability option.
-Come already paired, so you don't need to fiddle around with that.
-You can cover up to 4 separate zone areas with this unit by adding 3 more sensors to this unit. So, you can have one in the front of the house, one in the back, and one on each side. Although I don't know where to buy those extra sensors. I guess they will be coming out with them soon.
-Each sensor has its own unique alarm sound so you know which zone area is showing the movement.
-Super easy install hang. Hook back so you can move it around easily.
-Looks like an inconspicuous birdhouse!
-Good volume, nice and loud, or turn it down.

But, a couple of issues.
-You get 4 alarm sounds, one for each zone, and most of them are obnoxious! It comes preset to the "polka music" zone. We changed it to the doorbell zone; But, if we ever want to expand this and make use of all four zones, the polka alarm will have to be used. It would have been nice to have a little library of sounds to pick from.
-Ours has been inconsistent. Sometimes it recognizes movement and goes off, and sometimes it doesn't. We are still playing around with it. So, we might have met the end of the range by installing it at the end of our driveway, and so that might be causing a problem. Also, we have only it up for a couple of days and had cloudy days only. We didn't pre-charge it, so that might be the reason for the inconsistency. I will update once we figure it out--which, I hope we do, because all-in-all, this is a really nice and easy-to-use alarm with its own network and a super long range! For that, I will deal with the Polka music.

title: Complete set, minus instructions, comfortable
text:
[[VIDEOID:92ad1ad4ebbbd969e9158a49097bb057]] I love my Fitbit Inspire2, but sometimes the watch band clashes badly with what I'm wearing. This set gives you options to go with pretty much anything, color wise. It is a very casual set, so it may not be appropriate for every setting (ie, formal occasions), but you certainly will be able to match your watch band to your outfit.
There is a packet with the fasteners for each watch band, 4 packets total. Each packet contains 3 fasteners, so you have an extra for the inevitable drop and lose situation. There are no instructions for how to attach the fasteners, but I was able to easily figure it out by pulling off my current watchband and looking at how it works. The fasteners just slide into the plastic end, and there is a slot to push the protruding pin into so it stays in place. Then you just put one end into the watch opening, push back the pin and push the other side into place, then let go of the pin. Now, the first side was easy, but the second side is a bit trickier because the band is a loop, and it keeps getting in the way of your work. But with a little patience, it's doable.
The band itself is elastic, with a sliding adjustment. It's pretty much impossible to adjust while on your wrist, so it takes a few times of putting on and taking off to adjust according to your preference. The band is comfortable, not too tight as I adjusted it, so it stays in place. It is a canvas type material, so again, not very dressy looking, but will do for everyday wear. I think it will work well for exercise, keeping the wrist from getting too sweaty, and keeping the watch in place properly without having to tighten it too much.
I took off one star because I think the watchband would be better if there were a clasp rather than strictly elastic with an adjustment loop. That would make it a lot simpler to attach. And also the one star off because of lack of instructions. Everything should come with at least basic instructions, in my opinion, even if pictures only. Otherwise, I think the bands are well constructed, should last well, and be comfortable. And no more mismatched clothing and watchband!

title: Nice Digital Magnifier
text:
As the title indicates, I would label this device as a digital magnifier.
A microscope is defined as a piece of scientific equipment that lets us see very small things that our eyes otherwise couldn't see.
There is quite a difference between a magnifier that lest you see p.e coins or insects in great detail and a microscope that lets you see clearly p.e bacteria, amebae, algae.
To give an idea, at 400x magnification you will be able to see bacteria, blood cells and protozoans swimming around. At 1000x magnification you should be able to see these same items, but you will be able to see them even closer up. The claim that this device can magnifies up to 1000x to me seems a little far fetched. I think a more realistic magnification would be between 50x and 200x, that is without distortions of an excessive use of the digital zoom.

But, lets get back to this product. It is nicely built in aluminum. It comes with a handy weighted base were you attach the magnifier and permits to position correctly with your subject.
The DM1S connects through WiFi (not Bluetooth) to the previously downloaded Uni Lab App in your phone. It will appear with a WiFi SSID as WTM-W1... Upon connecting, you will loose your internet connection. The connection process can be buggy sometimes when initiating the "start to observe" button, I had to restart the process sometimes for it was not functioning correctly.

The rechargeable battery of the DM1S charges in about 2 hours using the enclosed USB-C cable and will last for 1,5 hours of use. You can also use this device while connected directly to your computer through the USB cable, it should detect automatically (windows 11) as a camera/scanner device and install its drivers.
You can snap photos of your observations with the camera button, although sometimes it would save the images as PNG instead of JPG in the album. On the side of the DM1S you have a three setting light brightness / darkness buttons, very handy. There is also a kind of hidden RESET hole between the buttons, just insert a paper clip to restore to factory.
In conclusion, this is a fun product that you will enjoy making observation of small things, much better than a magnifying glass but don't expect to see micron sized subjects as in a real scientific microscope.

text:
[[VIDEOID:c69a7722db0717a720340b1d6290d0a8]] Almost any projector looks good in a dark room on a purpose made screen, so to get a real indication of its brightness and picture quality, I deliberately tested this device in a bright room with a window exposed to full midday sun, while projecting onto a light green wall (see video). title: Nice light, surprisingly good radio, crank, solar and USB charge port aren't useful
text:
[[VIDEOID:81748aa6d2b7a832e268e042865fc1a]] This is a nice emergency radio. It does all the things you'd expect - with a few extras that don't really work.

The one thing I was impressed with - the audio quality is quite good, and the reception is quite good too. NOAA Weather Radio came in loud and clear even with the antenna down, and I was even able to receive AM stations, which is generally a problem due to all the electronic gadgets around. The antenna is quite hard to get out, I had to find a business card or similar to slip behind it. It's too smooth to grab with my fingernails. It might work if you have long nails, though.

The flashlight is fine - has 3 power settings to help conserve charge, and it has useful larger light behind the solar panel. Both are quite bright.

The USB power output is a joke. Rated for 1A @ 5v, but can't even do that small amount. It cuts off at around 600ma, not enough to charge anything. Your phone probably uses 600ma, and most chargers are at least 2000ma.

It comes with a solar panel and crank for charging. Don't be fooled by them, they're really not as useful as you'd think. When you look at the specs on the listing - it takes a whopping *9 hours* to charge the unit via the hand crank. That means you'd have to sit there and run the crank for 9 hours to get a full charge. But you can probably crank on it for 15 to 30 minutes and get a little useful light and check the radio. I seriously doubt the crank would withstand 9 hours of continuous cranking.

The solar panel is even worse - they state it takes 100 hours to charge via the solar panel. If you have 10 good hours of sunlight a day, that's a whopping *10 days* to get it charged up. Again, you might get enough for a useful amount of light and radio by letting it charge during the day, but don't expect a ton of charge via the solar panel.

Overall the radio is good, the light is good. But don't get drawn in by the solar and crank gimmicks.

title: Inexpensive entry-level security that’s easy to set up
text:
I didn’t have high expectations for this camera originally, but I’m happy to report that it’s a good deal if you’re in the market for a quick and easy system for watching your door. What I needed was something to watch for movement at my front door and alert me, maybe take a picture and send it to me wherever I am.

What I got exceeded my expectations! The camera comes with an app you can download onto your phone and tablet. This app is amazingly easy to set up, and once the cameras are connected, it works without needing any further tweaking. Setting up and mounting the cameras is also easy, the app walks you through each step with video tutorials to help you out.

Once set up, the camera activates on movement and you can set it to send you an alert plus a video of the movement. We found one of our neighbor’s dogs had gotten out and was on our porch wanting help, so this camera already paid for itself in social capital alone! Another bonus is the ability to talk with people outside without opening the door - very helpful if you don’t know the person and aren’t comfortable opening the door to strangers.

Overall, I’m very happy with this security camera. Best advice I can give is this:
1. When the camera arrives, go ahead and give it a full charge, regardless of the solar panel. While it’s charging, download the app and get ready to configure the camera. The app is incredibly helpful, they’ve done a great job with the setup process, tutorials, and user interface.
2. Configure it to your network before going to where you want to mount it so the setup is fully complete with good wi-if connectivity. Then go check the signal where you want to place it.
3. Put a micro-so card in and format it once the setup is complete. Then mount the camera where you want it. You can use the app to see what the camera will see so you can position it for maximum effectiveness.
4. The solar panels really are optional, the battery is long-lasting enough that you could just let it work off the battery and just bring it in once a quarter for a full recharge, as long as you don’t have it placed in a high-traffic location with lots of alerts.

title: Good quality turntable and speakers for low price
text:
The turntable and speakers came well packaged and included 45-rpm adapter, about 3 foot long speaker wires, RCA cables, 12VDC 2A power supply and a manual. The manual was brief, but there was sufficient information to set up the system. The manual only said to adjust the counter weight for 3 gram +/- 0.5. But it didn't mention how to set it to zero first. I had to undo the set screw in the counter weight slightly in order to adjust it. I adjusted it until the tonearm was balanced, then set the dial to zero. I then adjusted the counter weight to 2.5 g, 3 g sounds high to me. There was no instruction for the skating control - I left it at the set position.
The finish on both the speakers and the turntable is imitated walnut. But especially on the turntable it looks good. The turntable has feet that dampens vibrations. The cloth fronts of the speakers are easily removable.
The Amazon description indicates that a speed of 78 rpm is available, but there are only two fixed speeds 33 and 45 rpm. I'm only using 33 rpm. The nice features of this turntable are the AT-3600L moving magnet cartridge, the belt driven full size platter and adjustable counter weight.
There is a power switch on the back and then you can select between Bluetooth and the turn table by pushing the mode button. Blue for Bluetooth and red for turntable. The light will flash blue to synchronize with another Bluetooth device. I used my phone and it got connected immediately. The sound quality was good but since the speakers are relatively small you don't get a really deep bass. But the sound is well balanced and not over emphasized at the low end.
Using the turntable with a few different LP records I found that the sound was very good considering the cost of the system. It is loud enough for most normal sized rooms. The motor is quiet.
There are no tone controls, like treble and bass, only volume. But I found the balance to be good. You do have to lift the cover in order to adjust the volume.
I tested the RCA outputs by connecting to another amplifier and speakers and it worked well.. The output level is fixed, independent of the volume control, like it should be.
There are no specifications for amplifier power output, distortion, frequency response, etc.

title: Fantastic Large Travel Backpack
text:
I occasionally travel by air for work purposes and when I do I struggle to get all the things I need into one modest sized checked bag and one carry on backpack. I ran across this and ordered it for future trips.

This backpack is much larger than your typical around town/school bag, maybe twice as large. It is like combining a small suitcase, a school backpack, and a hiking pack, with the best features of all. It is taller, wider, and deeper, especially when the expander zipper is undone. I’m not sure how much foot room will be left if you put it under an airline seat, but it should fit fine in overhead bins.

The main compartment will easily hold any size laptop, power brick, mouse, a writing tablet, and still leave plenty of room for a couple changes of clothes. The straps inside will help ensure the contents don’t move around much in travel. This main compart opens in a side fashion, like a suitcase, so you might not want to put anything in that part that you’d want easy access to in the airport or on a plane.

There are a number of medium and small pockets incorporated in this, to include one against your back that would be a good size to hold some items that you really don’t want to get pilfered such as IDs, boarding passes, etc. These all open on the top with zippers so would be better places to store items you’d like to access in transit.

All the zippers work very smoothly. The shoulder straps are padded so they should be comfortable and there is a chest strap between the two straps to keep them from sliding off your shoulders. There is a strap next to your back that can be put over the handle of a rolling suitcase so you can take the backpack off while you’re waiting in the never-ending line at the airline counter.

The weight is a happy balance, lighter than a suitcase, but heavy enough construction that it shouldn’t fall apart under normal use.

The only slight negative is that it has a strong odor right out of the package. I’m sure this will abate over a short amount of time, but I wouldn’t recommend ordering it to use for a last-minute trip; rather give it at least a week or two before using.

title: Can't beat the price! But some caveats...
text:
I'm using this triple monitor stand to replace a Mount-Up Gas adjustable mount I was using for the last 2 years.

I bought this for the single wide arm that didn't offer any articulation of the individual monitors save for slight angle adjustments, and THERE ARE TONS OF FINE-TUNING adjustments with this mount!

Trying to align my monitors before was a nightmare! Everything was always just that little bit off. When I decided to buy all new 27" Dark Matter monitors to match up, I didn't want to leave it to chance. I took a gamble with this Joy Seeker desk Mount and I got a bit win!.

There are some caveats however...

The loss of a star...
-For me, installation was a bit unintuitive. Trying to handle a monitor (even a lighter 11lb one) was rather difficult when the arms and main post was already setup (Per instructions) Instead I took it all apart and mounted each monitor to their respective positions. Which helped me identify some spacing issues preventing the included mount hardware from tightening (should be snug, but don't force it! That could ruin your monitor) So invest in some #8/#10 washers from the Home Depot, a box of ~100 costs like 3 bucks. I needed 3-4 to snug up the screws and ensure my monitors were snug and mounted. Then attached the arms after centering and setting height on the center mount/monitor.
-Do yourself a favor, and wiring it up next, strapping any wiring to the center post BEFORE you attempt any alignment.

This is where I came across the only other gripe about this mount. It has tuning for everything...and I mean EVERYTHING! even that slight 1mm off height for the side monitors, easy twist of a knob!

BUT, the side to side pivot, has NO WAY to tighten. I took off the plastic housing, but the Hex bolts were tucked behind metal plates and has zero chance to ever tighten. After tuning, I should have to budge it much, but time will tell if these cause issue. So far though, I am happy with the end result.

I high recommend, even with the caveats as they may be minor to some, but the super clean and lined up triple monitor setup is my favorite thing!

title: Great first run
text:
I have been waiting for a product like this for a while. There are a couple other brands on the market to write with the electronic ink but being able to also have access to the Amazon library is pretty awesome. There are some noticeable flaws to it however.
Most notably is that the touch screen has some dead zones as well as certain areas it isn't super precise.
