The right top and bottom corners do not work with the pen so if you are writing and then get to those spots nothing shows up which is annoying. There are also certain zones less specific where when you are writing where the pen is and where the ink/writing shows up is does not match very well so it gets a bit sloppy looking. This is annoying for my needs which is mostly writing text and drawing chemical structures, but I imagine it would get increasingly annoying if you were drawing and couldn't get the details you want.
Eventually it would be awesome if you could directly add files to your Kindle Scribe by a USB C cable instead of having to upload to Amazon's website and then send them over, which many commenters have noted could be a security/privacy issue.
Ultimately I would also like it if they could get the device compatible with Microsoft Office so you could look at and edit PowerPoints and Word documents, like competitors are able to do.
I have heard that some of these fixes are on the way, but until it happens I won't hold my breath.
If there were additional pen tips or settings to increase the precision of the pen this would be a no brainer purchase. As is there is a little to be desired when it comes to the level of detail in the writing/drawing you can do.

Although that all may seem a bit negative I do like this product and am happy with the purchase. I have wanted a large Kindle like this to read and mark up PDFs for years and this does the job really well. The battery life is fantastic even with extensive use and I am excited to see how this product gets improved upon in the future.

I moved it down from four to three stars after using it extensively for a couple more weeks. The spots on the screen that have lessened sensitive. My next tablet like this will probably be a competitor like the Remarkable 2 as it has the ability to work with Microsoft Office and turn written notes to text so you can easily share them and all around seems like a more functional tablet.

title: Specialty Product
text:
Let me start by noting that bone-conducting headphones are a specialty product. The purpose of bone-conducting headphones is to give you acceptable audio quality while also allowing you to hear what is happening around you. As such, they are a compromise. The sound quality of bone-conducting headphones lacks classic headphones' dynamic range and precision. For example, they need to produce better bass tones. Also, all of the tones they can deliver are muddy. So, bone-conducting headphones are for something other than listening to high-quality music.

So, what are bone-conducting headphones for? Well, I use them while teaching classes online. That allows me to hear what the student online are saying, and I can quickly switch to taking a phone call. Given that I can use them and still hear what is going on around me during classes, there are great for this. You may have your use for them.

So, with bone-conducting headphones, what should you look for? A lot of the things you want in more mainstream headphones are the same in bone-conducting headphones, including comfort, Bluetooth connection stability, and battery life.

So, how do the Bigozones deliver? They are a bit small, so they are not especially comfortable. However, they are not uncomfortable. However, this is subjective. The Bigozones claim to support Bluetooth 5.3, the latest Bluetooth standard. This means that once you make a Bluetooth connection, the Bigozones have the connection locked. Many expensive Bluetooth suffer from stability problems, with periodic disconnects and such. I have yet to experience a disconnect with the Bigozones. Bluetooth 5.3 also means that the Bigozones support connection to two devices at the same time. So, for me, it is a smooth transition between my computer and my phone and back again. This is a real strength for the Bigozones. I also get a bit over 5-hours of continuous battery life from the Bigozones. Given how small and light these headphones are, that is a good use time out of their tiny batteries.

For special use in which, you need headphones and need to hear what is going on around you. The Bigozones are a good candidate for your consideration. They could be more comfortable, and the battery life could be improved. But as they are, I would get another pair if they needed replacement.

title: Decent picture but must be in complete darkness, easy set up, easy use, ok sound.
text:
[[VIDEOID:a3beca3a34bdea5052dfd233807e77fd]] This was my first cheap projector and was not disappointed. Very easy set up and connection to a video/internet stick. I used ONN, a cheap app stick connected via HDMI. You can basically connect anything to this via HDMI and it should project whatever you have connected, like a Firestick or a Google Chromecast disk, or even a laptop.

I connected my phone as well and can play videos from the phone or YouTube, or basically anything that's displayed on your phone will be projected, you just need an HDMI to lightning cable for iPhones or HDMI to android cable for Androids.

The sound from the projector is just ok, at least it has one, and it'll do if you don't have an external speaker. Which you can connect if you can connect it with an audio jack cable. It's good if you're in a quiet room, but if you go outside and you turn the volume way up, it can get a little crackly and sound like it's coming from a can. No bluetooth so you can not connect a bluetooth speaker.

It has an easy manual focus and basic controls. On my video review you can see a decent picture, despite me projecting on a rough and dirty white wall. I'm pretty sure that if I had a clean white and smooth projector screen that the picture will be much better. I also think that for this to have the very best picture you want to be in a very dark environment or better yet somewhere in complete darkness.

It's pretty small and light, very portable, but with that said, keep in mind you also have to have all the cables that are required to connect it to power, the cable for the device you are playing the video on and/or an external speaker if you want the best sound. You will also need something to put it on in order to face it correctly, and ideally, level to the screen or wherever you are projecting on.

That's where the tripod hole on the bottom comes in handy, so if you'll be using that you'll need a standard tripod(or mini tripod) to carry around. You might also need a projector screen if you don't have a smooth white wall. Just things to keep in mind. Overall very happy with this mini projector!

title: Great Tiny Printer, Poor Quality App that Demands Your Location
text:
[[VIDEOID:4f5a950cfd16a0c6d1a4a513d58e2327]] I like this little printer, and I wanted to give it five stars . . . but couldn't because of the Android App. I didn't try the iPhone app, so maybe that one is better, but I loaded the app onto my Samsung Galaxy Tab 8+ and it had problems with the display, problems connecting with the printer, and it demanded to access my location for no reason. I could not use the app, and thereby the printer, without granting location access to the Canon app, and I tried every which way to do it, but could not proceed. In the interest of giving a good review, I went ahead and allowed access, and then the display problems started, and it wouldn't connect to the printer. When I went into settings and manually set up Bluetooth to connect to the printer, it worked, but the various buttons that the app displayed offering to connect to the printer, didn't work. The building of a picture is easy enough, you pick from a variety of formats like side-by-side, top-and-bottom, and so forth, and then you click on the pane you wish to populate, and it brings up your device gallery. I didn't have many pictures on this tablet, so that's the reason for the eclectic mix of images I used. The print quality is VERY good. Much better than I expected. I did another one of color, and it looked great too, but I didn't want to share the image with you, gentle reader . . . sorry.

This package came with the printer, a 50-pack of special paper, and a sturdy case to hold everything. The printer itself comes with a 10-pack of paper, so you're getting 60 images worth of paper in the deal. If only it were not for that pesky app demanding to know where I am, I would have given it five stars.

Let that be a lesson to you Canon . . . don't allow your app developers to require any more rights than necessary to run the app. This app needs access to Bluetooth and the image gallery . . . and that's it. It doesn't need my location. Full Star Off for this invasion of my privacy.

Four Star Mini Printer Than Can!

title: Versatile 36 W power supply - cheaply made, not very rugged
text:
I like the idea of having 10 different tips to adapt this power supply to different applications. I especially liked the terminal strip output tip as an option, and it made testing with my electronic load very easy. Unfortunately, I don't think the power supply is very well designed overall.

One thing to note up front: the prongs that plug into the outlet are too thin. They measure about 1.1 mm in thickness; others I checked were more like 2 mm. This means that the supply is prone to falling out of the outlet. Take off 1 star for that.

See the graph I uploaded showing the voltage v. output current of this power supply. It will do 3 A (though the voltage has dropped to 11.5 V using the screw terminal output connector).

I'm not rating this as severely as I might, considering that the product essentially broke while I was testing it, because I did abuse it. However, I think a power supply should be designed to stand any overload, or short circuit, indefinitely.

As I was testing, I noticed the output connector was getting quite hot. It eventually must have melted and fused the terminal strip tip to the barrel connector. The output no longer worked. I'm not sure exactly what happened, but the connector/tip combination had gone open apparently, and there was not output voltage.

However, the supply itself was not damaged; I was able to cut the connector off and connect to bare wires (see photo).

I then re-tested the power supply without the connector system. Under load, I observed significantly higher voltage.
3 A - with connector: 11.45 V
3 A - no connector, bare wires: 12.15 V

0.113 Ohms without the connector
0.35 Ohms with the connector

3 A using the terminal strip connector would dissipate about 2 W right in the connector, and the overall voltage drop is quite significant (about 0.7 V).

So the real problem here is apparently that the output connector is not designed to handle 3 A, even though the power supply can produce that much output current.

I would not recommend using this power supply if you really need 3 A. It might be ok for a less demanding application.

title: Good solid blast of air!
text:
After years of using canned, compressed “air”, I decided it was time to go a more eco-friendly route. This compressed air duster packs a lot of oomph in a reasonably small footprint. At first, I was concerned that it wasn’t very strong, but then I realized there are three speeds. At the highest speed, this chases out the dust bunnies pretty well. The included additional tips are of varying usefulness, as my needs are limited to blowing dust out of keyboards and off of vent ports on computer cases. That said, two of the tips seem designed to be used for inflatables, so there might be more overall utility to this duster than I initially thought.

I will say that if you’re after the pinpoint effect of canned air, this unit doesn’t quite match it even at the highest speed. It’s close, like 93% close, but not quite 100%. It seems to be a compromise between fan power (not speed) and nozzle width, because when I put on the concentrating tip then the airflow seems slightly restricted… ie, making the aperture smaller would result in less efficiency because the fan itself can’t push quite hard enough to move all the air volume through. Presumably, a more powerful fan would deplete the battery faster and would result in a higher cost for a more powerful motor, two factors that aren’t exactly desirable from a manufacturing standpoint. That said, for the retail price of this unit, I expected a little bit more. And that’s not necessarily more in terms of fan power… even the added thoughtfulness of including some sort of case to hold the duster and the tips and charger cord would have been appreciated, as the cardboard box isn’t going to last forever. That seems like a bigger deal to me in terms of the “big picture” perspective.

Even still, the performance from this duster means that it will be a long time before I need to but any more canned air, and for that I am thankful. The battery still hasn’t run out after a bunch of use in the past couple days, so that seems like a good sign. I’d take off a half of a star for these reasons, but in a world of whole stars it rounds up to five. All around, I’m pleased with this unit and the convenience it offers.

title: Bose Are Lying Rats Trying To Sell Your Location To Advertisers
text:
The noise cancellation works fine, but I absolutely cannot believe that anyone recommends these things after trying to get them set up.

If you want to use the headphones with the active noise cancellation you're paying $300 for, you have to connect it to a garbage app that lies to your face the second you enable it. These things are the product of the encrapification of everything we use, and one of the worst offenders of further encrapification of things in my life.

Right out the bat, laughably short included cables (hope you're not over 5ft tall if you want to use the included 3.5mm cable with something in your pocket), even shorter charging cable. No play while charging, even if you have a cable capable of it. When you power it up the first time it annoys you to get the app and disables functionality until you get the app and connect it at least once.

Why annoy the hell out of your customer right out of the gate? Well, I'm glad you asked. You see, it's all a scheme to steal your location data, so that advertisers can spy on you and serve you ads. When you attempt to pair the device over bluetooth it demands access to your location data. Connecting bluetooth has never once ever required location data from your phone, and it never will. This is Bose lying to your face for their gain. I'm mad, but not surprised, that Google and presumably Apple as well, allow their app on the store. The executives and product designers behind implementing that prompt (which may actually be an illegal request for unnecessary location data due to your inability to refuse giving it and still continue using your $300 headphones), should be barred from ever being in control of anything significant ever again in their lives as they're obviously a hazard to the well-being of their peers when given any sort of influence.

And Bose rep, before you respond saying you need it to find my device, just save the lying for someone who doesn't understand the tech.

I've never encountered something this maddeningly stupid from a piece of tech before, and given an opportunity I'd advise anyone to never touch another Bose product for as long as they live. I sure as hell never will. I'd return these instantly if I knew Amazon wouldn't throw them in a landfill instead of selling them as refurbished.

title: Cool Microscope, But Not 800X
text:
I ordered this so I could show my grandson how things look when they are magnified.

This is a nice handheld microscope with a built-in LCD screen. The unit comes with a carrying case, microSD card, set of specimen slides, and USB charging cable.

To use the microscope, you just hold it over the object you want to look at. If you want to look at a bug, for example, just place the bug on a flat surface and lower the microscope all the way down to the surface. A built-in LED light will illuminate the object. You can focus by using the focus knob located near the end of the microscope. It does a great job magnifying small objects. I have no idea, to be honest, why the manufacturer would claim 800X magnification. It is nowhere near that. Using the slide of human blood that is included, it is obvious that you are not magnifying by 800X. At that magnification level, you would be able to see individual red blood cells. You cannot see individual cells with this microscope.

I don't really consider the lack of 800X magnification to be a major negative, though, at least not for the purpose I ordered this microscope for. It does a fantastic job on common, everyday objects that my grandson would be interested in. An ant looks particularly fearsome under this microscope. The individual strands in the threads that make up fabrics, the root of a human hair, the printing of a photo in a magazine or newspaper -- all of these are examples of great things to look at with this microscope.

This microscope is listed as being for adults and for kids. Based on my usage, I would say that focusing is going to be difficult for younger kids. But, they don't need a cell phone or tablet running an app to use the microscope thanks to the built-in screen. It is small, but it provides a nice, clear, bright image.

As a test, I connected the microscope with the USB cord to my Windows 10 computer. The computer recognized the microscope and I was able to view images on the screen using the Windows 10 built in Pictures app.

This microscope costs a bit more than others, but the LCD screen, overall ease of use, and sharp clear imaging make it worth the few extra dollars.

title: Provides peace of mind for accidents and theft
text:
Bought this because I got into an accident recently and the other person was super shady. I unfortunately didn’t have any good proof or a third party witness so it became a he-said she-said situation. Anyways, got this as backup the next time anything happens to me.

The installation was not too difficult. I am not exactly a car person so if I can do it, most people should be able to imo. If you follow the qr code provided in the pamphlet in addition to the user manual / instructions, it takes you to an instructional video that was super helpful and easy to follow. I recommend hiding the cables/wires by removing the panels and tucking them in the trim rather than running it along the top edge. It looks more seamless that way. The size of this dashcam suited my purpose since I didn’t want a bulky one with a screen, which to me is totally unnecessary since I can see everything from the app/on my phone. This one tucks nicely behind my rear view mirror and the rear cam is also not too obtrusive.

Now this is my first dashcam so to me, the quality of the video looks pretty clear. Haven’t had any problems capturing license plates and the night vision works surprisingly well. But then again I haven’t tested it in a scenario where there is absolutely zero street lights. Most of the time there is some ambient light somewhere and the exposure sensitivity of the camera does a good job capturing what I can see with my eyes.

Oh also this cam is handy for me not just in the case of accidents but in the case of theft because I drive in a car that tends to get hit a lot. With the rise of catalytic converter thefts, I have gotten a bit paranoid and like that this dash cam has a parking monitor and the angle of the lens is wide enough to capture most people that pass by. While there are minor blind spots, it would be hard for someone to approach without being partially captured. It isn’t foolproof but it does give me at least an added layer of security.

All in all, I like this product so far. Not sure about the construction quality and longevity but will update should anything happens. There supposedly is technical and customer support offered for at least 1 year so we will see if they will honor that should the device start glitching.

title: Wow! Another game changer from DJI!
text:
[[VIDEOID:996131c65e6a42c5cdef9ea3a808c190]] OK, OK. Maybe not a total game changer…, But definitely a super useful piece of kit for all the smaller cinema cameras that are coming out.

Before I get into my review, I just want to say that I highly recommend this gimbal… With the caveat that you obviously keep the weight of your camera and lens set up within the specified weight of the gimbal. I run a Sony FX3 with a sigma Art 24-70 mm lens, and it balances fine… Though I am close to the end of all the adjustments for balancing.

I’ve had the original ronin, the ronin Mx, and the RS2. I tried another company’s smaller gimbal for my Sony a6500, but it was just not up to par with the motor algorithms like DJI’s. I was skeptical at first with the RS3 mini, but my wife of all people insisted I give it a try. We travel a lot for work and we’re always looking for ways to save on weight and size. it works just like it’s big brother and with my set up, I dare say even slightly better. For some reason with my RS2 I have issues with the motors when I add a variable ND filter on the front of my set up, but with this, whether I have it balanced for the filter or not, it works great!

The one issue I had was when adjusting the roll, I was not able to get it perfect, as the included Arca Swiss mounting plate, wouldn’t slide over far enough. I fixed this issue by simply pulling the quick release off and flipping it around backwards.

I do highly recommend watching some YouTube videos on how to balance your camera properly. As with this gimbal, if you are running a set up that is closer to the weight limit, mine is just over 3 pounds, you need to know the proper way to balance it to get things just right.

I wish this came with a carrying case, but I’m sure I can find one that’ll fit it and it’s small enough that you can just throw it inside your camera bag and not take up too much room.

title: Great compact digital microscope - it's our new favorite thing
text:
This was one of those things where I had high hopes but low expectations.... fortunately, I was very pleasantly surprised on both counts. The microscope comes with a stand, plus a charging cable. The microscope needs to be charged for a few hours first. The microscope itself is very lightweight, while the base has is weighted to prevent it from falling over.

That said, you won't always need to use the base; it's possible to hold the microscope like a flashlight and get some great views - it's probably easier that way for some things. The microscope broadcasts a WiFi signal that your cell phone connects to, and then you use an app to see the image on your phone.

You can also connect it directly to your computer with the USB cable, but of course, you're a little limited in terms of portability at that point.

The instructions were relatively easy to understand, but probably could be a little clearer. The app works fine and didn't crash at all (on a Samsung S20+). The images were colorful and sharp, much better than I was expecting, but I'm not sure of the magnification.

The documentation states it can magnify between 50x and 1000x, but be aware it's a digital zoom, so the image quality rapdily degrades as you zoom in. However, I found the lowest magnification to be just fine.

The images attached are of our wood dining table, a citrine crystal, a smoked almond and the print on a letter.

My 7 year old son and I had a lot of fun trying out different things - including a bee, but I'll spare you those photos LOL

I only have two minor gripes - firstly, it's not easy to see what each of the buttons on the microscope are for. It would be nice if they were marked in some way, otherwise you'll find yourself pushing the buttons randomly to get it to do what you want.

Secondly, I wish the app would give some indication of what magnification you're using.

Lastly, not a gripe, but a wish - I would love to have a small hard case for it, as this would be ideal for hiking, exploring and just travel in general. I can easily see this entertaining my son on vacation, and that alone makes it worth the money!

title: Impressive and Reliable
text:
I bought a dozen of these several months ago to put in some test equipment I am building, and have been very impressed. I tried using the Intel stick PC with an Atom processor, but they were under-powered and had fan issues. So when I looked for a replacement, fan-less was a key consideration.

As with so much of the electronics on Amazon I had never heard of MeLE, and buying a dozen of these was a bit of calculated risk. As it turns out, every single one installed thus far has performed beautifully. They are very responsive and boot in about 15 seconds. I am using with an industrial FHD touch screen and performance is very good.

These get a bit toasty when running as they must move the heat out via convection. You will want to be sure they have some room to breathe.

I used wired Ethernet so I cannot attest to the WiFi capabilities, and I do not game so no experience with that. I do think they would not do well with FPS games, but less performance-intensive games will probably be just fine. I can say they run rings around the Atom-based stick PCs I had tried at first. I can can compile code with little pain and my development environment doesn't crash for lack of resources.

The power supply was my only beef at first. It uses a USB-C connector, but it is NOT a USB-C compliant device. MeLE warns you of this, but I tried anyway; no boot. This means you either a) use the specific power adapter that comes with the computer, or b) cut the power cord and wire in your own. I did the latter as I was using power blocks and had 12V readily available. It turns out the power cable has two wires inside (not 20-some like USB-C). One is red, the other black. Red goes to +12V DC, black to ground. Make sure you have at least a 2A power supply or the PC will be unstable. This probably voids any warranty but no problems thus far.

I expect to buy a another batch of these later this year for more test stands. I have developed a good deal of trust that they are up to the task at hand, and far less expensive than every a modest micro-desktop.

title: Nice visuals and audio at the higher range but this is a very small monitor
text:
[[VIDEOID:cdba708c869ae7ae6a8c2bd46d21d3cf]] This is a cute little monitor that isn't much bigger than my hand. It is easy enough to use. All you need to do is plug it into your computer or phone and it automatically mirrors your screen. There's 2 ways to adjust it plus you can take the stand off and hang it instead (for instance, to use it as a display behind the seat in a car.) When I use it with my laptop, I attach the HDMI cable (provided) to both the monitor and laptop and it automatically both mirrors my laptop screen and also made the display and type on my screen be smaller. This adjusted to the normal settings I have it on, on my laptop, as soon as I disconnected the HDMI cable again.

The visuals were good. Not stellar but really good. I liked the settings on my laptop (hadn't really adjusted them) better than the ones on the monitor, but I'm still happy with the monitor's settings. And you can adjust them somewhat.

I'm not completely sure what uses most people would use this for - I would probably use a tablet instead of this monitor in most instances, since then I would not need to hook it up to a phone, tablet or computer....It's nice to extend your phone screen if you want to see something bigger but use your phone as your computer. It's something you could definitely take with you to a cafe, for instance, if you were typing on your phone, and you wanted a bigger screen to view it. However, at that point, with laptops being so extremely cheap these days, I'd probably just get a laptop. I guess it is smaller/lighter but with the stand it would be more awkward to carry.

The speakers' output was amazing at the higher range. At the lower range, I was cringing. It works with earbuds/headphones so it's adjustable. And you could always attach a speaker to it, but again, with all these attachments, it seems easier and more convenient to use a laptop in most instances. Most laptop screens are bigger than 10.5 inches. There's a lot of tablets at lower price points than this monitor. I like the monitor but I'm not sure what exact use it was designed for since there seems to be more convenient alternatives at comparable or lower price points.

title: WARNING NOT COMPATIBLE WITH M2 MAC
text: I’m trying not to be too salty here as my experience with this tablet was really bad. I bought it as a Christmas gift for my daughter and when I hooked it up to my MacBook I got the grey lines pictured. I followed troubleshooting steps on the website and read through countless message boards with no solution. I contacted XP pen and they took me through the same troubleshooting steps as the website making me send screen shots of everything I did to prove I was doing it right. They then told me my adapter was bad (tablet needs an HDMI input and USB-A which aren’t on most modern computers) even though it worked on my other monitor so I went and bought one but got the same result. XP Pen would only respond to one email per day so by this point it had been a week with a useless Christmas gift. I tried the tablet on an old Dell and it worked. XP pen said it must be my MacBook. So I contacted apple and spent a day with them. We created a new library on my hard drive to make sure other software wasn’t interfering, same result. Apple suggested I try it with another MacBook. I found a friend with a MacBook with an Intel chip and it worked. Another friend had an M2 chip running Monterey (mine was Ventura) and it didn’t work. I got back with XP pen and told them and they said it ran on their M2 MacBooks so I asked they send me pics of how they hooked it up and their adapter so I could replicate it and they ignored me. After a couple of days I reached back out and they told me they had turned the problem over to R&D and didn’t know if or when they would get back to me and that I should probably purchase another brand. Two weeks of working on this with Apples help, and I’m decently tech savvy myself. XP pen never offered to replace the tablet or the cable, just blame it on my computer or adapter since it worked with my old dell. I just sent it back and bought a Wacom One. It doesn’t have the same screen sensitivity but I couldn’t notice a difference and their customer service was prompt and it actually works with a modern computer. I will say this worked well with my Dell, I really wish we could have made it work. But, there is a limited life on this product if it doesn’t work with modern hardware.

title: Better than expected, but definitely not equivalent to good hybrid IEMs.
text:
This review is for the KZ ZST in-ear-monitor (IEM) featuring a hybrid configuration with one balanced armature for highs and mids and one dynamic driver for bass. Specifically, I ordered the colorful model (which looks like something Harley Quinn would wear) without a microphone. Over the years, I've owned more than my fair share of relatively high-end headphones and IEMs, and frankly, I'm shocked that a dual-driver IEM is available for less than $20. I recall paying over $200 for a dual balanced armature model roughly ten years ago.

The KZ ZST offers good sound for the money, but the results are different from what I'd expect from such a driver configuration. The dynamic driver produces powerful bass and is capable of deep rumbles, but the balanced armature's characteristic detail never comes through. I have dynamic earphones with equally good bass and much more detailed highs, but they cost $100. Compared to my single and dual balanced armature IEMs, the KZ ZST's bass is decidedly more powerful but somewhat muddy, and the mids to highs lacked clarity. For music that doesn't rely on a heavy bass track, there's no comparison, though.

When it's all said and done, the KZ ZST sound better than what I'd expect from a $20 pair, but they're definitely not equivalent to a good hybrid IEM. Also, the included accessories are decidedly budget-oriented, which may also detract from the overall experience. For example, IEM ear hooks are typically made with memory wire to enable a custom fit, but the KZ ZST's ear hooks are non-adjustable. Isolation, fit, and comfort were acceptable, however. Another issue I experienced with the KZ ZSTs is that they're relatively low impedance with high sensitivity, meaning they're easy for portable devices to drive, but this was a double-edged sword. On an airplane, for example, I could hear a lot of hissing and popping from the in-flight entertainment system.

Notes:
1) The cord I received doesn't differentiate between L/R and I initially had them swapped. You should listen to a test track to make sure they're set up correctly.
2) The rubber ear tips feature a rippled design that's a first for me. It seems like a gimmick to me.

title: Ears beware: headphones almost always connect at 100% volume! Alerts are shrill & at 100% volume
text:
I purchased a pair of these Beribes headphones in March of 2022 and have been using them for 10 months. I'm not sure if there's been any changes to the designs or features since March '22, so please note that this review is for the model I received back then.

Here are the pros: these headphones have great sound and good microphone quality for calls, even if I speak quietly! They stay connected even if I move across the house. I rarely experience disconnection issues. The noise suppression is good enough that I can still hear everything in a busy airport.

Unfortunately, I personally can't recommend these headphones until the following issues may be addressed.

CONNECTS AT 100%:

Ears beware: these Beribes headphones almost always connect/reconnect to devices at 100% max volume. This is unfortunately super loud and undesirable.

I had to remember to lower my volume from 100% every time I used these headphones. This was on a daily basis.

I looked for a fix (outside of manually limiting my Bluetooth volume via my device settings, which was inconvenient when using multiple sound devices).

Unfortunately, the manufacturer said this feature is on purpose and completely intended (in their replies on Amazon).

VERY LOUD ALERTS:

The following alerts always play at 100% max volume no matter what your device is set to:

- Power on/off (very shrill beep)
- Call answered/hang up (very shrill beep)
- "You have an incoming call"
- Headphone alerts

People sitting across the room can easily hear these alerts going off when I'm wearing the headphones.

SUDDEN SHRILL ERROR SOUND:

9 months after purchase, these headphones occasionally emit a SUPER loud, prolonged, and high-pitched sound at random that lasts until I turn them off completely.

I'm worried all this will cause ear discomfort or hearing loss over time for users.

I ended up replacing these headphones with another brand due to these unfortunate features. I hope this review may help people when choosing a good pair of headphones.

title: Very nice and compact WIFI dashcam
text:
This is a really nice and compact dash cam that is easy to mount and easy to operate. Though I'm still learning, most of the initial configuration and operation functions are intuitive. After mounting the camera, I discovered a number of bubbles between the thin "electrostatic sticker" and the windshield. They're difficult to remove but other than the aesthetics, it's not a problem.When applying the sticker, I recommend starting from one edge or corner and slowly pressing the sticker to the windshield, pressing out the bubbles along the way. That said, even with the bubbles the dashcam is firmly mounted with no signs of instability.

A great feature of this dashcam is the magnetic mount. In seconds you can easily remove or attach the camera. This enables you to easily store it for security reasons, to move it to another vehicle wired for the camera, or to plug it into your computer via included USB cable to quickly copy videos and photos directly to your computer.

Video and picture quality are very good (not excellent) both day and night time with adequate detail. The buttons on the camera are easy to use and the remote control is very handy. I really enjoy having the ability to take a quick snapshot photo simply by pressing the button on the remote. The remote includes 3M adhesive for those who would like to permanently mount it in a convenient spot.

I find the WIFI to be a very handy feature, allowing me to download photos and videos from the dashcam directly to my iPhone. I can easily switch to the dashcam's WIFI network to retrieve them (while not driving) and then switch back to Apple CarPlay. Another very nice feature of the WiFi is that it makes it much easier to configure and adjust the settings of the camera from your smartphone via the VantrueCam app.

I use the included 12v adapter connected to the car's 12v "cigarette lighter" port and the cable was easy to route (and hide) with plenty of cable length provided. My car turns off power to the 12v supply after 15 minutes so no need to worry about the car's battery running down when not in use. There's a convenient accessory available to semi-permanently power the camera via the fuse box, necessary if you want to use the "parking" feature.

Overall, I really like this dashcam. It's high quality and a good value.

title: Perfect for M1 Max
text:
I spent over $4k on a CTO 16” M1 Max MacBook Pro, and I wanted to protect it. I’ve used other cases in the past on my MBPs and have been happy with the results. However, there’s so many more available now than there used to be that the options are almost overwhelming.

I wanted some protection, but didn’t need the armored-car type that has thick bumpers all around it and added bulk. I wanted to keep the slick look of the machine and protect the iconic silver finish.

For (at the time of review) $9.99 this is a rock star! It’s got a crystal clear shiny finish and snaps on perfectly. It feels strong and secure. It’s just what I needed to keep my beast looking new underneath. I can add stickers or leave it be without damaging the surface. The slick surface, makes it slide effortlessly in and out of my laptop sleeve in my bag.

It came with a keyboard cover, that’s nice and thin, and will keep the crumbs and cat hair out of the crevices. I have another one that I like the tactile feel better but this one is frosted clear and more professional when visiting clients. This one is still great, and I type just as well with it.

It also comes with a screen cleaning cloth that doubles as a travel mouse pad, with non-skid nubbins on the bottom. It’s pretty ingenious, I wish I would have had this years ago for all my business travel. Mouse pads don’t take up much room but this would have been a perfect solution, rather than using the desk in a hotel that didn’t slide well or on a piece of paper because the wood grain often screwed with the optical sensors. I want more of these to keep in all my business travel bags without taking up essential space!

This is a great minimalist case for a 16” M1 Max MacBook Pro, if you’ve got more substantial protection like a sleeve or padded case when out and about. Like all cases like this, I wouldn’t trust the corners to last long floating around in a tote bag alone without padding as it’s not meant for substantial bangs and drops. For $10 this is a WINNER!

title: I have a love/hate relationship with these headphones
text:
I ordered the OpenMove headset about two weeks before I ordered these. I absolutely love the OpenMove. Great sound without anything in my ears. The OpenSwim. . . I'm undecided. The OpenMove is great for my five mile daily walks and gym sessions. I also lap swim a mile four days a week. So I got the OpenSwim specifically for my swim workouts.
The first day I wore them I was unimpressed with the sound I got while at home loading up some MP3's. Particularly since I was so happy with the sound from the OpenMove. I swam a lap and was extraordinarily disappointed. I couldn't hear a thing during my freestyle and kickboard work out. During my freestyle, there was just too much noise from my arm strokes to hear the music. During my kickboard workout the music quality was just terrible. But when I fully submerged my head under water...Holy Cow! What fantastic sound. The problem is, of course, I'm rarely submerged while I swim. I don't ordinarily do turn kicks because it takes too much out of me. So even though I like the concept of not having anything inserted in my ears, for the last week I've been swimming with ear plugs in.
There's a marked difference in sound quality for the better with ear plugs in. However, the music quality is still terrible while I'm doing my freestyle strokes. I'll compare it to having a radio playing by the side of the pool. You know it's playing music, but you can't tell what song, or even what type of music, is playing. But my kickboard workout is much more enjoyable. BUT, the problem that I was trying to avoid by not having in-ear headphones is painfully smacking me in the face. With the ear plugs in I can't hear a single thing going on around me at the pool. I can't carry on a conversation with my lane neighbor. I can't hear people calling me to get my attention. I hate being so situationally unaware. It reminds me of visiting NYC a couple years back and looking at all the idiots on the subway with junk in their ears. None of them knew what the heck was going on around them. I'll try them out for another week. But for the price, I just don't think they're worth it.

title: Works great, awesome value!!
text:
I was a little skeptical going into this purchase due to the price so my expectations were low!
Upon arrival, which arrived a couple days later (USPS, they're not the greatest), this thing is pretty small and nice looking device!
It came with the device itself, a short (stubby) 3.5mm to 3.5mm jack, a short 3.5mm to 3.5mm cable, and a USB to type C cable to charge device. It was easy to pair to my old Note9 phone (I used short stubby adapter to connect to my radio). The lights on it is intuitive to let you know the status of device.
The device has several controls on board for volume control, voice answering phone calls etc (haven't tested that yet). I left my volume set to max on device along with my phone set to max volume and just controlled master volume through the radio. I must say, I was using a good quality 3.5mm to 3.5mm cable before that was becoming annoying, but this device for some reason has improved the sound quality of the music! I noticed that I didn't have to increase the master radio volume as much as before and the sound quality was much crisper, bass was puncher (even with one of my speaker being slightly blown)! This device must be processing the sound better or something before entering the radio, I don't know! Yes you have to connect to it each time you turn it on (not automatic) but it's a miner gripe for me and will give it a pass due to the value and impressive sound I'm getting from this thing not to mention no more long cable hanging around again! It was said by some that when in use and plugged in for charging in cigarette lighter (which is great that you can do) can make/ have that awful buzzing sound (interference) coming from it (my older cable did it/ unusable when I plugged and charged my phone), the sound was extremely minimal was there but for me it was minimal! Now I haven't tried charging my phone when operating this device to see if there's any interference yet! I still have to test other features but so far I would definitely buy another one if need be so far, great value at $12.50 (less than 1.5 dozen of extra large eggs these days🤣)! If anything occurs or something I will add to post or adjust my thoughts in the future!

title: Not bad for the price
text:
Probably the best thing about these headphones is the price. My current headset is the Bose NC700. And while these clearly don't compete directly with the Bose headset in pretty much any category, they are also 1/8th of the price and still quite functional. In my testing, I used these for a day of work connected over bluetooth to my laptop running Ubuntu 22.10 and a Google Pixel phone. Over the course of the day I wore these for stretches up to several hours, joined several calls on Microsoft Teams, listened to recorded meetings and to music, and took a phone call.

I like the over-the-ear design. I have large ears and found the cups on this headset to be just a tiny bit smaller than I would have hoped for. After multiple hours of wearing these, my ears were aching a tiny bit from the pressure. The sound quality of this headset was fine for meetings but I detected a bit of warbling when listening to music. I'm not much of an audiophile, but imagine that this would be annoying for anyone that was. The mic seemed to work OK. I did not get any complaints about my audibility on computer calls, but when taking a call on my phone the caller said I was breaking up a bit. The noise cancelling is not quite as good as the Bose, but that's not a huge surprise. Range on these were about the same as my Bose headphones. I could get up and walk several rooms away from my desk without losing audio.

Connecting the device was pretty straightforward. However, after turning the device off and then back on again, my computer did not seem to automatically reconnect the audio. I had to manually disconnect and reconnect the device from with the computer's bluetooth settings to get audio again. This may be an oddity of Ubuntu rather than the headset, but it's not a problem that I have when using my NC700's. I was able to simultaneously connect to both my phone and computer. This is a nifty feature that allows me to answer a call while otherwise connected to laptop audio. But to get both devices to pair I had to turn the bluetooth off on one device to get the headset back into a pairing mode. The buttons on the headset worked well to answer the phone call without having to reach for the actual phone.

All in all, these aren't a great headset, but not bad for the money.

title: Five stars for the picture, two stars for the experience
text:
It kills me to write a negative review for this TV, because it's so _beautiful_.

But this is a negative review none the less. As a display, this thing is AMAZING. The picture quality is very good. The brightness, the blacks, the latency, the color, everything. Top notch.

But the software and manufacturer's decisions really let this thing down big time.

Almost every time you turn on this TV you will be greeted with "notifications." These are mostly advertisements for new ways the TV can sell you features and apps. Sometimes they're about updates. Sometimes they're about taking a feature away. Whatever they are, they appear for a few seconds each, and you can't disable them. Expect it to be a full minute between when you want to use your TV and when it actually lets you use it, rather than LG using it as a billboard.

You CAN disable the notifications by telling the TV it's region is somewhere outside of the supported countries. But if you do that it disables Alexa and HomeKit and AirPlay and a bunch of other features that have no reasonable reason to be region locked. So you have to pick between being free of obnoxious notifications and ads, or having access to the features you paid for. You can't have both.

Then there's the apps. Most of them are OK. Fine. Same as on any TV. But some of them, for whatever reason, require you to make an LG account to download them. Why? Who cares. LG doesn't need to or deserve to know what I use MY TV for. Not their TV, MY TV. Additionally, there are some important apps missing. No MLB.tv for example. I know it's up to MLB to decide to put their app on LG, but for LG that's a pretty big deal. Get a deal done with MLB and get the app back on there. Or use some other OS that supports MLB and give up the control you have to track me on ... again ... MY TV.

Anyway, if you're a Roku or AppleTV or anti-smart-devices type of person, you'll love this thing 'cause you'll never even connect it to the internet. But if you want a TV that does what it says on the box without abusing your trust and time and data, this isn't it.

title: keeping this over the Show 8 due to table size
text:
wanted a smart display beside my bed.
the most important features is playing spotify music and voice controlling my bedroom lights so i dont have to get up
getting the clock and outside temperature is a bonus that gets rid of the clock radio

i like the look/features of the nest hub the most and bought it initially.
however, the nest hub had a fancy feature that uses a radar for monitoring sleeping patterns
that is cool and nice, but having thought more about it, i looked into the safety of the radar that stares at your 8 hours a day for many years
then i researched the google device more and discovered that the radar required a FCC waiver because it exceeded the safety power limit for 60 ghz (new frequency with little long term safety data)
then i returned the nest hub after 2 days and went to the amazon offerings.

decided the show 5 over the show 8, as it was a better size for my night stand.
sound is good enough.
screen looks small compare to the 8 but it fits the table better.

want to say that before you buy a smart display, need to consider that amazon will only support it for 4-5 years in terms of security updates
that is a big difference between this and your old clock radio without a camera and microphone connected to the internet
without security updates, it is more likely that someone can hack into your show device and perhaps even your amazon account...
having said that it is only $35 before tax
so it is not a big deal to treat the device as disposable in 5 years if lack of security updates become a big deal

features-wise, still annoyed since i cannot voice command the spotify playlist because i refuse to pay spotify for premium account
but i actually keep my chromebook always next to me
i just have to designate the device to play music and then pick my playlist

the strangest issue with this order is not the device but the delivery process.
for the 2nd time in last 2 weeks, the amazon system indicated that the product was delivered to someone in the house when that was not what happened, as it was left at the front door.
not sure if anyone else has experienced this issue.

title: Every component is first quality
text:
I opened the case to add another 1TB NvME and was able to give the construction a once-over. I have built every desktop I've ever owned, and if I were building a laptop, this is how I would do it. There are no weird proprietary decisions made in the construction, and I would compare it to some Sager models I've worked on.

I installed MX Linux in about 15 minutes from boot stick to login, and everything is supported in current distros. I use dual boot so that I can run either OS as needed.

The keyboard is exactly what I want. I have clacky mx blue keyboards for every desktop application, and it is really nice to not have to adjust to a mushy generic membrane keyboard. My wife hates all of my keyboards, especially this one, since I'm not restricted to an office on this one.

The numpad is sadly lacking. It is a membrane pad, and I can't count the times I've tried to hit 'Enter' with my right pinkie. I will probably adjust eventually, but it is a disappointment.

The display is incredible! I have never handled a laptop with anything better.

BIOS options are plentiful. I haven't found anything missing yet. I probably won't do much to tweak performance, since it is a 12900h, but many options are there.

My prior laptop is a core i7-9750h with an RTX-2070, so I am only noticing very minor performance increases. I really like that laptop except for the display quality and the lack of numpad. This one is bigger and heavier, but I don't travel as much now, and work provides a decent notebook for that, so I felt it was time to move to a desktop replacement, regardless of weight and size.

Is it the best laptop I've ever owned or worked on? Yes
Is it worth the price tag? are you kidding?? absolutely
Is it a good choice to give to a college kid? NO, it will break your heart when they get it stolen or break it through carelessness.

If there is anything I would suggest to Eluktronics, it would be to offer an MX brown or red option because not everyone absolutely craves a clacky tactile keyboard.

title: So easy!
text:
I grew up being an avid reader as a child, which continued into adulthood. After a couple of moves, with books packed away in boxes and other things that interfered with reading as often as I used to, I started thinking about the fact that I haven’t read anything significant in years.

I realized how much I missed it, and how much time I was wasting with my “nose in my cell phone,” rather than a book! With those things in mind, I started reading reviews on Amazon to compare the various versions of Kindle.

I’m so happy with my new Kindle Paperwhite! I love the fact that there is significant storage to hold books to read without depending on Wi-Fi. The auto adjust feature for various lighting conditions is very handy. For me, the very best part is that when I pick it up, I can immediately begin reading where I left off! No more opening a book to two (2) side by side pages, and having to think about where I left off, or worse, having a bookmark fall out. No more having to decide which book to take with me, which I wasn’t doing anyway… I can have them all with me, any time I want, wherever I am. I can drop it in my purse any time I go out; you never know when you’ll find a few minutes to read, instead of wasting that time playing on a cell phone!

Years ago, I resisted switching over to a Kindle because I preferred the feel of a book in my hand, and the satisfaction of physically turning each page.

As the years passed, while becoming accustomed to electronic devices being part of everyday life, I now realize that physically holding a book, and the tactile pleasure of turning pages was not being enjoyed because I was no longer reading at all.

Getting my Kindle has shown me what’s most important: It has given back to me the ability to enjoy reading again.

I am particularly pleased with the features of the new Kindle Paperwhite, but for anyone with a more limited budget, I have no doubt that the less expensive versions can also bring the joy of reading back into anyone’s life if they experienced the same gradual straying away from daily reading that I did. I highly recommend it!

title: It's not a can of compressed air, but it's the next best thing
text:
I got tired of spending money buying cans of compressed air, forgetting to get new cans and not having them when I need them, all of that. This popped up for me right around the time I was thinking about getting an electric duster, so I took it as a sign. Now, here we are.

First off, it's soft-touch. Yep, that satiny-smooth finish that's destined to melt back into petroleum goo in a few years. Not thrilled about that, but in the mean time it feels really nice in the hand!

It features four strengths. For the sake of dusting, I only use the full strength. There is a master power button on the bottom, along with a power/charging light that indicates how much power is left in the charge. The trigger button lights up different colors to visually indicate what strength is selected. It's a nice touch, as I have in fact lost track of the setting on it a few times, so the visual reminder is nice. It comes with three attachments, a narrow nozzle to focus the air for stronger dusting, a nozzle with a brush that's good for the keyboard or other areas where you may need to agitate the dust a little, and a wide angle nozzle that I take to be for drying your hair. Yes, the instructions say you can use this to dry your hair, as well. Which, honestly, is kinda nice. I don't like to blow dry my hair because it really doesn't like the heat, but this doesn't get hot, so it's rather convenient for me to take some of the dampness out of my hair after a shower. But really, it's not a hair dryer, don't expect it to do well for that.

As for dusting, it works decently well. It's not as good as a can of compressed air, which it won't be because the air isn't focused nearly as tightly as it is through that straw on the cans, but it still works pretty well. If dust isn't allowed to cake up to where it wants to stick, this does a good job of blowing it off. If it does get a bit caked, the brush nozzle helps a lot. For the majority of my dusting needs, this will work just fine.

Good price, good blower. Definitely happy with it, I'd recommend it to others.

title: Pretty darn good…hoping for a few tweaks in the app. Though.
text:
We were forced to upgrade from our Arlo camera system when Arlo unceremoniously emailed us telling us (despite the fact that they still worked perfectly) that they were “end-of-life” ing our Arlo system. Well, of course we’ll never use Arlo products again for that FU from them, so we found these.

They seem well made, at least feel as sturdy as our old cameras do, and the picture quality is very, very good esp on “QHD” setting. The Wi-Fi connection to each of the camera seems very robust despite the fact that we still have one older Wi-Fi router serving our household, not a newer “mesh” or similar system. All 5 of these ieGeek cameras we have scattered around our property have been nearly bulletproof connectivity-wise so far. Impressed.

The set-up was easy, but the App feels somewhat clunky to us, BUT that may be due to the fact that we are having to re-learn from an app we are longtime users of with our prior cameras system. Time will tell but functionality is good.

Per the title of this review, I DO hope they had some additional “image” related settings which would allow zoom, pan, and some lightening/darkening of the image (esp. on a bright sunny day). Also, some scheduling settings enhancements would be nice to avoid un-needed alerts during certain times of day when family routinely comes and goes, etc. These are all simple enough tweaks/improvements to an app which I hope ieGeek pushes out at some point which would make a pretty darned good system even better.

My biggest gripe with these is the mounting brackets which in a word are….terrible. They are plastic, and VERY hard to adequately tighten when precision aiming the cameras for best results. They really cheapen the experience but I eventually have them all set up, hopefully the brackets will hold in place as aimed once they start to broil in our hot So Cal summer. They need to up their game on the mounting brackets!

All in all we are happy though, and despite my opinion of the app needing some tweaks, these do exactly what we need them to. I hope the improve those darned brackets too.

title: Very small and light but made extremely well
text: This USB hub is a very nice unit. I was surprised when I removed it from the box and gave it a look to see how it was laid out and the build quality. The first thing I noticed is the outer casing. It is an all aluminum case which is a dark grey color and is anodized. The unit itself is very solid and very easy to carry. The ports are all of high quality and are nice and flush with the outside of the case. The micro SD slot, SD slot, Ethernet port, and the HDMI port are all made directly into the body of the case which makes for a very attractive look and design. It has a small blue LED on the top to let you know it has power which is bright enough to see in the daylight but not so bright its obtrusive or distracting. The cord is very short at about 6 inches or 160mm and terminates into a USB type C plug. I have used every feature this little hub offers and everything works flawlessly. The onboard Gigabit ethernet port works straight away without any need to install drivers or change anything in Windows. The HDMI port also works great and came on as soon as I plugged it up. I could not successfully get the HDMI and ethernet port to work simultaniously but I don't think they were meant to as there wouldn't be enough bandwidth to carry both signals at the same time over the USB 3.1 bus. There is also a port on the side which lets you charge things such as a laptop or phone and maxes out at 100Watts. There are 3 USB 3.1 Type A ports on the other side where the MicroSD and SD slots are located. It's nice to have a hub this powerful work right out of the box with HDMI and ethernet and do this without an external power adapter. I have been using this for a few days now and I am very pleased with it. The price is very good for the quality you recieve. No drivers, no fuss, just plug it in and go. That's the way USB hubs should be and do it all without some clumsy external power adapter you have to lug around with the hub and have to be near a power outlet to even use it. This unit is truly portable and is a must have for those individuals on the go and need a few more ports to plug things into or another HDMI for a projector, etc. You can't go wrong here for the price and you won't be disappointed with the quality.

title: Beautiful, Comfortable, & Loud - A HIDDEN GEM!!!!!!
text: So, truth be told, I rarely write a review.  But I had to, guys.  So recently I've found myself buying earbuds, after earbuds.  In the space of 2 months, I've purchased (in this order); Sony's wf-1000xm3, Beats Studio Buds, Samsung Galaxy Buds2 Pro, Sony's wf-1000xm4, and finally, my real favorite - the least expensive of them all, (I had to buy the Sony and Samsung buds refurbished) the unbelievable fabulous Tempo 30 earbuds from Back Bay!  In the first place, these are the only earbuds that fit my small ears, which makes them the best by default.  Every set had a warning preceding their purchase, that if the buds don't fit, you will not be able to enjoy them properly.  But I was beginning to think that earbuds were just supposed to lay on my ear tucked behind some cartilage, because how could Sony and Samsung both get it wrong for folks with small ears?  Sony's wf-1000xm4 sounded beautiful, and came closer to my ear canal than the others. In truth, if they had all fit me properly, it might change this review.  But it can't change the fact that I only paid $45.00 for them.  They came in the smallest case of them all, the rose gold is quite elegant, and they appear to be very well made.  I'm not an audiophile in any kind of technical sense but the sound was incredible to me.  I achieved a volume which I couldn't seem to achieve with the other buds.  The Beats Studio buds came the closest in volume, but I watched Youtube reviewers, all of which said the volume of these buds were unmatched.  I had no problems connecting to any of my devices.  And the one thing I can say is a "con" is that I had some difficulty with the controls.  But I think this might be a "user" issue, because I was the kid that had to practice all summer using scissors.  I'm sure the fact that they fit me for a change has everything to do with my joy in terms of these earbuds, but I challenge anyone to a duel.  These earbuds, the little known Tempo 30 from Back Bay, are seriously lovely.  A true diamond in the rough.  I'm really pleased.

title: Great Replacement!
text:
My original case had been getting temperamental about charging. It would connect initially, then stop charging, then just stopped altogether. I tried cleaning the charging port, trying different chargers, wireless charging, resetting, various suggestions from Google, etc. I certainly wasn’t going to pay Apple what they want for a new case. I thought the reviews on this were decent, and more than anything it had same day delivery. I got it just a few hours after I ordered.

I’m so glad someone posted the photo of their instructions, or rather their key of what the various lights mean since the colors vary a bit from the original, mine didn’t come with instructions except for a sticker on the case that said to charge for at least 15 minutes before trying to sync it. I charged and it synced just like usual. Look for that review if you need that!

It charges just fine wired and wirelessly. It does take a bit longer to charge, and the airpods don’t last quite as long. I did heed the warning about how hot the case gets when charging wirelessly, so I take the airpods out before I do that so I don’t risk them getting warped. Others mentioned this as well, but when you open the case and look at your phone to check the charge status, it takes a moment to show up rather than instant like the original case.

As other reviews have mentioned, it is a bit lighter than the original case. The hinge looks a bit different from the outside and is a little looser than the original when opening and closing. The last difference I noticed is that the button is on the front vs. the back. These things don’t bother me at all as the case is just a way to charge the airpods, but if that’s important to you those are the facts. It does look identical otherwise. I wouldn’t have noticed any of those things if I hadn’t had them both in my hands comparing them.

All in all, this is a great purchase! I think most of us realize when we buy a generic piece to replace a brand name piece that the quality is not going to be exactly the same. I do believe for the price it is well worth it!

title: Update as of April 2023 after buying in December 2022
text:
[[VIDEOID:b12147f4cd09f02266d75cf3b5256319]] SECOND UPDATE AS OF THE END OF APRIL 2023: Arizona heat is already making this glitch like crazy. Nothing seems to help get the device to stop hitting the volume button or home button on its own. This is now worthless to even keep. I have a video attached on how it’s glitching. It was 90°F outside today for reference.
UPDATE AS OF MARCH 2023: I’ve noticed when there’s a bit more heat, the device seems to act as if I’m pressing the volume buttons and the menu button but I’m not. I’ve noticed after hitting factory reset on the device set up, it seems fine for a bit. But other than that, it seems to work well! I’ve also noticed when I try to call anyone they cannot hear me, it’s just a static noise on their end. It’s the same when I try to record anything from my phone while it’s connected wirelessly or via usb. But again, other than the glitches & mic issue, it seems to work fairly well for 2012 Chevy Cruze!

I have been SEARCHING for something that’ll work with my 2012 Chevy Cruze without all the complications of having to change out the stereo and wires and all and I’ve found one finally! This was actually super easy to set up surprisingly too. The adhesive sticks pretty well on the windshield, we’ll see how it handles in the summer here in Arizona! Hopefully I’ll remember to update this in the summer :P so far I’m pretty happy with this purchase honestly! Not sure how well it works for android phones since I have an iPhone 11 Pro, but it works like any other car play! There’s one piece I’m not sure what it’s supposed to be for yet but I didn’t really need it, just the arm piece with the suction and the CarPlay device and the shade thing you click into place. The unfortunate thing I have to say is the auxiliary cable was too short from the windshield to the center console where the auxiliary port is so I had to use another one that was longer that I thankfully already had. But all in all I’m happy with this one!

title: An interesting upgrade
text:
There are parts of this pair of earbuds that I really like, and parts I really don't.
Pros:
Type c charging
Speedy charging
Screen on case is convenient
Touch controls work pretty well
Cons:
Case feels cheap
Sound quality is maybe a 7/10. Could be better, especially for the proposed full price before sales
Earbud shape is a bit odd and doesn't fit as well as others for me personally.

The case:
The screen on the case is very convenient. It's bright, the 'animation' is perfect and speedy, and it's easy to interpret. However the actual build quality is just okay. It's all plastic, and it's very lightweight. You are told to be careful not to drop them in the instructions, and when you do the earbuds fall out. I dropped them in the parking lot once and the black earbuds landed on the black pavement and I was worried I was doomed. So, since you're warned, I can't necessarily complain. Just keep it in mind if you happen to be clumsy.

The buds:
I'm not a huge fan of the shape. They don't stay in my ear as well as other buds I've owned in the past. If you're used to the buds that are wider and don't have the long stem, these might not be as comfortable. It took me a bit to get used to them. However they're not terrible at all. You can customize the size of the plastic pieces to get a better fit of course, and that's definitely necessary. The sound quality is not bad. Not too much base but it's clear and easy to understand. Nothing to write home about but I also can't complain. They're a little quieter than others I've had but they still get plenty loud. They connect very quickly and don't talk or beep at me as much or as often as other pairs have. The battery is great and I can't rave enough about the fact that they are usb-c instead of b. They get all 4 stars just for that.

So, when I bought them they were originally 130 dollars. I bought them for like 20. If I'd paid 130 dollars, I'd be devastated. Since I paid 20, I'm pretty happy.

title: Review of the C11 Black by an Experienced Headphones User
text:
In these COVID times, I've gone overboard buying all kinds of headphones. I don't like to put things in my ears sometimes so, for on the go, I have, along with earbuds, lots of open ear headphones -- several expensive, major brand bone conduction headphones, several budget bone conduction headphones, and one pair of headphones that, like the C11, is air conduction -- sending sound directly into the ear.

The C11 are the best of the open ear headphones that I have, including the expensive bone conduction, for sound quality and equal to the high end bone conduction for phone call quality. Like all open ear headphones, the sound is not as full-bodied as earbuds--it is limited in bass, but the sound on the C11 has a balance of bass, mids and treble that is superior to the other bone conduction and air conduction headphones that I have, making it noticeably less tinny and, unlike the others, enjoyable to use for music as well as spoken word. The C11 do not stream the LDAC codec that my phone allows, but do stream AAC. They are clear and have separation of instruments, but (like the other open ear phones using the AAC or SBC codecs) do not have any sound stage to speak of. No noticeable distortion at high volume.

I am a large person, and the C11 fit very comfortably and lightly on my ears -- including because there's a little give in the ear loops. I've worn them for about two hours so far with no discomfort at all. They can be used one at a time too.

The case is not too heavy or big, and it and the headphones charge as advertised, the case using a type C cable. The battery life appears to be as long as advertised -- which, because of the case's charging ability, is much longer than the other open ear headphones I have for being out and about. The controls take a little getting used to, but work flawlessly. The C11 connects to only one device at a time.

At the time I write this, the C11 appear to be unique on Amazon -- meaning, they are the only quality true wireless air conduction headphones with very long battery life that I could find. For what I paid, I'm very happy with this purchase.

title: Insane quality, picture, and motion for an unbeatable price.
text:
I've never had a reason to dislike my 27" Sceptre monitors. I'm used to having a 22" monitor and a 24" monitor at work, but I've always thought that they needed to be bigger. Once I set up my office the way I really wanted it, I decided on having a dual 27" monitor setup. I've liked it a lot, but when I saw the option to grab this monitor while it was still in stock, I had to take it.

PROS
This is a BIG monitor, and the picture is great. It's nice and sharp, and the motion is really great as well. I know there's a lot of enthusiasts out there who can't wait to tell me how wrong I am, but for someone who doesn't need the top of the line, I'm very happy with this.

It still has a VESA mount, despite its size. For anyone wondering, it needs risers in order to work.

The LED strip on the back is a neat touch.

The borders are really small, so you get a lot more out of the picture itself.

The backlighting is incredible. Despite how bright it is, it's easily turned down either from your system, or the monitor itself.

CONS
This boi is H E A V Y. If you already have a dual-monitor mount at home, make sure it can support the weight. If it can support over 20lbs, you should be fine. Anything else, it will weight it down immediately. If you have a mount that has a straight pole with the arms that hold your monitors, it'll definitely get weighed down by this beast.

There seems to be a slight buzzing/humming sound coming from the monitor when its on. I usually have headphones on at my desk, but I could imagine that it could be problematic for those with exceptional hearing.

Overall, I don't think that you can find a better value for a monitor. What you get with this vs. what you pay is astounding. I've used Alienware and LG monitors that don't seem as good, or are as good, but with an additional $500 on the price. For anyone looking to game or work in style and on a budget, look no further than Sceptre.

title: Amazing headphones at a decent price! The companion app is great!
text:
I want to prefix my review by just saying, I really like these headphones. They have so much customizations and features that they have become by daily use headphones.

They arrived in a small branded box packed full of stuff. There are multiple sets of ear buds so you can fit them to whatever size you need. The box included a single card "quickguide" and I had them paired and ready to use with my phone instantly.

The headphones themselves are slick looking, and respond to touch, no need to press a button on them. The default setting is to tap left to turn down, tap right to turn up, and double tap either to pause / unpause. I love the settings out of the box, but if you don't then don't worry, you can change them with the app!

Out of the box the sound is pretty decent. But the app is where things shine for customizations. There are multiple pre-build noise reduction filters, and three different types of modes to pick from. I have been using TRANS mode because it allows for ambient noise to pass through into the headphones! This keeps me alert to the sounds around me while I am out and about and I can hold conversations while keeping them in. The other modes help block out noise entirely. So lots to pick from with a bunch of default sub settings to play with.

I liked that it has several listening types for equalization, the only one I found missing was for podcasts / audio books. Luckily you can add your own and I quickly set one up for "books" and saved it. SO NICE!

As for other features of the headphones. The battery is pretty decent, lasting me a full day of use with the charging case. I have noticed that the app tells me that the right ear bud seems to drain faster for some reason. The bluetooth range is okay. I own several other pairs and they seem to have a longer range. There is a loud noise that goes off when you disconnect or reconnect so you will know for sure when you get outside the range. It is worth also knowing that there are two white LEDs that constantly blink on the headphones when using. Some people may not like that.

Overall though these are great headphones for the price point. Some of the best I own in the category I feel and I hope they last me a good long while.

title: UPDATED REVIEW: First one was a dud, replacement is good so far.
text:
SECOND UPDATE: After the first one of these began to fail within a day, I decided to swap it out for another one. Amazon was great about sending the replacement and letting me send the defective item back in. So far the replacement sounds great and I hope that it keeps on working. I still say it’s worth the tube swap (the manual even says it’s fine to swap tubes so don’t sweat that). For now I’ve revised the rating to 3-star until I have the replacement a bit longer. I’ll update this review in time.

UPDATE: I’m less than 24 hours in and this amp is already cutting out on the right channel. Looks like this one is going back.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: Bought this to pair with my Fluance RT-81 turntable. Although the RT-81 has an internal preamp, I found the tone to be pretty flat and lifeless. After doing a bit of research, I decided to give this T3 phono preamp a shot.

Install is simple. Run a two-channel RCA cable from the turntable to the amp and a second two-channel cable from the amp to the main amp/receiver. Keep in mind the preamp doesn’t include any two-channel RCA audio cables so grab those when you order (the product includes a single 3.5mm to RCA cable). Plug in the included tubes, then the audio cable, and you’re in business. The size is minimal, but build quality seems good for the price. The blue LEDs are a nice touch and aren’t so bright that they are distracting.

With the stock generic tubes the sound was an improvement over stock preamp in the RT-81, but I found the midrange was a bit lacking. Fortunately I had ordered a set of GE JAN 5654W tubes from Riverstone Audio (these tubes are likely suggested on this project page). When I installed these tubes, the tone really came alive! The mids and lows are full and the highs are more mellow. If you’re considering this T3 preamp, I strongly encourage you to spend a few bucks more and get the upgraded tubes.

Assuming it holds up over time, this preamp is a win, especially with the GE tube upgrade.

title: Battery Life is Incredible!
text:
I got these for Christmas and I use them all day long. I work in a setting where I have to hear people talk to me and I’m not allowed to wear in ear headphone due to obstruction. So these headphones are a life saver! If you think you’re going to get in-ear quality sound-you’re daft. They’re open ear-bone conduction—-duh! They sound ambient, almost like you’re listening to the radio. Only no one can hear that radio. I wear them for 13 hours a day (continuous) and I’m barely on medium! Think about that. You could go on a two day camping trip with these guys and be fine. Think of all the stuff you do that you can do more of and longer with headphones that don’t die at 4-6 hrs. Apple earbuds die at 4-6 hr mark, my Dre beats die at 6 hrs. But these headphones go strong all day.

My only complaint is better controls. I wish it was a touch sensor or voice commanded, because touching the unit is a little fumbly. I often forget where I need to touch it to lower and increase volume. I’ve found my Apple Watch allows me to change the volume easily, but those without an Apple Watch may have a harder time using the unit. If you push too long, you could shut the whole thing off, when trying to adjust the volume, that’s annoying too. When I wear a mask at work, I get a little pain on the top of my ear, but that’s it. Not bad enough to take them off, just annoying. I love these headphones, they are my new favorite.
