One more thing! Rap and R&b sound sub par on these head phones. The bass also vibrates in the front unit ear pieces and it’s annoying. I love rap and RnB but can’t listen to many songs on these headphones. But that’s okay, listening to indie, rock and roll, and classical are all excellent listening experiences. I just avoid any seriously bassey music when I wear them, most music sounds okay. But that bass man, it will vibrate the ear pieces and tickles lol. Can be come really offensive when you’re trying to forget they’re in your head.

title: Very good sound, good noise cancelling on phone/mic- great for all around use
text:
These headphones are, for me, a great all around solution.

The noise cancelling on the mic is superb. The background noises don't make it to my phone calls, thank goodness. Receiving or making outgoing calls, I can count on them to keep things clear, and I can hear the other side perfectly well- even though one of my ears isn't up to original specs, if you know what I mean.

The connectivity is great, via bluetooth, usb, or the dongle they provide. The dongle is simply a USB bluetooth LE device, adding bluetooth if you need it to connect. I do have one laptop in my stable that doesn't have bluetooth built in- and I'm glad this dongle serves that purpose well.

I tried this headset every way I could think of- and in the process, once I ended in a state where the bluetooth light was on whether I had the headset on OR off, and I couldn't connect. I couldn't see any way to "reset" in the instructions- but gave it my best guess.

Pushing both volume buttons up and down and the pairing button (three buttons) all at the same time reset the headset nicely. I didn't see that in the documentation, but when you've used as many different headsets as I have, it made sense that Nuroum would include a reset feature- and they did, which is consistent with the level of quality I've felt from this set.

Some folk might not like that the earpieces rest against the ear, but I am quite happy with it. It's comfortable, doesn't distract from the sound, and keeps you _just enough_ in touch with your surroundings. When I wear full over the ear muffs, I'm likely not to hear I'm being called from the next room. I've gotten some soreness from full muffs at times- I wore these three hours straight, and they were still cozy enough to forget. That's good by me.

So, easy to use, easy to connect, dongle in case you don't have bluetooth on a PC. Comfortable, great sound, and clear calls both ways. Good for multimedia and music. I couldn't want any more than that. Definitely recommended.

title: Loudest Alarm I’ve Heard Yet - Delivers 100% of Promise
text:
These door/window sensor alarms are a bit different from similar alarms that I’ve purchased in the past…
▪️First, they are black (black makes things disappear against darker backgrounds).
▪️Second, these alarms seem to be much louder than what I’m used to. My ears hurt for awhile after activating the alarm warble - test/install these with ear plugs in.
▪️Third, there are “activated” tones that indicate that a selection has been made: a high-pitched squeak, and the green light flashes. I noticed that it doesn’t always squeak or flash when setting alarm or chime.
▪️Forth, when the description says that the chime sounds twice, that’s what it means… not just “ding, dong” as with other sensors (that’s what I call “sounding twice”), instead it’s “ding, dong, ding, dong” (sounding four times in my book).
▪️Fifth, the chime is equally as loud as the alarm warble. It may be the volume, but the chime is just plain unpleasant - not the nice store chime announcing an incoming shopper. My cat was super displeased with both, screeching every time I set off either sound.
▪️Sixth, these sensors are way more sensitive to misalignment. They seem to be much quicker to sound when the two parts aren’t lined up perfectly. Be absolutely sure of their placement before affixing to a surface - use some painter’s tape to do a dry run.

I’m not thrilled that the battery compartment cover is screwed down… usually those kinds of compartment covers are hard enough to get off just as they are. The small screw, and tiny print in weak white print for setting labels are going to force me to mount these lower on a door or window than I normally would.

Now, will either the alarm warble or the chime alert a homeowner to a “guest”? Very definitely! These sensors deliver 100% of what they promise! One minor thing: The description is inconsistent with the product: It says: “connectivity technology” is “wired”, it is NOT.

title: It my first set of these, won’t be my last
text:
I bought these - or something very much like them - several years ago, and I had to get new ones just because over the years, whatever they were attached to had been thrown away or sold or moved in some way, but these are a fantastic way to both organize your cables, and help keep them hidden where they ordinarily would stick out like a sore thumb.

It’s a large pack, and a couple of the organizers probably don’t have much utility, I think two of them hold like five cables each, all very close together, which, personally, I cannot find a use for, although the singles, doubles, etc., which are more practical, I’ve used several and I’ve got several left, so this pack should set you up for a good long while.

The adhesive is exactly as I remembered it, it comes already stuck to the rubber piece, and you just have to clean the surface you’re about to place it on, peel back some wax paper and stick it on - and these things stay stuck, as long as the surface is dry, you will not have an issue with these falling off, or shifting or drooping.

Yet, they remove very easily, and factoring in how well put they stay, that impresses me. They don’t leave residue on hard surfaces - though watch out using it on light particle board, and what residue they do leave behind on the organizer itself, usually rubbing your thumb back-and-forth a little bit will help peel it right off, and then you could find some other adhesive and use it again if you want.

If you have a lot of cables that either jut out from behind desks, or don’t look that neat plugged in near your living room end table, whatever - there are a ton of uses for these. In this pack, even though a couple are may be impractical, is large enough that, unless you have a whole slew of cables you’re trying to manage, it will last you a good long time.

You might run into some issues when one is designed to fit three cables, and the cables you’re fitting in there are sort of thick, but if you put them in the channels strategically in the correct order, you can pretty much work around that problem.

I would recommend these.

title: Awesome Monitor That Has Worked Well For Years
text:
I'm a huge fan of this monitor! Here are some pros and cons that I have found over the last few years!

pros:
- the stand is sturdy a
- easy setup. not happy that i can't just use a standard power cable but whatever.
- supports vga/hdmi/dvi. looks like you can connect speakers to it too but who the hell is going to do that?
- brightness is easy on your eyes on the default settings. my asus monitor is stupid bright and it hurts my eyes. as an IT guy who stares at a computer screen for 9+ hours a day this is wonderful.
- colors look great and distinctive. i'm not some sort of nerd who is going to talk about whether this adheres to adobe rgb/color accuracy or anything but it looks great. i've played doom and final fantasy on it and it looks fantastic.
- for the price it's reasonable for a 24 inch monitor
- no built-in speakers. nobody wants them and if you are into built-in speakers on monitors YOU ARE DOING IT WRONG.
- vesa mount compatible. you can use it with your monitor mounting systems.
- unboxing is something i pay attention to with monitors as i deal with them often in my line of work. this is a piece of cake to unbox and you dont have to worry about tearing the entire box apart or breaking apart the styrofoam to get the panel out. i could actually see myself saving this box for whenever i move again, it was that easy getting everything out and i don't see it being difficult getting everything back into the box.

cons:
- looks like 144hz is only available via dvi connection. not a big deal for me though, my gtx 970 has a port and this is my primary monitor so whatever.
- this is nitpicky but the power button protrudes a lot and can be a little distracting. if you are the type that struggles finding the power button this could be a pro for you.
- the controls for the settings are not labeled on the front of the monitor---this can make fiddling with the settings confusing. for you power users out there that just HAVE to have the perfect settings at any given time for whatever you are doing this could be a major downside.

title: It's okay.
text:
This is priced annoyingly linear with the product quality, so it's hard value this above or below other competitors. For +$100, you can get a full-NDI magewell. And second-hand could be an even more economical solution. So yeah, just keep it in mind.

Some thoughts.
I was hoping this encoder's lesser NDI HX1/2 encoding bitrate (50Mb/s max) would be acceptable for A-camera transmission, but it's ultimately not, unfortunately. Probably fine for B-camera. For A-camera-quality video encoding, look to full NDI (+100Mb/s), from something like Magewell/Birddog/Haivision.

The image quality from the encoder is ehh. Image quality would change when the thermals raised, so I put a 40mm blower fan on it, and that stabilized it. I stuck with 50Mb/s CBR@1s. VBR was as expected; fine when the image was nearly-static, but then shockingly blocky pixelation upon change. I don't remember what ABR resulted with, but I remember specifically not using it. (sorry) CQP/CRF seemed to add latency and dropped frames right around level 18 when it started looking better, so I avoided it using it. It did look decent though, but with the risk of inconsistent frames.

By the way, if you want inexpensive but high-quality NDI encoding and have tons of space and don't mind a little Frankensteining, you might could just use an old computer with a GPU/fast-CPU paired with a HDMI capture device. I did this in a pinch, and it was surprisingly acceptable. HDMI->Capture device->into OBS->out using NDI. With tweaked settings, you can get under 5fps frame-buffer. Magewell capture devices (about $80) are USB UVC and can capture at about 1.5 frame latency. My Elgato capture devices appear in software as NDI devices, and was ok in latency, like 2-4 frame delay. Maybe a computer can bridge the internal NDI device directly to the LAN network at lower latency? idk, maybe test this idea if you're in this boat.

I still have this device, so I can answer more questions if needed.

title: Pretty cool!
text:
I am _shocked_ how good this thing is.

I have reviewed MINI projectors in the past, and with this one I was expecting to be disappointed, but I am not at all.

But let's be clear, you have to know what you're getting into to set your expectations accordingly.

This is a native 800x480 projector. That means, the maximum number of rows of pixels is 480 and the max number of columns is 800.

When you first boot it, and focus it, the pixels are pretty chunky.

But the nice thing is that the focus works really well. Compared to other cheap projectors, I was able to get a perfect focus on this device. Most of the time, the corners will blur or one side will blur while the other is focused. I was able to clear focus for all the pixels here.

While the resolution is pretty low, when video is in motion it's surprisingly clear. Don't expect some super HD home-theatre experience. This _wont_ be it.

However, for it's limitations, it's surprisingly good.

The other thing I was expecting was to turn off all the lights in my apartment, so I could see it.

But this thing is also shockingly bright!

In the photos I attached to my post, I didn't turn off the lights in my room, and you can see the picture very clearly.

With the lights fully off, this thing is more than serviceable, with great contrast.

LED based mini-projectors have come far since the last time I tried them.

Finally, I also threw some ancient AVI files and more modern MP4s at it and it was able to decode all of them just fine.

OVERALL I am shocked that projector tech has come this far. At the time of writing, this item is ~80 dollars, which is cheap compared to other projectors. This wouldn't make sense for a home theater set up. But maybe for children's room, camping, or just keeping in your bag for use as an impromptu screen.

Oh yea, it's also pretty smal - so easily portable.

title: Good Value In Small Package
text:
Let me start by saying I think this is a very nice little MP3 player. For the price, one gets a lot to like. It has all the bells and whistles that usually require spending much more. Some of those features are overkill, since I can't imagine having the patience to watch videos or scroll through photos on a screen that is even smaller than the one on my cell phone, but, in an emergency, I can see the utility of having those functions available. The FM radio and voice recorder are more useful, but, for me, the important feature is as an MP3 player.

What makes this player a bit different than some others I have seen is that it does not have its own on-board memory. It comes with a MicroSD card onto which one transfers music or other media. The card pops out and can be replaced with a larger MicroSD card if desired. As it happens, I have some music on MicroSD cards which I use in my car and on a Bluetooth speaker. When this player arrived I just switched in one of my cards and they worked perfectly. This is a feature I like, since I can transfer music on my computer to the MicroSD card and then just pop it into this player without messing with any cords, etc. I also find it easier to manipulate the music on my computer, rather than on the little device/screen.

If I have a complaint about this little guy, it is the non-intuitive, quirky interface. I have had a number of MP3 players over the years and sort of know my way around them. Nevertheless, the interface on this one had me flummoxed a bit, and I really had to play around with it to figure out how to do very basic things. About four buttons perform all the functions, but sometimes not the function you expect. The play/pause button, particularly, does a lot more work than one would assume. The power on/off switch is also very tiny and a bit stiff to turn on and off, but even when it is left on, it does not drain the battery too much, if the "off" button on the player is used. All of this having been said, however, once one figures it out, the player works pretty well and has good battery life. At this price point, it would be difficult to find a better MP3 player.

title: So many options in a compact adaptor
text:
Wow! This thing is packed with options. All the common data ports you definitely need on a docking station intended for modern ultrathin notebooks. My wifes' Dell doesn't have an SD-Card port. It doesn't have an Ethernet port. It doesn't have a Display Port . It has only 2 USB-A ports and 1 USB-C port, and 1 HDMI. She runs a 3-monitor setup using multiple video output adaptors. Its a cluttered solution with too many points of failure because of loose connections, which happens enough to be distracting; bump a cord and a monitor disconnects. This docking station covers all those deficiencies. This device is lightweight but solid. The enclosure finish is a very nice, matte micro-textured Space Grey color (it looks Aluminum). I intend to put a grippy cushion tab on the bottom of the device, whichever "side" I decide to use. This is a nice design, with all the ports along the outer edge. So up or down is decided by your cord management situation. The ports are logically, generously spaced, so even the bulkiest HDMI cable will fit next to a Display Port cable On the USB side of the device, all 4 ports are 3/8" apart. I would prefer 1/2" or more. All ports feel tight and secured. The build quality of this adaptor is real quality. The master output USB-C cable has
a tight-braided sleeve that is semi-ridgid, in a good way. It is a generous 19" in length.

Look at the scrolling Product image gallery. The images convey the impressive features in a well-designed format. Every section of the scrolling presentation describes everything you need to know about this Docking Station. Well done Fairikabe Store. I admire the attention to detail this seller commits to. It really reflects a trust in the quality of their products. There really is not much more for me to say about this device that isn't already nicely described on their Amazon product page. I didn't mean to turn this review into a user interface overview. I'm just very impressed by the presentation. Well written. Clean graphic design (my old profession) and it all works very well to sell a product. It sold me. You too?

title: Convenient, but horrible sleep mode issue
text: I bought this along with the M720 mouse to have a wireless combo that would take up less space on my desk and use only one wireless USB dongle. The connectivity works generally fine, and while installing multiple pieces of software just to make a mouse and keyboard work was annoying, I was happy for the first few days of using this combo. The mouse has a more troublesome lag issue overall, as it will just randomly be unresponsive, miss clicks, or jerk around the screen with regular use. While the M780 keyboard does better with normal operation, it apparently has a sleep function that has caused me some serious problems. Specifically, if you don't use the keyboard for a time, it will go to sleep, but there is no obvious signal that this has happened. I haven't noticed a light change on the keyboard, there is no onscreen notification, it just happens after the keyboard is idle for a time. Pressing a couple keys will wake it up, but you have to give it some time to fully reconnect. Again, there is no signal for when this has been achieved. Once the connection is established, it works fine again. However, during this process of waking up, if you don't realize what is happening or you don't give it enough time before you start typing, it will not just ignore all your keypresses, instead the keyboard will let some through, ignore some, and multiply some of your keypresses in an endless loop. For example, a single press of the D key will come out as "DDDDDDDDDDDDDDDD" until overridden. For normal typing, this is a small inconvenience, but if you are using productivity software or using the keyboard do enter shortcut commands, and your keypress is to delete an item or use some other single key shortcut, that will similarly get multiplied. As a result, this has resulted in me accidentally deleting files or seriously messing up settings in programs when I didn't realize the keyboard had fallen asleep. I'm not giving this a full negative review because aside from this sleep issue, the keyboard is fine (I'm less happy with the mouse), but the issue would be less of a problem if there was just some better signal for this sleep mode and for when the keyboard is successfully connected, because there's no way I have found to know until you start typing if it is ready to work. If you're ok dealing with this idiosyncrasy of the keyboard, I can recommend it. Otherwise, look elsewhere.

title: Great controls, okay sound, do not stay in my ears very well.
text:
I've tried a lot of these wireless earbuds including a couple of other SoundPeats. I've generally been very happy with the SoundPeats brand. That said, I didn't really care for these all that much. However, the things that I disliked were mostly about the basic type of earbuds these are.

They don't fit into the ear canal like ordinary earbuds do, rather, they just kind of rest in the outer ear. This makes them very comfortable, but it also means that they aren't as loud as ordinary earbuds, they also don't block outside noises very well and worst of all they tend to fall out on occasion. If I'm just wearing these while sitting on the couch or going for a walk in a quiet location, they are fine. I do hear outside noises though, which may be good depending on the circumstances but in most cases I would prefer not to. They also tended to fall out of my ears when bending over. This makes them not so great for working out or cleaning the toilet.

Bluetooth connection and reconnection was quick and reliable. Range was about the same as other earbuds. Battery life was a little less, so expect about 2.5 to 3 hours.

The control scheme is excellent. Everything that I want to be able to do, including volume control and fast forward and rewind, is available. The touch controls are very sensitive which is mostly good but due to the shape of the bud I wound up adjusting the volume or pausing playback when I was just trying to reset the bud in my ear. One nifty little feature is that when a single bud is removed from the ear, the playback pauses. This is great for when I want to talk to someone briefly.

Playback latency is very good, and I didn't notice any delay on videos or while gaming. There is a dedicated gaming mode which is supposed to reduce the latency, but I didn't notice any change in my testing. During a phone call, I would hear the other side perfectly well and they told me the same.

I only recommend these earbuds if you are looking for something a little more comfortable than ordinary earbuds that you are only planning on using in relatively quiet environments while performing relatively sedentary activities. Otherwise, I would recommend a more traditional style of earbud in the SoundPeats brand.

title: The Search Continues
text:
Okay, yes, I have unusual needs in a keyboard. I write for a living, so my keyboard is important. I prefer keyboards with short travel keys—I hate those trendy mechanical keyboards everyone raves about (there, I said it).

The gold standard for me so far has been the Logitech MX-Keys, which is basically everything I want in a keyboard except one thing: it's wireless only. It comes with a USB cable, but it's only for charging. I like wired keyboards; the wireless kind always run out of battery at the worst possible time, plus I have a USB switch to switch my keyboard and mouse between computers.

If there were an MX Keys that worked in wired mode, I could die happy. As it is, there isn't, so I have been on the search for a new wired keyboard. Macally makes a keyboard that's almost perfect, except there's a design flaw in the spacebar--it dosn't always register if you hit the edge of the spacebar, and I type fast. Missed spaces screw up my rhythm.

This keyboard has a feel almost identical to the Macally. And if it were otherwise as good, I'd give it five stars in a heartbeat.

Alas, while it looks like metal, the body is plastic--and a very soft plastic at that. When I got this keyboard, the body was so soft it bowed slightly in the center. Not a lot—less than a millimeter—but it was quite noticeable. Hitting keys in the middle of the keyboard causes the whole keyboard to bounce up and down.

Other than that, it's great. Bluetooth plus wired, you can pair it to three computers at once (not that I do; I keep it plugged in all the time), and it even comes with a nice silicone keyboard cover.

But the bow in the plastic body shows an inattention to design. I fixed it with several layers of masking tape, as you can see in the second photo, which made it perfectly adequate (and better than the Macally keyboard, since the spacebar is more reliable)...but it's still not perfect. And so the quest continues.

Oh, Logitech, why won't you give us a wired MX Keys? You have everything right there! You're so close to perfect!

title: Works for an LG 43" 4K monitor!
text:
I am using a standing desk convertor on top of my desk and the weight of my monitor (LG 43un700-b) is 38 lbs if you include the weighted base, so that was too much for the motor in the standing desk convertor. You could hear an audible groan as it struggled under the weight and I wanted a bit more room on the surface anyway.

There are a lot of items to research when you're looking for monitor stands on Amazon and after literally two days of hypothesizing the best new set up (monitor arm mounted onto the standing desk convertor? floor stand behind the desk? articulating arm? non-articulating arm?), I decided on this one.

I really didn't "need" any articulation, but this was a good deal and included the feature. To ensure it was safer, I added some metal plates (also sold on Amazon) to reinforce the Ikea desk.

Putting the base and pole together were easy, but I wish there was an easier mounting system (similar to some flat-panel TV mounts) where you mount the VESA plate first, then hook it onto the arm, then secure it with bolts.

In the end, I used the standing desk to help support the monitor at the proper height while fighting with the VESA mount. This monitor has a 200x200mm mount but requires spacers since the plate won't fit entirely into the "cavity" that's at the back of the monitor. If you look closely at this specific monitor, you'll see some plastic ridges that help keep their original mount in place and they interfere with this plate. No big deal, but I will note that one of the spacers snapped, so I will be replacing that.

Regardless, the monitor is holding steady and I've checked the bolts underneath for the first few days/week after mounting it. There doesn't seem to be any give or wobble.

Now, I've got my desk space back and it's mounted just a big higher than it was sitting before. That way it's about the right height whether I'm sitting or standing.

Overall this is a 4.5 out of 5 for the great value, sturdy arm, but the installation/mounting could be easier. Especially for someone trying to mount a monitor larger than 32" by themselves!

title: Quality, well built lamp that gets the job done.
text:
TLDR;
- Great product that does what it says it will.
- Well built, feels heavy and premium.
- Causes some glare on glossy objects on my desk.
- Buy it now before the price increases if you're shopping for one of these lamps.

This light bar does the job; one of those things you didn't know you needed until you got it. It cost $40 instead of $200. The build quality is excellent. The lamp is aluminum with touch controls and a light sensor. The mount is a sturdy plastic. The unit feels solid and well-built, heavy even.

The controls and light sensor mean I don't need a hockey puck or awkward cable controls on my desk. I'm grateful for that because I dislike the clutter of those options. My webcam mounts on top of the lamp in the center. So, there was no problem there.

The only downsides I have encountered are slight flickering and a few glares. The lamp will sometimes flicker while I'm at my desk. It's slight but annoying. The flicker is subtle. I thought my eyes were playing tricks on me at first. Not a deal breaker at all, of course.

As for the glare, well, there's not much of a glare on the screen (Asus ProArt 32). It's very slight but noticeable. Again, not a deal breaker. If anything, it showed me I needed to dust my screen off. The glare on my iPad screen while I draw or on books with glossy pages is real and causes me to reposition them.

There are no shadows from my head or hand as there would be with my overhead light or a desk lamp. But the light source is so close and bright, even on lower settings, to glare on glossy things. This is alright, of course. It doesn't get in the way of reading, and the iPad screen gets brighter, but it's something to know. You'll be fine if you use regular paper, a moleskin, or something. If you don't use paper or books in your day-to-day work, this lamp will cause no problems.

In conclusion, I'd rebuy it. It's a solid lamp and does what it says. It's worth the $40. Get it now before the price goes up.

title: QUIT SEARCHING NOW! THIS IS THE ONE!
text:
100% sincere review.
If you're anything like me, buying a cheap smartwatch is difficult.
You have a lot of options, but you don't want to buy a subpar watch. I seek affordable rates and high quality. Then It's done!
Every time I purchase something from Amazon, I'm let down because I didn't truly know what I was getting until I receive it in the mail. Images of sellers are not particularly useful because some sellers slant their watches, making it impossible to determine whether they are good watches. I bought a watch few years back, it was fantastic in the images, but when it actually arrived, I was shocked. It was enormous and like a redneck's circular cigarette box. The battery only lasts him a day, and there aren't many features. I now take great care while purchasing a new smartwatch.

I bought another just before buying this one. I made the decision to return it and purchase this watch instead because this smartwatch costs the same and has much more functions. Let me just say that this watch totally blew me away. This watch is extremely fantastic. For health concerns, I was looking for a specific feature. The one I gave back had a heart rate monitor, but my mind was elsewhere. I noticed this watch at that time. It costs the same and has practically all the features you require. Check your blood pressure, blood oxygen level, and heart rate. All three characteristics can be easily found in a single watch, but they will cost double or treble the price. Add to that all the other features this provides. The cost is unbeatable!
The screen looks great, the response time is excellent, and the battery life is as stated. This watch isn't as big and bulky as most. (Duration may vary according on usage.) It includes every amenity needed for an active lifestyle. Also included is a sleep monitor! I urge you to test out this watch. As I read some of the evaluations of several smartwatches, I notice that several customers have expressed dissatisfaction with other watch's build quality and the functionality of certain watch’s capabilities, but I can promise you that it is not. All the features of this smartwatch function flawlessly with my high-end IPhone . So, if you want an excellent smartwatch but have a tight budget, start with this one. With such a low cost, what do you have to lose?

title: BEWARE OF FANS
text:
I installed this on an old overclocked p8z77-v pro with a i5 2500k. The 2500k is overclocked at 4.5ghz. After install I booted and received a CPU FAN error. I went into setup and noticed the this fan was running below the minimum 600rpm threshold. I adjusted the rpm threshold down to 400rpm. This allowed me to boot into windows. I decided to run PRIME95 to test my overclock and see what the temps would look like. The cpu temp went north of 80c in a matter of minutes. My computer began to act erratic before the system eventually crashed. Booted back up the system to be met by cpu fan error again. I went back into the bios setup to see what was going on. The fans were showing 0rpm. I went through a host of configurations with the fans using the provided fan splitter, no splitter, one fan, both fans, every possible combination. Some times I could boot to windows but, was met with and unstable system/crash every time.. Sometimes I was met with the CPU fan error message. I finally put one of my old fans on the cooler and plugged directly into the CPU fan connector on the MB. Booted up into windows and started Prime95. Every thing now runs as it should. However. if I plug either of the provided fans into the CPU connector I end up with a CPU FAN error or an unstable system that crashed. The fans appear to randomly stop working resulting in high temps or they fans just stop reporting to the system causing the system to freak out and then crash.

With my fans on the cooler the cooler performs well keeping my temps at of below the 70c threshold. With my previous cooler the CPU temps would hit 80 plus degrees with the fans at 100% With the provided fans my system is unstable and will not function. Bad sensors? Bad wiring? Bad connectors? Well, it really doesn't matter. The fact remain the same. The fans are trash and could lead to a major system malfunction with serious potential for cpu or motherboard damage!

I would not buy this again based on the potential for serious damage. However, if you have a couple of fans lying around that you can install or are okay buying a couple of good fans the cooler its' self performs well. Aside from the janky paper clip style mounting brackets the cooler seems to be of good quality.

title: Nice light for numerous occasions
text:
The JIGA RGB Video Conference Light is a compact light with a “cold shoe” 1/4” style thumb screw driven part used to tighten against more of the same model, comparable cold shoe interfaces such as DSLR cameras, camcorders, light stands, and other similar equipment. This is a simple light that can be used for accent lighting in videos, video conferencing, fill lighting or lighting for closeups. It also includes a handy clip that can be attached to items such as a phone or laptop.

The camera provides 0-359 (360 in total) degrees in color adjustment between Red, Green, Blue, and everything in between. There also is color temperature of 2500-9000 Kelvin with CCT mode. Finally there is a set of 20 different preset lighting effects from what mimics an emergency vehicle light to a camera flash to a candle. All of these can be “dimmed” on a 0-100 scale for brightness allowing the user to “dial in” what exactly they’re looking for. You will see in a few of the photos and one of the videos the various colors this device can produce.

There also is a moderately powerful magnet inside of the device, so make sure to watch out for items sensitive to magnets, as well stacking them against each other and possibly decreasing the power of the magnet.

Included with this model is a 2000mAh battery that can be charged with an USB-C cable and with the testing I’ve had so far, I’ve been impressed with its reasonable power consumption. With maximum power I’ve found it lasts around 2 hours and low power (brightness) as much as 14 hours.

I’m unable independently confirm the claim of 95+ CRI as I do not have a spectrophotometer.

I have noticed some other reviews reference cost in their review, I feel it’s important to stay cost neutral in my review and simply review the item itself. I feel this product is accurately described both here and on the item page. I believe the product has been constructed properly and meets/exceeds specifications.

If you found the part or all of my review was helpful, please press the helpful button below so I may know I’m helping.

title: Huge, great for outside, but some reservations
text:
I am having a difficult time rating this one. When I started to write it up I was somewhat negative. And that's because while writing this review, I reread the instruction sheet and noticed for the first time the mention of a YouTube channel. I found the video - LEABIOLT Direct and It changed my mind - somewhat.
My wife and I had a hard time assembling the frame by following the enclosed instruction sheet. We got so frustrated we broke for lunch and then finished assembly. Then I discovered the video and watched and listened carefully comparing what he did with what we did. And just after he slipped the rods into the pockets on the screen fabric edges, he changed the sequence of steps, pointing out that his sequence of connecting the corners was "a lot easier." That was quite an understatement.
We had one other difficulty. Two parts which should have been identical had a slight difference. The vertical sections on the two lower legs (#5) were not equal in length - one is too short and the 'bullet catch' was off by about a quarter inch. As a result it wouldn't catch on the 'stub' tube of its #4 mate. This results in the feet being free to rotate making the screen unstable. Not a giant killer, but it is a technical foul.
Projected image is fine if you are in a dark environment and have an appropriate projector. Later this year I may take it to my brother's backyard. He has a deck, and I will try mounting it on a bench with the stub legs lashed to the railing. The guests will be scattered around the lawn. I will see if it works well with rear-projection.
PRO: It is large. Yet fits in the provided duffle bag. I will guess that by using the YouTube sequence to assemble with practice it might take 20 minutes to assemble. The elastic on the rod pockets will remove any wrinkles in the fabric. It can be used outside.
CON: Instruction sheet was lacking or out-of date. It appears that there was an inconsistency on one part with resultant foot alignment problem. Assembly/disassembly may take more time than I'm willing to invest for casual usage. BTW - The video did not include taking it apart. That's another story. I may want to keep Dad's 1960's era movie screen after all.

title: Works exactly as described and doesn't consume too much power
text:
Using for the following configuration:
- MacBook Pro 2017 13in
- LG 4K60Hz display 27UP600 27in

My primary purpose was to drive the display with 4K 60Hz. This works very well. I'm using a usb-to-DisplayPort cable (my display accepts DisplayPort and HDMI)

My Mac is usually in clamshell mode and receiving power from the Thunderbolt Hub.

No problems with waking up the MacBook using my bluetooth keyboard or trackpad.

The TB4 Hub works well with various USB devices.
I haven't tested its speed with Thunderbolt devices e.g. an external SSD drive w thunderbolt interface. Mainly cause I don't have any such devices and they are really expensive!

I used an AC power meter to compare power consumption in these 3 cases:
1. using the TB4 Hub's power brick sending power to the laptop thru the Hub;
2. Using Apple's 60W power adapter direct to the laptop's Thunderbolt/USB-C port.
The difference is about 5W more or less with the TB4 Hub way consuming more. So the Hub itself really doesn't consume that much power.
3. An Anker USB-C w HDMI hub that I have consumes about 3W more then direct Apple AC Adapter
So the TB4 hub doesn't consume much more in this simple scenario.

Go for ThunderBolt 4 mainly because:
a. it doesn't seem to have the wake up the Mac problem that's sometimes reported with ThunderBolt 3 Hubs
b. it's more future proof and doesn't cost much more

Note: Thunderbolt accessories are really expensive mainly cause the bandwidth is very high at 40Gbps. USB-C accessories work fine with this TB4 hub. You can even attach a USB-C Hub to one of the TB4 ports as and when needed e.g. for SD card reader etc.

I needed to go this route because my laptop only supports DisplayPort 1.2. There are many cheaper USB-C hubs that can do 4K60Hz too. But they assume you have a DisplayPort 1.4 capable laptop. Otherwise it gets limited to 4K30Hz.

title: Outdated software, no means to change animations and lacks options.
text:
I don’t love it. This seems overpriced for what you get. For the price, I was expecting it to look more like a photo frame but instead, it kinda feels like an old monitor. My goal was to hang it on the wall during art shows with process videos playing. It will work OK for that but I’m disappointed that unless the video is in the exact proportion of the frame, it will always look a little “off” and there’s no means of changing how it’s framed in the display.

I think it’s at its best without the clock or any other additions.

The pros: It really does work right out of the box. It only took minutes to get photos onto it. The big screen is nice, I can see details in my photos. It is also bright with vivid colors. I like that it is flat which is why it performs better than an average monitor as a picture frame. The simple black frame doesn’t detract from its appearance. I like that there is an app and my husband and I were able to add photos, and I also like that there is a way to add photos via card in case software changes make the app obsolete. With the app, I was able to get videos onto it in minutes. I also like that it has a large amount of storage space and the means to expand it..

The cons: It is slow. I didn’t love the way the photos are displayed. I also hate the default animations because they are a bit cheesy. I want it to fade or some other non-intrusive way to change photos, and there is no means to edit it. The features are incredibly barebones. I hate that the default includes the time etc, I just want it to look like a photo frame! The audio is a bit tinny, much more so than a television etc. I also find it bizarre in 2023 to have an item that warns that it can destroy a USB if it’s removed without turning it off first…that seems like such an old-school problem!

I wish the plug was white because the black looks bad against the wall, and I prefer a minimalist look.

For the price, I feel like this could be better. There are just so few options for customizing the display.

title: Mid-size backpack/travel bag that’s flight approved, water resistant, and built to last!
text:
[[VIDEOID:a32d675762d7bc5a3cbe3bb551b6fc19]] This mid-size bag packs a lot features in a compact size. The material has a subtle, rubberized look and feel to it, which is probably why it’s described as being water-resistant.

The front, back, and shoulder straps are well-padded for protection and comfort. All the zippers in this backpack have a protective seal to prevent water entry.

Designed for work, school/college, or light travel, the bag has three main sections. Here are several features I really like:
• The rear, dual-zip section opens on three sides for full access. There’s a padded divider with a Velcro-close flap. This flap has an open slip pocket you could use for USB sticks or earpods. There’s also a large slip pocket for files and folders.
• The middle section has dual-zippers and is expandable to 4” deep. It’s ideal for packing clothing, shoes, and outerwear. Inside, there’s a netted zip-close flap that secures your belongings and a side zipper pocket for small-ish items. There’s also a USB port/cord in this section.
• The front, dual-zip section has an open pocket on one side, and five open and one zip pocket on the other. There’s also a detachable key ring.

I also like the horizontal zipper pocket located on the front of the pack – for those items I need quick access to, like credit cards, ID, cash, etc.

The back is made of a ventilated mesh material. There’s a horizontal strap to slip the pack over an extended luggage handle for travel. There’s also a zippered pocket on one of the shoulder straps. It’s pretty small, but it’s a good place to stash quick cash, lip balm, or other small items.

Overall, I like the flexibility and design of the bag. It's not only great-looking, it’s flight approved, water resistant, compact, and is built to last. I’m looking forward to road-testing it on my next business trip.

title: Wow!  High quality earbuds at a great price!!
text:
This might be the very best value in earbuds that I have come across (and I own AirPods). I bought these for use at the gym. I was looking for a high quality, sturdy, and easy to use earbuds for the gym. This fits the bill and then some. Here is what I love about these wireless earbuds:

- sound is excellent, on par with the more expensive earbuds, but at a much lower affordable price. I am a music junkie that uses earbuds on a daily basis, at work, at the gem, etc, so sound is most important to me. This makes the grade and will not disappoint, from low range, mid-range, all the way up to live concert level!

- battery life might be the best characteristic of this model. With volume at mid-range, these airbus’s will last a long time. I am in the gym for 2.5 to 3 hours per session. So far, I have not had to recharge after using these for 2 plus sessions. I will not be surprised if it lasts through my third session this week. You will definitely be pleased with not only the long charge life, but it provides great options for recharging them, through your phone, wirelessly (which I love via the case that comes with it), or just through the charged case itself. Love this flexibility.

- the fit is very secure, yet comfortable, on the ear. My sessions at the gym include cardio (treadmill, elliptical, bike, arc trainer), weightlifting, as well as outdoor running. No issues doing it all. Perfect for these activities.

- the range on these earbuds is superb. You can walk away from your phone or mp3 player and not lose connection or get connection static feedback. When connected to my iPhone, I walk approximately 100 feet away and it had zero impact on sound quality.

What I dislike:

Nothing yet. For the money, you can’t get a better pair of earbuds as far as I am concerned (and I’ve gone through various models at different price ranges. This is a “can’t miss”.

title: Wow! Just, wow!
text:
What Amazon's product page says:

Every Moment Counts: Sharing life moments with loved ones is always a delightful thing to do. NexFoto smart Wi-Fi (Only 2.4 Ghz network is supported) frames make whole experience much easier and more fun than ever before. Place it at your own place or gift it to families & friends as a sweet spot at home displaying all happy and cherished moments.

Add-On Smart Features: For energy-saving, built-in motion sensor will detect movements and automatically turn off the frame when no one is around; a timer can be setup to keep frame on during desired period of a day. There are even more useful functions available in this smart versatile frame, including weather, music, calendar, clock and alarm.

The Most Wished Gift: WiFi electronic picture frames come with beautiful gift-ready box and are perfect gift ideas for Mother’s Day, Father’s Day and Christmas. For special occasions like anniversary, wedding, graduation and birthday, it would be such a meaningful gift to keep all shared memories come alive and stay close to your loved ones. Sleek modern design also makes it great as decoration for every home.
Splendid Image Quality: Featured with 1280 x 800 HD screen (aspect ratio 16:10), Digital photo frame present images in stunning details and superb quality. IPS display technology brings outstanding color accuracy with much wider viewing angles. Multi-touch screen makes it pretty easy to navigate and user-friendly.

Premium Quality & Life-Time Service: NexFoto is committed to present top-notch digital frames with premium quality in the industry. We offer one-year unlimited warranty and life-time customer service to make sure every customer is happy with the purchase.

What I say:

I got this item for my own home. It is under three pounds so it can be mounted on a wall, but I have mine sitting on a shelf so it is easily seen. Sort of the focal point of the living room. Mine is the 10 inch size.

Can you it with wifi (that is what I use) and uploads are easy. Simple directions come with it.

I have not had it long and I intend to come back and tell more of what I like or do not like in the near future.

title: Won't use it.
text:
I was using this case on my Galaxy Tab S8+.

I'll get straight to the point:

1. It's almost impossible to separate the two pieces (top/bottom covers). You have to pry them apart with your finger nails. (hopefully you don't rip out your fingernail). - you have been warned.

2. The top cover fits around your tablet, but it is very tight. I was afraid that I would scratch the sides of the tablet. There is no soft liner on the inside of that top cover.

3. Once your tablet is inside that top cover, the next journey is to insert that top half inside the bottom half cover. This was a huge struggle because it is such a tight fit. I had to push/stretch out the side edges of the bottom half so that the top half would fit more easily into the bottom half.

4. There is no hole in the protective screen cover for the fingerprint reader. It now takes me four-five attempts for my tablet to read my fingerprint.

5. In portrait mode, the case will fall over if you tap/bump either of the top corners. - wow!!.

6. Taking apart this case (while the tablet is installed) is another journey, - very difficult.

7. The kickstand compartment (~3x4 inches) extends too high inside the bottom cover. Thus, your tablet sits on top of that small area. The remainder of your tablet surfaces does not sit on anything. (air gap).

On the positive side:

1. Very sturdy case.
2. Screen cover will protect your tablet screen from scratches.
3. Finger swiping seems to work ok. - I did not even bother to test with the S-Pen.
4. No magnets on the kickstand. This is good because kickstand magnets are known to interfere with the tablet electronics.

Overall, I spent way too much time/effort just getting my S8+ tablet installed in this case. In the end, I decided to not use this case anymore.

title: Longtime User
text:
I've been using these almost every day for over a year now. I've had good experiences and bad experiences with them.

One bad experience is that the entire plastic circle on the outer part of the right earphone switches modes if you press it. That seems like it would be a good thing, but in reality, when I use these while lying down I am constantly hitting that button by accident if I move my head or roll onto my side. Ironically, I find that if I am trying to press that big button using my hand, the button almost never works. Another irony is that I never use the other two modes (normal and transparency) so it would be better for me if that button didn't even exist.

The second bad experience is that when the headphones are not connected to anything by bluetooth they turn themselves off after an hour. I often wear them just for the noise cancelling in loud spaces, without listening to music or anything. I find this very annoying.

The third bad experience is that they have never worked for making or receiving calls. I have to scramble to turn off bluetooth when someone calls me so I can use my phone's built-in microphone and speaker.

The fourth bad experience is that the five buttons around the rims of the earphones all feel the same when I touch them. When the headphones were new to me I constantly struggled to push the right button, especially the power button. Even now, after using them for over a year, I still feel unsure and I have to run my thumb along the rim of the earphone, feeling for the rectangular hole of the usb input. The on/off button is the one closest to that hole.

One good experience is that the battery seems to last a long time, especially if I'm not listening to music or anything. The battery also seems to charge quickly.

A second good experience is that when I am listening to music or an audiobook or whatever, I really like the quality of the sound. I find it clear, loud enough, and balanced between bass and treble.

A third good experience is that I feel like the price equals the benefits I get from the headphones.

Overall, I'm not unhappy with them but I probably wouldn't buy them again if I could find something better for around the same price.

title: Very good consumer level security camera
text:
I own two of these and use them with Blue Iris. The software integration is simple and has been very reliable. Streaming rate is adequate for 15 fps on both main and sub stream. Image quality is excellent during the day, and seems to be very good during the night, but that is deceptive: the clear static picture you see is achieved at the expense of massive smoothing of the pixelated image. This becomes apparent whenever anyone walks through the field of view at night, all you see is a "comet" with a blob for the face and a blurry tail. I tried to experiment with the amount of 3D and 2D smoothing that the web interface provides, but to achieve realistic motion capture in the dark I had to sacrifice image quality so much that the pixelation and digital noise made the image unusable anyway. Long exposure mode showed promise but I had to extend the exposure to the point of reaching the frame rate, and also had trouble having the camera switch between night and day mode. That resulted in the long exposure mode extending into daylight, saturating the sensor and whiting out the image. The IR illumination only seems to blur the image instead of making it better, so I turned it off. Note that the camera is not even in a particularly dark area, there are 4 garage night lights lighting up the driveway that it is looking at. So that is a little disappointing. But that said, my other brand of consumer camera that starts with R performs more or less the same in the dark, and much worse in all other aspects with Blue Iris, so I will not complain. But take the "starlight" label on the box with a grain of salt. You probably need a $700 camera for that to be true.
The second one I have looks at an area under a street light. That one is doing better at night, which makes me think that the IR from the street lamp helps it a lot (the garage lights are LED, so they probably are lacking in the IR range). So if you stick with these cameras, you may want to add a dedicated IR illuminator over the area it is looking at.
During daylight this camera is great. The mic works fine.
I wish it had field curvature correction in the firmware as the FOV is very distorted on the edges due to the wide angle. Alas, you don't get that at this price point.
Overall I like these cameras and recommend them to people using Blue Iris.

title: Recycle old laptops
text:
Can I have a moment of silence for my dearly departed technology?

Like many people, I had a stack of old laptops collecting dust in my closet -- did you know old batteries can explode? Mine didn't thankfully but someone recently warned me they could so I bit the bullet and decided to rip what I could off of my tech graveyard and send them to laptop heaven. Unfortunately two of my four dead laptops are dead dead and haven't worked in years. Enter this thing.

I consider myself moderately tech literate so I wasn't too worried about being able to figure this out. The product listing has a guide if you get stuck but it's pretty intuitive. Remember if the device you are using to copy the drive to another drive has only USB-C you will need an adapter, this thingy has just a regular USB A (the flat rectangular one) connection.

My 2011 MacBook Pro ripped beautifully, that was the one I thought would give me trouble but ended up being the easiest (thankfully by some miracle I remembered my password which I needed to unlock the volume). As did my 2010 Windows 7 laptop. For some reason my 2009 netbook (remember those??) did not spin up correctly when connected to this doohickey, luckily that one still worked so I was able to transfer files directly by booting it up. All of them utilized the same kind of connection -- power to the drive and then a wide connector to a cord that goes directly into the working device you'll use to copy files over.

I had no problem using this device to copy files from my old laptops to an external drive using both my Chromebook and MacBook Air, the product connected to both just fine. It is no different than connecting a regular external drive as far as file management.

Other reviewers suggested this product literally arrives on a slow boat from China, I did not have that issue, it took a few days more than Prime though as it came straight from the vendor via USPS. And yes, it does look janky. But it does the job!

I can't say how this set would handle a large number of laptops but it worked just fine on my small one. Except the netbook of course but that thing was always a mess, I don't fault the device for that. I give it an A.

RIP laptops and thank you for your service

title: Out-Performs The Ubiquiti UAP-IW-HD-US For Much Less
text:
I don't have any .ax clients yet and I mounted both the UAP-IW-HD-US and 615 APs on the same wall box with the same network. The TP Link is 50 to 100Mbps faster to my Wifi 5 clients and has better antenna coverage to my far clients in a dense wifi area.

I almost bought a second UAP-IW-HD-US until I started reading around and saw the 615 is like half the cost, so I bought two. I wound up installing both 615's but it's probably overkill in my case. One 615 was connecting fine to clients that the UAP-IW-HD-US could not. The UAP-IW-HD-US's antenna coverage doesn't seem to be very good at the edges. I wonder if the metal trim on the cover has a negative impact. A lot of people like the Ubiquiti console but there isn't a compact low cost stand alone console like the Omada system offers. I haven't tried Omada cloud yet, but it looks more straight forward. I don't need Omada Cloud or controller yet as the standalone mode with the app and logging into the AP's IP works perfectly for me. I set one to 5G and the other to 2.4G.

If I ever need a new wired router I will try the Omada model and the controller unless the cloud is free. Currently, I use an Ubiquiti ER-X 5 port router with the HW routing enabled and it's a great little router. After that I connect the TP-Link TL-SG2008P for my cat5 outlets and to power the 615's. I just pulled 390Mbps over the air to my 2015 MacBook Pro.

The next .ax version of the Ubiquiti should be faster, but until then there are better options, and even then the price premium for Ubiquiti doesn't seem worth it unless you need that ecosystem. The 615 is fast and great for a home application like mine - love having no router around the house taking up space.

Before this upgrade I had a Nest Wifi and it was fine. The Nest wound up devolving to a state where it would be so slow and it wouldn't recover without a power cycle or for many hours. I'm pretty amazed how much faster the TP link 615's are.

title: LOVE IT
text:
I was reding a lot of reviews about some radio, and someone put 1 or 2 stars , because there was no reception or any signal for SW. or MW. especially if there are in urban area.
ANTENNA, ANTENNA ,ANTENNA , I can buy the most sophisticated expensive high tec. radios in the world , but without proper antenna, I will get nothing in SW.just insulated speaker wire with alligator clip ,attached to the radio antenna , I was able to get a lot of stations , with clear voice and static free.
for TECSUN R9012 Radio is portable multiband radio receiver,
and TECSUN R9700DX 12-Band Dual Conversion AM/FM Shortwave Radio , I love it.

I am a TECSUN fan for long time, For the size of it and the price, well done. Compare it to my old National Panasonic and Toshiba analog radios from the 90’s MW local tuning outdoor is nice and most of the channels very clear FM inside my warehouse with metal roof and statics and electrical equipment still working perfect Without extending the antenna, so far so good very compact and portable .Now let us get the real challenge.
SW well so far by 1 pm afternoon with sunny day in south Florida , still sound very good outdoor with
extended antenna still working, I WAS ABLE TO PICK UP A LOT OF CHANNELS:
SW8 - 19 m BAND
SW7 - 22 m BAND SPANISH RADIO FROM SOUTH AMERICA
SW6 - 25 m BAND USA BORADCATING FROM NORTH AMERICA.
This is the best band to hear daytime, for evening and night, best is with the lower frequencies
31 m 41 m and 49m
Now the real test is with my broom stick homemade ¼ wave and ½ wave antenna , evening or sunset. There is no external antenna input with R9012 radio.so my best choice is with alligator clip attached to the antenna. It’s working very well.
R9700DX has external antenna input , so I used my SANGEAN ANT 60 portable antenna, I picked stations from Africa and south America in Arabic ,English, and Spanish , voice of China ,Radio Romania, I am very happy with it.

title: This is the Koss set you're looking for.
text:
The KPH30i is darn near the perfect set of koss on ear headphones. I own/have owned the KPH30i, KSC75, KHP40, and Porta Pro's. The only two I kept/still own are the KPH30i's and the KSC75's.

The Porta Pros are far too muddy and bassy. Instant return.

The KPH40 are a little better as far as clarity goes, but still way too much bass that overpowers the mids and highs. If you like actual music, these are not enjoyable. Probably the most comfortable set, but a disappointment soundwise so they too we're returned.

The KSC75 are the brightest of the bunch, but still not over the top shrill or anything. Mids are nice and present which help guitars cut through the mix if you're into heavy rock/metal/etc. I go back and forth between the KSC75 with the parts express headband and ear clips. Both sound great and are useful depending on your wearing needs. Ultimately I think I like the KSC75's more with the stock pads than the Yaxi pads. The Yaxi pads + the Parts Express headband are S tier comfort, but the Yaxi's smooth out the treble a bit much and it kind of takes away from the character of what makes the KSC75's enjoyable.

The KPH30i is just right with the balance of bass, mids, and treble. (If they were just a bit brighter they'd be perfect. (If you EQ, you can always add it in). Great sound stage, again bass is just right, not overpowering like the others, mids sit very well and make everything just sound cohesive.

Now the cons of the KPH30i. They are the least comfortable of the bunch unfortunately. The headband really doesn't have great swivel movement where the drivers attach. The pads are a bit scratchy/rough and unfortunately not easily swapped without popping drivers off/risking damage. The head band quality itself as many others have stated leaves a lot to be desired. Fairly weak plastic just waiting to snap.

So honestly just buy the KPH30i's, they're the best sounding and the value is there. That's all, have a good day.

title: Huge, Overpriced, Buggy Albatross. Sent it back.
text: If you want a portable device to take with you anywhere and listen to your favorite music anywhere, in the highest quality, DON'T BUY THIS. It is huge. It is as long as a cell phone and as thick as an old skool cassette walkman. You can't throw it in your pants pockets along with your wallet and cell phone. It's TOO BIG! On top of that, for $400, you get a player that skips every time it changes tracks - skips at the very beginning of each track, and sometimes just randomly skips, as well. The sound quality is not even anything to write home about. It has very weak bass. I am using Beyerdynamic Dt  770 pros in 32 0hms  and the bass is very weak. I also have to turn any headphones I use with it up really loud for them to be loud enough, and none of them are high impedance headphones. I can use the same headphones on Fiio's M3K player (originally a $50 player, but discontinued now) and get great bass and volume. That's ridiculous.  This is unacceptable performance for a $400 device. I sent it back. If you want the most portable player ever, with great sound, for a great price, try Shanling's M0 Pro. I sent the M11s back and ordered the M0 pro instead. It's only $120, sounds great, is TINY for ultimate portability, and accepts up to a 2TB sd card. It has more bass than either the M3K or the M11s, and a nice, balanced sound overall. It's like a high fidelity Sansa Clip. Awesome. I wish I'd have seen it first, and I wish they would make it clear in the pics for the M11s how big it is. I wouldn't have ordered it. I considered keeping the device as just a home player and not using it for portable use, but the skipping and generally unimpressive audio performance made it not even worth keeping for that. I don't feel like anything about it is worth $400 besides that it is big and has a huge screen, but to me that's not a good thing, and nothing I need for listening to music. Unless Fiio starts making smaller/better quality players like the M3K again, I will not purchase any more of their products. I don't want a big brick for an audio player.

title: Dumbest "Smart" TV on the market will absolutely frustrate you, I guarantee it!
text:
This TV is terrible. Every time I turn it on, I have to navigate to whatever is plugged into the dumb thing or try waiting 30seconds to a minute for it to finally detect that something is actually connected to it and fullscreen that device. This doesn't sound too bad but it will start playing it's bloatware/ads at me while entirely ignoring the device that I have connected. Sometimes it even starts playing god awful lifetime movies it calls "samsung exclusives" instead of doing what I want it to do. For the love of god, please just connect to my PC.
My previous TV was SO much better even though it was a: 1080p, 60hz refresh rate, not "smart", Samsung tv. The picture quality is so washed out and dark compared to my old tv, I considered just going back to the lower definition and refresh rate.
This thing is a $2000 piece of garbage that I'm not willing to pay to ship back; plus I'm too afraid to even touch the thing because a stiff gust of wind could break it in two. It is thinner than my smart phone which probably sounds really cool! Let me remind you, that means there is no protection on the glass. I would warn against having any pets or children near it. It is quite literally a giant sheet of glass with delicate electronic parts peppered throughout. The smallest bump could send a crack across the whole television screen ruining an incredibly overpriced hunk of junk. Not to mention, the base on the stupid tv is so small it could easily be tipped over and shattered into a million pieces.
I had to be VERY careful taking it out of the box and setting it on its base because I live alone. The instructions say a two person carry is needed, holding the glass at specific points in order to not utterly destroy the flimsy tv. Instead of calling a friend/family member to waste 30 seconds of their life helping me, I decided to risk taking it out of the box myself. Everything went fine despite me holding my breath and nearly having a heart attack the two times I handled it. Me admitting this here probably voids some stupid warranty on it. Oh well. If at some point it stops working for me, I will just buy a cheaper version that isn't "smart", from a different brand and likely be happier with that other tv. I promise you will be happier buying another brand tv or at least not wasting the extra money on this specific tv.

title: Noob with BlueTooth Earbuds somewhat impressed with these EARBEANS!
text:
I have literally bought 5+ pair of Sennheiser MX-680 over the years, because they sound great, and work for my purposes with same situation Sansa Clip+ MP3 players (way more than 5+) for about 12 years. Both of those devices are rare now, and I am facing the fact that it's time to get into the modern era. I download about 25 podcasts on Sunday to listen to while I toil at my job all week. I have tested and returned several devices in the last month or so, but I have held on to these earbeans. If you have seen or own a set, you know why I refer to them as earbeans. They sound and/or fit better than 3 other wireless sets that I have tried. More consistent bluetooth connections with several devices, and may even sound better than the wired Sennheisers on my gaming laptop... They tend to work their way out of my ears gradually requiring me to push them back in a little after a couple hours, but it beats the alternative of having my ears clogged with silicone ear tips which I don't care for. Weirdest thing I have to complain about is that when I go outdoors, the bluetooth connection gets real flukey. I don't understand it, but when I am indoors or in a car, it's perfect. When I step outside, it's in and out (same with Raycons which I tested at the same time)... Finally, when paired with my Galaxy S8 (yes I am old and don't buy a new phone every year or less), I can't seem to get them loud enough, but I think that's the nanny nature of the phone not wanting to damage one's hearing and not so much the earbeans because they will go much louder on the PC... Take it from someone who will reject anything of questionable quality, these are good. Raycon on the other hand (at $55 more) - going back.

Edit 04/14/2023: The inconsistent BlueTooth performance outdoors was not related to the earbeans, but the player I was using at the time. BlueTooth performance is great with my older Samsung phone (S8) which is holstered behind my right hip. I do have to push them down a few times per day for maximum performance, but that's a small price to pay for the sound quality that these provide. Was a 4 star review now 5 for my experience.

title: Pro Perspective... WEAK compared to other FF motors and non-existent customer service
text:
Quick Summary - Good reliable wireless range And feature rich. However, pulls can be jerky... read on for more.

First of all, the instructions are terrible and you are basically left to figure out how to do everything yourself. Since SmallRig is expanding to everything video, you can make a safe assumption that they may just be overextending themselves a bit. Customer service is non-existent! I have emailed them and I either don't hear back or they don't know the answer. I have to continue the conversation which gets responses days later. This is what happens when you got somebody there that has to have the answers for everything and they simply don't because SmallRig hasn't offered this many different products until recently. I think they make quality stuff, but if you're looking for support or a device that you can learn completely day one, buy Tilta or another brand because it ain't here.

Now let's talk about the motor... it is quite progressive but fairly weak causing it to jump when doing pulls. It will do fine for most lenses, however it will have problems with stiffer lenses. The motor does not have enough torque and is limited to 7.2v with the battery and I cannot seem to pull anything more than 5.2v on USB C. This was pretty disappointing... Tilta Nucleus Nano (which is ancient), can pull 18v. Now I may be mistaken, but SmallRig customer service is non-existent and there aren’t any good instructions so I don't know if there's a way to increase the torque or voltage.

Outside of the above, everything else is great! I like the displays, the brightness, the record button and how I can change the color of the LED on the knob. I also like how the color of the knob will change when recording and that it can be shut off. I also like how you can flip the display on the knob, but I hate that you can flip the display on the motor. Calibration is also simple and easy. I would love to be able to set waypoints on buttons instead of turning the knob. That way you can press a button and have it pull at a steady speed.

Anywho... the search for the perfect FF motor continues. This will likely end up on eBay as soon as Tilta's next gen Nucleus comes out.

title: If you have cute kids, PICK could be a gold mine of adorable images
text:
[[VIDEOID:61593b9b2be27e5176e7f66dc3b30b6b]] The Canon Power Shot PICK is an impressive mini AI robot camera. The package contains everything you need to get started- an Anker PD charger and small Sandisk mSD (TF) card. You have to download the Canon Mini PTZ app to your phone, and setup is pretty quick and easy via Bluetooth. During operation, the PICK will routinely ask to set up a local WiFi connection to your phone, when it senses the need for additional bandwidth, such as streaming video. I suspect the PICK would probably be delightful for a family with small children, where it could no doubt capture some adorable images and video.
We don't have any human children, so I attempted to use it with our cats. The facial recognition is good for people, not so much for felines. You can control it with your phone, not unlike an IP security camera, which is how I captured the attached feline images and video. Using a magic arm, I tried clamping the camera to a chair leg to get it down to cat level, and all of the cats immediately spotted it as soon as they heard the PTZ motor kick in. Our almost 20 year old cat regarded it with suspicion and left the room- the camera did auto track her as she fled to safety. The youngest, 19 month old Tishna, stalked up to the camera, put nose to lens, swatted the PICK several times, then reached up and pulled it down to the floor! This took all of 20 seconds-video attached. Prior to this, the camera did learn to track 'cats' (sort of) - it produced a number of 10 second video clips of any large dark object, including the front of the garbage disposal and the black plastic food trays on the floor. It did easily learn my face, and very effectively followed me around the room, which was a bit unnerving at first. The resulting images and video were very sharp- closeups showed every enlarged pore, acne scar and wrinkle in detail. Definitely not Instagram material, but the camera is not to blame. If you have a few adorable kids to 'PICK', I fully expect this device could be a gold mine of cute images and video, if you have time to 'PICK' out the gems.

title: Accurately Depicted, Gorgeous, High-Quality Stickers
text:
I ordered these stickers to embellish plain stationery and envelopes, and they are superb for many reasons:

1) They are sized EXACTLY as shown. You need only to view the images in the product listing to ascertain their size. For example, observe the adult-sized human hand holding one of them. You can plainly see that the stickers are on the small side but not smaller than most other stickers made to be applied to small objects. Again, look how--in the online product description--they are applied to water bottles and the top corner of a writing journal. I am making these points because I am always amazed when people neither read nor observe product information and then give a less than stellar review on that basis. It is unfair.

2) Rather than being adhered to sticker sheets, the stickers are individually cut and enclosed in a box to keep them neat and tidy. This way, you use what you need without ending up with stacks of partially used sticker sheets that often end up sticking to one another and destroying some of the unused stickers. I love the packaging of this product.

3) The printing and material are of the highest quality with a lot of detail packed into each and every sticker.

4) The stickers are easy to peel away from their backing without tearing, and they adhere to various surfaces, including paper and plastic. They could also be used in a well-lacquered decoupage project. You might apply them to lunch boxes, stationery paper, envelopes, invitations, and place cards at weddings, tea parties, and Easter brunch. They would look beautiful in a scrap book, photo album or journal. The uses are limited only by your imagination.

5. The sticker set encompasses a large number and variety of flowers.

6.. The vendor has focused and excelled in its product offerings, stationery products. They offer beautifully colored pens, cases and other products to help one add beauty to paper.

7. The vendor was kind enough to include a written note of thanks to the customer. I wish more people would express gratitude to one another.

8. The vendor has a sense of humor. A mustache sticker was enclosed that can be worn by children and adults alike.

title: Great monitor, even better than I expected
text:
I bought this Dell Curved Gaming, 34 Inch Curved Monitor with 144Hz Refresh Rate, WQHD (3440 x 1440) Display, Black - S3422DWG and would be going from a 27" IPS screen to this VA screen. Reading about the differences I was expecting the picture on my new Dell to be a bit of a downgrade on how the colors would pop. I was willing to make this tradeoff for more screen real estate. However while there is a difference in the two monitors, as to be expected between any monitors, the color issue is nonexistent. This monitor, hooked through the display port, running at 144 HZ, on a 1660 super card is simply brilliant.

I did a lot of youtube research before deciding on what model to buy and this one kept coming up as the best in it's class as a VA screen. The next possible option was to go IPS and spend another $300-350. I'm glad I decided to save a bit of cash and go with this Dell.

It's bright, clear, with no dead or bright pixels. Sitting in front of the screen there is no fade as one looks to the edges. Also for a VA screen one can go quite a ways side to side before noting any fade in the picture. To me that is a nonissue anyway as I'm always at the desk if using the computer.

I was going to install it on my moveable arm but, the stand is so nice, and the monitor so big that I decided not to do that. Instead I used the included stand and it works great. My adjustable arm and old 27" were moved together to my old standby computer and are doing quite well there.

The only issue I had was registering it at Dell. When I clicked on the link at their site to register it would only take me to their diagnostic tool that would determine what product I had. Here's where the trouble started as it would only scan my pc, not a Dell, and say my computer couldn't be registered. Duh, it's not a Dell. So to register it to my Dell account I had to call Dell support and talk to a tech who completed the registration for me.

I've had it now for almost three weeks and couldn't be happier with my choice.

title: Great Surface Pro alternative
text:
I primarily game using cloud GeForce Now over the cloud, so I don't need an incredibly beefy machine, but I do want something with a dedicated video card for light gaming (ex. Lego Star Wars) when I can't install the games locally, for using Office apps, and basic image editing with Affinity Designer and Affinity Photo.

I've had a Surface Pro, recently a Lenovo Yoga, and finally wanted something to game on that I could also travel with (and was affordable). After a bunch of research I'd landed on an Alienware m15 r7 and waited for it to arrive, knowing it'd be big and not have a touchscreen but was upgradeable. While waiting for delivery I came across this ROG Flow z13 and realized it might fit what I really want. Now that it's here and I tried both laptops I'm sticking with the ROG.

Great
- Can upgrade the SSD drive
- Only slightly heavier than my Yoga and runs much quieter and cooler
- Fine for running basic games on ultra settings
- Fingerprint reader on power button is great
- Touchscreen is really responsive
- Armoury Crate app is great, providing a lot of options for how the machine runs based on specific apps, RGB effects, and like wallpapers
- Runs on USB-C power
- Sound quality is excellent

Not so Great
- Can't upgrade the Ram (I wish it had a 32Gb option)
- By default it uses the integrated video to save battery, but I had to mess with Armoury Crate settings to get a game to run using the 3050 card (using Turbo mode), which I wish were out of the box
- Screen resolution is fine, but I wish it were slightly higher
- Like Surfaces, the keyboard feel is going to be a dust/hair magnet
- Still makes more noise than a Surface, but FAR less than any gaming laptop (the Alienware was insanely loud running just app updates)
- I mostly stay plugged in, but I'm sure the battery will die in no time when running unplugged
- I wish each key had an individual RGB setting, but it's not really critical, and I like that I can have the colors set based on the CPU temp or usage

title: Expensive made cheap
text:
I'd like to start off by stating that I've been using it ever since it arrived. Theres a lot of pros to this product. For starters it has great quality in sound and keeping ambient noise out.
