The earphones fit snuggly and ensure that sound is consistent and clear. The great fit keeps any noises including bus noises to a minimum. I commute using public transportation and can normally hear various conversations going on but with this product I was able to cancel those out and listen to my music without any interuptions. They stay in without moving during exercise sessions like cardio or lifting weights. Keeping in line with this, the earphones are also useful on the go anywhere.
Another thing that I'd like to point out is battery. These last quite a while by themselves and with the case, it lasts a whole lot longer. I'm able to use them for hour long gym sessions or studying in public without having to worry about battery for a while. The case also holds charge very well compared to other products on the market and is designed such that the earphones fit without being loose into the case so you don't hear rattling of any kind and that you can also see the state of charge via a LED display that shows you the exact charge on the device. It's really great in that sense because you're able to tell exactly how much battery you have left in the case before having to charge it.
Lastly, and my most important point about this product is wireless charging. I've bought $50 earphones, I've bought $20 ear phones, I've bought all kinds of audio head sets but until now I haven't had wireless charging on any of them. The earphones I was using before didn't have wireless charging and as a person that loves to move, its annoying to keep wires for different things. I'm also a very heavy user of wireless charging especially now that its becoming more commonplace and lots of other products like cars and phones have wireless charging built in, these earphones make it easy to move around as I only need maybe one wireless charger and it can charge my phone and my earphones. Less wires is always better so you don't have to worry about replacing them or making sure you have the right one.
Overall, this product is definitely something that you want to take advantage of. A quality audio, long last battery with LED display built into the case and wireless charging. Those are the hallmarks of quality and product viability for people everywhere.

title: Several things about Mine Doesn't work!
text:
I was really looking forward to getting this so that I could connect my wireless headphones to my non-Bluetooth audio receiver/amp. Sadly I cannot get my brand new Bluetooth 5.3 headphones or my Bluetooth 5.0 earbuds to connect to it. I tried everything including resetting and un-pairing each from the other components they were connected to. This is problem #1 and by far the biggest discouragement as it is what I specifically got this for.

Problem #2, The unit has a switch to change from APTX LL to APTX HD audio format and has an indicator light that is supposed to correspond to the setting it is set to. On mine, neither of the lights come on no matter the switch setting and the switch makes no perceptible difference in sound quality.

Problem #3, I set it up to also pass through audio over ToSLink optical from my TV to my receiver/amp. Before adding this my TosLink went direct from my TV to my receiver/amp and I enjoyed DTS audio. With this now in the middle doing pass through I can only get a my TV to output stereo or Dolby Pro Logic to get sound. If I set my TV to DTS or DTS Neo 2.5 all I get is loud static.

Other Problems, but not really a big deal as I knew this when getting but the unit does not include a power brick for charging. Normally my entertainment system can be fully controlled by remote and it is inconvenient to have to switch this unit on and off manually every time I sit down to watch something. I did get around this though by plugging the USB charge cord into the TV and leaving the unit turned on.

In the end the only thing that seems to work well is that it successfully paired to my mobile phone allowing me to play music from my phone to my receiver/amp and the range is good. I can go upstairs in my house with my phone and it doesn't cut out. Being able to use my phone as a music source on my receiver/amp is the only reason I am still using it. Otherwise I would probably toss it in the bin and will probably do just that once something better comes along that can do everything I need it to do.

Overall I am very unhappy with this. Given the mostly good reviews, maybe I just got a defective unit, IDK.

title: COOLEST MINI TRIPOD YET!
text:
I have had a lot of tripods over the years (I've had a LOT of stuff over these many years at that) and I find this to be about the best little photographic accessory I have had in a long time. First, it appears to be well thought out and engineered to be something that you could be happy to own and in my opinion, it is.

Starting out with the actual tripod base, it's legs are textured if you want to hold your camera, phone, etc. in your hand and very compact. The legs snap out to a tight tripod stance and press the Red button in the center and the legs open further to a wide stance with rubber feet to keep it from slipping or sliding around. The tripod "Head" is extremally versatile and well designed with professional features like 360º rotation, 90º tilt and an accessory ¼"-20 threaded mount hole.

The cell phone mount is the best I've seen so far, you don't have to strain to spread it to put the phone in it, you just push another Red button and it pops open and you place your phone in and squeeze to hold the phone securely. It has 2 accessory ¼"-20 threaded mount holes, one on the bottom like everyone else and one on the side, again, well thought out and versatile. There is an extension arm with a ¼-20" treaded mount that can be used collapsed or extends about 20 inches as a selfie stick or above the crowd, plus it works as an elevated extension to the tripod section.

Finally, it comes with a Wireless Bluetooth remote control made with a U.S. chip for remote picture or video shooting up to 30 feet away for convenience which is nice to have. There is one thing I absolutely did NOT like was the .... manual??? They created a new format in instructions, there is normal, small, tiny, mini, micro and now "NANO" Type. Okay, I took some closeup pictures with my phone to read, but really, is that necessary to make everything so darn small? I'll live with it and I wouldn't hesitate to spend $29.99 on this if I didn't get it at no cost other than an honest and truthful evaluation. The product description has complete pictures on every aspect of its versatility, so not much point in me adding any, but I did anyway.

title: Outstanding Convenience and Versatility - A Must-Have for Every Tech Enthusiast!
text:
I recently purchased the Anker Outlet Extender and USB Wall Charger, and I must say it has exceeded all my expectations! This device is an absolute game-changer, providing a perfect solution for anyone in need of extra power outlets and USB ports.

Firstly, the build quality of this extender is top-notch. The sleek design seamlessly integrates with my home decor, and the sturdy construction assures me of its durability. Anker's reputation for high-quality products is certainly upheld with this outstanding extender.

The presence of six additional outlets is a huge plus, as it enables me to power multiple devices simultaneously without the need for additional power strips cluttering up my space. I can now conveniently connect my laptop, smartphone, tablet, and even a lamp, all from one central location. It's a true convenience that saves me time and hassle.

The two built-in USB ports are a fantastic addition, especially with the inclusion of a 20W USB-C power delivery. Charging my USB-C devices has never been faster or more efficient. It's incredibly convenient to have dedicated USB ports available without sacrificing the use of the outlets.

What sets this extender apart from others on the market is the intelligent charging technology. It automatically detects and delivers the optimal charging speed for each connected device, ensuring fast and safe charging every time. I no longer have to worry about overloading or damaging my devices.

Furthermore, the inclusion of surge protection provides an extra layer of security for my valuable electronics. I feel confident knowing that my devices are safe from sudden power surges or voltage fluctuations.

In terms of convenience, the compact size of this extender makes it perfect for travel. Whether I'm staying in a hotel room or working in a coffee shop, I can easily carry this device in my bag and have access to multiple outlets and USB charging ports wherever I go.

Overall, I cannot recommend the Anker Outlet Extender and USB Wall Charger highly enough. Its combination of superb build quality, versatile functionality, and intelligent charging capabilities make it a must-have for anyone seeking convenience and efficiency in their daily lives. Anker has once again delivered an exceptional product, and I am extremely satisfied with my purchase.

Do yourself a favor and invest in this outstanding extender. You won't be disappointed!

title: Pretty solid budget option with some limitations
text:
I bought this because I have a Gaming Desktop and a work laptop (connected to a thunderbolt dock that has DP out) and I was previously using a USB switcher and manually changing the monitor input from DP to HDMI (dock).

I have a 44" 3840x1200 display and had to drop to 120Hz to stop flickering, was hoping that since it could support 120hz in 4k that I could get the full 144Hz but no dice. The 24 lost Hz is a fair tradeoff for the price and convenience that this unit offers though.

As far as EDID, etc. goes, my windows pretty much remember where they were when switching back and forth, Microsoft may have added some extra functionality in Win 11 to help make up for any deficiencies there but not sure without further investigation. Suffice to say with this KVM + Windows 11 I don't have issues with windows minimizing or all going to one screen.

I bought 3 DP 1.4 cables separately and didn't use the included cables with this (there are 2 but you need 3, and I'd recommend getting 3 of the exact same cable. I left my old DP cable connected to my monitor and the new cables for the two PC connections and it didnt work until I swapped the original monitor cable for one of the new ones, so just food for thought).

Switching is pretty snappy, takes maybe 2-3 seconds.

Remote works surprisingly well. Have the unit hidden under my 2.5" solid maple desk and the remote goes through it. Occasionally have to press the buttons more than once but for me thats fine.

Only thing more I'd like to see possibly is inclusion of Audio, but I have a USB 3.5mm jack connected to the USB hub that's connected to the shared ports on the KVM which serves the same purpose (with less cables). The 3 shared usb 3.0 ports are a nice touch too, more than you get with most KVMs twice the size/price, and I was able to connect a separate USB hub to one of them for more ports for more shared devices with no issues.

Overall, for the price, it's a great pickup as long as you don't care too much about high refresh rates in higher or widescreen resolutions for gaming.

title: Inexpensive but fully featured and works well.
text:
I finally had a chance to road test this dual camera while driving on a day with heavy snowfall. Not having any smooth dash surface to attach it to I mounted it to the windshield next to the rear view mirror. The suction cup is the type with a lever that allows you to forcibly draw it down once a seal is established, which is much more positive than the simple push-down suction cups.

I did not try out the many operating modes for motion detection, the gravity sensor, or parking options, instead opting for the simple mode where it turns on with the ignition to capture only driving events. The picture-in-picture mode on the display makes it easy to set up the adjustable rear-facing driver (or passenger) camera. The buttons for operating the various functions are imprinted with fairly subtle symbols and are a bit hard to read. I would have preferred some high contrast text, but once you learn the button functions this is not an issue.

I did go through the settings to set the exposure to -1, turn on Wide Dynamic Range, and make sure that the highest resolution recording (of 3 choices) was set. When I was initially testing the camera by using it like a hand held camcorder I felt that the auto-exposure response was a little slow, but in the vehicle this was totally a non-issue.

On the road I could see that the progressive scan of the camera was making the moving windshield wipers look like rubber hoses, but both the driver and road video quality was perfectly adequate because of the relatively low rate of motion. The snowfall looked like it was being taken through a high speed shutter, and I was quite impressed by the detail in the video in the full HD (FHD) mode. Because of the windshield mount I was picking up a lot of wiper noise, but the audio recording was always more than adequate to capture conversations.

The front and rear videos are captured as separate files in short segments with time stamps on the TF memory card, so it is easy to go back and find an event should the need arise.

I still have a hard time understanding how you can get so much functionality for this price. I can imagine finding uses for this dual camera outside of the vehicle such as for a temporary security camera. This seems like a very good value and is highly recommended.

title: Good case, but getting old
text:
So, a Noctua NH-D15 is a common air cooler for people with fast and power hungry CPUs and don't want to use water cooling for the many different reasons that a person could possibly have. For people wanting air cooling and want to get the beefier ones because you have a CPU that uses more power, 170mm clearance over the CPU for an air cooler is a pretty reasonable ask from a company, and with a case like this it SHOULD be able to deal with bigger air coolers, but no. I had to replace the front fan that came with the Noctua NH-D15 with a 120mm fan. Yes, some of this falls on the cooler design, but still, this is supposed to be a performance case for gaming.

The next issue I have with the case are the ports. NONE of the ports worked for me except the USB 2 ports. I wish this was a rare problem but I've seen it a few times with different case manufacturers where you get one case and the ports work and another one and something in the front doesn't work. I can't give 5 stars to a company if this VERY SIMPLE THING of making sure the ports work by either having a manufacturing process that ensures they will work or checking them. I can't even plug a headset into the front port and that's pathetic. This is the first time I've had both USB 3 ports and a sound port be an issue. When testing the USB 3 ports it corrupted data coming off the disk and after unplugging from this system I had to reformat the drive because the partition got corrupted and locked up the next system I plugged it into.

So as far as the front ports this case was a disaster, as far as the clearance over the CPU, it's on the "olden days" side. Yes there's enough clearance for the old faithful Cooler Master Hyper 212 EVO, from more than a decade ago, but aren't we past that now?

I can't give more than 4 stars for a case that's supposed to be a high quality gaming case but can't accept more modern air coolers and the NH-D15 seems to be the one many people want to use for high end builds without using water, and I have to take off a star for each port that doesn't work.

Two stars.

title: Super lightweight, good Teams integration
text:
Used this work my work laptop. The corporate environment is locked down so no third party software or drivers are allowed. Fortunately the plug-and-play drivers worked first time and Microsoft Teams even popped up with a notice about a certified device connecting.

Hopped right into a meeting with the headphones. The Mute function causes Teams to mute but also mutes the microphone at the hardware level The microphone is truly 'cold' when muted. There is also the mute button on the cable which I use rather frequently - It hasn't missed a beat even when muting every in between sentences. It just a little bit irksome that every time you mute the headphones make a sound that say "Mute On" at about the same volume as everyone speaking. I wish it was just a beep like my old Plantronics headset.

There are also volume adjust buttons on the inline remote which I used a few times. It jumps the volume by 6% at the OS level every push of the button.

There's a Teams button which supposedly responds to notifications from Teams as they pop up but I never had a notification be so critically urgent that I needed a dedicated button to address them. I never used the button. I feel there may be others out there where this may not be the case.

The audio quality is actually pretty good. These aren't the type of headphones I'd normally use for listening to music since they're mainly a communications headset but regardless the option is there. When naturally resting on the ears the bass is somewhat light and the overall sound feels bright but pushing down on the headphones slightly has the bass come more forward. Not practical to be pushing down on the pads like that but if you have a wide head or perhaps aftermarket pads it's something to consider if they're a daily driver. Not that any of that matters for the average Teams call; Everyone is calling from their bluetooth earpieces so it all sounds like compressed garble. If they all used wired microphones it'd be way better. The quality also goes down when the microphone is in use, it seems to drop the output sampling rate below 44.1khz. If you're looking to use this for gaming, it's not ideal.

Update: I previously mentioned the tilt function mutes. That isn't the case, the mic is still hot when up. Just tap the mute button and it'll mute.

title: Does what I need it to do!
text:
Grabbed this since my other tablet died. I wasn't sure what to expect for the price and not being a known brand. As you can clearly see it comes in a white box that says tablet and, on the side, says made it China. Thats not an issue at all so I opened the box to see the tablet in a protective silk like bag. I took the tablet out and thought the screen felt weird and notice it already had a screen protector on installed. That was a very nice touch and then when I looked in the bottom of the box there was another screen protector include. So, you get two screen protectors include with your purchase. It also came with two USB-A to USB-C cables. One is very short and the second seems like 3 feet. There's also a user's manual but it doesn't have a picture of what each button or plug on tablet is, but it's easy to figure out.

The tablet comes with a USB-C power port, plus the sd card slot to expand storage. Slot looks like a micro or mini manual doesn't tell us anything. It just covers operating system. Love that this tablet has a headphone jack, and it works great. I personally would use that over the built in stereo speakers. Built in speakers don't get very loud and sound lifeless. There's also a volume rocker up and down and the power button which is about the size of a USB_C insert.

Operation: Tablet start right away had about 80 percent battery. right away it searched for Wi-Fi network, and I picked my network, and it brought me to set up via a google account. I did a clean install and within 5 minutes tablet was running. There's no update to android 11 but there are updates for aps installed via play store. That was the longest portion of set up downloading updates from the play store. As for the camera, well let's just say its fuzzy even with flash. The rear camera even when using flash seems dark. I haven't tried front facing camera yet but didn't grab tablet for the camera. The tablet was very responsive and had zero touch issues.

Last thought: For me I am not sure I would purchase this at $65, even with the extra protector. The quality of the cameras and the stereo speakers make it a hard choice at that price. If its $50 I would have zero issue with buying another.

title: Good for nature watching. Easy to use. Tripod and phone attachment just OK to meh.
text:
This works well for getting a closer look at nature on the back porch or out the window. Easy to handle and use. Relatively light weight (definitely lighter than binoculars). One hand use and focus. I find it best for things that are a few hundred yards away that you want to get a better look at. May be my new companion on hikes as it’s easier to pack/store than binoculars.

Tripod is just ok. One of the little rubber pieces on the bottom was already off when I took it out of the box. It’s not super adjustable, but it does work and helps keep the device steady if placed on a flat surface. You just have to adjust yourself to the height, as the height of the tripod itself is not adjustable and the legs do not lock… they are either open or closed. You can loosen the ball socket that holds the scope to change its angle, just not the height of the tripod.

The phone attachment piece is not my favorite. After significant manipulation and frustration, I got it to work…kind of. Using this piece on the tripod is difficult because my phone sits lower than the leg of the tripod, hard to explain, but it’s a bit of a mess. Honestly, the hassle factor using the phone attachment piece was too much and I really don’t see me using it. There are no directions, so you have to look at the picture to figure out how it works (basically it just clips over the scope… similar to the eyehole cover).

Even with the phone attachment and tripod shortcomings, I do like the scope itself. It’s easy to use, and brings nature a little closer to me. I did try using it to look at the moon and stars, as it’s advertised as being useful for stargazing, but I don’t think it was great for this. It does bring things a little closer, but not like a decent pair of binoculars or a telescope. I find it best for things that are a few hundred yards away that you want to get a better look at. The glass is not quite the green color shown in the pictures… if you look at it in the right light, it looks like it has a green tint – not that it matters, just don’t expect it to be that bright green color shown.

title: Watch out for these guys they are the next big thing especially if they can keep up the prices
text: I would like to start with some background to show some self righteous validation to my opinion, as it is of course the most important. Hahaha sorry for my awful stale attempt at humor, and get to gritty nitty to this. I have been building custom keyboards in all forms since the days of mil max hotswaps homie. I have been an in house reviewer on advance projects for multiple companies that are big enough and well known enough that I'm cool with admitting I'm too much of a little b*tch to namedrop for effect because of what they can and WILL do if I break their ndas. I've seen companies grow from niche providers to become household names to the world. Out of all the years and all the cool things I've seen this company is a true nk silk in a field of broken box jade click bars if you catch the krytox I'm whippin. My little dude just finished his new gaming board with a red and black theme so when I saw this I figured getting a coiled cable to look good should be easy enough for them to achieve at an acceptable for us to use on one of our own projects. I can't even express the surprise and pure love for the bigger open market that keyboard building has become, because without it no company would've been able to hit this level of value at such a low price. Honestly I am having a little bit of a hard time seeing why we ever were expected to pay 2 to 3 times the price of this, especially when this is one of the best looking cords I have ever had the pleasure of getting my mitts on. It took everything in me to not revert to a childish state and get into a pissing match over it with an 11 year old. Razer, Glorious, Logitech, watch out there's a not just a new player in the game if they can keep this quality to cost value through the inflation like they have, because if they do there's a whole new game to be played and the first shot has been taken. If they have the color or theme your looking for stop right there and have faith they understand how things should be. Put your money and support behind them and watch the rat race while some play catch up and others  just darwin their way out because of refusal to be true to the people who got them where they are. Rant over sorry not sorry take this 100% recommendation and use your brain for more than apex!

title: A Winner:  Sharp images, can't-miss-it lens cover, and no-fuss Windows install
text:
What I like: Checks all the boxes for a decent quality video conferencing solution.

What could be better: Some may prefer a less obvious lens cover

Out-of-the-box experience was smooth as silk. The camera has a mounting hinge-style base / lever that secures the camera along the top edge of my LCD monitor, snug enough that it won't budge with an occasional jostle. The supplied USB cable is more than enough length to run from the camera to my monitor's USB port. It is probably long enough to run between the camera and a below-desk PC case.

My Windows 10 OS recognized the camera and microphone automatically. I fired up a Zoom meeting, using a nearby computer as the second participant, and observed the camera's behaviors in all its glory. Display rendering is spot-on and of generous dimensions (wide angle). I'm no video expert but to my everyday user's eyes, image rendering is perfect, with the usual, subtle ambient lighting found in a working office environment.

Audio quality is also fine, using it for its primary use case of a video conference call.

When reviewing the materials shipped with the camera, I couldn't find any reference to specific software to tweak camera behavior. If you're the sort who wants to dabble with the image or audio settings, it seems using either Windows or a third party platform will be your answer there. For me, there are no adjustments needed, and in any event the Zoom platform I use provides more than enough toys to play with there.

The camera has a lens cap that's affixed to the housing with a short, but quite adequate string. It is easy enough to apply or remove the lens cap, which lies on its string behind the monitor when not in use. The cap is easy to recognize, so there's no doubt your image isn't going anywhere, when you don't want it to. Yes, there is an LED that illuminates when the camera is "hot." I suppose the cap is provided to ensure that no image will be available, even if malicious software could activate the camera without illuminating the LED warning.

Overall, there is much to like here, especially for my routine use cases. A winner. Five stars.

title: SO FRUSTRATING!!!
text:
I’ve attached the pictures that are the main instructions for how to get this thing set up. After plugging in the power cord, the expectation is that you’re either plugging it into a Bluetooth device like a smartphone, which usually makes pairing easy, because the easy on-screen Bluetooth pairing procedure, or the directions expect that you are connecting it to a basic stereo type device, which isn’t too far off of what I am trying to do. My connection doesn’t have an on-screen toggle or pairing code; I am trying to connect it to a television, so that it will pick up the Bluetooth signal to my Little Bose speaker that I have sitting beside the bed. I’ve been using the “transmitter from TV to Bose” via Bluetooth set up for a number of years, until recently, when my former transmitter puffed up and died. It literally swelled up and stopped working. So I went on the hunt for another transmitter to send a signal to my sweet little Bluetooth speaker. I’m hearing impaired, so this has been a fantastic way for me to be able to not only hear the TV when I’m in bed, but it also improves the TV watching experience, because Bose offers a superior sound experience above that which my television’s speakers do.
These instructions, however, do not offer any other insight after you’ve plugged in the power cord. From that part of the set up, the choice of which type of audio device cord connection is the only other pictorial information offered. I have tried to find something online that would give more insight about how to make this happen, but there is nothing about what to do when both the transmitter and the Bluetooth speaker to which I’m trying to connect are flashing blue as if they are trying to find a signal to connect, but they are not connecting to each other. So, now I have to return this darn thing, and try to find another transmitter like the one I used to have that never gave me any trouble and connected immediately and worked with all different types of speakers, JBL, Bose, my iPhone, my iPad, my earbuds, etc.
I am quite technically savvy when it comes to things like this. I was a DJ and engineer in radio for many years, I have worked in IT for decades, and yet this tiny little black box has really pissed me off!

title: Awesome Bass! Lacking treble/high
text:
I come from a 5.1 surround system to a 2.1 because I wanted to downsize a bit, so I bought this 2.1, and I have to say that I was very impressed with the Z623.

I have no words to describe the bass quality! I have a slab foundation, and the house still shakes with 75% bass and with a volume level of around 15%. So, I am 100% satisfied with the bass. I usually have my bass level at 100%, but with this unit, I cannot afford to do that. It's too much. I tried putting it at 100% with a low volume level, and the sound quality stood its ground. I gradually increased the volume, and I did not notice any issue beyond shaking my house. I didn't get to 100 to test its limit, but I didn't feel it would be an issue if I did, though my neighbors would probably have a thing or two to say about that.

The speakers look gorgeous and are of great sound quality for their size. They fit nicely on my computer desk. The size of the subwoofer was surprising. That thing is huge. I would have preferred something smaller. But that's neither bad nor good. It's about your preference. Just keep in mind that the picture doesn't do the size justice.

Now, my main issue with the unit is the lack of crisp sound with not enough treble/high power. This causes the sound to be muffled, and that drives me insane. This could be a personal preference, but I am annoyed listening to sound where the treble/high frequencies are subdued. Unfortunately, this is what I feel about this unit. Sadly, this is a big issue for me and will be returning the unit.

I bought the analog version, and I noticed some initial buzz (This buzz does not last, is just an initial buzz and it goes away. It is kind of like when you receive a notification message, the sound gives this kind of buzz effect as if the speakers were dying) that comes with using that type of connection. However, I think using the optical output would solve that issue.

Overall, I think this is a great unit if the treble/high frequency of the sound is not a big issue for you. You will love it. While it is not for me, I definitely would recommend it!

title: Great Sound Quality & Best Noise Cancellation BUT…
text:
They have EXCELLENT sound quality. GREAT bass, good mid range & good treble. All three can be enhanced through the EQ in the app. They sound slightly better than AirPods Pro 2 and the Beats Pro Fit earbuds but when you add more bass & slightly increase the treble through the EQ... No contest! It’s only adversary in sound quality would be the Status Between Pro for half the price but no bells and whistles like ANC or Transparnecy mode. Status Between Pro ear buds have much clearer mids and treble and a solid bass.

And the Noise Cancellation is arguably the best. Better than AirPods Pro 2 (a close 2nd), Anker earbuds, Sony ear buds, Beats Fit Pro, etc.

It’s Transparency mode matches AirPods Pro 2. I’d argue they have the best transparent modes on the market as others sound too “tinny” and/or have latency issues, sounding like you’re in an echo chamber.

BUT

I’ve gone through 3 sets of replacements… and I am done.

I had constant connectivity issues. They would intermittently disconnect from my iPhone X stating “iPhone Lost”. I’d get a new replacement, all was well and then after the most recent update, back to having intermittent connectivity issues.

Also, the earbuds literally fell out of my ear like butter irregardless of what band and ear tip combination I chose. These are the only earbuds on the market I found that I had issues with keeping in my ear. BOSE had much better earpieces on their past earbuds although they didn’t have a great “seal”. These have a great deal but slip out of my ear! I have ZERO issues keeping an unsupported AirPod Pro 2 earbud in my ear. Odd.

Customer Support was great, making exchanges/replacements easy.

Overall I would’ve kept them due to exceptional sound quality and ANC BUT I couldn’t get past the connectivity issues. Obvious deal breaker.

In any case, give them a go. Perhaps you’ll have a better experience than I did.

title: Keys get stuck, no space!
text:
Pros: great battery life, compact & lightweight,
Cons: The keys get stuck. No space, not even for updates.

I really love the battery life on the laptop. I've used it for 8 hours, and there was about 20% left, and it charges very quickly. It's compact, easy to fit in backpacks, and on small desks for typing. It's very light, I kept checking my bag to make sure it was in there, and the color was beautiful.

I would have loved to keep this laptop and wish I could, but unfortunately, the keyboard kept getting stuck. The caps lock light would remain on even though it was typing in regular letters and would type weird characters. I googled the problem, and it seems as if the shift keys got stuck. So, after fixing that problem, it was another problem with the keyboard, and I had to google the fix. This occurred pretty frequently, and it got rather annoying.

It was supposed to come with 1 year of Microsoft, but after 3 weeks, I got a pop-up message that said the Microsoft was about to expire. It was almost a MONTH of use, not a YEAR.

Additionally, there was an update for the newest windows, but I did not have space. There is no way this laptop had 32 GB of ram. The system itself used up all the space, I had nothing on the laptop. I had to delete some of the items that came downloaded on the laptop, like solitaire. Even with enough space, the download kept getting stuck and starting over. Then it said it needed more space, so I got a flash drive, and the same thing happened again.

I only had the laptop for about a month and contacted HP because it should have been under warranty. They informed me that the warranty expired on this laptop 4 months before I even purchased it. I was so frustrated. At this point, I want to return the darn thing. I was putting in too much work for a laptop that was supposed to make my life easier.

I can see other customers have had a similar experience, so my advice to new buyers would be, if you don't mind these things, then go for it but there is an issue with the keyboard and HP is aware of the issue because they have fixes on their support site.

title: Easy to carry around, on a trip, concert, etc…
text:
First of all just to be fair, my rating is based on my comparison on about a similar digital camera and not a high-end SLR camera.

This is my go-to camera. As a photography enthusiast, I must say that I absolutely love the NEZINI 4K Digital Camera for its impressive features, ease of use, and the exceptional image quality it delivers. However, it was a challenge at first. It took me sometime to figure out how to adjust everything. I wanted a point and shoot and at the same time I do have the option to play around with speed and light for the I
Ages that I after.

With its 48MP resolution and advanced autofocus algorithm, capturing high-definition images is a breeze. Whether shooting close-ups or long-range views, the camera's 16x zoom and fast autofocus ensure excellent results. The CMOS image sensor further enhances picture quality and reduces noise for both photos and videos. It did took some time but once I figured it out, it so easy to use.

This versatile camera offers 4K video recording, a pause function, and anti-shake technology, making it suitable for various shooting needs. The optical viewfinder enables real-time composition and minimizes the impact of outdoor light on photography. The retro design, user-friendly shooting mode dial, and small grip contribute to better stability while shooting. Additionally, the built-in flash and hotshoe allow for clearer images in low-light conditions and the option to connect external accessories like a fill light or microphone. With connectivity options such as HDMI and Type-C cables, it's easy to view content on a TV or upload files to a computer.

It comes with a soft case. Two batteries. A charging cable and charging station. A manual, micro card and insert for SD reader and an HDMI cable.

Overall, the NEZINI 4K Digital Camera strikes an excellent balance between performance and usability, making it an outstanding choice for capturing high-quality photos and videos. As a photography enthusiast, I can confidently say that this camera has exceeded my expectations in terms of features, image quality, and ease of use.

The one thing I hope that it has was a water or weatherproof camera.

I would definitely recommend it and rate it about 4.5.

title: Still testing this out
text:
I purchased this from another source but is writing my review here.

I purchased this for all of my virtual keyboard devices. I seriously loathe everything that I have that has the virtual keyboard to it. This includes my Samsung Galaxy S10 cellphone. I have a Samsung Moment that still have the keyboard but since the updates stopped for that phone I had to resort to getting a cellphone with no keyboard and this S10 is the second cellphone I own with no keyboard.

I avoided getting a mini keyboard for the longest but I just about had enough with the virtual stuff! I got this in the mail today and couldn't wait to pair it to my cellphone.
Did I say 'pair'?? I don't know why I thought that's what this keyboard did. It does not. That's the first teeth gritting moment.
It does come with a dongle....Well, that's all find and dandy except my cell only has a type 'C' port! Second teeth gritting moment...
So I have a USB-A to USB-C adapter from a portable cellphone hard drive and went to use that...Small problem, my protective case on my phone won't allow me to connect unless I take off the case. That could spell for disaster because I could drop that thin phone and break it.
I took the risk and was able to use the USB-A to USB-C adapter. Now I was excited because my cellphone picked it up with no problems. But that's where the third teeth gritting moment comes in.
I go into Messenger and it won't type. I can get out of a app when I hit ALT F4 though. It does type when I go to the internet. I had to toggle around in order to get to certain things because the 'tab' feature didn't work.
I then went into my email to type a message which for the most part worked but some keys kept getting stuck. At this point I had enough. I haven't tested this on my Surface Pro or Galaxy tablet. My tablet don't have a port for a dongle either.
IF I had known this doesn't pair with bluetooth I wouldn't have purchased it. There are no instructions and no indications that it's bluetooth compatible.
Until I can manage to get a better adapter to use for my cellphone this will be going back in the box.

title: Buyer Beware, Not Recommended!
text:
Honestly I try to be patient and understanding but after 3 strikes I just have to say something.

I purchased this plan to cover my daughter's backpack. At the time the backpack was $44.99 so the plan that was selected was one with a coverage of $40-$49.99. The strap on my daughter's backpack tore so I began the claim process.

I went to the website as instructed and selected the options presented. After going through their steps the process determined that I was not eligible for a claim and that I should instead contact the manufacturer. Let me state what the terms are for an eligible claim:

What's covered by my plan?
Stains, rips or tears, seam separation, broken moving parts and more are covered from the date of purchase. Coverage for defects in materials and workmanship begins after the manufacturer's warranty ends.

Rip is clearly stated there by them. So this was strike one. I decided to chat with the Asurion company instead of using their automated process and lo and behold I did qualify for a claim.

After the claim was accepted and approved I was not happy to find out that I first had to send back the item before receiving a gift card. This is not ideal since my daughter needs a backpack to go to school with (even with a tore strap). I understand the reasoning but Amazon typically mails you out a replacement and if you don't return the original they charge you for the replacement. This is the ideal solution, so strike 2.

Lastly, the amount I will be refunded will be $44.99 although the current price for this item is now $55.89. One would think that since I purchased the $40-49.99 coverage plan that they would refund me the maximum amount of $49.99 and that I would need to cover the additional cost. This makes sense right? Nope, they will only refund the original amount even though I paid the same price for this protection plan as someone who purchased an item worth $49.99. This was the last strike. Honestly... I wouldn't doubt that if the item dropped below $44.99 they would reimburse me the current price. This could just be me throwing shade but whatever, upset.

Buyer beware, if you are okay with these terms then should work for you.

title: Dash CAM - VANTrue E2
text:
VANTrue Element 2 Dash Cam

The VANTrue Element 2 is a Voice Controlled Dash Cam, Front, and Rear cameras.
The installation instructions provide clear and easily understood diagrams. I installed it in my 2003 F150 Crew Cab, where instructions on cabling and camera locations are for an SUV-type vehicle. No worries if you take some time to plan out the installation path, and location of the cameras. The extra cable can be hidden behind the column panels. The car charger connection does provide a Type C connection that can be used to charge an external device, phone, tablet, etc.

Not included in the package is the SD Card. Dash CAM will support up to 512 GB (FAT32). Do look and purchase the recommended VANTrue Micro SD Card.

Note: Check and upgrade the firmware as suggested. Firmware can be downloaded from the VANTrue support site. The last step of the update will reformat the SD Card.

The VANTrue E2 Dash CAM videos can be downloaded to your PC via the provided Type C data cable. I would recommend downloading and installing them to your phone via the VANTrue App. The App provides easy access to the videos via the built-in WiFi connection making viewing, downloading, and creating 30-second snippets of your videos. These videos can then be shared via your favorite social media app.

Voice Control - I was able to turn on and off the WiFi via voice control. I tried several other word combinations to try and control the VANTrue E2 Dash Cam all of which failed. An example is to take a snapshot. I also had to turn up High Sensitivity. Thinking here that voice control would be much quicker than using the remote.

Remote - The remote is very simple to operate as it has two buttons, One to turn on and off WiFi and the other to take a Snapshot

Final thoughts - Overall I am impressed with the ease of installation and operation of the VANTrue Dash Cam and its App. I do recommend getting a VANTrue Dash Cam as it has proven to be a wise choice on my part. I was a bit disappointed that the Micro SD Card was not included.

VANTrue Element 2 Dash Cam

title: Excellent DMR Radio
text:
After a bunch of research, I purchased this radioo from Radioddity prior to the release. I'm very happy wiht the purchase. It's a very good DMR radio and works well.

However, there are a few issues, so let's get them out of the way. First, volume controls & volume. The nice thing is, this radio is good and loud, a complaint many have of other radios. The complaint here is that it's a tad too loud. Further, the digital volume control is a bit laggy and acts kind of odd. This is not a huge deal, but it's a bit of a pain.

Next, Analog APRS. It works. It really does. However, it doesn't work consistently. Some days I'm able to get the beacon to fire automatically, others, not so much. Manual transmission always works, so that's good. Also, no analog APRS receive, and it really should. It's an SDR radio (two actually), so this can, and should, be added with just a patch.

And that's all I have to say bad about this radio. I've heard people complain about the code plug editor, but I found it basically OK. Maybe because I learned how to do code plugs on truly heinous software, merely poor software wasn't a big deal. Doesn't matter though because there's a 3rd party CPE from MM7DBT.

I was able to program all the zones I wanted. I made contacts within those zones, and I was able to make digital, as well as analog, contacts. The signal reports were all very positive with no issues at all. Transmission and reception over distance is excellent. I even added a Signal Stick antenna to make it a bit better.

Construction is very solid with good materials. Knobs and switches all have a positive feel and feedback (except for the already mentioned volume control). Battery life is good. The charging station can even charge two batteries at the same time. The screen is very clear and easy to read, even in sunlight.

Overall, this radio just works (except for APRS) and does what I need.

Oh, and Radioddity customer service is good. So you're not just buying a radio and then you're on your own. They'll help.

title: The best so far...
text:
[[VIDEOID:c782c1b61b15b3ef5ef9db4ced7cedd0]] Where I’m coming from: I have been looking for the perfect pair of earbuds for some time. I’ve tried the AirPods 2, LG Tone, and I have just about every set that TOZO produces; the NC2 has been my favorite set thus far.

But I’ve still been looking…

And I got the TOZO Golden X1s and maybe…

So, here are details on each aspect:

Audio: they sound fantastic. But with one caveat, you need to adjust them with the app. It made a huge change. It’s cool to do a hearing test with them and see how you need to adjust the EQ settings. Plenty loud too.

ANC: Active noise cancellation. It works fine for what I need. It’s just peaceful. Wearing them in a car makes it nice and quiet.

Case: I love the size. It easily fits in the pocket. Completely necessary to have the percentage of the battery charge. If your earbuds don’t have that, move on. Nice to drop it down on a charging pad at the end of the day. My only complaint is for some reason for me, I have a hard time opening the case. Not impossible; it’s just not an easy first-time opening.

Fit: I’m still working on this one. This fits a little differently than some past ones. I wish they went a little deeper into my ear.

Battery: These last, especially if you just charge them daily. I don’t ever run them out of juice.

Bluetooth: Every now and then, one will disconnect and then immediately reconnect. I haven’t figured this out yet.

Phone conversations: I experimented with my wife with five different earbuds, back to back. And she immediately said these X1s sound the best.

So, best yet of TOZO’s attempt to make the best earbuds - for half the price of the “best” out there.

title: Marginal performance improvements over the original but still worth it
text:
I love the Godox Movelink wireless mic system since the first version. These mics are just as good as any other top brand system on the market, but in my opinion the Godox version just looks better.

Honestly the mkII version only offers marginal improvements over the original version, but if you use these systems for work or paid gigs, then it’s well worth the upgrade. Otherwise if you just use the original Movelink system for personal use or small projects, you could probably save that money to invest in some of Godox’s other amazing products, such as their lights, as great audio and great lighting are the key elements to amazing production value.

The Movelink mk II comes with just about everything the mk I came with in the kit, but the new textured design on the units look much better. They are basically identical in size and weight. The display on the mk II seems to have a higher resolution than the original, as the information on screen is a lot less pixelated. The improved display also gives you color, and for me that makes it stand out more and easy to identify when I monitor my levels.

There is a slight improvement on the signal transmission as I did notice I could get a little more range when line of sight was broken. The audio quality is still as amazing as it has always been in the original Movelink. I’m not sure but I feel like the lav mics have been improved or the unit itself just has improved connectivity, as the audio I recorded through the lav mic was just a little cleaner.

The battery life is great for these units. I know I can get through any session or project with confidence. The carry case quickly recharges your units in between use and the case itself charges fairly fast through the industry standard usb-c connection.

There are a ton of little attachments and all the cables you need, come in this kit. The only feature lacking on this new model, that I wish they had incorporated would be the ability to record audio straight to the transmitter. That would give you a safeguard for your audio if you somehow lost signal, but this is in no way a reason to not purchase as the improved transmission greatly limits those scenarios.

The Movelink upgraded version is an amazing kit and will serve majority, if not all users flawlessly.

title: Well Suited for Smaller TVs, etc.
text:
I have a home recording studio that I've been using to digitize old VHS tapes and make copies of DVDs for friends and family. YES! Some people still watch DVDs. But I've grown tired of the piddling sound from these dinky little PC speakers. That's when I found the LARKSOUND Small Sound Bar. Its a great alternative to the usual tiny tinny speakers you get with small TVs, monitors, smart phones and tablets, etc.

If you're looking to upgrade your bedroom TV or PC audio, the LARKSOUND Small Sound Bar is adecent choice. It's not going to replace your JBL Soundbar and Woofer in the living room. But despite its compact size, it delivers room-filling sound with a scaled back built-in subwoofer that produces clear and dynamic audio. With professionally tuned EQ modes for music, movies, voice, and normal, you can expect explosions, dialogue, and even subtle details in your favorite films to sound far crisper and more defined than ever before. And it gets plenty loud for a medium sized room.

What's more, the soundbar comes with a unique night mode that lowers the volume by 50% and compresses the bass to prevent disturbing others while they sleep, though I don't know anyone that's trying to "suppress" their bass...more like BOOST the bass if possible. I like that this soundbar also offers multiple connectivity options, including Bluetooth 5.0, USB, AUX IN, HDMI, and optical connections, making it incredibly versatile. The BT worked flawlessly, was easy to connect and readily reconnected when I tested it out.

The compact and low-profile design of this soundbar means that it won't take up much space in your room, and it easily fits under your TV. It's flat so you might even be able to set the TV on it, assuming its small-sized. You also get a remote control, an optical cable, an AUX cable, and a wall mounting kit, including a mounting template and step-by-step guide for easy installation. Pretty cool setup for a secondary unit.

Overall, the LARKSOUND Small Sound Bar is a great all-in-one solution for enhancing your TV or PC audio and making your movie and gaming experience even more enjoyable.

title: Best for the Money at MSRP?!
text:
Let me start by saying obviously - this is the hardest card to get on the market. Ironically, it was also a budget choice for me due to the fact that 3080ti's are selling well above this on the aftermarket and third-party vendors are selling their 3080ti's for the same if not more expensive so it was an easy choice for me to get this card since I have the intention to water-cool it at some point.

Performance - it is the top of the top, the only knock is the temps under high load so what I recommend is buying new thermal pads and replacing them (I Used Thermalright Extreme Oddesey 1.5mm) for more efficient cooling. It is super easy to do and there are tons of videos on how to do it as well. You CANNOT lose your warranty for disassembling the product - so don't fear as this is a relatively easy task to do.

Build - I was SHOCKED with how heavy this GPU weighed and it is because it is made VERY WELL. Also, it should be it is $1500! It has caps for all the screws, the fans run really quietly, and generally just feels good to the touch. Being my first reference card ever bought I was blown away with how much better its construction is vs some 3rd party vendors. On a side note, this card is HUGE - it was about 3/4th the size of my G915 Full-size keyboard so make sure your case and PCI slot can fit this as it is a huge and heavy card. Make sure you get a bracket for your motherboard as well to prevent GPU sag. This card does have two white (non-RGB) lights that are either both on or both off, they aren't very bright so if you don't particularly care for them or the color it isn't a big deal as you can only slightly see them through tinted glass.

Conclusion- If you can secure this card and afford it, It is the best on the market in the 1400+ range and especially so at MSRP. Bragging rights, frames and a solid-looking card that can blend in with most builds is what you can look forward to. It is super easy to say this is the best card on the market when many can't get it - but if you get the chance to at MSRP I would pull the trigger every single time on this card.

title: Works great! But beware during installation…
text:
This screen protector was one of the first that I found on Amazon that specifically called out being compatible with the new Canon R50 (released 3/16/23). I figured I would give it a shot and see how it went. Overall I feel like it will provide plenty of protection for the touchscreen. And with the R50, you will likely be using the touchscreen more often then with other mirrorless cameras.
I am no stranger to installing screen protectors as I have them on just about every device I own with a screen, even the touchscreen in our car! Installation of this screen protector was no different and went on just as you would expect. The kit comes with everything you need to install the three screen protectors, including the wet and dry wipes, “dust-absorber” and guide stickers, and as a bonus, they even threw in a hot shoe plug with a bubble level. All of this was in a nice plastic storage case.
However, the installation was not a flawless experience due to the quality of the wipes and stickers. The wet and dry wipes left a hazy residue on the screen that I had to go back and re-clean with isopropyl alcohol and a microfiber cloth. The “dust-absorber” stickers also had extremely strong adhesive that stuck completely to my camera screen, and again left a stick residue that had to be cleaned off with alcohol and a microfiber cloth. I would recommend not using these included items to begin with, and just use your own solution and cloth prior to installing the screen protector.
When the screen protector is installed, it fits the screen very nicely and has a nice feel to it. It also seems to resist fingerprints a little better than the original coating on the camera screen itself. The only thing I have noticed is that when you rotate the screen inwards and close it down, it does now sit slightly higher than the rest of the camera body. It still is held in place, so I do not see this as being a big issue, but it is something to be aware of.
Overall, I highly recommend this screen protector but time will tell how well it holds up in the long run. If anything major changes or I feel like I need to change my rating and I will update this post. Five stars for the quality of the screen protector, but taking off one star due to the added work required if you use the included materials to prepare your screen.

title: Highly stylish, and fits like a perfect glove
text:
I tried seven different cases for my RX 10 IV, and this is by far my favorite. I also use two other of the cases occasionally when I need more room.

Pros:
1- very compact and fits perfectly.
2- really easy to use. Very quick access to camera as needed.
3- really easy to put the camera way after use.
4- incredibly well designed, and made. A feast for the eyes.
5- a quick release plate can be screwed into the bottom of the case, but you do need one that will go off center.

Cons:
1- will not accommodate a polarizer on the lens, nor an L bracket or quick release plate on the camera.
2- no room to store any extras.
3- a quick release plate screwed into the bottom of the case will not be very secure. The camera will easily rotate and so the plate can come loose fairly easily. And if you tighten it too tight, the case screw will come off with the plate and it’s a pain to separate them.

The cons don’t bother me because they help allow its very compact size which I really appreciate. I can carry extras in my vest or coat pocket.

I like this much better than the far more expensive Sony case for the RX 10. That case is hard to use, although it is lovely and does allow an L bracket on the camera and a polarizer on the lens. But it is also bigger. The biggest negative is how difficult it is to get the camera out and use it. And then put the camera away. Most unpleasant.

UPDATE: I ordered a second one on March 6. It arrived March 10 from Turkey. Amazing! I wanted a second one because they are so beautifully made.

I tried the one made by Sony for the RX 10 IV, and have found now that it is quite easy to use. It will also accept an L bracket on the camera, and a circular polarizer on the lens. It’s not nearly as stylish as this leather one, but I often use the L bracket and the polarizer so this will now probably get more use than the leather one here. However, I will use this leather one when I don’t think I need the L bracket .

title: Yuk...
text:
I have some 20 year old computer speakers that have been decent (standard two speakers, no sub, I probably paid $30 for them back then?) but I wanted to try this one because of the good reviews, less cable clutter, and I thought the sound quality would actually be better.

Regarding a wired connection I thought it could do audio from USB but it cannot, it must be 3.5mm. It was super buzzy, lots of humming, noticeably louder buzz than my older speakers. Pretty annoying. I then thought I would try the Bluetooth connection. Buzz is completely gone! But, now there is a very annoying quiet "pop" sound every time the speakers go quiet. Thus, if there is no sound coming out of your computer and say you get a notification sound it will have a slight "pop" sound once the notification sound ends as if the speakers are being turned off. Super annoying. No way would I use Bluetooth connection for the speaker. Thus all connection methods produce annoying sounds.

What about sound quality? I would say it's easily well below average. If all you need is for sound to come out of your computer and don't care one bit about sound quality, especially music, then it is just fine for that. But the music sound quality is pretty bad honestly. Very hollow and tinny sounding, no real bass to speak of. This is probably due to the speakers being pretty small and so you can only expect so much out of something this small. So I can't really fault this too much. Also there is no sense of "surround" sound at all. It very much sounds like it's coming only from where the speakers are directly at. Below your ears and directly forward. My older speakers are spaced maybe 1 to 1.5 feet to the side of my ears and it sounds miles better in terms of surround sound both vertically and horizontally.

The sound quality would have been enough for me to want to return this soundbar. But the buzzing and popping noises coming out of it were enough for me to decide to return it before even listening to the sound quality. I will either be returning back to my old speakers or maybe looking elsewhere for a better soundbar.

For everyone else, if you aren't annoyed by these noises and don't really care about sound quality then these might be a good cheap set of speakers that have minimal footprint and minimal cables on your desk.

title: Underwhelming, Asus seems to have something to hide
text:
So, I bought this router because I needed a WiFi 6 capable router for VR streaming (I had an ancient WiFi 4 router before). I also planed on having a proper home network and building a set of hardware for it.

It was ok-ish when I bought it about 2 years ago, however, it is very underwhelming now. Though, I do realize that the price-range of this router might be too low to be considered high-end.

Just to give people a heads up, the AX3000 has very underwhelming hardware for the price. It has a 3 core CPU (I have a feeling that they are all chips with either defects or didnt pass QC with 1 core disabled, an odd number of cores is a major red flag for that). The CPU is somewhat underwhelming, along with the amount of RAM being very underwhelming as well. It may be able to handle a rather normal home situation where there are a couple PCs, phones, and smart devices quite well, but the moment you start moving into power user territory, it begins to fall apart. Just go to the official ASUS site and look at the page for this router. If you compare it to some of their really nice stuff, you can see that its suspiciously missing its information about the CPU.

I get stuttering occasionally when trying to wirelessly stream with my VR headset, and I do see that my software automatically limits my bandwidth to anywhere between 70-100mb/s when the max should be 150mb/s (I am more than able to push that with my system, it is a 5800X3D + 32GB of 3600mhz CL16 with a 4090 on a X570 chipset). When running everything maxed, I only push my CPU and GPU to 50% or less. I am less than 10m away from my headset as well.

If you are going to be a power user, this router might not be a good option. For non-power users, it may be just fine.

Looking to possibly replace this thing with a proper high-end quad+ core CPU 1Gb+ RAM WiFi 6 model that will do fine till Wifi 7 is rolled out and commonly available most likely (WiFi 6E is a weird transitory spec). This router is going to be relegated to mesh wifi extension/for non-active non-intense streaming.

title: Great sound for its size
text:
Bought two to use in a 4000 sq ft workshop, based largely on people saying they have good bass and are waterproof. I live near the coast where things tend to rust if they aren’t made not to, so waterproof seemed like a good thing.

They work properly and sound like real speakers instead of tinny like most Bluetooth speakers. The battery life has been excellent for me - I’ve used them roughly 8 hours at full volume with the lights flashing and they till show to be almost fully charged. The size is a bit smaller than the advertising pictures suggest, and the party lights aren’t as bright as they imply but I’m the only one dancing in the shop anyway!

Sound quality is really good, actually. Even my 20-something kids (years old, not how many kids!) were impressed and tried to steal my speakers for their rooms. As some have said, they aren’t INCREDIBLY loud but for me they fill the building sufficiently loudly to be heard plenty clearly over drills and general noise. I like a LOT of bass and they again do better than any BT speaker I’ve ever found, but there’s only so much boom you can get from a 3” speaker. I put one inside and empty steel cabinet with the doors open to see if it would enhance the bass - it does! Too much, actually. Makes it sound muddy. Maybe try a smaller cabinet.

Sound quality - very good (for a BT speaker! This will never replace a dedicated woofer but you also don’t have to transport or power a huge system when you have this!)

Pretty lights - Pretty! Look good in the dark.

Equalizer button - just turns the bass on & off.

Connecting - Works easy every time for me. Only issue I’ve had is when my daughter has her phone’s Bluetooth turned on it defaults to her phone instead of mine. I need to get her to forget my speaker to solve that.

Stereo pairing - worked easily and well for me. And I like that adjusting any feature on the unit you select as Master also makes the adjustments on the follower unit.

I’m happy!

title: Wow! Wow! Wow! Artcise AS95C is a beautiful, precise, and light tank of a tripod.
text:
Today, I received my Artcise AS95C, complete with the following:

1. AS95C
2. Fixed base plate with hook for adding weight below (all metal, removable)
3. Bowl and bowl base (installed, all metal except sturdy ABS handle)
4. Extension column (carbon fiber and metal)
5. Cell phone holder (all metal)
6. Bracket for connecting phone holder or other accessories into 3/8 threaded connector hole on side of triangular tripod base (all metal)
7. Three removable rubber feet (installed)
8. Three removable metal spikes
9. Two large hex wrenches for adjusting holding force (resistance of opening/closing) of tripod legs
10. One small hex wrench for adjusting various grub screws
11. Six 1/4 to 3/8 screw adapters
12. Padded and lined thick nylon case with adequate space, two zippered inner accessory pockets, two heavy-duty zippers that run along entire exterior length and around enlarged end
to gain access to grab the tripod and pull out at its head and/or to fully open case from end to end, an incorporated handle with velcro-joined handle, and an adjustable shoulder strap that connects at both ends of the case
13. Instruction Manual (in Chinese and English) with illustrated, well-written instructions

I am truly stunned by the very high quality of materials, build quality with fit and finish, sturdiness and precision of every component, and last but not least, the beauty of this lightweight tank of a tripod.

I have just received one of the most incredible bargains that I have ever purchased on Amazon. This tripod is so incredibly good. I have absolutely no doubts that I will get many very good years of use with it for my casual photography and well as my resurging astrophotography hobby.

Do not blink or hesitate, if you want an extremely impressive lightweight tank of a tripod at a terrific price that must be only 20% or 25% of what you would reasonably expect to routinely pay any day for such a beautiful, precise, and sturdy beast of such very, very high quality.

Very highly recommended!

title: Buen Rendimiento a Excelente Precio
text:
Después de varias comparativas me decanté por este producto que en el momento de su compra contaba con un descuento aproximado de USD $30.
Su diseño y apariencia visuales me agradan bastante.
A los pocos días de haberlo comprado, la actualización a Windows 11 ya estaba disponible para descargar y actualizar.
Me agrada bastante el poder ubicarlo en un sitio específico y conectarlo a cualquier monitor o televisor disponible, pero a la vez contar con la posibilidad de trasladarlo fácilmente en cualquier momento, sin que su tamaño implique algo más engorroso, como sucede con los pc de escritorio.
Aunque mi opción de compra no cuenta con una memoria y tamaño de almacenamiento generoso (sólo 8 GB de RAM y SSD M.2 de 128 GB), el fabricante confirma que se pueden ampliar hasta 32 GB (2x16) de RAM, y 2TB (compatible también con NVMe) de almacenamiento interno; así que el límite es prácticamente sólo nuestro bolsillo.
El único "pero" que le encontré es que ni en el manual ni en la página oficial del fabricante, encontré indicaciones sobre la finalidad del puerto USB C ubicado en la parte frontal, ya que no reconocía dispositivos externos conectados allí; y la respuesta la obtuve de una asesora llamada Sofía (de Soporte Técnico de Amazon), quien me indicó que éste se encontraba disponible sólo como un CONECTOR DE CARGA opcional para el PC, a quien agradezco por su amabilidad para atender y la información que recibí con respecto a mi inquietud.

title: Security monitoring for anyone at a low price.
text:
While this camera may not have exactly the features that you want, when tested against the features described in the manual I have to give it a high rating. When you consider that this is one of the lowest-priced devices of this class out there and it includes a solar panel that allows completely wireless operation, it is hard to beat.

I have tested every function described in the manual for this camera (except for subscription cloud storage) and everything works as advertised. It should be noted that pan and tilt, video, and audio are all a little sluggish or delayed, but I have not run into any WiFi camera of this type in this price range that is not. The Android app also has some occasional quirks and lags, but again, compared to a few other systems that I have tested I find this to be the best.

The video is quite sharp with good color rendition under daylight or even flood-lit night conditions. Under very low light conditions the camera switches to monochrome and opens its internal IR filter to make it sensitive to the built-in IR LED illumination. The monochrome night vision sensitivity is very good. The pan and tilt controls have adjustable speeds, but given that there is a delay between pressing a direction button and the actual movement I tend to keep the speed setting on low to prevent overshooting. Digital zoom is like any other with a limited resolution camera - don't expect much usable enhancement.

It's unfortunate that these WiFi cameras by different manufacturers really don't have any standardization that could make them work together or as part of a central software-based monitoring system. Different camera manufacturers have their own software apps, and some are good and others are terrible. This particular camera is well suited to monitoring a remote area that is without power, although the solar panel will only support intermittent operation-upon-detection and not continuous recording and lighting. And if you are out of WiFi range it does record to its internal memory card, but you will need to retrieve the card to review any events.

The portability and true cordless option with the solar panel makes this well-suited to setting up wherever you currently have a need, whether it be watching for porch package or catalytic converter thieves, mailbox bashers, or nefarious acts by neighbors from hell.

I believe this to be a good deal for the price.

title: Spacious and Good for Travelling
text:
This is a good backpack for frequent travelers when you need to pack stuff for your frequent trips and always be on the move. This provides plenty of room for apparel and other items such as a laptop, brush, razors, shaving kit, toiletries, and so on. It comes with two inner net zippers that can hold tiny items conveniently in place. Two front pockets where you can hold your travel documents like passport, air tickets, etc. The large front pocket has enough space to hold a 17-inch laptop. The bigger inner compartment, as you would expect, has a center elastic band to keep clothing in place. It can sufficiently hold stuff for 3 days just fine, and if you need some additional room, you can expand it by an additional 2 inches in height with exterior expandable zippers. It comes with a USB 2.0 powerbank adaptor, which is useful when I want to attach my powerbank, which stays inside securely and charges my phone from the outside. Bag seems water repellent. Four-sided buckles are perfect for keeping this securely and tightly packed. This is all good stuff.
Overall, this is decent backpack and can be given a try.

There are a few drawbacks and improvements that would make it an ideal travel backpack:
1. It comes with only one mesh pocket, and that too on the other side, where there is no USB outlet. It would have been nice to have another mesh pocket near the USB outlet so I could easily attach my phone and keep it in the mesh pocket. 2. I didn't find any of the zippers lockable as advertised. Also, only the zippers in the main compartment may be lockable somehow, but for sure not the zipper where I would keep my laptop or other electronic stuff. 3. There is no padding in the area to keep the laptop secure. 4. The advertised front picture on the listing is not what I got. I got different front pockets than shown in the picture. 5. Zippers at the corners seem to be skipping the zip teeth, which would eventually cause the zips to fail with frequent use. 6. There is a back pocket zipper right under the breathable mesh padding that doesn't seem very useful, in my opinion, and would be highly inconvenient when you hold the backpack on your back. I would rather not keep anything in there and keep it fully breathable, as seems to be the idea from the manufacturer.

title: Decent, But Not Professional
text:
I ordered this as a backup tripod when stability is not as important as size.

First, the plusses, This tripod is nicely finished. It is smooth and has no chips, dings, or sharp protrusions. One of the legs detaches and can be used as a monopod. You can remove the ball head from the tripod and attach it to the monopod. You can also remove the entire center column and attach it to the monopod. In terms of height, with the legs and center column fully extended, your camera will be sitting nearly 80 inches off the ground. The angle of the legs is adjustable, with three different presets. Set to their largest angle, the bottom of the tripod will be about 4 inches off the ground and the camera will be about 2 feet off the ground. The locks for extending the legs are easy to operate and hold the legs very securely. The center column can be inverted. The tripod comes with 2 generic Arca Swiss type plates for mounting onto your camera, a mount for a cell phone, a carrying case, a couple of allen wrenches, a user manual, and a warranty card.

Now for the negatives. The ball head is very basic. There is a single lock, so getting the camera completely level can be a challenge. Also, the ball head is pretty small, and you can't expect to use this tripod with a heavy DSLR or a camera with a heavy telephoto attached. The center column suffers from an issue common to inexpensive tripods. That is, it wobbles slightly from side to side. This issue is worse when the column is extended. Locking the center column after extending it with a camera attached is cumbersome because you need to hold the camera with one hand while tightening the center column with the other,

If you don't own a tripod, and you don't need to mount a heavy camera, this tripod might be good enough for you. It's a cut above the typical "cheap" tripod in terms of both versatility and finish. But if you want to attach a prosumer level DSLR, a medium format or larger film camera, or a mirrorless with a long lens, you'll need to bite the price bullet and spend 2 to 3 times the cost of this tripod for an entry level "pro" tripod.

title: SoundPeats Failing Quality / DONT UPDATE EARBUDS VIA APP
text:
I'd like to begin this with saying that I got introduced to SoundPeats by a Kickstarter of there's for the TrueEngine 2s and that I'm a Kickstarter backer for both the TrueEngine 2s and the H1s.

And that to this day those TrueEngine 2s still work and sound amazing if not a little quiet. Unlike the H1s.

I own both the TrueEngine 2s and the H1s (2 Sets of H1). I also own the Truegine 3 SEs.

Out of those four, the only set that works are the TrueEngine 2s.

The true engine threes both work. however, for some reason their drivers have made it so that they only max out at 50% volume. I've checked it on both my computer and my phones and they confirms that they have a driver error.

I've also checked on my H1s that they also have driver errors. on both sets of h1s I own the left side is significantly quieter than the right side. I would say the left side is at about 40% volume compared to the 100% of the right side.

I've gone through support for this and that's why I own two sets of H1. That's cause my first set came from the kickstarter and it developed that problem after the update. I then got the new set to replace it from Support and it worked fine at the beginning. Then it got updated and now it's broken too.

So out of H1 Premium (Kickstarter), H1 (Replacement, TrueEngine 3 SE, and TrueEngine 2s (Kickstarter). The only one that works fully are the TrueEngine 2s. The oldest earbuds out of them all. Though the paint has begun chipping paint due to age and use. The other 3 sets have no proper reason to fail besides poor Quality Control and Drivers.

They sound great and have amazing features and latency. When they work that is. Now they're just pretty pebbles I own.

I'm not sure if I should go back to support because it's been a while and the fact that if I go back to support I just might get another broken product. I'm skeptical of ever buying a SoundPeats Product again.

title: What a PHENOMENAL value
text: I simply can't believe what you get for under $200. I received mine within a few days of ordering (I think it was supposed to be 2 day, there was a delay, and I got it in 3 ... but still). Admittedly, I didn't get it working immediately, and I emailed the support. They responded within 24 hours, and I had a second questions and they responded again within 24 hours. They provided PDF of installation manuals. The thing I had missed is that CANBUS didn't exist last time I installed a car stereo and didn't know what it was and didn't know it was required and essential. It is. And that's not really clarified in the manual. But it really is 'plug and play' -- click in the Power Harness (it is 100% obvious where both ends of this go) and click in CANBUS DECODER onto the CANBUS Harness, and again once you know this is needed it obvious what to do, and it powers on works perfectly. Apparently the CANBUS allows all sorts of specifications with your model, so for example, when I turn my headlights on or off, it impacts the illumination of the radio -- it is amazingly tailored. The ZLink application works 100% and needed no set-up on my Android phone. I'm a bit of an audiophile, or so I fancy myself, and have Amazon Music HD tracks [192Hz and 24bit] downloaded to my phone. I use the wired Android Auto feature, and as you can see in the photos I attached, it streams through the USB cable Hi-Rez to the amplifier.
