Speaking of, at 4x 45Watts, it isn't the blaringly loud, but plenty loud enough for me, and if you want more, you can add an aftermarket applifier and have even better fidelity and still amazing value. The sound I get is crystal clear. Plus, all the features of an Android 11 tablet. My Google maps and calendar and messenger all integrated seamlessly without my having to do a thing. And, for goodness sake, it comes with the frame which I had practically zero issues installing. I feel like I'm driving a high-end custom install. Could not be happier, and at less than $200, I'm blown away. You can't even get a "regular" car stereo for that these days, let along an over-sized 10" tablet screen and frame. If you have the right model, just get it.

title: Stays in place with comfort for toddlers- total confidence in headphone success!!
text:
Trust me.. from one who’s tried them all- if you want headphone to fit a toddler or little one choose a style such as this!! A wider band over the head actually is whats needed to hold in place. the comfort helps kiddos not to fuss with or remove! Bands padded fit rests right atop the crown of head to hold steady.. and adjustable length lets you customize and even grow with child to use for years.. how great is that!!

Avoid my mistakes trying to save a few $. I tried old school Walkman skinny type headset- using everything but duct tape and bubble gum to MacGyver a secure fit.. it was a total bust!! (I tried sweatband, ball cap bandana rag.. even hair styles like a ponytail + clippies to hold but, nope!) Ha! and earbuds?! It sounded good at the time- only lets just say to spare a longer read.. I have just x1 bud left! Getting a realistic design compatible for kiddos wiggles is a must- just like this has. Offered at a respectable price.. is icing on the cake!

Ear cushions like tiny “donut pillows” plume outward the so no hard plastic presses against ear.. comfort’s what brings a toddler to forget device is even there! Ergonomic style cups also keep the sound from escaping.. ideal if you can’t tolerate another round of “baby shark or cocomelon” sing-along x1 more time!

Volume feature is brilliant with a safety level it place, it cant get dialed up to harm eardrums.. and yet still able to deliver respectable sound quality! Love old-school plug-in method… Kids can use themselves.. Bluetooth option usually requires adult help! Splitter is nice feature for sibling/buddy use- haven’t used but, glad it’s there.

Foldable design is perf. for use on the go.. slip in carryon for airplane, road trip in car.. or, store easy at home! Comes with carry bag- my only wish is this included a hard case to protection vs. nylon pullstring! Otherwise, it’s perf. Great gift or spoiler for little.. 4.5 star for sure. Hoping info helps decision- stay safe everyone.

title: A quality filter with a thin rim - particularly suitable for use on ultra-wide angle lenses
text:
The filter I received (NiSi 77mm UV filter) fits the product description and my basic expectations - a coated UV filter with an extra-thin rim.

I can't readily verify the claims of an "ultra hard coating" (more resistant against scratching) and "double-sided nano coating" (repels water and dust, so the filter stays clean longer). But I can see that it has anti-reflection coatings, as expected in any quality photographic filter.

The mechanical machining of the rim, including the thread, looks very good; it easily and smoothly screwed onto my Canon L lens. 

I measured the rim thickness with a digital caliper - 3.56mm. This is indeed thinner than a typical/traditional 77mm filter rims. (For example, a brand-name Japanese 77mm UV filter I just checked was ~4.70mm thick.) And this makes this filter particularly suitable for use on ultra wide angle lenses that can be prone to vignetting.

(Vignetting: The darkening of image corners due to partial blocking of light rays, that could be caused by using a filter (or multiple filters) having a thick rim. Actually, however, most brand-name lenses are designed with filter use in mind, so this shouldn't be a problem on most lenses. But slim filters have become increasingly common in recent years, mostly because filter manufacturers can use it as a point of product differentiation from competitors - not so much because it's so necessary or better.)

In terms of value, lately I am seeing more and more exorbitantly overpriced photography filters on Amazon - some costing more than a brand-name camera lens! In the sea of crazy expensive filters, this product appears to be a little more sensibly priced. And I like that about this product.

Overall I have no complaints. So I am giving it 5 stars.

(Personally, though, I have come to prefer a Japanese Hoya filter or a German B+W filter over the years. It doesn't mean others are bad. But quality control can be harder to predict with other manufacturers, in my personal experience.)

- - - -

As measured (77mm filter):
- Rim thickness: 3.56mm

title: RUN FOR YOUR LIFE
text:
[[VIDEOID:6117fedf0fd342a72b5d1dd56900e426]] Picture it: you’re a full time work-from-home employee who is also a mom to a toddler and an infant. You finally get your toddler down for a nap. The baby finally dozes off after rocking her for 30 minutes. AT LAST, you have a spare few minutes to get some work done.

You pull up your two excel sheets to begin working (which are the only things running on this BRAND NEW COMPUTER that was delivered yesterday) and it takes the computer LITERALLY 92 SECONDS TO SCROLL TO THE BOTTOM OF ONE SHEET. Yes, I timed it. You finally get to the bottom but wait, it scrolled too far to the blank cells, you have to scroll back up, 32 SECONDS LATER, and OH NO it went too far again. 34 seconds later, you get to the right place. You click copy. You wait until the other sheet finally loads, you click on the cell to hit paste. Nothing happens. You click on another cell, nothing happens. BUT WAIT it finally clicks the other cell. Sweet. BUT WAIT it finally clicks the next cell. You click back to the other cell and pray to whatever god you believe in that you can, at last, paste your data. NOPE STILL NOT THERE. IT FROZE. YOU CANNOT MOVE FROM THIS SCREEN. YOU CANNOT PASS GO. YOU CANNOT COLLECT $200. YOU LOSE.

The baby wakes up. The toddler starts screaming. You’ve lost any glimmer of hope in your work-from-home journey. I bought this strictly to use for transferring excel spreadsheet data, a single column of 145 cells of VERY simple data to be specific, which should be no problem unless you’re living in the pits of hades that is this computer. But alas, the memory gods frown upon whatever horrible device this is. You had one job, literally.

Returning this worthless excuse of a computer as soon as I can get my babies dressed to go to the UPS store.

0/10 recommend.

Video of me simply trying to open said spreadsheet. It BARELY made it in time for the 60 second time maximum.

title: Very responsive, easy to use after a few days learning and adapting
text:
Context is probably needed:

Post carpal tunnel surgery, developed tendonitis - ulnar deviation, not flexion - so moving a normal mouse on the surface of a mousepad side to side was very painful. I also have Rheumatoid Arthritis and other trackball mice had such stiff buttons I had difficulty clicking the buttons.

The Relacon mouse is not perfect, but it has enabled me to do dragging and dropping (photos in MS Publisher). On 'normal' mice, dragging and dropping requires continuous pressing down of the Right mouse button and moving the position of the entire mouse. With the Relacon mouse, a very light pressure with the middle finger and gentle very minute movement of my thumb on the trackball will move and item. You do have to learn to be still when hovering the mouse (using the trackball) cursor over an item and waiting for the + to indicate that the mouse can select the object. I found that this took the most time to adjust to when using the Relacon mouse. With 'normal' mice you can click and grab an item more quickly - but only a split second more quickly.

I haven't yet used the adjustable settings on the Relacon mouse, but so far after several weeks using it - at a distance of 10ft from a large screen and also at a normal distance from my desktop computer - the mouse (in combination with a tented split keyboard) has allowed my wrist inflammation to disappear almost completely.

I don't know if anyone else reading this would want to know this, but I searched everywhere and this was the ONLY mouse that allows you to move objects without moving your whole mouse on a mousepad while allowing you to maintain an ergonomic position (45 degree angle as you would see on a vertical mouse).

The only downside to the Relacon design is that if you have issues where you need to keep your wrist flexion neutral (to avoid carpal tunnel syndrome) and avoid ulnar deviation, you have to rigourously train yourself to hold the Relacon mouse in the correct position. I did this by propping my hand holding the Relacon mouse on my upper thigh at the right angle and then I leave it there in a relaxed position. It took about 1 week to train myself (8 hrs a day on a computer). So, it's not perfect, but it is better than anything else out there.

title: A WINNER THAT MAY NOT SEEM LIKE AN ESSENTIAL  - UNTIL YOU TRY IT!
text:
Who knew a small bit of blue silicone could be so life-changing?

NEVER LOSE YOUR ROKU REMOTE AGAIN!
1) It's blue! (Or your choice of color) You can see it and find it in the darkest of rooms.
2) Non-slip grip keeps the remote where you left it. No more sliding into the couch cushions or off the bedcovers.

BUT THE BEST PART---

No more "Random Netflixing" in the middle of whatever you're watching because you "picked up the remote the wrong way." For YEARS I have grumbled about the branded hot buttons on the Roku remote. Yes, that sponsorship probably keeps the cost down on the units, but HOW MANY TIMES have I made an awkward grab for the remote to pause a movie on one channel and magically found Netflix or Hulu randomly loading because I accidentally hit the button? TOO MANY.

Well NO MORE! The design of this remote sleeve is raised around the hot buttons, so since I've installed it, an errant grab has yet to load a service I was most definitely not watching and not wanting to watch. That alone would make this remote wrap worth the price, but it's also saved me at least an hour so far of life in not having to look for it. I'm sold!

Note on installing wristband:
It will be easier if you nudge a paper clip into hole #2 to grab the string you insert into hole #1. I wondered if the strap was really necessary, but it's been very handy to hang the remote off a nightstand knob when I change the sheets on the bed. Also, if you game with your Roku remote, will keep you from inadvertently flinging it across the room.

OVERALL:
This product falls into one of those "Do I really need it?" categories for me, but I've been over the moon with the conveniences. It has solved a lot of minor gripes for me that makes life a little easier, and who doesn't need that nowadays?

Would make a great gift for someone who thinks they don't need it! You will be their hero after a week of using it.

title: Works for Me
text:
My CD player broke, so I decided to rip all my CDs to .flac files to an external drive and play them through Sonos. The ripping went fine after a short learning curve, but Sonos had all kinds of trouble recognizing the drive and I finally resorted to running it thru a Roku 3 (using the USB port) with HDMI to the TV and an optical cable from the TV to to a Yamaha S301 integrated amp hooked up to Wharfdale speakers.

Everything worked fine, but the sound wasn't right, actually fatiguing in hour or more sessions. (I am a painter and rely on the music as background and during breaks.) During this time I listened much more to vinyl and that was obviously part of the reason I was having difficulty appreciating the digital sound feed. The Sonos was now working, but spotty, so I was pretty much relegated to the USB thru Roku.

So, after researching DACs, including those in the Yamaha and the Sonos Connect, and including all those who say there is no real difference between DACs, I decided to try one and settled on the Modi 3E.

Wow. There is no question that the sound is much improved; much better than I anticipated. Sonos is now fixed and I decided to try running that thru the DAC as well. Noticeable improvement. This system has never sounded this good to me. I really look forward to my listening sessions. It is just great.

Setup is: (for playing from USB stick or drive) Roku 3 (USB Port w USB Stick) HDMI>TV Optical Cable>Modi 3E RCA>Yamaha S301 RCA> Sonos Connect
...and (for Sonos connection) Synology Router USB Port with Seagate 2TB External Drive; Sonos Connect Digital Cable>Modi 3E (with RCA to S301 and RCA from S301 to Sonos Connect)

The difference is notable enough to me that I started thinking about how much better could it get. But even if the next level DAC would make a noticeable next level improvement, for now that's irrelevant. The sound I have is great. I don't need to improve it. I enjoy it and really don't think I need to make any more changes. The Modi 3E was a great decision.

title: It works... barely.
text:
I just decided to test my new unit and was hit by a bit of a surprise. It says I should be able to get 11 mins at half load and 2.5 mins at full load. I'm at 1/4 load (250w) and my "Estimated Runtime" and "Battery Capacity" dropped from 29 min. and 100% to 10 min. and 43% in under a minute. My system wouldn't have even have been able to fully shut down in that 30 seconds or so I had remaining. Now I have to wait a few hours for it to charge just to be able to attempt to test "Preserve Battery Power" as the "Keep Computer Running" option mins out at "5 minutes" which, by my math here is about 15 seconds, if I'm lucky.

I saw a bunch of reviews of people being pissed about getting a used unit, I made sure mine was not, but it functions like a used unit on it's last days as far as my initial test would suggest. The only reason this is getting 2 stars is because my system did stay powered on for a minute or so and the app actually seems to work. Though, as I said before, I haven't been able to fully test the "Runtime Configuration" options yet. I will update if anything changes, but I don't anticipate they will.

Update: So, I set it to "Preserve Battery Power" and toggled it to "0 minutes" so that when power goes out my system immediately shuts down, leaving the absolute most amount of time for my system to shut down, in case something went wrong. I unplugged the UPS, forcing it into battery mode to test it and see what it does and if it will work in the event of a power outage. Yes, it effectively shut down my computer, but it seems to have borked my BIOS. I'm assuming it has something to do with the fact that the power, according to two different independent YouTubers who tested this exact device, is in fact, NOT a pure sine wave, but rather an odd stepped version of it. Now my RAM profile is disabled and I can't get into my BIOS at all. My system had no issues shutting down and turning back on on normal wall power, but being plugged into this thing has just cut my overall RAM performance by 1/3 and made it to where I can't fix it.

title: Straight Up AWESOME 👍 Worth the price
text:
****Some quick updates!!!

The phone call feature works great. I was able to accept calls, the caller could hear me without a problem, and I could hear them fine. All those features work as expected.

BUT....now, I do have to say, I put music on the device to play back, and this feature does not work at all. Therefore, I gotta deduct a star for that issue.

Still though, the blue tooth connects to my phone so I can listen to my music on the go that way, or if at home, on my laptop, etc. Overall, a super product for the price e range. 👍

ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW ****

I was lucky enough to get a chance to test and review these Bone Conduction headphones through the Amazon Vine Voice program.

These are FANTASTIC 😊

Wow!! I had no idea this type of headphones even existed. They came nicely boxed, and they are soooooo simple to use. And, yes, they truly take 1 hour to charge (as advertised), then these are incredibly simple to pair with any device. I decided to use these headphones for running so I paired them with my phone, but you could pair them with other devices, laptops, etc.

Next, wow, the comfort is spectacular. They stay in place, and you don't even notice them. Not to mention, the bone conduction setup means you don't have to shove ear buds in your ear canal, which is great for better hygiene, ear health, and safety because you can still hear what's happening around you.

Honestly, I wish I would have found something like this years ago. These are totally worth the cost, and I love using them. AWESOME PRODUCT 😁👍👍👍

Oh!! And, being waterproof/water-resistant is super helpful because my last run was in storm conditions so they performed great plus there is no latency in my music, and the controls are easy to access as well.

Please note, I did not use them for phone calls so that is a feature I still need to test. I will say, even without trying that - I couldn't be happier with using these for my runs.

title: We LOVE our ALEXAS, Own 3 and gifted 3!!
text: We love so much all our Alexa’s. We have a 3rd gen, two 4th gens and 4th gen with clock and now a 5th gen as a gift. All white and charcoal. They are amazing. So helpful when needed, we listen to music daily via pandora or Amazon everyday. Great for homework or instant questions. Got this for my father whom is a doctor working from a home office via telemedicine. This was perfect for him for any questions he may have. He also bought a Samsung QLED smart TV which works with Alexa and I thought this would help him navigate how to use the television more easily. We haven’t hooked anything up just yet, but excited too. The charcoal is nice coloring for his office too. So many possibilities. I have mine in LR  with smart Amazon plug which turned on off my Xmas tree. Will be getting more plugs too. So many possibilities sky is the limit. Love the payment options as well gives an opportunity to get multiple at once as gifts. Also gifted one to my Neice last year the gen white 4 and she loves it,  got same for my brother too . Amazing for all ages. Literally we are 8-78yrs. So compact easy to display. Modern looking. Picks up commands well. Gives weather if requested. Download app to make all your preferences easy and personalize it to just you.  Responds to your voice command. Name it with the small choices it gives. We have an Echo, Alexa, and a Ziggy… we chose different names for our home so when we command her they all don’t go off at once. We set reminders and errand lists.  I do wish they gave more naming options for this purpose but we are lucky we have enough names for the amount owned. We love them. It’s a cool device and everyone should have one! Makes life so easy at times. The pictures listed are of my white gen 4 clock choice but the gen 5 charcoal looks the same just diff color (this gen 5 doesn’t have clock option) . I believe it’s the software that separates the two. Wanted to give you a picture of what would look like. Connect to your Amazon account and will notify you when your packages come, and any updates regarding your account. As you see mine is lit yellow at the base stating I have a notification. Sound quality is amazing. Little goes long way.

title: Almost my favorites of 2022
text:
While I didn't try every higher end earbud that came out in 2022, these ranked 2nd among those I tried (including releases from Sony, Jabra, Bang and Olufsen, OnePlus, and more). The top spot went to the Bang and Olufsen EX (super pricey at $400, but the sound quality is just the best of everything I tried, and they're also quite comfortable for extended use). The Free Byrd from Beyerdynamic ranked slightly lower on sound and comfort. That said, they may have your preferred sound profile, and at their current price, they're a much easier sell than when they first came out. For the rest of the review, I'll break them down by a few areas I think are important.

Sound quality - 9/10. Excellent detail, but no matter how you tweak the sound in the app, they tend toward the warm side. If you set it to a v-shaped sound profile, it's a bit too warm and bass heavy for me. Others will completely approve of the sound, however. It's definitely among the best I've heard, but I like the slightly more neutral but still warm B&O.

Comfort - 7/10. These are big earbuds. They protrude from your ears more than others will. They fit generally well, but they are slightly more prone to falling out of place or needing adjustment. It's not a huge issue for me, but if you have small ears, you'll likely struggle with these.

ANC - 7.5/10. Good ANC, but nowhere near the industry leaders Sony and Bose. It's not even as good as my Jabras. It is, however, better than the B&Os, and these earbuds are half the price of those. If ANC is important to you, these may not be quite good enough, but it's not bad.

Other features - 8/10. You've got most of the standards. Ear detection (which I don't like), a competent app that does some personalized sound, etc.

Overall, these are great, and much easier to recommend at under $200 than at $250, the price at release. If you really want to splurge on the best for sound, I still like the B&O EX better, but those are so pricey...

title: The best at a great price!
text:
I've used this device for several days now. There's so much to like about it.

The design: awesome and solid! Because of my vehicle's cigarette lighter placement, I wasn't sure if this device would fit. It easily fit perfectly. It swivels so you can easily tilt it like you want it. Everything you want it to do is easily found and visually attractive.

The physical look and feel: again, VERY solid. The part of the device that swivels is strong and not at all flimsy. The bass and treble wheels...absolutely solid and easy to adjust. (I love the bass/treble wheel feature.) This device is definitely well made.

The layout: exactly what I would want. The digital display (that shows which radio station it's tuned to) is sized right so I don't have to squint. The placement allows for a quick glance. The "volume wheel" is sized correctly so you don't have to fumble around to find it whilst driving. The equalizer lights are to the right where they should be. The controlling wheels are closer to the driver, right where they should be.

The features: whoever designed this device knew what they were doing. It's feature-packed yet simple enough to set up and operate that I still haven't read the instructions. I love being able to skip to the previous or next song from the device instead of my phone, which is a convenient feature and also one of driving safety if you think about it. The volume wheel is sized well and easy to locate by feel without having to look for it. Besides volume, it also controls answering a call among other things. What most impressed me about it is how much it will do while remaining simple to operate. The dedicated bass and treble wheels: again, they are solid and textured: very easy to use. I didn't think I would use the bass/treble wheels that much but I have. What it wound up doing was making the tunes sound better. Having that feature allows you to adjust the sound of the songs you're streaming without having to change your car radio's sound which is awesome.

The price: perfect, considering what all this device will do and how solidly it's made.

I've used a ton of these things over the years and this one is by far the best.

title: Great Trendy Keyboard That Works, Battery Life Might Be of Concern
text:
This is a great keyboard that serves its purpose. It's definitely trendy and looks awesome with those 3 different modes of lighting: - Rainbow effect, Monochrome light that stays, and Ripple mode which will flash light on each key stroke when typing. These modes are activated by pressing the M1, M2, and M3 keys on the keyboard. There is also a light in the mouse that changes color at random and is controlled by the center button. Keyboard light or backlit can be turned off completely, but this can't be done with mouse light.

Keyboard light can be adjusted, but even at the lowest settings, it's very bright, and that won't be ideal for working in a completely dark room with others trying to sleep. This keyboard and mouse both have a very shallow form factor, and it's a membrane-based keyboard. I'm not very fond of typing on that kind of keyboard and mouse. That's a personal preference, but yes, it's indeed very quiet when I type on this, and that's good.

Pros:
1. Cool and Trendy: Color combinations on keyboard are just awesome and can add a bit of fashion to your game room or home office.

2. Quiet typing: When typing, the keyboard is very quiet, so you can write those long emails without worrying about annoying anyone with that typewriter sound.

3. Feels Sturdy: Both the mouse and keyboard have that rugged feel that suggests they would last longer.

Cons:
1. Smaller Battery and Longer Charge Time: The keyboard has 1600 mAh and the mouse has 650 mAh. Even with this smaller size, it takes a long time to charge. Charging time is 8 hours and 3 hours for the keyboard and mouse, respectively. With this small battery, I did expect a lot faster charge time.

2. Battery Drains Fast and Mouse Wakeup Time: I did observe that the mouse battery drains pretty quickly, and the mouse takes a bit to wake up. The keyboard seems to be working perfectly fine, both with the battery and wakeup time.

3. Slightly Expensive: Other brands of wireless keyboards and mice are available at a lower price and with a larger battery capacity. As a result, this appears to be slightly overpriced for what they offer.

title: Very Nice Webcam
text:
Pros:
Price Point
Picture Quality
Zoomable lens
Tri-pod connectivity
Remote Control Included
USB C adapter included
Dedicated software for the camera
Build quality is nice, it seems decently durable
Nice and well packed
Responsive customer service

Cons:
Privacy shutter is just a flimsy plastic sticker
The remote is sometimes unresponsive
Mic is not the best

I needed a new webcam and I previously had an older Nexigo branded one and I was very pleased with that. The previous still works perfect but I designated that to my work PC and wanted one for the home office.

The N940p did not disappoint and I will be keeping it. With the correct lighting, the picture is super clear and crisp, if you are in a poorly lit space you will see film grain as this is not a dslr, it is a webcam and not a super fancy one at that. This being said, I tested it with just natural day light coming through a window on an overcast day and the low light compensation looked great. Then I tested it at night with not a lot of light and the picture was pretty grainy wherever there wasn't light directly on it. And to be fair, I have never came across a webcam at this price point where you don't get film grain in low lighted areas, its a webcam, not a cinema camera. Now in this low light environment I placed a washed out white light behind my monitor to shine on my face and the picture looked pretty good. The included remote was actually one of the main selling points for me, and it works good. Sometimes it is unresponsive but 95% of the time it works perfect. A cool feature is the power button, you can actually turn it off with the remote as well as pan, zoom, mic controls and image flip.

Overall 4 out of 5 stars, I left one star off due to a few minor things like the mic quality, the included privacy shutters and the remote responsiveness not being perfect.

I would recommend this to anyone who needs a simple webcam for conferencing or video chat, even streaming. But also want the added picture quality and functionality of a zoomable lens and remote control.

title: It Does It All
text:
This 17 inch frame replaces my old 10 inch frame (both pictured for size comparison). I really like the picture quality despite it being a large frame there is no loss in detail. You can load your photos by three methods - all three of which are pretty simple as a 29 page User Manual comes with it along with a USB cable for direct transfer from your computer to the Photo Frame. I also like the remote control that comes with it though you can do most everything by touch screen. You can also upload videos (200MB per clip) which I haven't tried and you can upload music as well.

UPDATE: While pushing my second load of photos into the Mini-SD Card slot, the card slid in past the opening and disappeared into the bowels of the picture frame never to return. I can not retrieve it. It's gone inside the frame somewhere. I spent all evening trying everything I could think of to fish out the SD Card but it's gone. I won't return the frame now with my personal SD card floating around inside the frame with 250 of my favorite photos. They are not copyrighted so where would the card end up? My advise is DO NOT EVER use the Mini-SD Card slot. They can be misaligned and you'll sadly loosed your card and all its photos. BEWARE OF THIS DESIGN AND MANUFACTURING FLAW.

UPDATE 2: My Mini-SD Card finally dropped out thru the enlarged hole I made around the Mini-SD slot in back of the frame while trying to fish out my card. This was while I used the additional USB port with a thumb drive that is located next to the mini slot. The USB port works fine and I have resumed loading my photos thru this port. The good news is - I still think this frame is worth the money and has very good picture definition. Just be very careful when using the Mini-SD Card slot. It is designed to lock your Mini card in place when pushing it into the slot. I don't believe this is a necessary feature as many other products featuring a Mini slot just require you to slip it in - pull out and do not lock your card in place. With this frame you must put additional inward force on the mini card in order to release it back out. In doing this function you can, if not careful, easily push the whole Mini-SD slot deeper into the frame and causing the same problem I had.

title: Great performance and features for the price
text:
My brief, high-level (TL;DR) assessment of these earbuds is that you really can’t ask for much more, at this price point. I’ve been using them/getting used to them for about 10 days and have no complaints at all.

I’ve had a previous iteration of these (T59) for a few years and really enjoyed them, but the N35s up the game in a number of meaningful ways. The function controls now include separate (+/-) volume buttons on the top of each earpiece, as well as the usual multifunction buttons (MFBs) on each side. The buttons are positioned and designed to ensure that tactile location, identification, and operation are never a problem. In addition, the units provide audible cues at all major functionality points (e.g., on, paired, incoming phone call, max volume level).

Initial location/pairing with my iPhone SE (3rd-gen.) was a snap, and the connection process each time I use them is seamless and automatic. Sound quality is great for audio books and as good as could be expected for music (again, in this price range). Play is automatically suspended and then resumed to accommodate incoming phone calls (which are also announced). Phone calls can also be accepted, rejected, and/or disconnected via the MFB. Carrying on a conversation with them in was trouble-free.

The N35 case is definitely heavier than the T59 (by about 54%), but boasts extra functionality as well. You still get good long battery life and the level read outs for the case (numeric %) and for each earbud (bar graphs), but now the charging case doubles as a charging source, via a standard USB-A port. While this function is likely not as robust as pure charger bank device, it’s still a great feature to have in a pinch. The case can recharge either via a USB-C port (cable included) or any wireless inductive charging pad (not included).

Of course, they include the standard sets of ear tips (S, M, & L) and have soft, flexible “ear hooks.” After a little bit of experimentation and usage, I found them to be as comfortable as my old T59s.

title: It is somewhat over specified
text: I bought two of these.  After I installed the first one, I was going to give it a 4, but after I got the second one in, I have to lower it to a 3.  Both sets installed with minimal difficulties.  The first set was a 26 inch set weighing 15 lbs and it was mostly easy to install.  The only difficulty I had was that the the drill size that the directions say to use for the pilot holes to mount the unit to a stud is too small.  When I tried to tighten down the screws, it got harder and harder to turn them, and finally one broke off.  I had to go to a hardware store to get more screws.  The second attempt, I moved the unit up about 1/2 inch to clear the remains of the broken screw, drilled pilot holes about two drill sizes larger, and then scraped the screws across a bar of soap to provide some lubrication and everything went as planned.  Then I started on the second TV.  This was a 42 inch set weighing 40 lbs.  That makes it very near, but not over, the upper limits of this unit's specification.  The TV installed with no difficulties but it really is too heavy for this unit.  It feels floppy as you move it around.  If the center of gravity of the TV was very far left or right of the center of the mounting bracket, as one reviewer noted, the TV would just tip over onto it's side. The bolt that is supposed to hold it level (that the directions tell you not to over-tighten in large bold letters, is not up to the job.  Also, if you move the TV as far as it will go to one side, as I did to connect the cables, the unit sags to the point that the swivel axis is tipped over and the TV will just swivel as far as it can go.  Re-leveling it does not help because the weight of the TV is now producing torque around this axis and there is no way to tighten this axis to hold it against this motion.  Again, the unit is not up to the job.  40 lbs is just too much weight for it.  The 44 lb limit is way to high.  I'm not sure that even 30 lbs would feel stable. This unit is fine as long as your TV is light enough and otherwise meets the required specifications but the max weight need to be revised downward.

title: Update 3 👎🏼👎🏼👎🏼
text:
3rd one I decided not to use the USB function that caused 2nd unit to get really hot to the touch and die on me. 3rd unit started flickering and after a week also died.

Something about this device must be flawed, or I’m the unluckiest person in the world only having received faulty units that either stopped working after a few days or a couple months.

I’m done with this product, I’ve had it. Never again.

——————————
Second unit that I received worked great for about a month and a half and then the USB side stopped functioning. (Keyboard/ Mouse)
The screen part of this unit (DP) still works but the unit feels really hot to the touch.
I’ve initiated a return as this is the 2nd unit thats failing on me while I use it only for its intended purpose. I’ve got all kinds of electronics, computers and synthesizers, I’m not abusing or using it beyond its intended purpose. Something about this product is just poorly designed or implemented for it to fail a 2nd time within barely 3 months.

I really badly wanted this product to continue working cos when it does, it does exactly what I need it to do. But the failure rate is just too high and there’s not many other KVM’s that support higher refresh rate/ resolution.

##UPDATE##

Had a new one shipped out that arrived a day after I reached out to support after having received a faulty unit initially.

I’ve deleted my initial review as it pertained a defective unit and not a sub-par or poorly implemented product.

Thankfully this time the unit operates just fine. The remote works each time and toggles between my devices without any glitches or problems.
I’m satisfied and glad it all worked out.
I can switch to and from my computers without hiccups, sharing one Alienware keyboard and mouse between both computers.
Also the speed at which a new one was shipped out and delivered made my day.

(Alienware R14 /Windows 11 /GeForce RTX 3080 /Samsung Odyssey Neo G9 /iMac Pro 2017 /MacOS Ventura)

title: I had high expectations for this soundbar, but...
text:
First, the things I liked. The soundbar and subwoofer package looks very classy and feels nice and sturdy. The remote allows you to adjust sound and volume, and select input source.

In Bluetooth mode, this system sounds fantastic. However, the sound signature is on the bright side, and some songs can sound a bit harsh even with the treble turned all the way down. Some people like a brighter speaker, so this might suit you just fine. And of course, the subwoofer really adds a lot. I tried the unit with and without the subwoofer, and the difference is dramatic.

Things that could be better:
* Most importantly, there's no HDMI input. Virtually all soundbars these days have HDMI connectivity, so I was surprised that this feature isn't included. When it comes to TV sound quality, the input source definitely affects the sound quality. Ranked from worst to best: USB < RCA < Optical < HDMI. For me, the lack of HDMI is a deal breaker. Using that input type not only gives you superior sound, it also allows you to control most soundbars using the TV's remote instead of needing a separate remote.

* I tested TV sound using the RCA input. It sounded very nice, much better than the TV's speakers. But it didn't sound as good as optical (more on that below) or HDMI.

* There is an RCA cable and aux cable included, but no optical cable. Similar soundbars in this size (even less expensive systems) include an optical cable, so this was a disadvantage for me.

* I wanted to use this soundbar with an older TV. It has an optical cable, but I wasn't able to get sound from the sounbar because the soundbar requires PCM 2.0. My TV offers only Internal Speakers and Audio System. I also couldn't get signal using the aux input, so my only option is the RCA input.

My overall impression is that this is a great system when used as a portable sound system, especially with Bluetooth devices. But if you're using this primarily as a soundbar, I think there are better options out there. I would rate this system 3.5 stars, but that's not an option, so I gave it 4 stars.

title: Forget everything they tell you...and then get lucky
text:
First off, I just got this RE450 today and got it set up. Works great...so far. If that changes, I'll definitely come back and revise this critique.

Second...and this is the really important part...the company's setup instructions are straight up garbage. Ignore the instructions. The manual (what supposedly counts for a manual, anyhow) includes links and QR codes to videos showing how to get it to work - these are also garbage. Ignore them. Lastly, there is a tech support-ish website you can visit if everything fails. Guess what? Absolute garbage; ignore it.

Now that we're ignoring everything, here's where you'll find success:

Step 1. Choose your little internet buddy's new home. Do this first, otherwise you'll unplug it, move it, and have to deal with this all over again. Yes, seriously.
Step 2. Plug the thing into the wall, fire it up.
Step 3. Download the app.
Step 4. If you're one of the 99.8% of people who experience the constantly blinking blue light, just pretend the light is solid, and carry on. (The instructions would have you wait for a solid blue light...but we're ignoring those instructions, right? Yes, we are. Especially if you have high blood pressure.)
Step 5. Make sure the location settings in your phone are turned on, at least for the purpose of installing this thing. Switch it back to "I don't want the government tracking me at all times" mode afterward if you like, but make sure it's on when you try to pair it to your app.
Step 6. Have it connect to whichever network you want, then either use your network password, or set a new one.
Step 7. Profit! Err, wait...I mean...internet! Hooray!

Just remember that any devices that require the use of this extender will have to be added to the network you just created. They'll be obvious, because the name will end with "EXT."

And for the love of all that is holy...set all common sense aside for five or ten minutes, and willfully ignore any and all official instructions related to this product. (Mine was a mere two minutes away from falling victim to my Rage Hammer.)

title: Pretty good in general, perfect for what I needed
text:
TLDR: sound is pretty good but bass is mushy, not enough highs, noise canceling is ok, volume is plenty loud

I had a very specific use in mind, and these headphones are perfect. I do woodworking, and I like to listen to audio books while I work. Unfortunately, regular headphones are drowned out by the constantly running shop-vac and assorted tools. I’m concerned if I turn up the volume loud enough to hear what’s being said over the noise I’ll blow out my hearing.

So, after hearing my ex-wife brag about the sound cancelling abilities of her air pods, I decided to give the tech a go. My guess is the noise canceling on these headphones isn’t anywhere near as good as the apple pods, but they also aren’t several hundred dollars. And frankly, I don’t want them to be that quiet - the last thing I need is to forget that the table saw is running. With these headphones, I get: reduced volume from the tools, which is better for my ears, decent enough clarity in sound for audio books, and I can hear the narrator without having to turn up the volume, even when running my Dewalt lunchbox planer that sounds like a jet taking off.

I don’t like the sound for music - too bassy, which normally I love, but this bass is pretty mushy. But again - in this price range I give them 5 stars.

UPDATE: I’ve been wearing these for a week or so now, and I’ll add a couple of points:

They are very comfortable. With my other headsets I usually have to remove them after a couple of hours because they hurt my ears. I leave these on all day.

I tested the active noise cancellation against the fan in my bathroom (never mind why I had them on in the bathroom, shut up) and what I found is that turning the ANC on in no way diminishes the volume of the fan, it just sucks the bass end out, probably storing it up to make songs sound mushy later. I think that’s why it works well for me, as most of my tools (e.g. my Ridgid shop vac) operate in that lower register.

title: Great Mouse until it is not.  Perma Sleep mode issue.
text:
I had a non Perixx mouse with the exact same vetical clam shell structure which I loved, but the optical sensor did not work on the material of my new bean bag chair (velorish), while other higher end mouses (microsoft & logitech) did. Thus looking for a new vertical mouse, I found the Perixx mouse and looked at the specs and it had a newer optics sensor with a higher DPI than my much beloved vertical mouse, so I took a flyer on it. The mouse is idential in form to my existing vertical mouse and worked great on my new bean bag chair. Besides the internals, the outer shellis identical but with a different logo printed on it to my prevous mouse. 5 stars for the mouse until...

After 5 months of use, averaging about 4 hours a day (lots of Visio diagrams), the mouse went into perma sleep mode. Technically the mouse works, but it goes into sleep mode after 2 seconds of non use. I am use to some type of sleep mode on wireless mice, you shake them and everthing is good again. However with a 2 second sleep mode trigger, mouse clicks get eaten because the click is waking up the mouse and then ignored. Its like typing and having random keys not being typed at all.

I bought this mouse from amazon.com vs perixx's amazon store. Perixx will not honor their 1 year warranty since the item was sold by the seller amazon.com and therefor they cannot verify the amazon invoice via their amazon store tools.

Overall this common vertical mouse clam shell has the best feal of any of the 30+ mouse shapes i have tried. The difference is night and day the mouse is used at waist level or below from a seated position. I will be purchasing another vertical mouse of this clam shell soon, but I will not be this or any model with an internal battery going forward.

Overall I think my experience with mouse warrents 2.5 stars. I lowered it down to 2 starts since a half star is not allowed. Amazon gave me a good deal on the mouse, if they had not, I think I would be more upset and lowered my rating to 1 star purely on the mouse not living to or honoring to its 1 year lifecycle.

title: Would buy again (depending upon longevity/quality/durability)
text:
Bottom Line:
I would buy again if the durability holds up.

Pros:
- many separate pockets/storage-areas to keep things organized
- quality zippers (look like they will last)
- black with gold accents is a nice visual
- quality stitching (i checked everywhere i could and it looks solid and well made; see additional comment below)
- the back straps seem to be placed and designed perfectly, making the backpack feel lighter than the backpack this replaced, while wearing.

Cons:
- none (as of now; will update if something breaks)

Other comments:
- i read one review where the handle started to separate from the rest of the backpack. I have not had this issue, though will definitely keep an eye on this.
- my daughter LOVES this backpack and said “I want to use this backpack forever”. No joke. Still makes me laugh recalling her voice.
- we pulled out the USB port, as it is removable. Since we’ll need a charging cord anyway, we’ll just plug directly into a battery and snake the cord through the opening. Also, you can put your phone inside the backpack, and snake through wired earphones if you still use them. Just put the phone in the slot where the ‘battery’ would have gone. Though honestly, everyone i know uses wireless earbuds.
- while the zipper ‘pulls’ are a shiny gold, the zipper itself is… hard to determine. It kinda looks white in the photos, but in person it looks more yellow when light hits it… sometimes it looks like a yellowish white… it’s really weird to be honest. It is not advertised as such, but I wonder if the zipper is ‘reflective’?
- unsure what the description/title means by ‘anti-theft’? Any skilled pickpocket i don’t think would be stopped by any backpack?
- overall, it looks really sharp and classy. As long as the quality lasts and it is durable through normal use, I can’t see why not to get this.
- purchased around 02/2023.

title: FITS FIRMLY & EASY INSTALL ON A HONDA PIONEER 1000-3 OFF ROAD UTV
text:
It is not possible nor practical to solidly mount conventional side view mirrors to view behind either side of our 2020 Pioneer 1000. This is because of fitment of dealer installed OEM Honda accessories including glass windshield, hard roof, hard cab rear panel with glass window and quick mount/remove soft upper door window panels. The roll over protection frame tube structure is covered, by fitment of the the hard panels and, the hard weatherproofing flashing to seal the upper door soft window closure points at the windshield. We do not want to cut such accessories to fabricate a way to install conventional side mirrors NOR HAVE SUCH MIRROR PROTRUSIONS BECAUSE OF THE NARROW PATHWAYS IN OUR AND OTHER WOODLAND AREAS.

We acquired one of these backup camera systems with the intent to install on our 2012 pickup truck. We checked to see if we could fit it on the Honda Pioneer and by carefully bending one side of the camera license plate mounting bracket to fit at the top upper corner of the hard rear Pioneer window panel. We temporarily assembled the camera system, installed the windshield suction cup mount and energized the camera/monitor system. We found that the camera could be adjusted perfectly to get the rear view we needed for the driver’s side of the Pioneer.

The glass front window suction cup mount for the monitor is very firmly adhered. The camera/monitor picture resolution is more than sufficient for our needs. The monitor size is good because the Pioneer windshield is much closer to the driver than in any car. We just ordered a second exact same system for the passenger side of the Pioneer 1000. Also, we plan to install one in our truck and probably another in our diesel tractor(s). Night vision is also a plus.

We shall install both UTV monitors adjacent at the upper left windshield corner, left for left side viewing, right for right. A 1/4” hole behind each camera will allow their wiring to enter the cab. Zip ties shall affix all wiring to the UTV ROPS frame to deliver video signal to the monitors. Systems shall be energized by the 12V accessory via 2.3’ pigtail to 3 way 12V splitter also zip tied to frame. Inside and outside backing plates will firmly affix the cameras to the back window panel via small stainless steel fasteners.

title: Premium Engineered Z690 (12th gen + 13th gen) Motherboard
text: [[VIDEOID:e5dacb1743eeadb6028be0d6a14ff99f]] EVGA has incredibly designed a capable EATX board with a premium focus. The EVGA Z690 Classified has a triple BIOS design instead of normal dual BIOS in case something goes wrong for an added safety net. They had provided a tiny USB with the required driver as a .exe file with their manual. I would like to note in the manual there is a typo for the power on flashback instructions (for those who only have a 13th gen CPU)-corrected version would be holding down the bios flash button for 2 seconds to initiate the flashback if you do not hold the CMOS reset button. They have provided two pump headers for AIOs and several system fan headers for even the most spacious cases. I tested this system and it worked upon first boot with XMP on with 6000 MHz DDR5 RAM. Overall, you can expect the BIOS flashback to take around 8-10 minutes. You need to follow the manual and use a USB 2.0 flash drive that is in FAT 32 that contains only the extracted bios file downloaded from the EVGA website. Afterward, plug in the USB to the dedicated BIOS flashback port on the motherboard. Make sure only the CPU power and main ATX power are connected to the board, then flip the PSU on (not the front panel connectors). Hold the BIOS button on the rear for 2 seconds and start the flashing process. You would see the debug led going into a clockwise position and flashing. It will stop when the process has ended, and you may get a debug code like 00 or other depending on the setup. One thing to note is to control the ARGB or RGB headers on the board you will have to use the EVGA ELEET X1 to customize your PCs LEDs will have to disable Windows Memory Integrity (can turn it back on later and changes will be saved into the system). Moreover, you must bypass Windows default online setup to a local account during OS install (Shift + F10 | In Command Prompt, type the OOBE\BYPASSNRO | restart) then load your drivers provided from the USB .exe file (no need to download the Intel Rapid Storage driver). Please note that the system will not recognize ethernet LAN or Wi-Fi without installing drivers which is the last step. The EVGA team made the entire process straightforward with all the documentation for even the newest PC builders.

title: Stick with it!  Worth it in the end.
text:
At $13 each, it was hard to pass these up. They are a Chinese rebrand of some common camera core, most likely. I must admit that I was almost ready to return them because the documentation is so poor and getting them going was tricky. As stated above and clearly, they are for 2.4G wifi only.

Start with the phone app using the process in the manual exactly with the iCSee app. For many people this may be enough if you are only using these cameras in your setup and that's the only way you will ever view them. You can stop right here. To do anything more advanced, you need the "VMS" application on a MAC/PC.

You need to determine the IP address from your router as it is not visible anywhere in the ICSee phone app. The VMS application did not automatically discover my camera, so I had to manually add it using the IP address and kind-of guessing at the fields to add. Surprisingly I was able to connect. That was the make/break moment for these cheap cameras. If I hadn't been able to connect, they would have been returned.

Once connected via the VMS application you can change a ton of parameters and configure these things fully. I was actually surprised at how many knobs they expose. After some experimentation, I was able to determine that the stream addresses are:

rtsp://(your IP address):554/user=admin&password=(xxx)&channel=1
rtsp://(your IP address):554/user=admin&password=(xxx)&channel=1&stream=1

The first is the high-def stream and the second is the low-def stream. Obviously use your IP address and whatever password you set up in the ICSee app (no parentheses). Don't use punctuation or funny characters in the password you chose for these cameras as it will affect the string interpretation.

Now don't expect cinema-quality video and they do seem to lose I-frames more frequently than I would like, but for $13 each and such a simple screw-in-a-lightbulb-socket installation, they are an easy/cheap way to add more eyes to a home security setup.

title: Love it
text:
The MOKiN USB C Docking Station Dual DisplayPort is a versatile and powerful docking station that provides comprehensive connectivity options for laptops with USB C ports. With its dual DisplayPort ports, USB 3.0 ports, Gigabit Ethernet, 100W PD charging, and multiport adapter, this docking station offers a wide range of features for enhanced productivity and convenience.

One of the key features of the MOKiN USB C Docking Station is its dual DisplayPort ports, which support 4K resolution at 60Hz. This allows you to connect two external monitors to your laptop and extend or mirror your display for increased productivity and multitasking. The high resolution and refresh rate ensure crisp and smooth visuals, making it ideal for graphics-intensive tasks such as video editing or gaming.

The docking station also features three USB 3.0 ports, providing high-speed data transfer and charging capabilities for your USB devices. This allows you to connect peripherals such as external hard drives, keyboards, mice, and other USB accessories for enhanced functionality and convenience.

With its Gigabit Ethernet port, the docking station provides a reliable and fast wired internet connection, ensuring stable and speedy data transfer and network access. This is particularly useful for users who require a reliable and low-latency internet connection for online gaming, video streaming, or other bandwidth-intensive tasks.

The MOKiN USB C Docking Station also supports 100W Power Delivery (PD) charging, which allows you to charge your laptop and other USB devices simultaneously while using the docking station. This eliminates the need for multiple chargers and simplifies your workspace, making it ideal for users on the go or those who need to charge their devices quickly and efficiently.

The docking station is compatible with MacBook, Dell, HP, Lenovo, and other laptops with USB C ports, providing wide compatibility for various devices. It is also easy to set up, simply requiring you to connect it to your laptop via a single USB C cable.

Overall, the MOKiN USB C Docking Station Dual DisplayPort is a comprehensive and versatile docking station that offers dual monitor support, USB 3.0 connectivity, Gigabit Ethernet, 100W PD charging, and wide compatibility with laptops. Its robust features and ease of use make it a valuable addition to any workstation, enhancing productivity and convenience for users who require multiple connectivity options.

title: Lots of work to get answers from customer service.
text:
The good: connects very well. The controls on the app are excellent. The software is very good and comes with an instruction manual. The manual is very specific For the most part. It is missing some elements. Picture quality is excellent Both day and night. It’s human detection is excellent as well as tracking.

The bad: You need two extenders because the camera will not work properly if it is above the outdoor wall lamp. I had to buy a 6-inch socket extender and it still didn't fully go beyond the lamp. I had to purchase another 2-inch extender so it would work beyond the bottom of the lamp holder. Could not get it to scan properly because the camera would screw in so that it did not give a full 180 degrees, even after I adjusted the camera using the app. CUSTOMER SERVICE IS mediocre. . It takes them a long time to get back (they are in China) and customer service reps take weekends off starting on Friday mornings instead of the end of the day. Then, when they return, they tell you to read the manual. I told them the SD card sticks out of the unit. I followed their instructions to the tee, but as you can see from the pic, the SD card sticks out enough for someone to steal it easily. They then insulted my intelligence by asking me to read the manual. Well, duh! I'm a tech guy and know that!

Update 2/6/2023--I received an email from the rep. They asked some questions and decided it was defective. They are sending me two (I think) more since I bought two. I'll update this when I test the ones coming to me.

Update. 2/6/2023

After a number of times asking the same questions, they finally admitted that the SD card does stick out a bit. ( see photo). So they need not send replacements. It works fine. New problem: I have to repeat my question which was how to get the camera to go back to its original position? They never answered the question, ( since I’m sure they have trouble with our language) so I sent the message again. I do like the camera but it is very difficult to get immediate answers from them. They do answer after 24 hours. Otherwise, it would have received 5 stars.

title: Portable. Basic but functional remote + cables. Outside or small business use. Needs a carry case.
text:
Use for watching TV, movies, YouTube, etc. in a room where you don’t have a TV. Also an option for outside use/viewing during warmer months. People in our house also like to do crafts, and this can be used to project images onto large surfaces like a wall or canvas.

I did my initial testing at 110 inches away from the screen. The screen I used is an old white comforter hung on the wall (this will replicate how I’ll use it in the back yard). I connected using HDMI.
I’ll definitely want a higher table or tri-pod, but that’s not a big issue. It is bright enough for comfortable viewing, but not as bright as a TV or computer screen. If you are not doing a side by side comparison, it’s not an issue, but if you look at the projected image vs a computer or TV screen, there is an obvious difference. A brighter white surface to project on could help as well. For the record, I did try with different settings for brightness, etc.

It’s definitely easy to operate and it’s a portable size. Remote is basic but good, in fact I preferred it over the on-device buttons. I have a 6mm tripod that fits several camera bases I have, but it does not fit the projector... the projector screw/insert is smaller than the standard camera size - just be sure to measure this before buying a tri-pod or ceiling mount.

This isn’t going to replace one of my screens, but it will be nice to use for outside viewing during warmer months, craft projects, etc. I also have a small business, and it could come in handy if I ever need to present and the facility doesn’t have a projector.

Comes with some cables and a functional remote. It would have been nice if it came with some sort of storage/carry case – not a show stopper, but would have been nice. Time will tell how well it holds up.

Given the price point, and what you get, I’m rating it 4 stars. I think it could have been a little brighter, WiFi for video streaming would be a welcomed addition, power cord is a little short, but overall, a solid option for an entry level projector.

title: Very useful device at a great price but NO optical zoom. Works well w/iPhone but lacking w/iMac.
text:
This small, lightweight microscope is quite a useful device and was very easy to set up and use with my iPhone. I simply downloaded the app and followed the easy instructions (only a few steps). It uses WiFi to connect to your phone and the image is remarkably sharp and clear for such an inexpensive device.

One thing it can NOT do is zoom, as the description would have you believe. It has no optical zoom capabilities whatsoever. The control ring around the unit is simply used to focus the microscope depending upon how far you are away from your subject. You can focus on a 12" wide object from several feet away or move in super close with the clear plastic housing resting on your object where you will only be viewing about a ¼" wide object. That is what they mean by zooming; simply focusing at different distances.

The app they built for the iPhone does allow you to digitally zoom the image up to 4X but that is just enlarging the pixels; no additional detail is being captured.

Despite it not optically zooming, it does quite a good job of showing you the fine details of very small objects which your eye couldn't resolve without help.

One thing that does NOT work very well is the option to plug the microscope into your Mac desktop computer and use the Mac's built-in Photo Booth app, as the microscope's instructions recommend. The Mac will recognize the camera without any problem but you will need to select it under the "Camera" drop down menu which the instructions don't explain.

Once the camera is selected you will see the image on your desk top but the image is unfortunately laterally reversed (flipped left to right like you see yourself in a mirror) which is annoying at best. Photo Booth does give you the option to "automatically flip new items" but you will only be able to view the flipped-view AFTER you shoot a video or take a still photo. While you're shooting, everything is still reversed.

The other thing to note is that the microscope sets an initial color balance when it first sees its subject and then keeps that color balance until you turn off the camera. That means if you decide to add some supplemental lighting that isn't the same color as your initial lighting, the image will be way off color until you turn the camera off and back on again.

title: Sacrificial Screen for Scratches and Moderate Drop
text:
I have Spigen protector glass on 2 iPhones. I recommend the product (about $16 for 1 + Tax). My expectation is the Protector is a sacrificial layer for scratches and drops from desk chair, bed heights, on INDOOR floors like carpet squares, loom carpet and hardwood. IF used with a case. IF you drop your iPad on OUTDOOR surfaces like cement sidewalk, or indoor marble, stone, garage floor, etc., I think your iPad will be toast.

Second point is installation. Buyers have a variety of experiences. My was VG-to-Excellent: the package was in a nice retail box (for store display), there is 1 large install plastic tray where your iPad is inserted into the tray. Cleaner wipes are provided to clean fingerprints, organic matter, etc. (otherwise, debris is trapped when the protector screen is applied), plus a dust wipe. After cleaning, use the dust wipe to remove dust that will fall from air. Remove the protector glass from the plastic sleeve; then peel out the clear film from the contact side of the protector. Then lay the protector on your iPad; the glass can inserted only 1 way. As instructed, swipe & press down in the middle; from the middle, I then worked my way left, then right. This is to attach the protector to the iPad screen.

I removed my iPad from tray, and removed the 2nd film from the glass, and there were several large bubbles between the protector glass and iPad screen. I used the provided plastic blade to push out the air bubbles; what worked for me was to press down the blade, then push (always applying pressure so air doesn't into the area behind the blade ) the bubble towards the closest edge. This technique allowed to to get rid of all the bubbles.

The screen protector only covers the visible display, and not edge-to-edge of the iPad. The glass becomes a bevel surface around the visible part of the screen face, like crown molding.

In use, I didn't feel the screen to be "thicker" or less responsive than a bare screen. Again, my expectations are to absorb scratches, and with my iPad body case, survive a drop on indoor surfaces.

I recommend this, as this is my 3 Spigen for an average price.

title: Should be really great for regular sized monitors, tuning necessary for 21" and larger monitors.
text:
A real plus with the Nulea wired trackball is the ease of installation and unlike a mouse, that you don't need to move the entire trackball to move the cursor. Just use your thumb to move the red ball. This is handy if you have limited real estate on your computer to physically move the device. This could be a great advantage when you in situations where you would like mouse type control but no space to move the mouse like on an airplane or in bed without a hard surface.

The first photo shows an illustration of the buttons that you'll find on the trackball. It is very easy to connect and install. Just plug the cord into the USB and it should be ready to go. I'm using Windows 11 so it was immediately recognized when plugged in. I didn't have to configure anything, but I went to settings anyhow just to see. Windows recognized the trackball as a USB input device as shown in the second photo.

The Nulea handles nicely, and the track ball is responsive. Depending on the monitor you have, you may need to press the button under the wheel one or more times to find the DPI setting that works best for moving the trackball pointer on the screen. I'm using a large 21 monitor, so I need to pick my thumb off the red trackball to reposition and move it a second time to have the cursor get from one edge of the screen to the other. If you are using a regular monitor this should not be much of a problem. For me it is only a concern when playing a game that takes up the 21" full screen. That is when I switch to the traditional mouse. Note that in the last photo that I keep both the trackball and the mouse hooked up to the computer at the same time. I can simply stop using one and switch to the other. I like using the trackball when I'm on the internet doing searches, shopping, and doing input type work like writing this review. For full screen games I'll stick to the mouse.

From prior experience I learned that a trackball may need to come out of the hole for cleaning when the cursor starts to skip and act semi responsive. There is a hole on the bottom of the device where you can press up and force the red trackball out. Then you can easily clean it and put it back.

title: I expect this $300 earbuds to be a lot better than my $40 from amazon
text:
I bought it directly from Bose website in Oct. And I really tried to convince myself that it is a great product that I purchased. Now after 3 months, my frustration with this Bose QC II won my patience.

I will try to be fair and write down goods and bad.
TLDR: good for listening to music. bad for having calls, meetings, conferences.

Pros
------
+ It is very comfy to wear. Other earbuds gave me headache or pain in ear after a few hours. This one does not.
+ Noice cancellation while listening to music is great (But if you are in call, it's horrible.)
+Battery life is decent with chargeable box.

Cons
------
- it disconnects so often and reconnecting is a very cumbersome process. E.g. once you take out one earbud for a short while or dislodge, you need to remove both, then put it back into the box to reconnect. If you just wear one back to your ear without putting both in the box, your bluetooth connection is lost.

- It amplifies other static (buzzing ) noises around the house during the call . I don't hear it when I listen to music or even without headset. But Once I'm my meeting call, all the buzzing noises (low frequency noises) from fridge, microwave and all other electromagnetic appliances noise become so loud in the earbuds. It is even in my "Quiet" setting. I tested with different apps (zoom, FB messengers, normal call, Teams) all are having the same issue only with this earbuds.

- It doesn't have noise cancellation for its microphone. So, other party in your call will hear all the slightest background noise while you think it's completely quiet with your earbuds. Many often people in my meeting complains about background noises with this headset more than any other headsets.

---
I have $40 no-name headset from amazon that I bought . It has better quality ( athought it doesn't have long battery life) than this $300 bose qc II.

Summary, I won't recommend this if you are thinking of using it for conference meeting calls.

title: Finally I can work
text:
I don't own a Surface. I bought this for my work laptop because the keyboard was starting to fail. The keys stopped registering unless I pressed hard which made it frustrating to enter things like passwords. I had to plug in a USB keyboard just to be able to get any work done. This Bluetooth keyboard saved my job. I'm able to work all over the house now, not just at my desk, and I've gotten so much done. The keyboard sits on top of my 13 inch laptop perfectly. And all the keys are pretty much in the same places. Its so light, I don't mind traveling with this extra keyboard in my bag.

The keys feel amazing to type on. Short throw like most thin boards but has good resistance and pressure. Quiet too. The backlighting is not too bright but there is quite a bit of leakage around each of the keys. I leave it on the lowest brightness setting. The touchpad is wider than what I'm used to but it feels okay. Sometimes it doesn't register my taps but that might be my finger.

The switch on the side is difficult to operate and only moves a millimeter. This helps prevent accidentally turning it off but a little more play would have been welcome. Thankfully it pairs fast with my Windows 10 laptop. You just have to add it manually within the Bluetooth settings. It comes with a meter long USB-C to A cable to charge.

The layout is also different here as it has dedicated PgUp and PgDn keys and the inverted-T arrow keys. The Function keys (F1-F12) require you to hold down the Fn modifier key to press them so that top row of keys defaults to the special functions like brightness, volume, and media keys. The keyboard material is smooth plastic on top, easy to clean, and the bottom of the keyboard is completely covered in this soft felt type material that feels nice and cozy.

This is one of the more pricey 3rd party options for Surface type covers so you could probably save some money by going cheaper but you're already saving so much just by going with 3rd party, and you get wireless support which Microsoft's doesn't have. Buy this if you need a cheaper type cover for your Surface or buy this if you just want a wireless keyboard for your Windows machine. I plan to use this for my HTPC later because its so compact and lightweight.

title: Super comfortable without sacrificing sound quality
text:
These are extremely comfortable ear buds that do not go into the ear canal. They sit outside and partially cover the opening allowing sound to travel through but it doesn't block other outside sources completely. So for instance, your jamming while washing your car and your wife is trying to tell you something from the doorway, you'll be able to hear that she is talking to you, unlike when I wear my noise canceling headphones and she has to tap me on the shoulder scaring me to death.

If noise canceling is what you are going for, these are not for you. These are for comfort without sacrificing sound quality. The sound quality is what really has me liking these. I have two other pairs of wireless in-ear buds and not only do they hurt after a bit, but the sound doesnt compare to these, now keep in mind they range in the $50 range. For those of you who pair your wireless headphone to a watch, like a galaxy 4, you may have experienced a drop in sound quality when using some lower end products. These continue to sound pretty good, not as high in quality as going through my phone, but there is still some base and you don't get that flat high all treble cheapness.

I've worn them for about 4 hours non-stop and I can barley feel them. The clip that hooks around my ear are comfortable and not tight or "pinchy". After 4 hours the battery is sitting at 80%.

The case is nice and sturdy, doesn't feel cheap, nor should it for $130. The ear buds were 100% charged when I paired them up. I charged the case up while I was playing on my computer. The case is a bit bulky but nothing that I'd really feel would make me not purchase these.

The controls I'm still getting use to but to turn sound down you double tap left ear button, to turn sound up you double tap right button. Pause by pushing either ear once. Move tracks forward by long pressing the right, move backwards by long pressing left ear. I don't really like the controls but it's not a deal breaker.

Overall these are my new favorite music listening Device. They are light, connected easily, allow me to not lose track of what's going on around me, and most important to me, the sound quality is above reasonable for $130.

title: Wonky setup, good results, decent features
text:
This FeiyuTech Scorp Mini is a decent looking lightweight gimbal that brings a great amount of features in a run-and-gun style package. The packaging that it shipped in is great, and holds everything in a nicely presented package.

Setup:
The physical setup is alright. I have two other gimbals, one from Zhiyun, and one from DJI. The Feiyutech here is worse in pretty much every way when it comes to actually attaching the camera to the gimbal. Having a two piece attachment is good in theory, but the adjustment mechanism for balancing and the way it attaches is just wonky. Definitely some improvement to be had there.

The balancing of most gimbals is a huge pain, and this one was no different. Worse, in fact, because of the way that the axis locks work. Using a rotating mechanism to lock the balance is not great, and makes it annoying to do minute adjustments. Having axis LOCKS, as in, they wont move when not in use, is great. My DJI has that, albeit automatic, and seeing them here, although manual, is a great feature.

After finally getting the gimbal balanced, with a Sony A7III and 50mm prime lens, it worked great as a lightweight gimbal. The interface on the gimbal was glitchy, and the instruction manual was absolutely vital to actually figure out what the buttons did. I figured I'd check out the app, which is also poorly constructed. The firmware updating process was glitchy but seemed to work.

After updating the firmware, I didn't really have any desire to use the app again. Fortunately, you can do most of what you need on the gimbal itself - except, sometimes the touchscreen doesn't really do anything you think it should do. In addition, I couldn't get the auto-calibration to work at all.

Overall, this gimbal is a bit wonky, but seems like it will do the job it was designed to do well. I really expected a lot more polish for something so pricey, but it is what it is. Feels overkill for a gopro, and a little underpowered for SLR-style cameras. The low weight limit really wants you to only use a small camera with prime lenses.

title: It works, but doesn't protect the hard drive well at all
text:
This is a review of "iDsonix 3.5 Inch Hard Drive Enclosure SATA USB C 3.1 Ultra 6G Speed External HDD Caddy Tool-Free Design for UASP , SATA HDD/SSD"

I debated whether one star was the right rating for this hard drive case, but decided on three stars because it does function as advertised, even if it is a poor choice of an external case, in my opinion. I have helped design data storage systems professionally and really the only application I might consider this case for would be to temporarily hook up bare drives that were being stored to archive data. This isn't a case of having too high expectations; I've seen plenty of "consumer grade" cases that are way better than this one.

1) First off, the instructions show the top sliding nicely off to make room for the drive. It took me quite a few minutes to realize that you need to pinch the plastic sides to pop the top off, the mechanism doesn't work at all like the instructions imply. Frustrating, but not the end of the world.

2) Once the lid is off it becomes apparent that there is no cushioning at all. You slide the bare drive into the slot and that's that. Since the drive isn't screwed in and there's not even any foam to hold the drive in place once it's installed and the case is closed, the drive is left to rattle around if you jiggle the case. If this is for a drive you are going to use very infrequently and the case is going to be left on a desk surface all the time, maybe it's sufficient. I would never transport a drive in a case like this. This is pretty much of a deal killer for me, even though I don't intend to be carrying the drive around much. My data is far too valuable to trust to a case like this.

3) On the plus side, the Seagate Enterprise 8 TB hard drive fit and powered right up, formatted well and I got the expected performance in my drive performance test application. So functionally it appears to work well.

Overall, it was worth trying, but this case really doesn't meet my expectations, even looking at this as a consumer. I will not be using this and will look for a better constructed option, probably one with a fan and temperature monitor.

title: Know What You're Buying!!!
text:
I'll start with the cons before the pros because there's little downside to this product.

What I didn't like is the misinformation on the title of this product and not being clear on the type of cable. This is NOT a display port cable/connection and this is a UNIDIRECTIONAL (one-way) cable. To be more accurate, this cable is MICRO-HDMI (Source) to HDMI (Output) with an adapter to turn it into an HDMI to HDMI cable.

With that out of the way, this cable is amazing. You need to know what you're buying first of.

Expensive: This is a Fiber Optic Cable. Its expensive because its fiber optic, meaning this is thinner than the regular long HDMI cables and also means you don't compromise with the signal just because its thinner. You get faster and better quality compared to the typical HDMI cables. Compare it to your internet provider, we always hear that Fiber Internet is faster and better signal compared to regular internet provider. Hence you pay more for Fiber Internet, its the same with this cable, you're paying for the quality.

Durability: Normally, Fiber Optic Cables are very fragile, they break easily when bending. But because of the heavy duty nylon braided, normal bending and use doesn't break this cable easily. You can easily use this on a live production and not worry about signal breaking just cause someone stepped on the cable or twisted the cable wrong.
