But don't get the wrong idea that this can be twisted and knotted without damage (I haven't tested that, but I wouldn't try it).

Use: You can tell this product is meant for professional photography/videography/broadcasting because those devices (cameras and camcorders) still use Micro-HDMI. But because of the adapter, you can use this cable for pretty much any type of device (computer, video games, appleTV, Firestick, etc).

Testing: I've connected this cable to my GoPro which handles 4K at 60Hz. And this works flawlessly at an amazing quality. Very fluent and clear image/video, no drop frames. I've also used this cable to connect my PC (4K) to my monitor and I get the same type of quality. Haven't had any issues and would definitely recommend

title: Nice Turntable Stand, IF It Isn't Delivered Damaged
text:
My wife ordered this turntable stand under her Amazon account, so I won't show as a "Verified Purchaser." However, we did indeed purchase this product.

This is a nice looking turntable stand, albeit a bit overpriced for laminated particle board. The old- school retro look, and distressed "wood" laminate, make this turntable stand look unique. The included dual outlet and dual USB power strip is also very convenient. The dual drawers will hold a lot of useful music related items. The metal record dividers and legs are also a nice touch. The assembly of this turntable stand is easy and straight forward, and it took about 45 minutes to build (after I repaired the shipping damage).

That is where the good ends. The turntable stand we received arrived in a box that looked like it was drug down the street behind a dump truck. This caused one of the drawer fronts to crack and become gouged. I ended up having to temporarily fix the gouged front of the drawer with wood filler and furniture repair markers in order to match the distressed finish. I also repaired the crack by using wood glue, and small metal straps and screws inside the drawer front. The pre-installed drawer glides for the right drawer were also installed about 1/4" too high, making it so that the drawer would not close. I had to removed the drawer glides and reinstall them 1/4" lower. Also, the holes for the metal record dividers are drilled all the way through the particle board to the laminate. If pushed to hard when being installed, the divider legs will poke right through the bottom of the turntable stand.

My wife contacted the seller under her Amazon account, and sent them pictures of the damaged drawer front. The seller stated that they will send us a new drawer front, but it could take several weeks (or more) as it has to ship from China. Say what? It's a good thing that the "temporary" repairs I made work, and look good, for now. Otherwise, I would not have even been able to build the turntable stand for many weeks.

I recommend this turntable stand IF it arrives without any damage, as it does look nice. However, trying to get replacements for broken parts can be a hassle. Caveat Emptor!

title: Works well with phones, but not good for TVs
text:
This was a tough product for me to review. Overall, it works well, but it doesn't work well for the purpose for which I got them: watching TV. The headphones do not have the aptX codec which allows for several audio enhancements, most notably (for me) low-latency reception. This means that when using the headphone while watching on a TV, the audio and video will be out of sync. The time difference is not huge (maybe a second or two), but enough that its very noticeable when characters are talking. It's like watching a non-english language movie where an english voice is dubbed in.

This delay is not noticeable when watching a video on my phone, however. Maybe because the distance between the phone and the headphones is much shorter. When watching on the phone, or listening to music, the sound is pretty good. I find the bass to be muddled, but the midrange and highs sound good to me.

The headphones appear to be well-made. I like the stainless steel look of the backs of the earcups. I'm less a fan of the color of the foam and headband, but that's just personal preference. The headphones fold up nicely and come with a carrying case. The ear cups are soft and comfortable. When I first saw the headphones, I was afraid the ear cups would be too small. But they weren't; the cups surrounded my ears, without touching them (it might not work out so well for someone with a much larger head [I'm 5'10"]). I thought he head band might be a little big as it didn't contact the top of my head, but then I noticed that the ear cups are angled such that the headband actually sits towards the front of the head, rather than on the crown.

In summary, these phones have decent sound (not audiophile quality, but I'd be shocked if they did at the price), are comfortable, and work well with phones. The price ($56 at the time of this review) is higher than similar headphones available on Amazon, but the quality of the cheaper headphones may not be as good.
When watching on a TV, however, the sound is out-of-sync with the video. I'm hoping the company can add the aptX codecs via a firmware upgrade.

title: Excellent mATX board for Ryzen 9 7000 series
text:
This is a very high quality board with generous heat sinks and no tiny fans to get clogged.
Stuff I liked:
Metal reinforced PCIe x16 slot.
A robust retaining clip on the x16 slot that won't break off if you need to remove the video card.
Both a gen 4 and a gen 5 nvme drive slot. Both have heat sinks.
Indicator lights on the motherboard help with basic diagnostics. They actually came in handy for me.
UEFI BIOS is easy to set up. Smart memory access is called Resizable BAR here, but is trivial to enable in any event. AMD EXPO memory profiles are likewise trivial to set up.
Built-in backplane for all external ports made of a real alloy plate.
Built-in Bluetooth is a nice touch.
Armoury Crate installs automatically when you install a bog standard version of Windows 11.

What I didn't like so much:
Armoury Crate wants to install chipset and video drivers rather than let Windows install the chipset drivers. I prefer to install video drivers directly from AMD.
PCIe 5.0 is only available for 1 nvme slot. It is not available to the x16 card slot.
No optical or coax out for on-board HD audio.
Manual could stand to use a better, more legible font.
The number of SATA connectors is dwindling compared to previous generations.
The DRAM indicator comes on and stays amber for a disturbingly long period of time during boot. The boot eventually proceeds just fine, but this behavior can make diagnosing RAM issues a pain.

Warning! Installing DDR5 memory is tricky. The manual tells you to use what appear to be secondary slots for installing 2 sticks, and this does seem correct BTW (one per channel, use the gray DIMM slots). But since DDR5 is notched just about dead center, it may not be obvious which way to insert a module.
General rule of thumb is, the branding on the RAM should face away from the CPU. Since I bought G.Skill memory, both sides of the heat sink had branding. D'oh! The trick is to look at the branding on the top edge of the heat sink (see photos). Also, the holographic stickers were facing toward the CPU.

title: Well Made, Powerful, Easy to Setup & Use, Nice Value
text:
This is a great and powerful mini PC! First off, the unit itself feels nicely made and doesn't feel cheap. I really like the design and the size is perfect. It has multiple USB ports and has support for dual HDMI displays.

The PC came with a fully licensed copy of the Windows 11 Pro operating system and had no issues doing the updates and getting it setup with my Microsoft account. I was also able to hook up a wireless mouse and keyboard and had no issues with operation. Other peripherals such as webcams, printers, and others worked just fine, too..

The setup of this PC was extremely easy - plug it in, turn it on, follow the on screen prompts for setting up Windows and your account, and you're all set. Depending on the monitor or TV you are using for this mini PC, there may be some over burn along the edges. If this happens, just simply adjust the settings on your monitor or TV.

Once this was setup, I tested playing 4K sample videos and it played them with no issues - no stuttering or jitters during play back. I also played games on multiple cloud gaming services (Luna, Stadia, xCloud, Shadow, and GeForce Now) and this had no issues playing. I tried other other games that you would have to install and most of them ran fine. If you are looking to play more graphics intense games, then I wouldn't recommend this. However, if you just want to play casual games or don't mind playing in lesser quality, then you will have no issues with this one. I can also say I used this to render a 4K video through Power Director and it handled it with no problems to report.

The dual monitor output works as it should and allowed for a great overall experience. When using this setup, I was able to multi-task without the PC slowing down much. In fact, I would say it was hardly noticeable.

All things considered, this a great mini PC that works as described and in my opinion, is an excellent value for the price. It's portable, pretty powerful (for most things), and easy to use. It's not going to be a gaming power house so just be aware. If you want to do light gaming, light video editing, and anything else below that power wise, then this is perfect! I really love mine!

title: Work Well!
text: Ankbit E500Pro+ Hybrid Active Noise Cancelling Headphones. Out of the box they feel solid. They come with a very nice case for storing the headphones. They look modern and feel comfortable. Charging was simple using the included USB-C cable. They also included a standard audio plug cable that I won’t be using as none of my current devices support this. I could see the cable being helpful for older devices with plugs and no Bluetooth support. The included instruction manual is all pictures but pretty easy to figure out. Pairing this to my iPhone and iPad was simple. The button layout and their functions are straight forward. The only thing lacking is that there is no way to gauge power remaining while using. There is a charging indicator light for when you have it plugged in and the light goes off when fully charged. I have an older Bose headset that tells you by voice how much power is remaining each time I turn them on. I find this very helpful as it allows me to gauge if I can use it with what power is left or if I need to charge it. I will say that the Bose were almost 3 times the cost of these so maybe the trade off is worth it. In almost all other areas they compare very favorably with the Bose. Sound quality is clear and excellent. Noise cancellation seems almost the same as the Bose which is very good. They support Siri for voice control. The Bose offers an App that works with the headset, there is no App support with these, but I hardly ever use the Bose App. Noise cancellation is always on with the Bose as long as the power switch is turned on. With these you need to press the ANC button each time after turning these on for noise cancellation. Some people may see this as an advantage as the noise cancellation does use more power and you cannot turn noise cancellation off with the Bose and still listen through the headset like you can with these. These also have a transparency mode that allows you to hear voices with the noise cancellation on. There is some white noise when you use this feature but the Bose does not even have this option (at least not on my model). I have been using these on and off for 2 days and they are still going strong on only one charge. Overall, I like these headphones which seem like a really good value. I would have given them 5 stars if they had a way to know the power status each time you turn them on.

title: DO NOT BUY, stopped working in less than a month, no customer service to hear back from.
text:
Another Update!:
Has stopped working completely. Sounds like this is a common problem looking at how many other 1-star ratings they have that say the same thing!

Backlight shows when USB-C (power cable only it seems) is plugged in, but nothing happens when the included HDMI-to-mini-HDMI cable is plugged into any source. Have tried two separate computers, both with history of working with this and other external monitors, and Android tablet, to no avail.
Called customer service line and got voicemail after many rings, saying they are receiving a high number of calls.
I wonder why!
Sent email as customer service has suggested.
No response in 48 hours via email.

UPDATE: Change to 3 Stars!
:After installing and finding out the issue with the cables, I looked for an alternate product before returning.
There are none that have the build quality. So I have decided to keep it.
It is still inconvenient that this requires BOTH my Gen 1 USB-C port to power, and the HDMI port to view. But it is more solidly attached and stays in place (and is more flexible on viewing angles) than anything else I have found.

Original:
Only after it arrived and I opened the manual did I find out why this was not working just like my last screen.
This does not work with any other USB-C port except the absolute most recent version, USB-C 3.1 Gen 2!

My previous extended screen (Duex Plus by Mobile Pixels) worked just fine with my USB-C 3.1 Gen 1 port. Unfortunately the construction on that unit is a bit flimsier and I broke an important part very shortly after starting to use.
This looked like (and still feels like) a more robust design.
BUT it requires the use of BOTH the USB-C port and the HDMI port to operate with my newer (less than a year) Windows 11 laptop (because as was FALSELY ADVERTISED, the HDMI port cannot generate power for the unit. It requires both ports to work.
SO sending it back. And pissed about the waste of time and resources that would have been skipped if the manufacturer/reseller would have just been honest in the advertising.

title: A great head unit for the money
text:
I bought this head unit for 2 main reasons: wireless Android auto, and 2 wire input for steering wheel controls. It has definitely fulfilled both of those reasons very well. There's plenty of reviews on the head unit in general so I'll touch on these specific points. That being said, the head unit overall is very nice, especially considering the price point.

Firstly, the wireless Android auto. Wireless Android auto, although getting more popular, is still pretty hard to find on a not expensive head unit. I didn't want to have to plug my phone in every time I got in the car, and my phone for whatever reason has connection issues when plugged in. The wireless aa on this head unit is really nice. It takes about 20 seconds for it to enter Android auto from when the key is turned on, which is pretty good to me. The connection is really good, with a few occasional disconnects. That can be resolved quickly by just tapping the aa button again and you'll be back in about 10 seconds. I also don't have any of the issues I had with wired aa. Not sure what that's all about, but if you have a similar problem, this probably will work good for you.

Secondly, the steering wheel controls. I have a 2009 Subaru outback 3.0r, and it has a 2 wire steering wheel control output. For this specific generation, you need to convert to the jdm climate control/radio bezel, and need a seperate harness to get the steering wheel control output wires. This radio has 2 wire input, so I was expecting the hookup to be similar to a past head unit I had, where I just matched 2 wires up and it worked. However in this, you have to ground one of the car-side swc wires, and hook the other up to one of the radio ones. The other radio one isnt hooked up to anything. This allowed it to work, and it's suprisingly responsive with the input too, which is a nice bonus from my last head unit.

Overall I would highly recommend this head unit. The only thing I wish it had was the ability to turn the screen completely off while still listening to music. I do realize that thats a fairly uncommon feature, but I miss it from my last head unit. That being said, that's essentially my only complaint, so I'm still very happy with it.

title: Good for custom length install
text:
This mount is cheap and does what it is supposed to. The armature has enough room to hide power, HDMI, and trigger wires with a little to spare. The mount is white just like most ceilings (why black mounts and projectors on a white ceiling? Silly.).

This is ideal for my particular installation. Nobody makes a mount designed to clear a standard ceiling-mount ceiling fan. There are long down rods and tight surface-mount brackets , but no mid-length mounts.

This mount is made of thin aluminum and is easy to hacksaw through to create a custom length. Measure twice and thoroughly think through the geometry first. To accomplish this you will need:
Tape measure
Hacksaw
Masking tape to protect the finish
Motor tool or file to finish cutout for wires
Sandpaper to clean up edges
Drill and bit to redrill holes in down rod

There are countless odd custom installation needs that this could be the answer to. Plus it’s cheap enough that if you muck it up there’s no need to cry.

I do not like the way the projector bracket mounts to the down rod. It’s awkward and damned near impossible. Perhaps it would work better if the bracket/down rod assembly were connected first and then slid into the female section of the down rod. You’d still have to fight the wires but at least there would only be one screw to contend with.

The second big ding in the score is the lack of fine adjustment in the mount. Using the mount to correct projector/screen alignment is preferable to using lots of keystone correction. Most mounts have provisions for tilting the projector front/back and left/right through screws or thumbscrews. This one relies on manhandling. I even had to shim the top of the mount to get it to hold level.

If I were still installing projectors for pay I’d definitely keep one or two of these on hand for odd installations. It would not be difficult for the manufacturer to modify this design to intentionally be cut to size. That sure would be handy and, I’d assume, probably sell well.

title: Quality parts, warm CPU, cool GPU
text:
This is my first case from Fractal, and overall I am impressed by the quality and engineering of the case.

The panels have thick durable paint. The magnetic front panel has fabric, but it's only for appearances, because air does not pass through it. The only piece of the case with questionable quality is the long plastic base/foot. It's super flexible and I could easily see it breaking if you move your computer around a lot.

The build I put in here is probably beefier than Fractal intended the case for: The RTX 4080 FE easily fits, and stays between 50c and 60c during use, with no case fan installed. An RX 6950XT also fits easily alongside the two massive fans that Fractal included. The 4080 stays cooler in this case due to the location of it's air intake and exhaust.

As nice as the fans are, I found that they were not useful in the case. Air does not move between the CPU and GPU chamber. You can not fit any fan within the CPU chamber, where they're needed most.

Finding a CPU cooler that came in under 70mm that also fit the motherboard while keeping the chip cool was a challenge.

I tried a few configurations with my 12600k and my Gigabyte Z690i Ultra Lite MB, but the only one I (forcefully) could fit was a low profile Noctua L12S. The required force was due to my board, not the case.

I had to reshape the cooler to fit around the board's tall VRM heatsink and mount it sideways. It is keeping the CPU around 50c at idle, but spikes quickly with lots of fan noise under any load. The fan struggles to both cool and exhaust the heat.

It's a beautiful and usable case from Fractal, but do consider the cooling limitations if you are thinking of purchasing. Additionally, consider where you'll place the case, if you sit to the right of it you're going to cook... Lol

A+ packaging, assembly instructions, and design
C+ for case base/foot

My biggest suggestion to Fractal is to add an inch or so to the width of this case. It wouldn't jeopardize the appearance, and would allow many more cooling options.

title: Good budget mSD
text:
Got this TMEZON 64GB Micro SD Card for use as local video cache in an IP security camera. Design and build quality are atypical micro SD card, not noticeably different from any other.

Functionality is good, slow read but write is better than expected. Passed badblocks -wsv scan. Overall performance stats are, average read speed 79.2 MB/s is 99% of claimed 80 MB/s, average write speed 45.42 MB/s is 302.8% of claimed 15 MB/s, average access time 2 ms, according to nine Gnome Disks benchmarks. The benchmark graphs for read are flat, for write it's a little jagged with short downward spikes, no major drop offs, no curves, meaning this is card is probably performing normally.

Test data - read MB/s, write MB/s, access ms:
1000x1MB High I/O:
Test 1: 73.6, 51.9, 2.05.
Test 2: 73.8, 52.1, 2.02.
Test 3: 73.9, 52.5, 1.96.
Average: 73.77, 52.17, 2.01.

100x10MB Balanced:
Test 1: 81.3, 48.3, 2.01.
Test 2: 81.9, 48.4, 1.98.
Test 3: 81.1, 48.4, 1.92.
Average: 81.43, 48.37, 1.97.

10x1000MB Bulk Data:
Test 1: 82.6, 35.7, 2.00.
Test 2: 82.1, 35.7, 2.02.
Test 3: 82.5, 35.8, 2.02.
Average: 82.40, 35.73, 2.01

Test platform is a new, low-end, but surprisingly decent mini PC with a USB3.0 flash card reader, running a fresh basic install of Fedora 37 WS, updated.

Price point is good, consistent with similar items.

Overall, 5 stars, good budget mSD.

title: Best thing for plex
text:
Finally bought this to add to plex as well as an antenna. So glad I bought this. Hooked a coaxial cable from the antenna to this. And an ethernet cable from the hdhomerun to my router. Didn't need to download the hdhomerun software. Just went into plex and it showed up. Selected what ota(over the air) channels I wanted in my guide. Let it pull the programming guide up and it started recording. It was extremely easy. I'm using it through plex. So keep that in mind.
Now for some cons.
1. You can only dvr ota channels. Not plex channels themselves.
2. I noticed when viewing through the phone app the ota channels will stutter. Best thing to do is play 3 seconds then rewind it. That usually stops the stuttering.
3. Most issues I have experienced are with plex. Not the dvr itself.
4. The more channels you select the slower it loads on the guide. Don't know for sure if this is a plex issue or a dvr issues. But less works better.
5. A shorter coaxial cable from your antenna works better than with a long one. The longer the cable the less signal strength you get.
6. 2 tuners just doesn't seem to be enough. I should have bought the 4 tuner version.
7. If you don't close out what you are watching it will keep that tuner locked up as in use and fail to record.
8. If your plex server is not on and running ypu will not get ota channels. So make sure it is on during a power outtage or have a back up antenna hooked to a tv.

Pros
1. Didn't need to download any software. Just worked straight out of thr box with plex.
2. Better signal strength and picture than with the antenna hooked up to the TV.
3. Dvr feature is nice. Buy a secondary Hard drive for your recordings.
4. Played very nicely with plex. But buy the 4 tuner model.
I would highly recommend this for anyone with plex that wants local channels. No extra software or downloads needed. No looking for guide software. Just plug and play. Will definitely be buying another one.

title: Fits Sendy Aiva
text:
I ordered these to try with my SendyAudio Aivas, since I know DT990 pads are compatible size-wise (the pads measure roughly 100mm on my calipers). I trust the Dekoni name, but had yet to try anybody's cooling gel earpads.

The Dekoni Gel Series fit the Aivas perfectly; before these pads, I was using aftermarket lambskin leather memory foam angled earpads. Compared to those, which have stitching at the edge of the "lip" that stretches around the mounting points, the Dekoni pads are easier to install.

Dekoni states that these pads will yield tempered sub-bass along with increased mids and highs. For my use, I noticed a slight decrease in sub-bass, but no obvious effect on the mids and highs. Sound isolation is as good as can be expected with open-back headphones. Since Dekoki's sound comparisons apply to Beyerdynamics using factory pads, keep in mind that my assessment may not be indicative of your experience.

I've avoided cooling gel pads for so long because (regardless of manufacturer), you can usually find reviews that say the cooling effect is marginal to ineffective; this is logical to me, since the "cooling gel" is typically a thin layer of material placed in front of whatever primary foam is being used. Unfortunately, these pads from Dekoni are no exception. They are indeed "cool" at first, but that sensation goes away quickly, and, in my experience sitting in a 70-degree room, they are indistinguishable from most traditional pads within 10 minutes of use. To be fair: you may notice a bigger difference if you move around a lot while gaming compared to my passive music listening; also, I do not find the pads to be hotter than others, either.

Despite not being magical air conditioners for your ears, the pads do deliver the comfort you expect from Dekoni. The foam is soft and remains comfortable during extended use. The front of the pads are not leather or velour, but appear to be polyester (think of the activewear popular today); it is indeed cooler than velour, comfortable, and easier to keep clean.

If you're in need of new pads, Dekoni is always a good choice, and you may be happy with these as long as you don't expect miracles in the cooling department.

title: Get these instead of Sony Linkbuds, skip the app.
text:
tldr: If you want open air, these are the best option, especially for the price. Don't fall for Sony's hole gimmick, it's terrible. The Soundpeats copy the 1st gen Apple Airpod design, and are a great open-air headphone. Just avoid their app. If you want to spend on Sony, get the Linkbuds S (the one with no hole).

Full review: These aren't perfect, but they're much better than the price indicates. Compared to the $150 Sony Linkbuds:

-Sound quality is no competition, Sony's hole ruins music. SoundPeats' sound is very nice, with plenty of Bass response, and a relatively flat sound curve. It's open air, so no subwoofer feeling, but still plenty of depth and dynamic range. Sony didn't use LDAC because the Linkbuds can't reproduce music accurately. The SoundPeats allow me to hear the difference between LDAC and AAC/SBC. It's not the highest quality out there, but it's very nice.

-Comfort and security: Soundpeats is more comfortable and stays in the ear just as well as Sony. This is becuase Soundpeats copied the design of the first gen Apple Airpod. No fancy wings, they just stay in place. Sony's fat donut causes physical pain after an hour. SoundPeat's tapered design does not. It's still hard plastic, but the shape allows me to adjust the fitment to avoid any pain. Still not as comfortable as a silicone tip, but it's much closer than the Linkbuds.

-Sony's app is awesome, so I can recommend the Linkbuds S (the one without the hole and uses typical silicone tips). Even if you need to hear your surroundings, the Linkbuds S has great transparency and ANC. I use the SoundPeats without ever installing the app.

-SoundPeats' touch controls are more robust, but less reliable. Sony's Wide Area Tap should be standard with wireless earbuds, it's a shame they didn't include it with other models.

-SoundPeats' case is more flat than Sony's, so it's easier to fit in a jeans coin pocket. Both Soundpeats and Sony have similar battery life.

title: I'm going with 4.5
text:
I've gone through a lot of BT speakers. I hope these last: I love the sound for the size! and i got two, as I've always wanted to try stereo pairing. they sound great! I listened to these for a couple of hours today. now I'm back on headphones as everyone goes to sleep. my bucket is full, I'm so satisfied with good sound today.

it's unreal to me how much imaging we miss when listening to music through a mono speaker. life is too short for mono! I love smart speakers but virtually ALL of them are mono. my opinion, if you don't regularly enjoy a great set of headphones, higher-end earbuds, or fairly spendy stereo speakers you are missing out on what music can sound like. makes me miss my big receiver and speakers.

anyway the size of this speaker is perfect for me. it's not my daily driver: i have a bigger speaker in my office that stays plugged in. this can't quite compete on sound, but then the other speaker/soundbar isn't portable. this one I can put my phone or Chromebook in the bedroom and take a speaker into the bathroom with me. forgot how much I like singing in the shower lol. i don't take it IN the shower but it sits on a cabinet not far from it. i can grab it to adjust the volume or whatever and not worry that getting it wet will hurt it.

the battery lasts forever. the Bluetooth has insane range.

the light is not terribly exciting, but I do like the little splash of color. bonus points would be awarded if it would sync the light to the other speaker in stereo mode, but it does not.

last (for now) but not least, the price/value is fabulous. they don't have the punch that some bigger brands do, but you get a great speaker for A LOT less money. nothing about them feels or sounds cheap.

now i see Notabrick has a 40W version also! hmm.

I'm intrigued by the review that suggested these need to be broken in. maybe messing with us. but... I may have to try that! is it possible these just get better?

title: Nicely Made, Easy to Setup & Use, Pretty Powerful, Good Value
text:
This is a great and powerful mini PC! First off, the unit itself feels nicely made and doesn't feel cheap. I really like the design and the size is perfect. It has multiple USB ports and has support for dual HDMI displays.

The PC came with a fully licensed copy of the Windows 11 Pro operating system and had no issues doing the updates and getting it setup with my Microsoft account. I was also able to hook up a wireless mouse and keyboard and had no issues with operation. Other peripherals such as webcams, printers, and others worked just fine, too..

The setup of this PC was extremely easy - plug it in, turn it on, follow the on screen prompts for setting up Windows and your account, and you're all set. Depending on the monitor or TV you are using for this mini PC, there may be some over burn along the edges. If this happens, just simply adjust the settings on your monitor or TV.

Once this was setup, I tested playing 4K sample videos and it played them with no issues - no stuttering or jitters during play back. I also played games on multiple cloud gaming services (Luna, Stadia, xCloud, Shadow, and GeForce Now) and this had no issues playing. I tried other other games that you would have to install and most of them ran fine. If you are looking to play more graphics intense games, then I wouldn't recommend this. However, if you just want to play casual games or don't mind playing in lesser quality, then you will have no issues with this one. I can also say I used this to render a 4K video through Power Director and it handled it with no problems to report.

The triple monitor output works as it should and allowed for a great overall experience. When using this setup, I was able to multi-task without the PC slowing down much. In fact, I would say it was hardly noticeable.

All things considered, this a great mini PC that works as described and in my opinion, is an excellent value for the price. It's portable, pretty powerful (for most things), and easy to use. It's not going to be a gaming power house so just be aware. If you want to do light gaming, video editing, and anything else below that power wise, then this is perfect! I really love mine!

title: Amazing battery life
text:
OK, I may not be looking for the same things in a smart watch as most people, but this watch satisfies all that I was looking for.
It comes at a reasonable price.
It pairs with my Android phone without a lot of difficulty. Yes, you do need to install the app and set it up appropriately, and it's not completely obvious how to do that, but it isn't as confusing as some. I prefer that my watch shouldn't hijack the phone call function, and I did have to hold the watch to my ear for a few calls before I figured out that turning the phone off on the watch would keep it from answering calls without stopping text messages from displaying on the watch. You do have to set up the app to get messages on the watch, but that feature seems to work once set up.
The main point of a watch for me is to tell time, and the time it gets from my phone is, of course, what it gets from the network.
The really remarkable feature of this watch is its battery life, though. Its 400 mAh battery gives me a couple of weeks between recharges, and that's when I charge it, even though it's still showing about 35% battery power left. It should go for 3 weeks without much trouble, and there are steps like dimming the display that could give more time.
You can select from a large quantity of watch faces. That's OK, but you are limited to the choices in the app. The choices are like the channels on cable TV; lots of options but few you'd want to look at. You can insert your own background photo on one watch face, but that watch face shows only day of the week, date, and digital hours and minutes. I was hoping to be able to do more customization. I'd also like to see a digital time display with seconds.
The features are interesting and entertaining. I like the blood pressure feature because it gives me a much lower reading than a blood pressure cuff, but I am curious how it works at all. Things like heart rate and oxygen percentage seem to be accurate. Weather (outside temperature) depends on the phone to connect with an unidentified source on the internet and is updated hourly, which may not be enough.
This watch has more features than I'm interested in using, and the ones I've tried all seem to work. It has premium smart watch characteristics without the premium price.

title: Night Vision is Surprisingly Good BUT 😯
text:
[[VIDEOID:ee41a9ae9281cee8f8896af275708c1a]] This comes preloaded with an upside-down video. 😲🤣 I think I received a used item or a returned item. 🤨 The night vision is surprisingly good with distance capability. In my pics the shot is over 100ft and it was clear and bright. If it looks out of focus it's because I didn't focus it with the wheel which BTW is smooth but long meaning turn turn turn to focus.

The build quality is a couple notches above cheap. It's good with a solid ok feel but it's not high end or anything. Didn't expect it to be. Why is this only 1 star? Woooh let's get into it.

The SD card slot broke the 1st time I pulled the card and reinserted it. 😐 Now I need some tweezers to pull it out. Still works though but the spring is caput. The display screen has wavy lines the whole time. The anti shake does nothing. There is no image stabilization. The microphone recording level is low only picking up your voice that is a few inches away. Good for narration if you speak loud enough but thats all. The mic is on the low end quality wise.

The button press is way too clicky and it's apparent in playback videos. Theres also some kind of noise during playback sounding like a film reel rolling or something. Annoying. The display brightness cannot be adjusted it's glaringly bright at night but ok for daytime.

Despite all of its flaws the night vision is really impressive with good adjustments. Too bad they didn't make all of it as good as the night vision. And I am extremely disappointed that I received a used one. 🤨

Will update to see if you can buy with confidence from this seller. If everything worked the way they claimed this would have been a must buy. Too bad.

UPDATE: It doesn't charge. It's completely dead. It didn't even take 1 charge. Got a replacement thinking maybe I got a dud. 2nd one won't focus right image is slightly blurry no matter what. This is a low quality product with problems. 😐 For some reason they won't post my review. 🤔

title: Stunned at rave reviews. This is a miserable brick
text:
[[VIDEOID:ca7cf7aaa7071275e3857b52855584c6]] I got this as a gift and was so excited. I was a bit surprized at how big it is, and with the 2 'D' batteries it weighs 2 pounds. I don't think I'll hang it on my shower head.

I like the features -5 AM presets, 5 FM presets and the weather alert channels of which there seems to be 1 that come in. It's easy to set up but that's where it ended.

Hitting the "band" button to go from AM to FM would just activate the 60 second timer, which uses the same button. For those 60 seconds there was no radio. All I'd get is *any and every button" I'd press bouncing between the weather channel and the clock until that 60 seconds ran out with no way to turn it off. I thought it was defective until I had this happen a few times and realized that I guess there's some luck or secret to merely trying to change the band.

The sound is horrific. AM is ok but FM ...yikes. The sound I'd scratchy, faint and fades in and out with worse interference if you move the radio any direction an inch. I don't expect this out of what I was stunned to see was a really pricy radio.

There's a long, wire FM antenna that hangs out the bottom but you wouldn't have this hanging out in the shower and it's very intrusive period. I put it in the bathroom just to humor myself and the several places to hang or place it gave me lousy, fading-in-and-out sound I found utterly unacceptable, annoying and unlistenable. It's now sitting on my bed fading in and out, with static, at the angle I best got any reception. I have several battery radios that are decades old and use 2 AA batteries that are tons better than this thing.

Maybe I got a lemon, but im so sorry the person who got this for me wasted so much money. As usual, reviews are glowing and the majority so im hoping to give more perspective on this. An expensive brick that is like playing a casino game of buttons just to find a station, at least this Thing I got.

title: It's ok for if you're on a budget
text:
Do you just want a tablet but don't want to spend the couple hundred that most name brand performance tablets costs? Then this may be a tablet you may want as long as you have the tolerance to be dealing with an off brand android tablet.
Out of the box, there is a thin plastic screen cover/protector. That's nice, but it not a very swipe friendly surface and may feel a bit of a drag. It also came with a case cover to put the tablet in so it could be propped up on the side.
The set up was very slow, much slower than I anticipated with the advertised specs. The screen keyboard sometimes has a long delay before it shows up and I would question if the tablet was even responding to the touchscreen when I needed to fill out the search bar and stuff.
I've ran roblox on it and it would be slow and lags at times. I've tried pokemon go with it and it works great for a spread out wide area but suffers badly if you get to an area that is densely populated with gyms and stops.
The battery life is poor in my opinion but is close as described on the listing during my frequent usage. The worst part is the stand by or sleep mode. Seems the battery runs down too fast than I would expect if it has nothing running in the background. I would have it fully charged before I unplugged it for the night and then come morning (8-9hrs later) the battery percentage would be around the high 80%. It can do fast charging.
Now for the biggest gripe I have with this is the wifi. The wifi works just fine when it is connected. I can search the internet, download apps from the google play store, and connect slowly on games that use online connectivity. The thing I don't like about the wifi functionality is if the tablet is in sleep/standby mode for a long period of time, even if it is 2-4 hours, the internet connection would be disconnected and will not reconnect at all in settings. Only sure way of correcting this is holding the power button down and select the restart option. This is the only way I know of that will bring the internet connection back on the tablet until it does it again soon.
If you really want to get this tablet because it's at a cheap price list then be sure to consider what I have described in this review if you will tolerate it daily.

title: H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector - Great for Quick, Non-Mission Critical Applications
text:
In this review, I'll be discussing the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector, a product that provides a quick and easy way to splice two wires together without the need for tools or stripping the insulation.

What is the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector?
The H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector is a small, H-shaped device that is used to connect two wires together by clamping them securely in place. It features a simple, push-together design that allows you to splice the wires together in just a few seconds.

How does it work?
To use the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector, simply push the ends of the two wires you want to splice together into the open ends of the connector. The connector will clamp down on the wires, securing them in place and creating a physical connection between them. No stripping of the insulation is required, and no tools are needed.

What's to like?
There are several things to like about the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector. First and foremost, it is quick and easy to use. Simply push the wires into the connector and you're done. It is also very convenient, as it requires no special tools or equipment. This makes it a great choice for non-mission critical projects where speed and ease of use are more important than a strong, reliable connection.

What's not to like?
While the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector is great for quick, non-mission critical projects, it may not be the best choice for more demanding applications. The connection it provides may not be as strong or reliable as a crimp connector, and it may not be suitable for use in high-voltage or high-current situations. If you need a strong, reliable connection that can withstand high levels of current or voltage, you may want to consider using a crimp connector instead.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the H Type 2 Pin No Strip Wire Connector is a great product for quick, non-mission critical projects. It is quick and easy to use, requires no special tools, and is convenient to have on hand. However, it may not be the best choice for more demanding applications where a strong, reliable connection is required. I give it 4 stars.

title: Basic laptop with good support
text:
This is a Windows alternative to those who don’t want a Chromebook or iPad, but do a lot of web browsing and Office applications. This runs Windows 11 Home S Mode out of the box which is excellent for young kids or people who are not tech savvy as you can only run applications that are available through the Microsoft Store which means less chances of viruses and malware. Prepare some time when you first turn it on to install a lot of updates.

It’s not the lightest laptop by any means, but typical of this size and price range. The body is made of plastic and feels pretty solid, though I did notice the screen wobble a bit while typing. The matte anti-reflective screen looks gorgeous with good viewing angles and just average brightness. At 15” you have enough space for work and maybe also view a video in the corner, but note it is NOT a touchscreen. There is a webcam on top with average video quality and 2 built-in mics for audio. The keyboard is not backlit, and the trackpad is one solid plate with no buttons. It took me a little to get used to clicking on it as I found it a little on the small side. Speakers are good, but nothing to go wild about. While I like how slim the laptop is I find it difficult to grip the lid to flip it open.

Performance on this feels snappy. Web browsing was smooth and fast. It played YouTube videos at 1080 60FPS for 30 minutes straight and no dropped frames. Fans do kick on more than I would like even at idle.

On the sides of the laptop you have a Mic/Headphone jack, SD Card slot, 1 USB-C and 2 SuperSpeed USB ports, and an HDMI out port. The processor is a 12th gen Intel Core i3 1215U 1.20GHz with 8GB Ram and 128GB SSD. The battery, hard drive and ram are not user accessible. Bluetooth is available if you are looking to add a mouse, speakers, headphones, etc…

Overall I think this is a solid laptop in the low end price range. It has some decent performance boosting to eliminate work flow lag plus HP offers great support for their products. While I don’t recommend this for gaming, if you have Xbox Game Pass Ultimate you can stream games with it (it has Wifi 6.)

title: Amazing Tiny PC; Great for Office Work, Passable for Older Games
text:
I'm working from home these days, so I got this little Small Form Factor (SFF) PC to do my work on.
I've been using it at least five days a weeks for months now, and am pleased to report that I'm xtremely happy with it.
Here's why I say that:

Pros
-----
* Tiny. It can sit largely unnoticed on your desk, especially if you put it behind your monitors. Alternatively, you could also mount it on the back of a monitor or underneath a desk.
* Powerful. This PC is more powerful than most of the PCs I've owned throughout my life, and handles day-to-day tasks such as web browsing, creating and viewing documents, web browsing, and listening to music without breaking a sweat.
* Passable (non-AAA) gaming performance. I tested this little PC with several video games, and was frankly surprised that it could run them at all. It wasn't able to handle modern AAA titles very well, but older titles - those that have been out for a few years, or those with lower hardware requirements - ran surprisingly well.
* Supports multiple large monitors very, very well.
* Comes with a Windows 11 Pro license, which is worth over $100 on its own.
* Has more than enough ports for most people: 4 USB A ports, 1 USB C port, 2 HDMI ports, a 1G physical Ethernet port, a MicroSD slot (easy way to add more storage for cheap), and a 3.5mm headphone jack.
* Comes equipped with WiFi 6E and Bluetooth 5.2 - both of which are surprisingly modern and up to date for such an inexpensive PC.
* Very quiet.
* Clean, minimalist industrial design.

Cons
-----
* Only one USB C port. More would have been nice, since USB C is where everything's slowly going. I'm not deducting a star for this, though, since the description clearly stated that this is the case.
* Manual isn't very useful, so you'd better be comfortable plugging everything in yourself. This isn't really difficult, but I thought I should mention that it doesn't do much hand-holding.

title: A good projector with portability and decent sound
text: This projector is nice at times and frustrating at other times. I’ve had this for almost a month now and can definitely say it’s not quite as user friendly as I would’ve expected for this price point. The remote is an essential part of this projector. Many of the controls are only available through the remote. That would be fine if the working distance wasn’t 2 to 3 feet from the base unit. You literally cannot sit 5ft away and have the remote work. Once you’ve got your picture set the correct way the picture is average to slightly above average for a 4K projector. One nice feature is that you can project video on the ceiling. It must be used in an extremely dark room to get the full effect. Harmon Kardon has collaborated with this company to provide sound and it does a good job for a Bluetooth speaker. I wouldn’t say it’s outstanding but it’s good enough. My honest opinion is that this will appeal to someone who appreciates the design (and it is a very cool retro design) but not the actual functionality as much. The bottom line to me is that it’s overpriced. There’s no screen mirroring from an iPhone. I contacted the company and they replied to this issue stating that there would be an upcoming app with a technical fix for this problem in the next month or two. As you can see from my first picture,  I plugged in a fire tv box, however my main reason for ordering this was the portability option- being able to screen mirror movies from my phone while camping or traveling. It does have a lithium battery that can last as long as 3 hours for video and longer if you only use the Bluetooth speaker. It also comes with sound deadening discs that are supposed to reduce speaker vibration-you place them under the three pointed brass like pointed feet. That would’ve been a cool touch had this not been designed to be so portable. The discs are separate and not attached or magnetic. Consequently, we’ve already lost one of them…That makes the other two useless…So, it’s a nice Bluetooth speaker that can project video. Not exactly cutting edge stuff but if you like and appreciate really cool, well designed, aesthetic retro items this may appeal to you. Personally, i would’ve liked this a lot more at half the price. I hope that’s been helpful.

title: STOPPED WORKING AFTER A MONTH - GOOGLE NIGHTMARE TO WORK WITH FOR REPAIRS
text: Watch worked fine for about 3 weeks. Then the battery display was not going down (after 27 hours of being at 94%, which anyone who uses a smartwatch knows the batteries are not that resilient!). Tried charging it, but it didn't fluctuate the battery at all, then tried powering down and restarting. The screen became unresponsive anytime I navigated to it. Couldn't figure out how to get it to respond to anything at this point, the entire watch was just non-responsive. Figured a factory reset would be best option, so I did. Then in reconnecting the phone to the app, this is where everything fell to pieces. It spent 8 hours "connecting to phone". Finally contacted Google, who recommended a hard reset (holding the wheel and button for 45 sec). It would then pair to the app, but that is as far as it would go. It sat for hours "updating watch". Called Google again. They wanted proof I actually paid for the watch before moving forward with my case. Sent them all documentation to their liking, including proof of purchase, serial number, price paid and from where etc. etc. I was told they would escalate my case and I'd have a resolution within 48 hours. SIX DAYS LATER there is NOTHING, not even a "Hey, we are still investigating this issue". Emailed them re: the open case. Nothing. Called again and after 20 minutes of investigation they inform me I need to fill out this email survey (that they should have sent days ago, because that is what they were waiting on to move the case forward) and said they would replace it. Get the email and they asked for EVERYTHING except my firstborn child. Videos of the issue, the purchase confirmations, pictures of the original box, SN, operating versions of watch, app, order numbers. I spent over an hour gathering all their requirements, sent it in, and they kicked it back saying they could not see the screenshots embedded in the email, nor could they open any of the attachments they requested. These are not odd files People, a jpeg, mp4, PDF, C'MON GOOGLE. Resent everything AGAIN. No response yet. I have now spent more time trying to get this fracker working than I have been able to spend with my kids. It's ridiculous. I have never had so many infuriating issues with a Google Product, or Google Support.

title: No wonder this is one of the most popular IEMs in the market!
text:
For the last 6 months, I have tested many IEM from $20-$300. I am surprised how good they are.For the ones I evaluated. None of them are bad. In fact, all of them are better than my airpod pros. Many times better. Unless you have to have wireless earbuds, there is no reason not to get one of these budget IEM to listen to music. KZ ZSN Pro X is one of the more popular budget IEMs in the market and one of the earbuds I tested.

There ore tons of YouTube reviews about this IEM. You can learn about the Pros and Cons from these videos.

It comes with a number of silicone ear tips. You have to try them all to determine which set best fits you. Ear tips make or break your experience. If the bass is lacking, it is probably due to poor fit of your ear tips
As for the sound quality, I have mixed feelings about it. It has a V shape sound signature with strong bass and shape highs.

I prefer warm and dark sound. I love how deep the bass is. It is punchy. Sub bass is strong but not muddy.

The mids are thick and comfortable. It gives you the sense of weight but not overwhelming.

As for the highs, this is my biggest concern. I found this IEM is more on the bright side. It can be shouty depending on what kind of music you listen to although the detail is very good. I can’t listen to it for more than a few hours without feeling fatigued. But for a quick short session or for a workout, this is perfect.

Soundstage is just average. The sound is more “inside your head’ instead of “outside of head”. However, the imaging is good. Instrument separation is surprisingly capable. I have no problem pinpoint position of different instruments.

Overall, this is a great little IEM. Sounds super engaging. Although I don’t like the highs, but for the price you can’t go wrong. This is still a great IEM and a 5 stars product to me.

title: Just what I needed! A bit misleading in the posting...
text:
The pros:

I purchased these for my apartment that moved to where the modem was in the far corner of my apartment away from the main room, and oh boy these were just what I needed! They are so simple to use with just two ethernet cables to clip into both sides, it's as simple as that!

The outside is a plastic-like material and the connector insides are metal with chrome finish inside! It looks as good as it does in the image! --- Please keep in mind that not all ethernet cables will "click" when inserted into them. I have various ethernet cables that I own and while some have an audible click, others do not. You can see if your cable is in all the way if you gently tug on the cable and see if it slides out. If not, then it's in all the way!

The cons:

I give this 4 stars, mainly because almost everything about this product is perfect, except the listing... I have a 10 gig network in my apartment and these are not capable of handling 10 gig connections... Both couplers I got are incapable of handling 10 gig network speeds. The fastest I got was 2.5 gig speeds. This may be due to the way the couplers are designed, similar to how ethernet cables have to be specially designed for 10 gig speeds (wire quality, thickness, shielding, etc). In the product description, it says can support speeds to 10 gigabit, that is incorrect. Perhaps I got a bad pair and other people can say that they can handle 10 gig/gigabit speeds? But my network interfaces are unable to establish a 10 gig, or even a 5 gig network connection over these. I'm guessing it's probably because the internal bits are not sheilded and there's too much crosstalk with the individual pins.

Overall, if you do not need anything over 1 gigabit ethernet speeds, this is a perfect product! It's well-built, it's designed with a very modern look and very simple to use! However... If you are coming here for a coupler to connect anything over 2.5 gigabit, like 5g/gigabit or even 10gig/gigabit speeds... you're taking your chances and I would just buy a long CAT 6 ethernet cable at that point!

title: Not bad for the price
text:
Overall this capture card is a really good value. It's UVC-compliant, can output up to 1080p 60 fps, has dedicated audio input/output, and is barely $40. The one downside I found is that it only really supports the MotionJPEG format in the UVC driver:

title: RGB Fried in less than 2 months. HOWEVER, great customer service!
text:
Read to the bottom to understand four stars.

Original Post: Looked amazing. Then the RGB controller dies. I found other people left reviews on Musetex cases here on Amazon that had the same problem. I try to ignore negative feedback and give companies a chance, but this time it backfired (at first: EDIT). I will probably be ordering a case from another manufacturer and returning this one if I can get it done in time. (I did not.: EDIT)
Edit: I was contacted by the company and offered both the refund or a replacement control board without waiting on the RMA process. I declined the offer since I had already purchased another controller which is on the way. So with that said, I have increased my star rating for two reasons.

1. The company attempted to make it right when seeing what I had to say about my experience.
2. The original review should not have been 1 star. The case is well designed for the most part. It is very difficult to find cases which offer tons of features whether or not you use them all.

*Update 4/23 and why this review is now four stars: I was sent a completely new fan set which does not rely upon the RBG control card to operate. This gesture was not cheap by any standard. This means I will have to eventually gut the case cooling system and replace the fans to get my RGB back, but it definitely shows dedication to quality to have paid attention and discovered an issue in production, then fix the problem. The new style fans are to be included with future cases, so this problem will most likely be solved by now in cases offered on Amazon.

This really was a case design that handled everything I needed, and RGB is a nicety. That RGB doesn't keep my video card and processor from frying. I wish good luck to this case company because I believe they actually care about the end product.

To the Designers: I did have to remove the HDD mount in order to use the modular power supply I picked (EVGA 1300W). This meant I have lost a huge backup storage drive I planned on installing with this build and had to settle for USB. So perhaps moving that mount further away from where the power supply will be installed would be a good idea. There was plenty of space toward the front of the case to do so.

title: Very capable PC for the size and price, not a full-blown gaming system
text: I got this in the hopes of having a much more portable gaming rig. The initial setup could not have been simpler. I went through the OOBE (Out Of Box Experience) with Windows 11 and once I signed in to my Microsoft account, it kinda finished itself. It shipped with Windows 11 Pro 21H2. The solid state drive is plenty fast and the 16 GB of RAM is twice what my regular gaming rig shipped with. Do I wish there was more space on the internal hard drive? Yes, but swapping in a larger M2 2280 drive would be easy with an external adapter and some free online software. There is supposed to be the ability to add a 2.5" drive to the case, but after taking it apart I was unable to easily discern where that would get hooked up as I didn't see a cable or connector available (see pictures). I am impressed by the responsiveness when doing day-to-day computing: Spreadsheets open quickly, websites render easily, and everything points to this being a very good value for the money. As someone who's used many different 'business-class' laptops over the years, most of which were roughly three times the price of this, you could very easily deploy this PC with a nice monitor or two for folks, and most folks would likely be happier with a real mouse and a full-size keyboard (none of which are included with this PC). I installed Steam and downloaded a first-person shooter from 2011. The in-game movies rendered well and the gameplay was comparable to my full-sized gaming rig. I then installed a current game (still regularly getting updated) to test and see how that worked. I was disappointed to say the least. You could play the current game with this PC, but the video was jerky and not nearly as responsive. I was running the graphics at 1920 x 1080 resolution, I would expect 4k video would be even worse with regards to how many frames per second you'd get. Will this replace my full-sized rig? It will not. But, for the price this is still a very capable little system. While I disagree with the 'Gaming Computer' label, this computer is very quiet, takes up a very small amount of space on your desk (or none if you mount it to the back of a monitor), and would handle pretty much anything short of full-on immersive video gaming with ease. I do feel this PC is still a really good value for the price.

title: As advertised
text:
I was an original investor in their kickstarter campaign and received the headphones on Christmas Eve (nice Christmas present). To this point, I could not be happier. These headphone are perfect for the remote employee that needs to wear headphones most of the work day.

I wear them from 7am to 5pm (yesterday was the first time that I received a low battery warning) . I have them connected to my computer and to my phone; switching between the 2 works seamlessly. I go for a 3-4 mile walk daily and listen to audiobooks. I have had multiple phone calls while on these walks and people cannot tell that I am outdoors because the mic is so good at noise cancelling. It is so good that a extremely loud garbage truck passed me while on one call and no one on the call was able to hear it. I don't listen to a whole lot of music, but when I have, sound is extremely good.

PROS:
* very light and comfortable
* connectivity to multiple devices simultaneously
* long battery life (10+ hours talk time)
* quick charge (30 min max for full charge, 5 min gets a 50% charge)
* ability to mute by merely rotating the mic back (can also mute with a mute button)

CONS (and these are very petty):
* I wish the multi-function button was easier to get to
* muting the device is easy and works but it does not seem to communicate this to the connected device. this means that even though I am actually muted the software (I use Teams) doesn't actually show that I am muted.
* my buddy also got a pair but he has a very large head and though they work well for him, they are not comfortable and he therefore does not use them

2 Month Update: Still really love these headphones; I literally wear them from 7am to 7pm and have only received a low battery warning 2 times. Recharge to 100% it without fail only 30 min.

The noise cancelling microphone is the boss. Had a 30 minute conference call that I took in a bar with a live band playing; Others on the call had no idea that I wasn't at my home office.

title: Impressive! Paired Out of the Box. Nearly Flawless Sound Reproduction for Podcasting & Voice-Overs.
text:
This review is of the GODOX Mini Mic (2 TX+1 RX+Charging Case), 100m (328ft.) Range, 24-Hour, 2.4G Noise Cancelling Mic, Wireless Microphone for PC, Andriod, Record Interview, Vlogs（White).

I have purchased two other wireless mics -- both black -- but they only have the ability to connect to USB-C. And one does not work with my Android phone: Moto G Stylus. The GODOX works well!

This GODOX is handier for me because I can use it on devices that only accept 3.5mm TRS or TRRS audio jacks. It ships with 3 adaptors. These are the first that I've seen with swappable adapters. Cool.

I have an old computer that I use for some editing and does *not* have a USB-C port. I could probably use a USB-C to USB-A adapter, or a hub but now I don't have to. I can just plug this into the mic jack.

Another thing that I like about them is that they're white and blend in with lighter colored clothes.

One minor but very cool feature is that the mics snap back into the charger. I don't know if you've ever had the experience when you put a device, or two, on a charger, come back the next day and it's still dead because the contacts didn't quite align properly. Sucks. I doubt that will ever happen with these Godox mics.

One feature that would give these mics a 6-star rating from me -- :) -- is if they had a jack to plug in an external mic. So, it would function like a mic-pack that you can hide the pack and only have the tiny mic on your lapel, collar, etc.

Of course, I can obtain better sound quality using my wired mics, but for podcasts, Zoom calls, and most voice-overs it's barely noticeable wearing high-quality headphones.

Note: the mics I received shipped with protective plastic over the electrodes, so be sure to remove them before charging.

All-in-all, I give these mics and accessories 5 stars.

title: What a disappointing flagship for google
text:
I thought this phone would be a great upgrade for the pixel 5.
Unfortunately it was not. The key detractors are the ergonomics, the fingerprint scanner which works so poorly I've just been using my password, and the speed to get to the camera.
For the ergonomics: the phone is a two-handed phone in 2023 (2022 release date)! How is it two handed? The point of balance for where you hold it is above your finger and my hands are over 9 inches across. The position of the volume is rather low on the phone likewise the power button is right at 2/3 from the base. This is far too low so when you're holding it if you don't want to manipulate your power button you have to hold it in the bottom one quarter. So the phone becomes completely unstable in your hand unless you're using two hands! Additionally to that it is rather thin so unless you have a case it'll flop around in your hand, then when it does you manipulate the screen. Also the phone is darn slick I had to use duct tape prior to getting a case because it was just fly off a table if it had any sort of incline.

The fingerprint sensor is atrocious and in the middle of the screen. So have you using this say at night and you don't want to wake up the person next to you that fingerprint puts a huge white light in your face instead of being on the back of the phone and not causing any sort of light in previous generations. It honestly works so poorly I don't use it at all.
The amount of time it takes to get to the camera is ridiculous. iPhone figured this out and has it on the lock screen why can't Google? You have to fully unlock your phone then pull up the camera which takes a while to load and then you can get to whatever setting you want. But then with the poor organomics even if you're in the right setting if you're trying to get that quick shot you might hit and move your phone to a different setting and now you've blown it. I've missed multiple cute shots of my infant because of this. The software they tout for the phone like unblur doesn't work very well. I guess it is sort of cool you can film in portrait mode but that isn't worth $1,000.

Tldr stick to the pixel 5 or 6 you already have

title: Excellent Power Strip and  USB Charger
text:
This product is a very nicely made power strip and USB charger. It has a flat plug on the heavy-duty extension cord, allowing the strip to be plugged in behind furniture. It has a sliding bracket that allows the strip to be hung up, which also doubles as a phone stand. It has 3 AC outlets (which it says have child-protection shutters) and 3 USB charging outlets (a USB A and 2 USB C ports) It has an on-off switch with power indicators for both the AC and USB outlets. It also says it has a surge protector.

The interesting thing about this strip is that it is capable of smart fast-charging cell phones that have fast-charging capability. It supposedly supports 14 different fast-charging protocols (who knew there were 14?).

I tested this ability with my old LG phone, which does support fast-charging. My phone has an Micro B type socket (a plug can only be inserted into it one way). Normally, I fast-charge it from an LG wall wart with a USB A to USB Micro B cord.

I used this cord to test the strip's ability to charge my phone. Using the A socket with my cord, the strip would charge my phone, but it did not fast-charge my phone. A careful reading of the instructions seemed to say that only the type C sockets support fast-charging. This would mean that I needed a Type C to Micro B cable, which I did not have.

I bought a Type C to Micro B cable, and then tried charging my phone with this cable. It worked! It fast-charged my phone from a C port! So now, I do not need a separate wall wart, since I can fast-charge from this power strip. The one thing a user definitely needs to know is that in order to use fast-charging mode, you need a cable with a type C plug on one end, and whatever type of plug your phone uses on the other end. If you only have a cable with a USB A plug on one end, you will be able to charge, but not fast-charge. With a cable that uses the the strips C port, you are all set.

I was very favorably impressed with this power strip, and give it my high recommendation.

title: Love, love, love, and love...
text:
So good, I bought two instead of one Marshall Middleton. As wanted, I pair them together to get surround sound, smaller size, and save about $50. Although I own two pairs of Marshall headphones which I'm taking with me to Heaven, at that time - it took awhile for me to commit to buying the speakers. That's because I already own a pair of off-brand Bluetooth speakers that sound so much better and lasts many hours longer than more expensive Beats, Bose, Sony, etc. They have all the other bells-and-whistles specifications, including USB-C, rapid charging, 20+ hours playtime and only cost $30 each. The seller stopped selling them on Amazon.

Emberton II was a huge jump in price. The difference from Emberton I - is it will pair with other Marshall speakers. But only the latest models like the Middleton or more Emberton IIs. Also, the Emberton II has a grain texture finish. The hardest part about buying Marshall products is knowing if you actually got authentic products. Knock-offs provide knock-off quality and it hurts the reputation of genuine products with bad reviews. I won't describe the differences in great details. The box is printed on all sides that spills over to other sides. It looks and feels real money, very expensively printed. Inside packaging and booklets too. The speaker is very well crafted down to the smallest details and feels solid. The grills are finished very well, individually, without any rough edges or mistakes and so is the Marshall signature emblem. Look closely.

The Emberton II sound quality is phenomenal for all music genres. It's a work of art pumping out sound, spatially separating all the tracks of instruments and voices, to hear them together in one song. This is studio quality at a reasonable price. It exceeds my $30 pair, which already beat-out all the other more expensive speakers, in the only way it could. I heard sounds playing in music I've heard so many times, I can replay it verbatim in my head. Some folks might scoff at this price point comparison. But if I'm completely satisfied at $30 or $170 - no one can entice me to spend $1500 or $15,000 I can afford to pay too. I might purchase more Emberton II's to install wireless speakers throughout the house. For now, I'm pretty satisfied.

title: WILL NOT CHARGE IPHONE
text:
Most importantly "BE PREPARED" Now I do not need a device that (although it is nice it does batteries etc) to rely on it to charge my phone. I need it to crank up (PRIOR MILITARY HERE) and do that job without the batteries. Also during hurricanes and severe FLOODING etc, THIS FEATURE IS the most important element.
One thing I will make clear is all phones have a USB cord, so NO matter your phone, rest assure it will go into the USB port. NOW I do have an issue even after CRANKING it FOREVER and it did nothing, then plugged it in and hooked up my phone did nothing. And did batteries (WASTE OF TIME FOR EMERGENCIES) and still did not work. I am technically sound and know how to do things.
In a disaster, you need this to work as it should....CRANK and go... I find this NOT representing what it says as I am testing it out for disasterous situations.. Do research, but and test. DO it like another review said, before you need it and it is not working. ALL items sold and advertised as a necessary survival piece of equipment should function as they say!!! Or that is basically saying "OH WELL... We used terms and language that made it SEEM the ultimate survival item..."
I get selling things and making a profit is important, but imblesshing is not a good thing. I am NOT in anyway steering you away from this, I am just saying (If war happens, or A hurricane, tornado ETC comes, you need what works.) And you do not and will not have access to batteries NOR to plug it in. So try it for yourself. NOW IS THE TIME.... DO NOT wait. But I do encourage you to not depend on using any other ability for this to work other than the crank and the solar.... THAT IS the survival aspect.... Just a heads up.
Also a question I wonder is if they are not saying we have to download an app??? I think I am going the military route. But try it if it is what you are thinking it is for your needs. For me it is not... I bet this review will be erased. But I am copy and pasting it and will post it again and again!!!

title: ST40 - Great (and large) BT speaker, not so great app
text:
After preparing to shred the crummy Samsung app running on my Samsung S21 for this Samsung speaker, I see the shortcomings of the app are pretty well covered in other reviews here and instead I'll rate this just as a large bluetooth speaker and keep it simple. My current use has been around the house and when working out in the basement. Planned use includes tailgating and backyard in the summer.

Good:
- Streaming music from my phone sounded great (Spotify, high bit rate setting)
- Lots of thump from the bass with or without the extra bass setting (most useful at lower volumes)
- Plenty loud on battery (80w max), louder still plugged in (160w max)

Bad or Meh:
- I have to manually connect to it in BT settings every time I use the speaker (maybe just a me thing)
- Speaker volume and phone/BT volume are separate. i.e. for max volume I have to turn up the speaker using the buttons on it, as well as turn up the volume on my phone.
- The app (it had potential but is just so half baked)

OK I can't ignore the app. I thought other reviewers just gave up too soon, I'm super good with tech and can figure it out... Sorry for doubting you other reviewers. Ignoring how hard it was to get it to connect to the speaker (which drops whenever the phone sleeps) and eventually losing connection until rebooting the phone a few times... I did try out the various sound modes (DJ effects) using MP3's from a USB drive. The effects are pretty lame, but I was hoping a combination would be funny (e.g. crank up wah-wah mode and also speed it up) but you can only use one effect at a time. See attached photo (from the app) showing the modes - you can cycle through them on the remote, from the panel on the speaker, or directly from the app. Using one cancels the other you were using. Given the lights, effects, and MP3 file from USB input I feel like the extras would have been amazing around 2002-2010. Reminds me of the early days of MP3's on a PC - get the trippy visuals going on Media Player! Great BT speaker, forget the app!

title: Lights Come On . . . But No One's Home
text:
I was topping off my new DTV antenna system and decided to measure signals from various towers. I decided I needed a signal meter. Read all the reviews for this meter and it looked like a 50/50 proposition whether it would work. Bought it on the 50/ side that worked. That's the intent. Here's the fact. The meter showed up on time. I read the instructions, attached the power supply with a 9v battery, the light came on. Attached the new antenna's coax to the meter, pointed the antenna south. Meter read "1". The antenna is known "good" as I had tested it in a dry assembly the previous day. The antenna pulled in 51 stations when pointed south where I had only been able to get 17 previously. Not the first time I might have done something wrong so I reread the instructions. Adjusted the meter so that there would be no artificial reduction in input strength. Meter still read "1". Remove the 60' antenna cable and attached a production 12' cable. Meter read "1". Completely removed the coax from the meter. With no coax attached the meter still read "1".

I got bit by the /50 downside. Shame on me. I would return it but someone would probably resell it to another customer so I'll toss it into the trash instead. Nice box though.

Feb 2 2023 Update:
Since I had decided to trash this thing I decided I had nothing to lose taking it apart. Uses a very small star screw (I have the tools). I thought I'd maybe find a bad connection or something obvious. Removed the screws, cut the warranty tamper seal and opened the case. Couldn't see anything obvious with the PC broad or physical elements so I put the shell back on.

Decided to try one other thing to see what happened. Assembled the system with the antenna and a signal booster, wala, the signal meter maxed out when the squelch nob was turned down, so the device does do something when fed and artificial load but was uncontrollable i.e. either 0 or 10, nothing in between. Removed the booster, connected meter to the antenna - meter read "1". Today is trash day. Meter will leave.

title: Does the job, it's a got a 7.4mm plug
text:
This AC adapter has a 7.4mm DC plug! NOT 4.5mm as another review states. The product description itself says, "Connector Size: 7.4 X 5.0(mm)". The description is accurate!

This AC adapter is identical in shape, size and LED placement to the original Dell that came with my Dell WD19S docking station. I replaced the Dell with this one, and it worked perfectly without any issues. My 2020 Apple Macbook Pro M1 connected to the Dell WD19S dock with this powering the entire setup worked just fine. No issues whatsoever. As for temperature, it only gets lukewarm to the touch.

There are some electrical differences, so it's definitely not a 100% clone of the original Dell adapter. The Dell adapter measures 19.1V no load voltage, this one measures 19.58V. The green indicator LED is not as bright or as diffused as the Dell. With no load, after unplugging the Dell, the green LED stays lit 40.71 seconds before it goes completely dark. This one, it stays lit 23.80 seconds. This doesn't mean one is better than the other, just that they are different designs. I don't have the equipment to do a scientific test and verify whether the adapter is stable up to the rated 180W, but it'll do fine to power and charge a modern laptop + dock + external keyboard & mouse.

Someone mentioned it's FCC certified, but he couldn't find an FCC ID. This was not the case with mine. It's KCC certified (Korean FCC) with an ID of MSIP-REM-DVP-ADP-180MBK. It's listed on the FCC site as "Manufactured by DELTA ELECTRONICS, INC. (Delta Electronics (Jiangsu) Ltd.)" The original Dell was made by Liteon. As to whether Delta makes good power supplies, a search came up with this result, "Delta is one of the biggest and easily one of the most reputable power supply OEMs in the business, one of their big markets being high-reliability server products.
