Their build quality is consistently excellent as is their performance and reliability." As to whether it's really a Delta inside, that I can't say for sure.

title: The best RGB LED Light I have owned so far
text:
As a content creator and photographer, lighting is one of the most important aspects of getting good results.

Over time I have acquired an assortment of about 20 different LED lights.
Of them all my favorite "type" is the low profile, edge lit, battery powered LED panels.

The issue I have with the others I own is output. Either they can not get bright enough for a large scene, or sometimes I actually have an issue where they can not get dim enough without over powering the scene I am trying to set up.

This is what I would consider my first "PRO" quality light, as apparent by the fact its labeled as pro, but also other other things like the Pelican style hard case, DMX control, and of course the OUTPUT.

This one light will easily put out as much light as the other 4 I have with a similar design, it has a much much higher build quality.

So it has now become my favorite light for sure, and it allows me to do some new things that I could not do before.

The only warnings I would give, this much power needs a fan, when it is on you can hear the fan if you are close to it. So if your someone who needs a silent setup, this is not it. However I do not hear the fan on any microphones, only if I am in a quiet room and no other sound is happening.

Second is this lights design is both it's biggest strength and also its biggest weakness.

The "edge lit" LED design gives a WONDERFUL light diffusion, so you can get soft light without the need for a huge modifier. In my small studio space, this is why these kind of lights are my favorite.

However that also means, this thing fills a room with light, unlike a COB light, or the more direct LED lights that are more focused this is a big wide spread.

You can at least buy barn doors and a honeycomb filter to add to it to change the light pattern and control it more, again another feature my other lights do not have, but a fair warning for someone looking to add a spot of color to a scene and then suddenly the entire scene is now lighting up with this light.

title: A great stand for the IPad Mini 6
text:
Packaging: I've used Pitaka products for a while and as usual their packaging felt premium, earth conscience and thought out to help me understand how to set up the device. You're welcomed with an introduction to their ecosystem and given instructions on a piece of translucent paper for how to install the base into the mount arm using the included hex screws and hex driver (which is cleverly attached magnetically underneath and hidden from sight so you don’t lose it). Included was the USB C to USBC cord but you'll have to buy the charging adapter separately that is compatible with USB C PD charging. Luckily I had one but I do wish it was included. Not a big deal for most since I think at this point most people have spares.

Setup/Mount: Setting up the stand was simple. Fasten the 2 hex screws (appreciate they are hex and not Phillips or flat) of the base to the mount arm. Make sure to push the base and mount arm all the way together to ensure screw holes are aligned! The build quality of the mount was impressive and had a premium weight to. Then just plug the included USB C cable into the base on one side and into your power adapter on the other. The base has a nice notch for cable routing and strain relief as well (another nice well thought out touch). Once you’re powered up there’s a nice LED at the bottom of the base that cycles through some colors at power on indicating it’s on and ready!

Charging: This stand does require the Pitaka MagEZ Case Pro for the iPad Mini 6 to function as intended. Just install your iPad to the case and the case will SNAP to the stand with a very strong magnetic connection and start charging. At the base of the stand is another Qi charger that worked for my iPhone 14 pro and AirPods Pro with no issue (and also includes a nice status lights while charging). While mounted the stand offers tilt functionality and rotation of the iPad to dial in the position as needed. I do wish the height was also adjustable as I did find the height a little tall but it’s possibly better for ergo and posture to be at this height.

Final Thoughts: Pitaka has another great product for the iPad product series. If you’re looking for a stand to prop up your iPad Mini 6 for increased productivity then look no further.

title: Nice Performance for a Budget Device...butt....
text:
For a budget tablet you get a very well made device. At first glance it looks and feels on par with the big names in the tablet space. Nice presentation when you open the box. You get a USB cable, charger, Sim tool and your paperwork . Mine came with enough charge to get things setup, Google, Microsoft and Amazon. Once all the updates and all my apps were installed, I put it through a few web things. Websites seem to open as fast as most of my other devices. I have a lot of other devices (ios,windows)to compare this performance against. The processor and the 8gb of ram makes for a good budget to midrange performance on most tasks. I see this device as primary a entertainment and lite gaming use. I got great start and stop times opening and closing websites and apps. I was a little disappointed that Netflix is only in 480p or something like that. The device is only Widevin level3. Having said that, for me with a10.4 inch screen on Netflix, HBO and Prime Video still looks fine. If Teclast has a software fix please let it rip.....please.
As for gaming, I tried some of the Play Store ones, Temple Run,Call of Duty and Pub G just for the heck. They all seem fine for me but I suck at most games. Gaming will take a toll on the battery which brings me to my biggest problem. The battery life is not its strongest suit. Even with the brightness at 60 or 70 percent its still not great. I am using a 20 watt charger because the one included is slow and cannot keep up if you are using the device (it seems to me)
I still have to say that this is still very much worth the money. When compared against some of the other lesser known budget brands around. There's a quality in this device that you would be hard pressed to find. So far ,so good. If you are new to Android tablets ,I would say this could be a good starting point. I think Teclast has a new T50 that has Widevine level 1 and a Unisoc processor. I probably would have purchased had I seen it before I got this one. Overall I am happy with this one. BTW....it works very well as a remote to my Windows PC which I have not from some of my other budget tablets.

title: Really cool modern CD player
text:
I've been streaming music for years now, but was recently give an CD to listed to. I soon realized I didn't have a CD player anywhere in the house. Luckily, I stumbled across this one and ordered it.

Let me start by saying, I love the way this thing looks! It's about 100 times cooler looking than any CD player I had back in the day. No cheap plastic and flimsy door that pops up. This thing looks really cool, fairly solid for a CD player, and I love the metal (copper?) door on top.

One of the things I really like about this is that you have the option to use headphones/aux cable or you can use Bluetooth. Bluetooth wasn't even an option in CD's heyday and so it's a little weird to see it here, but it works great. I was able to get this thing connected to my Bluetooth speak in less than a minute and it sounded great! I also used it with headphones, and again, no trouble whatsoever.

My only real objection to this CD player, and the reason I took off a star, is because the buttons are super difficult to see. Except for the top, the whole CD player is black - kind of like a soft black silicone feel. The buttons are coated in the same material and are all black. I'm able to use the CD player, but it's really difficult to see which buttons are which and I frequently hit the wrong button when trying to pause or skip a track. Maybe will a bunch more use I'll be able to memorize the button order, but I'm not sure I'm going to use it that much. I mostly wanted it to listen to one particular CD and though I may listen to some of my old CD collection, but I think I'm likely to continue streaming music. I'm going to keep this thing handy in case I want to listen to one of my CDs, but I'll probably never get to the point where I memorize which buttons are which.

This CD player is probably best for someone who will use it frequently or someone who will use it at home or work (I don't think it'd be good to try figuring out the buttons while driving).

Overall, I think this is a really nice, well-designed CD player.

title: Works, but who is this for?  A solution in search of a problem.
text:
This is an off-board (e.g., not on the iPad) charger for a 2nd Gen Apple Pencil. You may ask yourself why you need such a device when the Pencil charges when magnetically attached to the iPad itself? Well, I'm asking myself that question too.

First of all, I will say the unit works. It feels pretty well made, has a nice charge indicator light and is straightforward to use. Thanks to the Pencil's magnetic attachment, it is a little cumbersome to dig the pencil out of the charger well, but that's not a big deal. It has a rubberized bottom to help it stay put on your desk.

I just don't see a scenario in my own life when I'll end up needing this. It proved not as easy to use as the typical attachment to the iPad and I don't really want to carry another device with me.

I suppose the one use case I can imagine is if you are someone who is just a rabid user of your Apple Pencil, such that you are always burning through the battery and want a backup ready to go. But the Pencil has such a quick recharge ability that I think next to no one would be stuck in a situation like that. But maybe there are a few of you out there. If so, this can help with your Pencil battery anxiety.

For everyone else, this is probably a solution to a problem that doesn't exist for you.

Wanted to provide an update: the seller noted that this is targeting those who have cases on their iPads and cannot use the built-in charging mechanism of the iPad. I don’t think there are a ton of cases for the iPad Pros or Airs (that use the pencil 2) that don’t have the appropriate cut out on the charging magnet side, but I suppose in those cases, this could be a helpful tool — recognizing this will NOT be able to help you pair your Pencil to your iPad. But you really only need to do that once. So I’m adding a star since they have reminded me there is — for a small user base — a need. I still don’t love how it’s a bit difficult to remove the pencil once it’s in the charging well…

title: great little speaker - but no instructions
text:
This little speaker has great sound quality. I am pretty impressed with how good it sounds. I had it out on my porch today while I was working out in the yard, and it was loud enough and the music was crystal clear, you'd never guess it was coming from this tiny little device. It's small enough to throw in your purse and take to the park, pool or beach, too. Love that it's rechargeable.

It is pretty cute too, with rose gold metallic color and multicolor lights that glow at the bottom. It comes with a charging cable and a suction cup, which is just your basic clear suction cup. Not sure how that would hold up in the shower, so I'm just going to use the silicone strap attached to it to hang it while I use it in there. I ordered this mostly so I can listen to audiobooks while I get ready in the mornings, but I think it's great and will use it elsewhere as well.

The one drawback to note about this speaker is that it didn't come with any instructions, as far as I could find. The listing says there should be a user guide, but I didn't get one. I eventually figured out that there are buttons in the silicone base all the way around the bottom of the device -- one is a power button, then there's a play button and left and right buttons that control volume. I only knew how to pair it because I've paired similar devices before. (Power it on, go to your phone's bluetooth settings, find it on the list, connect - this was quick and easy and worked perfectly). Then you can play music, podcasts, audiobooks, etc. from your phone on the speaker. You can't go super far away from the speaker with your phone, though ... maybe 30-40 feet before the sound gets glitchy if there are walls between your phone and the speaker.

Instructions would be really helpful, as I am sure it has functions that I haven't figured out yet. Also no idea if it's possible to turn the lights on and off while playing music. Surely there's a way to do that, but no instructions. Can't find instructions online, either. Will come back to read comments to see if anyone has figured out any other functionality that I haven't discovered yet, or if others got a user guide that they share pictures of.

title: Useful, especially for emergencies, but the belt clip could be far better.
text:
This walkie-talkie set seemed a great choice for our family, when we're traveling and the kids want to hike in one area, and we want to see something else. Also, these seemed idea for visiting theme parks, when the kids want to go on thrill rides and we're happier with more relaxing attractions.

In other words, we hoped to use these walkie-talkies to remain in contact, letting each other know when and where to meet up again.

After testing these, I can recommend these for emergency use. I think it'd be wise to have one of these in the car's glove compartment and one at home, and maybe another in a friend or relative's home.

But that's all. They're not suited to our needs.

Here's why: The sound quality is good. The design is pretty good in terms of ease of use, after reading the instructions. The ability to recharge it is good, though we might have liked a longer battery life.

Also, it seems to have good range, though we haven't tested the full range (described as 30+ miles) yet.

But right away, we spotted something that's an issue for us.

It's the belt clip. I'm pretty sure it's plastic, but whatever the material, it's brittle and only a very tiny piece of plastic holds the clip onto the walkie-talkie.

If you press against it, the clip practically falls off. If you sit down so your thigh pushes against the walkie-talkie, the clip fails.

Worse, gravity works against the clip, not with it. A simple redesign would make 100% different, if it was an S-shaped clip that's more sturdy and works with gravity.

If you're not going to use the belt clip, this might be a five-star item. (The battery life is still an issue for me, but maybe not for others.)

For us, the brittle quality of the belt clip, and how easily it pops off, means I can give this just four stars. We'll keep one in each car's glove compartment, and one in our home as a receiver, for emergencies like snowstorms, but that's all.

title: switch & cord feel sturdy.- Nice size,easy operation- It works fine(at least on non "apple stuff")
text:
Switch feels sturdy. L.E.D. light marks which input is active. Worked fine on a "non Apple" computer , “60Hz TV”, and DVD player that I tested it with. It says you MIGHT need to add a power supply for "power hungry equipment like Apple products.
Possible Problem Is that even the cheap TV's now "feel that they need to be 4k"
I like TV's with Native 120HZ refresh rate. (Although right now I am starting to wonder about "all of that"? Aren't movies filmed a 24 or 30 frames per second, and not much is filmed at 60 frames per second, {or needs to be filmed/PLAYED BACK at above 60 frames per second?} For now I am sticking with True/native 120Hz TV’s )
This switch says it can only transfer in 4K at 60HZ. (If you can get/have a 1080p TV you will have no problem with the refresh rate.) But most "inexpensive TV's these days are Only 60HZ, (or some "upscaling stuff" trying to pass off as "120Hz") So this Issue may Not mean anything to you...
The switch is nicely built and functioned nicely for its minimal use during testing. I like the way the switch is laid out and the size of it. Easy to operate buttons. The tension relief on the cord might be a little bit Too Stiff? (MIGHT allow a bit of extra wear?)
I tested it on a “60Hz” LCD TV. It worked just find going between a computer and DVD player feeds.
I would not let the “4K 60Hz issue” stop me from getting it if the 60Hz rate is not an issue for you.
I Can Comfortably Recommend this switch for people with TV's and monitors that have a True/native 60Hz refresh rate and for TV's with a "upscaled/ Interpolated/"Effective" 120Hz rating<< a "Bogus Rating" it really is a True 60Hz TV. SO MANY TV’S ARE RATED THAT WAY TO DECIEVE YOU. So this switch will also work just fine for those TV’s.

title: great size and price, but multiple issues
text:
I wanted a larger screen Android Auto compatible radio for my older Civic, I found a kit fascia that would fit a 9" screen, just had to relocate the A/C heater controls. So it was a lot of working getting this radio installed, and unfortunately, I will be looking for a better one.
Pro's it is a large screen, and a great price, but with the multiple issues below, I will be looking for something better.
First issue was the amplifier would only work when the radio app(FM/AM) was on, I realized I had hooked it up to the main Blue wire (Antenna-out) instead of the Amplifier-out wire on the RCA plugs. I switched to this one, and then had no amplifier at all. Checked voltage on the Amplifier out wire, and there was none. I hard wired it into my ACC power wire to get it to work for now.
Next issue Android Auto, first of all it requires opening an app (Zlink), and would not ever auto load. It also will only work in wired mode, unable to get wireless to connect, phone connects fine via Bluetooth and can play music and make calls, but Zlink will not connect to go into Android Auto. Checked with my daughters iPhone, and CarPlay was the same way wired only no wireless, and still need to use Zlink, and will not autoload, even though this feature is turned on in the Zlink settings.
Next Issue night mode just dims the screen and doesn't put Android, or iPhone into night mode, even through phone shows black maps when connected at night you get bright white maps on the display, only the backlighting is dimmed.
I also know these issues are not my phone, because it works fine in my daughters car with a double din Pioneer head unit.
Next issue backup camera, the car is a Manual so I have no reverse signal in the car, I wired it up per the instructions, using the power feed on the video cable, but the Display never switches to the rear camera, checked camera and it is powering on, but no display change. and no way to manually show backup camera.
If you just want something cheap, and don't mind all the issues/work arounds to get things to work this may be for you, but I would gladly pay more to get the correct features, and options.

title: Built in Privacy!
text:
The XPCAM 4K is perfect for using on my desktop computer. The camera worked immediately after plugging the usb into my motherboard. I didn’t have to download any software or do any updates. It worked on windows Camera app and also on OBS. OBS immediately found the camera and I was able to very easily set it up in a new scene.

I am glad this camera comes with an internal privacy cover. This is especially important as my computer is located in a bedroom where I do get changed in often. It is very easy to slide the cover over the lens to create less worry. The camera also has a tiny front light to indicate when it is turned on.

The camera is a little bigger than I expected. I was worried the mount wouldn’t work well but I have had no problems with it. It just sort of sits on top of your monitor and you fold in the back side. It isn’t a tight fit at all. It also comes with a tripod stand that you can use if you don’t want to place it on top of the monitor.

In the Microsoft Camera app you can select 8.0MP 3264x2448 resolution a 4:3 ratio at 25 fps. This might not be considered true 4k and many won't like the 4:3 ratio as most screen ratios are 16:9. If you want a 16:9 ratio you need to go down to 2k resolution. You are also able to choose a 50hz or 60hz refresh rate. But for me these details don’t matter that much knowing most people will be looking at my face through a phone or 1080p resolution computer screen.

The microphone worked fairly well. My program auto selected it when my headset wasn’t turned on. I didn’t notice at first and everyone on the call seemed to hear me fine. It was slightly annoying that when I did turn off the mic on my headset the program we used would switch to the camera’s microphone. I had to make sure I hit mute in the program’s settings instead of on my headset. This isn’t the fault of the camera but the program trying to switch to a connected microphone.

Overall I am happy with this web cam. I will be using it for light streaming and conference calls.

title: Instructions are lacking, wobbles, plastic joints. Phone holder and ball head attachments are nice.
text:
You’re going to need to assemble this by trial and error, as the instructions are very lacking. The “instruction” sheet is printed front and back with the identical content in English on both sides. No reason to have printed it twice. I put “instruction” in quotes because there are two tiny instructions and lots of marketing material. The instructions really aren’t that helpful anyway.

When I first assembled this, I put it together upside down and couldn’t for the life of me see how to attach the ball head piece to the stand. It looked like I was missing a piece, but I wasn’t (at least I don’t think so.) when I took the stand out of the base and unscrewed the end to expose a hidden thread area, I found I could flip it over in the base and attach the ball head to the other end. You won’t find that in the instructions, or any indication that the cap at the end unscrews besides fiddling around with it.

There also weren’t any instructions for the phone holder. Initially I thought it wouldn’t fit my phone at all because it looked too skinny.

TIP: Pull the sides apart to stretch it wider than your phone, beset your phone and release the sides. It will now securely grip your phone.

The phone holder screws into the ball head, and that can be adjusted to any angle with the knob. The ball head piece screws into the stand after unscrewing the cap on the skinny end of the stand. Both of these two accessories are decent quality.

Once assembled and adjusted to the angle you like via the knobs, tighten everything up. You’ll find that the stand still wobbles. It did not feel very secure at all. I think it would hold my phone OK, but I wouldn’t trust anything the slightest bit heavy (or expensive) to this stand. Plastic wasn’t the right choice.

Between the lack of meaningful instructions (or even a good diagram), and the wobble, I can’t rate this very high. It might be just what you need, but I’d prefer something more stable, that could hold more weight securely, and came with better documentation than this.

title: Solid, professional quality extendable boom arm with 3/8 and 1/4" mounts
text:
This thing is amazing! I was really expecting a somewhat flimsy, consumer-grade boom arm.

Not even close. This boom arm is made with a heavy-gauge steel mounting plate and bracket, with an aluminium extendable boom. It comes with concrete anchors for mounting onto concrete or cinder blocks, as well as a set of wood screws for screwing into wall studs.

It should be noted that the picture in the listing shows the unit mounted upside down! The straight boom arm goes on the top, and the angled support arm goes on the bottom.

Once installed, you can swing the boom from side to side, as well as up and down. The angle up and down is held in place by tightening the clamp on the support arm, and once it is tight, it is SOLID.

The boom has a clamp at the end that when loosened, extends out almost five feet! At the end is another clamp that holds a reversible screw mount in either a side orientation or straight out. This reversible mount has a 3/8" screw mount on one end and a 1/4" screw mount at the other.

In practice, this mount can easily hold the weight of a DSLR or box light. I don't know what the rating of this boom arm is, but it feels solid enough that I would easily trust it with a 15 pound load, and even more if it was not extended all the way. It's that solid.

It has a foam grip to grab and move the boom around, and included several self-adhesive velcro wire ties. It also came wrapped with a couple pieces of plastic for some reason, which unfortunately left a mark on the paint when I unwrapped it.

This boom is a game-changer for my studio, getting cluttering tripods out of the way and making lights and cameras alwasy easy and quickly at hand.

Who is this for?
- Anyone needing overhead or steady support for cameras or lights

Pros:
- Very strong, sturdy
- Flexible positioning up to 5 feet away, at various heights

Cons:
- I wish there was a friction adjustment for the side-to-side adjustment

title: Well featured miniPC, if only it had more USB-C ports!
text:
This is a great alternative to an Intel NUC, even though it skimps on a few features and upgradability options. Removing four screws on the bottom reveals two m.2 slots, one populated with a 512GB SATA SSD. Note that the slots will support NVMe SSDs, the SATA one tops out at around 520 MB/s. An NVMe SSD should get multiples of that performance, and should make the machine feel more performant. Note that only 2280 size m.2 SSDs will fit. Any other size will require a thin adapter. While peeking around, you can see the wireless (802.11ac) card tucked away in a corner. I am going to look into popping in a wifi 6 capable card in there soon.

16GB of memory is a great configuration for a integrated solution like this. Usually these configurations start at 8GB.

Windows 11 Pro is included, which was a pretty pleasant surprise. The key is already pre-loaded, so no need to fish around for that.

A couple of nits. Only one USB-C port. And it isn't even USB PD. I use a thunderbolt KVM, and the USB-C port wouldn't pass through the video signal. That forced me wire the machine up with HDMI to a dedicated monitor instead. My KVM passes through USB PD as well, which makes for a single cable solution for power/video/data/keyboard/mouse. The lack of support in this machine negates that excellent feature.

The memory doesn't seem to be upgradable, but I didn't go beyond opening the bottom panel. There is what looks to be a button on top, but it doesn't do anything. It seems like that's a location for a fingerprint sensor which was not included with the particular variant I received.

Finally, there is a fan and it seems to ramp up and down a fair amount. The good news is that it is very quiet. Even running benchmarks didn't seem to make the top of the machine feel even remotely warm.

Overall, this is a good miniPC to use as a media player or a medium duty desktop use machine. Gaming with the integrated Intel graphics won't be great.

title: Great product, but the support is terrible.
text:
So I purchased this after hearing some promising stories about the company. So I was willing to give them a shot. I was in the process of doing a big upgrade to my pc for streaming purposes.

The performance and speed all seemed to show that this was indeed a fast and reliable ssd, it started showing some bizarre behavior. Anytime the pc was reset either manually or when an update requires a pc reboot I would end up in the bios. And the ssd was not detected. I eventually found out I could hold down the power button for a few seconds and I could boot back into my pc. I didn’t suspect the ssd at first and assumed it was my windows install. So I did a completely fresh install and the issue remained. I made sure everything possible was updated to the latest firmware and bios settings. No success. I ultimately decided to live with it. It didn’t crash while gaming or streaming so I assumed it was fine.

I recently did a motherboard and CPU upgrade and the issue was still there. So at this point the PC had everything replaced with the exception of the ssd. So at this point I’m certain it’s the ssd and reach out to Sabrent. After registration and pictures of the purchase recipe they also wanted me to take front and back pictures of the ssd. Their solution was for me to send the ssd to them and they would determine after inspection if they would send me a new one. Mind you this PC is my only one and I use it to stream. So after asking them how long it would take they explained it could be two weeks or more. I ask for an alternative and they tell me to buy another ssd from the Amazon seller and they’d reimburse me if they found that my drive was faulty.

So either go two weeks without my PC or shell out another $200 and potentially be told that they can’t reproduce the error and not refund me. At this point I’ll be looking to return to Samsung. Who offer a cross shipping replacement so you can copy your files from your old drive to your replacement. Which unless Sabrent makes that offer in the future will mean they’ve lost me as a customer in the future. And I hope this helps some people save themselves some time if they are unfortunate and just go with a company with a better warranty practice.

title: You can do better for $80
text:
For some context: I purchased these to replace my Jabra 75t elites. I have some airpods, airpod pro 2s and several truly wireless Anker products. These rank lowest for me for the following reasons:

The fit: the shape and material of the ear tips make keeping these in very difficult. They fall out after about 10mins in my ears, it's worse with going to the gym.

The touch sensitivity: when they do start sliding out, grabbing the base to readjust them into your ears almost always pauses them or skips your song. This can also be caused by a beanie moving against them, or hugging someone. They are too sensitive to touch. Granted: they give awesome haptic ( it gives the illusion of a physical sensation) feedback when you do press the touch controls.

Sound: these sound good, but not great. For $80 ( what I paid for them on sale) they only sound marginally better than my cheaper Anker earbuds like the spirit dot 2s which can be had for around $20 now. They are better than airpods, and a little worse than the jabras due to no sound customization.

Noise cancelling: The noise cancelling itself is pretty good. Far better than jabras, maybe 70% of what apple does, but the pressure it creates in my ears is worse than the others. After about an hour of wearing these I start getting a headache. I'm not sure why, but this never happens with my other buds and it consistently happens with these.

The case: It's okay, Hard to know which side to open without looking, but it does the job and has some nice features.

Battery: battery is good, better than jabras, worse than Anker's and apple pros.

Overall, I would avoid these. It's probably worth mentioning I have a One plus device ( 7pro) and even with the added features of connecting easily, it still doesn't make them worth it. I would prefer the jabras ( which I paid $70 for on sale) over these any day. If they stayed in my ears better and the touch controls were less sensitive, I would keep them. But I'd rather have the $80 they cost me back in my pocket, so here goes the return process

title: Great but died after a couple years..
text:
[[VIDEOID:d2f8b1a75decf1f2f1ee0e892fbab8b0]] I bought these in January 2021, after buying them on a whim. Luckily they sounded amazing! Wanted to hear every song I liked thru them, which didn’t disappoint. Everything was great and dandy for awhile, I used to listen to them everyday on my bus ride to and from work, but in August of 2022, I began driving to work again. Put these in my center console just in case I’d need them for driving or whatever. Last night I pulled them out 3/19/2023, but they were dead, so I plugged them into charge all night. This morning I checked and it seemed like they charged, took them out of the case, they paired with my phone immediately, I didn’t do anything they just started playing thru the earbuds themselves, thought all was great but then 5 mins later, I heard the dreaded, “battery is low,” message thru the earbuds. That crushed my hopes, I knew they had sufficient time to charge, 10 hours should be good right? Well I plugged them in again but this time noticed the charging lights would flicker instead of showing a steady charge, which would light up the 5 lights in a sequence, 1,2,3,4,5. Instead 1 would flicker, 2-3 would light up for a millisecond and turn off, 4-5 didn’t light up at all. I went ahead and left it there for a couple hours hoping for the best but when I came back, pulled them out tried listening to some Tidal, but before the first song could play, “battery is low” message came on. I suppose I could still listen to music but that message would play every couple mins till the battery dies. So I had them for a couple years now, not sure what the expected life is for these. I would say I had a good 1.5 years listening to them everyday 1 hour to work, 1 hour back. They played perfectly throughout that time. I guess I got my money’s worth, but I just wished they still worked, I really enjoyed them. It feels like I just broke up with a girlfriend, kind of.. well onto the next!
BTW, the video shows how they charge now…

title: User friendly controls, but has a major flaw or two!
text:
Picture quality is good and I really like how easy and user friendly this dash camera is to operate. The manual is pretty well written so no complains about that.
BUT!!!!
The BIG CON is the proprietary mount which is just a sticker that sticks to the windshield and then the only movement the camera can do is up and down (not left and right). I do NOT want to have random stickers on my windshield!!!
So I had to go to lengths to build an adapter plate to stick to a regular sucktion cup that has a ball joint that can pivot and therefore allows the camera to swing in any direction. As most ball joints, this particular suction cup has a standard threaded stud. All dash cameras should have a STANDARD attachment, not a proprietary one.
However, after I had my mount built with my suction cup, the suction cup wouldn’t stick to the windshield just above my mirror because the windshield has some dots there that are the rain sensors.
I abandoned the suction cup idea and uninstalled my mirror, fashioned a metal bracket with holes and installed the bracket to my mirror. Then I attached a second, simpler mount with a screw to the bracket. Again, the camera can still swing up and down and now also left/right.

Because I had to do all the work to figure out how to install the front camera without gluing a permanent sticker directly to the windshield, I lost considerable time and a few nerves too, and therefore this dash cam doesn’t deserve more than 3 stars.

I haven’t installed the back camera yet but it too has a proprietary mount that I will have to modify.

The second con is that not all custom settings stay preserved after I turn off the car. As an example, i can have this cam connected via Wi-Fi to an app. I don’t care about this app, so I also don’t care about having the Wi-Fi turned on in the camera. Every time I turn on the car and the cam automatically starts, it goes to the default “on” with the Wi-Fi, even though I don’t even have the app on my phone.

In summary, a good camera if you don’t mind a sticker on your windshield and you never can move the location of the camera….

title: great size and price, but multiple issues
text:
I wanted a larger screen Android Auto compatible radio for my older Civic, I found a kit fascia that would fit a 9" screen, just had to relocate the A/C heater controls. So it was a lot of working getting this radio installed, and unfortunately, I will be looking for a better one.
Pro's it is a large screen, and a great price, but with the multiple issues below, I will be looking for something better.
First issue was the amplifier would only work when the radio app(FM/AM) was on, I realized I had hooked it up to the main Blue wire (Antenna-out) instead of the Amplifier-out wire on the RCA plugs. I switched to this one, and then had no amplifier at all. Checked voltage on the Amplifier out wire, and there was none. I hard wired it into my ACC power wire to get it to work for now.
Next issue Android Auto, first of all it requires opening an app (Zlink), and would not ever auto load. It also will only work in wired mode, unable to get wireless to connect, phone connects fine via Bluetooth and can play music and make calls, but Zlink will not connect to go into Android Auto. Checked with my daughters iPhone, and CarPlay was the same way wired only no wireless, and still need to use Zlink, and will not autoload, even though this feature is turned on in the Zlink settings.
Next Issue night mode just dims the screen and doesn't put Android, or iPhone into night mode, even through phone shows black maps when connected at night you get bright white maps on the display, only the backlighting is dimmed.
I also know these issues are not my phone, because it works fine in my daughters car with a double din Pioneer head unit.
Next issue backup camera, the car is a Manual so I have no reverse signal in the car, I wired it up per the instructions, using the power feed on the video cable, but the Display never switches to the rear camera, checked camera and it is powering on, but no display change. and no way to manually show backup camera.
If you just want something cheap, and don't mind all the issues/work arounds to get things to work this may be for you, but I would gladly pay more to get the correct features, and options.

title: Excelente rendimiento pero con detalles
text: Excelente placa para overclock y soporte ram. Lamentable que no tenga flashbios para los que desean usar directamente gen 13. Lo positivo que la actualización a 13gen es impecable. Yo pasé de un 12700k a 13600kf sin problemas y de 5600mhz de ram DDR5 a 6400 mhz cl36 (2x16), lo malo que esa compatibilidad no la tienen documentada, pero me arriesgué y fue lo mejor, y el 13600kf lo tengo en 5.6/4.4 all cores estable! y uncore 49. (con buen AIO), impresionante!! (auque quizás mi proce es de los buenos en lotería de silicio). A propósito, otras de las cosas positivas que se mencionan poco, que tiene compatibilidad de cooler para diseños anteriores, como 1151, lo cuál me salvo cuando me la compré (no tuve que cambiar cooler ni comprar un adaptador). Hermoso diseño, su cantidad de puertos M2, y sin conflictos con los Sata, y 3 puertos argb. Pero otra cosa realmente negativa y es un desbalance técnico evidente, que a pesar de tener demasiados puertos para FAN (lo cúal es bueno), en la bios no puedes configurar el objetivo a ventilar de acuerdo a la temperatura monitorizada, de hecho, en ninguna parte te indican cuál es para los FAN de gabinete ¿es por temperatura cpu o motherboard?. Otro punto negativo que comparte con otras placas asus con algunas GPU rtx de gama alta (3090 en mi caso), es que tener ASPM activado genera errores en windows, por lo que hay que desactivarlo, lo cuál tampoco está documentado o se considera en la configuración optima por defecto.

title: Okay budget well featured tripod. The one I got was covered in blobs of grease.
text:
Aoesin 71" (180cm) Phone Tripod & Camera Stand

Decent enough for a budget tripod, there is a lot of plastic components that seem very hard but not dense, I am not sure if they would break easier than other materials if this fell over.

I am awarding stars based on the current price point, not compared to other better made and more expensive tripod.

For a budget tripod this is well equipped with features and components. However there are things that came with this that I do not know what they are for, how to attach or use them and they are not mentioned in the instructions. I am also deducting another star because I got some sort of grease all over my clothes and hands. All the moving plastic components at the head of the tripod were oozing big blobs of grease. Fortunately it washed off my hands okay so I don't think it was a silicone based grease.

I have attached a photo showing the complete instructions with the pieces that are not mentioned in those instructions. There is some sort of hardware attachment that seems to be missing parts to be able to do anything with.

There are also no instructions for the shutter button but it is easy to figure out. Turn on with the side button, scan and connect to 'AB Shutter' on your device. I connected to my Samsung galaxy phone and the Shutter button worked for taking a photo and starting and stopping a video recording. Both the Shutter buttons worked on my Samsung Galaxy phone even though one is labeled IOS and the other is labeled Android, it made no difference.

Thank you for reading my review and looking at my photos of this product. I hope you found it helpful!

REVIEW PHILOSOPHY: I only review a product if it is something I am capable of critically evaluating through comparison, testing and use. This means I have experience of using similar items; or that I have equipment or tools that I can test it with; or that I have an upcoming need so I can actually use. I am as selective about getting an item to review as I would be about purchasing that same item, so yes, I expect it to be a good product. My reviews are NOT based on packaging or if it was delivered timely.

title: Terrific Headphone-Microphone for PCs, Tablets and SOME Cell Phones
text:
I use an ANDROID cellphone and GOOGLE apps on my WINDOWS 11 PC. The newer version of WINDOWS lets you seemlessly link your phone to the PC, and I prefer to use a corded microphone/earphone combination for a sure connection on my calls.

I liked this RAYHONTECH version due to the onboard DAC convertor. DAC stands for DIGITAL TO ANALOG CONVERTOR, which works through a USB C port to allow you to use a headphone-microphone combo as well as headphone audio only. I currently use a SAMSUNG Galaxy A13 5G phone which is getting a bit archaic, but still does most of what I need. I have been using a combo headphone with a 3.5" jack and a GOOGLE button on the cord. The new RAYHONTEC has the GOOGLE button PLUS a volume control, which for me was a big plus.

On the PC it was terrific. I had immediately noticed the large and strong magnets in the headphone earpieces, and knew they would provide excellent audio range, which they did. They closely rival the quality of the wireless earbuds that I use, the microphone was flawless, and the GOOGLE switch worked great for me.

The only problem with these was with my GALAXY A13, as the RAYHONTECH signal wasn't recognized by the A13. The AMAZON description listed the newer GALAXY phones in the A2x series only, so I while I had hoped it might work, it did not. This isn't a dealbreaker for me, as I typically link my phone to my ASUS Laptop and then can use my GALAXY phone for either calls and texts thrugh the laptop. Big plus in my mind, as I can touch type all of my texts instead of using thumbs.

If you have a newer phone that has no 3.5'' jack, this will probably work fine on your phone, but check the model listings in the AMAZON description first, or check with RAYHONTECH. I'm going to be upgrading to newer GALAXY soon, and this excellent headphone will help me make that decision quicker.

OVERALL: This is a terrific product at a good price.

title: A Symphony of Comfort and Quality
text:
As an owner of the Ankbit E700s, I was eager to try out what Ankbit had to offer at the lower price point of the E500s. After trying them out, I'm truly impressed, and I highly recommend them.

The active noise cancelling technology of the Ankbit E500 is definitely on par with the E700s. From noisy traffic to the conversations at the coffee shop, these headphones effectively eliminate low and mid-frequency distractions, allowing me to fully immerse myself in whatever I happen to be listening to.

The sound quality is exceptional. The dual 40mm drivers deliver superior Hi-Fi audio (24-bit/96 kHz) with a well-balanced deep bass, making each listening session an absolute pleasure.

More than just providing a hi-fi listening experience, the E500 headphones do an excellent job with clear hands-free calling. The advanced ENC technology ensures crisp, clear phone conversations without any ambient noise interference. The mute button is a nice touch, too – simply press the ANC button three times, and voilà!

Battery life is among some of the best. With up to 75 hours of playtime in standard mode and 45 hours in wireless ANC mode (at 60% volume), I never have to worry about running out of power. Plus, a quick 10-minute charge provides an impressive 4 hours of playback, perfect for those last-minute trips.

Comfort is high on the list as well. The ultra-soft protein leather earcups with memory foam padding, adjustable headband, and 90° rotating earcups make it easy to find the perfect fit. I can wear these headphones for hours without any discomfort.

The wireless connection to both my phone and my computer was quick and painless. Just turn on the headphones, look for the E500 in your devices list, and pair. Bluetooth 5.2 technology ensures a stable and efficient connection with faster transmission and a wider signal range.

The Ankbit E500 noise cancelling headphones are a fantastic investment for anyone seeking superior sound quality, comfort, and reliability. If LDAC is important to you, then consider the E700s (which recently got a firmware update). But at this price point, I think you'll be more than happy with the Ankbit E500 ANC headphones.

title: Beast
text:
I've always been a fan of MSI components. They've never let me down. I decided to upgrade to an i9-13900K with DDR5 because I do tons of media transcoding, and this looked like a good choice to put it all together with. I've been up and running stable for two weeks now with no issues except for one thing - the default power settings for the 13900K. The limits for both short and long term bursts were at 4096 watts. What?? If your AIO is hooked up to your air conditioner, then maybe. Throttle temp was still the standard 100C. While doing some transcoding, pretty much all of the 8 P-cores throttled out. I saw that this is pretty much standard across the board for all mobos with the 13900. So I set the wattage down to 200 and 140. That kept the temps well below 100, but I noticed that now all 24 cores are working together for my transcodes. When the wattage was set wide open, only the 8 P-cores seemed to be doing any work (and were the only cores throttling out), which is probably how it was intended. But I don't think there is any cooler that will be able to keep that below the TJ Max. So I'll just use all 24 cores for my work and keep things cool. Works just fine for now.

The board comes with XMP1 thru 3 and I'm running Corsair DDR5 at 6000 MTS with zero issues right out of the gate. Runs a little hotter than I'm used to with DDR4, but no issues with that. 5 M2 slots for your NVME drives that all come with shields. One of the M2 slots will take lanes from your PCIe 5.0 x16 slot, so be wary of that. Superspeed USB ports on the I/O as well as a 2.5G ethernet port. I don't do RGB, but there seems to be plenty of RGB customization options if that's your thing. And of course the Z790 chipset for all your tweaks.

Overall a very powerful board with a lot of capabilities and expansion options. Put the power to use with an RTX3090 or 4090 and you'll have a future-proof rig for quite some time.

title: How it really sounds!!!!
text:
First of all, let me say this: Overall, this is NOT a bad unit. It's just built for people that don't truly hear and appreciate all the bass notes in out hearing range and some outside of that, as most people don't.
However, I do wish 1 single person would have given an accurate description of the sound output before I waisted my time on this unit, knowing my ideal requirements. .
With that being said, here is my accurate description of the quality of the Bass it puts out:
Point Blank, there is NO LOW BASS! None at all. Everything under 40Hz is nonexistent. I assuming its a combination of the impossibly small amount of air space in the enclosure and the subsonic filter being more overactive than they say. So R&B, Hip Hop, Techno, Anything Electronica, & Doom Metal all just have frequencies/bass that are just missing from the music. It's like they cut it out of the song. That does not work for me. I need to hear it as close to original as possible.
Now, everything from 45Hz-200Hz sounds really good, and it does lean to the higher bass notes being waaaaaaaay louder, so that kinda also bothers me, bc its not accurate to the song.
Also, the case does vibrate a bit on those 100Hz-150Hz notes, but its not overbearing as long as its covered or under a seat.
Overall, for what it is, its not bad, but it could easily be better, as I'm sure the likes of Kicker, Alpine, Cerwin Vega, Pioneer, and other higher end units may be.
I guess I was hoping for too much.
Unfortunately, my audiophile tastes do not fit the space in my Subaru Baja or I would have a 12" or 15" sub in a big box that does all the frequencies.
with that being said, I did decide to purchase an Earthquake SAS-10X shallow mount sub and I'm going to attempt to build my own underseat enclosure out of aluminum or steel that is around .5cuft. I guess we'll see if it works to my taste.
Overall, if you're an audiophile or just a lover of bass, and you're stuck with small space requirements, this is not the package for you.

title: High quality dash cam video at a decent price
text: [[VIDEOID:264704a7c4ded53803454782ed5c5031]] This is my second COOAU dash cam I have purchased. The other one (M53) that I purchased for our other car met my needs and has a screen on it, but I found that screen to be distracting to the other passengers in the vehicle and didn't really serve any functional purpose other than initial setup. This model (M26) does not have a screen, but does have the ability to see the camera angle on your phone using an app. It has much better video resolution at 1080P, plus a much wider angle. As you can see in the attached video, it not only covers both lanes of traffic, but off to the side to include two more lanes on each side, so six lanes total if you were on an interstate. I did the video in poor weather conditions (raining) so that you could see what it looks like in less than ideal conditions. It still took an excellent hi res video. The unit is fairly easy to install in my car, although it did take me some time to get the cord hidden in the headliner and run it back to the center console to plug in. Also included with the product is a cigarette lighter USB plug if needed. Note that you have to purchase a mini SD card like the one I have in the first pic (it was under $10 for 64G). The unit will voice prompt you to format the SD card upon initial setup. You need to download the required phone app to do so as well as to see the camera angle setup. There are two different COOAU apps in the Play Store, you want the one marked as "Ficam" for this product. It was easy to install and get setup. Use the wifi password "12345678" to initially connect the device. I like how the product has an emergency lock on the video storage in the case of a collision, protecting it and keeping it from being overwritten in the recording loop. The one drawback to this device is that it does not have a backward facing camera. You can rotate it to face backward temporarily, but it doesn't have two cameras (front and back). COOAU makes a dual camera dash cam, but it is more expensive. This one fit my needs and budget. Hopefully I never have to use the video in case of an accident, but it's there to cover me if I need it.

title: AMAZINGLY COMFORTABLE!! HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!*SEE UPDATE
text:
Like many others, I had issues with the OEM silicone tips that Apple provides with the AirPod Pro 2nd generation. I tried every size and although they weren’t uncomfortable, they just would not stay in my ear if I was exercising running, etc.. I decided to give these a try, and upon receiving them I was immediately impressed with the box they came in, the instructions and tips they provide and most of all the comfort of the memory foam. I used the size medium in the OEM silicone tips from Apple so that’s what size I tried first with these foam ones. They fit perfectly. I followed the instructions as it says to pinch and compress, the memory foam, insert firmly with them pointing forward, and then rotate down hold for five seconds. Within 30 seconds, I felt the foam expand in my ear. Once the foam expanded it created a tight seal that is not only more comfortable but they stayed in my ear. I’ve put them and literally tried shaking my head violently just to see if they would fall out. THEY DIDN’T FALL OUT ONCE..
1) I would definitely advise buying the black colored ones because the white and gray get dirty fast and they are hard to clean. The reason they get dirty so fast is because they are not silicon, they are memory foam, so any dirt or earwax or stick and discolor. 2) Follow the instructions that come with the box. It specifically says to use a cloth or a clean tissue when removing them from the box or from your AirPods. If you don’t and just use your fingers, the oils on your on your finger tips will make it difficult to remove them and you can potentially tear the foam.
Update: 3 months after purchasing them, I accidentally tore the foam on the size I use toe most. I used a dry cloth like I always do and I try to be as delicate as possible however, I still somehow ripped the foam. I just sent out an email to the original manufacturer to see if they will still honor the one-year warranty, even though I purchased these from Amazon. I am waiting to hear back from them and I will update again. Even if they don’t honor the one-year warranty, I would still purchase these again. The only thing I would do differently is I would buy them from the site directly to ensure I don’t void the one-year warranty.

title: Good soundbar!
text:
I ordered this to use with my iPad and Laptop when in bed.
I was particularly enthused when I saw that there was an aux input!

When I received the unit I was immediately impressed by the weight, as it was a touch heavier than I expected. A good feel, like something well made. Tons of wires included, and I noticed the power adapter (wall charger). While the product description clearly states this, I in my mind kept thinking batteries, but I prefer power so I am glad I can plug this in. This does not take batteries at all.

Next I hurriedly found the aux cable, and discovered while one end is the 1/8inch male, the other is the L and R RCA type jacks. The input on the soundbar takes the 1/8 inch end, meaning that the dual RCA plugs would need to plug into the source. So much for using it with the iPad/Laptop as those have the 1/8 inch as the output…My momentary fear was allayed when I remembered this is also BT. I was pleasantly surprised by how easy it was to pair BT, as previous devices never paired right with my iPad. This paired in seconds and I was up and running.
The sound quality is nice! Great sound, no distortion, and a pretty full range. Keeping in mind that this is replacing on board iPad and Laptop speakers, the difference is night and day. Keeping things in perspective: it will not replace a proper receiver + speakers + subwoofer setup. It will not even come close to that. It’s easy to carry, use, set up, and sounds much better than onboard speakers. In fact, it exceeds what I use it for. It can easily be an upgrade to TV speakers. And when I think of all the trouble it is to set up proper audio systems in years past, I can really appreciate the simplicity presented here. Frankly, for most applications this is a good way to go.
If you are someone that for gaming or movies needs a bit more bass response, consider a separate reciever + sub setup, but for common use this is a great option. I love the size, that it is not 30+ inches long. This gives it a ton of flexibility. The packaging is also simple and nice, with full instructions on the box itself. Excellent quality product!

title: I've used it twice. The first time I'd give it 3 stars. The second time 5 stars.
text:
I've wanted a GPS golf watch for a long time. I settled on this one for three reasons. First, two guys I regularly play with have one and both love theirs. Secondly, my golf game doesn’t require a more expensive model that provides an endless list of detailed information. Third, the watch finally came back on sale for $50 off. It seems to periodically. I’ve used it twice. Here's my reaction so far:

Liked:
* Rather than hoping that someone in my foursome will have a GPS, now I can just glance down at my wrist. So convenient.

* I like the multiple-face display configurations. I have mine set so the numbers showing the distance to the middle of the green are extra large, which makes the number I care about easy to see, even in bright sunlight.

* Super comfortable. Normally, I hate wearing watches but this one is ultra-lightweight and didn’t bother me a bit.

* I’m no techie but downloading the app and pairing the watch to my I phone 13 was a breeze.

* This watch provides far more information than my golf game requires but it’s nice to know it’s there if I start getting better.

* No complaints about battery life. I still had plenty of power left after two rounds.

Didn’t like:

* On several holes during my first round, my watch had trouble finding the next hole. Even my cart-mate, who has the same watch, couldn't figure out why. His watch found every hole without any problem. That was frustrating. But during my second round (at a different course), it performed flawlessly. In fact, during that round, the golf cart had a GPS screen. I compared the distance on my watch with the cart GPS and found they were very close every time.

* It took longer than I expected for the watch to locate and load the course, but I don’t consider that a major issue.

* There is definitely a learning curve. I read the instructions at home but it's challenging to practice using it unless you're actually at a course with the course downloaded.

title: Great quality dock with a lot of connections, extra driver software required
text:
The UGREEN 9-in-1 docking station is a great docking station for USB C powered laptops, and want dual monitors. The docking station connections are as follows:

~2 USB 3.0 ports
~1 USB-C port
~Dual display, both supporting HDMI or DP (up to 4K 60 hertz)
~Ethernet jack
~100W PD charging port (Charging adapter and cable not included)
~Host port to computer

The dock connects to your laptop via the USB C jack and supports up to 100W charging power to your laptop. The charging cable and adapter are not included. My setup includes a MacBook Pro M1 Max. So if your laptop charges via USB C, you will not need to use your laptops native charging cable if you buy the separate adapter. This is great to keep your native charging cable in a backpack for traveling or maybe in a second location in the home. Otherwise you will still require the native charging cable.

I am unable to speak on the 4K displays as I currently use 2 UltraWide monitors at 3440x1440. The maximum refresh rate of a display this size is 100 hertz via the Display Port.

The UGREEN docking station is not Plug-n-Play. You need to download and install the DisplayLInk drivers in order for this dock to work. This is clearly labeled in the instructions and they provide the exact location to download it. As soon as I installed the driver on my laptop and plugged in the USB C plug, everything worked perfectly.

The one thing I feel is missing on this docking station is headphone/microphone jacks for people who use cabled headphones or desk speakers.

**It is normal for a dock like this to be warm to the touch after it’s in use for a bit. There are vents to help keep it cooler and prevent overheating**

Conclusion:
The UGREEN 9-in-1 is a great docking station for any laptop with USB C but especially for laptops that can charge with USB C. It has all of the necessary ports to setup all of your devices minus the headphone/microphone jacks. The power adapter is not included which is a shame but it is available separately.

title: The Perfect Blend of Portability and Versatility
text:
After testing out the EVUMO camera tripod, I am happy to report that it is a fantastic product for photographers and videographers looking for a convenient and versatile support system. Its compact and lightweight design, 2-in-1 functionality, and impressive adjustability make it a must-have for any content creator on the go.

Portability: 5/5
With its relatively light weight at just 3.5 pounds and its ingenious foldable design, the EVUMO camera tripod is a breeze to carry around. Carrying case is included. Whether you're trekking through the wilderness or navigating a bustling city, this tripod won't weigh you down or take up too much space in your gear bag.

Versatility: 5/5
One of the standout features of the EVUMO tripod is its 2-in-1 functionality. With a simple adjustment, it can be transformed into a monopod or walking stick, offering greater flexibility for various shooting situations. This makes it an ideal choice for photographers and videographers who need a multipurpose support system.

Adjustability: 5/5
The 4-section leg tubes make adjusting the working height of the tripod a breeze. With a range of 18.9" to 80", you can achieve the perfect height for your shots in seconds. The monopod's height can also be adjusted from 23.2" to 70", providing even more flexibility.

Convenience: 4.5/5
The 36mm aluminum ball head allows for 360° rotation, granting you complete freedom to capture unique angles and stunning panoramas. With a maximum load weight of 17.6lbs, the tripod can accommodate most cameras and lenses. However, heavier setups may require extra caution to ensure stability.

Extras: 4/5
The additional 1/4" threaded hole for an external magic arm or phone clip is a nice touch, allowing you to further expand your shooting options. A 2-year warranty is also included, providing peace of mind when making your purchase.

To sum everything up, the EVUMO camera tripod is a fantastic investment for any content creator seeking a portable and versatile support system. It offers an impressive blend of features at a competitive price point. I highly recommend this tripod for both amateur and professional photographers and videographers alike.

title: Great Dash Cam; Great Customer Support!
text:
This Dash Cam is pretty nice... the quality and clarity is super. Overall, it performs great "right out of the box", so to speak. So, yes... this is an excellent Dash Cam for my 2020 Honda CR-V.
The hard part of course, is the installation. As with any dash camera, you need to develop a strategy and have a plan as to how you're going to go about setting it up. There are a lot of YouTube videos out there on Dash Cams, so it's a good idea to view some of them. If you decide to hardwire it, you will need to get familiar with your car's fuse box diagram; which again, you can find online. However, that said, that was still the most challenging thing for me; finding/deciding on the right fuses to "fuse tap" - ACC/BATT.
For 2020 Honda CRV Touring owners: I used fuse slot 19 (Moonroof) for the ACC, and fuse slot 16 (Door Lock) for the BATT. Try to use 20 amp fuses to fuse tap with. For hardwiring you will need a fuse tap kit - ask REDTIGER customer support for one if it didn't come with the camera (it should though). Again, lots of YouTube videos out there to show you how. Videos by AutoFun, "RedTiger Hardware Kit How to Use..." is a good one; explaining how to perform a fuse tap set up.
Finally, installing the cable wiring was a little less challenging as it was actually fun and rewarding.
I think the most important aspect of this purchase is the company - REDTIGER. Besides standing behind their product, they really do appreciate you as a customer and are more than happy to help you - very gracious people there. I received many follow up emails, making sure I was successful installing it. For example, I had an issue with the rear camera's rotation; it didn't really work for my car. So I contacted them, and they mailed me a different model (a barrel type) which better accommodated my car's hatch window. That... by the way, was free of charge!
I don't recall a company who's customer support was as good as this!
So, great product; even better customer service.

title: A new PC format that has advantages
text:
[[VIDEOID:d978c1a436aaece3b40f642ae69a8612]] I've been building PC's since 1991 and have built hundreds since then. Most have been full tower type with all the bells and whistles available at the time I built them. This KAMRUI Mini Computer, is my first opportunity to get my hands on a new type, a mini PC.

It's about the size of a book. This KAMRUI Mini Computer, contains a quad core Intel Celeron processor, 12 gb of DDR 4 ram and a 256 gb ssd drive. It also comes with Windows 11 pro pre installed. These mini computers do not come with a screen, keyboard or mouse. I already had a portable 15.6 inch screen plus a wireless keyboard and mouse and was able to have the computer booted up and ready to test in just a few minutes.

Like any new PC, you need to go through the setup process. That takes about 10 minutes to get your account information, sign in and password ready to go. Then you need to attach the computer to the internet. It does have a full gigabit ethernet port, but it also has some of the latest wireless connections.

It set it up with my wireless network and it was up and running. I also started downloading all of the windows updates to the operating system. That whole process took about an hour, with all of the downloads, installs and reboots required.

The mini pc format is not what you really want for gaming. It will work with many pc games, but the included Intel UHD graphics, while perfectly good for most uses, falls a bit short for most gaming.

Where the format becomes very attractive is in the use this computer will be put to. I'm going to use it as my audio and video server. There are multiple server software programs that are available, and I'll have to try a few of them and see which I prefer. This mini PC is fully capable of running most of them, and it's small form factor and very quiet operation makes it ideal for that purpose.

This mini PC comes with all of the ports you will need to hook peripherals to it. It has multiple HDMI ports, plus USB ports. It also has full bluetooth capability.

title: DOA and poor design
text:
It was dead on arrival and I wonder if there could be more than one cause. Amazon now ships some stuff without any packaging (to save paper, more environmentally friendly?!), they just slap a label on it and ship it. So did a lack of cushioning in transit contribute to its demise? Or was it faulty to begin with? I've used plenty of external enclosures over the years, mostly Rosewill (who has stopped making them esp with fans probably because HDD going the way of CDs...?!), so this was straightforward to me to setup. I noticed the poor design with the screws that people have complained about in general in reviews.

I took a working drive from another enclosure and put it into the Vantec. This is why the design is poor. Once you put the drive in, you have to hold the drive with one hand and then turn the enclosure over and put in the screws on the bottom with the other. That's why they enclose a screwdriver which is magnetized or the screws are magnetized because you can't use the other hand to hold the screws. The workaround to this is to set the drive down on top of the outside of the enclosure so the drive rests on it to keep it in place so you can use two hands to put in the screws. The screws go in the bottom instead of on the sides like Rosewill enclosures and if it falls out it gets lost in the enclosure and you have to shake it out. This is ridiculous! Anyway I got the screws in and connected the enclosure to power and USB. Flipped the power switch. Initially the blue light came on but after a number of tries to get the thing to work it stopped lighting up. The drive failed to spin up or be recognized. I tried turning on the fan with the dial switch and nothing happened. I tried a number of things to troubleshoot to get the enclosure to work but it did not. Drive was never recognized, fan never turned on, blue light stopped working. Compared to the old Rosewill's this thing is a piece of junk! But if you get a working one and it works for you then congratulations!

I returned it and don't want another one. In fact I'm not ordering a different one from Amazon nor any type of electronic device which could potentially ship without packaging (and get damaged in transit) again. (I either reuse or recycle all packaging I get from online orders.)

title: Sony vs. Airpods
text:
I'm not an audiophile, but I was looking for great sound, noise cancellation, and fit. I got the Airpods first, but was a little disappointed with the sound quality so I got the Sony's since I love the sound on my WH-1000XM4 headphones.

Sound-I bought the Sony's (WF-1000XM4) second for one main reason, SOUND! I have the Sony WH-1000XM4 headphones which are amazing. The Sony earbuds sound very close to the headphones. The Airpods didn't quite have the same sound although they sound great. I was actually surprised that the Airpods sounded very close to a pair of Mpow M30 earbuds that I got in 2020 for $30. The Sony's seem a bit louder with richer sound. Also, the Sony buds have the ability to change the sound profile using the equalizer app. The Airpods rank second to Sony in my opinion.

Noise cancellation- Both Sony and Airpods do an amazing job, but I think the Airpods beat out the Sony but a hair. The noise cancellation does not disappoint on either one.

Fit- The Airpods are way more comfortable for my small ears. The Sony feel big and like they are going to pop out. I find both comfortable, but the Airpods feel more natural in my ears. The Sony's take a little getting use to.

Controls- I prefer the Sony controls. The Airpod controls still feel a little awkward to me. Matter of preference.

Voice/Calls- LOVE the Airpods!!! I haven't tried the Sony's on calls yet simply because I automatically go for my Airpods. They connect quicker. The calls are clean like the person is in the room with you.

Battery Life- Airpods lasted a bit longer.

Overall, if you mainly make calls or workout, I would go with the Airpods. If you are looking more for music listening, then the Sony's are way better. Noise cancellation...either one, but because of the better fit of the Airpods on small ears, I would default to the Airpods...although the Sony headphones beat out both. If you can afford both, then I'd say go for it!

title: Test Immediately to Avoid Flickering + Dual Controller Problems
text:
I've had this monitor for over six months now. I wish I tested everything immediately because Amazon only allows 30 days to return it.

I bought this monitor to run two laptops with one monitor, one mouse, one keyboard, and connect my accessories to the monitor (i.e. webcam). It doesn't offer that. The Ergo stand however is fantastic and well worth the cost, just wish it was compatible with monitors of other brands so this isn't a complete dud. Monitor has compatibility issues, flickering/power disbursement issues, and KVM/Dual Controller issues.

LG won't refund the monitor until you send it in 3 times. Nightmare going back and forth on this.

Flickering:
I had this issue and it was infuriating to the point that I got a new laptop. Turns out you can't maximize the ports on the monitor because the monitor doesn't diffuse power to connected devices in a smart way (i.e. your other connected devices are getting more energy than your laptop). Basically the reps said you need to connect your accessories to the laptop instead of the monitor, which defeats the purpose imo.

Among my two laptops, the X1 suffered endless flickering issues but the Dell XPS didn't. The Dell did experience flickering when viewing certain applications though. I ended up resolving the Dell's issue by switching to a different browser. The X1 is still hopeless. Both run i7 and are in excellent condition, so it's a loss on why the X1 isn't compatible.

Dual Controller:
I've sent in the monitor for repair and it still has the same issue. First they said to connect the laptop with USB-C and HDMI, but now it's DP and HDMI. Still doesn't work, and by using DP, I can't charge the main laptop with Thunderbolt PD. This makes this monitor a nightmare and obsolete. Recommend getting a different monitor capable of delivering as promised.

The repair process was fairly simple but required more than 1 hour on the phone with a rep, waiting for a return box to arrive, then shipping the monitor within a month. But, the box I received didn't meet their shipping specifications and I had to bring the monitor into FedEx to have them pack and ship it. Then, chat or call in again to ask for a refund.

title: A Great Investment
text:
I wanted to test the functionality of the watch for a few days before putting in my review. I have to say I am very impressed with the watch. It has all the functions I needed. The sleep tracker is on point, heart rate and steps records are correct. I was pleasantly surprised that it has the function to remote snap photos when connected to my andriod phone and shows accurate weather (added bonuses, if you ask me). The watch is little weight compared to my former fitness watch (which had NO weight whatsoever and has limited functions) - this watch makes for a good investment. I still have more testing to do and want to make some comparisons with my daughter's apple watch. So I'll be back to update this review. Personally, I LOVE the watch. ❤ I'm very happy with it. 🥰

2/26 -update: So I made comparisons in the past several weeks with the apple watch. Here is what i found.....the functionality is similar or same to the apple watch with accurate tracking workouts and health biometrics, which is superb! It tracks the steps, calories burned, distance walked and tracks the beats per minute for your heart rate. It shows weather, date, time and day of the week. Most important the battery (on a 2 hour charge or less), lasted close to 14 days!!! Something I never got with the fitbit watch. The watch plays music (tap the music icon on the watch, press play on the phone and the music plays thru the watch) and capture photos when connected to Bluetooth (when you open the camera icon it becomes a shutter button-tap on it and the camera on your cell snaps the photo).

The watch has a dial pad to make calls as well as pull up your list of contacts, it receives calls. Yes, you can answer the call and talk through the watch! As for texting, the watch certainly receives the messages but DOES NOT have the functionality to send texts. ☹️ hopefully, they developers can add it later on. (Quick note: Make sure you read the booklet that comes with the watch. It helps with step-by-step instructions on how it set up).

Overall, since the purchase of this watch, I have been extremely happy with it. It was by far, THE BEST INVESTMENT I've ever made. 🥰🥰🥰

title: Great external build quality and it fills a niche that typical outlet strips miss.
text:
This is a very solid unit and it takes only a modest amount of common sense to avoid tipping it over. It's larger than it appears (to me) in Amazon's photos, but I'm sure that you could tip it over if you hang a bunch of heavy cords and wall warts all on one side. That's why most competing products include bases that are larger than the towers themselves.

The surge suppression may actually be useful because there is an indicator light to show that it is (allegedly) still functional. That's a big problem with many surge suppressing outlet strips -- the MOVs wear out after taking some number of surges and there is no indication that the surge suppression no longer works. The bad thing is that the light is on the back corner just above the power cord, where it's likely to go for months before someone notices that it's off (if they ever do). It should be on the front corner with the USB ports.

The USB charging ports on mine are likely to see use charging flashlights, Kindles, and other modest cost devices. I'm not a big fan of plugging expensive smartphones and high-end tablets into power strip USB ports. If my in-warranty iPhone is fried by a failed, in-warranty Apple power adapter, Apple owes me a new phone. If it's fried by a failed circuit inside of some off-brand, Chinese power strip, I'm probably out of luck.

All in all, this is a quality product that deserves the price charged.

Note: My evaluation is based on physically examining and using the unit and on the published specifications. I have not disassembled the unit to evaluate the electrical engineering, internal workmanship, or parts quality. Nor have I subjected it to stress-testing of any kind.
__________

Note: Complaints about the type size of the manual seem rather silly. This is a power strip, not an airplane, so how much do you have to refer to the manual? I've worn glasses for decades, correcting for both focal length and astigmatism, and I have no trouble reading the printed manual. Even more absurd are complaints about the font size in the PDF version; you're free to zoom in as much as you want when reading a PDF.

title: Good headphones, perfect fit, worth the price.
text:
To preface, I've tried several inexpensive True Wireless buds from Amazon. Most ranging from $20 - $40. My general issue with them is either:
A) They sound horrible
B) They don't fit well while running
C) They break or stop connecting

So far, these Earfun buds have leave all those boxes unchecked - which is great!

They sound good. I wouldn't say they sound GREAT, but they sound good. The Tozo T10s sound better in my opinion, but these do have a balanced soundscape that doesn't hide behind too much Bass like other inexpensive buds.
The noise reduction is OK. Honestly it's hard to tell when it's on or off - there's very little difference. You also need the left earbud in to activate/deactivate, since the toggle requires to hold the left bud for 2 seconds.
The fit is PERFECT. These fit better than any other buds I've worn. I run 25-35 miles per week and one issue I've found is a lot of buds fall out too easily (which is the downfall of the Tozo T10s), stick out too much so that it's uncomfortable to wear anything over your ears like a headband/sock hat, or they have a hook that causes some excess noise or flopping. These latched into my ear perfectly out-of-the-box and sit flush with my outer ear, so I can wear something over the top without it interfering. Definitely the best fit I've had with buds.
Battery life is fine. I don't really need a million hours of battery. I charge the case about once a week and that's good. The buds themselves I use for no more than 3 hours at a time and they've never gone below 50%.
