The case is TINY! Again, I've used lots of buds and have never seen such a tiny case for them. It's like a roll of Rolaids. I love that it fits so much easier in my pocket.

All in all, I give it 4*. The sound quality is above average but I've heard better on cheaper buds, and the noise cancelling isn't very noticeable. Other than that, these are incredible buds and are worth the slight premium over other "budget" true wireless buds.

title: I was sick of un/re-plugging HDMI cords every time I wanted to play my switch. Problem solved!
text:
I can’t believe I didn’t know these things existed…but now that I do….they’ve made dealing with our projector SO much easier!🥰

We don’t have a TV at the moment. That said, using a projector is just fine— most of the time.
The biggest downside to using a projector as your entertainment center -VS.- a T.V.? There’s only ONE HDMI port on the projector.

Until I ordered this HDMI 3 In 1 Out HDMI Switch, every time I wanted to use my Roku instead of my Firestick…I’d need to:
1. Unplug the power source to my Firestick.
2. Disconnect Firestick from the *one* HDMI port on my projector.
3. Connect my Roku to a power source.
4. Plug one end of the HDMI cord into the Roku.
5. Plug the opposing end of the HDMI cord into the projector’s single HDMI port.

That is just ONE example of a scenario where I’d need to fiddle with all of those cords in order to simply watch what I want to watch.😐

With this device? I’m able to keep my Roku, Firestick, *AND* my Nintendo Switch’s HDMI cord ALL PLUGGED INTO THAT 1 HDMI PORT!🙌🏻😍
• It’s super quick & easy to switch back and forth from one input to another, using the IR remote.
• Plugging the HDMI switch to a power source (using the provided Micro-USB cable*) is totally optional…which I LOVE because I HATE dealing with additional power cords! It may have a short delay (3-5 seconds after pressing your desired input button)…but just give it a moment. It will switch inputs!

It’s working perfectly so far. HIGHLY recommended for anyone who’s short on HDMI ports, whether your display is a TV, a computer monitor, or a projector!

5 out of 5 stars, hands-down!🙌🏻
🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟

title: Broken Foot but cool keyBOARD.  Pay no attention to the mouse.
text: The flip out feet on the back are junk and will break on you.  The design was poor and left the hinge of the feet fragile and thin.  I never use the flip down feet. But I do always put the keyboard back in the box when I'm not using it and the other day I pulled the keyboard out and the foot had broken off inside the box. See Picture.  I liked the keyboard. The light up keys also has a heart beat pulsing setting you can use...which is creepy.  It has 3 things that other keyboards don't have.  Illuminated key, oversize jumbo keys, without being uncomfortable for people with small hands who do like to touch type.  Most of the time keyboards that stray from the normal standard size that people are used to...tend to create a mess of mistakes when you go to use them.  Either the keys are too big and too far apart and your fingers miss key strokes, or they are too small and you end up hitting 2 keys at the same time when touch typing.  YES, it's wired.  Otherwise it wouldn't be able to illuminate for long.  I ordered it because I love to type in the dark and I really wanted a keyboard that I could quickly find the delete key or backspace key without having to place both hands on the keyboard and feeling for the F and J keys.  I wanted a keyboard that created an ambience in the room, so I wouldn't have to burn so many candles or keep a little flashlight near me to find that illusive thing on the nightstand.  So, I kinda wanted a nightlight that doubled as a device that I'm using.  This was it.  The wired, optical, boring, nothing to right home to mom and dad about, MOUSE.  Is really just thrown into the deal to make you feel like you're getting a pair of socks.  Honestly, if I was the seller.  I wouldn't even box the keyboard and mouse together.  They are WASTING THEIR MONEY.  Nobody gives a crap about a boring mouse, it doesn't light up, it's really a junk prize.  They should just sell the keyboard by itself and use the money they would save giving away junk mice, to further improve the keyboards design.  Oh and it the keyboard has two little feet.  It's made and put together just like the old compact keyboards from high school.

title: Not ideal for Mac Mini, probably fine for Windows
text:
I just got a new Mac Mini M2 and I needed to get a monitor for it. I really like curved monitors (even though there don't seem to be many of them made) and I wanted to get a 27" monitor, so this one seemed to fit the bill for my budget. It's not a 4k monitor, but I'm coming from a 2013 iMac, so I figured the screen has got to be better than my decade old iMac right? Wrong. The first thing I noticed was that all the text on the screen was a little blurry. It wasn't unreadable, but I definitely had to focus my eyes a bit more to be able to read it. Some of icons had a bit of "fuzziness" in their appearance as well. I never had this issue on my old iMac and this was driving me nuts.

I did some research into the issue and the bottom line is, you will never get anything close to what you see on an iMac unless you buy an Apple monitor, which is insanely expensive. Apple's monitors have almost quadruple the pixels (typically 5K or 6K monitors) and then they downscale the resolution so everything doesn't appear tiny. With a 2K monitor, it just doesn't have enough pixel density to display everything clearly. I did find out that Apple has enabled font smoothing by default because they assume you will be using a retina display. You can turn this off at the command line (or through your Settings if using an older version of MacOS). It did help to reduce the blurriness of text for me, but now the text appeared jagged. From everything I read, the best compromise is to get a 4K monitor to get greater pixel density. It still won't be perfect (definitely not like what you'll see on a Apple retina monitor), but at least it will be a step up. I actually sent this one back to Amazon and I'm now hunting around for a 4K monitor. I think I'm going to go with the Samsung S80A or Dell S2721QS.

If you use Windows, this monitor would probably be perfectly fine to use. With Apple's combination of using high-end monitors and then downscaling the resolution, it can be really hard to make this look perfect on Apple computers.

title: Awesome, retro looking player with nice source options
text:
[[VIDEOID:3f072fc7493cacfc69d229e3b98b6206]] Here's what I love about the CYBORIS Retro Bluetooth Speaker.
- The look. Sweet looking retro radio. The guys at work are jealous.
- The size. Not too small, but nice and compact. Lightweight too.
- The "feet". Sort of rubber and grip to surfaces nicely.
- Input options. Micro SD card comes in so handy for all those mp3 files I have stored up over the years. USB, and of course Bluetooth. All work well.
- The light show! Pretty cool, changing colors, flash to the beat. Importantly, this can be turned off as well. Fun show tho!
- Radio & Radio dial. Very nice extra option to pick up radio stations. The dial fits the style so well.
- Button feedback. Makes an acknowledgement noise when you operate it.
- Easy to use. Not too many features so there are a total of 5 buttons on this unit. Long press and short press make up the manipulation of settings/options. Although, some things seem to be missing....See below

Things I'm not as fond of:
- I can't seem to find a way to randomize SD/USB play. Need to research. But it's no fun hearing the same playlist when the card holds so many songs. You always get the first several then I've moved on. So for now I press Fast Forward, which is a long press. Slow and inefficient.
- Speaker quality. Now granted, this is a small and lightweight device. The sound is about what you'd expect. Not terrible, but not impressive either.
- Battery life is fair. Not terrible, not great. I think I got about 6-8 hours out of it on average.
- Seems to be FM radio only. Not a big deal to me.

Lots of options out there for bluetooth speakers. I like the look and size of this one. That retro look makes it stand out. Not the best in certain categories but I am pretty happy with it despite some shortcomings. Solid 4 stars.

title: Love it!! Who knew you could be so happy over a keyboard
text:
I immediately love it!! I only just opened it minutes ago and and seriously loving everything. The keyboard is super light weight, sleek, and has a slight bump out underneath creating a tilt (perfect for me). The color is beautiful, I was worried it would be an off-putting color but it's great. There's an on/off power switch which could be helpful for some. The instructions do say it goes to sleep after 10mins, so I may not need it.
I was a little worried about the thinness mouse, but it contours to the hand nicely. I'd say I have a large hand (gloves I wear are men's large/women's XL if that helps). It slides nicely across all surfaces so far with no lag in play.
The setup is basically non existent.. in that you just plug the USB receiver in & immediately go to work! No downloading of anything, no driver setups, no settings to adjust (other than mouse speed preferences). I even swapped from the Surface to LG gram mid stream with no issues, no hiccups, zero lag.
The keyboard cover is pretty nice. I really didn't have any expectations other than hoping they've come a long way from the DOS computer days (a given). It's very thin and fairly opaque. You can tell it's on the keyboard by looking but slightly. Thickness doesn't play a factor in hindering feel for the keys at all either. I will say fuzz and hair do stick it really fast & strongly and for me the effort to which you have to put in to pick the things off is slightly annoying, you can't just blow them off. Mine did come with a very slight tear, I only noticed it when I running my palm across the top. It doesn't seem that it would tear easily, from the little bit I was checking it out. I'm not going to mess with it or test it too much just in case. I'm not sure if it's the material or me just not being used to a cover, but so far my fingers don't slide across the keys as easily (or as I'm used to). Seems to be a silicone type material, I'm sure it says somewhere I just haven't looked.
The first set of pictures are without the cover, and then with the cover to see the difference. Either way I absolutely love it! Who knew you could be so happy over a keyboard haha

title: Great Keyboard!
text: I've used laptops as my primary pc for years. I recently switched to an all in one that came with a standard wireless desktop keyboard. I was beginning to think it was an expensive mistake because I simply could not get comfortable using the keyboard or the mouse. I was forever trying to trace my finger around and click on my desk since I haven't used a mouse in probably 20 years or more. I tried a track pad. The function was great, the placement was not intuitive or comfortable which led to more tracing and clicking on my desk. The search was on for a keyboard with a familiar, non-compact layout with a reasonably sized touch pad with the least amount of notably aggravating features. This keyboard hit all the marks. The only minor caveat is it goes dormant if not in used for a period of minutes. I don't really mind as it's not hard to wake up and it since it is rechargeable, backlit wireless it ultimately saves battery. Something I didn't realize until this keyboard arrived was how much I hate the height of the keys and the tactile feel of a standard desktop keyboard. This keyboard has the pleasant, solid and springy feel of a laptop keyboard. Not the clumsy and clackity noise of a desktop keyboard. While the touchpad is to the right rather than below the keys, it's easy and comfortable to use. I was able to change settings to allow more functionality through the pad itself instead of having to use the buttons for so much. I can change the colors on the keyboard as well as the backlight intensity. The lighting can also be turned off to save battery. I'm kind of enjoying low light purple so I'll deal with having to plug it in every other day or so. I knew I would miss having a number pad but realized it would not be as awkward to reach for that as a touchpad. So I also purchased a generic (labeled Jelly Comb) wireless keypad. It also has the same brightness and color selections to match the keyboard. I've been running the same low light purple on it for a week and no need to charge yet. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0B87G8P34/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1  These two items turned what I thought was going to be a keyboarding nightmare back into a pleasant user experience.

title: A Somewhat Slow, but Working RAM Kit
text:
This is an okay deal for RAM if you really need something in a pinch if you don't care about heatsinks or RGB lighting on your DIMMs. These arrive in a plain-barebones OEM-style configuration, without any temperature protection for the memory modules as well as there being no RGB or cool looking heat spreader to spice up your PC aesthetics. However, if you just need a basic RAM kit for troubleshooting purposes or as a backup, this works well enough.

My RAM did arrive in a clunky package, so my DIMMs were already loose inside the box when I took it out. Luckily, they did work, but the packaging does not inspire confidence. The RAM sticks were able to be installed like any other RAM, and my computer was able to boot. By default, this kit still settles for the non-XMP speed profiles, so you do have to make some BIOS adjustments to take advantage of this "measly" speed increase if you want to get the most out of it.

While the RAM did function, and I didn't have any crashes or weird issues overall, I did notice quite a steep performance drop when compared to the 3200Mhz Corsair Vengeance RAM that I had been using for my main setup. Games were more stutter-y, and my frame times were way less consistent compared to the Corsair DIMMs. I dropped an average of 6-14 FPS in some games just for the slight difference, but I don't know if that's just because the speed is lower or due to the unusually high CAS latency on these sticks. I don't know, but you will see a performance decrease compared to faster DIMMs.

For my use case though, I mostly wanted these as a troubleshooting kit as I don't care how good the RAM is if I just need to figure out an issue with my PC, and I am confident enough that this will help me troubleshoot faulty RAM should I ever have the need.

Overall, there are a few issues that I have that prevent me from rating it higher. While the RAM does function, it comes with a much slower speed, lack of adequate shipping protection, no heat spreader, and a higher CAS latency when Corsair Vengeance RAM is much more reliable for only a few extra coins. I would recommend it as a backup or troubleshooting kit but not for daily use.

title: Fast.  Great TBW. Simple. Super boot times.
text:
I have bought this multiple times and when the need arises another will be gotten. Sure some have faster R/W times, but using this on a Ryzen 9 I see no lag, no negative whatsoever. I do not game, but I edit photos and video, create html and php pages, crunch numbers in spreadsheets, do web things, etc - this drive is faster than it needs to be - well almost, but it never seems to be the bottleneck as drives historically have been. When I remember RLL and MFM or even PATA - this outpaces to a great degree. The boot times for this vs using NVME is truly not noticeable. I cannot tell if the drive boots in three seconds or four and besides during some boots various behind the scenes activities occur that do not happen other boot times. The manufacturer says four times faster than a HDD. I think even more in practice as I had a 2.5" platter drive where this was to test that and the boot times were an eternity, the OS was slow and pokey and it got replaced with this wonderful SSD.

One special reason I use these , and buy the 2 TB size is the longevity. The TBW is wonderful. The company states:
512GB Read/Write: up to 530/470 MB/s , 400TBW
1TB Read/Write: up to 540/490 MB/s , 800TBW
2TB Read/Write: up to 540/490 MB/s , 1,600TBW
so the large drive has exponentially more life than the smaller one. That said I do have a 512 that is my oldest purchase and it is still working fine and has no SMART error, it is in good health.

Two of the 2T are booting Windows 11 that is about 256 GB with about 750GB drive D: and then the remaining 1 TB is an ext4 partition for Debian to use. This lets me share Windows created content on the 750 GB very easy and this scheme works well in my workflow. Linux boots on its own NVME drive. This SSD mounted well as size is exact to the standard with threads facing down and out the side for versatility.

Packaging is simple: A SSD in a clear plastic tray in a small cardboard box. Easy.

title: A Full Suite of Content Creation Tools in One Package
text:
As a content creator, I'm always on the lookout for new gear that can help me produce better quality videos. Recently, I tried out the Movo tablet vlogging kit, and I'm happy to share my thoughts on this all-in-one creator package.

First off, I was impressed by the full-size tripod included in the kit. It's made of lightweight yet durable aluminum, making it easy to carry around without compromising stability. The tripod expands up to 57" tall, giving me a wide range of shooting angles and options. The pan head is smooth, allowing for precise adjustments during filming. I also appreciate the built-in bubble level, which helps me ensure that my shots are perfectly framed and level.

The tablet tripod mount is another standout feature of the Movo kit. It has a sturdy design that keeps my iPad secure and stable during filming. The screw-tight locking mechanism is reliable, and the holder expands to fit a range of tablet sizes. I no longer have to worry about my tablet wobbling or falling during my shoots, which is a huge relief.

When it comes to lighting, the Movo kit has includes an ultra-bright compact LED light. It offers a combination of warm and cool LEDs, allowing me to easily adjust the color temperature to suit my filming environment. The three brightness settings give me the flexibility to control the intensity of the light, which is essential for achieving professional-looking videos.

The cardioid condenser shotgun video microphone included in the kit is great for capturing high-quality audio. It significantly improves the audio quality of my videos, as it's designed to pick up sounds directly in front of the microphone while minimizing background noise. This has helped me create clear and crisp audio that matches the quality of my visuals.

One thing to note is that a Lightning or USB-C dongle is not included in the kit. This wasn't a big issue for me, as I already had one, but it's something to be aware of when purchasing this kit.

Overall, I'm extremely satisfied with the Movo tablet vlogging kit. It has elevated my content creation game, providing me with professional-grade tools in a convenient and easy-to-use package. If you're just beginning to create content, this is a great way to get a complete set of tools.

title: Expensive but Powerful
text:
My experience is coming from a 2070 to the 4070ti. In summery, I'm very happy with this GPU even if it cost a lot. For me, this is an investment into many years of high quality gaming which is my favorite hobby and what I spend much of my free time doing. I've listed my pros and cons for the GPU below with cons first.

Cons
-Price. This GPU is expensive even if it is less expensive than other 4070ti's and would be of better value at a $700 price point. Maybe wait for it to go on sale or get a used one if you can wait. If you have to get a 4070ti on Amazon right now, this is the best value one I could find.
-Massive Size. For some people, this is a pro. But for those of you with smaller cases or cases full of hard drive bays, this GPU will be too big. It's at least twice as thick as my previous RTX 2070 and 3 inches longer. MAKE SURE YOU RESEARCH WHAT SIZE YOU CAN ACCOMODATE. It fits my NZXT H510 just fine with a bout an 1.5 inches of spare room.

Pros
-Runs all my games at 1440p max settings @ 60fps+ with no problem. It often reaches frame rates in the hundreds no problem.
-Runs most games at 4K max settings @ 60fps. (Exceptions include modern titles with horrible optimization.)
-Runs very cool with temps no higher than 60° C but often runs in the high 40's while gaming. It idles in the low 30's.
-Low wattage requirement. A 750 watt Power Supply and 2 8-pin connectors is all you need. There is a converter for the 8-pin connectors that comes with this GPU.
-Quiet. The fans that come with the cooler aren't loud and the don't hit high RPM's because the GPU runs so cool.
-Overclockable. I haven't experimented with this yet, but this card does allow overclocking.
-Build Quality. This GPU is built like a tank with a metal back plate, and it doesn't sag in the PCIe slot and doesn't require a bracket.
-RGB customization through PNY's VelocityX Verto Software

title: Constant re-boots/BSOD errors
text:
I purchased this to upgrade my laptops hard drive – the old drive is a WD SN750 1TB.

I’ve had nothing but trouble with the new SN770 2TB drive!
I cloned my old drive, replaced the old 1TB with the new SN770 2TB drive, and powered up my laptop; laptop booted up perfectly… for about 2 minutes. First, my mouse froze, the I got the Blue screen “Windows has encountered a problem”, and my laptop re-booted.
This time, it got to the windows log-in screen – and froze up again. I had to resort to holding the power button to shut the laptop down.

I ended up re-installing the old (original 1TB SN750) drive, and everything worked perfectly. I decided to try to re-run the cloning process, which completed successfully; I re-installed the new SN770 2TB drive and had the same issues as before – random re-boots/BSOD, with Windows trying to repair itself on start-up.
I ended up trying 3 different disc cloning programs:
- Easus Partition Master
- Macrium Reflect
- Acronis True Image
I’ve tried cloning from
- original 1TB (still installed in laptop) to new SN770 in an external USB enclosure
- New SN770 installed in laptop, cloning from original 1TB installed in external USB enclosure

I get similar problems each time; the last try was the ‘Acronis for Western Digital’, from the WD website. I thought that I’d finally had success; I used my laptop all day (working from home) with no problems – I logged off from my work, went to prepare dinner, and came back to find that my laptop had re-booted.
It re-booted again after about 30 minutes, and just sat there with the Laptop boot logo – I had to force shutdown again.
Ended up putting my old drive back in and have had no problems.
Cannot recommend this drive.

Update : Replaced with a Samsung 970 EVO and have had no issues; almost 3 days of continuous use with no re-boots or errors.

title: Important!  (The 1/16 update tells you how to set computer to use 802.11ac)
text:
I bought this computer for my roommate on Black Friday so it was a great deal. I've read most of the reviews for it here on Amazon so I had some expectations about how it would work.

I'm happy to say that 4gb of ram is probably going to be sufficient for the tasks that she is going to be doing. No resource demanding programs will be used. Though you can easily add an 8gb stick of ram for 12gb total.

The wifi card was said to be slow by 2 different reviewers here and using the computer myself for a couple hours indicated that it's speed was fine. The computer downloaded and installed updates quickly and browsing the internet was satisfying. It worked similarly to my Acer Aspire 5 which I am very pleased with.

I credit the nvme SSD with making the performance snappy with this computer. And you can easily upgrade the SSD to a larger capacity if you want. There is also an empty bay for a 2.5 inch sata SSD but you need to purchase a cable and mounting bracket for it.

Overall a decent computer for many people who don't need a high powered machine. Recommended.

Note: I just updated it to 22H2 and the Disk Cleanup utility has been moved. The only way I can find it is with the search box on the task bar. (I have since found it in Start>All Apps>Windows Tools.)

Update 1/13 - I've spent even more time with this machine and I will say it rivals my Acer Aspire 5 which is saying something. At the current price of $245 from Amazon it is over $110 cheaper than the Acer Aspire 5 so it is a best buy in my opinion. The Asus VivoBook 14 is a great computer.

Update 1/16 - I discovered why people are getting low wifi speeds using Ookla Speedtest. The computer comes set to only utilize 802.11n rather than 802.11ac that it is capable of. Go to Device Manager, Network Adapters and double click on Realtec Wireless LAN. On the advanced tab Wireless Mode set to 802.11a/n/ac. Then Task Manager shows that 802.11ac is being used. It's too bad the computer didn't come set to use 802.11ac out of the box.

title: Amazing sound, perfect for specific use cases
text:
Over the years I have built up a collection of headphones from the likes of Sennheiser, Bose, Koss, Parrot, Philips, Apple, and Sony. I've been aware of Grado headphones for a while, but this is the first pair I've owned. These have quickly become one of my favorites, but they are best for specific use cases.

If you are going to use headphones in a noisy environment, in close proximity (i.e. within 6 ft) of another person who would be disturbed by sound leakage, or while exercising, these are not the headphones you want. They do not have noise cancellation and are open back, meaning sound leaks both in and out.

They are a larger on-ear, rather than over-ear, design. The clamping force is not too strong, but can get a bit uncomfortable after a few hours, especially for glasses wearers. They support Bluetooth 5.2 and the latest AAC/AptX codecs so the sound quality is the best available over Bluetooth. The open-back design and the efficient 44mm drivers provide a truly wonderful soundstage for a wide variety of music. Compared to most closed-back noise canceling headphones these sound like someone turned on spatial audio -- voices and instruments are clearly distinguishable, almost directional. The mids are clearly defined, revealing details that are muddy in other headphones. The highs sparkle, but are never harsh or sibilant. The bass is quite good for an open-back design, but it's a controlled rumble rather than a rattling thump. They play loud without need to crank the volume up and the sound is less processed and fatiguing than many of my other headphones. I'm not aware of any other open-back, wireless headphones on the market.

The batteries last forever, USB-C charging is fast, and the physical buttons work exactly as you'd expect. The plastic-y construction and light weight mean these definitely don't have the high quality feel you'd like at this price point. They don't even come with a case.

But if you are willing to pay up for sound quality and can handle all the other limitations, these are great headphones with nothing else quite like them out there. However, I would not recommend them as your only pair.

title: Mouse feels great, the keyboard not so much
text:
UPDATE: After about a week of use, I'm noticing that the keyboard is giving me some input problems. I sometimes have to press a key a few times for it to register. It doesn't happen all the time, but it is something I'm beginning to notice. I'm unable to determine if this is a connection issue or if it's an issue with the contacts beneath it's keys, but an issue nonetheless. I still enjoy using the mouse.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: Let me start by saying I love the feel of the mouse. It has very soft buttons and do not make a loud "click" noise as with some other ones. Glides well across my desk and has the dpi button. The mouse takes 1 AA battery, but does not have a compartment for the usb adapter as I've seen on other models. Too soon to talk about battery life, but overall the mouse feels really good, IMHO. The keyboard works great, but didn't immediately connect to the included adapter. The keyboard takes 1 AAA battery. I had to read a little deeper into the instruction to notice that you have to press "ESC" and "+=" for a few seconds to wake up the keyboard in order for it to connect. At the beginning of the instruction booklet it said it would automatically connect. Not a big deal, but not clear either. Once connected it has been fine and reconnects every time. I'm using the keyboard to write this review. The keyboard keys feel good and sounds as a normal keyboard. On the back it has two legs that you flip open to give a more ergonomic position for typing. I just think that the keyboard feels a little cheap, especially compared to the mouse. It has a very light, plasticky feel. Nothing major, but worth mentioning. Also, I was a little disappointed as I misread the title for this keyboard/mouse combo and read "blacklist" as "backlit" and thought I was getting a backlit keyboard. My mistake LOL, but just mentioning it here so others might avoid the same mistake. This is NOT backlit. I think the price is ok for what this is, again the mouse feels better compared to the keyboard, but that's just my opinion. If the price looks right to you then it's worth a look because it does work.

title: Supports Samsung Fast (but not Super Fast) Charging
text:
In order to charge my phone in my neoprene phone pouch (sized to fit both my Samsung Galaxy 22+ phone and my Anker Powercore Slim 10000 PD) I wanted to have a cable that would support the Samsung Fast Charging (but not Super Fast Charging) that this external battery supports.
Eventually some company will make a similar, phone-size/phone-shape slim charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, but we're not there yet.
So as to fit neatly in the phone pouch, I wanted a cable with right-angle USB-C male plugs on both ends.
I found three here on amazon, but couldn't figured which would be best. So I ordered all three to do some camparison testing to report for all three cables.
Here are the three I bought, with my analysis of each.
zdyCGTTime: The cable is short (~20 cm/7" between the centers of the two plugs). The cable itself is thick and stiff and doesn't bend well. When plugged into a wall charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, the cable also supports it. However, I found that the USB-C male plug would lose the connection with my phone when it was jiggled so I discarded this as an option.
AAOTOKK: this superficially looks similar to the zdyCGTTime cable, but longer (~32 cm/12.5" between the centers of the two plugs). Like the zdyCGTTime, the cable is thick and stiff and supports Super Fast Charging. Unlike that zdyCGTTime, the plug fits securely in the phone's USB-C socket and no amount of wiggling causes it to lose contact. It supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, and even if the longer cable is heavier and bulkier, the length allows it to lie next to the phone/external battery so fits better into the pouch. If my external battery supported Super Fast Charging this would be my choice.
KOOWOD: like the AAOTOKK, this cable is longer, but the cable is thinner, lighter and much more flexible, bends easily and sits happily in my phone pouch next to my phone and external batter. It does NOT support Samsung Super Fast Charging, though it does support Samsung Fast Charging. But since my external battery only supports Fast Charging, I am using this cable.

title: Not Your Moms old Digital Frame!
text:
Remember back in the early 2000's? (wow Im getting old) and these digital picture frames were all the rage? They seemed great indeed, but the limitation of yesteryears tech really didnt do them justice. They were a pain to get pictures on (moving pictures from memory card to frame) and they looked terrible unless you were looking at them dead on within 3 inches of the frame. They just never really took off because they just didnt work well. And not to mention the horrible burn in they suffered in just a couple of months time. I convinced my young cousin that Uncle Herbs ghost was in every photo of any of our family that was ever taken since you could see his outline in every picture from burn in...

Well....let me tell you those problems in the past are gone for good and so sadly is Uncle Herbs ghost! No longer do you have to manually download photos. The app can autosync the photos from whatever source directly to the frame without any intervention! They can also hold tens of thousands of pictures (if not more) Also the LCD tech has come a long way and these can easily be seen from any angle in any light! Colors are vibrant and look just like an actual high quality printed photo. Theres also no more burn in and they are not nearly as thick as theyre old counter-parts. Anyhow lets roll into some pros/cons of this frame in general.

Pros:
-Perfect size @ 11" (not too big and not too small)
-Excellent quality and brightness (easily seen on a bright day)
-Frame looks regal and nice (not cheasy like a lot of other plasticy frames)
-App and software are crazy easy to use and work off all mediums (ios, android, windows etc)
-Easy to wall mount of put on desk (all be it looks best on wall to me)

Cons:
-You still have to plug it in, not exactly a con, but if you dont do some wire tidying and youve got a wire randomly running around it, it does make it look unappealing. However some basic wire knowledge can fix this.

All in all this is the perfect frame for a wall or desk, its clear, concise, and inexpensive compared to other name brand frames.

title: Moderate decrease in brightness but definitely more glare
text:
tl;dr
The mounting tabs for removable option not very secure and started to peel away almost immediately. About what I expected with reduction of brightness but a bit more glare than I was hoping for.

Privacy filters like these are always going to reduce the brightness to some extent but some have decent glare resistance. This filter did reduce brightness but had a bit more glare than I have seen in others. Make sure you mount it the correct side out because one side appears to be glare resistant and the other side is glossy and very reflective. Unfortunately the instructions do not specify which side should be out even though the tabs for the peel off shipping protection film is numbered 1 and 2. It would have been very easy to have the instructions tell you which side to face outward but it doesn't. Now let's talk about the mounting tabs. It comes with 2 options. First, transparent double stick tabs and second, plastic tabs to hold it in place so that the filter can be removed when not needed. I opted for the second one and I will say that they do not hold very well. The long tabs that go on the sides have a 2.5mm strip of adhesive and 2.5mm of non-adhesive. The idea is to stick these on the sides and slide the filter between them where it's not adhesive. These tabs are lifting so I've had to repeatedly press them back on. I think they should have made the adhesive portion about 4mm and the non adhesive about 3mm to ensure they will hold for longer. All in all, it works and does what it's supposed to but the glare and poor adhesive on the mounting tabs are significant issues that should be addressed.

Good
- Polarization is good and provides privacy at approximately 60 deg angle as advertized
- Filter has decent thickness but not so thick it distorts

Bad (-2)
- Adhesive is not holding very well (-1)
- Mounting instructions don't specify which side out but it's relatively easy to tell if you look at both sides and see which side has the anti-glare surface (-1)

Ugly (-1)
- Glare is much worse than monitor by itself and a bit worse than other privacy filters I've used (-1)

title: Great tablet for the price!
text:
[[VIDEOID:c382fb103d8e77459af93b59ccae9944]] I bought this nice, blue Goodtel G10 tablet for my wife, and she just loves it! She enjoys watching movies, YouTube, engaging in all manner of social media, and this tablet handles it all effortlessly. I added a 64 GB microSD card, which was very quick and easy to do, then used the included USB-C cable to transfer some TV shows and movies directly to the tablet. I also connected the included Bluetooth keyboard and wireless mouse, which makes it very easy to navigate and do almost anything you can do when using the onscreen keyboard. I also connected an external Bluetooth speaker, which I only mention because the Bluetooth connection process is almost instantaneous and trouble-free! I tried out both MP4 and MKV files, and both ran perfectly with zero hiccups or ghost images. The display is bright and colorful, and can be seen clearly from an angle, and the built-in stereo speakers can be quite loud when the volume is turned up! And whether you're using the onscreen keyboard or the included keyboard and mouse, navigation is fast and easy. The included case fits very nicely and doubles as a "kickstand." making it easy and convenient to watch your favorite movies and videos. Considering the great functional characteristics, the slick Android 12 operating system, AND all the extra items that were included with the tablet, this is an incredible value for the money! Regarding the initial setup, I found that once you add your Google account, that it's best to go to the Android Play Store and install the desired apps one at a time; simply copying all of your backups via Google from another device may result in compatibility issues.
If you plan on transferring files from your computer to the tablet via USB-C cable, then you should set up the SD card for "portable" transfer of files. If you'd rather that the SD card is used more as an extension of device memory, then choose the other option. All in all, this is a fantastic tablet and and a real bargain for the money! Finally, let me add that this is the second tablet I've purchased via Amazon from JINDAKE, and these folks have the best and most responsive customer service that you'll find. Their service model is one that that every other seller should copy if they want to establish a loyal client base and keep folks coming back for more!

title: Experience for now - updated!
text:
Update 3/08/2023:
Up one more star.

My favorite feature - GPS location which tracks the car in real-time, well, it would be nicer without hitting the update button, but it is working again. I think I turned off and on for both the iphone location service and the Ring app’s privacy location sharing, might had fixed it.

I like this car cam and think it is a great product needed some time for perfection.
The picture quality is actually not bad, just hope to have real-time GPS on the map like a regular GPS navigator or Tesla app, plus better battery efficiency so the camera can stay on longer.

I installed it just yesterday, will update my review as time goes by, but so far I can only give it a 3 star.
1. Connecting to my home wifi couldn’t find my home wifi, while it is strong 50 feet outside of the house. I skipped and finished the setup without that setup. But strangely, after 10 minutes I went inside the ring app, it showed the wifi was connected with weak signal.
2. So I tried to see what wifi it is connected to, unable to find it in the app, so tried change wifi connection. Here’s the stupid part, it required me to give the pin code under the QR code on the bottom of the device, which now tucked in between the windshield glass and gutter, cannot see it unless remove the camera from the windshield, meaning the adhesive tape must be removed and replaced for a good grip when attaching the camera back on the windshield. Such a hassle for a simple change of setting, should have warned the user to save the code, or why not just text me a code instead?
3. The menu is not intuitive, I had hard time trying to see if it will show my car’s location, thought it should be in the camera review or dashboard. Turned out it is in the setting under the location tab.
As this is a new product, so a lot to be worked out to make the best use of it. This is by far the most expensive dashcam I bought, but if it can have the new features it supposed to offer, I would then say the money is worth it. But until then, I will update the score periodically.

title: Small and lightweight but made extremely well
text: This USB hub is a very nice unit. I was surprised when I removed it from the box and gave it a look to see how it was laid out and the build quality. The first thing I noticed is the outer casing. It is an all aluminum case which is a dark grey color and is anodized. The unit itself is very solid and very easy to carry. The ports are all of high quality and are nice and flush with the outside of the case. The micro SD slot, SD slot, Ethernet port, and the HDMI port are all made directly into the body of the case which makes for a very attractive look and design. It has a small blue LED on the top to let you know it has power which is bright enough to see in the daylight but not so bright its obtrusive or distracting. The cord is very short at about 6 inches or 160mm and terminates into a USB type C plug. I have used every feature this little hub offers and everything works flawlessly. The onboard Gigabit ethernet port works straight away without any need to install drivers or change anything in Windows. The HDMI port also works great and came on as soon as I plugged it up. I could not successfully get the HDMI and ethernet port to work simultaniously but I don't think they were meant to as there wouldn't be enough bandwidth to carry both signals at the same time over the USB 3.1 bus. There is also a port on the side which lets you charge things such as a laptop or phone and maxes out at 100Watts. There are 3 USB 3.1 Type A ports on the other side where the MicroSD and SD slots are located. It's nice to have a hub this powerful work right out of the box with ethernet and all these fast ports and it without an external power adapter. I have been using this for a few days now and I am very pleased with it. The price is very good for the quality you recieve. No drivers, no fuss, just plug it in and go. That's the way USB hubs should be and do it all without some clumsy external power adapter you have to lug around with the hub and have to be near a power outlet to even use it. This unit is truly portable and is a must have for those individuals on the go and need a few more ports to plug things into. You can't go wrong here for the price and you won't be disappointed with the quality.

title: Too Good To Be True
text:
I really wanted this camera to work. I already have two LaView interior cameras as well as 2 outdoor cameras similar to this one (and cheaper) from another brand. I wanted a camera that was compatible with Alexa so I opted for this one instead of the other tried and true wireless battery powered camera by the other brand. I didn’t notice this camera was magnetic until after it arrived and that really made me want it to work. I was thinking I’d be able to upgrade my interior cameras to these to get rid of the wires and have easy mounting.

This camera was setup right next to my existing camera for testing purposes and it failed miserably on all accounts. I spent days trying to get this camera to consistently connect to the app but it doesn’t. I would say 1 out of 4 times I would open the app and it wouldn’t connect and/or wake the device. Considering the device is “sleeping” it’s not working to detect motion. I got more notifications that the device was offline than I did motion alerts. When it did detect motion it only took a picture, where the other brand takes a video clip. Next, the battery lasted less than a week following a full charge, while the other camera (that is over a year old) lasts about 4 months where it’s placed. (My other outdoor camera that’s setup in a more remote area with motion detection turned off lasts over 6 months.)

I did contact support and they blamed my router, suggested I change it. Yes, because it’s so easy to just change out routers that are owned by the internet company. This was also after I had already informed them that 2 of their own cameras and 2 other cameras that are either of equal distance to or further from the router were working fine. It was also apparently irrelevant that the camera wouldn’t wake to even attempt to connect to the network half of the time.

By the time this review is published it will have already been returned. I would not recommend this camera to anyone for any reason because a security camera is not something you can have only working half of the time. I rolled the dice on the price because I have two other cameras that are only a little more than half the regular price of this camera that work fine… I expected the quality of this one to be better.

title: Product description
text:
This looked like just what I needed. I will tell you folks what this thing actually is next.

I wanted something to consolidate my audio inputs and give me a remote with volume and input selection. Short story – this unit will NOT do that.

I went the used route from Amazon. The first one had no output on the speakers or headphone jack. Amazon, of course took it back. The second one did have speaker output, but the 3.5 mm headphone jack didn’t work. Another review said they tried twice with the headphone jack problem. I wish I had paid attention. You could pull it out a bit and wiggle it into intermittent sound but alas another dud. So back it went.

The second one worked good enough to evaluate it.

What you have here is a reasonably good analog amp with knob selectors for various line inputs and 2 speaker outputs. You can mix that with 2 microphone jacks with knobs for levels. Knobs for treble, bass, and levels. A knob for output volume. All the analogue works fine with knobs.

Then - kludged onto this is, AND TOTALLY SEPARATE, is the blue tooth, radio, digital audio, and remote control. I mean totally separate. The remote only works the kludged part. The volume on the remote only works the kludged part. If there is a signal on the line in, the analog wins and the kludged part doesn’t work at all till you turn the selector to an input with no signal.

So, if you can get one that does work, don’t expect the remote to select line inputs or control volume from them. It’s knobs and input selectors for the analog, period.

I wasted way too much time on this already. Haven’t tried it all. Just sending back. I will also note that the near useless remote also lacks sensitivity. Point right at it from close.

If you want a small analog amp with multiple inputs and microphones for mixing with knob control, get a NEW one and hope. You even get a separate add on gee wiz of Bluetooth, radio, digital audio, …, and a remote for just those add ons.

title: Sturdy, heavy, many pockets
text:
I own a lot of backpacks - for any situation or occasion. Through it all, I have learned a lot of things about them - developed likes and dislikes - what works and what doesn't - and this bag ranks pretty high in my book - for what I needed.
I used this for a carry-on bag during my mini trip last weekend, and it was super convenient. The many pockets, zippered or not, helped organize many small items, and I didn't have to bring small bags separately to carry inside this backpack. You have to remember which pocket you used for what, though, or you will end up looking through all the pockets until you find what you are looking for.
Zippers work okay - no snags or pulls or hiccups like the cheaper brands. I especially like the zippered/cushioned pocket at the back, and I made sure more important documents were kept there - no way of someone trying to pickpocket that.
The zippers for the bigger compartments open all the way, so it is easy to access the things in the bag - just like a suitcase. I keep the zipper tabs towards the bottom of the bag, just in case the zipper decides to roll open by itself - although this bag's zippers have not shown that potential.
I usually choose black bags, but what I have come to find out during my travels is that having a bag that does not look like everyone else's could be a good thing in preventing something bad from happening to my bag - at the airport.
The bag is not heavy at all - it looks bulky and heavy, but it is not. It just expands and holds so much that you have to be careful not to put too much stuff in it or you might have difficulties standing up. You also have to be mindful of the size of the bag you are carrying, or you might end up bumping into everything along the way, or when you turn around you might hit someone and earn a grimace.
Its soft shoulder cushions make it comfortable for hours of use. It also has a handle both on the top and the side of the bag in case you want to carry it like a suitcase - which is definitely a useful feature at times.
Overall I recommend this backpack - the pink is subtle, and there is no loud, unsightly and humongous logo burnt on anywhere which is a complete bonus.

title: Not happy with purchase and here’s why.
text:
My main complaint is the charger. It is way too sensative! I have listed some things I’ve run into when using these earbuds.

Charger:

The charger itself will charge without it being plugged in. However, it stops in the middle of a charge. I find this earbud charger extremely sensitive. One slight move of the charger and the earbud magnets will slide off the charger magnets and you’ll wake up in the morning wondering why your earbuds didn’t get charged. The charger is very touch sensitive. It’s also very sensitive to movement. Actually very annoying when you are trying to place the earbuds just right inside the charger. Even when you know they are placed correctly one will stop charging at the slightest movement. I haven’t figured out a way around this.

Charging Colors:

The case does light up and change colors. But sometimes they stop changing colors and just light up Green.

Earbuds are easy to loose.

I left them in the charger overnight and brought them to work. Not realizing they had fallen out of the charger somehow. Some people say these are comfortable. They hurt my ear canals. Just being honest here. They did not come with any earbud covers. These earbuds have good sound quality.

I haven’t figured out how everything works yet. They sit in your ear canal a certain way. That’s how they will stay secure. However, working with these for a while I find they are very sensitive. Meaning, you have to place them on the magnetic chargers just right or they might not get charged during the night. One day I had found only one of my earbuds was charged and not the other.

Overall, having these for a few day now I find these more of a bother to work with because the charger is extremely sensitive. Today, 1/16 I did not even get 4 hours of use time and my earbuds shut down. They are not worth it. They need to redesign the charging case in a way so that the earbuds will stay put and not slide around. I will be looking for other earbuds with a better designed charging case.

title: Guiheng 2.4G Ultra-Thin Compact Wireless Keyboard and Mouse Combo
text:
If you're in the market for a new wireless keyboard and mouse combo, you might be interested in the Guiheng 2.4G Ultra-Thin Compact Combo. In this review, I'll go over my personal experience with this product and its key features.

Overview:
The Guiheng 2.4G Ultra-Thin Compact Wireless Keyboard and Mouse Combo is a sleek and slim set of peripherals that are designed to provide reliable and comfortable use. It features a 2.4GHz wireless connection, a compact design, and quiet typing and clicking.

What is it?
This is a wireless keyboard and mouse combo that connects to your computer via a USB dongle. The keyboard is ultra-thin and compact, making it ideal for use in small spaces. The mouse is also small and features an ergonomic design.

How does it work?
The keyboard and mouse connect to your computer using a 2.4GHz wireless connection, which provides reliable and lag-free use. The keyboard features quiet, low-profile keys that are comfortable to type on, while the mouse has a high-precision sensor for accurate and responsive movement.

What's to like?
One of the best things about this combo is how comfortable it is to use. The low-profile keys on the keyboard are easy to type on and require minimal effort. The mouse is also comfortable to hold and use, with a responsive scroll wheel and buttons. I found that the wireless connection was reliable and didn't experience any lag. Additionally, both the keyboard and mouse are very quiet, making them ideal for use in quiet environments.

What's not to like?
One downside to this combo is that it doesn't feature a backlight, which can make it difficult to use in low-light environments. Additionally, some people may find that the small size of the keyboard and mouse isn't suitable for their needs.

Conclusion?
Overall, I think the Guiheng 2.4G Ultra-Thin Compact Wireless Keyboard and Mouse Combo is a great choice for anyone looking for a comfortable and reliable set of peripherals. While it doesn't feature a backlight, the low-profile keys and ergonomic mouse make it a pleasure to use. For this reason, I give it 4 stars

title: Does what it says
text:
I already have a dash cam , but thought I have so many ring products I would try this .

The biggest negative for me was insulation , probably a good thing nobody was around me . As I was trying to push the power cord into the window area I had all sorts of trouble . If you are short and big in the chest area - you might want to find a talker person to help . Each time I tried to push this in it would come back out , so I tried to scoot forward to do this and I blew the horn , turned on my wipers hit the turn signal and turned on the hazards light. I was not amused to say the least and proceeded to use foul language. I had to ask for help to get this done . Set up was simple just not tucking in the cord .

I have a 2010 Corolla , this is another negative for the camera . It is in the dash with a little cover that opens , and the latch can’t be closed . My car is old but in good shape , so this makes me feel like it’s falling apart .

I have the settings to motion on the outside so I can get notifications if a person is around the car . This would have been handy two nights ago , because some idiot banged my car while I was at work . It’s a small ding but has me upset . I am hopeful this will alert me to another ding .

I have a battery in the car that’s one year and almost two months old , so no issues there , so far .

I’m hoping this lasts , time will tell .

Would I recommend this , I’m not sure , but one thing is I will not purchase one for the second automobile . I don’t hate this but with a regular dash cam you can hide much better , this is up front and in your face kind of thing that sticks out like a sore thumb .

Now this thing starts to shut off after 5 hours after the car is parked . I am not thinking this was a good purchase , save yourself money and buy a real car dash camera . Just today it turned off after 8 minutes , not impressed at all .

It’s junk and stay away .

title: Not the greatest
text:
We got these cameras for both inside and outside of our home.
I have so many different issues that I don’t even know where to start.
First of all, the quality of the picture isn’t great. If there were ever a time when someone was caught on one of our cameras, I don’t believe their face would be caught well enough for police to be able to identify who they were. Much less for me to discern my neighbor from a complete stranger. I say this mostly regarding night vision and not so much day but the range on either is not great. Even if you zoom, it doesn’t seem to help the graininess of the picture.
Secondly, the fact that I have to keep hitting a “continue” button to keep watching live view is maddening. If you don’t catch the button fast enough, love view ends and then you’re met with a “system busy” message when trying to pull it back up.
To add to that, you can’t save your live view session unless you pay for the subscription plan. Even if you have an external drive attached to your sync module.
Which leads me to my third issue. Everything is made difficult without the blink subscription. Certain features are blocked completely which, to an extent, is understandable. But features such as saving live view and the cameras taking a picture every hour shouldn’t be limited to the subscription plan if I have an external drive installed and am connected to wifi. It seems to just be their way of tempting you into caving and getting their subscription service.
The last thing I will mention here is the delay. While there is a delay when you are watching live view, that’s not the delay that bothers me. Many times I get an alert for motion but when I view the clip, the delay is so large in the motion event and the start of recording that I usually don’t even end up seeing what caused the motion. The motion detection on these cameras definitely have room for a lot of improvement.
All in all, if you’re just looking for something to monitor but not necessarily for something that you can roll back the tape, check specific times during the day, or actually see motion the moment it happens, then they’re not terrible. But definitely not worth the price if you ask me.

title: Excellent docking station, 2 HDMI ports, 3 USB-C ports, and more. Lightweight.
text:
This is a very well made docking station that comes in several colors. I ordered red, and it's very pretty. The docking station has 2 HDMI output,1 DP output, 4K resolution 60 FPS and vivid video,1 Type C PD 3.0 charging port which provides 100W super-fast charging speed, 3 USB 3.0 ports help you transfer the data with 5Gbps super-speed and connect with your wireless devices; and an SD & TF card reader makes transferring photos and videos easier.

These are all wonderful features, but I don't want or need an SD and TF card reader to make transferring photos or videos easier, and I don't need two HDMI ports, and I could use some USB-A ports to go with my older devices that came with those. Clearly, I should have read the description more than once before ordering this. My computer system is too old for this docking station to work well, which is certainly not the fault of this docking station.

The docking station is very well made and comes with exactly the ports it claims to have. I'd love to be able to transfer and back up my files at speeds up to 5Gbps via the 3 USB 3.0 ports, and I'd be very happy if this could lead to a better connection with my wireless mouse and keyboard. I've been working on that and think I'll eventually reach that point. I CAN use this to back up my files at higher speeds.

Excellent product, just not what I needed for my system. My computer's ancient, almost two years old, and I don't want or need an SD and TF card reader to make transferring photos or videos easier, and I don't need two HDMI ports, but I could use some USB-A ports to go with my older devices that came with those. Obviously, it's time I upgraded my peripherals, so that's what I'll do, a little bit at a time.

This is an excellent product that just doesn't fit in with my computer system well, and that's through no fault of the docking station. Still, it would have been nice to have at least one USB-A port on this, because some of us do still have peripherals that are outdated but work well for us. This is a wonderful product for newer systems, and I'd highly recommend this to anyone with a newer system.

title: Comparatively great
text:
For the first time, I think, I find myself writing a review in comparative terms. I mean, if I had only ever bought this frame, I probably would rate it lower. However, compared to the appalling previous frame I bought (and returned at a loss) from another manufacturer, this is truly marvelous.

The frame works pretty much as advertised. It is easy to set up, and it has a feature that I really like: it can be set up as a Samba server, so that you can upload images directly from your computer via your local network. While this is not particularly hard to set up, if you don’t have some technical knowledge, this task may be out of your reach though.
For me, it made all the difference between the frustrating experience trying to load images with the previous frame, and simply dumping the images here directly from my laptop. So much easier and faster!

The app method is very weird, though. For some odd reason the only other way to load images remotely is via email. So the app allows you to select up to 30 images, which it then compresses and sends as email.
I don’t like this, and I don’t use it, so I’m glad for the direct network alternative.

Some of my peeves are:
It does not play HR video. I can’t be bothered to convert and compress my videos, so I’m only using it for still images.
It claims to have a “motion detection” setting, which should activate the frame only when it senses motion in the room. I have not been able to get this to work.
The web radio setting is inconsistent. It plays for a while, then it stops, and if you want to continue listening, you have to go and find your radio station and set it to play again.
The clock, even in its smallest setting, is a very obtrusive analog clock animation, and it can’t be moved from its default position. So I have it off.

Regardless, the images look good, and the frame works consistently on the on-off schedule I set so, again, I am comparatively very satisfied.
I still think manufacturers could do a much better job with the user interface and features, though.

title: Good way to improve your WiFi network with a caveat
text:
Let's start saying that this product work as it is supposed and is very easy to setup but not all devices like them.
I live in a typical Suburb House with a Basement, ground floor and upper level where there is a Home Office. I use AT&T fiber because is a Passive Optical Network and the modem can (and is) powered using a 12 VDC battery power supply. I have all NEST & RING cameras powered with batteries too and before eero I used MEDIALINK WiFi routers, that for several years worked great but each floor level had a different network and was really annoying to remember that sometimes we had to adjust the phone or tablet as we moved to different levels. These MEDIALINK devices also work with 12 VDC so in the event of an outage I got the peace of mind that neither the Internet service or my internal network will give me an outage. The last utility power issue we had left the house for 6 hours without power but we could still work on our laptops, tablets, etc. I decided on eero because of some reviews but also feedback from other users. For the initial setup each camera was hooked into a UPS to prevent issues until I could power them with batteries. The first thing I noticed when the system was setup is that a couple of NEST cameras, one YAMAHA receiver and my Canon 7500 printer did not like this network, had to temporarily stop the 5GHz section until these devices joined the network. After everything was setup I purchased some 12 VDC to USB power adapters so I could move the cameras to a more reliable power source. I picked the eero I installed in the basement for a try but to my surprise none of the adapters I purchased, some of them the same I use to power the Nest cameras, worked for the eero. As soon as I plug the USB-C cable to the eero a yellow light starts to blink indicating that there is a power supply problem. I also tried using different cables and USB power supplies, each one of them gave the same issue. I researched on the eero site and they do not offer a 12 VDC adapter and wont use a power inverter due to un efficiency. So far the eero devices are powered by APC UPSs but if a power outage hit us won't be able to get more than 20 minutes of power. This certainly the most concerning issue and from my perspective is a drawback for the eero design team.

title: Actually useful review- its one of the best camera cases I've ever used
text:
Honest review, after I've had this camera case for years. I've put it through the extremes - beach vacations, boat charters, skiing, concerts, four-wheeling, hiking, horseback riding, Las Vegas, airports, in the wind, rain, cold, heat, all my activities over the course of my many adventures- and I take hundreds of photos on each trip. It hasn't stained, ripped in any way inside or out, deformed, or faded. No issue whatsoever with any of the zippers. It has a plastic or thick cardboard piece internally that does wonders helping with protection. Its gotten drenched in rain or ocean water splash and its kept my Canon G7X camera dry. Its a perfect fit for the GX7 too. The front pocket holds two extra batteries and a large size SD card all at the same time. There is no room for cables or the charger, but when I take my camera out for use, I generally want to have as little on me as possible, so I don't want the charger or cord with me anyway. It is small enough to not get in my way, yet big enough to fit the camera snugly and with the red material in front, I can find it in seconds when I'm in the car and I'm handling cell phone, maps, brochures, snacks, purses etc. I look around and find I'm sitting on a red case that I was scared I left somewhere.

The only gripes I can find is that it doesn't have a wrist strap or loops/rings on both sides to attach a strap. I used a camera strap from an old camera and put it through the zipper ring, that gave me ability to carry it securely around my wrist. But I am going to look for a case that does have dual rings so I can carry it around my neck. Otherwise I was trying to stuff the case in my back pocket if I didn't want it swinging from my wrist or carrying it in my hand.

The only reason I am switching to a different case is that I worry there is beach sand imbedded in it from so many Caribbean beaches that I've taken this case to, and I want a clean fresh camera case for a new G7X that just arrived, and I want to keep this camera clean of sand because I ruined my other camera by letting sand get all in the inside and never having it cleaned.

title: Supports Samsung Fast (but not Super Fast) Charging
text:
In order to charge my phone in my neoprene phone pouch (sized to fit both my Samsung Galaxy 22+ phone and my Anker Powercore Slim 10000 PD) I wanted to have a cable that would support the Samsung Fast Charging (but not Super Fast Charging) that this external battery supports.
Eventually some company will make a similar, phone-size/phone-shape slim charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, but we're not there yet.
So as to fit neatly in the phone pouch, I wanted a cable with right-angle USB-C male plugs on both ends.
I found three here on amazon, but couldn't figured which would be best. So I ordered all three to do some camparison testing to report for all three cables.
Here are the three I bought, with my analysis of each.
zdyCGTTime: The cable is short (~20 cm/7" between the centers of the two plugs). The cable itself is thick and stiff and doesn't bend well. When plugged into a wall charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, the cable also supports it. However, I found that the USB-C male plug would lose the connection with my phone when it was jiggled so I discarded this as an option.
AAOTOKK: this superficially looks similar to the zdyCGTTime cable, but longer (~32 cm/12.5" between the centers of the two plugs). Like the zdyCGTTime, the cable is thick and stiff and supports Super Fast Charging. Unlike that zdyCGTTime, the plug fits securely in the phone's USB-C socket and no amount of wiggling causes it to lose contact. It supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, and even if the longer cable is heavier and bulkier, the length allows it to lie next to the phone/external battery so fits better into the pouch. If my external battery supported Super Fast Charging this would be my choice.
KOOWOD: like the AAOTOKK, this cable is longer, but the cable is thinner, lighter and much more flexible, bends easily and sits happily in my phone pouch next to my phone and external batter. It does NOT support Samsung Super Fast Charging, though it does support Samsung Fast Charging. But since my external battery only supports Fast Charging, I am using this cable.

title: Works fine with built-in audio drivers
text:
I wanted to connect my Linux box to a digital receiver. This device works great for delivering stereo PCM over S/PDIF, and the built-in Linux audio drivers support it. Coax and optical both work (simultaneously).

Various pieces of documentation are split on whether 5.1 output is supported. I can report that it enumerates configurations for 5.1, and my receiver reports receiving a 5.1 data stream when one of these is active.

I tried the analog outputs briefly, and they sound fine to my ear. I haven't listened for DAC quality because I won't be using it that way.

The product photos show a "power indicator", but I think that might just be a hole to expose bleed-through from the TOSLINK emitter, which seems to be always on, even if you choose a non-digital config. Hey, it works!

There are configurations which include "mono microphone", even though none of the documentation mentions such a feature -- I didn't try this, so while the USB sound chip almost certainly supports it, I don't know if it works on this device.

The packaging is minimal. There's a tiny booklet written in broken English, and I can't figure out what some of the sentences are even intended to mean. There are (minor) contradictions between the product listing, the tech support answers here, the booklet contents, and the front of the box. Don't buy this if you expect a fully comprehensible manual.

In software, it reports itself as "C-Media Electronics Inc.", with the C-Media vendor ID. This is a C-Media chip, on a board with a couple connectors, in a little metal box. That's not necessarily bad (or good), but that's all it is.

This is a nice (and cheap) little box for bus-powered USB to stereo S/PDIF. For 5.1, you may want to use HDMI audio to avoid compression. For analog, you may want a nicer DAC, and maybe a hardware volume control and a full-sized headphone jack. There's really only one use case where I'd choose this device, but for that one use, it works fine.

title: A very capable computer, moreso than I think most will realize
text:
I live and breathe tech and love everything about these mini PCs. From the engineering, to the performance, to how much raw power they are cramming into these boxes--mini PCs have come a very long way.

The thing is, most folks have a monitor lying around. They have a keyboard. They have a mouse. If you're looking for an exceptionally capable, budget friendly setup for sub $300, this SER5 is extremely compelling.

We're talking a 6 core, 12 thread ZEN3 chip boosting up to 4GHz. Yeah, its not top of the line, but at a 15W TDP, you're sipping power and still able to do some entry level gaming off the APU. This thing easily handles multiple running applications, light video and image editing, plenty of browser windows, etc.

Worth noting, the max boost for AMD processors is the maximum frequency achievable by a single core on the processor running a bursty single-threaded workload. Max boost will vary based on several factors, including, but not limited to: thermal paste; system cooling; motherboard design and BIOS; the latest AMD chipset driver; and the latest OS updates.

The other beauty of this little machine is the accessibility for upgrades. Just pop off the bottom plate and you'll have access to the SATA bay for additional storage, the RAM and the NVME. So if needed, you can install up to 64GB DDR4-3200/LPDDR4X-4267 (this is the technical max that the CPU supports, not a chipset limitation) and you can upgrade the NVME to any PCIe 3.0 M.2 2280 (I'd go Samsung 970 EVO Plus--inexpensive and will max out the PCIE3x4 pipe).

And then there's the native 3 display support. Most options at this price point can output to 2 displays at 1080p and then you'll need an external Display Link adapter for the 3rd. Natively handing 3 x 4k displays is impressive to say the least and for those who need multiple monitors, its always a plus to not need a 3rd party intermediary device to facilitate.

Anyhow, I could go on and on but at the current price of $299, heck, even at its normal $320, this is an easy recommendation.

title: Decent option (but doesn't have 360* swivel as advertised)
text:
I'll start by saying that the installation was pretty easy, and the mount seems like it'll work pretty well. With that being said, it's not perfect. And required some minor modifications and installation adjustments

The biggest issue I found is that it definitely doesn't have the advertised 360* swivel action. In reality, there's basically no swivel if installed as outlined in the instructions. Fortunately, the solution is pretty simple. Just remove one of the two bolts that comes installed in Pan & Tilt component that attaches to the mounting plate (see picture). It'll still be plenty strong with only one bolt installed, and will then allow you to easily swivel/rotate the projector from side to side. A nice bonus is that it frees up an additional M5 bolt (which will come in handy later).

Another minor issue I found was that the included hardware to mount the bracket to your projector was insufficient. They specifically include m3 and m4 bolts for mounting the bracket. But many projectors use an M5 thread pattern. Fortunately, there were a couple extra M5 bolts. And by choosing to install only one M5 bolt in the pitch holes (also pictured). And by removing the above mentioned M5 bolt to allow for swiveling the projector. There were just enough M5 bolts left for the bracket to projector mount.

Other than that, everything went together pretty easily. My projector's footprint is a little smaller. So I had to swap in the two included Small Plates into the bracket. I also didn't use the included expansion bolts (anchors), as I was able to secure the mounting plate directly to a solid wood surface. However, to do this the holes in the mounting plate weren't ideal. So I drilled a couple new ones on each side. In doing so, the metal seemed pretty soft. But should still be good enough for this application.

Overall, it's a pretty good value. And may work just fine for folks without any modification or installation adjustments. Once installed, it's fairly sturdy, even though the metal seems to be a little soft.

Giving it 3 stars because if installed as instructed, the advertised 360* degree swivel functionality is non-existent. And while this was an easy fix, the claim of 360* swiveling was not at all accurate.

title: This is really nice.
text:
This is getting bad reviews by others - felt I should give my 2 cents.

I bought an IR 'fill' light which showed up weak...and pitiful. I am unsure the purpose of a fill light in IR but it was a waste of money. I bought this - at a similar wattage and function - to see if my expectations were wrong. This is a 'flood' light and not a fill light...so note I'm not expecting them to be identical. But this one is WAY WAY WAY brighter. Both are 940nm which is usually only good to 30-40' due to the wavelength...but this easily hits 40' out to 50' and with lots of bleed off out to 60'. If you've ever observed anything approaching a light source from the darkeness you'd be able to imagine how this works...first a shape is seen...then the shape takes form, then details can be seen then they become clearer clearer bright brighter BRIGHT TOO BRIGHT! That's just how IR illuminators work!

What's also nice about this one is the fact it has a day/night sensor as well as a button to be always on or use the sensor.

It's heavy and chunky and NOT discreet AT ALL...so make sure you verify dimensions and recognize that this thing WILL STAND OUT...it's not svelte or tiny by any means...but on the plus side, lots of chunky aluminum heat sinks on the rear. Note also this doesn't come with a power supply so you'll have to grab that also - which does add to the overall expense...12vdc/3a. Note that transformers or wall warts of this size start to get chunky...you may opt for a plug style where the plug is a big housing and takes up multiple plug spots...or you may consider the plug with cord to a 'brick' style. So keep that in mind that you'll have to get one. I tested mine on 12v/2a and it worked...but I suspect the LEDs weren't outputting to their max. And usually power supplies are oversized - so 3a may be a safety margin...I don't know what they actually pull in amperage - but I've got on order a 3am and I may update this review later to mention the differences between 2a supply and 3a supply.

title: Good product, not for me
text:
I bought these so I could finally stop having to constantly push my AirPods back in my ear at the gym. Initially I really liked them.
Pros:
The teal color is very pretty and I loved the oval shape of the headphones.
They’re very comfortable to wear and I didn’t have the issue of them slipping off or being too tight or loose. For reference, I have a biggish head and even bigger hair and I also have 6 piercings, 2 of which are still quite sensitive. They didn’t cause me any discomfort at all.
Battery life is also really good. I’ve had them for a few days and haven’t needed to charge them yet. The little light is still green so I’m taking that to mean full battery.
Controls are easy, functional, and make sense. Without using my phone, I can turn them on and off, adjust volumes, pause and resume, and and skip and restart songs.

The meh:
The sound quality is just alright; I definitely prefer my AirPod pros.
The noise cancellation on these is not exactly noise canceling, but rather the speaker just plays loud enough to drown out any outside noise. This is different than AirPods which automatically cancel out noise whether anything is playing or not.

Con:
I found just one real con but for me it’s a deal breather; it’s the fact that sound from the headphones BLEEDS. SO. BAD. If I take them off, I can still hear the audio even when it’s on the lowest bar! I wish I wasn’t exaggerating. This ruined the product for me because I like to listen to my music loud and the point of wearing earphones for me is to not have to disturb those around me but with these I may as well be playing music/videos straight from my phone on high volume because it’s THAT loud.

TLDR; If you’re not worried disturbing other people and just need something loud, pretty, comfortable, hands off, and with great battery life, you will love these headphones. But if you hate hate hate when earphones bleed like I do, skip these or you will end up returning like I did.

title: Incredible Value for the Price!
text:
My wife has the Apple Pencil (Gen 2) and I was going to buy same until I found this. The Apple Pencil (referred to as “AP” in the rest of this review) is 5 times the price of this one so I figured I’d try it out.

I was worried it wouldn’t work with my iPad since I’ve had other non-Apple accessories that had problems. It seems like many off brand devices don’t work well with Apple products. There was no problem at all with it.
