While the AP is a Bluetooth device and you have to pair it with iPad before you can use it, this stylus works off of capacitance and didn’t need pairing. I just opened Goodnotes, clicked the on button, and started writing.

It writes smoothly, but there are differences between it and the AP as you can see in the picture. The fine setting is finer than the AP, but the thicker 2.0mm setting is a lot less. If I were using it to draw this may be a deal breaker, but I will only use it to take notes so not a big deal to me.

It is magnetic and sticks to the iPad similar to the AP, but it will not charge the same way. One thing that is annoying is the cover for the USB charging port is on the same side as the flat, magnetic portion. Because of this it doesn’t stick flush with the iPad. It would have been nice to have the USB on the opposite side so this wasn’t a problem. One more issue is the flat portion (charging side) of this stylus is not as pronounced as the AP and it has a tendency to roll across the desk whereas the AP does not. (Maybe I am knit picking, but those two features are the reason I gave it 4 stars rather than 5. If they aren’t that big of a deal to you, you will love this stylus.

It took about 15 minutes to fully charge and I really like the blue battery/charging indicator. It comes with the charging cable and 3 replacement tips.

Are the features of this device and the design as sleek as the AP? No, but for the $$$ savings, it will work just fine for me.

title: Update with Fixes on the Way…
text:
Update:

I’ll start by saying Eufy support is top notch. They reached out to address some of my concerns.

1. Regarding the light attachment to the base. I was told they are implementing a fix to secure the light to the base top and bottom.

2. HB integration end of March. This should resolve the human detection and image quality issues I personally have. My 2k doorbell cam runs on HB 3 and is a great camera. I’m assuming this light running on HB will be the same.

The light features and functions itself are great. I have no issues with that at all.

All-in-all, with the base fix and HB integration I’d say this will be a solid buy.

Quick summary:

- Crappy light attachment to base
- Doesn't utilize Homebase
- Poor human detection
- Subpar image quality

I have three Eufy S300 4k cameras, one 2k doorbell, bunch of entry sensors and now this wall light.

First complaint is the how the light attaches to the wall base. You screw the base to your wall then attach the light to the base. There is only two tiny screws on the left and right side to secure the light to the base.

You can see from my pics the weight of the light pulls it away from the base creating a gap. 100% water is getting in there. There should be a screw in the top and bottom as well.

Next the camera quality. It’s pretty poor compared to the 4k which is amazing. It’s even lower quality than my 2k doorbell for some reason. Maybe is the location but I’m not sure. Big fail by not using the 4k camera in this application. Night and day difference.

It does not integrate with Homebase. Why release a new product that doesn’t support HB tech? About 20% of my alerts have been false. The camera thinks a red bag sitting on my porch is a human.

Huge miss not making this 4k and not integrating with Homebase.

title: Well constructed and everything advertised really works!
text:
This is a compact monitor that comes with all possibly needed cables along with adapters to use if your system happens to need one. The color accuracy is stunning and clarity is very good even using a three year old integrated Intel graphics chip on my LG Gram laptop. This is one of the best anti-glare screens I've encountered. The included cables are solid and clip firmly into ports on the monitor. The OSD offers every setting I've wanted including sharpness, brightness, contrast, saturation and preset color temps and the option to create a custom setting with RGB sliders. There's even an option to change how long the OSD stays open for adjustment. There are several gamma settings and I found myself using these to achieve the tone I was looking for.

I'm using this mainly with a display port connection because I sadly discovered that the USB C port on my laptop is for power only. However, I tried it on a friend's newer computer just using the USB C connection and it worked quite well. With this connection the touchscreen seemed responsive and accurate although I only tried it for about 10 minutes. Considering the specs the monitor is light and easy to carry around although the case/stand does leave something to be desired. I've not tried the speakers which are are well placed on the frame.

CONS: this is small but annoying - the OSD "wheel" has to be activated and adjusts by pushing it in and then rolling it up and down. For some reason the piece that protrudes slightly to push in is almost a sharp point digging into my finger. Perhaps mine is faulty or it's a bad design. It's annoying but it is too small an objection to take any stars off considering the quality of the monitor and its performance.

I had the good luck to come upon the monitor when it was on special for $50 off but having used it, I think it's still quite a good deal at the usual price. My only hesitation is the availability of Casking for repairs, tech support etc. Their website says it's coming soon.... They offer an email address and I did contact them with a question; so far I've not heard back. I hope they thrive because this is an overall excellent product with most of the details addressed. It even has a small but comprehensible manual.

title: Pretty good but lacking some control - 6 Month  Update
text:
Update after about 6 months: The firmware continues to improve both stability and speed. I now see about 650Mbps when hard wired in to a mesh unit. Wireless connection on non-wifi6 devices is ~400Mbps. I live in a denser part of town, so this is pretty good for wireless.

Here's a tip: Setup a weekly reboot of the system, this is done in in the web interface -> Administration -> System tab, then 3/4 way down the page. This will reboot the router and mesh points, no need to log in to the mesh points to setup their reboot. Reboots help with stability and speed.

This is a pretty solid setup for mesh wifi, especially Wifi 6. I'm seeing ~540Mbps in real world, high density neighborhood. If you live in the burbs you will likely see better performance.

Pros: The setup is just technical enough for me and no too bad if the average person reads the setup instructions first. Pairing mesh units is better than other systems I have used. Something I don't see documented is the WAN port on the mesh units acts as a regular access switch port. Meaning you can hookup a 5th device to the mesh point, unlike the router unit where the 5th port is reserved for WAN (your internet connection). Configuring wireless is pretty easy, leaving defaults is fine for the average person.

Cons: I would like a little more control over the mesh units. For example, I would like to easily use one as a bridge, so it does not repeat the main wireless network. Unfortunately, I haven't found a good way to do this and maintain the ease of maintenance. It's not a deal breaker, should would be nice nice to blast the air waves needlessly with my network. Remember, wireless is a finite resource. Finally, this is nitpicking, the user interface is antiquated. I've owned other asus routers over the years, since 2006. The interface is basically the same. I felt right at home but was disappointed there haven't been advances with the interface.

Conclusion: It's a good option in the consumer wifi mesh space. It fills my needs enough to be satisfied. I wish there were a few more features. However, I downgraded from a Ubiquiti Unifi setup because I got tired of the maintenance.

title: An Okay Bag That Could Have Better Laptop Protection
text:
This review is for YAJIE Medium Size Laptop Canvas Tote Bag (ASIN: ‎B09QZYF88L). I really wanted to like this laptop bag. I have a Targus laptop messenger bag that I have had for about eight years that I really like. I was looking to see if I could find something that was even better, and unfortunately this YAJIE bag is not it.

This YAJIE bag is not terrible, but it is not great. On the plus side, there are multiple compartments, a removable shoulder strap with swivel clips, and a back strap for putting on luggage. Now on to what I don't like. The padding is very thin and flimsy. The compartments could have been improved to be more usable. The zippers are very low quality. I don't like that there is no Velcro strip in the middle of the back strap. I like it because it's more secure for attached to my luggage trolley handle and gives me a better piece of mind (I feel like it is more difficult to steal if I take my eyes off of my laptop bag). I would not want to fly with this bag, since I do not feel confident about the low quality and coverage of the protective padding. I also find the price to be too high for what you are getting. At this price point or slightly more, there are better choices that offer more protection and usability.

On a side note, if you are going to be doing any flying with a laptop bag, make sure you get the features you need. If you do not have TSA pre-check, you will want to get a laptop bag that allows you to open it like a butterfly so that you don't have to take out the laptop or wireless keyboard (if you use one). Also, you will want to get a laptop that fully protects the laptop. That means fully covers it and uses quality padding. You will also most likely want to get one that is as close to airline maximum allowable size for carryon purposes. Since this will be the bag you store under the seat, that means you will want to be able to fit more than just your laptop and accessories, like snacks, book, medications, or anything else that you may need or want. It is absolutely worth every penny to buy a good quality laptop bag that will allow you the most flexibility and protection.

title: 2-Way Audio ONLY Works With Danale App
text:
I REALLY wanted a 2-Way Audio camera for my front porch, as I do NOT want a Ring Cam.
This 2-Way audio cam is not the best, as far as 2-Way communication with people.

First of all, these "ONVIF" compatible cameras ONLY means they will provide video, audio, and motion detection for your NVR to record locally.
So unless you have the exact, or compatible, NVR brand, you will NOT be able to utilize the more advanced features of these cameras, UNLESS you install the manufacturer specific app on your smart device.
(IE: Danale, in this case. Who wants to install multiple apps on their phone to use features on each vendors camera? NO THANKS!)

I am using an Amcrest NV4108-HS NVR with 3TB HDD and was able to get it configured to record and mark motion triggered events, BUT CANNOT use the Amcrest View Pro Android App to communicate via 2-Way Audio; It ONLY monitors the mic (1-Way communication).

Ring cams sound and look like a toy, not a real security camera.
I do NOT want a "Ring" cam and refuse to pay a monthly fee for their Cloud service, although I hear the Ring cams CAN send video/audio to an NVR to save recordings locally.

If the manufacturers could only make a more compatible camera WITH 2-Way Audio which supports multiple NVR brands, I believe these cameras would be selling like CRAZY!

Now, on the positive side, this camera has a nice clear 4K 8MP picture, LED lights, and audio that can play a small MP3 file every time it senses motion. The flashing LED strobes can scare off would be theives, but can startle legitimate visitors.

Although I'm still in the "Testing Phase" of this camera, bottom line, for the price point, it's a decent camera, but don't expect the 2-Way Audio intercom feature to blow you away. The Danale app that MUST be used to have 2-Way Audio is pretty slow and the cam speaker is "tinny" sounding.
BTW, the Danale app is buggy and SLOOOOWED down my cellphone substantially!

title: Big sound; small footprint
text:
The JBL Go 3 measures 1.61" x 3.46" x 2.95" and weighs 10.4 ounces. Despite its small footprint, the JBL Go 3 packs a 1.7" by 1.9" full-range driver that delivers up to 4.2 watts of output.

I paired the JBL Go 3 with my ASUS Zenbook Duo because they're both blue and the sound this little speaker delivers turns heads. The sound quality is good, bass is present, vocals are articulate and this thing gets far louder than expected from something so small. I was listening to music outside my favorite coffee shop and a passerby looked at my speaker and said "no way...you must be paired with something else." I said nope and held up this JBL Go 3 to show him the JBL Go 3 was my only speaker and he replied, "Oh, it's JBL -- no wonder." That was the end of the conversation with no other explanation necessary. JBL has set a performance standard and this JBL Go 3 lives up to it in its own diminutive way.

What I liked most about the JBL Go 3 was:
- Highly portable
- Big sound despite its small size
- Dust and water resistant
- Stylish

What I liked least about the JBL go was:
- Battery life. I didn't get 5 hours on a single charge from this speaker but I probably play it too loudly to get those results.
- No sub-bass. Even though this is JBL and it packs plenty of bass, physics doesn't allow this speaker to produce much or any sub-bass.

Overall, if you have to take a single speaker along with you during your daily commute then the JBL Go 3 might be the one. The JBL Go 3 looks and sounds great, is dust and water resistant, has a built-in carrying loop, and weighs a mere 10 ounces. While this speaker packs plenty of bass there are some people who are going to expect sub-bass from any JBL product and that crowd might not be happy with the amount of sub-bass this speaker produces. That said, for the vast majority of people this is an excellent, cost-effective way to experience JBL sound. 4.5 out of 5.0

title: Solid Wi-Fi Based Camera with Solar Charging Capabilities
text:
The camera was easy to set up with the included hardware.

First thing I did was to fully charge the battery to see how it would perform with no solar panel. It has been running for over a week now and is still at over 60% charge. With the solar panel to provide ongoing charging, power should not be an issue; even with several days of cloudy weather.

Setting up the camera is pretty straight forward and handled through the app. Once the app is loaded and you provide credentials for your Wi-Fi, a QR is provided to scan with the camera to get it connected. This is similar to other Wi-Fi based cameras I have used. You get both instructions in the manual, on screen with the app, and voice prompts coming from the camera. Once set up you can control the pan, tilt, and zoom function live from your phone. You can also access stored images or videos, switch between SD and HD, activate the white light, sound, and microphone. There are a number of other settings you can customize beyond this.

Video quality is fine with this. I generally keep it in SD, and find that is generally sufficient. Images and video can be stored to the cloud using a subscription service, or you can opt to store them to a Micro SD card. I did this. It uses a looping function, meaning if the card fills up, it goes back and records over the oldest clip. Night time images are in the expected grayscale unless you choose to activate the built in light, in which case it will switch to color. You also have the option to manually start recording or snap an image from inside the app. Otherwise, it will activate when motion is detected and record for the time specified on your settings.

There is sound available too. It is probably the low point of the camera. It works, but is fairly low quality. The sound allows you to hear what is happening around the camera, and by activating the mic, you can also talk to who ever is there. This is a great way to mess with your kids.

Additional settings you control are the camera name, you can flip the image orientation, set motion detection sensitivity, and even arm or activate an audible alarm.

Overall I am very satisfied with this camera. It offers a lot of features and control at a reasonable price.

title: Very easy to set up and control. Provides excellent coverage and video image.
text:
[[VIDEOID:bcfff113d3805e166adbb328524b17bb]] I've been wanting a means of monitoring conditions in my house while away for extended periods. I purchased a POE system with hard drive, 8 channels and 4 stationary cameras. I decided to add two Noonkey 2K/3MP Light Bulb Security Cameras to the system as well, adding the ability to scan conditions that stationary cameras can't.

The Noonday cameras were an absolute breeze to set up and connect to my system, and the EseeCloud app is capable of selecting and controlling any camera. These cameras can work standalone without any system simply using the app, but I was really surprised with the seamless integration with my system.

If you can screw in a light bulb and download an app, then you can install the Noonkey Security Cameras and have a solid surveillance system in place in no time. Now the biggest hurdle may be finding a light socket in your home with downward hanging incandescent light fixture or electric socket in an area you want to monitor! I'm not kidding about this. My home is older and there are only a few light sockets that point downward. The camera doesn't perform as well without this bit of infrastructure. I removed the light fixture just inside my front door, and also in my basement, and chose those locations to install my Noonday cameras.

Using the EseeCloud app on my iPhone, the cameras were recognized immediately, and ready to go without any issues. Capable of 360 degree horizontal and 90 degree vertical rotation, the Noonkey camera can see any conditions around it. The images are clear and sharp, and with illumination for full color night vision, the images are great, far better than the stationary cameras sold with my system.

I have a lamp on a timer set to come on for a good part of the evening so that gives me additional illumination source for the camera to monitor temperature and conditions in my home.

I'm not concerned about criminal activity, but mainly concerned about power failure and heat loos during winter while I'm away. If my cameras go out, temperature on the nearby temperature gauge falls below thermostat setting, or any other unusual activity occurs, I can call someone to intervene in my absence.

Overall, I'm completely satisfied with the Noonkey wireless cameras.

title: KIND OF LARGE, "LIMITED USE"  Long time to charge, FAST TO DRAIN BATTERY!
text:
This item is "Larger than you think". With a bunch of random parts to keep track of. It would eat up desk space/cabinet space.
It does come with a nylon bag to toss it all in to though.
It takes a long time to charge. I charged it Fully before testing. It does have some good suction.
but It really has limited uses. THE BATTERY TAKES A LONG TIME TO CHARGE and according to the "percentage of charge display"on it, IT DRAINS AMAZINGLY QUICKLY, SUPER FAST!
It does not have a bunch of good uses that could not be done with other things. Not Amazingly good at what it does. IT IS ESPECIALLY LIMITED BY HOW FAST THE BATTERY DRAINS and how slowly it recharges.
You would have to always have it out charging. From my limited amount of testing use it seems like its little filter would be rapidly clogging up and needing cleaning and drying. As it is now for its use it is limiting because of charge/charging issues and Eating Up, wasting space. it is kind of a hassle at it is. It seems a bit gimicy to me and a bit of a first prototype, rought draft kind of an item. I'm not sure how many "balls/rafts or air matresses" you are going to get inflated before it goes dead, and then the long charging time. If you have some constant need to be vacuming your keyboards or something VERY QUICKLY every day. Maybe this is something for you. OR MAYBE I GOT A DEFECTIVE ONE AND IT SHOULD HOLD A CHARGE LONGER? I can litteraly see the charge imediately and RAPIDLY going down when it is turned on.
I don't know, but as it is now for me, it would be more of a hassle to mess with than it is worth. I can see it would just become a space eater and dust colector. It needs to go back. BUT IF YOU HAVE a use for a quickly going dead lilttle air pump vacume thing. (with very limited dust catcher) This Might Be For You? It does feel pretty solid for what it is. ("heavy")

title: Decent low cost camera with a few annoyances
text:
The camera is a decent pan and tilt camera that needs better instructions and the app could use some work also. For the money you pay, you can't expect an 8k camcorder that will do everything! For the price point, this is what you get. It is a basic webcam with pan and tilt options. 2-way audio is ok but if you don't install the app on your phone you cant use it like a bunch of other features. Power cord a WAY too short. Like most things now days it is a usb cable with the power block at the end but the included usb cable is so short you would have to be right at a socket in order to plug it in. Other annoyance is you have to push the camera the whole way up to access the sdcard slot and reset buttons. It doesn't tell you if you can do it by hand or have to do it through the app so hopefully doing it by hand doesn't hurt is as that is what a lot of people will be doing. Picture quality is pretty darn good for a camera in the price range and I have no problems with that other than the lack of zoom...yea, no zoom! I guess you could digitally zoom in but they missed the ballpark with not including that. You will get color in the day and black and white at night (like I said, low cost webcams all do this). Not too loud while panning or tilting but the motion tracking is spotty. It could work perfectly for a while and then just have a fit and start tracking a piece of paper that hasn't moved lol. Anyway it really is not bad for the price!

As for the cloud stuff - I HATE IT!!!!!!!! These subscription things are horrible! I don't want a webcam that will be using my internet to transfer pictures online especially when I do not even know where they are going! I could do packet sniffing and figure everything out but I should not have to. I should be able to have this use my NAS or JUST the sd-card to capture an not be reliant on he internet for features because they were too expensive to put in the camera. This fact alone I took the 2 stars off. Give me something that works the way it should UNCONNECTED! I like in a country setting so internet here is shotty at best anyway but with this using up bandwidth it would destroy my bill so keep that in mind.

title: I liked it until I didn't
text:
**UPDATED**

Well the device sh!t the bed. When I turned on the TV this morning I had a black screen. I unplugged the device, waited a minute or two, plugged it back in, and it wouldn't keep any app that I opened open. It would open for a moment, then just close. After trying to open a couple of apps it just froze. Unplugged it again, waited a few moments, plugged it back in, same result.

There was also no help that I could find in regards to casting so I never did get that to work.

Thank goodness I still had my Roku Ultra plugged into the TV.

HiYa!
I've been streaming ever since the internet was available to the public. I've used several different methods.
I've been using a Roku Ultra for a few years as my primary streaming device. Since the Chromecast with Google TV (HD) was on sale I figured I'd give it a try.

It did not take long to set this up, however I was already familiar with how to set up ChromeCast devices since I own 2 (without Google TV). Setting up the various accounts (2 Google, other apps) was relatively easy with the scanning of the QR codes.

The controller is dinky compared to the heavier somewhat larger Roku but it functions just fine. Setting up TV controls was easy. I remember the days of having to look up numbers that coincides with your device, put in the numbers, doesn't work, try different numbers until the tv turns off. This does all that pretty much automatically. Very nice. I've also ordered a cover case for the controller because if you drop it without one it might shatter into millions of pieces.

The picture appears crispier than my Roku. The sound is a bit louder also which I like. After adding my other services like Netflix Amazon Prime PlutoTV and such I get a recommendation watching list on the home screen. Navigation is pretty straight forward.

All in all I like this device so far. The only reason why I left out a star is because I have not tested the casting capabilities yet. I'll submit an update once I've played around some more.

My best,
-John

title: A Very Good Kit for the Money
text:
The Octa Softbox Lighting Kit is an expansive assembly of the most useful pieces wanted to pursue artificial light photography.

Two quite large soft boxes producing wonderfully soft light with their white covers easily installed are simple to deploy; two powerful 135 watt bulbs are controlled by remote control to provide white, warm, or cool temperatures, each with steps from the lowest to the highest of brightness; two tall light stands; individual on/off switches; remote on/off switches; two (empty) weight bags ready to aid balancing; and even gloves with which to protect oneself from hot bulbs if you need to remove them from the soft box before they cool down. Also, individual storage/transport bags for each folded soft box and a large bag with which to contain the entire kit are here if you wish to go on the road. Everything required to get in business is included except batteries for the remote control units.

The 135 watt bulbs are of higher power than my other kits and are smartly engineered with many large fins to dissipate heat quickly. Each soft box comes with its own remote controller ( that is, 2 are included) which enable quick changes of the light temperature to white, warm, and cool. No pairing or complex setup is needed. They also allow quick changes of brightness with a single button that performs a 20%, a 50%, or a 100% instant result. And, the remote control will also change brightness in much smaller bites with different buttons from the brightest to the lowest if you don't wish to use the instant buttons. However, there is no alternate way in which to make these changes. Only the remote control devices will suffice. Each controller takes 2 AAA batteries.

Either remote controller works with either soft box. Either one soft box, or the other, or both, is controlled by a single remote control depending on your proximity to the soft boxes. Nothing difficult. The controllers can also control on/off.

The maximum light produced is very bright and the minimum is quite small. Thus, a wide range of light is available to the photographer and is completely under his/her control from both soft boxes. The remote control units work responsively and the light stands are adequate.

There is a lot of content here for the price and I find it a very good buy. Highly Recommended.

title: Great range of motion. Easy to adjust. Tilt function could work better
text:
I had recently purchased a new 32'' monitor and the base was taking up too much desk area so I thought I'd give this monitor arm a shot. This is my first monitor mount/arm and I'm impressed by what it can do and how easy it is to adjust my monitor.

I love that this arm uses a gas spring because adjusting to whatever position I want is a breeze (except the tilting which I talk about later). It took a little adjusting at first to get the gas spring set for my monitor weight but once I had everything set I can move my monitor up, down, forward, backward without adjusting something.

So far the gas spring has held up my monitor up nicely and it hasn't dropped down on its own since I originally set it up. I've seen some monitor arms not able to hold up monitors properly but this one has held my 32'' without a problem.

I did end up routing my cables though the integrated cable management and I think it looks great. I don't have it that way in my pictures but I'm glad I routed it that way because it keeps all the cables out of sight and it looks much cleaner.

I've only had a slight issue with the tilting function of the monitor arm. They show in their listing and videos that the tilting for the monitor either needs tightened or loosened depending on the weight of the monitor and then you can adjust the tilt as needed without messing with the adjustment. On mine I can't adjust it without the monitor tilting forward on it's own so I have to tighten it down all the way. So unfortunately I can't just reach out and tilt my monitor without loosening the bolt, adjusting the monitor, then tightening it back up. This isn't a deal breaker for me but it does make it a little difficult to adjust the tilt on my monitor.

Overall, I'm really happy with the monitor arm and it looks good holding my monitor up on my desk. Most of the adjustment is simple and easy especially moving it up and down or moving it forward or back. The tilting can be a pain at times but I don't tilt my monitor that much anyway - I mostly keep it in the same position tilt wise. If you're looking to get a monitor mount/arm I recommend you give this one a shot especially if you have a larger, heavier monitor.

title: Very different look, good features, and a few areas to be improved
text:
This is a really interesting pack that offers a much different look than other 30L competitors I've seen on the market. I'll comment on some of the features
- Baffled padding: Looks a little like a puffer jacket, and adds some extra padding if you have tech materials.
- Curved bottom: The molded design looks kinda cool, but the bag won't sit flat. It also would be better made of a rubber or tarpaulin material as it is a dust magnet and may be difficult to clean off dirt.
- Side access panels: I like this design, and it's something similar to the Peak Design Everyday pack. However, this one only has one zipper. I'd like to see one at each end for flexibility in opening it.
- Zippers: At this price point I'd really like to see YKK, but I don't see any branding. They're not the most robust zippers I've seen.
- Quick access top area: I like it! more bags could use this type of design for phones, chargers, and snacks.
- Zip-out water bottle holders: Reasonably large and deep. Pretty flexible. I generally don't need two, so one would've been fine to make the other side a fully sealed pocket. Some of the best designed bags also have TPU linings and drains for water bottle holders.
- Harness and back: Chunky, good airflow. The webbing on the top of the strap could use a few more stitch points to give better options for carabiners and other latch-on items. Lacks chest strap for longer hauls.
- Laptop compartment: Large and soft, false bottom gives the laptop additonal protection. Tablet sleeve

Overall, I like many aspects of this bag. I'd rather see some adjustments to the dimensions. Perhaps an inch narrower and an inch taller might make it easier to manage as an EDC. If one of the side water bottle holders was sacrificed for a small pocket, I'd like it built out with space for pens, business card area, thumb drives, etc. Beware that STM will only support the lifetime warranty for approved resellers, so you might check with them before buying from an Amazon 3rd party seller.

title: A fantastic blend of style, sound quality, and comfort
text:
Hey there, fellow music lovers! I just wanted to share my experience with the SAYAPE Noise Cancelling Over Ear headphones. These headphones have quickly become my third favorite ANC headphones, which is better than you might expect considering how many I've tried and the prices I paid for #1 and #2.

First off, the noise cancellation on these headphones is quite good. With 4 ANC microphones and 1 voice microphone, they filter out up to 95% of low-frequency ambient sound. That's a maximum ANC depth of 36 dB! With SAYAPE, you can say goodbye to distractions and fully immerse yourself in your calls, music, and movies. Of course, keep in mind ANC does best with regular noises, not necessarily sharp, random noises.

Now, let's talk sound quality. The 40mm large dynamic driver units and sensitive diaphragm work together to create rich instrumental harmonies, clear vocals, punchy bass, and a finely balanced sound. Plus, with 4 EQ modes to switch between, audiophiles and music enthusiasts will find new ways to enjoy their tunes.

One of my favorite features is the 50-hour playtime. The 700mAH battery lasts up to 50 hours on a full charge, and if you're in a rush, a quick 10-minute charge gives you 2 hours of listening time. And if the battery does run low, the included 3.5mm audio cable lets you switch to wired mode, so you'll never be without your tunes on long trips.

The Bluetooth 5.0 technology gave me a stable connection at all times. I was surprised to find out I could connect two devices simultaneously!

Last but not least, the premium design and comfort of these headphones are worth mentioning. The cool, retro aluminum alloy vinyl record design has eye-catching metal details that'll make you stand out. The headband is made of manganese steel, and seemed to promise durability and resilience. The soft ear cups can be swiveled and stretched for a perfect fit and they stayed comfy even during long listening sessions.

In conclusion, the SAYAPE Noise Cancelling Headphones offer a fantastic blend of style, sound quality, and comfort. They're perfect for anyone who's serious about their audio experience. Give them a try, and I think you'll be pleased with them.

title: A Nice Well-designed Tablet
text:
I’ve done work as a visual effects designer doing matte painting work with the large 22 in W**** display tablets, and I have a couple older drawing tablets as well. But what I really needed was a smaller mini tablet for quick concept sketches and annotations on work... so when I came across the Huion Inspiroy 2 tablet, I thought I’d give it a shot.

THIS IS A NICE TABLET! I’ve heard good things about Huion, and after working with it for a while I totally agree.
Pros
Stylus Performance: the pen that comes with the tablet is very intuitive to use, and supports pressure and tilt sensitivity. On a whim, I dug out one of my older Intuos 4 pens, and it was recognized by the tablet!
Buttons: you get six in a row, and with the software, you can set this tablet up for a right-handed (buttons on left side) or left-handed (buttons on right side) or even in Portrait Mode.
Software: the Control Panel for the macOS works great; no weird system issues, and the level of programming for pressure sensitivity, button options for general use vs specific apps is great.

Cons
Buyer’s Regret: I wish I bought the LARGER size now! But I did want a smaller tablet and this has worked to my expectations. Maybe too good!

I’m not sure if this is a Pro or Con for others, but I’m glad that the tablet connects to your host computer with a cable. I have so many other devices that either fight for Bluetooth or has a stupid dongle that plugging in a tablet when I need to just makes sense for me.

All the things I am used to doing with my other tablets can be done as well on this Huion. So far after a month of use, I’m impressed with the build quality and the usability of the software. If you are a starting artist, I have no issues recommending this since for $60 it’s a very minor investment for a full-featured tablet. The quality in this Huion tablet was a great introduction to the brand for me, and I’ll definitely consider a larger Huion tablet in the future!

title: Easy-to-use 1080p portable monitor with USB-C, MiniHDMI
text:
I got an A1C and a A3C from Arzopa over the last couple of months. They're very similar but have slight differences.

The high level summary is that they are great for what they're meant to do. I used them with my Dell XPS 15 9570 laptop, using just USB-C (for power and display/audio). No issues, reasonable audio and good video quality (which is hard to photograph since I was in a bright room at the time I was trying them out). There's a magnetic folding cover/stand that's easily removed. The screen is well-protected when it's closed, so you can leave it in your laptop bag without its own pocket.

Here's where we deviate between the two.

The A1C is 1080p 15.6" (1920x1080 wide), with a thumbwheel to control the onscreen display. One side's controls include power/return, the spin wheel for OSD controls/volume/brightness, and a 1/8 headphone jack. The other side has two USB-C ports and a mini-HDMI port. They include a mini-to-normal HDMI cable, C-to-C, and A-to-C. There's also a small wall wart, the size of a phone charger. If your USB-C device

I would have preferred a full size HDMI connector, but the adapter cable makes it not as painful as without.

The photo of the two monitors isn't meant to show video quality - it's meant to compare to a 15.6" Ultrabook. Without the glare it's pretty good shape, and plays 4k video (albeit downscaled) pretty well. There are adjustments to make to video settings if you want to enhance - I haven't done that yet as I'm still figuring out how this will get used.

All things considered it's a good display for travel or tight spots or sporadic use (where you don't want a full scale LCD monitor on a stand).

Note that this sort of monitor is not self-powered. Under average use they probably use 5-10 watts and can be powered from a laptop USB port or a modern USB battery pack if you're not using the USB-C data/video connector for it.

title: Awesome camera with lots personal preference of setting options.
text:
ieGeek security cam model ZS-GX3S

First off like most things I give a review after I have used the item first so as not to give an out of the box review with no knowledge of how things really work. So with that said this camera has it all going for it. It’s a nice size for a outdoor security cam, it feels to be quality made and the performance is superb. I can’t imagine that anyone would expect a higher quality image from an outdoor camera than what this one offers. It’s packed with lots of personal setting options as well, you can set the sensitivity levels for video and audio level to whatever you prefer. You can set when it record, how long it records and where it records. A cool thing about this camera is you can set exactly the area you want monitored (see pictures for example) It’s both a camera and a spotlight, you can activate the spotlight by app or set it to come on when movement is detected. It truly has all the bells and whistles you could want or expect from a much higher dollar camera, it has a siren, strobe/flashing lights if you desire. The battery life depends on how you have your settings, if you set the sensitivity high and it’s in a high activity area then of course your battery won’t last as long however if you set it more conservative it will last quite a long time. Personally I set it to record a large area, sensitivity high and high record time which does use more battery life but I can easily access it for charging so for me it’s a good trade off. To wrap it up it’s truly a 5 star camera in every way. This is not the first camera I have purchased from this company and they too are 5 star. As I go along I will start replacing other outdoor security cameras I currently have with ieGeek cameras. I’ve attached some photos, the ones with the squares colored in are showing how you can select exactly where you want to be notified and recorded, the other images are showing the difference between HD and QHD quality. HD alone is great quality and they took it one step further and added the option for an even better quality with the QHD plus a full color night vision option.

Thanks ieGeek for great cameras at prices that are affordable.

title: Better car navigation with this adapter (Yes. Really. Read why.)
text:
My cellphone tells me where to drive. Sometimes it thinks I'm next to the freeway, when I'm already on it. Sometimes it tells me to make a U-turn, but I'm on a one-way street. I thought it was bad software. Turns out it is bad GPS satellite reception. Navigation uses up so much battery, when I'm in the car my phone is always plugged into power. I toss the phone as it charges into the cupholder, and I roll.

Let's look at that more carefully.
* My phone's GPS antenna is near the top.
* My phone's USB-C charging jack is at the bottom.
* With a charging cable plugged in, my phone goes into the cupholder upside down.
The charging cable, coming straight out of the bottom, doesn't let me stand the phone right-side-up, so the GPS antenna sits in a hole. That's how I've been getting bad navigation advice.

I'm able to stand my phone up in the cupholder when I use this right-angle adapter. My phone now gives excellent directions. This right-angle USB-C adapter gives me better car navigation because my phone can now stand on the charging end while it charges, which it couldn't do before, while it holds the GPS antenna high.

That was a lot of improvement for very low cost.

One last note: you are reading a Vine review, which means this product was sent to me without my having to pay for it. I never believed Vine reviews, I felt people would say anything to get free stuff. The Vine program, at least for me, is a little different: I only get what I go out of my way to ask for, and everything I get is reported as income to me, so I'll have to pay income taxes at what will probably be reported as list price. I may actually lose on the deal. When I came across this right-angle adapter available for review I skipped it, but something clicked and I realized it might be help me. I got to try it and see that it very much does help me. This adapter is something I use, I didn't know it existed before I saw it available for review, and, hopefully, my experience has been a help to you.

title: Decent KVM
text:
Let me start by saying I'm picky with KVMs and I have been through a few. This one is replacing another unit from another manufacturer which has intensely bright indicator lights.
This box is very small and compact for supporting 4 USB and 4 computers. It feels solid with all metal casing. The buttons are not the best, but do operate well. The connections in the back are good for tucking away wires and avoiding clutter. The USB ports are in the front making them accessible. This works for me because my mouse and keyboard are using a remote dongle. If you are using a wired mouse/keyboard, be aware the cords will come out of the front.
I love that the external power is included but not required. A different KVM I owned required power to maintain video signal, this one does not. That is one less cable to clutter my area.
The connections to the PCs are made with separate USB-A and HDMI cables. For me, this was a disappointment because my pre-existing unit had USB-B connector /HDMI combo which won't work with this unit. I'll need to rerun the wires. The USB cables are included, which is good. However, the HDMI cables are not so you'll need to buy them separately if you don't have any laying around.
Switching is easy. You can either use the front panel buttons to select the PC you want or you can use the tethered remote. There is no keyboard key-combo to switch between PCs. This was also a disappointment compared to my prior KVM as I must now reach for another device with a wire on my desk to switch. Also, note that with a MAC I have a slight problem. Each time I switch back to my mac, it detects a new keyboard and prompts me to press keys to identify the "new" keyboard. The Mac doesn't remember the keyboard when you switch away and back. You can click through the notice, but it is annoying.
I'm happy to say the lights are not that intense. They are just enough to see the unit has power and which PC is selected. It won't light a room ;).
Compact, easy to use, and durable. Definitely a good purchase that would be better with MAC compatibility and keyboard switching.

title: Looks nice and appears well made, but compatibility is lacking.
text:
This PoE injector is one that I really wanted to like, as I like the overall appearance and construction of it. It just looks and feels like a nice product. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to work that well.

Just as a bit of a quick test, I decided to try out three VOIP phones I typically keep on hand. The first a Vtech conference phone (aka SNOM C520) is known for being picky about PoE adapters and is always pretty hit or miss. Well, in this case, it was a miss. It didn't even see the PoE adapter and never lit up at all. On its own, this usually doesn't bias me too much against a PoE switch or injector, as that is just a quirk of that model phone and likely means it isn't totally 802.3af compliant in some respect.

Next, I moved on to a phone that has always worked with everything I have hooked it to: a Grandstream GXP-1625. Well, while it lit up and was receiving power from the adapter, the phone never booted, which really surprised me. I even went back and tested the phone on another PoE switch just to verify that it was still working ok (which it was).

As a final test, I moved onto a Fanvil X6U and it fired right up, pulled an IP address, and connected to Asterisk.

So...one out of three really isn't the best luck. The SNOM I could forgive, but not working with a Grandstream is pretty rare. All I can think of is that the two phones it did not work with are both older 802.3af devices and this thing may have VERY picky PoE negotiation that doesn't like them.

When I have a chance to borrow one again, I may try this with a Netgear WAX615 to see if it works and if it recognizes it as 802.3af or 802.3at (as it is essentially designed to only work at full power with 802.3at PoE and tends to be quite conservative with which switches and injectors it recognizes as being compliant).

So....yeah, not the greatest luck with this and I really can't recommend it unless you can test it out with your specific device ahead of time.

title: Mixed feelings
text:
After Sean Olive's and DMS's social posts with graphs, I realized I can get a Harman reference iem for $20. My curiosity definitely worth that.

First thing you notice in any product is packaging.

In this case the cost of packaging is probably X5 of inears themselves. Sturdy box, nice prints, great unpacking, a lot of waste.

Iems feel very basic, though everything - cable, shell, resin cover - is soft touch which I like. Cover there is to presumably protect them against sweat.

They definitely tried to make the shell small, because cover is relatively thick and makes them notably larger.

I don't think the task was fully accomplished, since while my ears are not the smallest, with the cover inears are still on the larger side.
Also, with the cover tips do not fit my ears well, so I simply removed the cover.

Cable is very microphonic, it's possible to wear them only behind the ear in iem style.

Sound.

I appreciate how the FR graph looks - first of all it is very, veery, veeery smooth. No peaks, no dips.

Highly encourage you to stick to original tips. All the other tips I tried, are adding more peaks on highs.

I EQ the sh out of all my headphones with the help of sine sweeps and parametric EQ. I discovered that on any headphone I still hear some very specific peaks and dips, particularly but not exclusively in highs.
The sound significantly improves after I EQ those peaks and dips in and out, so the sweep is at the same volume at all frequencies.

The good thing about these JBLs is that I do not need to EQ them up to 2.5K! Which is rare. Basically bass and a large chunk of mids are very well balanced, maybe slightly thick, which is fine.

Having such a smooth FR through the entire range is definitely a nice accomplishment and it's easy to EQ.

So now I know what things I like about Harman Target and what I don't. For $20 bucks. I nice milestone in audiophile's journey.

title: Not a Shotgun Mic (Big or Mini)
text:
I was so hoping this would increase the forward directional volume for videos taken with my camera as a shotgun microphone should. It does not.
This is a single (mono) standard condenser microphone. The microphone (capsule) itself is located at the front tip and not at the rear of the tube as where on a shotgun mic it would be located (see my photo).
The box is labeled simply as a "compact cardioid condenser on-camera microphone" and that is what it is. Throughout the seller page (and in the title) it is listed as a "Mini Shotgun Mic" It is not a shotgun mic, not even a mini one.

It has a standard cadioid pattern. That means it has pretty much equal pickup of sound forward and to the sides, not just a forward and clearer sound as a shotgun mic pattern would have.
Testing using my DSLR camera with subject speaking loudly 100 feet (30 meters) away from the camera it had slightly better sound and reduced wind noise than the small microphone built into the camera, but not by much and not louder.

The built-in shock mount the seller touts is nothing more than the capsule mounted in a rubber circle attached at the front. If the recording device it is attached to is bumped you will hear the sound. I would suggest to use on a tripod to eliminate camera movement noise.
I'm sure the 2 and 1/16 inch (6 cm) long tube really serves no purpose other than looks and to allow for the included "furry" windscreen to be attached. I have to say that is probably the only reason I will ever attach the "7RYMS MinBo" to my camera again as the windscreen effectively eliminated wind noise that the internal camera mic had trouble with.
It would be worth it as an alternative microphone for the reduced wind noise but only "if" it was sold for a much lower price.
I have to add that to even suggest (as shown in one of the seller's photos), that it would be a suitable addition (replacement mic ?) for a $400+ Tascam Portacapture stereo recorder troubles me.

If the seller would just have promoted this as an alternative microphone for the poor small internal mic in your camera (or phone) and priced accordingly, this would be a much different review.

title: Very Inaccurate Data
text:
The two main reasons I wanted this watch was to respond to text via speech-to-text as I’ve seen others do with their watches and for the sleep tracking capabilities. I was even delighted to see that I could control the Spotify playing on my phone from it. I quickly realized that I was able to see texts on the watch, but not respond.

Which was fine. At least it could track my sleep and a host of other functions. The next day as I sat at a table reading, it recorded me as being asleep for 20 minutes when I most certainly wasn’t. I shook it off as an error. But the last several days it’s only recorder an hour and a half to 4 and a half segments of sleep when it was closer to 5-8 hours.

I’ve also since realized that the music control function only works if you keep the watch’s phone app open while playing the music. Even then the watch tries to function as a speaker and I’ll have to redirect the audio to my headphones. In fact, every time the app is open the watch instantly takes over audio even when I’d rather it not.

Tail end of my expectations was to use it to track my steps. Again I have sat at a table and had steps added to my count. I get the feeling it tracks steps via gps which can be highly inaccurate. I’ve also read other reviews on the watch’s accuracy for blood pressure and heart rate being poor. I can’t attest to this myself but I would easily believe it.

In the end I am keeping it as it does function well enough for the $30 I spent on it. I can see texts to judge when it’s worth taking my phone out while at work. It does display the time and date literally at the flick of the wrist so that’s handy. It takes calls fairly well so long as your wrist isn’t blocking the speaker or receiver and you are in a quiet area. It has built in alarm, timer, and stopwatch functions that I’m sure work well though I haven’t used them yet myself. Lastly it has a ‘Find my Phone’ function that works though I’m not sure how far away it can be and still function.

title: Short Range and Hard to Changing Eartips
text:
I been looking for a pair of earphones with massive range like at least 100 feet or more and I thought these would be close after seeing other people's reviews saying that they go over 60 feet.
But after charging them, I connected them to my phone easily and tried them out.
The tips were too small so I changed it to the biggest ones which are like a normal small size compared to other kinds.
They were very difficult to take off and more harder to get them on.
Finally I was ready to test the range and started losing connection about 30 feet.
This got me very upset and it pointless to try to return them when Amazon charges $7 for UPS pickup because I lack getting help with transportation.
The final issue I noticed is that I only played with them for about 5 minutes and the battery power was already at 90%.
And that was only checking out the controls, range, and barely listening to a part of a song.

Controls (Each EarBuds are touch type):

Play/Pause - Touch L or R Once
Skip Song Forward - Touch R Twice
Skip Song Backward - Touch L Twice
Turn Up Volume - Press and Hold R
Turn Down Volume - Press & Hold L
Answer/Hang Up - Press L or R Once
Reject Call - Press and Hold L or R
VoiceAssistantSiri - Press L or R 3 Times
Power On/Off - Hold L or R if not connected

Be careful with these because the touch is very sensitive.
Even setting it on your leg can start playing it or putting it in your ears.
They magnetically drop in place with placing them back in the box too.

Another thing is that you can turn the volume all the way down and you might think they are broke or somethings wrong, but always check turning the volume up before ruling that out.
It almost got me.

And the sound quality is not bad at all plus gets kind of loud.

It's the battery source I'm already worried about now since I'm stuck with them.

Basically, I will not buy again or suggest a friend.
Sorry.

title: Awesome sound for the money.
text:
The AIYIMA Tube T3 HiFi Tube MM Phono Preamp is a great option for anyone looking for a high-quality, affordable phono preamp. It features a warm, rich sound that is perfect for listening to vinyl records. The preamp is also very easy to use, with just a few simple controls.

One of the best things about the AIYIMA Tube T3 is its sound quality. The preamp uses two 6N1 vacuum tubes to create a warm, rich sound that is perfect for listening to vinyl records. The sound is full and detailed, with excellent separation between instruments. The preamp also has a three-position gain switch, which allows you to adjust the volume to match your speakers.

Another great thing about the AIYIMA Tube T3 is its ease of use. The preamp has just a few simple controls, making it easy to set up and use. The front panel features a power switch, a gain switch, and a volume knob. The back panel has two RCA inputs and one RCA output.

Overall, the AIYIMA Tube T3 is a great option for anyone looking for a high-quality, affordable phono preamp. It features a warm, rich sound that is perfect for listening to vinyl records. The preamp is also very easy to use, with just a few simple controls.

Here are some of the pros and cons of the AIYIMA Tube T3 HiFi Tube MM Phono Preamp:

Pros:

Warm, rich sound
Easy to use
Affordable
High-quality components
3-position gain switch
Cons:

No remote control
Not as powerful as some other preamps
Can be noisy at high volumes
Overall, the AIYIMA Tube T3 is a great option for anyone looking for a high-quality, affordable phono preamp. It features a warm, rich sound that is perfect for listening to vinyl records. The preamp is also very easy to use, with just a few simple controls. If you are looking for a great way to improve the sound of your vinyl records, the AIYIMA Tube T3 is a great option.

title: BEWARE; Spyware companion App
text:
***DO NOT install the software*** this product comes with companion software that is dangerous.
Even if the manufacture is not involved, they are the target.

Picture Attached: hours after installing the app on my phone my account access was attempted. in addition I began getting spam calls. (Coincidence?) nope... I do computers for a living.

Your kids may install this. Elderly may install this. Make sure you are the only admin on your computer.

Instructions (which you need a microscope to read) are to install well known out of date .Net vulnerabilities, then further install their vulnerable software.
NEVER install ANYTHING With Admin rights.
Clearly if this was a clean respectable app it would be on Microsoft store and signed certified.
If it can't be found on MS store its probably not safe for average users.

Immediately after install this app will reach out to the internet and/or ask to 'update'.
Your virus software will NOT detect this because : 1. you've told your virus soft that its ok you are the admin, and 2. it uses update services on the back end to mask, not just load a browser page, as most browsers will likely block it. depending on your windows system it might not even tell you its doing this in backend. as the old .Net framework has holes.

Same for the Android App. they all request permissions that will capture your info.
pic above is from an attempt to enter one of my accounts.

Again; Even if the manufacture is not involved, they are the target.
Manufacture needs to use safe design software. Its all over their software review page. Android play store already addressed them, now they have two apps out there.

Obviously this can't be done easily on Apple devices, therefore they don't support.

Common Sense! Their app asks for Camera permissions. This IS a camera; they don't need to utilize other cameras. And No; its not part of the software stack that you must ask for permissions in bundles this is a misnomer, and is common for developers who use templates and 3PL to develop. Plus they sell all your info when you dev this way.

title: Decent KVM
text:
Let me start by saying I'm picky with KVMs and I have been through a few. This one is replacing another unit from another manufacturer which has intensely bright indicator lights.
This box is very small and compact for supporting 4 USB and 4 computers. It feels solid with all metal casing. The buttons are not the best, but do operate well. The connections in the back are good for tucking away wires and avoiding clutter. The USB ports are in the front making them accessible. This works for me because my mouse and keyboard are using a remote dongle. If you are using a wired mouse/keyboard, be aware the cords will come out of the front.
I love that the external power is included but not required. A different KVM I owned required power to maintain video signal, this one does not. That is one less cable to clutter my area.
The connections to the PCs are made with separate USB-A and HDMI cables. For me, this was a disappointment because my pre-existing unit had USB-B connector /HDMI combo which won't work with this unit. I'll need to rerun the wires. The USB cables are included, which is good. However, the HDMI cables are not so you'll need to buy them separately if you don't have any laying around.
Switching is easy. You can either use the front panel buttons to select the PC you want or you can use the tethered remote. There is no keyboard key-combo to switch between PCs. This was also a disappointment compared to my prior KVM as I must now reach for another device with a wire on my desk to switch. Also, note that with a MAC I have a slight problem. Each time I switch back to my mac, it detects a new keyboard and prompts me to press keys to identify the "new" keyboard. The Mac doesn't remember the keyboard when you switch away and back. You can click through the notice, but it is annoying.
I'm happy to say the lights are not that intense. They are just enough to see the unit has power and which PC is selected. It won't light a room ;).
Compact, easy to use, and durable. Definitely a good purchase that would be better with MAC compatibility and keyboard switching.

title: Lowers analog volume nicely without messing with the sound
text:
I like this thing. I wanted an analog volume control knob on my desk that wasn't going to wreck the sound and that's what I got.

It's just a 50K pot on a board with two 3.5mm jacks which is exactly what I was looking for.

The pot is detented with 50 clicks. I wish it was smooth instead but it's pretty cheap so the notches probably help hide any roughness.

The pot's shaft is a 6mm diameter split shaft that protrudes a good 0.5in (12.7mm) so just about any aftermarket knob will work.

The stock knob is an aluminum shell with a plastic insert, not solid aluminum. It doesn't feel good with the stock knob and is too lightweight to stay put very well even with the included silicone grip tape.

I changed the knob for a 44mm diameter solid aluminum knob and it feels so much better. The extra weight helps keep it in place and smooths out the pot's actuation. 44mm is close but still slightly smaller than the original knob so if you want a flush fit you want ~48mm diameter knob.

My setup is PC headphone jack --> Nobsound volume control --> Tin T3 Plus IEMs at 32ohms.

The front panel audio header that goes to the headphone jack I'm using runs through some kind of op-amps. The motherboard is a Gigabyte ab350-m d3sh and I have no clue how much power it's putting out but it's more than line level and sounds clearer.

I tested it at the Nobsound's max volume (where the resistance should be 0 ohms) with my normal Windows volume settings and couldn't tell any difference compared to the IEMs plugged straight in to the same headphone jack.

Things still sound good as the volume comes down (and resistance increases) but get warmer I think. That could also be placebo. There is some channel imbalance when you raise the volume quickly but it seems to even out after you stop turning the knob. Still no audible noise in my setup as the volume comes down.

With Windows' volume turned to 100, I stay in the upper quarter of the range and have about 6 clicks I jump around in.

title: A decent RGB Microphone
text:
[[VIDEOID:ff63fbdc0661651dc0912d55bc3a690c]] The stand is made of three parts that screw together, the weight and size of it make knocking the microphone over a non-issue. At the bottom of the microphone is an RGB lighting ring, there are 6 different lighting effects (or you can turn off the lights), some of which are variations of the same effect at a different speed. You cannot control the color of the effects, but the inclusion is cool and requires no software to run. The microphone is made of some sort of alloy with the controls being on a plastic extrusion. The built-in pop filter works very well, but the orange color may be off-putting to some.

The built-in voice effects are very cool and are fun to mess around with in calls. The noise reduction does not do much in my case, My computer fans are not picked up normally by the microphone, and even with the reduction on my keyboard and mouse are audible. The knob on the microphone will control the levels for the microphone, headphones, or echo effect depending on what color the MVE button is on. The knob has sharp indents that make using it easy and satisfying. Pushing the knob in will switch the mic from cardioid to omnidirectional with the RGB ring communicating what mode it’s in by changing color. Muting the mic will leave the RGB ring permanently red regardless of whether or not you left the ring on.

The microphone sounds alright and looks good, I have another microphone that sounds better, but looks unassuming and lacks features (at the same price point). I have uploaded a quick sound check using this microphone in Cardioid mode, omnidirectional sounds the same save for the fact that you can speak from any angle.

Pros:
Good quality monitor output
USB-C
Decently clean audio
The color-coded MVE switch is a cool idea (Mic.-Vol.-Echo)
Can shift between omnidirectional and cardioid pickup pattern

Cons:
RGB effects are limited
Some of the controls take getting used to
The included stand doesn’t tilt
You must be very close to the microphone to get the best sound

title: Easy to use, simple to attach and easy to adjust
text:
[[VIDEOID:da830c169b8ed604708aae35fe0d439c]] Today I'm reviewing this set of variable ND filters in the 67mm size by K&F concept,

I have them right here in front of me. We'll break the seal so we can take a look. We'll remove the plastic, and we have two filters. The first one is 2-32, and the second is 32-512. Let's see how these boxes open. There is a magnet here on the side. Now it opens it.

A nice piece of vellum with the company logo, then a nice carrying case for the ND filter. We also have a little ad in the bottom. I'm opening up the carrying case and inside, inside a plastic bag is the ND filter. As you can see, we have the ND filter. I'm going to connect this to my DSLR, and we'll see how well these work.

What we're looking at now is some video from my DSLR. This is with no cover on the lens at all, it is a bright sunny day what we'll do now is switch over to the 2-32 ND filter. As you can see immediately at the 2 the colors look better. Now I'm adjusting this to the 32. I did not adjust anything on the camera. No f-stop or ISO changes, just twisting the adjustable ND filter. You can easily see the difference from the bright sunny day, then from the 2 to the 32. Next, we will swap on the 32-512. Right now, as you can see the 32 looks the same, and we're going to slowly ratchet this up and as you can see things are getting darker and darker. Until pretty quickly it is blocking all of the light. Without adjusting ISO or aperture on my camera which is why it blacked out.

These seem to be smooth on how they come on, I've got no complaints. They seem like high quality and are very clear, I'm not seeing any banding on these.

I'm rating five out of five stars.

Pros
- Smooth transistions as you turn the ND up
- No banding or abberations

Cons
- Nothing yet

title: Spectacular! Here's a shout out to 12x50 binoculars!
text:
Here's a shout out to the 12x50 binoculars! As other customer reviews have said, the clarity, brightness, field of view, chromatic aberration and ergonomics are incredible. Deesoo's binoculars are very ergonomically designed, from the shape of the barrel and the position of the focus knob to the well-constructed adjustable eyecups. These binoculars are compact and feel great in the hand, not too heavy or too small. The extra case and strap were well thought out. The 12x Deesoo Professional Birding Binoculars have a wider field of view than my 10x Leupold BX-2 binoculars. It is a dazzling display of color, clarity, light and nature like I have never seen before.

I purchased these binoculars to take with me when I go wildlife watching. My favorite part of observing wildlife is sitting in a peaceful forest and observing the animals around me. These binoculars keep me entertained throughout the day and allow me to get up close and personal with the animals and Mother Nature. I am not an optics expert, but these binoculars provide very clear and sharp images that allow me to easily focus on things like birds and deer and see these objects in great detail from 300 yards away.

I'm nearsighted and wear glasses. I can use these binoculars with my glasses on and with my glasses off. With glasses on, simply turning the adjustment of the rear eyecup clockwise provides a nice wide field of view. I was pleasantly surprised to find that I could also use these binoculars with my glasses off. I simply adjust the rear eyecup counterclockwise and then adjust the center focal length to compensate for my poor vision with my glasses off. I was able to clearly see 300-400 yards away without my glasses, just using these binoculars!

I also tried the included phone adapter that comes with the binoculars on my Samsung Ultra S21 phone. It was easy to set up and user friendly. To get a rectangular image, I just set the phone's zoom to 2x. I've attached photos with these settings in the comments. I'm sure I could have mounted it on a tripod with binoculars that include a tripod mount and it would have been much clearer.

Great value for the money!

title: People Can See My Clutter. Field of View is Too Wide.
text:
As other earlier reviews mentioned, that this j5create 1080P HD Webcam is great quality. Even in dim lighting, the video quality is excellent.

PROS:

- The way it firmly holds on to my monitor is impressive.

- Additionally, the cable is long enough so that I can run it beneath my desk without using an extension.

- Both the manual focus and the auto focus are excellent.

- The microphone works very well.

- Another nice touch is the privacy shutter.

- When I plugged it into my computer's USB port, it recognized it right away.

- It's also convenient that you can flip the camera down to examine a document; you can eliminate the need to flip the page over by just pushing and holding the red button for a few seconds.

CONS
- However, the field of view, though, is just too wide for me. Too much of my office is visible. I've spent a lot of time arranging my bookshelves behind me to be meeting-ready. However, this camera captures a lot more of my office than I want to show. Even at the 4 x 3 setting the cam angle is still much too wide.

Bottom Line(s)
This camera, in my opinion, would be excellent for an office meeting when several individuals needed to be recorded. It would also be great when the family wishes to connect with grandma and grandpa online. The whole family can enter the frame.

However, while I'm sitting in my chair doing a one-on-one meeting, this webcam has a way too wide a field of view and reveals all my clutter.

I'm aware that most web conferencing software has a backdrop blur function, however unless you have a green screen, the blur doesn't seem particularly professional. And, because I don't have a green screen behind me, I won't be using this camera at my home office until I do.

To be clear, this is not a camera fault. I'm sure it was designed with such a wide field of view in mind. I only wish the field of view was mentioned in the product description.

title: Supports Samsung Super Fast Charging
text:
In order to charge my phone in my neoprene phone pouch (sized to fit both my Samsung Galaxy 22+ phone and my Anker Powercore Slim 10000 PD) I wanted to have a cable that would support the Samsung Fast Charging (but not Super Fast Charging) that this external battery supports.
Eventually some company will make a similar, phone-size/phone-shape slim charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, but we're not there yet.
So as to fit neatly in the phone pouch, I wanted a cable with right-angle USB-C male plugs on both ends.
I found three here on amazon, but couldn't figured which would be best. So I ordered all three to do some comparison testing to report for all three cables.
Here are the three I bought, with my analysis of each.
zdyCGTTime: The cable is short (~20 cm/7" between the centers of the two plugs). The cable itself is thick and stiff and doesn't bend well. When plugged into a wall charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, the cable also supports it. However, I found that the USB-C male plug would lose the connection with my phone when it was jiggled so I discarded this as an option.
AAOTOKK: this superficially looks similar to the zdyCGTTime cable, but longer (~32 cm/12.5" between the centers of the two plugs). Like the zdyCGTTime, the cable is thick and stiff and supports Super Fast Charging. Unlike that zdyCGTTime, the plug fits securely in the phone's USB-C socket and no amount of wiggling causes it to lose contact. It supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, and even if the longer cable is heavier and bulkier, the length allows it to lie next to the phone/external battery so fits better into the pouch. If my external battery supported Super Fast Charging this would be my choice.
KOOWOD: like the AAOTOKK, this cable is longer, but the cable is thinner, lighter and much more flexible, bends easily and sits happily in my phone pouch next to my phone and external batter. It does NOT support Samsung Super Fast Charging, though it does support Samsung Fast Charging. But since my external battery only supports Fast Charging, I am using this cable.

title: Convenient, strong magnetic coupling
text:
Being a fan of Apple's MagSafe connector, I grabbed these in the hope of finding some good applications around the house. Gadgets are increasingly powered by USB chargers these days, and the ports can often be fiddly to hookup if done in a dark or in a hard to see location.

So far I'm having success in only a couple limited scenarios. The port adapters are 8mm in diameter, and 3mm thick on the back of the USB male piece. My iPad Pro is 6mm in thickness, and if it weren't for the low-profile case I'm using, the adapter would stick out 1mm beyond the front and back surfaces. Certain device cases may not allow you to fit the adapter so that the USB connector can fully slide into the port. Thankfully, it works for my iPad, but it doesn't work well on my iPhone since the case has an attached waterproof port cover.

The only other device I've found around my house where it's a good match is a USB desk fan. Note, you can't pass data using this cable and because of the small size of the adapter you probably won't want to be constantly taking it in and out. Therefore, it limits the utility quite a bit depending on your stable of devices.

Other observations:
- The magnetic cables clip on and off pretty easily. The magnets are strong for their size, so good win.
- The pack comes with 3 plastic organizers that clip onto cables to hold the adapters. These are fiddly to load adapters into, and the cable magnets are not quite strong enough to reliably pull them out. This is useless to me, and they will go in the garbage.
- Because the port connectors are quite small, you may find that it's challenging to pry them out of ports once seated. I had to use a letter opener to get one out, but it might've required pliers in a less accessible scenario. It's best to leave the adapters in devices where you plan to always use these cables.
- The cables are pliable and the braided jackets are nice. Lots of length options, so nice for the gadgets where you might use them.
- The max charge rate is pretty low, so don't expect to quickly fill those modern USB-C devices.

title: Very Heavy; some nice details
text:
Was very curious if and how a “multi-model” case would fit. - Used this on an 2020 iPad Air, 4th Gen (A2316). Item came in a very fancy box with all whistles and bells, way too much for a simple keyboard.

* FIT *:
- all cutouts fit the iPad well; some strange little extra lip on one of the speakers, each side, but not dramatic enough to obstruct
- TPC is soft and very heavy, back has extra honeycomb layer for support? and/or air flow; iPad was easily to place into the case but seemed to fit solidly
- The PENCIL fits well; holder is on the wrong side, it will not be charged w the Air/Pro magnetic charger; nevertheless a grove on the magnetic charge holds the pencil well, and lets it charge
- The keyboard sits loosely on one side of the cover; to use it, one will always have to take it off its magnet and move the keyboard in order for the iPad to stand up in the case’ provided grooves.

* KEYBOARD *:
- The keyboard is light and ha all the function keys needed - it is covered with a very thin silicone skin, I assume to protect keys from spillage - I liked it a lot and kept it on the keyboard while typing. It softens the keystrokes a little, which I like.
- The magnetic bond to the iPad case is a little weak, and it slipped a couple of times.
- I did not encounter any Bluetooth (dis)connection issues during the time I used it.
- At the time I cannot speak to the battery life; the charging is via Micro-USB, a cable only is provided.

SUMMARY:
OK fit, seems to work for multi-format; good keyboard but weak magnetic mount. The final negative is the weight, it is over 675g, heavier than the iPads it is to augment. Would give it a 3.5/5 if I could.
(MY RATE SCALE: 5=perfect; 4=minor imperfections; 3=likely wouldn’t buy again; 2= too many problems; 1= shouldn’t be sold or dangerous)

title: Ideal for data recovery, less so for long-term home use
text:
[[VIDEOID:d4aa162c7e7b059e3d0e9be2a0423526]] SETMSPACE offers an affordable casing for your wayward SSD or HDD. It's very straightforwards - there's no gimmicks or doohickys or readouts, whether you like those or not. One port, for power and data, a black casing, that's it. Oh, and these little felt sticky pads which, I think are meant to cushion the inside? but I'm not sure as no instruction's given for them. They don't belong on the outside.

If you're running an SSD this should fill your needs nicely. They've no spinning platters inside so they're a teensie bit less fragile and they make for totally silent running. There's no indicator light so you won't know it's plugged in until your computer tells you; this can be an extra step for troubleshooting but for the most part shouldn't be.

What I like best about it: It opens easily and drives pop in and out without difficulty. Some external cases are very reluctant to give up their drives, or aren't ever meant to. I don't like those, it makes them impractical in the long term and especially for data recovery. This is perfect for data recovery because of how compact and easy it is; the (short) cable length and light case means you could carry it empty in a small computer tool kit if that's your job (like what I'm aiming for!). USB ubiquity also helps this, and it works on OpenSUSE Linux too (tested with version 15.4).

But its strengths are also its weaknesses. The cable length (you can see in my photo, it's like as long as my thigh?) means, it's not going very far. The casing likely won't open by accident (not designed that way) but it didn't impress me with how durable it 'sounded'. Not terribly thick, closer to frangible plastic rather than something that can absorb shock or bounce it away or whatevers. For data rescue this isn't as much a problem, as drives it host, it only hosts temporarily. But for long term storage, I'd want something with better durability and maybe better cooling too - plastic isn't going to help much there and there's no room for a drive to breath inside.

title: Strong duster that functions better than any compressed air can
text: To clean out my handheld Shark vacuum, I purchased this. I take remove the filter from my hand vacuum and clean it every time I clean the dirt trap (or catch chamber, as you can refer to the area where all the dirt is collected). This procedure helps the vacuum last longer. I had been using compressed air cans, and they were great. But I went through a lot of them, and I wasn't happy about the ongoing expense and damaging consequences on the environment. I researched a ton of reviews for several compressed air dusters before choosing this one. I put it in with my saved for later items til I could afford it, and then it came up with a deal on the price (think it was one of those "Lightning Deals" but can't remember for sure), and so I bought it.
