I'm glad i did cuz i really like it. I love that its chargable and doesn't have to be plugged in. It's pretty powerful... maybe about 85% of what the compressed air cans can acheive. I use this everytime i clean out the vac and filter, and then i keep one can of compressed air around to do a deeper clean about every tenth time or so. Now one can of compressed air will last probably a good 6 months, instead of a week or 2. The charge lasts a good length of time cuz I haven't even had to recharge it yet and I've used it about 7 or 8 times so far. I use this every time I clean the vacuum and filter, and I also keep a can of pressurized air nearby to use every tenth or so to conduct a deeper clean. Today, instead of lasting a week or two, a can of compressed air will likely last a good six months. I've used it around seven or eight times so far and haven't even needed to recharge it, proving that the charge lasts for quite some time. Apart than not having quite as much power as the cans, the only negative aspect is how loud it is. I live in an apartment complex, and I won't use it in the early morning or late at night since it's simply too upsetting. Yet since it doesn't bother me in the middle of the day, I do it. Overall, I'm very happy I acquired it. In the long term, it will cost me less money and have a less environmental impact. Oh, and it works great for drying stuff as well. Recommended ✅

title: Worked great on my RV
text: I ordered this on a weekend. Then I called Waveform tech support on Monday. Tech Support was very helpful. I was told that this antenna mount was actually made for the eve of a home. But I elected to use it on my motorhome. I mounted the antenna right behind my AC unit so it was shielded from wind as I drive. I did use a bungee cord as a secondary hold down to measure for safety. Because of the panel design, the antenna will pick up a wide range of directionality yet because it’s not Omni directional it will increase signal to noise ratio by eliminating noise from the 180° direction  behind the antenna. I told Tech Support that I had two primary goals. The first goal was to receive cell signals when camping rurally in my RV when cell signals were not very strong and bandwidth was poor. I was currently in Senator Wash Az, about 60 miles south of Quartzsite Az. My second goal was to be able to drive and utilize the antenna if needed. Tech Support said the driving factor would be best served by an Omni directional antenna, but the first goal would not be served well by the Omni directional antenna due to no gain factor. The flat panel antenna increases signal to noise ratio and this gives a gain which improves cell signal and bandwidth. So when I received the antenna, before actually mounting it to the roof I mocked up the installation temporarily and did some testing. The panel antenna did improve my signal and bandwidth. I used Speedtest by Ookla to make comparisons. My AT&T MR 1100 Netgear hotspot tested at about 25 Mb per second download speed with no antenna attached. With the Waveform panel antenna attached and pointed in the correct direction. My bandwidth went up to 49 Mb per second. Quite an improvement out in the boonies. As a second test, I wanted to see if I can drive with the antenna down and still receive a decent signal. So I lowered the antenna mast with the panel pointing straight upward from the roof. I thought this upward direction might receive a signal omni-directionally. I then used SpeedTest again and still had 25mbps. That’s doable for me. With 80 to 85% of my driving being on highways and in town, my bandwidth should be much greater most of the time. And when rural, I should still have an OK signal while driving most of the time. I highly recommend Waveform for their excellent products and Tech Support.

title: Amazing!!!! ♥️Love♥️Love♥️Love♥️
text:
Took me months to decide which keyboard I wanted and I’m glad I finally just picked this one. I had a Microsoft keyboard many many years ago and it was stolen. I’ve been salty ever since. I paid triple the cost for that than I paid for this particular one.

First, let’s talk about the low profile keys. They make typing so smooth and effortless. I love it.

Secondly, the connection is awesome. I have not had any delays. I type about 65-70 wpm and my old keyboard was slow and laggy. I would often times get frustrated because I would have to go back and correct my words because it couldn’t keep up. Nope no longer have this issue. Love it!!

Thirdly, the trackball. Wow! I have never used a track ball before and prior to ordering I kept comparing it to the mouse pad on a laptop. Which I absolutely hate so I always had a mouse to hook up to the laptop or tablets. I just figured i would continue to use a standard mouse if I didn’t like it. The first day it was very ackward and I found myself reaching for the mouse. The second day I decided to put my mouse away and forced myself to try the trackball and finally figured out the best technique is to use my left hand for the button and my right hand on the ball. Ummmmm yea I now know I never ever want to go back to using a standard mouse. Oh yea and the biggest issue I had which I saw in other reviews was the speed and that was easy to correct by turning the pointer speed way down which made my life so much easier. Love it!!

Lastly, the design. The slight curve it has in the middle. I wish it had more of a higher curve but that’s okay. Love it.

I’ll end this review for now. If anything changes I will update the review. As for now I am so in love with this keyboard. If your on the fence about it I say don’t wait any longer just buy it. What do you have to lose?? You can always return it. And Amazon has made returning products so easy that I am not afraid to buy things knowing it can be returnable.

title: Worked great on my RV
text: I ordered this on a weekend. Then I called Waveform tech support on Monday. Tech Support was very helpful. I was told that this antenna mount was actually made for the eve of a home. But I elected to use it on my motorhome. I mounted the antenna right behind my AC unit so it was shielded from wind as I drive. I did use a bungee cord as a secondary hold down to measure for safety. Because of the panel design, the antenna will pick up a wide range of directionality yet because it’s not Omni directional it will increase signal to noise ratio by eliminating noise from the 180° direction  behind the antenna. I told Tech Support that I had two primary goals. The first goal was to receive cell signals when camping rurally in my RV when cell signals were not very strong and bandwidth was poor. I was currently in Senator Wash Az, about 60 miles south of Quartzsite Az. My second goal was to be able to drive and utilize the antenna if needed. Tech Support said the driving factor would be best served by an Omni directional antenna, but the first goal would not be served well by the Omni directional antenna due to no gain factor. The flat panel antenna increases signal to noise ratio and this gives a gain which improves cell signal and bandwidth. So when I received the antenna, before actually mounting it to the roof I mocked up the installation temporarily and did some testing. The panel antenna did improve my signal and bandwidth. I used Speedtest by Ookla to make comparisons. My AT&T MR 1100 Netgear hotspot tested at about 25 Mb per second download speed with no antenna attached. With the Waveform panel antenna attached and pointed in the correct direction. My bandwidth went up to 49 Mb per second. Quite an improvement out in the boonies. As a second test, I wanted to see if I can drive with the antenna down and still receive a decent signal. So I lowered the antenna mast with the panel pointing straight upward from the roof. I thought this upward direction might receive a signal omni-directionally. I then used SpeedTest again and still had 25mbps. That’s doable for me. With 80 to 85% of my driving being on highways and in town, my bandwidth should be much greater most of the time. And when rural, I should still have an OK signal while driving most of the time. I highly recommend Waveform for their excellent products and Tech Support.

title: Incredible sound for a mini portable - Excellent reception
text:
ZWS-700
I am an avid SWL and ham radio operator, and own multiple, high dollar, receivers. This thing holds its own against my Eton Executive portable for sensitivity and it is much better in sound quality. The first few hours I was using this I had to keep looking over at it, the 700’s sound seemed like it should be coming out of a much larger radio. A super feature on the audio is that they reduced annoying static (via digital processing) to mostly a soft hiss, all the while maintaining great audio fidelity.

Good points:
- Easily understandable, low noise sound, even on weak AM stations. That would be from good good DSP audio processing.
- Uses a low cost BL-5C type rechargeable battery. You can obtain spares for around $5 each. If you are concerned with battery life, keep a ‘charged up’ spare handy.
- I like that you can lay it flat on its back or sides without worrying about accidentally changing any settings.
- The antenna is only 11 inches tall but performs as well on FM and Weather Band as my portables with 20 inch+ antennas.
- For the SW bands, an external wire antenna is a must in most cases. This little kit has included an external, clip on, wire antenna.
- USB type-C charging port. No need to worry about accidentally breaking something by inserting the charging cable in upside down.
- If you need to switch out a battery, the memories will stay in tact.
- ‘Power on’ starts with your last frequency selection.

Points to consider:
- The ZWS-700 can do an ‘auto scan’ and fill its limited number of memory banks. There is no way (that I have found) to manually add or remove a frequency from those banks.
- The ‘analog’ tuning dial works well on AM and FM broadcast bands, on SW you can hear a slight audio shift as it switches through the channels.
- The controls are rather small, it is a tiny radio after all.

My thoughts:
I was worried about spending too much money on a radio this small. I do now love this thing :)

Enjoy

title: Another great gimbal from DJI
text:
The DJI RS3 Mini is pretty self-explanatory - it's a much smaller version of the RS3. I have been using the RS3 for a while and coming from another brand, DJI's smoothing algorithms are definitely part of the reason why they are a market leader in the gimbal space.

Size:
Compared to the RS3, this is a lot smaller, and it's nice and light. The handle is much smaller, and is definitely only big enough for one hand. Similar to the RS3, it brings over the small touch screen, joystick, mode button, and record button. There is no mode selector slider on this one though, and the scroll wheel is positioned a bit differently, and doesn't feel quite as nice.

Features:
On the left side of the gimbal, you get one single NATO rail to attach accessories. I tried out a smallrig handle that I use on the RS3, and it worked fine, but I wish that you got two nato rails instead of just one. Unlike the full size RS3, you only get one USB C port on the camera arm, instead of the three. You won't be using the focus puller on this tiny gimbal anyway, so that's not a huge deal. I like to use my cameras wired into the gimbal, and that's no problem with my R6.

Weight:
For payload, the RS3 mini has a massive 4.4lb capability, which is enough for a lot of camera options. I've used it with my gopro and my friend used it with his sony mirrorless and it works great! As for the weight of the assembly, it's significantly lighter than its bigger brother. See pictures for weight comparison

There are a couple of other things it's missing, such as the removable battery to dismount for travel, but it's pretty small as is, so not a huge deal. It's also missing the auto-lock and unlock, but that's just a convenience thing, and it still has locks, which is something I'd consider a necessity nowadays.

If you're looking for a high-quality gimbal coming in at low weight, with high load, and high-quality materials, this is a great option.

title: Excellent Wireless CarPlay Device!
text:
This is an excellent device if you are seeking to add wireless (or wired) CarPlay. It also works with Android Auto, but this is installed in my wife's vehicle so I haven't tried using it for that yet. I'm going to break down the pros and cons below:

Pros
1) Excellent sound quality using Aux port and FM transmitter
2) Bright display that can be dimmed for night driving
3) Extremely easy to use
4) Excellent suction mount with an easy install (under 15 minutes to get paired up and everything working properly)
5) When using the FM transmitter, the device has excellent call quality
6) The device powers up immediately and reconnects to the phone with no issues

Cons
1) The included mic is terrible, but the one built in the device is fantastic when using FM
2) FM transmission does require there to be open channels near your location which can be an issue in more urban areas
3) The swiping detection is a little slow
4) The power supply includes two USB ports to plug in other cords, but I would have liked to see a USB-c port instead of two regular USB ports
5) If your car does not turn off power to your 9v when you turn it off, you will have to unplug it every time. Thankfully my wife's car does turn off, so it wasn't an issue.

This is an excellent device with just some minor flaws that do not warrant removing 1 star in my opinion. I would have given this device 9/10 for these few flaws. If we lived somewhere difficult to use the FM transmitter, it would be 4/5 stars.

I would also like to add that it would be awesome if the manufacturer created a model of this device that included a dash camera so that it could be multipurpose.

If you are looking to update a vehicle with a wireless CarPlay experience, this is the way to go! We contemplated putting in the new stereo system, but this is a much cheaper option! It is definitely better if the car has an aux port or you live in an area with a few open FM stations, so make sure you can do one or the other before purchasing.

title: A very comfortable & secure headset for jogging & or cycling!
text:
So, let me start by saying that if you're buying this headset mostly for its sound purity, quality and or loudness, then you may want to look elsewhere. But if you're into outdoor sports (jogging, cycling, swimming, etc.) then this is surely worth considering. I use mine mostly when I go jogging as it's very light, secure and comfortable to wear with decent sound and still able to hear the background traffic. I've even paired it to my tv so that I can watch a show without waking up my wife & so that's another plus.

That said, let's start with sound quality which is very good but not great. It does have a HiFi stereo surround sound with decent bass but you can't control the amount of bass/treble or at least I couldn't figure it out. it can't also get too loud but then again no open-ear set will sound like an ear bud so you can't hold this against it either.

As far as control goes, this really has some getting used to. The small buttons aren't that easy to distinguish from each other so at first I often pressed the wrong ones but now I'm getting a little better at it and besides I learned not to mess with it too much but when you still have to press the button to answer a call.

Battery life is probably one of the best feature on this headset. In the short time that I've had this, I only charged it once and I have yet to recharge it again but then again, I'm not sure how much charge is left on it as it doesn't have an indicator to tell you anything about the strength of the battery.

As far as features, this headset comes with everything you may want in a bone-conductor type headset, starting with a good sound, sturdy (quality) frame, water-proof design, HiFi stereo, great battery life with noise reduction among others. One other cool feature is an inclusion of a 32 GB storage built-into the headset which you can load up with music and not having to take your phone along with you.

Overall, this is a very good headset especially for outdoor sports & importantly it doesn't come with a price tag of a Shokz headset but it comes with features that's important at this price-point.

title: Made him the popular brother in the house. And so many prints everywhere !
text:
This little camera has been the biggest hit amongst all of our kids. The fact that it prints as soon as you take the picture, and so quickly makes it a blast! We have literally hundreds of pictures all over the house right now of absolutely everything. The camera comes with 3 rolls of paper, each seems to get about 75 pictures I think it is?
The thing here is that the camera has "achievements " that you need to watch out for. You get awards (nothing physical, just on the camera) for 20, 50,100 etc pictures taken so...that uses paper quickly if they're watching that.
The picture quality can actual vary. As seen in my first, peace tea pic, I took a picture using grayscale printing and another using dot printing. Dot seems overall much clearer and is our new default for any pictures.
The dog pic, id taken a pic that printed, then printed the same picture from the memory card. Memory card print semes.to have printed just a tad more blurry than the instant pic. Not sure why this would be but the results are pictured here.
Easy to load with paper,and I grabbed some small credit card machine thermal receipt paper that we will try in it once he gets back from his other parent's place. I figure we may have to reroll some of it as it may be a bit too thick of a roll but not an issue. Width side SEEMS that it should be correct. I will try to update once we try the rubber casing on this one covers the charging port just a little as well as memory card slot. Slot isn't bad but the charging port is a bit annoying.
Sleeve stays on well but is removable as well if needed. Silicone I believe so holds shape and should be relatively durable.
Image quality on a computer varies a lot by light. A good, well lit image actually looks pretty decent on a 15" laptop screen running at a 4k resolution. Lower light or too bright not so good. Low light gets grainy fast and too bright oversaturates as well.
But it's a kids camera. A cheap, instant print camera. And it's hard NOT to recommend with the experiences we've already had with it. Even if never replacing the paper, but that really IS a huge part of the fun.

title: Nice bag.  Quality shell with well-thought compartments
text:
I'm planning to use this on a family vacation where I will wear it all day.
I LOVE the shell of this pack. It is a tight-woven nylon. Most pockets have rain-covered zippers.
With the exception of the small front one and the back one, all are lined with a tan liner so you can see inside to find your stuff.
This pack has a mirid of compartments -
- Main PC pocket is divided with a strap for the laptop and about 3" of additional depth. Ther is a hidden zipper pocket inside.
- 2nd pocket includes a small divided zipper space for cash and thumb drives and such. There is a bright orange 8" strap for your keys with a metal clip.
- 3rd pocket is on the outside and about 8x10" with the 4th below it on the outside about 8x5"
- the 5th is an on-the-back document pocket - so no one can open and steal your travel docs while you are in line.
Straps are padded with vented facing. The adjusters have a double-lock, to prevent the straps from sliding when the pack is well loaded.
The chest strap is adjustable, sliding up and down. Ther are side straps to tension the main compartment for less-than full loads. There are a pair of straps on the bottom for an umbrella or a mono/tripod. 2 Water bottle pockets on the sides.
I unloaded my "normal" 15" laptop bag and moved the contents over. That's 2 HP thin laptops, 2 Amazon 10" tablets, power supplies, USB chargers and cables, misc. "Stuff". All fit except the neoprene sleeve that the HP's usually call home. This bag is a bit narrower, but not by much. Overall, it works well. I'll use it loaded for a week or so prior to my trip to break it in and see how the straps adjust to my shoulders.
The only real drawbacks I see is that the 2nd outside pocket does not have a rain shield and the grab handle on the top is not up to par for this bag. I do wish there was a little more padding for the PC and especially for my back. My old "daytripper" bag has as much back padding as the straps of this one have.

title: Supports Samsung Super Fast Charging
text:
In order to charge my phone in my neoprene phone pouch (sized to fit both my Samsung Galaxy 22+ phone and my Anker Powercore Slim 10000 PD) I wanted to have a cable that would support the Samsung Fast Charging (but not Super Fast Charging) that this external battery supports.
Eventually some company will make a similar, phone-size/phone-shape slim charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, but we're not there yet.
So as to fit neatly in the phone pouch, I wanted a cable with right-angle USB-C male plugs on both ends.
I found three here on amazon, but couldn't figured which would be best. So I ordered all three to do some comparison testing to report for all three cables.
Here are the three I bought, with my analysis of each.
zdyCGTTime: The cable is short (~20 cm/7" between the centers of the two plugs). The cable itself is thick and stiff and doesn't bend well. When plugged into a wall charger that supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, the cable also supports it. However, I found that the USB-C male plug would lose the connection with my phone when it was jiggled so I discarded this as an option.
AAOTOKK: this superficially looks similar to the zdyCGTTime cable, but longer (~32 cm/12.5" between the centers of the two plugs). Like the zdyCGTTime, the cable is thick and stiff and supports Super Fast Charging. Unlike that zdyCGTTime, the plug fits securely in the phone's USB-C socket and no amount of wiggling causes it to lose contact. It supports Samsung Super Fast Charging, and even if the longer cable is heavier and bulkier, the length allows it to lie next to the phone/external battery so fits better into the pouch. If my external battery supported Super Fast Charging this would be my choice.
KOOWOD: like the AAOTOKK, this cable is longer, but the cable is thinner, lighter and much more flexible, bends easily and sits happily in my phone pouch next to my phone and external batter. It does NOT support Samsung Super Fast Charging, though it does support Samsung Fast Charging. But since my external battery only supports Fast Charging, I am using this cable.

title: Blends with Decor
text: This is review of Amcrest 4mp Wifi Camera Indoor.  Included in the box is the PTZ camera, power adapter/charger, charger cable, mounting clip, mounting screws, and instructions.  Nice to have power adapter included, as most only include a cable.  The camera unit is egg-shaped and is made for sitting on a flat surface (ie. table, shelf, etc.), the included mounting clip provides option to mount unit on the ceiling.  The white and black colored unit sort of blends-in with my decor, so it makes the unit less noticeable.  The unit works on 2.4GHz wifi only.  The unit also has a slot for a micro-SD card for video storage (256gb max.), I used a 128gb card with no issues.  There is also the option to pay for a cloud service for video storage.  Followed instructions to setup the camera; downloaded the Amcrest Smart Home App to my smartphone and opened an email account (free) to get it started and followed the App instructions to get it operational.  I also had the Amcrest Viewpro App on my phone already, since I own numerous other Amcrest cameras.  Adding a device through that Ap did not work as smoothly as the Smart Home App.  The QR code scanned from the device needed to have some characters of the serial number deleted in order for the Viewpro App to recognize the character string information.  Features of the unit include human detection and can track the movement of a person.  However, it doesn't outline the person, as I have seen in other cameras, where a tracking square is shown on the tracked subject on the App.  The video quality is good and has nice contrast, little sharper than typical 1080p cameras.  The night vision is average and motion detection worked when person was within 11' of unit.  The two-way audio is good, but there is feedback when I spoke into the smartphone (was about 7' away).  The panning feature of the unit for going left and right was okay, the vertical stuck a little, but got better, as I played with it more.  In regard to value, there are many other PTZ cameras in this price range, so competition is tough.  The lack of an adjustable bracket limits the placement options.  Overall, this unit does what it supposed to do, rated average, 3-stars.

title: Decent headphones for the price
text:
To preface this review, like another reviewer before me, I mistakenly thought these were active noise cancelling headphones - they are not. The only noise cancelling feature they have is the silicone pieces that get shoved into your ear to help block out noise, but even then, I could hear everything going on around me (cars on the street, toilet flushing, talking, etc.). The main purpose of this purchase for me was for the sound cancelling so I will be returning.

As to other functions - music does sound great, I can't fault it there. Very deep and rich sounds especially for a $30 product. Voice doesn't sound as great, when I played my Daily Jay from the Calm App it sounded flat which surprised me because music sounds great on these. I can't speak to the calling features, I haven't had a chance to test them since I'm going to return them.

The actual buds don't fit my ears very well, but I have a small head and small ears and have historically had issues with fit with just about every type of wireless ear buds I've purchased. Left one sits nicely but the right one feels like it's going to fall out, even with the smallest silicone plug.

When the buds initially power on and connect to BT the audio is violently loud. Don't put them in your ears before they connect because you may make a mess in your pants. I imagine the only reason they do this is so you can hear the power on and connect notice when they're out of your ears but god forbid you lose connection while wearing them and they reconnect immediately after. Keep a spare pair of underwear on you just in case.

The touch features on the actual bud work nicely, I didn't have any issues pausing and replaying music. The buds and case seem to made of a cheaper plastic, it feels kind of cheap in your hands and I have concerns about if it would make it through an accidental drop on a hard surface, but honestly, for $30 it's understandable and fair.

Overall, if you're looking for a budget friendly option, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend these with the caveat that all you need is to listen to some quality sound. Don't expect effective active or effective noise cancelling and don't drop it without a case on.

title: Doesn't work with my phone.
text:

title: Was even able to pair it to my android phone
text:
I would not call it ergonomic because it has the same old design I have had that causes problems with my wrists, but it does work well. I was pretty surprised that I could even use it with my phone. It paired very easily and also comes with a USB dongle if you dont have bluetooth.

The keys have a positive feel to them even though they are silent to use.

The dongle can be stored under the keyboard or the mouse and comes in the mouse with a small piece of tape over it so it doesnt come loose in shipping. The keyboard does have little legs on the back to help raise it up a bit.

The keyboard is not entirely laid out like PC keyboards in that some keys, like page up and page down are located in different spots than you may be used to (like next to the enter key instead of the number pad) but I dont know if that is a pro or a con yet.

Weight wise, it is similar to other wireless keyboards that I have and use. For touch typist, there are reference bumps on the F and J keys to help find your positions.

A few oddities that I have noticed. On most keyboards, the 'shift' keys are usually shown with the 'shifted' symbol above the unshifted symbol. Like '<' is over the ','. Most of the keys on this keyboard are like that... but not all of them. For example, on this keyboard there is a key with this '[{'. The shifted symbol '{' is to the right of the unshifted symbol '[', which is a little bit confusing when you look at it. It works just like a normal keyboard, but it is not as obvious when something needs to be shifted or not. Here are the keys like that:
,<
.>
/?
[{
]}

Its a little weird that the rest of the keys are printed like you would expect.

One other thing to note is that there are some grey keys with white lettering on them, like the tab key. It can be hard to read those keys in dim lighting.

title: Neewer overkill is better than uncertainty of other choices
text:
We're in a weird space here... Neewer is really making a name for themselves, putting out products that punch above their weight, for a price that is not as high as the old industry names. But that price IS somewhat higher than a lot of off brand companies they tend to end up on lists with.
So for something like this desk mount, I see it as: Do you go for the somewhat overkill that Neewer provides for this specific product case, or do you press your luck amongst the lower level, uncertain products that are out there in order to save a few bucks.
For me, in this case, I think ponying up is the better choice considering that whatever you mount on this arm is probably expensive, fragile, or most likely both. I just don't want to waste the time finding out by playing with a different product.
Specifically, Neewer offers you a super solid pole made of strong, beefy segments, coupled with high quality, firmly gripping extension couplers. At the top is a nice ball adjusted swivel head. The head screws onto the pole via a standard 1/4x20 screw in the pole, mating to the socket of this head or any other you want to put in its place. The head itself locks easily, and moves easily when you loosen the locking screw.
As pictured, on the side you get an adapter whose name I don't know, but it's designed for the mount that a lot of light boxes and reflectors and production lights come with.
It also comes with a spring loaded phone holder clip. The clip has a 1/4 socket on the back and on one end for mounting options. On the other end, there's a cold shoe.
For me, a product that stands out in the field would get four stars. I need to see a 'wow' in order to give that best of the best five stars. In this case, the fifth star comes in because the wow is due to the opposite end of the competition field. I don't see any old line, flagship company putting out this product in a way that would be substantially any better than what Neewer offers, but it would be a lot more expensive.
So congrats for standing out from the typical competitors. Hearty congratulations for being a better option than the flagships in this case.
~Cheers!

title: Great build but fatal flaws
text:
I was really excited to get this keyboard. TL;DR the unadjustable sleep timer and long delay to wake up make it unusable. Get the Royal Kludge RK98 instead.

Unfortunately it is borderline unusable in wireless 2.4ghz mode, which is the whole reason I chose it. It auto-sleeps after a fairly short period of time and then takes what feels like several seconds to "wake up". It is really disruptive to my workflow as I often spend a lot of time reading and then turn to type out my thoughts. With this keyboard the first few words I type are constantly missed. Apparently, with other Akko 2.4ghz keyboards you can change the sleep time in the app but that is not the case with this model. Another minor factor is that this keyboard has nowhere to stow it's USB dongle so that is guaranteed to get lost if you take it on the go.

I will directly compare it to the Royal Kludge RK98 which is a direct competitor. I have one as my work keyboard. The Akko comes stock with far superior switches and keycaps. Akko switches and caps are the clear winner of the mid-range custom keyboard market. However, the RK98 doesn't go to sleep as quickly and is much faster to wake up. On the rare occasion I do catch it sleeping, I might miss a keystroke or two. Despite a much less aggressive sleep timer, the RK98 also lasts much longer on battery. Often I go weeks at a time without charging it at work. With the Akko, I am charging every few days. Something is obviously burning battery all day despite the keyboard "sleeping" constantly.

The upside is that the build quality is very good. As I said, Akko switches are fantastic in this price range. The keycaps feel substantial and I'm a fan of Akko's key profile. They also look great. The letters are bright and crisp. They stand out with no color bleed where the plastic of the letter meets the plastic of the cap body.

If I just plugged the Akko 3098b and the RK98 in with USB, the Akko is the far superior board out of the box. Sadly, I purchased this board for its 2.4ghz wireless.

I returned it.

title: I love this camera but it has it's limitations - Read how to print from other cameras
text:
First off: I'm happy with this camera. It's a kid's camera that can print in black and white on rolls of thermal paper, which are easy enough to find. I love the look of the dot matrix print outs. They have a cool contrasty look, like some old newspaper picture.
The pictures themselves --not the printed ones but the digital versions, are pretty low quality, but comparable to a similar kid's camera i own. So don't expect "real" camera digital pictures or even ones as good as your phone.
The interface is a little funky, don't throw away the instructions until you have figured everything out. It's not very intuitive so it will require some time with it so you can teach your kid to use it. For example when picking options, it's the one that is greyed out and NOT highlighted that's the choice, which seems counter-intuitive. To delete a picture (not in the instructions) pick the picture and press the "ok" button for a few seconds and then you'll get the option to delete.
All pictures have a date on the side and there doesn't seem to be a way to take this off.
Can you use it to print pictures taken in a different camera? Yes and no. I experimented and it was able to print some pictures but not others. Here's one trick: it seemed to only recognize JPG's with the same file naming convention as the pictures it takes (as in it will accept a picture called "PHO00004.JPG" but not one called "dog.jpg"). And out of those it will only print some. I wasn't able to figure out exactly what it takes to be recognized. It couldn't find pictures taken with my "real" camera but it was able to read ones take with my other kid camera. And because those pictures didn't have the same aspect ratio, it printed them elongated. So when it comes to printing for all practical purposes assume that it will only print the pictures taken with the camera and not other jpg's you load onto the memory card. But that's fine, after all it wasn't advertised for that, though it would have been nice if it did print pictures taken with other cameras.
So overall i'm happy with the camera, but don't expect too much from it. The prints look cool and the paper is cheap to replace, so it's all good.

title: One Travel Router to Rule All Your Devices Wi-Fi Logins On The Go
text:
The GL.iNet MT3000 Beryl AX Pocket Sized Wi-Fi 6 Travel Router is a small and nifty device that packs a lot of features. From the basic Wi-Fi router (dual 2.4/5G bands) to VPN eligible, and even network storage capable.

As of currently (3/14/2023), this is tied as being the company’s newest device lineup (the other being the GL-AXT1800 Slate AX). Between the two, they are similar in being Wi-Fi 6 routers (faster speeds). The Beryl AX does have a higher maximum 5G speed (2402 Mbps) and one 2.5G Gig WAN Port (takes advantage of higher incoming internet speeds through ethernet). It also comes with a plethora of interchangeable international travel plugs, fitting as a travel router (though it can be powered through any USB C cable, such as in a power bank). For higher intensity usage (such as with VPN, etc) the router has a small fan underneath to dissipate heat and reduce temps (for basic usage, it almost never turns on at normal room temperature, plus temp range of activation can be adjusted). Compared to the previous iteration, Beryl MT1300, it does lose one LAN port (unfortunate) and is a bit heavier.

As many others have said, this router packs a lot of features, many of which are beyond what an average user would tap into. But for the basic wireless features, the settings gateway seems clear enough and there are plenty of instructions on how to set things up without too much technical knowledge required.

As for range, though this router isn’t intended to replace a typical home router, it does decent for something this small. On the go, it’ll cover around a hotel room or so.

Overall, I had no problems using the many functions of this router (repeater mode, ethernet mode) at home as well as at hotels I have stayed at.

NOTE: The Beryl AX MT3000 does not support EAP (e.g. EduRoam in many colleges) just like the previous iteration of this series line and denoted in the listings description above, so just be aware if that is one of your intended use cases (and can possibly consider the Slate line instead).

title: If you live for adventure, this is the one you’re looking for
text:
So as I write this I’m actually shopping for a new speaker. I’ve had this exact speaker from 2017-2022. Let me tell you, This thing has seen all the worst of my travels. I’m a seasonal worker and I frequently travel for a variety of jobs across the country.

I bought it while living in Maine and I needed it for its weather resistance and long battery as I lived in the wilderness building a section of the Appalachian trail. It held up great! Literally in a 9 day hitch of using it constantly during my 8 hour shifts I only had to charge it once! (With a battery pack) We worked in rain or shine and the speaker was right there with us giving us trail workers good tunes as we felled trees and made stone staircases.

Then I went to Colorado and would have it chilling in my pocket as I shred the ski resort on my board every time I bit the edge of my board it took a tumble with me. And it didn’t take a scratch!

I’ve used it while I was a bum on the beach in the
Caribbean and I had to walk to a public beach and it was trusty and true in a time when I didn’t know where my next meal was coming from.

Then I took it to Alaska where I sail and look at glaciers and whales for tours out here. When I’m in a rush and needed to tune out the sound of the giant engines I work around, it was again right there with me. And even when I was wrenching on the boat it would take paint/ harsh chemicals and again nothing stopped it.

So you may wonder “well why am I shopping for one now?” Well my dumb@ss left it at a bonfire during the northern lights going off forgot it and it got swiped. So I need a new replacement to something that’s been with me as I’ve seen it all.

And I don’t know if people from the company reads these things but it would truly make me happy if there was something you folks could do to get me a new one. I’m starting a new trip in Montana and need something as reliable as these speakers back in my life

title: This is NOT MEANT to be used as an EXTERNAL ENCLOSURE - It's INTERNAL...
text:
I was initially very excited to get this device in the mail. But my excitement turned into disappointment as soon as I discovered that there were NO INSTRUCTIONS included with (or for) this device. Nothing telling you what the MAXIMUM SIZE of the Hard Drives that you could use or HOW to Connect it (both the cables AND the Power Connections) nor whether or not you need a RAID Card or an SAS Card.

I was so disappointed that I even went back to the Web Site (where this item is sold) looking for a link that might provide me with an Instruction Manual. No luck there either...

Overall from what I can see there are 2 major drawbacks to this enclosure...

One, that there is no Instruction Manual or even a Spec Sheet included.

Two, that this enclosure is meant to be used internally. The main problem with this is that now-a-day there are very few PC Cases that even have the space for more than 2 HD Spaces and finding one with 5 bays that are open will impossible or at the very least, will be very difficult to find....

I recently put together a NEW PC with a Ryzen 16 Core CPU and was looking for a case that had 2 5 1/4' Hard Drive Bays that were open (1 for a CD/DVD Drive and 1 for a 6 Port USB connection and Memory Card Port Reader). It took me quite a while to find one, but I did. So finding a case with enough space for 5 Drive Bays open is going to be VERY DIFFICULT!!!

Also, supposedly there is (or was) a RAID Card that is (or was) meant to be used with this device, but there is NO MENTION of this card or even WHO makes it or the Model Number. Now this is hearsay so I cannot guarantee whether this statement is true or not. But it would be nice to know for sure if this is true or not...

As it stands (right now) I cannot recommend this device to anyone because of the lack of Instructions for this device...

Sorry guys... I was looking forward to this device, so much for that idea...

Better luck next time...

Joe...

title: Great laptop/businsess bag!  Very professional looking
text:
I wasn't sure what to expect from this bag, but I am very pleased with it.
I have an embarrassingly old and unprofessional-looking laptop/office bag and when I saw this, I thought I would step up my professional game.

I love the unique pattern - it's subtle, yet professional. It feels nice, too.
The tag says that there might be a slight odor for a few days. There was a slight smell, but after 2 days, there is no odor.

Here are some great features:

- The interior is made of a soft fabric, which is really nice for the laptop compartment, especially.

- The inside is roomy and has fantastic storage - there is a large zipped compartment, pockets for smaller items - chargers, business cards, pens - whatever, and a laptop compartment. I have packed the bag with my laptop, charger, pad of paper, little makeup bag, headset and other items - and it stays upright, and is easy to carry with the extra strap to go over my shoulder.

- Outside zipped roomy compartment for an office badge or cell phone, a mirror - whatever you need - there is room!

- Beverage sleeve/holder - It's a little strange to me that the beverage/water bottle sleeve is inside the bag; the material for the beverage holder is not waterproof - so that means if the bottle is cold, there will be condensation that is absorbed by the material. I will line that area with something waterproof so it doesn't ruin the inside and leak onto pads of paper or folders I may have in the bag. I haven't tried that yet. Or, I won't use it for a water bottle. I have used it for a dry umbrella and that works nicely. I still wouldn't but it would get everything wet inside if wet.

- Adjustable handles and strap. I LOVE LOVE LOVE that there are two options - handles and a strap, both of which are adjustable.

Overall, this is a really nice bag for a very reasonable price.
Nice job.

If there are any updates after a long period of use, I will come back to note them here.

title: Zero customer support. Recording subscription doesn’t work and they will NOT you!
text:
Do not purchase any of their items! Everything was great until it wasn’t. I have one Wyze camera indoors to keep eyes on my pets while I’m not home and I pay a monthly subscription to keep all footage in the cloud. One of my dogs may have ingested a potentially life threatening item. I went to my camera to check the footage. My camera is set to record for sound, pets, and people. I have four pets and two are husky’s, there is noise or movement in front of this camera majority of the day. There was one recording and it was me when I came home from work.

So I contacted their support, you can live chat, call, or email. I chose the chat option via my phone. The chat option is just a person (potentially robot) responding to your questions with a pre-typed answer. And they constantly asked me to open the Wyze app, but I’m using my phone for the chat, and you get disconnected from the chat if you leave it. So that was useless. If you have purchased a camera or any subscription from anywhere other than their website, Wyze has zero access to any of your information. They can not see any account, they can not see if you have any cameras connected to that account, and they can not see any subscriptions you are paying them for.

I spent 40 minutes on the phone with a customer service rep. In that time they talked me through all the settings and had me reboot my camera. Which put me back to square one. At the end of the call I had to submit a log to their team and now I’m waiting for answers.

I then asked about refunding my card. I have a monthly subscription that allows me to record 24/7. I was told they do not refund, all purchases are final. Even though their product isn’t working. I was directed to request a refund through Apple/google services because Apple/google are the ones that process the billing. Even though the service (or lack their of) is coming from Wyze. Cameras are suppose to help with pieces of mind. When I needed them to work, they didn’t. When I asked the company for help, they didn’t.

Do not waste your time on these products.

title: Impressively Powerful Little Tool
text:
I find I need small amounts of compressed air fairly regularly. Not only to clean keyboards and computer equipment, but when servicing firearms, and cleaning out charging ports on smartphones and tablets, and cleaning off my workbenches.

This little guy works wonders at getting small crevices clean and it is more powerful than I expected. I usually only need it for short bursts, so I haven’t testing the battery run time, but it requires little charging after I’ve used it for a short time. I was happy to see it uses the better USB-C charging port instead of the micro-USB that so many other brands still seem to use. When you plug-in the charging cable, red it’s charging, and green indicates charging is complete.

What makes this shine over other similar models, is that it is also a small vacuum. Just pop on the attachment onto the back and reverse your hand hold, and you can take advantage of some pretty decent suction. It’s a bagless design, and you just empty the canister after use.

The supplied various attachments and tools are very helpful for getting a precise air flow. I also like than a keyboard key puller is included. It was also a pleasant surprise to realize that it has an LED light that illuminates when the unit is turned-on. It’s also nice that you have three different speed settings to choose from.

Any cons? Only a few nitpicks for which I am deducting one star. The manual is not written by someone with a command of the English language, so it took a few moments to figure out how to use or fasten each attachment, but it wasn’t long before I figured it out. It also would have been nice if some sort of case or storage sack had been included instead of having to use the packaging box. Lastly, I can’t find a way to replace the battery when it eventually fails in several years, as all rechargeable batteries eventually do. Fortunately, this is not an expensive unit to begin with.

Despite my nitpicks, at this price this is more feature rich than many units that are twice the price. If you need one of these, it would be hard to beat this guy.

title: Lots of storage in a small package
text:
I love listening to Old Time Radio shows and have been storing them on my phone. Well, that takes up a lot of valuable space. So when this was made available it was an instant order. It holds all of the shows that were on my phone and much more. I will be storing video content to watch on demand too. You can store so much more as well.

This device is a very small item but can hold so much. Almost 64gb of storage. Unlike many other storage devices that I have come across at times, this one actually holds what it says it will. None of those large claims only to find that it will hold half of the rated numbers. This tells it as it is.

Performance is great and it responds quickly. Working with it is simple too. No major hoops to jump through in order to get it working. Just download the items to your computer and then transfer them to the drive. Retrieval is just as easy. I have not tried downloading directly from the phone but I am sure that it will also do just that. Find it on your device and open and play. No drivers required.

This is a very stoutly built drive too. It is made of a very strong material. It looks like it can take a beating and still operate. There are 2 plug ports to use, one is a USB A treminal plug and the second is a Type C. It has a swinging cover that can be placed over the unused portion. Wish they had some sort of cover for the other end when it isn't plugged into anything. These multi port treminals allow you so much latitude. It can easily be used on a phone, computer, laptop, tablet, even some televisions. Mine accepts a USB A plug in device. And... my truck even has a port to plug this into. They say that it can also be used on a Mac.

When in use I am saving my phone's power as well as keeping my phone available if needed. Draws power from the device that it is plugged into.

Comes in a nice labled box with a clear window to view the product inside. Instructions printed on the back of the box. This is one real handy device and I am very leased with it. Plus, the cost is so very reasonable. A great combination in my book.

title: I was not happy with the way this desk functioned
text:
Let me preface that there are a lot of pros with this.

This is a very sturdy desk when you get it into the correct position that you want it in. It already comes fully assembled, which is nice, but it can be a bit challenging trying to get it how you want.

You do have to push down on the lever while pressing down on the desk then lifting it up.

If you turn it over, you see where there are notches in the metal bar that is supposed to click or latch onto depending on the height you are trying to achieve. I actually wanted to use this to raise my monitor up because I didn't have a monitor stand at home.

I figured out how to raise up the desk on its own without anything on it, and I made sure that it was sturdy enough that it could hold some weight. Once I figured that out, I brought it up to my office desk and placed my monitor on top. I proceeded to follow the same instructions on lifting it up, only once it had the weight on it, it would not latch onto any of the notches until it was fully expanded. I tried it numerous times, despite the fact that it was a bit heavy with my monitor on it, and I went slowly to try to get it to latch onto the lower notches. It just would not work.

I removed my monitor and placed the desk upside down on the floor to see if I was crazy with thinking there were actual notches like I originally thought, and there were notches. I attempted to lift the legs backwards (in other words, the top of the desk was flat on the floor and the legs in the air where I could see the mechanisms working) and it seemed to catch on the notches while it was upside down. I saw that it was working, so I flipped it right side up and replicated this movement, but it would not latch correctly.

Maybe I have a defective product, but I'm not so sure. It seems if you want it all the way up or all the way down, those are the two options, unless you're willing to flip it over to get it to the height you want. I feel like that kinda defeats the purpose, although it is a desk riser so it does serve that purpose if that's all you're looking for.

title: Nice look, but horrible design & hardware
text:
Nice look and durable composite wood.
I spent two hours putting this stand together.

But, it was one of worst experiences I’ve had putting furniture stuff together. I’m sure an elderly person would be way more mad than I am.

Due to its horrible design, particularly that the top section uses wood dowels, the stand doesn’t stop falling apart until the last step when the metal supports/legs are screwed onto the sides of the stand.

Now the long screws that were used…the heads were made for Allen wrench installation. How dumb. Allen wrench kept falling off the strew. And since it falls apart so easily before one side of the legs/support are screwed on, good luck reaching for the Allen wrench every time it pops off the screw, when you risk knocking the pre-complete flimsy design trying to reacquire the wrench.

The 1/2” backing screws have Phillips heads on them, so the long nearly 2” screws should’ve also had Phillips heads.

Getting to the backing…not only does it have a piece of duct tape holding the top & bottom section together, it doesn’t even sit/fit correctly between the two sections.

Also, while there are pre-drilled holes on the wood composite backing, the holes on the stand stand on the top section didn’t even line up, and even though I flipped the boards around. So now any elderly people have to use extra strength to screw 4 screws into the side boards of the top section of the stand.

And since there were 2 extra backing screws, they could’ve also pre-drilled holes for the middle of the very top & bottom of the stand.

And after screwing the legs/supports on during the last step, the middle shelf board doesn’t even tighten/close the gap completely between the top & bottom side boards.

Truly an annoyance putting this stand together.

Although I was surprised to see a screwdriver included with the hardware, the manufacturer should redesign how it’s put together, besides using only Phillips head screws and checking quality control to make sure backing holes are drilled in correct places on the board pieces.

title: AMAZING CRISP PICTURE!
text:
My old Elephas projector just was just not cutting it for my events. I have 150" screen and it was blurry, distorted and the color was completely off. After searching for anweek to see if there was anything I could do for the elephas, I found they no longer had support. I opened Amazon and this was the first projector that popped up. I looked at a few others but they just didn't have what I wanted and the ability for a 450" projection and Bluetooth was very attractive. After reading different reviews on different projectors I decided to give this one a go. One of the reviews for this machine said the outside casing looked 3d printed... it doesn't. It has some nice texture and the casing is very well made. I tested the size and clarity outside during the day on the side of my 2 story home. Even Un the sun while dim, I could still see just fine. It was clear, crisp and the color is AMAZING! The size of the projection definitely goes up to and probably over 450" it took up a large section of the side of my house. The sound is FANTASTIC! My son didn't realize it had a speaker so when I turned on a movie he bout jumped out of his skin because I had turned the sound up so high haha! The controls and settings are very user friendly and easy to maneuver. Setting it and connecting via Bluetooth is amazingly easy! My Samsung and my husband's iPhone were able to pick it up with no issues whatsoever. It comes with a VERY nice protective case for carrying and storage.
The only thing I will say just because it freaked me out at first. Make sure your power supply is strong enough!!! The first time I turned it on... it turn on, went to the home screen for the projector then shut off. It did this 3 times. We were in the garage so I took it in the house and plugged it into the kitchen wall and it was fine. I also plugged it into the extension cord I was using to test to see if it was the socket in the garage or if it was the extension cord. It also worked fine with the extension cord. So just be sure the socket you plug it into has enough power to run it or it will turn itself off. Which honestly seems like a great safety feature for the life of the projector.
I really have absolutely nothing bad to say about this projector at all.

title: not bad really
text:
I like it, at first i was 50/50 with it but more used it more i found it not a bad budget option full set might be worth it. Mouse is pretty low quality i had a keyboard similar to the one comes with this not a bad keyboard but it lacks anti-slip pads and believe me when i say it sucks on a desk without them lol. (put some on it you'll thank me later) Screen protector was defected. I know how can you defect a screen protector, right? i have no idea but they did, there was a fairly large spot that didn't have adhesive and it made it look like an air bubble but actually was just where it wouldn't stick lol. Oh well I don't need it anyways. Camera quality is terrible both rear and front so don't buy it for the camera. I mainly use tablet as a security cam screen lol. But worked great for that, I do play some retro emulators on it. Does freevee pluto tv movie and video stuff fairly well works good for e-booking to. The screen and color gamut looks great, images look great on it. Touchscreen side is sensitive and responsive atleast for now it is, good enough for me.

The biggest flaw in my opinion is it's bluetooth it wont pair/connect with all BT versions. i don't know about 4.0 dont have anything to test but i cant get it to pair anything 5.1+ it literally causes a driver glitch so bad that it disables BT fully and only way to fix it is to restart the tablet. This maybe a Build v1.0 android 11 bug because I'm pretty sure it's software/driver related. BT works fine for some earbuds and wireless controller I had, though I'm unsure what their BT versions are. Keyboard included is BT 3.0 and works fine. I have a BT 5.1 keyboard and a BT 5.2 mouse that wont pair and causes the driver bug, keyboard and mouse works i used it on another budget android 11 tablet and smartphone with so issues.

Anyways, not bad for $105 with coupon unfortunately i was taxed at $140 I wouldn't give $140 if I had paid cash included mouse/kb etc wouldn't even costed $40if you bought it singled out lol.

Take care, I hope my review helps.

title: Welcome ol' 2003 Infiniti FX to 2023 Technology
text:
I wasn't sure what to expect from this T86DVR model - the least expensive front & rear dash cam with both Android Auto & CarPlay. So far, I'm very happy with it after a month of use. The wide and not so tall aspect looks really nice atop my dash and doesn't obstruct my view. All the wires are hidden so it looks nicely integrated.

Power is through a 12V to 5DC USB converter hidden behind the factory head unit. The hardest part of the install by far is cleanly running the wire from the rear camera to the dash.

The internal speaker and the FM transmitter sound was fine for navigation and calls but not that good for music. Using the Aux output to the car's amp is much better.

Android Auto (version 9.0.x) is working really well, including Coolwalk features. I have had a few random disconnections but only when my spouse was in the car with her iPhone. Maybe her phone is trying to connect to CarPlay which causes the AA disconnects? In any case CarPlay works perfectly well for her when she drives the car.

The dash cam quality is pretty good, both front and rear. It's quite nice now to have a backup camera that has really good night vision.

The best part is being able to keep my phone in my pocket and having it connect wirelessly to Android Auto (or CarPlay) and automatically bringing up navigation map using Android Driving Mode. No longer do I have to make a run back to the car to get my phone off the dash.

Lastly, I had some questions I needed help with and contacted USManju@163.com. I received very prompt and helpful replies and videos from Irelia in customer support.

UPDATE: Lowered the rating due to not being able to have a phone conversation while driving, even with the windows up. People simply can't understand me due to the audio breaking up. Voice commands are spotty as well. Calls through Android Autp do work OK when I pull over and stop and the engine still running. Obviously when stopped the ambient noise level is quieter, but this suggests this unit's microphone is quite poor at any noise cancellation above a certain level when driving.

title: Just one GIANT brick of power!
text:
[[VIDEOID:33806bad104bea1b67c02410963eb7d5]] This is a 5 in 1 Power Bank by VanSmaGO that is sure to turn a few heads wherever you go. This is not your ordinary 10000mah power bank created for your typical user, it is much more than that. THIS thing is a beast that transforms from a brick to a charging stand, to a phone charger and an apple watch charger with a flick of the wrist. It flourishes a bright LED display showing the charge of base and an added USB input on the side for those extra devices you might want charge on the side. I tested the charger using my iPhone 12 Pro Max with a Mag safe compatible case and it worked flawlessly as the phone charged from 5% to 50% in 30min. The base charged my Apple Air pods Pro like a champ, but sadly the Apple watch charging arm was a downright stinker. The charger for the Apple watch charges the watch, but the magnet on stand is weak and relies on the watch band to keep it in place as shown in the picture. I don't use a metal band or the original Apple watch band which I like to think most people don't, to wear their watch, so I currently use a thicker band for my watch because I have big wrist and the stand seems to not compensate for that, but for those who wear metal bands, it would be perfect, so I'm out of luck for my watch for now. The power bank is not heavy, but hefty, although very portable for whenever you are on the go and comes in handy when traveling, hiking or just need a little juice for just an emergency.

***UPDATE***
After only a week, the charger stopped working. NO LIGHTS, NO CHARGE, nothing works. Tried the next day and still dead. I might have received a dud, but on the bright side, I have myself a nice little paperweight. D-

***2nd update***
After a couple of days of posting the review, Customer Support reached out to me and sent me a replacement within a few days. The replacement seems to be working fine so far with no issues other than the Apple watch not sticking to the charger correctly, but still a great portable and powerful charger. Thank you VanSmaGO. Keep up the good work! B+

title: A beautifully dynamic sound.
text:
I needed a good pair of active noise cancelling headphones, so I gave these Tozo X1’s a shot (Amazon makes trying things out super easy) , and WOW, these earbuds don’t disappoint.

Putting these in my ears, for the first time, felt great! The low profile earbuds come with 6 different sets of inserts, to fit my ears, and the design of the actual earbud is such, that it fits the form of your ear, and locks into the intertragal notch of your ear, basically making it impossible to fall from your ear.

Turning them on for the first time to listen to music, was a dream. I’ve never heard such dynamic sound from an earbud. I’d liken the definition, and bass boost, to that of an over-the-ear set of headphones. I could even hear a dynamic shift in the sound quality of the podcasts that I listen to.

I wore these earbuds in the engine room that i work in, with the active noise cancelation turned on, and I could hear my music/podcasts without having to turn the sound up. These not only sound great, but will save your hearing by not having to turn sound up, to drown out ambient noise. You don’t even have to take them out to have a conversation, just simply tap the left earbud, and you can use transparent mode, and suddenly it amplifies the ambient noise, to the levels of not even wearing hearing protection! It even has an active move (off) so I can have a nice mixture of music, and ambient noise, to play the drums.

I’m getting about 5 hour playtime on them, but the case recharges them back to full within a 20 minute work break. So I’m never really without my tunes, The case not only shows the battery life remaining on the case, but what the battery level is, on both of the earbuds, during charging. The case can also be recharged on a wireless charger.

These are my go-to earbuds now, well worth the price, I’m almost sad now, that I’m addicted to a more expensive earbud.

title: Camera works good, app is awful.
text:
This is really a great quality dash cam but I have run into a few issues with it. It is not the easiest to set up. It basically has to be plugged into a power source or it doesn't power up. It comes with a short usb cord/plug to use in the house and a cigarette lighter plug for in the car. The in car plug has a very long cord so it is easy to snake it around your dash to wherever you need to hang the camera. The suction cup to mount it has a lock that makes it easy to hang up and sturdy. Initially the micro usb provided by the company would not work in the camera so I had to go out and purchase an additional card. I opted for a much larger storage card anyway so this wasn't a huge deal but was an extra cost for an already pricy device. Once I finally got a card that worked and put the camera up, it does what it is supposed to do. It begins recording clips that are of very good quality as you are driving. You can set the timer for the screen to time out and a screensaver comes up with the time on it. I like this so it is not as distracting as you are driving. I did notice that after a few short drives the camera is really HOT. Hopefully this will not affect the longevity and functionality of the camera.
Video clips are not hard to review on the camera but the screen is pretty small so you get a better picture if you insert the card into your computer. Ideally you should be able to view the clips and gallery on your phone through the company's app but I am pretty tech savvy and have not been able to connect the app to the camera on my iphone. It is supposed to connect via wifi with a password and just flat out refuses to connect for me. I have been unable to use the app at all so every time I want to review clips I have to take the camera down. I had to set my phone to forget my home wifi and only recognize the camera wifi and still it will not connect. It would be much better if it connected via bluetooth but that's not the way it is set up... although you have to have bluetooth enabled to get the app to sync? Overall, this is a good quality dash camera but it has a lot of connectivity issues that are just really frustrating.

title: Pros/Neutral/Cons - Be sure you want hexagon keys - Good bluetooth, overall fine
text:
I have been typing on keyboards for 30+ years and average about 70-80 words per minute. I have owned dozens of them but I do not consider myself a keyboard aficionado. I build my own computers, maintain a few servers, and do light amateur coding. My preference is for quiet, sleek, dependable mechanical keyboards.

The keyboard is nice in some respects but could use work in others.

Pros:
- Good Aesthetics - Looks pleasant and looks like quality. Has a nice honeycomb pattern

- Reliable bluetooth - Bluetooth connection hasn't failed me yet. After pairing I just turn it on and it works immediately as expected with no interruptions.

- Medium Weight - I like hefty keyboards and this has medium weight. So do not expect a super lightweight keyboard.

- Quiet Keys - There is some slight noise but pretty quiet for a keyboard, definitely quieter than most of my mechanical keyboards

Neutral:
- Key positioning - I understand that this is compact keyboard but some keys are out of position - Delete, Home, Insert, PgUp, PgDn, End. So if you use those keys a lot, better get used to the weird positioning. Everything else is somewhat normal.

- Okay Pricing - Seems right for a decent quality bluetooth keyboard, it does not feel low quality

- Rechargeable Micro-USB - This would be better if it was USB-C

Cons:
- Hexagon keys - These will inhibit efficiency if you are used to normal square ones, so this will decrease your typing speed. Not a good keyboard to learn on either as you will get used to hexagon keys and not be as efficient on the more ubiquitous square keys. The loss to efficiency is not super high though, and if you were so inclined you could probably get back that efficiency with a little practice and getting used to it. I am not so inclined, so this will be a last use case keyboard for me.

- No Leg Height Elevation - There is a slight raised rubber backing on the back to give it very small height. However, this is not nearly enough height for a normal raised back keyboard. Back legs would be nice.

title: Wow, we have a $40 shocker!
text:
[[VIDEOID:c3fe78fa29ac6816e0fb89e9c3e2b9a4]] Guys!!! What is happening! These sound absolutely INCREDIBLE (at this price level!). I am an advanced earbud reviewer. I listen to A LOT of them on a daily basis. I know and have analyzed in detail the sound of 1MORE EVO, Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro, Bose QC2, Sony WF-1000XM, SoundPEATS Opera5, OnePlus Buds Pro2, Edifier W240TN, Moondrop Nekocake and many others. I can tell you with full confidence:

THESE ARE AMAZING VALUE!!!

I had no idea what to expect and I think they are shockingly good. Broad soundstage, deep, satisfying bass, great mids and very, very nicely done highs. You can hear all detial and instruments in your songs much better than with comparable earbuds at this price level. Just: WOW!

Ergonomics are insane, too. These have a weird shape but they stay in your ears SUPER WELL! They come with two additional ear tip sizes so you can adjust if necessary.

Aesthetics: looks are not their strong side but with this crazy good sound - who cares!!!

ANC: GOOD! Maybe not Bose level but again, pick your battles at $40!

MIC/PHONE CALLS: check out my video here

Case: AWESOME. Compact and functional! That's what I'm talking about!

Touch controls: they work well, IMHO. You can stop/start songs and change volume with taps. Also cycle between ANC/TRANSPARENCY/OFF modes. An unusual control mode is you can turn individual earbuds on/off with a long press (5 sec). Haven't ever come across that before on any other earbuds. I guess this would be very helpful if you want to take a phone call and use one earbud only without taking them out of your ears.

This is 5 stars VERY WELL DESERVED!!! I am making a video about these because I am so positively surprised!

title: Nice Travel Plug with Minor Issues
text:
This is a nice, compact, and lightweight power strip. I think it's best suited for traveling rather than on a home or office desk/table.

The item works wells. One issue is that it's so lightweight that it tends to move around when you manipulate the cords. As a travel item it should be light, but for a permanent location it's annoying. It's also a bit awkward because the plugs typically stick straight out from all five sides (see picture). But I still like it.

I tested the USB chargers. Be aware that the three USB-A (rectangular) connectors share a maximum wattage (15.5w) that's not much higher than the maximum wattage (12w) for a single connector. So if you have three devices plugged in, the maximum power for each one will be about 40% of the maximum power for when a single device is plugged in.

I wasn't impressed by the power output of the USB connectors. I found it better to plug our existing 20w chargers into the AC outlets than to use the built-in USB chargers.

Regarding the USB chargers, the actual power being sent to my devices was never even close to the maximum ratings in the product listing. The maximum power output ratings are 15w for the USB-C (oval) connector and 12w for a single USB-A (rectangular) connector. I used them to charge a power cube battery, and the actual output was about half of the maximum (8w and 6w). I used them to charge my iPhone and iPad, both of which are older models, and while I got higher numbers (due to "fast charging" I assume) I never got above 10w power. Not sure how they'd perform on a late-model iPhone, but the experience with my devices was disappointing.

Finally, there are slots in the bottom of the cube to anchor it to a wall or table, but mounting hardware (screws, etc.) is not included.

Overall I like this power strip cube. It's compact and light, and would be great for travel. Not as good but still decent for home use. For the lack of stability (due to light weight) and the lower-than-expected USB charging power, I rate it 4/5 stars.

title: Better than expected but not perfect
text:
Pros: Surprisingly good ADAS, quality feel, 4k front camera is impressive, auto reverse is nice, easy install if you are ok with routing the wires its not hard.
Cons: rear camera is not great at night, enough that it can’t be used as a active mirror. Glare from the mirror affects the display in bright light, wish I could remove the mirror layer but then I would have to cousins on the rear camera at night so that won’t work. Can’t dash mount as the wires poke out from the top. ADAS only works on front camera or rear but not both at the Same time. ADAS only works on the displayed camera. So to get the front ADAS (collision (car, pedestrian), safe distance, lane departure one has to set it to use the front camera, then I turn off the display aspect so ADAS keeps working with the front camera. That way I avoid the poor back visibility issues of bright days vs the mirror reflecting faint images of the rear view. Front camera must be detachable from the morror/display assembly as multiple drivers results in repeated tilting of the mirror/display which moves the front camera so ADAS stops working properly.
Perfect would require: both front and rear use the same 4k front camera model, front camera is not part of the mirror assembly instead it sticks right on the windshield or that ADAS SW auto adjusts on tilt to avoid needing recalibration when the mirror is adjusted, ADAS needs to works on both cameras simultaneously, rear camera needs to be better than mirror both day and night so the mirror layer can be dumped. Better volume and clearer messages. Lane departure have an option to be bypassed by the blinkers, Price needs to be kept around the current price so it does not become a theft magnet. Connectors need to be sleeker, or attached to a hidden box to make the install cleaner. All this said i do like it and am considering getting a second one for the RV but it needs about 40’+ of cable to the rear camera. In an RV the mirror glare is not an issue and there is no need for a mirror so it can be a full time rear view camera, if only the adas would work with the front + rear or at a minimum the camera WHILE displaying the rear camera.

title: Substandard and Not worth it at any price
text:
Watch died after 4 months. Daily use. Exercise 7 days a week.
This was a Garmin replacement for a Vivo4 (which had all the same issues but lasted 1 year) I was told it was an complete upgrade from the Vivo4 however it has the same cheap internal components. I was offered this because they did not have a Vivo4 to replace mine. (which makes one think many failed) The screen was better (see rating below).

Music: 1 - Worked (intermittent cutout) 90% of the time by itself, 70% of the time if used with a workout app, 60% with GPS - Tried with multiple earbuds and headphones that worked flawless on other devices. Not a useful feature if it doesn't work while working out.
Heartrate: 2 - Only was accurate until 100BPM. Then is was off by +80-100% except when it was showing (footfall) cadence instead of HR. Completely unacceptable for a fitness device.
Stair Counter: 0 - Counted 60% of up stairs and 40% of down stairs. Didn't count any if you went up and down quickly like you would do when exercising. (I typically exercise using 2-story 12' flights of stairs)
GPS: 1 - Took 5 or more minutes to synch and if you miss the synch window (30 seconds) it reset. On the best resolution it would not show any change less then 20m in movement when it actually worked. (for example zigzagging 70' / 20m while moving)
Step Counter: 3 - Did not like tracking movement unless arm swings were exaggerated.
Battery Life: 4 - Surprisingly good and it was supposed to be the weak point.
Screen: 5 - Actually decent, bright, good visibility & resolution. Wish the rest of the watch was half as good.

HR Chest monitor (Garmin add on): 4 - however the watch had troubles synching making its use more trouble then its worth. Accuracy of the HR monitor was good & consistent when it did synch. I bought it to use with previous Vivo4 because the watch HR monitor had the same issues.

Do yourself a favor and buy anything else. You likely cannot do worse.

title: Great for international travel carry on
text:
I bought this to use as my carry on bag for an international flight that has a very small carry on size allowance: 21.65” x 15.74” x 7.87”. None of my suitcases meet this size. I’m also limited to 17.5 lbs, including my personal item. That’s a challenge! We will be checking one bag for two people, so I was looking for a bag for a few more outfits (in case the checked bag gets lost), and all the misc stuff (electronics, meds, toiletries, etc).

My first thought when unwrapping this: Wow, that’s a heavy backpack. But that included the packing cubes. It’s much lighter than a rolling suitcase, which is important when every pound counts. And I’m really amazed how much I can pack into it. I’m a fan of packing cubes for organization. I can fit two medium packing cubes in the main section, without expanding the backpack. Since my entire trip wardrobe fits in two medium packing cubes, this is perfect.

I love the front pockets. One I’ll use for passports. The other will be for a fanny pack that I keep my plane essentials in (eye mask, chapstick, phone, earbuds, snacks, etc). The bigger front pocket has great organization, and I like the key chain clip.

I’m not traveling with a laptop, so I don’t really have a need for the padded pocket. It just provides extra padding on the back, in addition to the other padding.

The trolley sleeve was a must for me, and this one works well. It is a canvas strap (not stretchy), right above the horizontal zipper on the back. It fits snug on the luggage handle, so it won’t shift around. If you pack the bag too full, you might have trouble sliding it over the luggage handle.

I don’t think this will be used as my day bag, it’s a bit heavy for that. But it works great as a carryon bag for international flights. I like that you can tuck the straps away.

title: I can't say with certainty that this delivers what is advertised...
text:
I hunted for hours if not a couple of days for something that could possibly "future proof" me for a couple of years moving forward that would at minimum support 4k @ 120 Hz instead of the typical you see around right now, 4k @ 60 Hz.
