While I actually don't have a display at the moment that supports 4k @ 120 Hz...there are other concerns that have come up for me with testing this product in particular, and are the reason I plan to return this. I can't say with certainty that this device will output 4k @ 120 Hz correctly, and some other reviews point out it does not, but the other problems for me of continuing to use this device now outweigh that.

I was happy to be able to output and display at the following formats with this:
1080p @ 144 Hz
2560x1440 @ 144 Hz
2560 x 1600 @ 60 Hz
3840 x 2160 @ 60 Hz

Ethernet port seems to work well and did not slow down my internet speeds without using the hub versus using it.

The problems started to come in for me with using the USB ports in this hub. This hub is more modern in terms of specs, yet it has problems correctly powering and transmitting the connected USB devices I was using it with.

I am using an Elgato HD 60 S+ and Elgato 15 key Stream Deck through this hub and the Elgato HD 60 S+ especially lags and eventually losing signal when working through this hub. This is a big problem for me and my use case with this set up. Mind you, I typically use both these USB devices in the same way with a much older USB C hub (~5 years old) and they have worked perfectly fine without issue to date.

Because of the problems I have already tested for myself that I will seem to have with the USB ports if I keep using this hub, I have to return it and cannot keep this product. While I was assuming the only hurdle at some point would be testing 4k @ 120 Hz and hoping it would work in the future, is now at the bottom of the list of concerns for me with using this product.

I'll have to keep looking for something that has the specs I'm looking for and works.

title: Works, but too hissy
text:
I bought two of these to use with my wired headphone / IEM collection. The good: the physical power switch is *really* nice to have vs. the firmware-driven switch in just about every other device of this type. Range is impressive. Pairing works well.

The bad: The noise floor of the Bluetooth chipset (or, I'm presuming, the BT chipset) is quite high. It's on par with listening to a cassette Walkman, except that the hiss drops in and out when a song or video starts or stops, making it impossible to fully tune out. The hiss doesn't seem to increase with volume, which is good, but this also means that listening at low volumes - especially to spoken word - sounds particularly rotten as the hiss is comparatively almost as loud as the signal.

I've also experienced some glitching / obvious repeated stream micro-dropouts and time corrections at close range for the first 5-10 minutes the 1Mii is on, although this seems to calm down or become less likely the longer the 1Mii has "broken in" with any single given Bluetooth source. I know that sounds totally crazy / like snake-oil nonsense, but I've experienced something similar in many other cheaper Bluetooth dongles that seem to need to have time to "get used" to a source before the glitches generally stabilize (or maybe other way round, and it's the source that must adapt). This prolonged micro-glitching does seem a bit worse and more obnoxious with the 1Mii, though.

I really wish someone like a Sony or Sennheiser, both of whom can clearly manufacture a passable Bluetooth chipset for headphones at a price point, would bring out one of these danged things and do it right, by golly.

One last complaint: I don't know why *none* of these things, other than the now-unobtanium Fiio uBTR, ever have garment clips on the back or at least a little case that you could use to "slip on a clip" for use with wired headphones. The integrated uBTR clip is / was the best thing ever. Finding an old lanyard/nametag badge clip and super-gluing it onto one of these dongles is not really the same level of awesome, I've found.

title: Good Sound Reproduction, Good Price AND IPX7 Waterproof
text:
I've been in the market for waterproof earbuds for sometime now as I spend a fair amount of time in the pool and would like to listen to music without worrying about shorting out the earbuds. When I saw these Vilard JR-TL1 Pro earbuds advertised, and at such a reasonable price, I had to give them a try.

Included in the case: hard plastic charging case with strap and charging indicator lights, ear buds, extra eartips, USB-C charging cable, a cleaning swab with cleaning instructions and the very easy to understand instruction booklet.

Control: The earbuds automatically turn on when removed from the case and can also be powered on/off by a 5 second push on the multifunction button. Pairing was easy. The multifunction button is an area in the center of each earbud's flat outer surface. Control of the voice assistant, of music stop, play, next and last song as well as of phone call answer/reject/hangup are all performed by various number of clicks on one or the other earpiece multifunction buttons. Unlike my experience with some other earbuds which have had the same control system, these worked perfectly.

Sound: Although there is no active noise cancelling there is passive noise cancellation simply by setting the earpieces in your ear. Sound reproduction of the spoken voice (eg audiobooks) was very crisp and full. Music, too, was very full, and though not what you would get if spending much more, the sound across bass, middle and high frequencies was clear and crisp throughout. One possible issue for some is that there is no volume control through the earbuds - volume must thus be controlled from the source.

I've worn these earbuds in multiple wet environments and so far have had no problems. If this changes in the future I will update this review.

Overall I recommend these JR-TL1 Pro Vilard earbuds for those who want to pay a bargain price for headphones that provide far more than bargain performance. Because there is no volume control built into these earpieces (which would require me to rely on my phone even in wet environments or when in the pool) I have deducted one star - if waterproof use was not an issue they would rate 5.

title: Works - But Bargain Basement
text:
The ienRon 8 Port Gigabit Switch is a small 8 Port unmanaged network switch. I tested this switch on my bench by plugging into another cascaded switch on my home network. The testing was done using a known good switch and this ienRon being what I would call an entry level switch if you are in a pinch.

The switch worked very well for my needs, but I did notice the uplink port ran at the 1GB rating while other ports basically worked at a little slower pace that I noticed during my upload and download testing. I passed files back and forth from my home server and the switch performed fine with smaller files, but once I started with large graphic files, I noticed some lag during the process compared to my standard switch that I'm normally on.

PROS: (The Good Stuff)

1. Switching was good.
2. Easy setup.
3. Small switch that can be hidden anywhere out of site if needed.
4. Metal case assembly.
5. The back of the case has 2-hole mounting option.

CONS: (Things to Think About)

1. This device is not a "UL" listed device.
2. There is no marking on the unit who actually makes this unit, so if there is an issue who do you contact? Service/warranties?
3. The documentation is really bad when you have instructions in the box representing 5-port switch versus the 8-port that is advertised.
4. The wall wart power supply cord is short so you will need have more electrical available nearby.
5. If you are proud of your products, why not put your name on them so people would know how to find you.

Even though I didn't really have an issue with my scenario, I feel at this price point compared to other equivalent products that are available from much better-known companies I would actually would have purchased from those companies because of warranties and support as well as reliability. This unit looks and is built cheaply in my humble opinion, however if you are looking into something new and unexplored you can give this a try. Like I stated it so far has worked for me...

title: Very sturdy, functional, and attractive
text:
Pros:

- Easy assembly. Out of the box, it came with the main adjustable magnetic part, the base plate,
instructions, a Philips head screwdriver, and 3 small screws. It took me less than 5 minutes to put it
together.
- It feels very sturdy and has a decent weight to it. I was worried due to other iPad stands that I've tried
being a little on the lightweight
and flimsy side, but this stand feels heavy and is sturdy enough to where I'm not worried about the weight
of my iPad tipping it over. It is also very easy to adjust the tablet to whatever screen orientation you prefer.
Adjusting the stand angle, height, and orientation feels smooth and the iPad remains secure during
adjustments.
- The magnets are strong enough to keep my iPad secure, even when I tip the stand forward.
- The silicone pads on the magnetic plate protect your tablet from scratches and also help to keep the iPad
secure. The silicone feet on the base plate ensure that the stand stays in place and won't be easily
knocked off of whatever surface you have it on.
- It has a sleek and modern appearance and it looks great on my desk.
- It folds down nicely and is compact and portable.

Cons:

- The only con that I can think of isn't exactly a con because it's just sort of expected, but, this will not work
with a case. I normally keep my iPad in a Logitech Combo Touch case with keyboard that I use for travel
and the case is too thick for the magnets on the stand to securely hold the iPad in place. Not really a big
deal for me because I wasn't expecting it to work well with a case on in the first place, but it's just
something to keep in mind if you don't want to have to take your iPad out of its case to use the stand.

Overall, this is one of the most sturdy, functional, and attractive iPad stands that I have used. I love how easily adjustable it is and how compact it folds down for travel.

title: Works quite well, but be aware that it takes a little time to connect
text:
My 2017 Mazda did not have Carplay installed at the factory, but I had the Mazda dealership add the module for Carplay and Android Auto. To use the module, I had been plugging in my iPhone or Android phone when I get in the car, which was a giant pain in the place you don't want pain. I had been reading about these wireless options and was excited to get this.

I would recommend reading not only the instructions from the seller, but also the comments in many of the reviews here to help you with the initial setup. I have at least four different wireless Carplay/Android Auto adapters, and they all work the same way. Instead of the cable you would normally use, this adapter plugs in to the corresponding USB slot in your car. If you're lucky, the adapter will be recognized immediately and ask you to pair it with your car's Bluetooth. In my case with this adapter, I needed to update the software. If you are having trouble reading the on screen directions, tap the globe in the corner of the screen to change the language. To update the adapter (ONLY UPDATE IF IT DOESN'T WORK INITIALLY), make sure your phone is connected via Bluetooth, open a browser and navigate to 192.168.50.2
Follow the directions to finish the update and you should be good after that.

Two things to note:
1. Since the entire point of this is to prevent the need to manually plug in your phone, your phone will not be charging while you use Carplay as it did before. As long as you're not on a long trip, that shouldn't be an issue, but you will need to plug in your phone to keep it charged if you plan be in the car for hundreds of miles.
2. Unlike when you are hard wired for Carplay, your music will not start instantly when you start your car. The adapter usually takes between 15 to 90 seconds to connect after you turn on the ignition, so be patient. It will connect if you give it a minute.

Is this the perfect replacement solution to wired Carplay? No, it is not. But for me, the convenience of not having to ALWAYS plug in my phone to use Carplay is worth the slight wait to connect when I get in the car. Your mileage may vary, but it works for me!

title: Nice Idea but Needs Work
text:
I'd purchased three of these with the foolish notion I could get rid of my expensive business telephone lines by purchasing two SIM cards on a discount cell provider and porting over my numbers, but it quickly became apparent that wouldn't work. To use those three phones, you need six SIM cards and half of them would need to be tied to one of the two numbers I have for my business. In addition, when one line is in use, there'd be no method to alert the other phones that line was in use.
Having three in my possession, I decided to get one SIM card and see about using one as a home phone--something I haven't had for years. I got a limited $5.00 plan and the phone works just fine. It wasn't hard to get set-up and the clarity is great. The biggest problem with the phone is the HORRIBLE Chinese instructions that come with it. Apart from a horrible translation, the instructions are just completely inadequate. The phone can supposedly store numbers on the SIM card and on the phone itself, but having tried again and again, I can't figure out how to do it. The instructions are woefully lacking and working with the on screen menu is impossible. I'm typically good with tech-gadgets and can figure things out, but not this one, and there very little information online for guidance. Entering names is done with the numeric keyboard by doing multi-presses of the buttons for the alphabetic characters, but then attempting to put the actual number associated with the name is impossible. Names are limited to six or seven characters too. SMS message can be sent, but inputting text via that numeric keyboard is slow and painful.
The cell phone era makes memorizing phone numbers a thing of the past, and if a cell phone can't store the numbers you use frequently, its sort of worthless. I have it on my end table, and its nice to have a backup phone, but rarely use it. At $5.00 a month for service, I'll keep it a while and keep trying to program numbers, but after about two hours of trying to thus far, I don't hold out any hope of figuring this puzzle out. Its a great idea, but would be fantastic with a touchscreen and better electronics. Even at five or six times the price, I'd bite...

title: Caveat Emptor
text:
This thing is terrible and, in my opinion, needs to be pulled from the market.

It's painfully slow and laggy. It's almost impossible to use it as a writing device.

It is running some version of Android that is so old my password manager doesn't work (installed from the Google Play store). Half of the apps are in Chinese.

The biggest disappointment, though, was the handwriting-to-text transliteration (as it calls it). I didn't expect it to be as good as the ReMarkable (which is really good, by the way), but it missed every single word I wrote in my natural handwriting. Even when I just used block letters, it couldn't get all the words. It translated some of my writing into Chinese. Why would it even try that? I'm sure it was gibberish.

Here's the thing, if you're going to sell these in other countries make sure they work in the languages for that country. I know that there is no official language for the USA, but most of us speak English as our first language. Not trying to sound US-centric, but I do live here and I wanted to use the device in my native language.

The reason I didn't go with the ReMarkable was because it is too locked down--but it is far more elegant in other aspects. I was looking forward to a more open-source (Android) experience so I could use it as an e-reader as well as a writing device, but the version you have on this device is either some strange port or too old for certain apps to work.

EDIT: I have been working directly with tech support to address some of the problems with this device. They had me turn on "global handwriting" which sped up the handwriting in most apps. However, it's still unnatural because of a slight lag. The transcription still misses a lot of words though. The password manager still does not work. Tech support is really nice and eager to help, but I just can't rate this any higher than two stars. The device is not ready for public use (at least in the U.S.), but I will give them an additional star for the effort they have put in.

title: Good overall quality in a large package
text:
This camera surprised me in many ways!

Build Quality: Out of the box, this camera had a good weight for a webcam. The camera itself is quite large, very wide, and is among the largest webcams I have used. The outer shell is all plastic and feels sturdy. There is a camera lens cover included, however you need to attach this yourself. It is provided with 3M tape already attached, I just thought it was weird that it wasn't just built in. Over time, this could be a problem as the sticky layer could diminish and you would be left without a privacy cover. The camera also features a clip that attaches to your screen and also has a screw hole to fit onto a camera mount for more flexibility.

Image Quality: Here I was on the fence. The image quality is acceptable to good. It felt more like 1080p than 4K, as advertised. The picture felt a little grainy instead of crisp like other 4K cameras I have used. Colors appear close to how they actually are, so no complaints there. This camera worked very well in my low light room, and this could have contributed to a little more of the graininess.

Other features: This camera comes with an AI feature where the image will follow you around the room while focusing on your face the whole time. While this feature is pretty cool, it stutters when following you around instead of being smooth transitions. For the viewer, this is not very good. Cool feature that needs a little work. The AI can easily be turned off with a button behind the camera. I say button because it does push in, however this button is actually touch sensitive and doesn't need to be pressed at all. My camera has a little typo on this button. On/Of was printed instead of On/Off, which is not that big of a deal, but something worth mentioning.
There was also a remote provided with the camera, where you can access features without having to leave your app/game. This was a welcome extra.

Overall, I think I can recommend this camera. There are a lot of cool features provided. The camera quality may not be actual 4K quality, but I feel the image is good enough for most applications. It's definitely a huge upgrade to any built-in laptop camera, but maybe a little to bulky for smaller laptops.

title: I don't think the noise cancellation works but for me I love them!
text:
If I needed noise cancellation I would probably have to deduct another star from the rating. and the only reason I gave this four stars out of five really is the price for me. as far as the noise cancellation goes the different methods that it has on it sounds like it's more static that it adds to drown out the noise which I am not sure if that's how all noise canceling works but it bothered me so I just turned it off. you do have the ability to do that which is awesome so I just use them as regular earbuds. the second part is the price itself I think is too high. I have the pixel buds which I got for the same price as these and I would say sound wise they might be slightly better. The sound of these are actually really good and I am actually carrying these more than my pixel buds as I think they are a little more comfortable for me.
I wanted the black but only white was available but when I received my order I actually received the black which I was fine with. the case is a little thicker than the pixel buds case. but it is shorter so I think it is probably a little easier to carry as well. I do have a pixel phone and I love the way the pixel buds integrate into the phone as far as some of the features and the way the phone can tell me that charge level of the case as well as each earbud. charging these is the same as you just put them in the case and you can charge the case when it gets down to a certain level. my pixel buds I'm able to see the case level so I know more when I need to charge it versus this case I just try to charge once a week or every other week depending on how often I use these buds. I have had many sessions of three to four hours and they lasted with no warning of needing to be charged. I would say around $70 maybe 80 these would be worth it still. but if you're an Android User I still think the pixel buds might be the best option. I do really like the way these look as well versus the pixel buds. I have not had any issues with these connecting to my phone anytime I open the case and remove a bud. they connect pretty quick one by itself or both. I would definitely recommend if you have a lower budget and if these were cheaper then $100 they would be a great option and work I would imagine for most people.

title: Very weird and funky app.
text:
Important things to note:

1. Requires you to download an app to connect the camera to your Wi-Fi and use an interface to your camera while you are away from home (to watch video events, live stream, and so on).

2. Has cloud service, but I wouldn't.

3. The microSD card slot is on the bottom of the camera -- not the base -- to access the slot, pull the camera away from the base to expose it and the reset switch.

4. From app, go to settings and have it only record video on events rather than record everything. It's not clear from the app or the manual what happens when you run out of space.

5. Format microSD card from the app (it will format as FAT32). I tried it with a 32-GB card, and it appeared to work, but phone app still says 0% used space even after recording a few events and watching them. After pulling the SD card out and putting it on a PC, it indeed hadn't saved anything. I actually had to go to the app settings page and tell it to download the events to the microSD card. After that, pulling it out and putting in a PC, I was able to watch the videos on a PC. The video files are very low-quality TS files.

6. App allows you to remotely activate an alarm (I didn't test it) and remotely talk (I tried it and I could barely make out what I was saying).

I would have given this 4-stars if events were automatically saved to the SD card. It's funny because there is definitely some kind of internal storage, and if you don't have the SD card inside the camera -- you can't watch them EVEN IF THERE'S NOTHING STORED ON THE CARD. They way it works is very sloppy. The app on the app store also has a ton of bad reviews and complaints from users. For example, I can't figure out how to delete video events from within the app. There are lots of things that you think should be by default implemented in this app, but they aren't. It really is very weird. If they fix these things, and make the app easier to use, I'd definitely give it 4-stars.

title: Good sound when deep bass is not needed….
text:
I received the LARKSOUND Sound Bar

I was happy to get this sound bar to have better quality music in my home bar. There isn’t a place for a subwoofer on my bar, so this model best suited my needs in this location. The sound from my Echo Dot was OK, this sound bar is much better. To be clear, the sound is not audiophile quality, but not every location requires audiophile sound and the price that they can cost.

Installation was easy. In my case, the sound bar mounts on the wall under the shelving. Assembly of the sound bar is easy, it has two halves that connect by a single wire and then slide together with groves in the housing. (see pic)

There are multiple input options available: Audio jack, USB-A, Bluetooth, optical and HDMI. I connected the sound bar to my Amazon Echo Dot via Bluetooth. Input type is indicated on the sound bar with different color LED, for instance, Bluetooth is blue. There are different sound options, selectable by remote, including: Standard, Movie, Music, Night, 3D. When playing from the Echo Dot via Bluetooth, the Play/Pause button on the sound bar remote will start and stop the music playing.

Set up and installation took less than 15 minutes, simply connect the parts and plug in. Mostly of my installation was for wall mounting into plaster wall over cement block. The included hardware and template made the placement easy..

The package includes the sound bar, a remote control, an audio cable, an optical cable, two optional wall standoffs for extra space behind for wiring, mounting hardware and wall template and a user guide. (see pic) The remote requires two AAA batteries, not included. An HDMI cable is not included if you plan to connect to HDMI ARC.

If your location can accommodate a subwoofer, I suggest you consider the LARKSOUND 2.1 Sound Bar with Subwoofer from the same brand. It’s not much more cost and the sound is improved by the subwoofer. Otherwise the two sound bars are similar.

I’m very happy with this sound bar and look forward to entertaining with it in my home bar and hope this information has been helpful

title: Just the right size
text:
As soon as I saw the light stand, I knew I had to try it out, it was just the right size to fill in between my handheld gimbal and full-size tripod. It’s easily mobile because of its size, I attached it to my little table on wheels that I can pull over to my workspace when I want to film an assembly video or instructions on how to accomplish something that I can send to a relative.
The unit itself seems sturdy and well-constructed when it’s mounted it’s easy to move back-and-forth or up and down within the limits of its length and with the light mounted above the unit it doesn’t move up or down when you move the main arm, however if you move the unit, you did get a little side to side movement with the light.
This assembly and mounting of the unit were no problem since it's 99.9% assembled all you have to do is attach the light to the frame, however to attach the light to the frame takes a little bit of muscle to make sure it stays stable and doesn’t come loose from the frame when you adjust the light. I found that once you learn how to adjust it, it will stay stable
The light is adjustable for brightness and color temperature to give you about any effect that you want when you’re recording or just a light up your workspace. The power cord for the light is long enough to be able to plug it in with no problems, however it is a USB light, and it ships with no power plug, which is not unusual anymore. The light switch is an in-line switch on the cable, and the length keeps it where it’s easy to reach and easy to adjust the light when you need to. The frame also comes with three cable attachments that keep the cable close to the frame, so you don’t have to worry about it flopping around.
I have three android phones, and it has no problem holding any of them, or allowing me to adjust them anyway I need to for whatever task I’m trying to accomplish. The phone attachment is adjustable and very stable, I haven’t had a problem with my phone moving once I put it in the attachment. From the base to the end of the frame it’s a good solid appliance, and it’s easy to use.

title: Well thought out, but room for improvement.
text:
Introduction:
Let me start by saying that this is a well thought out case and is well worth the asking price. To take full advantage of this case in my opinion, you would need one of the newer higher end motherboards that came with a USB 3.2 header on the motherboard. You will also need a power supply which preferably has a argb fan.

Pros:
- for a full atx case, it is actually very small. You can probably fit an eatx motherboard into this case.
- cable management is well thought out.
- your psu fan can act as an intake fan & also can take air from the front instead of the bottom. This allows you to put the case on the ground comfortably.
- radiator support is very broad and reservoir support is very broad too. The space is open and modular to setup variations.
- has more than 4 spots for 2.5 inch drives.

Cons:
- front has no filter.
- on the cable management side, I think they could have cut out some more holes and allowed for different placements of the hhd trays. For those who use 3.5 inch drives, there is only apparent space for 2 drives or 3 with some slight modification.
- No vertical gpu mounting options. At this price point, it's more of an expectation. Especially since Vetroo has cheaper cases with this option.

Conclusion:
I am comparing this case to a similarly priced Corsair 4000D airflow, I say this case takes the cake with the 4000D getting a ~7.5/10 and this case getting a ~8.5/10. This case is more general than Vetroo's other cheaper options which is good. There's room for improvement with little cost to them. Personally, after a year, I would expect a V.2 of this case with some good improvements for 10-20$ more. Mostly with the aforementioned vertical gpu mount option sold separately, a front intake filter, better hhd mounting options, an option to change out the front for glass, and an option to make the IO to be moved to the top of the case.

Overall - I highly recommend this case over the competition unless there's a feature you absolutely have to have that this case doesn't have.

title: Very Good Backup Solution for Windows and Mac
text:
I ordered to backup my files on my Mac. I had to set up to mount this external HDD for my Macbook Air. There are 3 categories that I wanted to comment on: durability, software and hardware compatibility, and portability.
1st is durability - I would say it looks sturdy, but time will tell if this external portable HDD from Western Digital will lasts for many years to come. I would say this product is great for backup solutions on many categories instead of relying a cloud to store your data, files that are important to you. You actually bring it with you, if you want security.
2nd is software and hardware compatibility - So I have a MacBook air and wanted to back up my files into this Western Digital HDD EasyStore. The name implies for NTS format that is compatible with Windows, so its a plug and play for Windows users. Highly recommend for Windows users. Also buy as much storage you can afford for your budget! That's all I can say. 4/5.
As for the Mac user, there is a separate user software that is 3rd party which you have to install. Or you can choose free software to mount this drive into a Mac compatible. It is not user friendly in my opinion. A free mounting HDD software is performs easily and its functionality is user friendly to users who just want to mount their HDD with one click of a button that does everything rather than go to your System Preferences > Privacy and Security in 4 steps. But I was able to because I know how to do it. But for other users, who cannot figure this out and resort to Support Help Center will have problems. 3.2/5.
3rd is portability - I would say it measures what is has been described on the product listing. It looks sturdy and is well built as a physical product. I haven't tried dropping it, but if you have a case. and labelled it to organize your digital files. Then yes! 4/5.
Budget, as storage space has become little cheaper like 5TB for $138. I would say it's cheaper! You will probably find better deals outside of Amazon. Just wait for sales on electronics after January! I trust Western Digital for its durability, portability and update my files in a very big storage solution. Please take care of your HDD which are like books inside your personal or professional workplace in the digital world. 5/5.

title: Does What It Says It Does . . .  Track A Face. . . But Maybe Too Well
text: This face tracking device is VERY good at recognizing a face, and keeping it centered in the frame.  There's no need for any additional app.  It's self contained.  Just turn it on, and it will recognize the face in front of it, and track that face during the course of fairly natural movement within a 360 degree range.  It will both rotate as you move, and also tilt to keep the face in the center of the built-in recognition camera.  The phone is mounted on top of the tilting base and clamped tight using a thumb screw to close the cushion lined clamp.  This helps to prevent the phone from slipping out during use.  This is really designed for a single person video recording (or streaming) where the person is either remaining stationary or moving within a somewhat limited distance, around the base.  Here is where the limitations of this device really show up.  You can't really step back away from, or close to, the base too far too fast, since it has no ability to adjust your camera focus or zoom.  This is why the movements have to be both natural and somewhat controlled.  The face tracking of this device works so well that it is actually a liability to the product.  Since it works so hard to keep the tracked face in the center of the screen, it's extremely difficult to try to move over to something that you might want to show in your video or stream.  Even trying to step backward to fit some prop in the camera view still doesn't work well, because it will still adjust the rotation and tilt to keep the face in the center of the camera.  And good luck if there is a second face that is present in the viewing space.  It's not feasible at all for conducting a two person interview, again because it will center on the tracked face.  So there is actually a very limited value to this device, based on the limitations of its own technology.  It also awkwardly centers the face vertically, as well.  So often there is a weird camera angle with extra space showing above the person's head.  It doesn't really help to stand up, or even place it on a tripod, to try to change the angle of the phone camera to accommodate.  Maybe requiring no app at all to allow for the user to establish some functional adjustments, isn't really the best idea.  An app may just be the answer to address these issues.

title: Low cost but great quality!!
text:
[[VIDEOID:da1e992d102a455ed13ddb94b4f84bd]] I usually wear over the ear headphones but wanted to get some extra earbuds/pods to always keep in my bag or pocket. I didn’t want to spend the $ on AAP because I was worried about losing them, or even liking the way they fit. I thought I’d buy a few different pair and see how I liked them before making a decision. After looking through all the reviews and products, I settled on these Gunatagy Earpbuds. They fit nicely in my ear and I don’t have issues w them falling out or feeling funny. They arrived already charged and paired instantly upon opening the case and setting them up using Bluetooth on my phone. The earbuds blink red and green to show they’re pairing. I don’t have any issues w losing Bluetooth connection either. It’s very reliable. The amount of power in the case is shown on the front as well as each individual earbud so you’ll always know how much juice you have. The case-like a pod-is also very small and can fit in any pocket. I found the volume to be sufficient for both music and talking although the bass is not overly deep. I didn’t have any problems w my voice being heard on the other end or picking up too much of the noise around me. The sound is also very crisp and clear. Navigating the taps for direction is very simple and the earbuds respond w out needing too much or too little pressure so you won’t have to worry you’ll accidentally swipe it and mess up your song or call. I’m very happy w my new earbuds and would recommend them to anyone looking for something sufficient to AAP but don’t want to break the bank... or even use from it. These are for you! You can buy yourself multiple pairs of these, have many to keep in various pockets or bags, lose one and not feel too bad and still have saved yourself a good chunk of $! Definitely recommend especially for kids whom lose and break things pretty easily. But I suggest getting yourself 2 so you won’t be swiping your kids to use all the time.

I’ll update this review w pertinent info as I get used to them.

title: No better than antennas half the price
text:
Pros:
Easy to set up and connect
Relatively well-built but I would question the durability outside on a rooftop
Works great with local channels

Cons:
Doesn't come close to receiving stated range (85 miles) in suburban environment
No better reception than antennas costing 1/2 to 1/3 the price

I’ve been trying to find an antenna that would receive 5 stations in a neighboring city where the broadcast towers are 40 miles away. I tried several types of antennas from a Yagi, all-in-one units like this, and even a traditional uhf/vhf antenna. None of them would get consistently good reception. So I thought I’d try this “Tesla” of all-in-one antennas before I spent several hundred dollars to have an antenna and amplifier professionally mounted on the roof of my suburban home.

This unit performed no better that the antennas costing half the price. I’m technically literate and have been at this for over a year. I accessed the station list I should be able to receive from the FCC website that shows all the stations in the area, the direction and distance of the broadcast tower, and the reception strength I should expect at my house (in dbuV/m). I have a high-end TV that shows the exact signal strength percent and the amount of interference, so I can objectively compare different antennas.

Unless you enjoy overpaying for an antenna, do not buy this product. I purchased two other antennas that were half the price that resulted in the same signal strength and level of interference as this one. I sent them back too because they didn’t receive the channels I needed.

Note that while most HDTV stations broadcast on UHF frequencies, there are a few that broadcast on HI-V (hi VHF). Check the list from the FCC website for your area and if there are channels listed as HI-V, you’ll need an antenna that receives those frequencies (30 MHz – 300 MHz). This antenna has that capability, but the reception range is really poor.

I’d rate the maximum usable range in a suburban/urban environment, mounted outside, at 30 miles. For attic or inside mounts expect less.

title: MUCH more powerful alternative to Raspberry Pi 4
text:
This is a fully functional desktop PC albeit closer to the level of a Raspberry Pi 4 than a Gaming PC. The Celeron N5105 quad core processor in this is VERY capable especially for this price. Great for every day internet browsing, watching 4k movies, and some retro gaming or even very light weight modern gaming. Even when the CPU was being stressed during gaming, the fan would stay super quiet and could only hear it if I put my ear near the computer.

## Games Tested ##
While I would highly recommend using Batocera for retro gaming, I first tested games out of the box running Windows 11 and then adjusted settings as needed.

- Wii Emulation via Dolphin: Any game I threw at it worked extremely well out of the box with few slow downs here and there. Changing the settings to us a Vulkan backend made everything buttery smooth 100% speed at native resolution.

- N64 Emulation via Mupen64: I played GoldenEye since it's such a classic and generally a more demanding game to emulated and had no issues.

- Final Fantasy XIV: Using the low settings at 1366x768 resolution allowed me to play the game but was usually around 20 FPS. While this is not ideal, it was still usable

- Minecraft: Very playable at 1366x768 with consistent framerate of around 25 FPS.

## Home Server ##
Since this processor supports virtualization, this works as a perfect Proxmox server and run Home Assistant server for automation. You can also attach an inexpensive 2.5" SATA drive to the detachable expansion bay and use it as a NAS as I was able to get full gigabit network speed when transferring files across my home network.

## Overall ##
This is an amazing little computer that's perfect as a HTPC, retro gaming pc, a home server, or even just a light weight desktop. At this price point, the closest competitor would be a Raspberry Pi 4 when adding a case, adapters, and power but this Celeron N5105 powered mini PC is vastly more powerful and capable since it can run any regular Windows program. Also worth noting that I was able to use a USB-C to DC 12v cable to power this computer via my laptop charger.

title: Holds a charge for the whole night, but not a lot of adjustability
text:
I got this sleep mask to replace an older one that doesn’t hold much of charge anymore. I use these mainly if I’m travelling or going on a retreat where I want to block out noise when others are staying up late and making noise even while trying to stay quiet.

I play white noise from several different apps on my phone (there are so many free apps, no need to buy one, just try a bunch).

At first, it took a bit to figure out how it works (the instructions are not helpful and are a poor output from Google-Translate)_ but I finally managed to get it to work.

I like the floral print, and it's comfortable enough -- about like any sleep mask with a speaker.

It can tend to be slightly uncomfortable if I’m sleeping on my side, though. I have to twist it around some so the speaker is not digging into the side of my head. These do hold a charge for the whole night so that is a big plus. The ones I had been using were shutting off after about 5 hours -- and of course when that happens I wake up immediately.

The biggest issue with this is its size and the strap that connects it together to encircle my head. It must have been designed for someone with a much larger head because, when I put it on the smallest strap setting that it can go to, there's no Velcor at the point where it fits my head, but I was able to fold the strap and staple a loop to make it smaller. I'll probably cut it to remove a few inches off the strap and then sew it back together, but it would be nice if I didn't have to, because they could have just made a little buckle or something to take up the excess length.

With my DIY hack to get it to fit, it works okay at keeping the light out and getting the speakers aligned so that the music/sound is where it needs to be. The staple is only temporary until I have time for some sewing, but it works . . . for now.

Overall, a good rating on the battery life, but dropping a star because of the limited range of adjustment -- especially if you have a smaller head. Still, a good value, so four-stars.

title: A fabulous reincarnation of the Logitech Trackman Wheel
text:
I have spent the last five years looking for a replacement for my old Logitech Trackman Wheel mouse (the silver grey unit in the photos). While I purchased a Logitech M575, which is considered a successor to the Trackman Wheel, I never felt it was either as good or as reliable as the original wired Trackman. The connectivity was always subject to interruption and the thing just "felt" different. I tried a variety of other trackballs, both wired and wireless, and all of them had some deficiency. Mostly, the manufacturers, in an effort to differentiate their product from the others, diddled with the ergonomics in significant ways--changing the height, angle or orientation of the trackball, altering the width or height of the entire unit, etc.

This trackball from NULEA (the darker unit in the photos) is the closest I have come to the old Trackman Wheel and I am delighted! The feel is the same and the NULEA has significant improvements from both the wired Trackman Wheel and the M575 replacement, in particular, adjustable cursor speed, multiple connectivity methods (two bluetooth channels and wireless USB via an included USB dongle), and backward and forward keys to the left of the left side button.

Note that the NULEA unit differs from most wireless mice in that it has a rechargeable battery that must be recharged via a USB-C connector. A full charge takes two hours. I have not yet operated this device long enough to require a recharge but I suspect several weeks of daily use will be about average. My approach will be to plug it in at night once every two weeks and not worry about it.

Also note that the unit has a black rectangular button immediately above the track wheel. This adjusts the cursor speed and there are 5 levels---100-200-400-800-1200. 100 is a crawl and 1200 is lightning fast. This is a wonderful improvement since, between selecting a cursor speed on the mouse itself and adjusting acceleration in the operating system settings, one can get exactly the cursor speed they are comfortable with.

A final note of caution. The manual says that the NULEA unit is not suitable for gaming. I am not a gamer so cannot address this but take the manufacturer at their word.

I really recommend this device. It's great!

title: Sturdy rising platform with 3 height levels - no assembly required!
text:
With folks working from home so much and many of them using their dining room tables as their work desk for their laptop/notebook, we often don't exactly have ergonomically designed chairs at the dining room table. Even if you do, sometimes not only does standing up feel good vs. sitting all day, but it's much better for your back being slouched over constantly. This rising desk does the job for when you want to work on you laptop for a bit while standing.

No assembly required! Take it out of the box and it's ready to go. It comes out folded flat and all you need to do is place it on your work area. You can actually leave it at that folded level if you want to work sitting now and standing later. When you're ready to rise it up to stand, it is all controlled with this single lever on the right. Push it downward and you'll be able to raise the table up. Let go of the lever and it will latch on to one of the three height settings to match what height is good for you. I measured from the table you will place this on, to the top of the rising table and it shows the three heights: 8.5", just under 11" and highest is 12.5". When you're done , push down on that level again, raise the table up a little and you'll be able to lower it down. It's really simple to use.

This thing is very sturdy. There is very little play when you place anything on the table but it's built to be very stable, which it has to be. Therefore, it is not light, so be careful with the base which is made of metal and trying to life it carelessly. I accidentally caught my finger on the corner of the base of the table somehow and gave myself a tiny little blood blister. The base does have 4 felt pads to keep it from slipping. but it doesn't give any real rise to the base to give you a grip to lift it off the table. So, just be careful with that.

Otherwise, there is very little else to say other than this was more than enough space for my Surface Pro. It does exactly what it was designed for and it does not feel cheap. I'm very happy with it.

title: It's $40...it's well built, works as intended (mostly), and provides decent audio...and it's $40
text:
The following pros and cons are relative to the price, not to more expensive speakers.

Pros:
Good build quality
Plenty loud
Great for basic computer audio (not sure about sitting further away for TV audio)
Optical audio and usb port
Multiple connection modes

Cons:
It seems I have to re-pair the Bluetooth from my Dell/Windows 10 laptop each day. iPhone connects fine.
Can't adjust volume from PC (Dell/Windows 10). Have to use video player volume, or, for things like Zoom or Teams, I have to use the remote to adjust the volume.
Can't connect more than one device
Bluetooth connection voice is loud and unnecessary

Remember...it's $40. I needed something slightly better than my Dell laptop audio and this works just fine. Don't let the built-in "subwoofer" fool you. It isn't going to sound like you think it's going to. Maybe it provides a bit of a fuller sound.

The company sure does tout this as an awe-inspiring and award-winning sound bar and companies should do that for their products. It's fine. It's $40.

Edit:
Had to remove a star. After having the speaker for a while, I'm about to send it back due to its incredibly frustrating bluetooth connection.
Majority needs to remove the obnoxious voice that says "Connected" and "Disconnected". I can't adjust the volume on it and it's way too loud. Plus, it's unnecessary. Just user a quiet tone instead of a voice.
Also, it doesn't like to play nice with Windows 10 Enterprise. Windows will show the device as "connected" but it's not. It won't appear in system devices as an option. I have to turn off bluetooth on my computer and turn it back on. Then it mutes my system audio and won't allow me to adjust the volume from the OS's volume control. I have to use the remote or the volume control from the music service application.
Sometimes the connection will drop randomly and I have to turn off bluetooth and the speaker and reconnect everything. Thankfully this only happens once a week or so.

title: Small and portable but mighty and powerful
text:
EDIT: gonna dock this one star off, weather's getting warmer so I brought out my small desk fan out of storage, got some dust on it. It Barelyyy took off some dust more specifically off the blades. Still had to open it up, it's not like the dust was hard simply wipe with a paper towel and it came out.
I know if I had the can of air with that little red straw it definitely would've of got in there and blown the dust away. What I stated before is still the same maybe a different attachment nozzle would've of done better. For the high price of $60, I would expect a little more. It's a tiny desk fan and it wouldn't remove the dust.

Came with a nice storage cloth, and only a few nozzle attachments, wish it bought more 'nozzles' possibly a very narrow one for tougher spaces. When comparing other brands I see they include a wider variety of nozzles for the about the same price or less.
4 power modes each increasing in power.
I placed my pixel 6 phone case side to side for a size comparison. If you're looking for portability or easily being able to be stored away this is the one. Cleaned my keyboard and it removed hair, bigger dust bunnies and just grime that gets in there in general.
I would say it removed 80% of the dust just fine but the smaller particles that have been sitting won't come out (probably because I have never cleaned my keyboard)
You will need to dig deeper possibly remove some key caps to get it 100% clean, but that's where the brush attachment comes in handy to help you get as much as possible. I really don't see much use cases for this FOR ME PERSONALLY, I will probably only use this for cleaning my keyboard and PC which I like to clean at least twice a year. This will make it much easier.
I compared prices with other compressed air devices and this seems to be on par more or less with the others. Some slightly cheaper but this one looks of better quality. For the price it seems a bit high, if they bought more nozzles it would be better, but it does what it's supposed to at around similar price compared to others.
Also you don't have to buy cans of compressed air anymore assuming this product has longevity.

title: Nice Product That Works, Just A Few Quirks
text:
This review will only speak to Android Auto use as I don't have an Apple phone and did not use Carplay.

One concern I had when ordering the Ottocast was whether it would work with my head unit since the product description seemed to imply it only works with OEM radios and not after market. I have a Boss BV800ACP and it works perfectly with this after market head unit. I imagine it will work with many others.

The product is a very nice size, approximately the size of a credit card, so it's easy to stash somewhere out of the way. It's very easy to use, just plug it into the OEM port where you would normally plug your phone in to connect to Android Auto. You pair it with your phone and you're done. Easy peasy. The USB C port that you plug into to interface with your radio is recessed (see photo) into an oval shaped hole that is small and restricts the use of many different cables so you have to use the cable provided unless you happen to have one that fits. WHY RECESS THIS PORT IN A HOLE???!!!

Another quirk, the Android Auto screen seems ever so slightly smaller than the screen I use when connected directly to my head unit via a cable. It's barely noticeable, but it's there. Not a deal breaker by any means.

Another disappointment I have is that I still have occasional Android Auto crashes. My hope was that with switching to a wireless connection, this issue would go away. It has not. I may try a different USB cable if I can find another one that will fit that stupid hole. The Android Auto crashes are certainly NOT the fault of this product, but if you're thinking your crashing issues will be a thing of the past, they won't be.

Last, but not least, my boot up times have doubled because now I have to wait for my head unit to boot and THEN wait for the Ottocast to pair and boot up. It all happens automatically so it's not a big deal to me.

Overall, I do love the convenience of not having to plug my phone in or unplug it when I leave my car. The Ottocast does work well overall. If you decide to purchase it though, beware your cable selection will be very limited to connect it.

title: High-quality board. Appears to be fully compatible with standard Nano. Reasonable price.
text:
This is the second MCU board I’ve ordered that was made by Osoyoo. The first was based around a LGT8F328P processor and I was very pleased with the quality and the performance of that. This board purports to be compatible with an Arduino Nano V3.

The product arrived nicely packaged in an attractive cardboard box with the board inside wrapped in an antistatic plastic pouch. The board had been positioned sideways in the box which helped stop it moving around in transit and, importantly, help prevent it from being crushed. A 0.5m USB-A to USB-C cable was also supplied. This board has a USB-C socket which is preferable to the USB Mini-B sockets used on most other Nano boards. The header pins are already soldered onto the board – which is a great bonus for users who don’t like or don’t want to solder these things on or don’t have a soldering iron.

The board components and their layout are almost identical to the official Arduino Nano and most of its clones. The big difference is the inclusion of a small IC labeled “6627” (see photo). It’s not clear what this does but it seems to be something to do with power management or VREF for the ADC.

In use, it worked perfectly. I installed it in a pressure and temperature logging monitor I had develeoped using a standard Nano for use with beer kegs. This circuit utilizes most of the capabilities of an Arduino Nano – I2C, SPI, OneWire, analog in, SD read/write, EEPROM and interrupts. This board from Osoyoo worked well. The only issue I had was with the green power LED on the board – it was intense and hurt my eyes!

Note that no instructions are provided with the product. However, there is a huge amount of information on the internet for a standard Nano device and they should all apply to this one, too.

This is a high-quality device and is sold a lot cheaper than the official Nano board but is more expensive than a lot of other clones – however it does come ready-soldered and with a connecting cable. I could find no issues with its operation or performance (apart from a very intense power LED).

title: Good alternative to the official Apple keyboard folio
text:
PROS:
- Less than half the price of the official Apple Magic Keyboard Folio
- Good quality keys 'feel' good, not cheap feeling
- Added bulk of the case is acceptable
- Apple pencil holder
- Backlit keys
- Nice to show the battery percentage left for the keyboard

CONS:
- Even though it's cheaper, it's still expensive for what it is. ESR is simply taking advantage of Apple's exorbitant price. There is no guarantee the next iPad will fit this case.
- Minimal angle adjustment of the iPad. You get either perfectly straight up/down up to maybe a 10-15 degree tilt max. It's fine most of the time, but would have preferred a little more adjustment.

NOT REALLY CONS for me but had to mention:
- The top number row and the QWERTY row below it are too evenly aligned, it's a little awkward
- Keyboard seems to fall asleep when it wants. Waking it up requires pushing a key, touching the trackpad doesn't wake it.
- Keyboard battery life drops faster than I would expect
- Turning the keyboard on/off is awkward because the iPad sits right above it. The button is simply a tap, not a physical push button. So there's not much room for your finger.
- The official keyboard has dedicated row for adjusting things like brightness, media controls, etc. This keyboard does not have those at all.

Miscellaneous observations:

Someone mentioned in another review that the trackpad can only be physically pushed in order to click on things. This is untrue. Tap to click can be enabled by going into 'Setting > General > Trackpad > Tap to click' This made the trackpad about 100% more usable as it was definitely annoying having to physically push the trackpad to click things. I think that's more of an issue with iOS simply not being that great with a mouse/trackpad. There are more settings in Accessibility that I had to tweak in order to make using the trackpad more usable. I disabled trackpad inertia and pointer animations in 'Settings > Accessibility > Pointer Control'. This made the trackpad behave more like a trackpad on regular laptops.

title: Switches between two computers (with limits), no power supply
text: I got this to better manage two machines I use for work. Having two monitors, I wanted a KVM that supported that. The USB switching works fine (I hooked that up first as I forgot to bring in the 'extra' HDMI cables to connect the computer video outputs up) when no video is connected. There's no power supply for this - which is actually kinda nice since outlets always seem to be in short supply - and the wired switch seems well designed to stay where you want it on a flat surface (the bottom is a rubber-type material that stays put). The switch has a solid click feel to it so you know you've actually triggered it and the case is a nice metal (powder-coated?). After connecting up the HDMI cables I was unable to get either the keyboard or my cordless mouse to work. When I tried a simple USB wired mouse and keyboard I was still unable to get a working mouse or keyboard. Apparently the lack of a power supply has its downsides. If you are OK with either the video switching (and having to set back up your windows after a switch), or the keyboard and mouse switching, this isn't a bad unit - nice small form factor and no external power supply. But, if you need is a switch that will allow you to connect both systems with keyboard / mouse AND video - this thing isn't for you. Since what I mostly wanted was a way to switch the keyboard and mouse (and not the displays) I guess I'm OK with it? The video quality is good and I'm not having any issues with that, it just doesn't switch both the displays AND the keyboard & mouse. One caveat I will say is that one dock (Dell) puts out two DisplayPorts and the other dock (aftermarket) has USB-C and DisplayPort and it could be that if all the video outputs were HDMI then this would work as advertised, but since I don't have those connections, I can't judge that. I really wanted to like this unit and to have it work, but with my setup it just... doesn't. If I connect all the video inputs and outputs, the keyboard and mouse won't respond (but my keyboard still lights up?). Without any video cables connected, it works fine to switch the keyboard and mouse. If I just connect the video cables, it will switch the video. So... depending on what you want this to do, it may work for you.

title: READ ME! General Recommendations. Don't buy this, Samsung Hubs are near end of life.
text:
Short Answer:

V1 Hubs are already dead (bricked and useless). Who knows how long V2 and V3 ones will last.

If you are new to home automation, just avoid this and go use something else. If you are just doing basic automation, there are many options, if you want a more advanced, programmable hub, look at Hubitat.

If you are using Samsung SmartThings and are looking to add or replace a hub and don't run anything advanced through web core, Aeotec makes a hub that is SmartThings compatible.

If you are like me and all of a sudden your WebCore has stopped working because Samsung killed it and you want something better than that level of programmability, check out Hubitat.

Long Answer:

Samsung is in the process of re-imagining their SmartThings app. They are no longer selling hubs and will likely stop supporting these soon. When I bought this nearly 3 years ago, they had a great app built into SmartThings called WebCore that allowed users create custom code driven algorithms called "pistons" that could do a wide variety of tasks. Two days ago, I noticed my scenes based on those pistons just stopped working. My smart house just turned into a remote controllable house. I forgot how much I had those pistons do. Anyway, I then figured out that it wasn't just a hub or some other issue and that Webcore itself is dead (killed by Samsung).

This is unfortunate, since up until this point, this Samsung Hub had been a great product. All of this IOT is a double edged sword here in the 21st century. You can control and automate many things from the other side of the planet. However, somebody, somewhere can also push a button and hack or brick something you physically bought. In general, I try to make as much of my stuff not reliant on a service and host as much of it myself. I try to avoid the big data collectors versions of products (Amazon, Google, Apple). One thing that is nice about Hubitat, is that you can directly connect to it and it is not reliant on a service. That means it can't be bricked as easily.

Good luck out there...

title: Volume control is a pain
text:
I'm no audiophile by any means but the Roku 4K TV I purchased had weak internal speakers. I wanted something that was easy to set up & didn't require any Tech wizardry.

After reading various reviews of systems at higher price points that offered more features that I wouldn't use (Bluetooth, multiple speakers etc.) I decided to purchase this. Shipping was fine & timely, set up was also thank fully easy took less than 10 mins.

After playing around with the settings on the Signa 2 remote for a bit I picked the settings I liked and used the Roku remote to run the TV after that. Changing setting on the Signa remote is very easy if you switch to a movie or music.

There are 3 settings for voice adjustments, I was surprised by how much difference there are between them. I watch a lot of anime and changing between the three really highlighted the difference. On the highest setting the voices are much clearer and more of the background sounds are suppressed.

Likewise the movie setting is very different & you will get a much better overall sound experience with it on when watching movies.

The only real problem is the sound control, while my Roku remote moves the sound volume up & down one number at a time the Signa S2 once it is connected overrides the Roku remote from an audio perspective and adjusts the volume up or down in increments of 3...odd but I have not found a way to change it after several months of use.

At lower volume levels its not so bad but going from 13/16/19 as your only choices in medium levels is annoying. And 22 is other than music always too loud and 10 is too low.

But other than the annoying sound controls the system works very well, much better than the built in speakers. I am listening to this in a 12x15 bedroom so a larger/smaller room may mean volume controls are more important.

As to the overall sound quality to me it is fine, I'm not as concerned when watching TV about sound quality like I would be with head phones for use in gaming or listening to music. If your just looking to enhance the sound quality of your TV coupled with ease of set up & use at a fairly low price point I think you'd be pretty happy with this system.

title: Oh So Close
text:
I am looking for a replacement for my 3rd (or maybe 4th) Microsoft Sculpt keyboard which all quit working after a couple of years because the membrane keys can't hold up to my heavy fast typing. Also I wanted to get a mechanical keyboard like the original Microsoft Natural Keyboard because as nice as the ergonomics of the Sculpt is, the membrane keyboard is very mushy with minimal feedback.

One other feature I was hoping to find was a split keyboard that put some type of cursor controller, either a trackpoint, trackball, or maybe even a small trackpad with left/right mouse keys below it in the otherwise wasted blank space between the two halves of the keyboard. That just seems like such a natural thing to do with that unused space on a one piece split keyboard. My laptop has a trackpoint and I really like using it the times when I use my laptop away from my desk because I don't have to move my hands off the keyboard. The trouble of course with the laptop keyboard is that other than the trackpoint it has absolutely horrible ergonomics that make my hands ache and cramp after just an hour or so of typing.

Also with a way to control the cursor with just a slight shift of my hands on the keyboard to the controllers in the middle, I could finally finally go back to a keyboard with an integrated 10-key, which is so much faster when entering lots of numbers in a spreadsheet, rather than the compact ones like the Sculpt. This is because a full size keyboard puts my mouse too far to the right and by the end of the day my right shoulder aches from the very unergonomic position of the mouse.

So when scrolling through the "ergonomic" split keyboards with mechanical keys here on Amazon, I thought I had found the one that I was looking for from the initial image for this keyboard with some type of controls positioned in the gap. Sadly no. The keys in the space between are just a set of multimedia keys. Sigh.

If anybody from ProtoArc is reading this, you are missing out on a game changing feature (IMHO) to make the entire typing AND cursor control process highly ergonomic rather than making just the typing part better while making the cursor control part less ergonomic. So skip the seldom used media keys and put in some type of cursor control in that space.

title: You can't realistically use the mouse while it is active
text:
[[VIDEOID:a6c8915a1679fb392ec1935a80a1c946]] I purchased this mouse jiggler hoping that I could leave it plugged in, and that it would provide a very small, almost imperceptible movement of 1 pixel every 5 to 10 minutes. Basically enough to keep the computer from falling asleep, but not enough to cause me to click on the wrong thing or distract me.

Wow, was I wrong.

You plug this jiggler USB into your computer's USB port, and you can turn it on by holding the button on the front. As soon as it turns on, your mouse cursor starts rotating in a small circle. The movement is constant and not subtle at all, going around an area about the size of a single desktop icon. Not only does it move constantly, but it also drifts towards the side of the screen in the process. So after a few seconds, your mouse cursor won't be visible anymore. You can take control of the mouse again by moving it physically, but unless you are constantly moving it, it will start rotating again. There are 2 other settings, and it only gets worse form there. The second setting causes the mouse to move around in a much larger circle, about the size of 1/4 of the screen. It completes 1 circle within the same amount of time, so it is very rapidly moving and it looks like it is jumping around. The final setting is so eratic that the cursor just appears to be randomly flashing across the entire screen.

The only reason I'm giving this 2 stars (instead of 1) is that technically it does work, and it should keep your computer from falling asleep when it is turned on. But instead of something subtle running in the background, it is very disruptive of mouse function while it is turned on. It is something you would need to actively switch on and off when you step away from your computer. I don't know about you, but that kind of defeats the purpose, since I often stand up not expecting to be away from my computer for more than a few moments. It might be useful to you, such as in a situation where you need to plug it in, turn it on, and immediately walk away from the computer. But I threw it straight in the trash as soon as I realized how wild the movement was. 2 stars.

title: Wow!!  Powerful & versatile speaker! Tozo has done it again!!
text:
[[VIDEOID:319b2ef079eb5bcbbeb63462bcf26257]] I'm really impressed with the quality of this portable Bluetooth speaker. My husband claimed it to use in his workshop shed. I supplied a short sample video showing that you can hear it over a skill saw that is loud and echos inside his shed.(I had to becareful not to cause a copyright issue with music so its not the best audio example but gives an idea)

We have almost every Tozo earbud model they make. Each of us in our family has a favorite, mine is the T10, our daughter with very small ears despite being a young adult was thrilled to discover the A3, and my husband has two favorites, both are in the noise canceling line(NC9 and I forget the other).

But this speaker is something each of us want.
It's so versatile, it has a microphone which is missing from many Bluetooth speakers. The sound quality is amazing, especially at this price point. I have one from another brand in a similar size that doesn't offer the lanyard, microphone, waterproof, nor is it as loud and clear as the Tozo, but I paid $119 for it.

I'm buying multiple ones for our cabin to use indoors and out. I plan to test it out on a kayak/camping trip soon to.

I can't believe the price point.
I never expected to like it this much and definitely didn't think I would be buying more for the Spring/Summer coming up. I borrowed it today from my husband's shed to listen to a podcast while I planted seeds that will be transferred to my garden in a few weeks & I plan to "borrow" it again from my husband while planting my garden.

Other pros, it connects easily, has a long battery life, looks nice, easy to use buttons, nice weight and it stays connected it doesn't drop off like some others I've owned.

I honestly can't think of a con other than it's going to be hard to clean where there's the grid and dirt/debris falls in it especially in his workshop, but then again, it will match the rest of his items with saw dust on them.

title: Good Product Marred by Outdated Labeling
text:
I’ve been using computers since the 70s when storage drives of this size didn’t even exist and a 5MB (not GB) might cost you $5,000.

Here we have a 128GB USB flash drive for $19 or so.

We’ve got a winner, right?

Well, sort of. If you don’t mind traveling back a few years – quite a few.

First clue? The box states several operating systems long relegated to antique shops such as Windows Me, Vista, 2000, Me and NT.

Wow! I can finally fire up that relic Compaq PC I discovered at the garage sale!

But the ad does state USB 3.0, so why should I complain?

Because it comes delivered in a package that states nothing to that effect. Plus, those operating systems mentioned above didn’t allow the 3.0 standard because it wasn’t around yet; however, to be fair anything marked USB 3.0 is backward compatible with 2.0 and 1.0.

On the plus side, it looks nice, holds a lot and comes with a nice lanyard ring for hanging on bulletin boards, etc. In addition, since it’s a single piece unit (except for the ring) you don’t have caps to get lost.

As for capacity, it states 128GB but shows 119GB when I checked. Slightly over 8GB was reserved for some drivers. I wasn’t interested in checking them out so I formatted the drive and now it holds 128GB.

So, is it truly USB 3.0? So far, from what I can tell, yes it is. An easy way to tell?

Look at the open end that plugs into your PC. If the tab is white, it’s 1.0. Black is 2.0 and blue is 3.0.

This drive does work, looks nice, has an lanyard instead of a cap and that earns it 3 stars. I dropped a couple only because the packaging needs a good deal of updating.

title: Great audio with good soundstage and imaging. Perfect for FPS games.
text:
Comfort:
Disclaimer: I have a large head and large ears that stick out. My ears do touch the inside driver wall just barely enough to cause discomfort and pain after a couple hours of wearing these. I have "fixed" or modified them so that my ears do not touch. Now they are comfy and make me happy ^_^

Sound:
These are open backs. They have no sound isolation. Do not get these if you are going to use them in a noisy environment or if you are going to bother others because they will be able to hear what you hear. If you're in a room and alone then these will be great for you as the sound "leakage" is not so drastic that the sound would go through walls or a room with a closed door. These are not speakers. Just wanted to get that out there.

They are tuned to be more neutral. If you like a lot of bass then these are not for you. They have bass and they respond really well to EQ adjustments but they are, by default, tuned neutral.
They are terrific for gaming IMO. The bass is clear and quick and does not muddy the mids or interfere with the mids at all. This is perfect for trying to listen for footsteps or other audio cues within games.

They are easy to drive or power off motherboard audio jacks. I have an Aorus Elite WiFi motherboard and the onboard audio easily drives this headphone. I just recently bought a Fiio K5 Pro amp/DAC and have them plugged into that and they sound pretty good.

I am impressed with the soundstage, imaging, and clarity of this headphone. In BF2042, I can easily hear enemies as they're running around a base or cap area. They produce sound quickly so even with intense firefights these don't get messy or jumbled at all. They produce each and every sound and move onto the next sound without issue. This is huge for those firefights where bombs, gunfire, magazine reloads, footsteps, vehicles, and everything is happening all at once.

This headphone offers a lot of performance and great sounding audio for their price point. Nothing really competes with them except maybe the DT 990 Pro 80 ohm. Those have more bass but the 560S I find better at speed and clarity.

title: Well made for the price, and the coax physically is exactly as advertised.
text:
This is by all indications a well-made jumper, exactly as advertised. I took mine apart to get a better idea of the quality, and here's what I found.

First, it arrived coiled up as in the attached photo. I don't care for the tight bend in the cable on the end with the SMA connector. They didn't do that to the end with the BNC connector, so there wasn't a need to do that to the other end.

The connectors at each end are crimped on and each end is protected with a significant length of heat-shrink. It is thick and very tough, providing some additional strain relief on the crimp connection as well as protection. Underneath the heat shrink was the crimp connection. On inspection I would describe the quality of the crimp as between good to very good. It's not as good as the crimps on some high-quality jumpers I have, but it's more than suitable for the intended purpose.

I stripped off some of the PVC jacket (very thick and tough) and found a very good tinned braid underneath. Under the braid the dielectric was coated with an adhesive foil, just as advertised. The center conductor is solid copper.

Overall it appears to be a very good jumper for the price. I can't comment on how long the cable will last (coax does wear out), but it seems to be well made with good coax and connectors. The jumper is not advertised as being suitable for outdoor use; I would say this is good for indoor use and temporary outdoor use as long as it's not subjected to rain or similar. I will certainly be able to get some use from this around my Amateur Radio station.

My only major concern with this jumper is the lack of labeling on the coax itself. The only thing the coax has on it is its type (RG8X) and the fact that it's low-loss (see picture). And a number. All good jumpers are made with coax that has a lot of information printed on it, including things like the manufacturer, information about the jacket, and possibly thermal and electrical properties of the cable. This coax is probably just fine, but if the company wants to really win the respect of the techie types, the coax should provide more information on it.

title: Great sound quality, unique look, solid IP rating, mixed battery life | Comparison Review
text:
I got two different pairs of bone conduction headphones to try. I had wanted something not in the ear but also not over my ears. Result of working at home and needed to be more aware of what else is happening and being able to help. Bonetalker 10 1/2 by Sazooy was one pair and the other is the KingLucky (ASIN B0B6TSSLPL) shown in one of the images above. I will compare both but highlight the differences mostly.

The Bonetalker battery life is the weakest aspect IMO. The headphones will run out of battery if you are sitting around wearing them versus exercising which brings it own time limits. KingLucky is much longer, likely due to the two large parts behind the ears. Bone conduction headphones versus earbuds do not sound as good due to how the sound is transferred. The Bonetalker was noticeably better of the two pairs and almost on par with some lowerend earbuds I have used. KingLucky's sound quality is not terrable just not on par with Bonetalker. The two pairs are very divergent in how they look, market, and even while being used. Bonetalker is smaller but looks much more energetic. And yes the "monster" you see in the box can be detached from the plastic frame and mounted to hold the Bonetalker when not being used. KingLucky is very low key and staid in appearance so it is more a choice of your style. Bonetalker lists itself as IPX6 while KingLucky lists itself as IP55. Bonetalker provides no dust raiting (X in IPX6) but a higher water raiting, so should be better able to stand up to exercise, rain, and other water events. Bonetalker survived me taking a shower while KingLucky failed when I was out in a rainstorm. KingLucky was replaced with the same product and I have been more careful about water since. In theory, KingLucky is more "beach" capable since it had a dust intrusion raiting in addition to water but I have not evaluated this factor.

Overall both pairs have pluses and minuses so it is really about the features and capabilities you are looking for to decide which is the right pair for you.

title: Supports SmartPhone/Tablet/AndroidTV box & No BlueRay DVD Support & a bad USB-C cable
text:
----------update
