Remodeling my room this spring season, using this as a temporary docking station to charge my smartphone host device while enjoying my self with external HDMI connected 27" 4K monitor for DVD titles or playing an android game through my smartphone + game controller, I notice while through the external HDMI connection, there's random screen disconnect and reconnect (audio too), a bit of HDMI latency lag noticeable for trained eyes. Interesting hybrid product hope they improve on future revisions.

----------update
After contacting support they gaved me a bit more confidence of troubleshooting effort.

Initially, I had a bit of difficulty getting it work under DVD play mode when using the factory cable via HOST port connection to all my SmartDevices & Android TV box.

Tested:
Sony Xperia 1iii
Lenovo Tab P11
Tanggula Android TV Box

Pros:
* Plays DVD titls
* Plays & Rips Music CDs
Convenient travel use with additional ports
* PD Port, convenience to use PD chargers or battery bank
(when not using PD Port, while HOST is connected, it will draw power from your smart device or computer, but not hot swappable)
* HDMI port for PC/Laptops to extend as 2nd monitor display (but only 4K 30Hz - untested)
* Additional USB-A ports x 2 (maybe they are USB-2.0)
* Additional Micro-SD card port

Cons:
No BlueRay Support
Requires additional small purchase on Android app store,
(the TrueDVD, i had to purchase twice for my 3 devices for some reason my TV Box don't see existing purchase - no big deal)

Summary:
I bought "I Dream of Genie" from amazon, and for the longest time didnt have chance to watch it until recently. I wanted something simple to connect, portable & functional for my mother as a gift, as she has alot of DVD titles she wish to watch and enjoy, this will be perfect for her to use on the road with out learning to operate a computer.

title: No issues so far 🤗🤓
text: Using i9-13900KS with Thermal Grizzly Contact frame + Kryonaut Extreme, EK Quantum Velocity 2 water block and 2 all copper radiators ( 3 x 120 TOP and 3 x 140 FRONT) in series just for the CPU cooling. Using G.Skill 64 GB DDR5 6400 RAM F5-6400J3239G32GX2-TZ5RK, Asus Tuf 4090 GPU, EVGA 1300P+ power supply, Samsung 990 Pro 1TB, SK Hynix P41 1TB, SK Hynix P41 2TB, WD Red 14TB, HGST 6TB. Asus Xonar Essence STX sound card, Samsung 49" Odyssey G9 curved and MORE....  Have been running the board a couple of weeks. Using the 10GB Ethernet to my Mikrotix cloud router to SFP+ port. Using latest BIOS, I turned off 1gb NIC, integrated sound and Wifi 6 in the BIOS. So far so good. Not having any issues. This replaced my 4 year old Threadripper 2950x CPU and X399 motherboard. It was stupid fast and honestly I had no real reason to upgrade except to stay current and take advantage of PCIexpress 4 or 5 NVMe drive speed. It is my job to stay current so I may advise my customers I service in the I.T. field on real world experiences. I cannot do that using old hardware so I try to upgrade at least one of my machines every 18-24 months.  I have built multiple i5-13600k and i7-13700k machines in the last 4 months. Honestly the i5 is plenty fast for most people including for gaming.  There was an Amazon review before mine about the Thermal Grizzly contact frame. I had zero installation issues.  My frame came with two sets of screws. One set is too short but I had no issues with the height of the IHS or frame. My temps are barely warm given the cooling capacity I have.  CPU Idle Temps are 29-32 C for this i9. Not sure about loaded. I haven't done anything to remotely stress it. My gripe to Asus is that the motherboard box is rather wimpy for this motherboard. I can barely store the do-dads, wires and misc documents for this build in such a pitiful box. Please step it up in the future.

title: Nice Camera, But Not 5gHz
text:
I ordered this to replace an existing AC powered security camera that does not have pan/tilt capability.

Although this camera is advertised as being capable of connecting to 2.4gHz or 5gHz WiFi, that was not my experience. When going through the setup process, the app had a red "X" through the 5gHz option, even though my WiFi is dual band. Other than that glitch, the setup process went pretty smoothly. I already own another camera from this manufacturer, so I already had the app and was registered. If this is your first camera from this manufacturer, you'll need to download the Android or iOS app and register.

The app allows you to view the camera's video and set up basic functions. If you want to save videos, however, you'll need to either install a microSD card or sign up for the paid cloud service. I went with the SD card option. You can set the camera to start recording when it detects motion. If motion is detected at night, when the camera is operating in infrared (IR) mode, an option allows for a spotlight to turn on. Like most LED spotlights, you would not want to be looking straight at it when it goes on. When the spotlight is on, enough light is produced to allow the camera to go back into full color mode. You can also set the camera to follow movement. I tried walking past the camera both in daylight and in IR modem, and it automatically panned to keep me in the frame. That's a very nice feature that is not always included in similarly-priced cameras.

The video from this camera is clear and stable and it maintains a solid WiFi connection at about 75 feet from the nearest WiFi access point. This camera is supposed to allow for two way audio. While I was able to listen to the audio signal produced by the camera, I was not able to talk through the camera. Each time I pressed the microphone icon in the app it produced an error. If two-way audio is important to you, you might want to keep my experience in mind.

If you want a camera that produces high quality video, will pan to follow movement, and will operate with either a microSD card or with a paid cloud service, this camera is worth considering.

title: Nope.
text:
My cat destroyed my last laptop with a scratch. Thus, I did not even open the box to my new laptop until I was ready to install the screen. In other words, the laptop was brand new and clean.

Nevertheless, I followed the video instructions and cleaned the screen twice. But it was pretty upsetting because the laptop screen looked spotless even before cleaning but these films already looked dirty and dented. I could literally see two bubbles on one of them before even beginning!

To be fair, I think the dust and tiny hairs were likely from my home even though I swept and cleaned the desk before starting this project. (At least I hope they were from my home but who knows?)

Because there are no instructions included in the project (why?) and I couldn't find my cell phone at the time, I opened the package and then didn't begin the project until the following day. (I had to find my cell phone in order to view the instructions online.)

BUT I had not opened the plastic packages to the screen protectors at all. I'd only opened the envelope. If properly protected, the screen protectors should have remained entirely clean. And neither one was. And both had scratches and were dented. Maybe Amazon shipping was to blame?

Regardless, the plastic packaging wasn't sealed which I think is ridiculous considering how important it is for these screen protectors to be spotlessly clean.

I gave it a go anyhow because this is what I had to work with. The results were predictably awful. In the video, the woman who's installing her screen protector ends up with only a bubble or two. Half of my screen is bubbles. The credit card thingy is not effective at all and I've now wasted both "screen protectors".

This was a definite waste of money for me and a bunch of plastic for the landfill 😭

Two stars because other people seem to have had better luck and maybe this was just a faulty set of films damaged during delivery or something. But I'm super disappointed and definitely would not have bought these if I'd have known how they would have turned out after all the work and wait.

To the manufacturer: Seal the plastic bags that you ship them in!

title: This is the best desktop for the price on Amazon
text:
I took the RME 9632 PCI Audio Interface Card from my old system & installed it in on the new system. The computer came ready to do the job i needed it to. My last DAW Computer was about to bite the dust. So i needed a replacement fast. The system had great specs for the price & Win 10 Professional which was a requirement.

I produce music for a living so this is functioning as my main DAW alongside a high-end laptop. I'm using this to run DAW Software along with the software for my MPC & a bunch of plug-ins etc. It's operating perfectly so far but i would have paid extra for something like a crucial SSD, especially given how important the OS drive is & the fact that's what failed on my last system. Granted it was a Mechanical HDD not an SSD...still i would have paid a little extra for some peace of mind. That said nothing is wrong everything is working & it came with a 4790 CPU perfect for my needs, the single core speed on this chip is great. Between that, the 32GB of RAM & the 1TB SSD running Win 10 Pro with an optical drive which is nice to have it's more than decent for the price. Better than anything else i could find. As i said Win 10 Pro was a requirement, i won't be moving to Win 11 anytime soon. I haven't had to use the sellers tech support yet (thankfully) but they responded quickly when had a question about the compatibility of my PCI Audio Interface Card.

Aside from that the Dell Optiplex 9020 mini tower is a tooless system easy to upgrade if necessary. It came perfectly packed along with the biggest mouse pad I've ever seen (maybe desk pad would be a better description) a great wi-fi card which worked without having to do anything except attach the bunny ears & push the button on my Router. It also comes with a decent wireless mouse/keyboard combo, so you're good to go if you need a working system & already have a monitor. A few years ago this computer would cost a couple racks. So not for nothing as long as it stays working, I'll be able to do great work with this upgraded Dell OptiPlex 9020 PC Tower.

As of right now it's working perfectly. 10/10 will update review if anything changes.

title: No integration with Sound bar, No integrated way to use USB for pause / ‘rewind’, Great picture
text:
Pro:
1. Picture quality is fantastic.
2. The usual ‘Smart Tv’ features are built in - streaming channels, web TV, etc.
3. There is some ability to customize the Smart TV Home Screen , once you figure out how to use the LG interface. It is quite ‘busy’, far more stuff on the Home Screen than is necessary. If you are not used to Smart TV’s and streaming it could be overwhelming at first.

Cons:
1. No built in ability to use a USB drive to have pause / rewind capability in USA (the older models used to have this enabled), there is not even a volatile 30 minute memory for this. IGNORE documentation on the net that references Time-shift, it is NOT available on LG TV’s in the US. This means an external product / service needs to be purchased to have the ability to pause / rewind.
2. The sound mode choices on the TV are disabled if you connect a sound bar. So you either need to buy a more expensive sound bar that provides a variety of sound modes (if there are any that have this) or be satisfied with back to basic simple bass adjustment that is on most sound bars. The TV sound without a sound bar is not very good quality, as is the case with most TV’s. If you want versatile, great sound, an external high end sound bar will need to be purchased.
3. Magic remote pointer is awful, jumpy, moves around, making selection on the screen difficult. Learn to immediately use the arrow keys instead whenever that screen pointer shows up! Arrow keys will disable the pointer until you press the ‘wheel’ / OK button again.
4. Directions on how to find the Live TV guide are poor. Rest assured, there IS an onscreen TV and channel guide.

Summary -
The picture is fantastic.
There is definitely an adjustment period to get used to: not having pause/rewind on Live TV, constantly having to disable the on-screen cursor, and not having sound mode options on my mediocre sound bar. It will go into a spare bedroom and be replaced by a different brand when I have enough funds to make that happen.

title: BEWARE SELLER WILL HARASS YOU. Worked great at the beginning…
text:
Edit 1/27/23: second message asking me to download a sketch file and asking me to email them outside of the amassing messaging system. I contacted amazon and was given a full refund through them. Purchased a different brand which worked better out of the box that this paperweight ever did. I’ll be reporting every single spammy harassing message I get from this company to Amazon, and if they keep messaging I’ll contact Amazon again and file a full harassment compliant.

Edit 1/25/23: Seller sent me a message offering a full refund which I accepted. Next message? “Download this strange file then send us your email so we can update your unit” after I clearly wrote here that I flashed new firmware and it works as long as I don’t hit any bumps. Talk about a bait and switch - and asking for a purchasers email address? Nope. This company is a scam. Beware.

Purchased last March (2022), and it worked great until about July when it started disconnecting from the phone for what appeared no reason. I unplugged it and went back to plugging in my phone directly because I was too busy at the time to try to figure out the problem.

Recently I decided to give it another go. I plugged the unit back in to my 2021 Mazda cx-5, installed a firmware upgrade, and it reconnected to my phone right away. I figured I was back in business.

I live in the northeast. It’s winter. There are many, many potholes. Potholes you can lose a car in. I hit a pothole and bam, CarPlay disconnected. “Bluetooth item not found” came up on the screen…then the screen showed the Bluetooth name for the unit, and then my phone reconnected. Okay…maybe a one-off…

Nope. At this point, you whisper the wrong way and it disconnects. It’s not the wiring in the car, either. I’ve swapped back to the iPhone cord and no problems. Go back to wireless with this thing and it disconnects constantly. I guess it was great for the four or so months before whatever connection inside it decided it wasn’t going to stay stable.

title: Almost useless as a security camera — cannot record continuous video
text:
These cameras work well, and are reasonably good for live viewing. The solar charger works surprisingly well. There are, however, flaws in the firmware that make these cameras almost useless as security cameras.

The cameras will not record anything other than 10-second clips when motion is detected. The duration of the clip cannot be changed by the user. Also, the cameras cannot be set to record continuously. If you try to review footage, other than the 10-second clips from when the camera detected motion (which it is not very good at doing), you get a message saying “No video available at the momento.” (see image).

It doesn’t matter if you are trying to record on the SD card or with their optional, subscription, cloud service. Continuous recording is not available at all on these cameras.

It is possible that they designed it like this because they built these with inadequate batteries. If this is the case, the battery choice was a poor one. But even if this is the case, you should be able to use continuous recording if you supply constant power to the unit. They did not allow for that either. There is just no way to get the camera to record continuous video.

The best you can do is set the motion-sensitivity to high, and hope that it catches important events. Most of the time it doesn’t.

Netvue acknowledges this recording issue, but has outright stated (on their forum) that they have no intention of fixing the problem.

One other thing that I’ve noticed is that the camera never records video of obvious movement, if I am watching the live view of it. Because it has so much trouble detecting motion, I can’t say for certain if this is a motion-detection flaw, or if it truly cannot record anything if you are watching the live stream. Either way, it makes it a pretty undesirable security camera.

I’m hoping that Netvue will eventually take responsibility for their mistakes and fix them.

As it is now though, buy this camera only if all you want to do is occasionally watch a live stream that you don’t need to record. If you want to be able to review footage, look at other brands.

title: Great audio, great battery life.
text:
I've been using these for about a week now. While I haven't used them constantly, I've had several multiple-hour music sessions, quite a few hours on YouTube, and a full-length movie. Not only do I have yet to have to recharge them, it's still reporting that the battery level is "high" when I turn them on. (Update: Battery lasted almost three weeks of very regular use! Impressed!)

They are light weight and have been very comfortable to wear for long stretches of time, I've forgotten I was even wearing them.

I am comparing these to an older but far more expensive set of noise cancelling headphones which these are meant to replace. These easily outperform the noise canceling, and the audio quality is certainly on par with those. As with any noise canceling I've experienced, it works best in lower pitches. It's not a complete silence of outside noise by any stretch, but it dampens it so that the audio more easily overpowers the background- and it does a good job. My workbench is sharing my garage, so I'm around an AC unit and other annoying sounds and it's very nice to be able to block those out and enjoy my music with good audio at a volume that doesn't hurt my ears.

The audio quality is very good, I am able to hear a full spectrum from lows to highs and everything between. Quality audio while I'm listening to my music is something I really appreciate, and these perform at least in the same league with the best I've owned.

There is an "aux in" to allow the headphones to operate in a wired mode. It only works when the headphones are powered off, meaning that there is no noise canceling when running in the wired mode, and the audio response is noticeably not as good. But it's nice to have, in case the battery dies or something while on a trip, or you want to use them with something but not pair the bluetooth. They will also not operate while charging, which is a little of a bummer, but given the battery life that's really not a big problem at all. The control buttons on the side are easy to locate by feel, and work as expected.

I am very pleased with these!

title: Another head banger by Soundcore.
text: A lot of reviewer's on U tube claimed these earbuds have too much bass to really enjoy, let's keep it real, all earbuds these days  have to be adjusted, this is not back in the day where everything was set straight out of the box, and it was all about the quality of your CD'S and CD player or cassette players, now days you have to be your own sound engineer, these earbuds are capable of any particular sound you want or need, Soundcore have a very unique companion app, once you become familiar with your custom EQ settings you can apply it to all your Soundcore earbuds, with noise cancellation on, it will give you a more bass driven sound, ambient mode will make it sound thinner, normal mode will make it sound flat. Keep in mind, your phone has a EQ running at the same time from the phone internal settings, they may conflict with each other, turn your phone EQ off then start your custom EQ settings on the earbuds app, then turn the phone EQ back on and adjust the earbuds again, then compare which sounds better to you, I have a 3rd party EQ app that will enhance every aspect of the sound of any headphones or earbuds, after the proper adjustments, these earbuds is almost perfect, also keep in mind you have to the right size ear tips to seal the best sound. All your music will not be digitally mastered on the same level from the recording studios, some may have a HD, hi res sound, and some may not, if certain songs seems like it's lacking something, it's not your earbuds, it's the sound quality of the song, to correct that problem, all you have to do is create several EQ settings with different highs and different lows and name them, you can create the best sound quality for any song. Soundcore is on top of their game, they create great sounding product's, but at the same time, they leave it up to you to create the best sound you like. Although these earbuds are considered sports earbuds, they're really high performance earbuds for any occasion. The reviews that said the bass is too much, that only tells me they don't have a clue on what they are doing. There's a android EQ app that can solve all their problems for free. To Anker Soundcore, Thank You. You are truly appreciated 👍

title: Roomy backpack for laptop - full of pockets and storage spaces
text:
I'm a big backpack user (I don't wear "purses") so this appealed. This laptop backpack is super versatile. The manufacturer addressed many needs in its well-thought-out design. INSIDE: It's roomy, with a light gray polyester lining. The description says it can fit up to a 15" laptop in one place and 17" in another place in the padded section (NOTE: I fit my 15.6" laptop which is 14" L x 10" W laptop in there and I'm pretty sure 17" would also fit). The padded opening is approx. just under 12" across. There are pockets and zippered sections on all 4 interior sides of the bag, including space dedicated for pens. Even with the laptop loaded in the bag, it offers plenty of room for additional materials such as papers, files, and books.

OUTSIDE: The bag is made of water-resistant polyester. I ordered the grey for something different than my usual black color preference. It's handsome. The bag comes with two exterior nylon zippers in fashionable bright silver with silver pulls. The bag features two large slightly expandable side pockets for a water bottle or other objects. The back side has a black canvas band that can fit over the handle of other luggage for piggybacking a ride. Under the band is another wide hidden zipper. ADDITIONAL BAG: This product comes with a separate matching smaller bag with its own number of pockets for storage. It can be used separately as a purse (a strap is included) or can be cleverly snapped onto a canvas strip that runs across the front of the backpack bag, so it piggybacks on the larger bag. Great idea and looks nice. The opening at top of the laptop bag is large and wide and has two strong hidden wire supports. The stitching is clean and linear. The top of the bag features a handle in case the owner doesn't wish to wear it backpack-style.

USB PORT: The laptop backpack has another useful feature, a built-in USB charger on the outside that connects to a built-in charging cable on the inside. as a way to charge one's phone while on the go. The bag owner needs to provide the power bank if using this feature; it's not included. It's a well-designed laptop backpack (and additional bag). I hope this information is helpful.

title: Scorp Mini
text:
I have a regular SCORP in addition to the Mini. The things I like most about them, compared to my DJI Ronins, are bang for the buck with respect to features, options, and form factor. The Ronins are nice, but they are straight. I like the SCORP handles because I can easily drop the camera down low and hold it comfortably. I film pets and use things like skateboards for movement, so holding the camera low to the ground is important.

Is the SCORP series better than the Ronins? I wouldn't say that but I will say that they are more affordable and cover my needs.

The Mini comes with hardware to attach a cell phone, GoPro, and smaller mirrorless cameras. It can also handle "regular" sized mirrorless cameras, but you are limited to smaller lenses. I have a Nikon Z6 II, and it was the first camera that I tried with the Mini. I got it to work with small telephoto lenses, but it seemed awkward. So, I check the camera and lens compatibility lists. Surprise, surprise. It turned out that the Z6 II is officially compatible with only one lens - and I don't own that lens.

So, I switched to my small mirrorless camera, the Canon M6 Mark II. I didn't even check the compatibility list because it is considerably smaller than the Z6 II. It balanced much more easily, and it worked without any problems at all.

The number of options and features exceed my needs. That's always a good thing. It works just fine, except for a soft shuddering that occurs when I first start it up. I don't know what triggers that shuddering or what it is doing, but because it doesn't hinder me at all, I figure it's not a defect but a feature.

The Quick Start Guide is not worth much. The diagrams are too tiny and difficult to understand. Toss it and go straight to the manual. I didn't see a manual. Maybe I lost it. I simply downloaded the PDF manual, and I was good to go.

If you think that your camera might be too big, check the compatibility list/chart. If you have a smaller mirrorless camera, cell phone, or GoPro, you should have no problems. Recommended.

title: Incredibly useful device for emergencies, camping, hiking, and more
text: [[VIDEOID:19972c12c4846bdd8dd7a5cf675b9735]] See my video review as well for a demonstration.  This product is incredibly useful and packs a lot of great features in a small package that would come in very handy in an emergency, power outage/storm, or while camping or hiking.  I'd even go so far as to say I'd probably keep one of these in the trunk of my car as well as a 'just in case' item.  For starters, there is an AM/FM and Weather band radio with pull-out antenna that allows you to listen to important radio broadcasts or weather information in the event of an emergency or bad weather - the speaker quality is so-so, but it's good enough for hearing voice transmissions very well, which is all you really need for this type of device.  Then, there is the powerful LED torch on the front of the device paired with two powerful LED panels that can be switched on in any combination to create a flashlight or floodlight. Additionally, under the solar panel, there is an additional, extremely bright LED light panel that can be turned on separately from the rest to provide another floodlight source if necessary. There's also an SOS button on the back of the device which, when held down, will start a very loud, piercing siren along with a bright, flashing LED to attract attention.  As a plus, the device also has a port for you to plug in your cell phone or other USB-chargeable device and get power from the radio's built-in rechargeable battery.  Speaking of battery, you can not only charge the internal battery with the included USB power cable from an electrical source, but you can also flip open the solar charging panels to recharge the battery when strong overhead sunlight is available.  In an emergency, there is also a hand-crank that will recharge the battery as well.  It also has helpful LEDs on the side that let you know when charging is taking place as well as how much battery power is remaining.  On top of that, the manufacturer included a spot for 3-AAA batteries so that you can power the radio on battery power as well if desired.  All of this in a very lightweight and easy to use device that will easily fit in your backpack, trunk, or other camping gear bag.  I now consider this a must-have product in my household.

title: The best monitor I’ve found for my home security system
text:
This monitor caught my attention as the listing states “Use for Home/Office/Security.” And I certainly needed some help viewing my home security cameras. I’ve tried 3 different brand 22” 1080p monitors with dismal results. As I’m using this Viewedge monitor for my 7 camera home security system, this review will discuss that use exclusively. If you’re interested in this monitor for computer use, other reviewers have presented very informative reviews.

The camera system I have automatically shifts from daylight (color) to Infrared (monochrome) as the sun goes down. It was really the monochrome (aka black & white) video that presented the problems with the other monitors I tried. Color rendition during the day was ok but the b&w had too much contrast. Adjusting the contrast and brightness for the darkest areas washed out the other 90% of the picture. I added additional IR lighting outside which helped but didn’t solve the problem. But the Viewedge monitor solved the problem both simply and elegantly.

The listing for this monitor states “wide viewing angle” which refers to the horizontal viewing angle. What it doesn’t state is that it has a large vertical viewing angle also. In all of the other monitors I tried, the image washed out terribly when viewed from above or below. In the Viewedge monitor all that happens is a slight loss of contrast most noticeable in the darkest parts of the image. And that is perfect at correcting the night time viewing problem I had.

The monitor is wall mounted above and slightly to the right of my computer monitor so that motion on the monitor will catch my attention in my peripheral vision while I’m working on my pc. I had to adjust the brightness and contrast for the best picture, but the picture is now superb. I look up at the monitor at about a 20 degree angle and can easily see details in the previously dark edges of the camera video. Color rendition during the daytime is great. Viewing from below only decreases contrast slightly. And of course with the wide viewing angle I can see the cameras’ video from anywhere in the room when I’m standing although I do lose the optimized b&w view if I’m not at the computer.

This monitor has made a huge difference in my security system.

title: Large backpack with a couple nice techy features
text:
Overall, this is a nice backpack. It does not have the numerous pockets as others but those also cost twice as much. For this price point, this is a good choice. If you need multiple small pockets to organize items, look elsewhere.

This backback does a good job at carrying various items of tech. The padded laptop sleeve is in the back which rests against your back when carrying. The padding will help keep it from feeling uncomfortable against your spine. The straps are nice padded as well with mesh to help them breathe if they get a little damp from sweat on your back or hands. The back is mesh for breathability as well.

The inside pocket for a spare battery with an included USB-A cable is a neat feature. Can charge devices without have to open the backpack up.

There are credit card slots with foil mesh to protect the RFID chips from being read by walk-by scanners. The slots are fairly loose so be careful as cards could get easily knocked out of them when accessing that larger pocket. Be sure to put the RFID chips down into the pockets. The RFID pockets are not large enough for something like a keyfob and since they dont close at the top, there's not full coverage which you need for a keyfob.

The large, center pocket can easily carry a sweater, light jacket, couple towels, etc.

I like that it has 2 water bottle mesh pockets, one on either side.

The front pocket has a couple areas you could store your phone and then route headphone cord out the rubber cutout. Not sure how many people still use corded headphones or earbuds but it's a nice feature if you do. There's also a slot large enough to pass a USB-A cord if you needed that, too. I see that as redundant given the built in USB cord for connecting internal and external devices.

The back also has the strap to allow you to slide it over the extension handle of a roller type piece of luggage if you dont want to carry the backpack on your shoulders.

Again, overall this is a good backpack at this price point. Time will tell how durable it is so that's the only unknown at this point.

title: It just works!
text:
As a tech enthusiast who is very particular about making sure that a switch does not reduce my signal strength, I am pleased to announce that this switch just works!

Pros:
- Power supply via the included Micro USB cable is not "necessary". I am attaching a pic from one of the pages of the user manual that clearly specifies this detail. However, if any of your HDMI devices have insufficient power, only then is it required. In my testing, power supply was not necessary when only connecting a PS5 but as soon as I connected a PS4 and PS5, the tiny circular LED indicator started blinking. The user manual did not help in troubleshooting this blinking behavior. However, when I connected the provided Micro USB power cable and supplied power to the switch, the blinking stopped and both PS4 and PS5 connected to the TV just fine.
- It just works. I have attached a screenshot from the PS5 "Video Output Information" screen that shows 4K60, HDR and also VRR. In other words, all the required specs were transmitted fine using this switch with no loss in quality that I could tell.
- Also tested on the PS4 and when I access the "Video Output Information" screen on the PS4, it showed all the correct signal specs with no loss of transmission. Since the PS4 is not 4K, I was receiving 1080p60 for the signal with HDR supported and Color Format as RGB.
- The center big circular button allows for easy switching between the two HDMI inputs if you press it. When turned on, this big button lights up green as well as the tiny circular LED. The tiny circular LEDs are labeled 1 and 2 for the respective HDMI inputs. See attached pic showing the lights (note: the pic shows HDMI Input 2 with green light because that input was active.) This helped confirm that the switch was operating and also confirmed which HDMI input was active. With the PS5 and PS4 in "Rest Mode", the big center button as well as the tiny circular LED will remain lit.
- Auto switch works great and automatically switches the monitor to the active HDMI input.

Cons:
- It would have helped if the user manual had a troubleshooting section that explained that if the power was not supplied, there would be a blinking of LEDs.

title: Not Sure About This Product
text:
This device sounded like the answer to my needs to move files from my iPad and Android phone to my PC. But I am not at all sure about its utility or safety.

I first tried it on my Android phone, to transfer photos to my computer. The instruction sheet packaged with the product required me to get out my 8x loupe to read them. We’re talking seriously tiny and dense.

The Android instructions only covered 3 panels. I followed them carefully, but the interface on my phone was not the same as they illustrated. I was told to find the pictures I wanted in ‘Files,’ select them, and ‘copy.’ Then go to the flash drive in ‘Files,’ and press ‘paste.’ Unfortunately, when I selected the photos, there was no ‘copy’ option that I could find, only ‘Copy To.’ When I tried ‘Copy To,’ this flash drive was not listed as one of the options. There may be a way to do this, but I couldn’t find it.

I thought things might be better on the iPad. But the instructions for iOS run 18 PAGES of microscopic type! It looks very complicated.

The very first step is to install an App on the iPad called ‘Y-Disk.’ So I went to the App Store and it was easy to find. But to be honest, the overwhelming number of One Star reviews claiming all kinds of things from from not working, to working very poorly, to data corruption and loss of photos, to being spyware, etc, etc, really took me aback. I sorted the reviews by date to see if perhaps the maker had fixed early problems, but this gave an even higher percentage of bad reviews! So many users REALLY hated the App and the Flash Drive it was made for that I had to take notice.

At that point, I decided that I didn’t want to risk my devices, or my data and photos and videos, for the sake of writing this review. Maybe it’s an okay product, maybe it’s not. But because I need to give it a star rating, I’m giving it a 2, and will leave it to the reader to consider their own risk tolerance.

title: Blu-Ray Region Free capability broke in 2 years, DVD still works
text:
Like others, I purchased this unit to allow me to play discs from around the world. The region free DVD capability works great, as it easily switches regions automatically. The Blu-Ray region free capability (at least that provided by the unit 220 Electronics shipped), leaves much to be desired. I must preface the following with the statement that I have NEVER switched Blu-Ray regions on this unit, ever, as I have yet to buy a non Region A disc.

With all the streaming options out there, I have not watched a Blu-Ray disc in about 8 months. The other month (25 months after the unit was purchased) I attempted to watch a newly purchased Region A Blu-Ray disc. The player gave me an error that it could not play the disc because it was not the correct region. After restarting the player and going through the instructions on how to switch between regions, it just refused to play the disc. I then tried another disc, a Disney title that happens to be Region Free/Multi-Region A/B/C. That disc played fine, as did all the other Multi-Region A/B/C discs I had. But all Region A locked discs refuse to play.

I contacted 220 Electronics and to their credit they promptly provided instructions on to re-set the unit. I did so, but it still refused to play the region locked discs. I do not have any Region B or C discs to check to see if the player somehow became locked on one of those and refuses to switch, but it really would not help me anyway. Despite their "region free guarantee" I was told since the player was out of warranty I would have to ship it in and pay for repair, but they could not provide an estimate for the repair cost.

I would understand if the basic functions of the unit itself were not working (e.g. refusing to play anything, skipping, not powering up, etc.), but the only thing that does NOT work is the region free capability that 220 Electronics added to the player, which is supposed to be "guaranteed". Again, for clarity, the unit plays all DVD discs, from the various regions I have, and all multi-region Blu-Rays. The unit just refuses to switch the region for Blu-Rays to allow region locked discs to play, which makes it useless for Blu-Rays.

title: A stand with integrated USB hub and cooling - good on paper, but the execution is lacking
text:
[[VIDEOID:a834d77e35560b2e63ac892d16447bd3]] This review is for the Ergopollo Laptop Cooling Pad with Ultra Quiet Fans and a 4-Port USB hub. On paper, this is a great idea since laptop stands tend to be rather bulky, and the added fan and USB hub functionality is both useful and a clever utilization of space. Unfortunately, this product doesn't live up to its potential because this product's stand, fan, and hub components all have substantial limitations, so as a whole, the product is somewhat awkward.

The stand is fixed height, which is disappointing from both ergonomic and portability perspectives. I prefer to align the top or bottom edges of my laptop's screen with my primary monitor so that on-screen elements are lined up when I move across workspaces. My other complaint is that while the stand is advertised as being suitable for laptops up to 17.3", the top deck is much too small. 15.6" to 16" is the maximum recommended size since, for larger laptops, their feet might be spaced further than the deck's width, resulting in the deck pressing directly on the machine's bottom cover.

Concerning the fans, while I appreciate that they can be turned on/off without impacting the USB hub's function, I'd prefer the LED lighting and fan speed to be separately controllable. As equipped, the Ergopollo's stand's fans spin at a single speed, and they're a bit buzzy. Also, while they start with the same light sequence, the fans lose color synchronization after a minute or so.

Lastly, the USB3 Hub functionality is nice, but it's a missed opportunity for this product to be solely bus-powered. I prefer having the option to use a separate 5V adapter so that the stand could also work as a USB charger when the laptop isn't there. Making the product self-powered would also allow for using more high-powered devices, such as SSDs, without the risk of the hub shutting down due to excess power draw.

Overall, I think this stand is "okay." It was easy enough to assemble, and it works, but it could have been so much more.

Notes
1) Ergonomic Chicken, anyone?

title: Small and portable powered USB-A and USB-C Docking Station for Desktops and Laptops
text:
Pros, Likes, and Features
*This connects to the computer with either a USB-A Adapter on the cable or just a USB-C to USB-C cable. It has 4 USB-A 3.0 ports, a 4 band audio/microphone 3.5 mm jack, 2 HDMI jacks (1 is 2k and 1 is 4k), a gigabit Ethernet jack and is self powered allowing for more devices connected by USB on the computer that won't take power from the ports on the PC or Laptop being used. This also has a power button on it so you can turn it off to disable USB-A devices plugged into this docking station when not in use.
*Unit is fairly small at about 5 inches wide, 4 inches deep, and 2.5 inches tall (roughly) but is very convenient to have and it makes it pretty portable too if needed.

Cons, Dislikes
*The 2 HDMI ports are different in resolution, 1 is 2k and 1 is 4k, but I don't know why they both couldn't be 4k. Can 2 monitors not work with 4k resolution through USB-C or USB-A 3.0 or greater data connection?
*This must be powered, it cannot function on its own as a docking station without being powered by its AC power adapter.

I think this is strait forward for a docking station. I put what I liked and what features this has but also shared my thoughts about them too like the HDMI. This works really well and I have 2 24 inch monitors using it now I just don't understand why 2 4k channels couldn't pass through a USB-C connection but I don't understand the data transfer involved either so I am curious too. The rest is strait forward and adding 3 USB's to a computer along with 2 monitors just taking up 1 USB on the computer - what could you want better than that? A Good Looking Docking Station, and that is this, no plugs or wires on the front so it keeps the desk nice and clean. Works great, highly recommend this for anyone needing multiple monitors, extra USB-A 3.0 ports, a closer headset jack, etc.

This requires a USB-A 3.0 or better USB-A port or a USB-C port on the computer to function properly.

title: Good for movies and games
text:
I got this projector on sale for $80 to replace the crappy TV I had in my room. On my PS4 in the video settings I noticed the projecter was 24hz (which means the max youre able to visually see is 24FPS or 24 frames per second which is how many "pictures" on screen show up in one second) which is normal for console gaming, but after some googling I read that 24hz is best enjoyed with movies and is too low for games. I use this mostly with the console portion of my game room and so far my PS4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch, have ran and looked perfectly fine. If anyone is picking this projecter up for cheap to play some games on a bigger display this projector would do perfectly. Of course with any projector youll want to invest in some speakers that either plug into the projector itself or your console. If you're looking for a projector that does 4k be prepared to do some more searching and have at least $50 extra that you're willing to spend. There arent many great projectors like this one out there, especially for $130. so your best bet is this projector, if you dont care if its 1080p or 4k. Now unfortunately mine would have been 5 stars, but the box came with a hole in the side and theres a small, but noticeable, black spot on the screen. I'm pretty sure the screen is just dirty but theres no way to clean it unless you want to try your luck removing the entire bottom part and cleaning the projector and remembering where everything goes when putting it back together. Mine was definately used, but im not sure how long. Hopefully their support responds and maybe I can get sent a new unit, or some instructions on how to easily clean the inside.

EDIT: okay nvm I was looking at the wrong tab on my PS4, video playback is 24hz, regular video settings (under Sound & Screen) show 60hz

EDIT 2: After talking with their support for a little bit they offered to send over a completely new projector free of charge! I got the projector in today and its definately way better than the one I was previously sent. The image quality is more crisp and the colors pop more. Theres no more weird smudge on the inside screen anymore! 10/10 great projector, even better customer service!!

title: Headset with great potential but a few flaws
text: This headset has a lot of great things going for it. The sound quality for a low-cost headset is reasonably good, both for calls and for listening to music. The microphone quality is not as good, but it is usable. I bought an inexpensive Sennheiser headset and its microphone quality is 10x better. But then again the Sennheiser costs more too (but not as much more as you'd expect). The combination of cables and options to use it either as a 3.5mm headset and a USB-A headset are great. Those are all of the good qualities of it. I think the biggest problem for most people will be the headphone size. At its largest adjustment, it is not large enough for the average adult head. I've got a small head and most headphones are too big for me. But these headphones were so tight, I'm inclined to say these were designed for kids. You should take this into consideration if you are thinking about these. The small size will make these uncomfortable to wear for more than a few minutes. The second issue is the angling of the on-ear pieces. Most on-ear have a hinge that allows the ear covers to sit comfortably on your ears. These do not have the proper hinge angle and are very uncomfortable and smash against your ears. Once again, a minor tweak could make these great, but in their current form, they hurt after more than a few minutes. The next flaw has to do with quality control of the USB-A to 3.5mm adapter. The build quality is poor and causes either heavy static or the microphone to function improperly due to lack of contact of the 3.5mm barrel and female receptacle. I had reached out to the seller and they sent a replacement. This one was better, but wasn't great and still has some issues. Its also difficult to tell if the "MUTE" function is activated or not. For the money, if they could fix the size/fit issue, I'd probably give it a few more stars. My go-to headset of choice for WebEx/Zoom/Skype meetings are the Microsoft ones. They don't sound as good as these and cost 500% more, but they are a headset that I can wear for hours comfortable and they fit an adult head. If Olyre did a little bit of work and made a few tweaks to the design, they could have a really great headset.

title: Performant Mesh system
text:
With the increase of connected devices in our home, the need for a faster and more reliable network is essential. 4 years ago I upgraded my internet service and router to the top of the line service and equipment. However with the addition of few IoT devices coupled with nonstop HD streaming my home network started to struggle, so I added a second WiFi6 router as its own subnet solely dedicated to WiFi traffic, that worked well for few months then I needed a WiFi6 extender to cover a dead zone, I chose a D-link E15 which turned out a good choice for my latest upgrade to this D-link Mesh bundle as it too is managed through the same Eagle Pro app.
The issue with my previous setup is I had to configure every WiFi access point with a unique SSID which made some devices to not know how or when to switch to the most reliable WiFi when another is down or slow. Of course I could've names all SSIDs the same which I did, but that caused a nightmare to troubleshoot when one is down or suboptimal and you can't tell which one is which without more digging.
This Mesh network solves all that as it basically sets itself as one WiFi across every Mesh device and all connected devices will seamlessly transition from one to another without you even noticing.
The setup was a breeze, all I had to do is unplug my existing WiFi gateway and plug in one of the two D-link routers. The app which I happen to already have installed detected the new device after scanning its QRcode and set it up in no time. All I had to do next is plug-in the 2nd router in the area where I wanted extended coverage, the router basically knew it's a part of a Mesh ans sets up itself!
My old D-link extender of course went offline as it no longer could find its old SSID to extend. But just resetting it to default was enough for it recognize the new mesh network and add itself to it, I was amazed I didn't have to do anything! After all I think this is how things should work.
One tiny complaint is the unconventional DC jack the routers use for power. To be able to use this as a direct drop-in to replace my old router, I had to reuse the same 12V adapter but with a DC jack converter to adapt to the new and smaller size.
5 stars

title: Bright, good quality of light and slim
text:
The brightness on this light is great, I did a bit of a burn in on this to see battery length and with my not totally full 65.1wh 7.4v battery, it lasted 6 hours at 100% at the mid level kelvin setting.

I'm a little disappointed that this light didn't come with an AC power cable since it has the option to run off of a 6.8-12v center positive barrel style power source. However, everyone uses Sony batteries and they're very cheap. My favorite Sony style batteries for these lights are the ones with the LCD panel that shows the power level: https://amzn.to/3KzK9FY

One aspect about this light that I haven't seen on any other smaller lights like this is it has a battery "test" button with four LED lights that show you the level of your battery on case you don't have a battery with a readout which is typically all of them. So that was handy!

I really enjoy the tactile potentiometers, the dials! 😃 the knobs turn with hard stops, pretty nice to know you're at 100% or at one side of the dial or the other without looking at a readout. That being said, the knobs could use some markings on them (a simple dot), if you for some reason need know the actual percentage of light volume or need more accurate knowledge of kelvin settings you're on, or I suppose if you were being directed to move from one number to another, simply adding a little dot with some nail polish or paint marker will come in very handy, specially if you need to tell someone at a glance what your light is set to.

So far I'm really liking this light, for run and gun shooters using this on top of a camera, know that there is not much battery "locking" on the battery mounting area. Meaning no actual button to release the battery, it's friction based, I couldn't see that being a horrible issue, but if it's bumped it WILL fall off.

The mounting base is a 1/4" inch female and cold shoe combo. The pivoting part of this is quite interesting to note that it is actually a "gopro" style neck and can fit other go pro mounts which is pretty unique.

title: Mixed bag for me
text:
For the record, I am a very seasoned software engineer who also knows my way around hardware. Anyway, this drive is a mixed bag for me. On the one hand, now that I "cleared everything up" the drive seems pretty solid. I didn't do any speed tests since many others will provide that information and honestly, I'm really not all that concerned about whether or not this SSD has 'amazing' speeds, especially since much of that depends upon what computer you install it in and what that motherboard supports.

In case it helps, I installed this on a Lenovo P1, replacing a 256GB secondary drive I already had installed in the P1.

Anyway, let's start with the positives. The disk seems to be plenty fast, and Windows sees it as having a capacity of 953GB which I think is pretty normal. After copying my backed-up files from my previous SSD backup drive, Visual Studio opened up the project I am currently working on and didn't miss a beat, so everything I copied over to this new SSD obviously worked as expected.

Now for the not so great. When I installed the backup SSD that this SSD replaced, it was simply a matter of plugging it in and turning on the P1, at which point, Windows saw the new drive, assigned a new drive letter and boom, I was done. With this SSD, not so much.

After installing this SSD and turning the P1 back on, Windows showed me two new drives, both of which did not actually exist and were not useable. I had to go into 'disk management' and set the SSD up properly. After that, I still had the two 'phantom' drives listed in Windows Explorer, so I had to go back into disk management and remove both of them. Not the end of the world but I shouldn't have to do that and neither should you.

If you are not a very technical person and you run into the same issue, I could see it being very frustrating. In all honesty, it probably took me less than 10 minutes to resolve everything, but I do have a decent idea about what I am doing. All in all, this seems like a good drive thus far but the original issues prevent me from giving it 5-stars.

title: Awesome Value
text:
I have used quite a few Bluetooth sound devices and these Tagry X18s stand out a having an outstanding feature set for a very affordable price. The attributes include:

The come with a well designed case with the USB charging port in front allowing you to charge your phone or other device. The case has a solid feel to it and has a easily readable display showing the overall charge percent and a charging scale for each bud.

The buds themselves are well-designed. My left ear canal must be inordinately large because I have tried many other buds with the largest rubber pad and none have ever consistently stayed in my ear. However, the X18s do. I think design of the rubber flange helps hold it in place, but I also think they seem to be lighter and therefore less apt to fall out. It's a huge benefit knowing they are going to stay in place.

In addition to their design, the buds function with ease. One feature I frequently use is the one-touch, start/stop. I frequently use the buds in the gym and walking my dog and having the ability to stop the sound when you need to talk with someone is super nice. I used to have to fumble with my phone to pause what was playing but now it's a quick finger tap to the right bud. You do have to pay attention though as I have put the buds in a pocket and later realized they started my audiobook by accident.

The sound quality is also very good. I have a couple of different Beats products and the sound is at least as good if not better. Music playback is very clear with a full range of sound. You get the sense the 'stereo' effect is improved with buds. They produce a surround sound or 'immersive sound' as they describe it. This really distinguishes the X18s compared with other products. They also have worked well with phone calls. The voices were very clear for both parties.

I haven't tested the battery life in terms of total hours but have noticed the battery charge goes down very slowly which means they will likely last a long time between charges.

Overall, the X18s are a great product at any price but are a super great value for about $30.

title: Comfy, Versatile... Some Small drawbacks
text:
Finally came the time to replace some cheap wired headphones I've head for a few years.

Wireless ones are looking decent enough where I said, why not let's try something.

I got lucky, comfort-wise with this pair. I'm a big guy and traditionally headphones have felt like clamps on my ears. These ones well... they're not bad at all. They don't get sweaty. The band is comfortable. The clamp is there but it's really pretty light... I'd say probably 50-75% less tiring to wear than the old pair, which is pretty impressive. I don't know how durable over time though.

Noise cancelling is ok. There's obviously not meant to be perfect there, but it's fine for my uses. And you still hear somebody trying to get your attention (well maybe not if you have the volume cranked, but that's your choice.)

Now on to the drawbacks:

- The bluetooth lag. Yes, lip sync on videos will be massively off when you're in wireless mode. That's a bluetooth thing.

- The charging. They don't last that long. Feels like two days working to me, maybe 20-30 hours. Worse... they don't function while plugged into charge. Bummer as I have a wall long cord charger that would be fun to use... but they just don't work when charging.

- The included short cable. They include two audio cables... the included long one is not the one I need of course. The short one they include I need for wired mode... and this thing will come out about 3 feet from behind the point it comes under my monitor. That's VERY awkward my setup because this little cord has to plug in the middle of my monitor so literally has to rest straight down the middle of my keyboard. There's no extra slack on it. The lack of flexibility and choices with wired mode plugged is just sad there. I will have to buy an extra cable for these now.

However, I still give them 4 stars for a few reasons... very comfortable. That and I can walk around the house and there's no problems with reception. So overall they're decent. I'm pleased within after a week or so of constant use.

title: Not Hi-End Sound Bar, but HIGH VALUE!
text:
Full disclosure.. I bought this at an auction, but felt compelled to write a review.

Straight up in the instruction booklet Wohome tells us this isn't a top end unit, but does a good job. It does NOT fail to deliver!
It is attractive, nicely built, solid, and comes with mounting brackets on the back and screw hardware. Everything except an ARC-HDMI cable is included in the box. (USB, AVI, Optical cables and Power Supply)
Many people will opt for the Optical cable hookup, as this was top of the line until more recently.

Tested on a portion of a program, GREAT SOUND! Nice to have equalizer settings on the remote, along with Music, TV, and Movie pre-sets, and full volume control on my ROKU remote.

Hooking up via BT with my living room Alexa was a snap, and it really enhanced the sound!.

Sorry this gets a bit long, but, to paraphrase Instagram reels, "read to the end!"

Since my TV has ARC-HDMI, I decided to try that. I also happened to remember that I had a 3 foot "Hi-Speed HDMI" cable from many years ago. Went and dug it out of my junk tub in the garage. Setup could not have been easier! Plugged in the power, plugged into the HDMI ARC socket on the TV, then into the soundbar. Powered everything up, switched the TV sound output to HDMI, everything worked perfectly!

Turned everything off, went on to other things for the day. Sat down after dinner, turned on Chernobyl, SOUND WAS TERRIBLE!! Kept shifting in and out, softer and louder, full of static. Went back ad wiggled the HDMI connections, and it got better for a short time, then went wonky again. DAMN! I figured this is why it was at auction!

Then I thought about that OLD HDMI cable, questionable speed, quality, and most likely oxidized connections. Ordered a new, HDMI ARC cable off Amazon for less than $10. It arrived this morning, I hooked it up, and everything works perfect! LESSON LEARNED!

title: Absolutely 100% Amazing!!!!!!
text:
This projector is !@#$% Awesome!!! It's supper small and compact, but packs some power! I love it! This was extremely easy to setup...without the remote I might add... It linked up to all our home networks and iphones. The projector has a sound speaker built-in, which is okay. But...you can also plug it directly into a sound source or Bluetooth it to another source. We have played videos from our phones, laptops, and the Nintendo switch to play games on the big screen. Speaking of big screen...I didn't know that this comes with it's own screen you can use!! We have an 6' x 12' inflatable one for parties, but this one is perfect for smaller events and is far easier to setup. The projector also comes with it's own lens cover and cleaning kit. It also has a remote (if you want to use it...not really needed). The image is super sharp and detailed, focusing is super simple and effective. Here are the pro's and con's of what I've found using it...

Pro's
- Small and portable
- Extremely crisp and sharp image
- Supper easy setup
- Connects very easily to networks, laptops, iPhones and gaming systems
- Comes with additional connection cables for older systems (HDMI, Sound cords, etc..)
- Does NOT overheat or get supper hot when running
- Quick startup!! AND shut down!
- Built-in tilt and angle adjustments
- Can still be viewed in low lighting conditions
- Built-in sound speaker, Or...can be connected to separate sound source
- Bluetooth compatible
- Puts a smile on your face!!!

Con's
- hmmmm???
- The only con is....that there IS no con's...sorry...
- Muscle cramps from smiling too much... I guess?? haha

Overall, this little gem works great! The kids and family love it!!! We use this almost every day! I would HIGHLY recommend this to anyone looking for a small, simple, compact projector that's easy to use and highly effective!! I promise you won't be disappointed!! Happy movie night!!! - Cheers!

title: Updated: Great Cable - Revised Plugs
text:
This is an up-date to my prior review. I have changed my rating from a 1 star to a 5 star, for the reasons listed below. I received a reply from the manufacturer after posting my original review. In their reply, the manufacturer advised:

“… I am writing to let you know that we have completed an upgrade to our product that effectively solves the problems you were experiencing before. We are willing to send you a completely upgraded cable.

Previously our cables had two problems.

The first was that it did not fit with the thicker phone cases. This is because our cable uses a zinc alloy case to enhance the quality, but the zinc alloy case is larger and when using some of the phone cases with smaller charging holes, it will cause the problem of not charging or charging intermittently.

The second problem, is that when using USB A to C to charge iPad, it may not charge. This is caused by using a low power charger and the low speed charging protocol is not compatible with the iPad.

We take customer feedback very seriously and continue to improve the product and have completely solved these problems. We have made the following upgrades.

1. Extend the Lightning connector by 0.2mm
2. Upgraded the charging chip, compatible with more charging protocols. No matter what combination can be charged.”

The manufacturer subsequently sent me a replacement cable with the newly designed connectors for both the iPhone (lighting) and iPad (usb-c) which now are able to properly connect to the charging port on both devices, while inside a protective case, and maintain a power connection, as intended. I will now order additional cable as the cables are very sturdy and well made.

Initial Review: The walls (see the blue arrows in the accompanying photo) surrounding the plugs are too thick to properly plug into an iPhone or iPad (lighting or USB-C) if the device is in a case unless the cut-out in the case is un-usually large (or modified) enough to accommodate the large housing around the plug. This was confirmed on various brands of cases. As a result, the cable will not plug far enough into the charging port to charge the device. The design is very unfortunate because the cable itself is strong and heavy duty.

title: Assembly experience
text: Just so much harder than it had to be because of short shrift instructions and just over a minute video that adds nothing.  Instructions for removing the side and front doors were okay.  After that, you can pretty much throw them away, except they do provide a framework for the order of assembly.  The first problem I ran into was where the rails fit.  After wasting 45 minutes to try to figure that out, I decided skip that step, with the thought in the back of my mind that not mounting the rails would result in me having to disassemble.  I didn't use any of the mounting hardware except for the washers.  I had four 2 1/2 inch stainless steel that I used.  I used a drill bit to drive a pilot, which really helps to sink the screws.  I mounted the side door frames which lines with the back plate.  Next slide the bottom of the tray - bit tricky but make sure the plate rests on the lip of the back plate - there are no screws that hold it in, but it was surprising sturdy.  Next is the top plate which snaps in similarly to the bottom plate.  Next is the front frame and it has places for four screws.  I revisited the rails and to my surprise they could be screwed in to place with no difficulty. At that point, I left off all the doors and essentially began transitioning my network.  I bought two shelves that I wouldn't recommend as they had some alignment issues, but I managed to get them to work.  I added the Pyle power strip, and it's not really that functional - access to outlets is very difficult and most adapters will use the space of at least two of the outlets.  But it looks good.  I re-routed all the wires and moved my router and modem - see picture.  Then I added the doors and the ground cable.  I'm sure I'll modify the wiring later as I look to add another network device and maybe a couple of hubs. But before I do that I want to add a couple of fans.  I was expecting the unit to have fans and it's not marked that they are not included.  Moreover, would have been nice if the seller had recommended a fan that is available online.  I think the unit should have included a couple of shelves as I think it's going to take some experimentation to find the best way to use the space.

title: The custom service is absolutely awful !!!
text:
I was using this docking station for about 1 year. It was working fine until one day it suddenly stopped working. All ports are down, I'm an engineer, I did all kinds of A/B testing and trial. I know it's broken for sure. And It's still within the warranty so I reached out to the seller and the customer service was absolutely awful.
------
I clearly described the issue, attached the photo, and followed whatever instruction they asked me to try. 
After lots of back and forth, I started to realize they never really try to resolve the problem but just try to hold you off.
------
They started with blaming the software update, then asked you to try a bunch of nonsense. They even lied about their product and see attached pictures for evidence,
------
I've told them all the ports of the station are not working, and I sent them a picture that shows the usb port is not providing power. They told me this, "Do you want the hub to be powered on when it is not plugged into the computer, and then the USB port will supply power to other devices? If this is the case, it is absolutely impossible to achieve. The hub needs to be plugged into the computer to start the hub."
------
1. I know this is wrong, the usb will supply power regardless if the computer is plugged or not based on my previous experience.
2. I've sent them a picture that shows usb has no power while the computer is plugged, so they didn't even look at the picture.
------
So, I re-bought a new one just to pop their lie. And check the photo I attached, see how they claim that the usb won't supply power when the computer is not plugged in. And the second picture shows the new one I got works exactly unlike how they said!
------
Spent days with the custom service, and based on the conversation, I can assure you when a problem happens, they are just trying to find excuses and hold you off until you give up.
I don't remember when was the last time I'm writing a complaint, but this seller is so far the worst I spoke with on Amazon. Waited tons of my time and found out they just trick you up.

title: Nifty VPN gateway for your home network
text:
This is a good little router with VPN that is easy to set up. I've run into a few challenges (more below), but overall it works well.

First thing to know: at its core, it runs the powerful and flexible OpenWrt router software, and that alone makes it a capable router. I won't talk about OpenWrt here: you can learn plenty about it elsewhere.

On top of OpenWrt, GL.Inet has layered:

- A Web interface that is simpler to use than OpenWrt's standard Web interface for configuring your network. (You can still get to OpenWrt's interface if you need it.)
- Support for a couple of popular VPN technologies (OpenVPN and WireGuard), allowing the router to supply VPN services for your entire network. This is the product's biggest value-add... more on that below.
- The availability of a few additional applications, including Dynamic DNS and AdGuard Home.

The VPN capabilities are the core of this router's appeal: it's a path to VPN for your entire home/business network. It can proxy all of your traffic through the VPN, or be configured for selective proxying: limited to certain destinations, or to certain of your hosts, or to a VLAN. So, for example, if you want your desktop PC to use a VPN to the central office, while leaving the rest of your network off the VPN, it's easily done.

The VPN also has knowledge of certain VPN providers (such as NordVPN), and makes it especially easy for you to set up and use VPNs through those providers.

There is one area I've run into trouble: the behavior of DNS while I'm doing selective proxying - that is, while proxying some (but not all) of my systems. Some lookups of web addresses and even local addresses return bad results. After discussion on the support forum, I got a workaround that appears to work well: configuring the router to use secure DNS. This shouldn't be necessary, but it does get me past the issue, and I'm able to keep selective proxying turned on.

I hope to see future firmware updates that address the outstanding DNS issues, but even now I'm using the router and VPN successfully.

title: Good but not Great
text:
I've wanted bone conduction headphones for a long time and finally decided to take the plunge and ordered several different brands to compare and use. One thing that is common to all bone conduction headphones is that instead of hearing sound through tiny speakers inserted into, or over, your ears the sound is transmitted through vibration. Because of this sound bleed to people near you is at a minimum.

These headphones do a pretty decent job. They pair easily with your phone or computer via Bluetooth and the headphones reproduce mid to high frequency sounds pretty well while the lower frequency bass loses its fulness. Because of this, which has so far been pretty standard across all the ones I have tested, I use them mainly for listening to audiobooks or other mostly spoken content.

Because these headphones are open ear ambient sound from your environment can be distracting or even drown out what you are listening to - largely because it is hard to get enough volume to isolate yourself.

Wearing these headphones is very comfortable, especially for long periods of time where in-ear earbuds can begin to hurt your ears. They're also waterproof with an IPX8 rating.

These headphones also allow you to download your own music into internal memory which provides 32 Gb of space. That is great when you do not have your phone with you or where/when you are having BT issues. Strangely, the volume and density of sound of internal music surpasses that which you get through BT streaming. I'm not sure why this is but it is something to keep in mind.

Charging (and loading your own music) is accomplished via a proprietary cord which is provided - although I am assuming this is to keep water from any internal components I always worry that the cord will break or get lost thereby requiring a purchase of a new cord or junking the headphones. Given that the sellers are often foreign companies of "questionable" sustainability or longevity on Amazon this should be taken into account when purchasing. The control buttons on the right earpiece sit behind your ear and the buttons are difficult to press - something I am again assuming has something to do with the waterproof rating. These problems are real but of limited weight when trying to decide whether to purchase these headphones.

All in all these are a good buy at the current price.

title: High-end performance and Top-notch features
text:
The ASUS ROG Strix Scar 17 (2022) Gaming Laptop is an impressive device that offers high-end performance and top-notch features for gamers and power users alike. Equipped with a 17.3” 240Hz IPS QHD Display, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Ti, and an Intel Core i9-12900H processor, this laptop delivers smooth and immersive gaming experiences.

One of the most notable aspects of this laptop is its display. The QHD resolution and 240Hz refresh rate offer a crisp and fluid image, making it easy to appreciate the details in the latest games and media. Additionally, the display is bright and vivid, providing excellent color accuracy and contrast. This, combined with the laptop's impressive speakers, creates a truly immersive audiovisual experience.

The NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Ti is the crown jewel of this laptop's performance. This graphics card is capable of running even the most demanding games and applications with ease. The i9-12900H processor is also a powerful component, allowing for speedy and responsive multitasking and computing.

The 16GB DDR5 RAM and 1TB SSD provide ample storage and memory for even the most demanding users, while the Per-Key RGB Keyboard offers customizable lighting and precise keystrokes for a comfortable and personalized typing experience.

The design of the ASUS ROG Strix Scar 17 (2022) is sleek and stylish, with a durable and well-built chassis that can withstand daily wear and tear. The laptop's cooling system is also effective, keeping temperatures low even during prolonged gaming sessions.

One potential downside of this laptop is its weight and size. It is not the most portable device, weighing in at over 6 pounds and measuring over an inch thick. This makes it difficult to carry around for extended periods, especially for frequent travelers.

In conclusion, the ASUS ROG Strix Scar 17 (2022) Gaming Laptop is an excellent choice for gamers and power users who require top-of-the-line performance and features. It offers impressive specs, a sleek design, and a superb display and keyboard. The only drawback is its weight and size, which may limit its portability. Overall, it's a solid investment for anyone who wants a high-quality laptop that can handle demanding tasks and run the latest games smoothly.

title: Will work in a pinch; but misses on most of the details
text:
I have a few a couple other screens (one much larger w/ a mobile attachment base; one similar size meant for the wall) but I thought this one would be the right size AND be easy to take on the go. It is more mobile and more sturdy than the ones I currently have BUT, I thought it would be a simple take down and transport and it's not. You have to completely take down and reassemble every time you want to pack it up and take it somewhere. Though the screen comes w/o wrinkles, this packing and unpacking will inevitably lead to wrinkling (and extra time wasted). Due to the screen type, you can see the pole behind it when there is a light source behind the screen. The cloth screen, however, is no worse or better than most other cloth screens out there.. Only a stiffer, more vinyl/paper like screen would completely hide the stand. The picture quality is 99.9% going to be a result of the projector you're using. (My photos are using a cheap projector made for night/total dark environments; taken during the day time with blinds mostly closed.)

I'm proficient at assembling things so I had no issues figuring things out BUT the instructions are pretty terrible and require a little intuition, which is a problem for those who don't like to or aren't as experienced in assembly. There are a lot of thumb screws instead of quick latching mechanisms. These thumbscrews and the latches on the upper/lower poles stick out and you have to maneuver the screen around them. You have to manually align the screen which usually isn't completed on the first try. Also not easily done in one try? Getting it tight enough to make a "flat" screen w/o wrinkles. I was able to get it real tight by pulling the corners tight, but the middle run of the sides sucked in and didn't make a good even sided rectangle. When I loosened the corners, I attained a better rectangular shape but there were wrinkles/slack in the middle of the screen which could create unwanted shadowing of the picture. I don't think this is made for outside unless it's covered/shielded from the wind. All-in-all, it's alright and can cover you in some situations---just know what you're getting into.

title: Some pros but some unfortunate cons
text:
Unlike many of the earbuds I’ve reviewed I was familiar with the Back Bay brand though I have never used any of their products. Starting with the pros, the case and the buds have a quality look and feel. The case is made of strong plastic with subtle magnetic closure. The earbuds are also sturdy and well-made. The individual buds are rated for 8 hours and with the case the rating is 80 hours of play time. I tested the buds for a 7-hour session and they still had power, so 8 hours should be a reasonable estimate. I charged the case to full power when I received them and did not need to recharge them after 10 days of consistent 4 hour daily use. Some other pro features are an IPX7 waterproof rating, Qi wireless charging, and the call quality was good.

Despite the pros, there were some bothersome cons for me. Regardless of the tips I tried that came with the buds I could only get an acceptable fit that became uncomfortable after about an hour of wear. Part of this was the ear hook is not very flexible and this style of earbud does not seem to fit my ears very well in general. I have tried a few other buds using a similar design and had similar problems with the fit so I’m attributing this con to be particular to my ears. Sound quality was okay, but I did not get the bass response that I was expecting even with the bass boost setting turned on. The sound quality may also be related to the fact that I could not get a good fit. The touch control response was inconsistent, working sometimes and not others or causing the wrong function. Though well-made the case is very large and cumbersome, not a good fit for a pocket. One annoyance that I had every time I opened the case is that the right earbud is on the left side of the case and the left earbud on the right side. Over time I’m sure I could get used to it but not in the time frame that I was testing them.

To sum it up, the case and earbuds feel and look quality, and I wanted to like them, but the cons outweighed the pros for me. Acknowledging that the sound quality may be caused by my ear structure, and they may produce better sound with a proper fit I’m leaving a 3-star rating.

title: Second Monitor, Easy to Integrate
text:
