[[VIDEOID:342a7e169c47a845b78c38d00b692719]] The InnoView monitor arrived in a timely fashion, packaged to protect it. (Box inside a box.) The instructions were simple, addressed several setup options, and provided QR Codes for additional online information.

Connection consisted of attaching a power cable and plugging in the standard-to-mini HDMI cable between my laptop and the extra screen. It powered up and initially mirrored the same background screen as the laptop.

By using the Windows Settings for Display, it took only moments to designate the monitor as #2, and then select the Extend function, so my usable screen space was doubled. With a friend's guidance, I learned to "click and hold" the #2 screen icon in Settings to position it in the same relative location as the physical location on my computer desk. (The cord is not quite long enough to situate the InnoView monitor 'comfortably' on the right side of my laptop, due to where the "out ports" are on the left side.)

Once the setup was accomplished, my screen real estate was effectively doubled. When opening multiple applications, I can now "drag" them from one screen to the other, and size them to fit or scale them down. This is incredibly helpful for having Second Life open to a dance club venue, and using the Mixxx music / voice mixer application to run my virtual DJ sets, keeping an eye on both. It helps during my Virtual TableTop Role-Playing Games (VTTRPG), so I can view the "world" map and still have access to all my character stats on the other screen.

The best part is the clarity, the resolution, and the size -- which is only nominally smaller than my laptop screen. By placing the InnoView close to my laptop, it's a seamless movement of the cursor from one screen to the other. Another handy function is to be able to stand the InnoView on its narrow side in order to use its Portrait orientation to view documents as whole pages.

This monitor is versatile, sturdy, and meets all the requirements of an enhancement for your working or gaming needs. Get one for yourself; you'll be glad you did.

title: Excellent Case, Independent Non-Solicited Review
text: First and foremost I read the reviews on the TXesign Charge 5 case,  all of which at the time were Vine customer reviews involving a free product and imho,  the  reviews are indeed genuine,  honest and accurate appraisals of this excellent case. I purchased two JBL Charge 5's because they sound great and then purchased two of the TXesign cases designed for the JBL Charge 5. No free products, and no connection with TXesign or anyone else on this, so this is my honest opinion. This case really accents the look and design of the Charge 5. Dimension-wise it should fit a Charge 4 as well, but may somewhat block the battery indicator lights if that matters to anyone. Material has the look and feel of a high quality leather.The fit is excellent and this case really elevates the speaker's appearance  to look more attractive and expensive. All buttons and ports are easily accessible. This attractive, quality build case  certainly offers some protection and is great for transporting the speaker with the convenient shoulder strap. Some reviewers felt the two Velcro straps were a bit difficult yo work with and this is likely true for some users, but I found no concerning issue with them at all, and the case is so nice, the straps are definitely not a deal breaker. In fact , once you strap the unit in, how often would there be a need to strap and unstrap since the case does not alter the sound and actually looks great ? Plus once broken-in the straps should become easier to manipulate.  It's a valid point though by some of the reviewers who commented on the straps; however, the many pluses of this case far outweigh the rare times you may have to use the straps and many folks may not experience any concern with them at all.  IMO, TXesign earns an A+ on this product for design, quality, function, appearance and value.  Exceptional value for the price! TXEsign, please keep up the great work on your cases! The JBL Clip 3 silicone case by TXesign is also excellent.  My compliments to all the Vine reviewers who gave very accurate appraisals so they certainly deserve any perks afforded to them by Vine. I typically don't ever pay attention to reviews with free products or perks but the reviews here have changed that view somewhat, and are indeed genuine appraisals of this product, and that's very good to see.

title: Sound is amazing but.( zero incentive) honest review is the best karma
text:
Sound: hands-down the sound is just like the expensive brands, I know this because I have four kids so they get the expensive earbuds and I get the cheap ones! Lol

Batter life: really good! No complaints here, I listen to my earbuds during work for like five hours, and I still have a decent amount of battery life without charging.

Controls: average. sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn’t register a tap, but I have found that to be true with almost all earbuds..

Comfort: for me, they hurt my ears, but to be fair I am 4” 11 and have a little body frame , so my ears would be more comparable to a child’s ears, so I don’t think a lot of people would have the same problem as me.

Overall : the only complaint I had was that they were uncomfortable in my ears, but I don’t think that would be a problem for everyone, but you cannot beat the sound that comes out of these. They are comparable to the most expensive brands and the battery life is good the controls are so so, but I really haven’t found a pair of earbuds are the controls are perfect.. as with all earbuds. The pause button always works on these, but trying to increase the volume or skip to the next song is a little more difficult..
UPDATE:
I have since ordered another pair of earbuds from Amazon because again these ones were just not comfortable on my ears .I purchased the
“iLuv TB100 Wireless Earbuds” in rose gold . They ranked in the top five most comfortable earbuds for small ears. The reviews were great, and they are a good pair of earbuds . BUT they do not compare to the sound quality of these earbuds! Even though in the reviews, a lot of people bragged about the sound quality of them, (they must have never purchased this brand. Lol.) I’m still searching for the perfect pair that fit and have amazing sound quality.🥲 but if you have small ears , this brand should work , every pair comes with several different size ear pieces so they will fit any ear size.

title: Not nearly as impressive as I'd hoped
text:
I already own two pair of the Jabra Elite 75t headphones and all of my statements are in comparison to them.

Unfortunately, the Sony headphones did not stand out in the ways I needed, to convince me to keep them.

I am a man in my early 50's. According to my latest hearing test, I still have excellent hearing.

The foam plugs reached deeper into my ear canals and made both of them hurt almost right away. Changing sizes made no difference. It was the same pain I experienced, with the foam hearing protection earplugs I wore, while running overhead crane at a steel company.

I noticed no difference in passive sound isolation when compared to the silicone ones used by Jabra. However, they did not lose the, "airtight seal" when talking or chewing food. This prevented any outside noises from leaking in.

One noticable advantage was that they did not feel like they might fall out of my ears. The Jabra's have done so on more than one occasion.

Active noise isolation was, in my opinion, no better than the Jabra 's.

Control options for the touch functions were frustratingly limited. Having to sacrifice one set of desired functions to prioritize another, meant I would always have to access my phone.

Sound quality was a tiny bit clearer to me. I was definitely able to distinguish more instruments on the Sony's. I sampled several different songs on different devices. I played one song at a time, repeating it, until I had sampled all three headsets before connecting them to next device.

However, I might be one of the rare individuals able to notice this, as I was musically trained. I played violin in orchestra since 5th grade and am higher than average at distinguishing between individual sounds.

Most people might not notice any difference at all.

Bass was noticeably weaker, in comparison, as was the overall volume.

I did not notice the larger size of the headphones or any weight difference when using them. The battery life and recharge times was superior, but I did not like that the charging case was larger.

Also, it would have been nice if the charging case itself, was waterproof.

title: One very effective archival device!
text:
I bought this and a variety of 25, 50 and 100GB disks, then spent days making secure copies of everything important to me - basically my digital life for the past 30+ years. It took a lot longer to make the copies than I expected, but I didn't take into account the mass of data I was attempting to back up. Now that it is done, I have the peace of mind that comes from having one copy set in the bank safety deposit box, and another stored in a secret place on my property.

For decades I've upgraded to the newest, largest storage available. I suffered data loss on occasion simply because I didn't have enough backup media. Now, with 100GB at a time, I know close to a terabyte of data is more secure than ever. This is a resource I will pass on to my children, who can find out a lot about their ancestors.

I safeguarded my data using an old copy of Nero Burning Rom - a wonderful surprise. Even a product almost a decade old had no problems doing all the work for me! Not bad!

Now, with this drive and the ability to store up to 100GB in one fell swoop, I sleep better. The copies are offline. Nobody can hack them. I'm a professional security guru. I know my business and an well protected, so it is highly unlikely anyone will be able to hack my system. Even if someone tries a ransomeware attack, I can laugh in their faces! I am covered.

This is a more or less "bare drive" in a box. The USB interface gives on demand access, and I have yet to find a computer it will not work with. Using it with my antique Nero software, I have a complete and secure solution for the protection of my financial and personal life. If there is ever a disaster, all I have to do is reformat affected drives, if needed install Windows, then apply my backups and I'm fully back in business.

Though not cheap, this proved to be a wonderful tool for protecting my data. I sleep better now! I'm very happy I decided to give this drive a try! I've already bought another drive, this time an internal drive for my server. Works great!

title: BUY ANY KINDLE DEVICE FROM BESTBUY. AT LEAST BESTBUY WILL REPLACE IT IF THEY CANT FIX IT.
text: I bought this tablet and straight out of the box, it charges and drops to 0% . It then charged and held it‘s charge but that was my first experience. No kids touched it…. No wrong cable or anything. So, I’ve been having trouble with the fire 7 and the 8. One uses micro usb and the other uses usbC. The 8 holds a charge forever… I couldn’t be happier, but there are times where it just won’t charge. I went through this with the fire 7 and after a few times, AMAZON won’t replace the product. Now I know how kids are… putting things where they shouldn’t be and trying to charge it themselves, but in my case, that’s not the issue. I use my children’s  tablets for educational purposes only. My kids sit down with no cables or anything else to mess up any ports. They’re used solely for abc mouse, taken and put away.  So after a few months, they slowly decline and the fire 7 wont hold a charge at all. I’ve troubleshot the hell out of this thing and the end result is these things just suck. The 8 is better, but now it’s having a hard time charging. I’ve tried it all.  Usually Amazon is good about returning and troubleshooting but in my own personal experience and the hassle of this freaking device, I say go ahead and PURCHASE THIS DEVICE FROM BESTBUY AND GET THE WARRANTY WHERE GEEKSQUAD WILL EITHER FIX OR REPLACE THE ITEM. I’ve Spent such a long time on the phone troubleshooting and the problem is that it just sucks. I’m shocked to see 7th gen still for sale. It’s such a jip. Abc mouse works with 8 gen and up so I’m just going to begin the switch with brand new devices, purchased from BESTBUY. This is the first time I’ve had issues with the fire 8 but I know it’s simply inevitable. It’ll be replaced twice and that’s it. I know for a fact that my kids did not mess this device up because of how strict I am with screen time and I’m always with them while they’re on screen time.

title: Get this vertical stand
text:
(Item: Kuzy Laptop Stand Vertical - MacBook Vertical Stand Upright - Vertical Laptop Holder Desk Stand, Closed Mac Dual Laptop Stand MacBook Holder Stand for Desk - Vertical Laptop Stand 2 Slot, Black)

Wether you get this one or another brand, don’t choose a cheaper, lighter stand. They all look good in the listing pics. This is one of those products you'll want to choose correctly the first time. A good one will easily last more than a decade throughout your various laptop upgrades.

Out of the box, this one stands beautifully weighing in at just over 1 lb. If you use your laptop in clamshell mode, you’d be hard pressed to find a significantly better stand. 1 lb may not sound like much but, it's very weighty (which is a good thing)! There are quite a few vertical stands that look similar but are (literally) half the weight of this one. When you dock your laptop here, you’ll have zero concerns about it tipping/falling over. It is solid.

I selected the Black color. It’s perfect for my desktop setting. The design is simple, clean and modern. The width of both slots are adjustable with the included Allen wrench. And, the silicone padding protects my devices. It easily held my brothers 16” MacBook Pro M2 Max (just under 5 lbs).

If I was forced to nitpick about something, I wish they had included a smaller 1/2” lip on both sides of the stand. Just enough height to maybe rest your phone or a smaller tablet on without covering too much of its display. Not a major gripe at all, mind you. And, it’s something I would only use once in a while. But, would’ve been nice just to have. That aside, however, I really have no complaints.

The first Kuzy product I bought was a case for my then-new, 2013 MacBook Air. The case held up through 5 years of heavy traveling. And, currently, I still use it as a media player in my office. Back then, they were a brand new company to me. Today, they’re a brand I confidently buy from. This stand is an easy reccomendation for consideration.

title: For me, a perfect set of features
text:
I've been on a quest for the perfect mouse jiggler for quite a while. I started out by using glass container lids and drinking glasses to fool laser mice into producing random patterns on the screen. This worked, but was very fiddly and not easy to keep going.

I tried some new USB plug in electronic jigglers, but I don't like the idea of directly connecting a data device. The mechanical jigglers available during the past couple of years were expensive and noisy. Nothing seemed to be 'just right.'

Then - I saw this device. It's priced right; there's no direct data connection; it has perfectly quiet operation; and while not tested by me yet, the battery life should logically be great.

First, the device is made in the U.S. What? Yes, it's labeled all over as "Made in America." Not a big deal, but interesting. Secondly, the device is simple and to the point. There's a built in AA battery activated the first time by a paper pull tab. The case is secured by two medium size screws. Notice I didn't say 'tiny screws.' When and if I replace the battery myself, I'll appreciate working with larger than microscopic screws.

Third, the yin-yang rotating pattern works well for moving the mouse cursor slowly in different directions depending on how you place the mouse sensor on the device. My Bluetooth mouse has a laser sensor off to one side, so the mouse must be set slightly off center on the jiggler. The jiggler is large enough to allow me to do this without the mouse hanging off the edge. Nice that the manufacturer anticipated this...

I'm guessing this jiggler uses an inexpensive clock movement with a second hand function to move the disc. The mouse pointer eventually moves to the edge of the display, but still manages to tell the OS that it's moving. (The included quick guide mentions this, and I can confirm it works.) A clock movement should run for 1+ years as claimed by this device, with no need for an on/off button - super convenient.

I'm very happy I happened onto this device and I recommend it highly as an ideal solution for those looking for a simple, reliable, affordable, and *safe* mouse jiggler!

title: Decent Replacement
text:
My old Logitech WAVE keyboard and mouse is showing its age. The keys are fading and the mouse has been dropped so often its begining to stutter. So I was looking for a dependable backup system for when the day comes and I found the E-YOOSO wireless keyboard and mouse combo.

This is a 2.4G wireless setup that seems stable and will connect up to 10m (33 feet). Its nice not to have to install any drivers. It comes with a USB receiver that can connect both the keyboard and mouse, and can be used separately. The keyboard has a comfortable touch and typing feel, and features a palm rest and folding holder for added comfort. I like a keyboard with some lip that lets it be handled without touching off any keys. The mouse is grippy with a stripe pattern on the side to prevent slipping.

This combo has some advanced features including an automatic power-saving function, which will automatically enter sleep mode after a period of inactivity to save power. It claims to be splash-proof which I'll have to see before I believe it. But the panel has a waterproof conductive membrane and multiple drainage holes for double protection. I'll try it out in the pool this summer and let you know how that works out. LOL! J/K. The advert says it has a an ABS injection-molded body, making it stable and non-toxic. But seriously, I like that the keyboard is easy to clean and any liquid that may get on it has a way to drain.

The wireless mouse has 3 adjustable DPI levels (1000/1600/2400) for sensitivity adjustment and smooth movement on smooth surfaces. It also has a symmetry design that makes it suitable for both right-handed and left-handed users. That's a definite plus because after years of right handed use, I have had to learn to use the mouse in my left hand. This mouse is much like my Logitech MX300 though without the batteries, it's much lighter.

Overall, the E-YOOSO wireless keyboard and mouse combo is a great option for those who want a comfortable, ergonomic, and reliable set of wireless peripherals for their computer or laptop. I'll miss my WAVE but this'll do fine when the time comes.

title: Retractable cable is the distinguishing feature
text:
Update 2023-Feb-25:
So far, I just used 2-prong plugs but now that I put the power strip to another location where I have grounded plugs and large-size plugs, I find the orientation of the outlets not very practicable. The ground points inward, therefore the cables meet in the middle. For large plugs that have equally sized prongs it is possible to plug them in in either direction.
I took another picture and attached it. I feel that the use of the power strip can be largely limited when using grounded plugs.

--- previously ---
The power strip comes without extra manual, but the packaging states some specs: Input Voltage AC100-125 ~50/60 Hz; Rated Power: 10A Max 125V; USB Output: DC5V-3A, 9v-2A, 12V-1.66A.

There's no spec regarding the surge protection capacity -- the marketing description talks about 2000 Joules but in a customer question the seller states "Yes it's a surge protector power strip. 120~180 joules."
I think that's contradicting and confusing.

The 4AC outlets are grounded and with 1 USB-A and 1 USB-C, the power strip is equipped for ordinary and common scenarios. With regard to the number of outlets, this power strip with the given compact form factor ranges only in the middle field of the competitors, but the retractable cable of course needs half of the space of the inner part of the device; therefore, it really depends on what someone's major criterion is when selecting a power strip.
The fact that the cable is retractable makes it a good choice for situations where the cable shall visually disappear -- to me, that is the only distinguishing feature of this power strip.
Rolling in and out the cable works smoothly -- I measured about 53 inch cable length from the plug to the point where the cable enters the housing -- the marketed cable length of 5 ft is probably meant to be measured from the plug to the outer, opposite edge of the housing.
The cable and plug are standard round and not flat, what would be even nicer.
The power strip can be hung with the attachable hook that is part of the product. Otherwise, there's no other mounting possibility available right out of the box.

title: Sturdy messenger bag
text:
This messenger bag is sturdy and well made. The stitching is strong and even. The main straps have metal devices on the buckles that snap into metal loops on the body of the bag; that means that to open and close the main compartment of the bag it isn't necessary to unbuckle the straps. One can just press the snap devices and release those, without moving the buckles. I mention that especially because I didn't notice it when I first looked at this bag on Amazon. I was going to reject this bag because of the hassle of having to buckle and unbuckle the straps any time I wanted to open it. You don't have to do that.

The small compartment attached to the front of the bag doesn't have such a snap in device, so you do have to buckle it and unbuckle it.

The bag has more compartments than was at first apparent. Many options to carry your stuff. If fully extended the sides are four inches deep, so fully stuffed the bag has a large capacity.

It is made of stiff leather which is fairly heavy. In my opinion this is proper since a softer, more luxurious garment leather wouldn't hold up to the abuse that a briefcase is likely to get. If you want to soften it and preserve it a good leather conditioner would help; you should probably do that anyway since real leather can dry out and even sometimes crack when it gets old.

Someone else mentioned that the bag smells. It does; it smells like the tanning chemicals, I think. Personally I don't find the odor to be very strong on my particular bag.

I am downrating this item by one star because of what I consider a minor design flaw. The main straps appear to be longer than could ever be necessary even if the bag is fully stuffed. I suppose this might be used to strap something to the front of the bag, under the straps, but anything so held wouldn't be secure. As it is the overlong straps are going to dangle and get in the way. One could trim them, but they are stitched all the way around the edges- a nice detail- so of course I don't want to do that.

All in all a very nice piece of luggage. I like it and I expect I'll get a lot of use out of it.

title: Microsoft wireless mouse model 1383 of Microsoft mouse 4000 is a piece of junk.
text: I've been using a number of Microsoft mouse units since the late 80s with the early versions of Windows 3.0 was issued. I have never had the issues, that I have had with this Microsoft wireless mouse model 1383 of the Microsoft wireless mouse 4000. This has to be the biggest piece of junk that I ever purchased. It eats batteries in a few months. It also has a cheap on/off switch. When I first got it, I had no problems. After about four months the pointer started jumping all over the place. I replaced the batteries, but that only fixed it for a few weeks. So I ended up switching it off and then on for the pointer to stabalize. That didn't last long. After a while the pointer would track and then jump somewhere else. It seemed as if the power switch would not engage in the full on mode, but seemed to back off to where it just barely stayed on. I ended up disconnecting this unit, and replacing it with an older wired Microsoft mouse. It works just fine. I just don't like having the wire get in the way all the time, but at least the pointer is under control. After using the wireless mouse in question, I found out that I could not highlight sections of a site in order to cut and paste. It would only copy the whole paragraph or nothing, but certainly not any words or single sentences. My old wired version works perfectly. This wireless mouse has been nothing but trouble, so I must assume that it is a cheaply made piece of crap. Finally I must complain about the battery cover. I had to press the one button before I could PRY open the battery compartment cover using one of my wife's metal nail files. I even tried pressing both buttons, and it never made a difference. If I ever buy another wireless mouse, it will never be one from Microsoft. Still I have to mention that every other Microsoft mouse, that purchased prior to this one worked fine, but it has been several years since I decided to replace a mouse unit. This new one just feels cheap and poorly made, so I am not surprised that it never worked as I needed it to work. And yes, before anyone asks, I plugged my wired mouse into the same port that I used for crappy, cheaply made wireless one, and the wired mouse worked perfectly. Oh how the great have fallen. I wonder if Bill Gates would have allowed profits to over ride quality?

title: Budget Warrior does the job...
text:
The Ankbit E500Pro+ surprised me in good way. I don't want to exaggerate and say this will blow away your Premium headphones, but they will surprise you in many ways.

PROS:

-Borrows design aesthetic from Sony WH-1000-XM4 which is a good thing I feel. You get the ability to fold this headset nice a neat into its storage case. Also, feel comfortable like the XM4, but the cans are smaller

-Supports Bluetooth with support for LDAC and High-Res Audio formats

- Includes a nice storage case to protect your headphones and fits easily into a backpack

-Call quality was surprisingly good. I kept getting 'you sound very clear' from my mates.

-Battery life is very good on these headphones, but not as good as XM4

-Price is very affordable

CONS:

-The sound quality is not bad at all, but it's definitely missing the BASS! These headphones have good treble and highs, but not much BASS at all. This leaves certain genres of music sounding a bit flat and tinny.

-The noise cancellation is just okay. I got a lot of external noise coming through with ANC on.

-Even though these headphones support high-res audio, your high resolution is wasted on these headphones.

-Gaming Mode and Music modes sound identical. I was kind of hoping that music mode would help bring in more quality into the music side of things, but not a noticeable difference in either mode.

-This might be a bit of nit picking, but these headphones initially came with a 'heavy chemical' smell. I let these air out for 3 days and it's still prevalent. I am sure over time the smell will fade, but it certainly persistent.

If you are an audiophile, I would not get these headphones. However, maybe you want a decent headset for younger user [child, early teen] or maybe a headset for work that won't break the bank...than I would certainly give these a try!

I hope this review helps!

title: So much better than a fish finder!!!
text:
So right off the bat I have about the most expensive fish finder you can get on my boat. And truth be told, it does work......But not very well to say the least. It interprets anything in the water as a fish. Old tire (school of fish), floating log (big school of fish) and seaweed as a whale (seriously it shows its basically a whale) so needless to say based on these facts my fish finder isnt so great. Now its good to get you in a rough area of where the fish are, but thats about it. Once you've narrowed it down to a quarter acre sized area you than have to rely on intuition and time to get a bite. Something both my kids and I dont possess. They are easily bored after a few minutes. So to keep their interest in fishing I got one of these cameras.

In all honesty I didnt expect much based on the cost. (My fish finder was in the thousands so good could this be) however I am happy to say that I was very wrong. Not only is this great for viewing the actual fish under water, but my kids absolutely love it. Seeing the fish swimming around and having them guide me to where to cast my line is pretty much their new favorite past time. Anyhow let me roll into a few pros/cons

Pros:
-Much cheaper than a fish finder
-IMHO much more useful than a fish finder
-Great clarity of camera
-Bright screen that you can see in sun light
-Comes in a nice carrying case and is easy setup
-Super easy to use, no complex apps or setup necessary, toss it in and turn it on

Cons:
-As its tethered it can get caught in the prop or on underwater debris

Outside of the one con in my book this is the ultimate addition to any fisherman that doesnt want to spend all day fishing. Which I really dont mind, but theres no way I can keep the kids entertained on an 8+ hour fishing trip....especially if we arent catching. Some may say this is cheating, but than again so is using a fish finder. I personally think of it more as a tool than a cheat....But thats just my .02

title: Really flimsy - cheap for a reason
text:
These mast mounts are cheap for a reason. They probably cost about as much to produce as a soda can. The metal is flimsy, and thin. The lack of rigidity in the material makes it hard to tighten down the mast and keep it from moving. I have no confidence in these staying in the position I placed them.

I used them to mount a wireless point-to-point bridge which was very light, <100g/.25lb. and will present almost no wind load. The base has a single column of slots down the center to screw the mount into the fascia board or whatever your mounting base is, and that makes it incredibly unstable. Most antenna mounts have a minimum of 4 mounting holes (1 on the top left, 1 on the top right, 1 on the bottom left, and 1on the bottom right of the bracket) which makes them stable. This mount with two holes in the center gives it almost no ability to withstand any side to side force like when the wind blows it left to right.

Once you have the mount adjusted and positioned the way you want it, there is a single screw on each side of the mast bracket that you tighten to fix it into position. Those single screws can't be tightened down enough to hold the mast securely. In our case, after cranking on the tightening screws the mast still drooped as soon as a little weight was put on it from the Cat6 cable.

I have zero confidence in this mast staying in position over time, and I regret ordering this over a more sturdy mast mount. The time that will be wasted having to readjust and tighten this will far exceed the extra $10 -$20 on a real mount. Keep in mind, I'm only expecting this to support a piece of equipment with hardly any weight on it, and I still have no confidence in it.

Not to totally bash the product, it does have a few good features. it doesn't look like it will rust, the base includes a pole mount which is actually much more secure than the screw mount, and it includes some worm gear clamps.

I can't think of many applications where I would use this mount. Again, I would recommend spending an extra $10-$20 for a real mast mount.

title: Great for every day use
text:
Overall, I've been very happy with these, and am purchasing a new set of these same headphones after 14 months of heavy daily use. My first set is just starting to have trouble with losing sound in the right ear. Also, the little rubber piece that protects the charging port broke off months ago, and I only recently finally lost it. The battery still holds its charge well - I haven't noticed any reduction in charge time.

I really love this over-ear clip design. I hate ear buds, and used the wired version of these same headphones for years until finding this wireless version. Not having noise cancellation is a plus for me, since I want to listen to music but still be able to hear when my kids need to get my attention. Also, this wire design works well - I wear it under the neck, and it's adjustable with a little sliding piece, though I never use that. Some similar over-ear headphones have a shorter wire that goes around the back of the neck, which is super inconvenient if you have long hair.

The weak point of the KOSS headphones for me has always been eventually losing sound in one side. However, this happened much more quickly in the wired models (maybe 6 months vs. 14 months wireless). The wired ones can easily get caught on knobs and things when you walk around, causing tugs on the wire, which is probably what leads to the problem. Wireless obviously doesn't have this issue as much, since it only has the short wire between earpieces, though if you are someone to stash them in a pocket/purse when not using, it would be advisable to be very gentle when pulling them out again so as not to tug on the wire connections to the earpiece. I was not diligent in this, and so am not surprised that they eventually gave out. Your mileage may vary.

Sound is really good in these, and I have had no trouble pairing these with my phone (Samsung S7). When battery is low, it starts to make a little chime every couple minutes during playback. The range is acceptable, but not great - it sometimes will start to cut out if my phone is on the other side of the house from where I am, but it's not a big deal. You can also accept incoming calls through the headset.

title: I really like this
text:
I have a 2,600 sq-ft house on three floors. The old router had been in the basement and worked reasonably well until I started working from home in 2020. With the computer on the second floor it made for a slow connection. I ended up connecting the router and modem to an unused coaxial cable on the second floor and everything was fine until last summer, when download speeds dropped to near zero. After repeated visits from the internet provider, we determined that the coax cable from the basement to the 2nd floor was bad. Why a cable buried in the wall would suddenly do that, I don't understand. But the modem and router went back into the basement, which was almost as bad as the bad coax cable had been. It also made for a bad connection to the master bedroom and the garage. The internet provider suggested a mesh router. I looked at a lot and after weeks, I finally picked this one. It has three units and they are spread around the house and different floors. Now, no matter where any of us are, we have very good wi-fi signals.

I was worried about connectivity with wi-fi 6.0 and everything has worked fine except for an old IPod mini from the mid-90's. For whatever reason, when I type in the wi-fi password, it keeps saying it's incorrect. I'm not worried about it since the mini is plugged into an alarm clock and if I ever need to update the music on it, it will be connected to a PC.

The app is nice and one can also connect to the wi-fi on a PC, which I like too. I especially like that I can priortize connections, so my work PC is set as a priority and if someone(s) is streaming a movie it does not affect me.

I have two items plugged into the ethernet ports on two of the devices and they both work fine.

I'm quite happy with it. It was a nice price and they both look nice. I was worried about the signal since this is the first wi-fi router I've had that does not have any visible antennas, but reception has been good everywhere in the house.

I would recommend this to anyone needing a mesh wi-fi.

title: A Decorative Record Player for Any Setup
text:
There are more things about this record player that shocked me than I thought there would be. Not only is it much larger than I assumed it would be, but there are several ways you can set up these speakers to fit any type of setup you might have.

The main record player has an excellent protective cover lid to protect your records from dust and other particles that may interfere with the needle, and there are multiple different playback speed modes and features to choose from when you play your records. It also has two large speaker units that serve as the output for the record player, but there is also built-in Bluetooth functionality for those that prefer to listen to music directly out of their phone, tablet or other connected device. You can also set up the components in different positions to work best with the space you have available to you, whether you need to put one piece on top of a shelf and the rest underneath, or you need to stack them, place them side to side, or any numerous other configurations that are within reach. This is definitely something I am glad they thought of as my desk has limited space and being able to spread out the speakers is a huge benefit.

As far as the sound quality goes, the speakers are more full and vibrant than I expected, but occasionally I did notice some quality drops when using records, but I don't know if that is due to my records having any scratches or if it is from the needle not balancing properly. However, when using Bluetooth with my phone, the quality issues go away completely and most of my tracks sound excellent. With Bluetooth the speakers also seem to get louder, in my opinion, than when playing records. Once again, I am unsure if this is how it's designed or whether there is an issue with my records or the needle. I will say that even if you just use it as a Bluetooth speaker, it adds a retro vibe to whatever room you might be using it in as the system looks very elegant. The speakers are also very dense, and I believe that everything was made with quality materials in mind.

Overall, this is an excellent, unique record player/Bluetooth speaker that most people would enjoy. However, if you don't own any records, then there are other Bluetooth speakers you might be interested in but at a lower cost. I would recommend this record player, but only for those specifically looking for this product or style.

title: OK, but could so easily be better
text:
The height and width are just what I needed to hold my two monitors at a healthy height for me. It would be nice if it were a little deeper, but I knew the dimensions when I bought it so can’t really have any complaint about that.

But there are several annoyances, that it would be so easy for the manufacturer to fix. First is assembly. It’s like getting something from Ikea, complete with the wordless, inscrutable assembly instructions, but MOSTLY not too bad. All the first steps are straightforward, though a tad tedious. But the last assembly step, putting on the outer legs, is horrible. It’s hard enough fishing the screws through the relevant holds then desperately trying to get them both threaded into the bottom of the top surface before things start wiggling around and separating. But once you’ve done that the Allen wrench supplied for tightening them can’t actually go around, so you have to spend nearly half an hour fiddling with it through tiny fractions of rotations and then resetting the Allen wrench, four times over for the four screws. They really should supply a more appropriate tool, perhaps a second, slightly shorter Allen wrench?

And once it’s all built it sags in the middle. Not a lot, but with a monitor on each end enough to be annoying. The reason for the sag is they have rubber feet on the legs on the ends, but NONE on the middle support, so that latter ends up being a tiny bit shorter. But the overall thing is long enough that a tiny bit of difference is more than enough to make a noticeable, annoying sag. I put some shims under the middle support and that makes it much better; but we shouldn’t have to do that, it should come with the middle support having matching rubber feet or whatever, to make it the same height as the end legs.

A slight cosmetic issue is the unsightly holes for the connectors of the middle support. It would be nice if they supplied some black plugs to fill them in. I’ve just used a little bit of black electrical tape to cover them, which makes things look much tidier.

End of story, it’s now meeting my needs nicely, but it was a minor ordeal getting to this point.

title: Not user friendly
text:
I had purchased a different brand camera prior to this one and had some problems with it,(i.e. no zoom while video, unable to operate from a distance without wifi) so I returned it, I EMAILED THIS MANUFACTURER with EXACTLY what I was looking for, how I was wanting to use it and what I required (I'm trying to video my son's baseball games to make highlights) they emailed me back and told me "the bravo 7 was the one I needed" .....WRONG.
I was excited when I saw it had a wrist worn remote now I'm laughing as the camera has to be turned on physically (and if you thought you could keep it on standby and press record as needed, NOPE it shuts off so you have to get up to turn it on...why have a remote?? yes, I had a full charged battery) speaking of the laughable remote, you have to be within maybe 1.5feet of the camera in order to get it to record and there's no way of knowing that it is recording (learned the hard way as I found out after I had pressed it that it did not record) so if you want a camera that you have to get up to turn on to then use a remote and HOPE that it communicated to begin recording within that extremely short distance this would be the one for you...does it zoom while recording? well, yes but there's no way to control it unless you're standing at the backstop manually adjusting depending on what you are trying to record at the moment an actual remote that does all that, turns on camera, INDICATES it is recording and you could zoom with would be phenomenal...I guess that is not an option. Oh, let's not forget that it does not come with a memory card so you need to remember to get one of those BUT not bigger than 64gb or it "won't be compatible" (here's an idea, charge $10 more and include it with the camera so we can actually use the camera when it arrives!!)also battery is on bottom of the camera so if you have it mounted it is a pain to unmount, open and change out. Theres no manual so you have to download it. All around disappointment. going back to the old fashioned way of recording with my cell phone :( or maybe I'll buy a camcorder from the 90's...

title: 2007 Scion tC, not a great option
text:
Was replacing blown factory door speakers. Bought these adapters.
Did not use them, because not the best option at my disposal.

OEM speaker-spacer has more depth than this Scosche adapter.
OEM also has dust/debris/fluid 'awning' plastic, that helps prevent debris that falls/drips into the door through the window seal, from landing on the speaker. Scosche adapter does not.
OEM speaker-spacer is already mounted to the door.

I opted instead to discard the Scosche adapters, and modify the OEM speaker-spacer, to mount my new speakers.

I left the OEM speaker plastic mounted to the door; but cut the old speaker out of it with these steps.
I cut the cone surround.
Yanked the cone out.
Cut the plastic speaker frame ribs, with heavy duty side cutters.
Cut the copper wires connecting the terminals to the voice coil.
The above allowed me to completely remove the old speaker cone, etc. from the old adapter plastic spacer.

I then did some clean-up trimming/removing of the OEM plastic speaker ribs.
I pushed the OEM speaker connector out of its mounting location in the speaker-spacer.
I did use the Metra wiring harness adapter to connect the OEM audio connector to the new speaker terminals. Much less hassle than trimming/stripping/soldering.

I lined up my new speaker with the OEM speaker-spacer.
Then, pre-drilled some mounting holes through the OEM speaker-spacer & door, that lined up with the mounting ears on my new speaker.
Some vacuuming clean-up work to remove drilling & cutting debris.
Connected the Metra wire adapter to the OEM connector, and the new speaker terminals.
I then used some sheet-metal screws to mount the new speaker to the OEM speaker-spacer/car-door-metal.

Wallah.
To my mind, re-purposing the OEM plastic speaker-spacer was less work, and a better outcome than if I had not discarded this Scosche adapter set.

Your mileage may vary.

title: Good Security Camera, Quality photos and Videos
text:
Advertised as: CG6 3MP Solar Security Camera Wireless, Outdoor, Rechargeable, Battery Powered, Vicohome App, 2-Way Audio, PIR Motion Sensor, Color Night Vision, IP66, SD Card/Cloud Storage

I have several other security cameras that work on rechargeable batteries, but this one interested me as it came with a solar panel. Living in Western PA, in the winter we get a lot of gray, gloomy days and sunlight is at a premium. The test for this camera was if it would stay charged with the solar panel. To set it up, first you'll need to download the Vicohome app. The process was straightforward and I didn't have any problems connecting. Mounting the camera and solar panel likewise was straightforward.

Once connected there are lots of options you can set including an alarm schedule, notification of events, SD or HD recording modes, how many seconds of recording up to 20 seconds/per event and many others.
The area I am covering is my front door and sidewalk. I found that the "medium" motion sensitivity setting was best and camera needed to be aimed downward so as not to falsely trigger when every car went past. On the high setting, squirrels and birds would set it off. The solar panel works well and battery level has remained nearly fully charged in spite of frequent recordings.

The pictures, videos and audio recordings are clear but the camera often starts recording later than what I would prefer. I have it set to 20 seconds of recording time, (which is the maximum) but I'd like to be able to choose 30 or 40 seconds. The VicoHome app is good and fairly straightforward. It's easy to see photos and videos and they can be stored locally if an SD card is installed, (not included) or on the cloud. A subscription is offered if you want to expand the storage capacity on the cloud.

Bottom line: Decent security camera. App is easy to use and provides a number of useful features such as scheduling, sensitivity settings, the ability to activate an "alarm" and to speak with a person at the door from a remote location. Recording times are limited to 20 seconds and recording often begins when the subject is close to the door rather than prior to.

title: Fantastic camera for monitoring basements, or other areas that have power
text:
I bought one of these for $20 at Walmart and just figured it would be a cute toy to monitor my parakeets when I'm away. The pairing is a pain, but once you learn how to do it it gets easier. The camera's powered by USB, so it's an indoor camera only which is something to keep in mind. What's awesome is you can put the SD card in, and not have to pay for a monthly plan like other cameras.

The video quality is very good in both will let areas and dark rooms. The IR absolutely lights up an entire room. Primarily I use this camera to monitor various areas of my basement for water leakage and to remotely view it when I'm away from home. The motion detection is very very sensitive to the point of being almost unusable, any light movement from the Sun or clouds going by will trigger it.

Overall for $20 a camera I'm very very happy for this application. I also have three Arlo cameras monitoring the house, however I feel like the Energizer cameras record more versus not having the Arlo cloud plan to store everything. I'm up to five cameras now, so it's very nice to have full coverage and not have to pay $120 a camera.

Overall if you have an area with good Wi-Fi coverage and outlets, these cameras are the cheapest and best way to remotely monitor them. The app works well, and I've even gotten the remote plugs which are about $20 for four, I put one on my wireless router to reboot it without having to go under the cabinets, and I use the others for lighting control.

Overall, once you get to know the products and have applications for them, the Energizer connect products are actually quite good. I just wish they'd get the water leak detector back in stock which would really really help me out.

Edit: The Alro cameras have now become worthless because I had a three month intro plan I had no idea existed, so the cameras no longer function as a security device without paying $12.99 a month. The Energizer cameras still function and don't require a monthly fee. Arlo is an absolute ripoff. I'm not paying them $156 a year forever to make the products I bought from them (at a premium price) minimally functional.

title: I love this light - but it's not without some issues...
text:
I did not get this light to use a selfie-light, instead I got it to use as backlight for a slide digitizer I was building. I'm going to point out some negatives first, but be aware that overall I do love this light (so keep these negatives in mind, but be sure to read through to the positives as well).

For this application it has two distinct drawbacks that can be seen in the attached image - the diffuser does not do a great job of actually diffusing the light from the individual leds, and in the "cold light" mode only half the leds are illuminated. As you can see from the picture there is a grid of leds, half are the 6000K (bright white/cold) leds and the other half are 2600K (very soft, almost yellow/warm) leds. because of this you can only get "full" brightness in the "natural" setting which illuminates both sets of leds. This isn't that big of a deal because even with only the cold leds lit the light is *very* bright at 100% brightness. This pic was taken at the lowest brightness, but the individual leds are still quite noticeable even at 100% intensity. Because of this weak diffusion I had to add an additional diffuser in my application.

Now the positives. This light is a very convenient size (4.375 x 2.125 x 0.75 thick) and the light extends all the way to the edges (it's borderless). It also is very bright at max intensity. It is working for several hours on a charge (I've generally been running at high brightness) and it can work even while being charged. It comes with a variety of mounting options - I'm not using any of them, but they seem useful and well thought out. The light does not get hot when operating, even at full brightness.

For my application this light turns out to be almost perfect (with the additional diffuser) - so even though I was tempted to remove a star for the weak diffusion I decided to add it back because of the overall ergonomics and how well it seems to work. I also suspect that the lack of diffusion would not be an issue if you used this for its intended purpose of a selfie light.

title: (Still) Needs More Instructions
text:
It took quite a while to figure the set-up of this device. For the instructions that were included, they may have well just left them out. It appears the instructions are geared towards iPhone users. I’m an Android Gal but I can usually translate such things over to Android but no so much with this device and the included document (I can’t even call it instructions).

The instructions fails to tell you that you need to start the set-up on a computer so that you can “bound” the email. I figured out that “bound” is probably the same as “verify”. Unfortunately, once you “bind” an email you can’t update it or change it (per the website). That makes no sense the way some people change email addresses but I suppose you could just factory reset the device and start over with a new “bound” email if necessary.

I installed a micro SD Card but can’t figure out where to get the videos that are saved on it. The instructions indicate you have to go online (not from the app) and download them from a certain area but I can’t, for the life of me, find this area to download the recorded videos from.

When I try to connect the app to my Amazon account that function does not work and I get an error message indicating “Oops! That page can’t be found” I have yet to figure this function out so right now it’s a no go with my Alexa account. I reached out to support. I’ll let you know if they ever answer back.

The two-way talk feature is very garbled in my situation. I can’t get it to sound very clear at all.

The camera itself has pretty good video quality. The camera will move once you finally connect it to the app and do your movements from the app. Also, you can set the camera to automatically follow movement.

I set-up to get notifications for movements but I have received no notifications at all and there has been plenty of movement.

I cannot recommend that anyone waste their hard earned money on this camera unless you like troubleshooting (and are good at it).

title: 5 Years And Still Look And Operated Like New
text:
First let me start with the pros and cons.
Pros:
Noise Cancelation Works Well
Sound quality is good but slightly lacking in bass
The muff material is comfortable
Easily adjustable and holds adjustment
The muff fits over ear, close for me but I have big ears
Durable (I will address this below)

Cons:
Lacking bass
Sound Cancelation works on batteries
The microphone sound quality
Some devices will not respond to volume control

I have used these everyday for 5 years, from working in the marine industry to the trucking industry and using them at home for my Xbox and computer and they look and work great. There are very little signs these have had such heavy use and I do not use the case that came with it. The muff material is comfortable and is durable. The muffs are big enough to surround my ear though it's barely big enough. I can wear and do wear these for hours without any issues. They do not make me sweaty and they seem to breathe pretty good. In high humidity areas such as the gulf coast you will get some dampness after wearing them for several hours but you will also be damp just from the environment. The adjustment for these have held mostly since I bought it and adjusted it the first time. The only times I have had to readjust is after storing them in my bag when traveling with them packed away or after my wife uses them. The sound quality is good, as expected from Bose, the bass is lacking but that is not exactly surprising. The noise canceling abilities is pretty good, worked in an idling semi truck when I would watch a movie but the batteries that power the noise canceling last about 4 hours. I wish there was an option to have it plugged into a power source but that is just me. The microphone sounds quality is OK and definitely could have been improved but I don't usually use these to talk in the phone. I have found that some devices will not respond to the volume control though I can't rule out that being a device issue instead of a headphone issue.

Overall I would buy these again if I needed to but unless my dog chews on them or I do something stupid and break them I don't see myself replacing these anytime soon.

title: Love it!
text:
I've had a non-screen XP Pen until I wore the surface off when one of the nibs became scratchy - I've upgraded and I love it.
I have a couple of issues with it:
Firstly, which turned out not to be an issue, is that it takes a second or so to turn on - you have to leave your finger on the touch sensor - It's enough of a noticeable delay that I thought mine was broken as it only turned on after I'd started wiggling the power connection - so I thought mine was defective, but if you leave you finger on the sensor and wait, it does turn on ok!
Secondly, it comes with cords, but they're all super short! None of them would fit from the tablet to my computer / power source - they're all on the right side of the unit at the back, and my computer and wall socket are on my left.... So I had to buy 3 more much longer cables before I could use it, so keep that in mind when you buy it - unless your computer and power source is a very short distance away on the right, you will need longer cables.
After that everything is easy - the manual is online, the quick start guide gets you to it, as well as the driver and it's really easy to set up and use after that.
My previous XP Pen was a Deco Pro - and I adored the wheel on that - I really wish this one had that wheel with the outer rim and the inner touch pad, but it sadly doesn't. I'm right handed so I have the pen in my right hand, which means the buttons and wheel on the right side are effectively unusable, so I find I'm having to reach over when I want to rotate the screen (which is what I've assigned the right wheel to do), which is annoying - my left wheel is brush size and I use that more. I don't use the buttons at all because I find it easier to have my left hand on my keyboard where I have access to a lot more keys in a much smaller space so I can work faster - This ultimately would rock if it had the big Deco Pro wheel either on one side (with the ability to turn it up the other way for left handers) or one on each side - that would be my absolutely ideal tablet. In the meantime I'm happy with this :)

title: Work from home IMPRESSIVE!
text:
This wireless noise canceling Bluetooth headset works crystal clear and connects quickly to my laptop. I somewhat work for a call center but I work from home and take multiple phone calls A-day. The software we use is Microsoft Teams & Voice for Pests + Soft Phone.
Don't get me wrong, this is by far the nicest headset I have ever used and definitely the most comfortable. With sponge on one side and that your piece is so soft it feels like a little marshmallow on your ear. The microphone is so noise canceling that I can't even hear myself speak into it which is very interesting but the noise cancel is Exquisite. The only downside to this is when my phone rings, the call will display on my screen on my laptop but the 1st ring doesn't come through. The phone doesn't make an audio ring sound until the 2nd call which can be somewhat vital when you work for a call center and the phone only rings 3 times before you miss a call so that's somewhat risky with this headset but other than that, the freedom to walk around my house while "at work in" Has been such a relief and enjoyment. I've been using this headset for about 4 days now and it's perfect other than the phone ringing.. there is also if you use Microsoft Teams, The notification pop up sound is extremely faint but that's very common for every Bluetooth device with that software. ..& I don't hate that at all!
I have been using this for a few days and I charge it every night but barely use any of the battery during my 9 hour daily shifts so if I did forget to charge it one night, I believe it would get me through at least 1 more day of a shift full time. I operate my phone thru the mouse on the laptop so I have not had the opportunity to answer calls or play with the volume.. I did turn the volume up and that seemed to work but I'm already hard-of-hearing as it is. .. But this headset is definitely very fancy and I am the envy of my coworkers regarding that. It's light but also heavy duty feeling because it's such a quality product I can tell. I just took away that 1 star because there is a lag in the phone ringing and that can be very dangerous when you work for a call center. Other than that, this is a perfect headset if you are in the market for a Bluetooth headset.

title: My go-to charger these days.
text:
Reviewing Tenergy T9688 (4 slot D-C-AA-AAA and does AAAA as well)
Purchased 08 Feb 2023
All slots hold officially supported battery sizes tightly. (I have also used it for my tiny quad-A batteries and they work also.)
I probably should give it 5 stars but sometimes I think people tend not to believe a review if 5 stars are awarded by a user.
Charge time is moderate which is just what Tenergy advertises and it's just what I desire because the batteries last longer when gently charged. The discharge/recharge cycle works fine, too. I have no complaints. It's rock solid just like my other Tenergy charger.
I also have a Tenergy TN162 8-slot AA charger since Juy 2021. It works fine all this time. No problems.
The 4 slot T9688 has a 500 milliamp USB port. It's not worth much because practicalliy nothing functions on that little bit of power these days. The USB port only works when the charger is not charging batteries. I have a low draw USB lamp that uses 100 milliamperes. I plugged it into the USB port just for fun. The light plugged into the USB port comes on. If you then charge batteries, the light goes off...until the battery charging process finishes then the USB port is automatically re-energized and my lamp comes on again. So, the USB port could be used to light a lamp to let you know it's done charging. Or, maybe Arduino or Raspberry Pi users would want to use that port to trigger something fun when the battery charge process is done--like send an emaill or activate a buzzer?
I don't know what else to say. The Tenergy chargers just do what they are supposed to do and they feel substantially weighted like high-quality materials probably comprise the devices. I plan to get another 4-slot Tenergy so I'll have 2 of the 4-slot models because my aged Vanson BC1HU 4-slot chargers are getting very old and smelling of phenolic overheat...so the young strong Tenergy chargers are ready to step in and take over and keep me powered up. Thank you, Tenergy.

title: Almost a five star (see review)
text:
Review of VETEK 1080 Video Camera Camcorder, 30MP Vlogging Camera with WiFi Digital Camera, 16X Digital Zoom Video Camera for YouTube, with 32GB SD Card, 2.4G Remote Control and Two Batteries（Red）

Very nice quality for the price. Great set of goodies, SD card, lens cap, mic, two batteries with charger are all quite nice. The case is small, only the camera fits, not the mic; or you can put the mic and accessories and not the camera, which is what I am doing with it.

I wanted this to use for a second video recorder for making painting videos and capturing a different angle to use for my editing.

There is a problem with this camera’s design: the battery compartment is too close to the tripod screw hole. This is a problem because it does not allow for practical use of a quick release plate. Sure you can put one on, but it has to be removed every time you want to take out the battery or the SD Card, which I would have to do several times during a painting recording session.

I overcame the problem because this cam is so lightweight that an unconventional arrangement is possible, and my cam now rests on a threaded screw into a threaded bar with several threaded hole locations to offset the camera clear of the plate, then I just loosen the bar by turning it a 1/4 turn to the side and it clears the compartment door (see photo). This is my one complaint with this camera. If the threaded opening was switched with the unthreaded opening (just a little in front of the other) this would not be needed. If you plan to just hold the camera it is not a problem. If you only need to change the battery or take out the card occasionally for your use, or don’t mind removing it from the tripod mount this is not a problem. For me it was inconvenient.

Nicely featured recorder, some surprising functions and features (slow motion and time lapse to name just two) for an inexpensive camera, video recorder. I just wish that the threaded hole to attach to a tripod was even a quarter of an inch further from the battery compartment door, to allow for the use of a quick release device.

title: Save yourself some time
text:
I spent a lot of time looking for a wake up light. So many options and considerations and often times, reading reviews don’t help. After an embarrassing amount of time I finally chose this one.

This wake up light is packed with features and well thought out. Of course with more features there’s slightly more to learn…but it’s worth it.

I almost went with another light that’s 3 X the cost of this one but found out the light only came on when the alarm sounded. That defeats the purpose. Also, this model has a lot more features than other models and at around $40 it’s a steal.

Pros:

~Attractive transition from warm/soft wake up light to a bright midday sun look. In other words, it’ll wake you up.

~Lots of sound options. From relaxing rain to an old time bell (great if you’re motivated by irritation) to your favorite radio station, and many more.

~RGB and mood light. There’sa whole bunch of options with these two. My favorite one is a reddish mood light that gently pulsates. I turn this one on before bed (it goes off in 30 minutes but you can program it for 5, 10, etc). It’s the right tone of red light and mesmerizing. This feature alone is worth the price for me because it has got me over my addiction of looking at my phone in bed.

~Snooze button is easily accessible, on top, push down. Other models had you searching for a small button.

~Many more options. This wake up light designer thought of it all. Yes, it takes a bit getting used to but anything new does. Personally, I prefer all the options. It insures it’ll fulfill most every need.

Cons:

~Durability? It too soon to tell. It’s made of plastic and at this price it’s expected. As long as you don’t knock it off your nightstand or wake up in a rage and punch the little feller it’ll keep shining bright on your pretty (morning) face.

title: Updated review - is a nice upgrade
text:
Good:
* Large, clear, responsive touchscreen
* Different UI themes to align with BMW appearance
* iDrive controller integration
* Wireless CarPlay
* The factory radio is still there and displays properly (depending on your radio, you may need to make adjustments to the display resolution).
* Factory 360 and backup cameras work as expected.

Not so good:
* The instructions included with the package overlook a step or two, but they do refer you to the video tutorial.
* I have no idea where the mic is but it sometimes struggles to understand me when dictating a text.
** I fixed this by adjusting the Mic Gain in the “factory” menu.
* I fought with Bluetooth and CarPlay for an hour or two to get wireless CarPlay working after a firmware update.
** This turned out to be user error. I had my hotspot turned on for my kid’s iPad which prevented wireless CarPlay.
* As mentioned in another review, CarPlay is an app within the Zlink app. It works fine but it’s not always obvious how to get back to it.
* My iDrive controller stopped working with it. The controller works for the factory radio. Not sure why. I’ll investigate more.
** This resolved itself after leaving the car off overnight.

The install took about an hour, and other than struggling to fit everything inside the dash, it was fairly easy.

I’m yet to see if this is worth the cost compared to the internal module that works with the factory screen but time will tell.

** Update: after having this for a few days, I revise my statement. It is a legit upgrade. The larger screen is very nice and now that I’ve adjusted to it, I think it is worth the cost. Everything works smoothly and I’ve retained the factory HU features as well.

The only thing left is that I wish you could use the Media button to go to the CarPlay audio player. The Nav button takes you to the CarPlay Nav (if you’re in CarPlay) so I’d think similar could be done for media.

title: No complaints, they do what they say they do, work great with open keystone panels
text:
I built a new mini-rack for my home network recently. I had an iwillink cat6 keystone patch panel (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0BF8J3KYW/) that I replaced a couple of keystones with USB-A and USB-C, but I want to update it with a bit more color and some more USB.

For this future retrofit, I bought a Monoprice blank panel (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B09QFVVM5C/) and will use the leftover keystones from the previous project and some others I have on hand - Cat6 (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07XWB63VT from an old 3d-printing network project), USB-A 3.x (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B078935SFG), USB-C (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07Z947FRN), and LC fiber (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08JMFG2FQ).

But to label special ports (like external connection uplinks, PoE ports, etc), I wanted to get some colored couplers. Picked a pack of these green ones, and the same brand of yellow (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0BRSFQ7D7, which will have pretty much the same review since it's effectively the same product).

The couplers come in 5 zipper bags of 5 each, in a cardboard box. This is better than loose, as I don't usually use even 10 at a time, and I can put them in an organizer bin on my shelf and easily find the color and style I want.

They fit perfectly into the keystone panel, and the cables fit fine on front and back.

Pretty much, like a lot of passive networking, they just do what they're supposed to, and I can't say a whole lot more. For the cable lengths I'm using, cat6 will be fine for 10GBaseT (I believe up to 55m in optimal situations, and I'm not likely to even run 5.5 meters).

title: A Vibrant, High Quality Portable Display
text:
This is an incredibly well made portable monitor that not only looks great, but is extremely durable and easy to use while remaining in a small, thin compact design. The display itself comes with a USB-C charging cable, wall adapter, HDMI to mini HDMI cable, and other accessories to get you up and running in no time. The monitor also comes with a removable magnetic front cover/stand if you decide you don't want it on. The monitor only needs your input (can be the HDMI input or a Thunderbolt input on the secondary USB-C port) and a USB connection to use for power.

When powered on, the screen has an all in one control switch/toggle on the left side for your volume, brightness, saturation, and other picture/input controls. I did make a couple small adjustments before taking my photos of the display, such as disabling HDR on my PS5 (HDR works on this monitor, but I prefer having a brighter display over the dimmer but higher picture quality of HDR) and turning up the brightness. Other than those two settings, everything is at the default levels. For the test, I also set my PS5 to 1440p resolution (which the PS5 now finally supports for those that are unaware) and I had no issues with the display at all. All the games I tested looked incredible, and I also had zero input lag in any of the games and the controls were smooth and responsive. The viewing angles are also excellent. Whether viewing it from the sides, top or bottom, the picture remains as vibrant and detailed as when looking straight on. The screen also has a matte finish which helps to block out glares from windows and lights that may be around you. However, the speakers could be better. The speakers are about as good as most laptop speakers and are easily usable. Like, the sound quality of the speakers are actually really good, but my issue is that even on max volume they are a little bit too quiet for my tastes.

Overall, I think this is an excellent, high quality portable display for whatever your needs may be. Since it not only supports mini HDMI, but Thunderbolt as well, you can connect almost any device you may need/want to this and it will work without issues. It can also be mounted as a normal monitor, and since it only requires a USB connection for power, this monitor has endless versatility. I highly recommend it!

title: These are such brilliant PCs!
text:
I already have an older model Beelink GK55 but I needed more PCs for my home office Siemens PLC lab. I decided to go for the extra horsepower of this 12th Gen Intel CPU and with it on sale, I couldn't come close to building a custom machine for the same money. The CPU, alone, makes up 3/4 of the pice. Add to that the excellent 500GB Crucial M.2 NVME drive, 16GB Crucial RAM, and Thunderbolt support via the USB-C interface and you have a lot of machine for the money.

On two different model Beelinks I'm running identical software setups. Siemens WinCC Professional Runtime v15.1 UPD5 (works great in Windows 11 BTW), Cogent Datahub, WITS Level 0 Server, SQL 14, a proprietary fluid hydraulics modeling software, proprietary data logging software, Microsoft Teams, Microsoft Power Automate, and SimpleHelp (remote access). All of this is running at the same time, including the remote control software. On the older Beelink GK55 I see CPU utilization of up to 85-100%. It handles it fine without any problems but on this newer Beelink SEi12 PC, my CPU utilization is only 4-12%. AMAZING how much more power this newer Beelink has with the 12th Gen i5 CPU.
I am very pleased with the new design:
Metal PC Case - the older GK55 is good quality plastic
Good variety of interfaces for USB, LAN, and HDMI Out
Wifi radio is strong
Disk and RAM speed is excellent
CPU power is unreal for such a low watt machine
Fan noise level is great even under periods of heavy load. I can hear it spool up but no more than the 27" 5K iMac sitting 2 feet away from it.

If you need a great computer for not a lot of money and you're not planning on doing AAA-title gaming, this is an outstanding value proposition. If you're like me and need a lot of computers in a lab-type scenario, this is an incredibly good option. They take little AC power, little desk space, make little room noise, and cost little money.

title: Great Device - NEEDS A POWER SOURCE!
text:
If I have anything negative to say about this product is that it is very disappointing that it does not come with any type of power source! There's not a DC power cable, no USB power cable, or no battery! The manufacturer expects you to be equipped with an NP-F or E6 battery! (I am a Nikon user, these batteries do not exist in my world.) In lieu of not having one of these batteries, they do not even supply a power cable. So, in order to even begin using it I had to purchase a pair of NP-F batteries along with a compatible charger.

That being said, it does not take away from the quality of this product. If you're like me, you love your DSLR, but it is hard to be applicable in some situations because the viewfinder does not articulate, so sometimes it is hard to get the shots that you want because you cannot see what the image will end up looking like. This field monitor breaks that barrier.

The amount of image data this field monitor provides is amazing. You can apply live filters (through LUT), get histograms, view waveforms, color information, sound information, and a multitude of important recording and image data.

The screen is super bright. You can see this clearly in the daylight and the finish of the screen mitigates glare fairly well. The touch screen is sensitive in a good way, too. You do not need to pound on the screen to get it to pick up your touches.

The standard tripod mount makes it applicable to most camera rigs or tripods, so it is easy to mount and place it where your need it most.

Watch your battery power, though. At full brightness it can eat through the batteries rather quick. If you have the option for DC power, that will honestly carry you the furthest!

If you need something to help you view your shots while you're on the move or help you get the angles you wouldn't be able to achieve with the viewfinder your camera is equipped with, this field viewer is certainly a great way to go. I enjoy using it as a personal monitor for a self-facing DSLR setup so I do not need to monitor it on my computer screen. The quality is great and it helps get the best shot angle every time.

title: So far has worked in everything I have tried it in.
text:
I have used this in a mokerlink switch with 4 10g sfp+ ports.. worked great. Had to set the ports to 10gig in the web management. connected 3 of the mokerlinks together and also a netgear 8port switch with 2 10gig Ethernet ports.

I have used them in Zyxel 12-Port Multi-Gigabit Ethernet Web Managed Switches
I have two of the switches connected together at 10gig with sfp+, also a workstation with 10gig card connected into the second sfp+ port.

I used on of these in a netgear nighthawk x10 r9000 router in the 10gig sfp+ port and connected it to one of the above zyxel switches in one of its 2.5 gig Ethernet ports. It is what is connecting my router to the LAN side. The zyxel switch reports it connected at 2.5gig. I have not tested performance though.

I did not see the increase in performance from workstation to workstation I had hoped for but did see 2x to 2.5x speeds from the Cisco 1gig switches I had been using. went from 60-90 MB/s to 200 MB/s. I did not change out to better cables so maybe seeing some performance issues there.

I have a Asustor NAS using a USB 3.1 2.5gig Ethernet adapter connected one of the USB 3.0 ports on it to one of the 2.5 gig ports on one of the the zyxel switches and though it runs a little faster than on the 1gig network its not much more. I am getting maybe 80 to 90 MB/s instead of 50 to 60 MB/s on average. I had been using a LAG with 4 1gig Ethernet ports on NAS to Cisco switch and this seems a bit faster overall. Was never impressed with the LAG.

I was surprised this was able to connect at 2.5gig. Its listed 1 or 10gig and I just tried it because. So was happy it worked.

So overall I would recommend this if you are using netgear routers with sfp+, mokerlink switches or zyxel switches with sfp+

title: A jack of all trades
text:
This Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone is a clever combination of a full 1080p webcam and a cardioid condenser microphone built into a single form. This Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone measures ‎8.35" x 5.83" x 5.79", weighs about 2 pounds, and comes with its own stand or can be mounted.

I used this ‎Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone for better than 4 months with a couple of different computers. I found this Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone ultra-convenient for setting up online meetings on the go. I even used it with a smart television for a Facebook video chat session and it was a great experience.

What I liked most about this Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone was:
- All-in-one design
- Effective as both a camera and a mic
- Color choices

What I liked least about this Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone was:
- Master of none. The flip side of being a jack of all trades is you get good quality on a good, better, best spectrum, and that holds true with this device.

Overall, if you need one device for plug-and-go online meetings then this Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone is better than most at being a one-cord solution at the sub-40-dollar price point. This Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone offers good audio and video but that is relative to other products in this price range. You can spend 20 bucks more for separate standalone cameras and mics but they're more expensive and require more fidgeting to set up. If you are a college student (or are shopping for one) who is taking online/hybrid classes and you have to show your face to get credit for attendance. This Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone is an ideal purchase for your use case.
