If you are a professional looking to impress clients with an online presentation this Movo WebMic HD Webcam and Condenser Microphone may not deliver the level of quality you need. 3.5 out of 5.0

title: Almost the exact laptop stand I was searching for
text:
A versatile adjustable laptop stand with a carrying sleeve, but with two design flaws. Yet, I still like it. I've been looking for a laptop stand for a while that would work something like this one. It is well-made of Aluminum and has a quality feel. I wanted a stand like this, one that is mostly an open design, light weight and adjustable. You can see from the picture I also wanted something that could be solidly placed on a turntable that is part of my custom-designed laptop stand. However, I did run into what I consider to be 2 design flaws depicted by the arrows in the picture. The arrows are also pointing to my temporary fixes. Flaw #1: the two adjustable legs move separately. Flaw #2: the adjustable legs have a small metal tab that fits into the adjustment holes in the bottom rails. This is where the problems arise. If you lift the upper rails where the lap top rests to adjust the height the legs immediately come out of the holes. Then, if you try to adjust the height while holding one of the upper rails you cannot set both legs at the same time. And if you try this with laptop on the stand it's even more difficult. Two design changes that would help would be to have a horizontal scissor brace to connect the two adjustable legs which would allow them to move together so that they could be placed at the same time, and to have a better foot mechanism for the adjustable legs to stay in place in the adjustment holes should you need to pick up the stand while maintaining the angle setting.

The challenge to updating the design is that the stand collapses and expands, allowing to set an adjustable width as well as height, but that flexibility eliminates using a fixed width horizontal brace for the legs. The arrows in my picture are pointing to my two temporary fixes. I put a small piece of Velcro on each adjustable leg and cut out a piece of hard cardboard with Velcro on the back. If I need to move or readjust the stand, I support the legs horizontally using the Velcro stick, and once set, the tape keeps the legs in place should the stand need to be moved.

So sorry for the lengthy and maybe boring review. In the meantime, I am giving the stand a 4-star review considering that most people will only be setting the stand once and it will remain in place without moving or adjusting.

title: Perfect for hours upon hours of meetings
text:
I have finally figured out what I do for a living. It's sitting on meetings.
You can have the greatest, high-end headsets possible but hours upon hours of calls and your ears will ache.

That left me with two choices.
1. Yell in the direction of my speakerphone and sound like a pack a day smoker at the end of the day.
2. Continue to have ear pain.

I had a pair of shokz. Pricey for what they are but serviceable. However, as they are bone conduction headphones, there was zero discomfort even after 9 hrs of meetings.

A boom mic was a must. Doesn't do me much good if no one can hear me. Browsing through amazon, there seemed to have quite a few bone conduction headphones, but there's bone conduction headphones and "bone conduction headphones".

A good # of the listings were just open ear headsets with a speaker port directed at your ears. Shrill and barely audible.
These however showed promise. About half the price as the open comms. Figured I'd roll the dice.

It was a good roll as these are excellent. The pads sit right in front of your ears, around the jawbone. Due to the ear loops, the fit is secure, and the pads do not squeeze your face uncomfortably.

Thus far the battery has lasted me all day. I do tend to top off the battery by sticking it on the charger in the precious few minutes that I may have between meetings. Headset hasn't died on me once.

They definitely are bone conduction headphones. You can test it out by playing music/audio then plugging your ears. If you still hear sound at roughly the same or louder volume you have bone conduction headphones.

Set your expectations if you intend to use them for music. Bone conduction headphones sound horrible. Doesn't matter the brand or model, they all sound bad. The model of shokz I have were praised for excellent sound quality. They sound like a dollarstore pair of earbuds.
Plugging your ears helps the sound quality in case you do decide to listen to music with these but don't expect miracles.

title: Good concept but execution does not work for me
text:
This product appealed to me mainly because of its solar charging feature and a discounted price at the time of my purchase. Other interesting features: FM radio (with a rectractable pull-up antenna) and a LED flashlight. Upon receipt of the product the first impression is that build and materials fall short of expectations, even compared to "value" brands. Ultimately, the combination does not meet my needs.

The battery life is rated from 3 to 6 hours (volume level not specified), per the product's packaging. That's not long enough for my outdoor activities (no way to charge) but might work if you are closer to a power source (other than the sun, of course!) to get a good charge. It's unknown how efficiently the two solar panels (one on the back of the speaker and another one on top) will keep the 1200mAh battery going while powering the speakers (per the product's packaging, output power is rated at 5W and the "working voltage" is DC 5V solar charging,) The top solar panel would be partially obstructed if one puts the phone on top of the built-in holder (at an angle, horizontally).

The sound is clear but on the tinny side, not much in the way of bass. It would work well for white noise, news reports, jazz, folk or more vocal-forward music. For most everything else, I was left wanting more sonically. Looking through the speaker grille, there appear to be two openings, purportedly for a (larger) driver and a (smaller) tweeter, respectively,

The quality of material is a weak point, but it is lightweight. I had intended to use this for outdoor recreational or light work duty, but I do not think it will stand well to my use. Fair enough, there is no IPX rating claimed, but I am not confident it will wear well with my intended use.

If the price is right, it can be a good option if a fuller-range sound quality or build quality are prime considerations. I can see this being of value in a garage or for light yard duty outdoors to take advantage of the solar charging features. For more rugged outdoor activities of longer duration (picnic, hiking, beach), consider alternatives to compare the build quality and expected battery life to meet your needs/expectations.

title: Easy install but plan on losing a fan if you have a current gen GPU
text:
Pros:
*Very easy to install in a O11 mini - literally takes 2 minutes
*Thumb screws only for install
*Leaves the bottom two PCIe slots open on a full size ATX mobo, which is nice
*Has slots in the bottom plate for more airflow to the GPU
*Overall is pretty secure and solid when installed properly, my GPU sits nice and level
*GPU fans sit at least 2 inches from the side glass (and thats with a 3 slot GPU), plenty of room for cooling. I have already confirmed no change in temps for my GPU.
*Bridge cable appears to be decent quality and is also flexible enough to move around a little.

Cons:
*If you have a current gen GPU (RTX 4000 series in particular) you are definitely going to lose the rear fan slot - look at my pic (thats an MSI gaming trio RTX 4070ti). The rear fan doesn't even come close to fitting with my GPU. I could install the fan on the outside of the case, that is actually an option and there is a slot to get the fan wires back through into the case, but I'm not sure yet if I want to do that or how it would look.
*One of the tabs on the left side of the mount (that interlocks with the case) is located where the mobo I/O shield is. This shouldn't be there because it actually interferes with installation. I had to flatten it out with pliers to get it to install correctly. I guess it would install right if you put this mount in BEFORE your motherboard install, but otherwise it doesn't.
*Its expensive for what it is. There are a lot of whole cases that don't cost this much. But if you have a O11 mini and you like the look, its worth having the one that is made specifically for this case.

NOTE: Depending on your GPU you may have to loosen the little screws holding the PCIe port down to the bottom plate, mine was too far back and the GPU wouldn't mount up properly. For a second I thought it wasn't going to fit, but luckily the port position can be slid forward/backward by a few millimeters as needed.

title: A little hard to understand and set up but it works
text: I bought this because I wanted to have a backup to my skeevy Spectrum internet, which is fast, but goes down far too often.  I have a Verizon home LTE device, and an EERO mesh network 6E that all my devices connect to.  I wanted it to cut over to the LTE when cable goes down, very quickly and seamlessly, and be able to do the full speed of hte cable internet (which is why I didn't by the Balance 20, which while supposedly easier, only gets 150 gbps).  So I bought this 20x balance device.  I'm no networking expert, but I know enough to be dangerous.  Took me about three or four hours to get it set up, now it's working.  Have tested by unplugging the cable modem and it cut over to the Verizon internet within a few seconds.  Excellent.  Why 3 or 4 hours?  Realizing that the Verizon device was the same IP address as the Peplink device, making everything kind of hitchy,  took about a half hour to figure out how to solve and do...solution was to change the IP address on the Peplink. Fairly easy to do but was difficult to find out how.  Updating firmware, and getting proper license (the VLAN requires an included one year subscription, which is a little tricky to figure out) and registration carried in took another half hour  or so.  Fairly easy to do but was difficult to find out how.  Spent the rest of the time getting the Vlan (where you can use a LAN plug on the device as a WAN plug in order to plug in the Verizon device).  Not super intuitive, and the instructions are a little difficult to follow, but I finally got there.  And it works like I said, well, and make sense now.  But this is clearly not a standard consumer device you'd give your mom or grandma or let your wife touch....you need to be persistent and/or know what you're doing (I'm very persistent with minimal knowledge of what I'm doing like I said).  But it definitely works.  I could have taken a star off because of the documentation but frankly it's a pretty sophisticated device and it does work, no bugs of any kind, and like I said this ain't your grandpa's router.  So five stars it is for now.

title: One of the best cases for the price. Comparable to the Logitech Combo Touch
text:
This case is really great, especially for the price. I own the Logitech Combo Touch, but wanted a second case for my bf’s iPad without having to spend the same dough. This case is about 80% as good and way better than most of the cheap keyboard cases on the market.

The touchpad is about 30% smaller than the one on the combo touch and not as responsive which is the biggest difference between the two. The other big difference between this one and the LCT is that the connection is Bluetooth vs. Physical between the keyboard and the case portion. There isn’t any notable lag when using it, but there is a lag sometimes when connecting. The keyboard also separates from the case a little easier so the case can come apart in your bag. The other noticeable difference is this one has multiple colors for the backlight whereas the combo touch is only a white light. I also like that this one has a pencil holder which won’t charge the pencil, but keeps it supremely safe inside your bag and won’t fall off like it often does with the LCT.

The similarities are a lot more between this one and the LCT. They both flip open to any angle and the kickstand can also be used to elevate the ipad when it is disconnected from the keyboard for a comfortable writing angle as long as you don’t put too much weight onto it. They are nearly the same size. The keyboards are nice, but this one has a little more travel to the keys which is neither positive nor negative to me, just different and maybe slightly louder than the LCT. The case part feels a little cheaper and is a naked plastic vs a rubber material. This one is slightly heavier and thicker because it carries a battery on board vs. being powered by the ipad, but it is hardly noticeable when the heavy ipad is loaded into it. I can’t comment on the actual battery life of this case yet because I tend to give it some juice at the same time I charge the ipad.

If money is no object I think the LCT is narrowly better just because of the quality of the materials, better trackpad and the physical connection, but this one is darn close and unless you just like having the best name brand things this will more than do the trick and protect your ipad.

title: Excellent value!
text:
A couple of months ago I bought a new(er) car - a Lincoln MKZ. I love the car. But I quickly realized that it has several blind spots such that I always felt uncomfortable changing lanes. The car has built-in blind spot and cross traffic monitors but I consider them to be more of a safety hazard than a safety feature because 90% of the (somewhat obnoious loud) warnings are false alarms.

I decided to try adding an always on back-up camera.

The first camera I bought was a 4.3 inch model. I quickly realized that the 4.3 inch monitor was too small to see clearly. So i returned it and ordered an Amtifo W70 7 inch model. the Amtifo W70 has a large crystal clear picture so it was just what I was looking for. I liked it so well that I also installed an Amtifo front camera. Now I can view the front, the rear, or a split screen. Excellent.

While it is very simple to install and use, the one drawback of the W70 is that the controls are on the back of the monitor. That isn't really a problem because I don't change views often and once you you know where the buttons are you can easily reach them from the front.

I like the W70 so well for the Lincoln that I decided to try the A19 model for my F150 pickup. The A19 is very similar to the W70 except that it is much more customizable and all of the controls are on the front. And it has a different monitor bracket which can be installed on flat surfaces such as the dash.

This is the best back-up camera kit I have seen! If have have any issue with this model it is only that I prefer the much smaller, simpler windshield monitor bracket of the W70 model. This bracket seems better suited to an RV, motor home, or bus. And you can't simply switch to the smaller bracket because of the way it attaches to the back of the monitor. But in any case, I would say both models are an excellent value. The important things are that the cameras are good, the night lights are good and the pictures on the monitors are crystal clear.

title: Almost
text: This is the closest thing that I could find to fit my needs.  I cannot find anything to make a retractable extender using my own cords however these work great….sorta.  First… I have no idea why these are advertised as great for travel……THESE ARE NOT made for travel.  These should only be used for permanent application.  You peel the adhesive off like they show and stick the winder where you want it.  For me I have a movable nightstand. On that night stand I have several items that require cords.  2 of which are an echo 15 and my 10 foot iPhone charger cord.  I absolutely love the ability to wind and unwind, very easy as much cord as I need so I can move my nightstand wherever I want and not have the cords everywhere.  I also love the fact that wherever the cord ends there are plenty of places for the charging part to be held.  I love that the cord is hidden Under what looks like a flower basically… and actually that knob in the middle came and useful.  My echo 15… Where I needed my nightstand moved. It happened to end right at a spot where I had the extender connected, but I was able to wrap it around the knob and it held in place just fine.  In my picture you will see that honestly there is too much cord wrapped around that winder.  Some things that you want to consider before purchasing:  the thickness of the cord you will be needing to wind up and the amount of cord. Example:  it could not wrap up 7 feet of my iPhone charger. Technically it could but it was really too much cord (quite obvious as it did not want to stay wrapped, and I had to try to really tighten it ) and I think that’s what made it end up popping off entirely.  The good news is I found out that the adhesive does not leave any marks. It did not even leave the area with any residual sticky mess. I’m really disappointed that they do not make a bigger size because honestly these do not hold that much cord. I cannot give a review how well they do sidemounted as all of mine have been mounted on top of my nightstand. I am going to try to use some command Velcro.  I do not think that the adhesive is going to hold up in general.  Also… Shipping took forever.

title: Every bit as good as a genuine Dell battery.
text:
After a month or so of basic use, I’m noticing between 5-7 hours of battery life. And for the price, it’s a great replacement option instead of the OEM Dell battery that will cost in some cases three times as much. Naturally, battery life will vary depending on your Windows settings but for most users, you’ll be utilizing the so-called “balanced” setting in Windows battery settings. Anything else will just kill it off as any other brand used.

The battery comes with a standard one-year warranty and you are provided with the tools to install the battery. The particular laptop this battery is for is really easy to install. Three screws and a battery cable and you’re done. Be advised the battery does “NOT” ship with a battery cable you will have to re-use the original one.

As a Dell-certified technician myself I have experience with this particular model of laptop (a Latitude 7480 in this case and many 7490s) I have seen many many of these batteries inflate due to sitting on charging docks on a daily basis and not being discharged on a regular basis. I don’t think it's a Dell thing, just this design of the battery itself. I’ve seen Dell OEM batteries replaced a year later start inflating due to being on a dock charging all the time so be sure not to do this. Discharge it from time to time and use the laptop on the battery, I’m telling you right now again…..discharge from time to time, I cannot stress it enough.

Luckily for me, the battery I was replacing had not inflated it just lost most of its charge capacity from being an original for 5-6 years. The bottom line is this battery performs every bit as well as an OEM manufacturer brand and I advise you to look at it as a worthy contender replacement. My experience with it has been great. And to prolong life I advise not using a USB-C charger (since the 7480 laptops have a USB-C port) of more than 65 watts.

In my pictures, you will see the original battery in the laptop, the new one in the box, and the new one freshly installed. This will likely be my go-to source for replacements in the future should I need one

title: Used 248 calendar days
text:
Hello, here's my review after 248 calendar days.

I bought two of these keyboards, both were Perixx PERIBOARD-329. After 8 months 3 days I think I have enough information to accurately give an honest review.
Lets start with the lighted background. All colors still working. FYI --my system is in my home office and stays turned on 24/7 with (no sleep mode) or unless there's a power outage. (There has been no power outages to report).

Reminder:
Dim effect still works accurately. Dim/Bright is done by holding down FN and Page Pg down for dim and Pg up for brighter.

Keystrokes:
Sounds good, they are not silent but not loud. just perfect for me and comfortable. They have white scissor action. (Love it) not annoying at all. Best key sound on the market in my opinion.

Overall daily use:
I use my computer in my home office and I'm online about 16hrs a day. The letters are starting to fade out on the keys. I tried to fix one but as soon as I popped the key off, it would not go back into place, no matter what I tried. A total waste of time after 10 mins trying to reset the key.
I love this keyboard, it's perfect but the fading of letters bothers me and being in a professional position and have people come and go. Fading letters on a keyboard does not impress people. I tried with a sharpie-Marker extra fine point, but it didn't last long maybe a couple months at best.

Final Notes:
It maybe I have an acidic skin oil in my system because I will admit the same issue occurred on a Logitech board also which cost me $139. They would not replace the keys. NOTE: I never asked this vendor to fix my Perixx PERIBOARD-329. I just simply toss the keybaord in the trash this morning and dug this new one out of the parts closet.
This is my review after using the Perixx PERIBOARD-329 after using it for 8 months 3 days.

title: This keyboard showed great potential, but has an irritating flaw.
text:
I got the Virfour Bluetooth Keyboard to update and replace the wired keyboard I currently use with my Mac Mini.

The aluminum Virfour appears to be well built and durable. I like its style and satin aluminum finish that matches well with my computer and monitor. The keyboard easily paired with my computer in just seconds in three ways: Via a 2.4G dongle and by either of two Bluetooth channels available on the keyboard. I’m not sure why two Bluetooth channels are included. Either one worked seamlessly with my computer and both seem to do the exact same job in the exact same way.

The keyboard is comfortable to use, but I wish it had a way to tilt the keyboard up in the back just a bit. One feature that may appeal to some is the ability to illuminate the keys in seven different colors, each at three levels of brightness. I thought it was an interesting feature, but didn’t anticipate using it much. However, when I showed this feature to my roommate, she went nuts over it, stating it helped her see the keys “so much better.”

To conserve the rechargeable battery, the keyboard turns off when not in use after just a few seconds, but instantly returns to life at the first press of a key. In fact, I charged it to 100% four days ago and, using it moderately, it is still showing to be at 100% capacity. Although the keyboard is rechargeable via a type C USB port, unfortunately when the non-replaceable battery wears out, as all rechargeable batteries do, the keyboard will become useless.

Unfortunately, for some unfathomable reason, the keyboard will spontaneously start typing in all uppercase letters. Furthermore, when that happens, it refuses to allow the cursor to be moved or select text for cutting and pasting. The issue is resolved by turning the keyboard off and then on again, but it happens too frequently to warrant its continued use. Given the sleek style, extended battery life and wireless technology, I really wish this keyboard worked well. By that I mean flawlessly and, unfortunately, it does not. Full disclosure: I did not evaluate this keyboard on a Windows based computer and the above stated problem may, or may not, occur with that operating system.

title: Works as a privacy screen; no noticeable effect on glare; weak adhesives; poor value
text:
Item: Computer Privacy Screen Filter 24 inch,Removable 16:9 Widescreen

Price (at time of review *): $40.99
(* Note that I receive some items at discounted or zero cost through Amazon Vine participation. The price indicated is the purchase price, with or without discounts, as advertised on the product page at the time this review is posted)

Pros: When affixed, the screen is only viewable to those sitting immediately in front of the monitor, so the privacy screen feature is effective enough if you are only trying to shield what you are viewing from those trying to view your screen from the side

Cons: I ordered this item specifically for the advertised anti-glare/blue light protection and I am not seeing any noticeable effect after several days of use. While I have not done any technical tests to determine the extent to which the screen filters out blue light/glare, I have not noticed any change in the soreness of my eyes or mild headaches resulting from extended screen time and the glare does not appear to have decreased considerably. While advertised as being protective in the listing, the packaging indicated this was a privacy filter only and there was no reference to eye protection. The adhesives are very poor. They are difficult to remove from the backing, particularly after you take the double sided tape off the sheet it is attached to, at which point the other side of the adhesive requires a great deal of effort to try and remove, which can wrinkle the adhesive itself and make it less effective. Once it is affixed, it does not stay attached easily and I needed to use small pieces of electrical tape to secure. Given the only noticeable effect of this screen is to prevent people from off to the side from viewing my work, which was not an issue to begin with, it was a very disappointing order given difficulties affixing properly and limited eye protection.

Ratings (1-10 scale; 0 = Very poor, 5 = Average, 10 = Exceptional)
Quality: 3
Value (based on purchase price of $40.99): 1.5
Utility: 3
Overall: 2.5

Hopefully you found this review helpful in identifying the best product to meet your needs.

title: The best I’ve found for sleeping
text:
Music helps me sleep but my wife likes it quiet. This is the perfect solution. I originally purchased the adjustable but it didn’t adjust as much as I expected and it dug into the back of my neck, so for me the standard is much better.

Here are my pros and cons:

Pros:

-Battery life
This will get you through every hour of the night and you won’t have to worry about it dying or a voice saying “battery low” as I’ve had with other headphones.

-Comfort
It seems tight at first but once it’s adjusted you can barely feel it and can sleep any way you like and will not get in the way or cause discomfort.

-Durability
The band can stretch a great distance and will not break. This is great for conforming to all head types.

Cons:

-Battery hardness
The control battery on the front is tight against the skin and was leaving a red mark on my forehead in the morning, but I’ve since put a couple folded up tissues in between and it feels much better. I believe some fur on the back or some kind of cushion would be a great solution for this issue.

-Width/Height
The width is great for the ears, but I feel it’s too high on the forehead. I believe it would benefit by being slimmer in the front so that it does not cover so much of the head. I ended up folding the bottom a bit so that it fits normally across my forehead.

-Ambient noise
The sound is a little low and does not drown out much noise around you. If your partner snores, you may hear it. Sometimes I put on noise canceling headphones over top of these when first falling asleep and that helps block out any noise. If the max volume was louder or if the ear buds could somehow grip over the ear, it could be an improvement.

Overall it is a great product and has beaten every other pair of headphones I’ve used for sleeping. It is the best but would be even better with the adjustments mentioned above.

title: Pretty nice, a couple minor things..
text:
[[VIDEOID:466bf8494d8c0aa7e4d51dd2ba2419d4]] I got this for my son to use in his room, he needed a new portable speaker as well as a wireless charger and this does both, so it seemed like a good fit. So let’s break down the functions-
1) portable speaker- easy to connect, sound is deep and rich. Not quite “Bose” level quality but pretty close.
2) wireless charger- it does wirelessly charge, but it has to be plugged in for that function to work. Which is a negative thing. I wish it worked whether plugged in or not. It defeats the purpose of being portable if only some of the functions work when it is unplugged.
3) touch lamp- the handle is also a touch lamp, it has different levels of brightness to suit your needs. Works great.
4) phone holder- the handle can be posed at any position to prop your phone up for you. I don’t think we will use this function a lot but it does work. If your phone/case is very heavy it might not work unless the handle is all the way up, as the tension on the handle is not super high-it lifts up and down pretty easily.

Overall this is a nice item. It looks sleek and modern, and my son likes it. He will use it daily to charge his phone as his charging port doesn’t work that well, and he will use it to play music a lot while he plays video games. He will also probably use the lamp part as well. Is it worth the price tag? I don’t know. It seems a bit steep for what it is, but if it’s something you will use for its multiple functions then it will be worth it. It also makes an odd, loud sound/tube when being powered on and off. And you can’t turn it up or down. No matter what you have the volume on, the on and off tunes are super loud. Which kind of takes away from the sleek/modern aspect of it. That, and the fact that it doesn’t charge your phone unless it’s plugged in, is the reason for deducting a star. I would still recommend this item however.

title: Excellent Subwoofer Amplifier! 5 Stars!
text:
I purchased this Soundavo PSB-1000DSP Class D subwoofer amplifier to power 2 old NHT SW3S subwoofers. The NHT SW3S subs were
6 OHM subs and originally powered by NHT
SA-3 250W Class G monaural amplifiers. One of the SA-3 amps died and no longer powers on. It was not a blown fuse situation. Rather than attempt to find a repair company to fix the 20 plus year old amp, I decided to purchase a new subwoofer amp which would also work with a 12V trigger. No 12V trigger on the old NHT SA-3 subwoofer amps. I was interested in the Soundavo PSB1000DSP because of the power-
1000W at 8 OHM, Class D and that it could power 2 subwoofers. I read the literature on the PSB1000DSP and was only concerned that the manufacturer cautioned that if you were hooping up 2 subwoofers that the nominal impedance of the 2 subs should not be less than 8 OHMS. My old NHT subs were 6 OHM and rated at 250W. I decided to take the plunge and purchase. I am glad that I made the purchase. The Soundavo PSB1000DSP has no trouble driving my 2 old NHT SW3S subwoofers. The new amp does not even get hot. There has been absolutely no overheating of the new amp driving my NHT SW3S subwoofers even after watching the movie, Top Gun Maverick. I run the 2 NHT SW3S subwoofers at 3/4 volume with the Soundavo PSB1000DSP. This new subwoofer amplifier is modern and powerful. All crossover, bass adjustments, etc. are made using the small remote. No more analog controls to adjust on the back of the old subwoofer amp. This is a modern digital subwoofer amplifier. Build quality is great. I now can utilize a 12V trigger. One PSB1000DSP now powers my 2 passive NHT SW3S subwoofers. Finally, the price. I bought it on Amazon from Soundavo with a $150 discount. I paid $600 for this new subwoofer amplifier. What a bargain for this great amp! Highly recommended!

title: Excellent Compact USB-C KVM Switch
text:
This is a really nice compact USB-C Video IN to HDMI OUT KVM Switch, I've tested it with a Samsung S20 Ultra in DEX mode and my MSI Laptop, both using USB-C out into the KVM switch with a Amazon Basics HDMI cable to a Samsung 55 inch TV with a Logitech wireless keyboard/trackpad connected to the SIIG KVM and it works perfectly. You can use the KVM with any device that supports video output through USB-C e.g. (DisplayPort or DP Alt Mode) or (Thunderbolt 3 or 4) to the KVM switch.

I LOVE the fact that I can use ONE wireless keyboard/trackpad combo to control both devices (or you can have one mouse and one keyboard connected to both USB ports on the KVM switch.)

Test done with:
Samsung UN550JU6500 (Below is the 50", I'm using the 55 which Amazon no longer lists)
https://www.amazon.com/Samsung-UN50JU6500-50-Inch-Ultra-Smart/dp/B00TWFHJWG

Samsung S20 Ultra (terrible camera):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B082XY39M7

Amazon Basics HDMI Cable:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08BS15FB9

Logitech Keyboard:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B014EUQOGK

MSI Laptop:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B09BP4YXFL

Other SIIG products I use that work well are the following:

SIIG 4 Port Ethernet
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MT8J8VN/

SIIG
https://www.amazon.com/SIIG-Cool-Docking-Station-SC-SA0412-S1/dp/B001QTW9G2

I highly recommend this portable/compact switch!

title: Work Headset is difficult/hard to switch from computer to phone.
text:
The shape and headset ear cushions are good, they are a little tight for my big round head. So after using it for a few days, by lunch time my ears hurt. The battery is good and seems to last a while. It would manage 12 ton14 hour talk time.
I often walk away from my computer/office and take phone calls on my phone using the headset and then walk back to my office for another Teams meeting. The two detractors that are going to make me return this item are:
1. I have found, when I walk away from the computer and I am streaming a podcast from my cell phone, the headsets start to beep every 10 seconds. It stops when I am back near the computer and the USB dongle has a clear connection again. This means, anytime I walk away from my laptop to make a sandwich or walk outside, wanting to take the headset, it beeps. That's not what I am looking for. I wanted a seamless switch from computer dongle or to my paired connected phone with no need to stay near the USB dongle to the headset.
2. The headset does switch between the computer and then to my phone somewhat seamlessley sometime, when the comouter is nearby. Even after listening to podcasts during lunch, and my computer is nearby but is off, the headset doesn't easily keep olaying the podcast/stay connected to my phone via Bluetooth, despite the headset being paired and connected to the phone. It wasn't playing the podcast anymore. The functionality is there, but the programming/software is not as seamless as I am used to from say a bluetooth ear buds or a Jabra evolve headset. To get the sound coming from the phone to start playing through the headset, I have to then power cycle the headset for it to reconnect again to my cell phone playing the podcast. These are unnecessary steps and I'm looking for better bluetooth 2 source switching by a headset between android and laptop.
I will be returning this headset once another candidate is found. I spent 3 years using the Jabra Evolve 75 for nearly 8hrs a day, everyday, and the mic recently failed. This is me starting to find an off brand replacement that doesn't have a 275 price tag. I need seamless muting within Teams and works flawlessly with Teams meetings. I also need better dual Bluetooth connections between my laptop and my phone.

title: Not senior friendly
text:
Here is the review I left for the LG TV that came with the Magic Remote. I have described the issue I have with that remote:

We purchased this LG 65" Class - OLED C2 Series - 4K UHD OLED TV in February so this is an initial review. Hopefully we will not have issues with the tv in the future. So far so good. The tv is great, with one caveat which I will describe below in detail. We replaced a 55" Panasonic Plasma tv that was virtually indestructible. But we wanted a bigger screen and a tv capable of displaying 4k content The bottom line is the LG picture is far superior to the Panasonic Plasma even with DirecTv regular broadcasts. The truth is there isn't a lot of available 4k content unless you want to pay more for each individual program or movie. The same is true for Netflix and Amazon Prime and none of that has anything to do with the LG tv. We would purchase it again in a heartbeat. The caveat is the horrible LG "Magic Remote" that came with it. The "magic" part is the pointer icon it puts on the screen to select programs and other functions. The pointer is so sensitive it’s almost impossible to use. You can go into the menus and change the sensitivity to "Slow" but that doesn't help much. We had so much trouble with the pointer we had to call LG technical support and have them remotely change the setting. Even after slowing the sensitivity, when we moved the pointer icon over whatever we wanted to watch, simply pressing the select button was enough pressure on the remote to cause the pointer to move off the selected item. Did anyone at LG over the age of 50 even attempt to use this remote? Is this a reason to give the LG tv a bad review? No and here's why: The wonderful LG tech in India had already heard plenty of these complaints. She recommended going online and purchasing an LG AKB75095307 remote. Bingo! $9.00 online from Walmart. Received it in the mail in 2 days, added 2 AAA batteries and problem solved! No evil magic pointer, just a tv and remote that work perfectly. You can be confident in buying this tv. Just order an LG AKB75095307 remote ahead of time. Then you'll have a remote for the adults in the house and the kids can use the "Magic" remote.

title: Good little amp for what it is.  Know what you are buying, and if it fits your needs.
text:
This little amp works great for what it is. Knowing what it is is the key to beign hapy with it.

Like most lower-end audio equipment, the listed power rattings are "Max" vs. RMS. This is the maximum output the amp can generate, not the measure of useable power delivered to the speakers. If I had to guess, I'm working with maybe 10-15 good watts here, which is plenty for the small bookshelf speakers I'm driving. The passive sub output is good as well; I didn't figure it would generate enough umph to drive an 8" passive sub, but it's doing just fine.

The sound quality is good; its not great. Not a lot of depth, but some of that is due to using small speakers. The low end of the frequency range is minimal. You will need a small sub to complement the smaller speakers that can be driven by this amp. Highs are represented well, mids are a little muddy. Adding a sub is a must as you won't be able to drive even larger bookshelf speakers. The passive sub support is surprisingly solid. There is no noticeable standing hum or static even at maximum volume which surprised me.

I plan to use this setup in my garage to extend the audio range of a TV and for streaming music from my phone; it's perfect for this application. If your intent is to drive large, power hungry, speakers in a sound centric installation then you'll be disapointed. If you are looking for audiophile quality sound form this amp, you'll be disappointed again. I'm using an old set of cheap Kenwood surround speakers with 4" drivers and a passive 8" sub. It drives them all and sounds surprisingly good.

The bluetooth support is solid and connects flawlesly and fast. The control pots seem to be nice quality although no detents are present. The speaker connections are of fair quality. They include both banana plug support and screw down nuts. The Aux inputs and Sub pre out (for a powered sub) are standard RCA.
All said, nice little rig for what it is. I've only been using it for a day but, unless it smokes, it's a decent value.

title: Works As Described
text:
We installed one of these cameras around mid Nov. 2022, the second around mid Dec. 2022. Outdoors, under the roof overhang but not completely protected from the elements. So, to answer a few concerns I read about battery life and weather.....let me attempt to give a thorough description for comparison.
We moved full time from So. Fla. to what used to be our vaca. home in western NC. Located about 2000 above sea level, in a mountain rain forest, and cold. Days of 0-2 degrees cold with plenty of rain. That is not smoke in the Smoky Mountains, but moisture. This is a fairly wet climate.
We only leave the cameras on 24/7 when out of town, or at night after dark. The traffic on our dead end road averages about 3-4 vehicles a day, and 0-1 after dark. Not much motion on our street other than postal, and a couple of us coming and going. We did leave for a week over Thanksgiving, but other than that our usage is as described.
Since installation, with indirect rain and very cold weather, here is the update. Both cameras have worked fine without a glitch. The first camera installed in Nov., and left running over Thanksgiving week, still shows 60% battery life. The second camera 80%.
The two wired cameras I have in the screened in porch areas also have worked perfectly........they are indoors but the rooms receive no heat.
Honestly, even though we have nowhere near the crime up here that we experienced in So. Fla., I would buy a couple more cameras for the garage and back yard. Unfortunately, even though we have gig speed internet, our provider does not offer a router with the same oomph as the top model Xfinity provides. And I do not like messing around with repeaters. But for what we have, and what we need, these four cameras work just fine. They are paired with two Alexas, a 5 inch and an 8 inch, which also become remote cameras when you leave the house.
I would suggest purchasing the Ring Protect plan as well. We only bought the mid tier plan since I do not want to set up the complete monitoring system. The mid tier account holds video, gives you 10% off on new equipment, and, unless I am mistaken, extends the warranty for as long as you subscribe. Hope this helps.

title: Good low-profile mount
text:
This mount is nice and thin, making TV very close to wall. The mount itself is fairly sturdy. The lack of
a center support between the upper and lower portion of the mount, as is present on competitors products, leaves room for a recessed outlet box if you need to place one in the middle of the mount. I did not notice any sagging after mounting TV and Sanus’s weight ratings are generally conservative. The Sanus website has helpful guidance on where to mount things based on make and model or size TV which was nice and I did not need to break out my calculator. The instructions are good and all hardware was included and is of good quality. I placed some Velcro wrap material behind the mount to make dressing cables easier before tightening mount fully to wall. My TV is not flat on the back so I had to make sure the mount protruded slightly above the thickest point and on my LG 55” I had to use the 2.5mm spacers. A speed square, not included, made it easy to get the rails on the TV squared up. You will need a drill, No. 2 Phillips screw driver, a 7/64th drill bit, small level, pencil, stud finder (or strong magnet) and a tape measure if you want to do this yourself. There is a nice printed template in the box to help with hole placement. I chose this mount because it works on wall stud distances greater than 16” on center and gives a bit more room to move TV left or right to center on wall if your studs are not exactly centered. You need to mount this in to studs or masonry wall (masonry wall anchors included and requires a hammer drill and larger drill bit to use). The TV was easy to mount by resting the top hook on the rails to the mount and then gently pressing button of TV to snap in to the bottom of mount. The rails have screw adjustment to fine tune the level of your TV some if you did not get the rails mounted perfectly square. You will likely need a friend to help lifting the TV on to the mount and to help hold TV away from wall to connect cables as it is very low profile there is not room to reach behind TV after fully mounted. I would also recommend picking up right angle HDMI cables and digital audio cables if you want to connect to set top box, game console, and stereo.

title: thicc boi antennas, works with Linux out of the box
text:
This OKN WiFi 6E AX5400 PCIe WiFi Card AX210 was just delivered today. I put it in my SFF Optiplex running Kubuntu 22.10. The wi-fi connected quickly and has stronger signal strength than the previous (MIS brand) adapter I was using.

Likes:
⊛ thicc boi antennas - I've had expensive routers with smaller antennas than these chungus doohickies.
⊛ minipcie card is easy to remove in case future upgrades are needed.
⊛ low profile bracket included - Factory screws are on really tight. Don't use the included screwdriver to remove the full height bracket, you'll just strip the screw head.
⊛ screwdriver and case screw included - don't need it, but it's a thoughtful gesture that I appreciate.
⊛ driver CD included - Who even does that anymore? Nice people, that's who. Again, didn't need but still appreciate.
⊛ stronger signal strength than any other wi-fi adapter I've had in this location. (Probably due to dem thicc bois!)
⊛ lastly, but most importantly: works with Linux (Kubuntu 22.10) immediately. I wasted HOURS trying to get realtek and broadcom wifi chips to work on newer kernel, without success. As expected, the Intel chip on this wifi adapter worked immediately.

Dislikes:
Being super, extra, unnecessarily nitpicky; I don't like the thin metal antenna connector retention bracket for where the antenna leads connect to the wifi card itself. It's probably fine but would rather have seen plastic or non-conductive coating on a better quality metal piece. It's really no big deal, but I couldn't think of anything else to put under 'dislike'.

Verdict: Based on the first hour of use after installing, I'd recommend this to anyone with a low profile computer and/or anyone wanting a solid Linux compatible wifi adapter. Wifi signal strength is better than expected and speed is what it should be. I can't speak to the Bluetooth yet, as I'm waiting on a header female to USB-A adapter cable to arrive. (no open USB headers on optiplex mobo).

title: Good speakers
text: Sometimes I don't pay enough attention when I order things. I guess 2 pair didn't register with me when I read the listing. I think all I saw was "Bluetooth speakers." These were really much larger than I anticipated and there were 4 of them instead of 2. I don't know if all 4 of them work, because I have only connected 2 of them as I just wanted them for an average size room and don't need nor have room for all four. I don't have an outside area in which to set these up. With that being said, the two that I have connected work great. I also had no idea what that little doohicky box was that came with them. After reading instructions I found out it was an amplifier/receiver/power supply that the speakers plugged into (again, I have GOT to start paying more attention to things I order online). I thought Bluetooth meant they did not have to be wired to anything. Nevertheless, the instructions told me exactly what to do and set up was easy (and that's coming from someone who didn't know what was going on). One end of wires hooked to speaker the other to the receiver. Just make sure to match colors. Plug the power supply to the receiver, press the MODE button until the BT light is flashing, go to your Bluetooth settings on the device you want to play find the speakers in your list of devices and connect. The name on my device did NOT come up as "HERDIO" as the instructions stated. I don't remember now what it did say (seems like it was some letters and numbers) because I changed it to Herdio once I found it. You can also play music on a thumb drive or any device with an aux line. Can also plug a mic into it. I think my only complaint is the annoying voice that loudly blurts out "Bluetooth (or whichever) mode," "connected" and "power off." I don't need to be told these things. If I can figure out how to set it up, I can certainly determine when it's on or off, what mode it's in (just look at the receiver), and when it's connected. If there is any way to mute this voice or just turn it down, I have not been able to find it. But I do like the speakers and have decided that just maybe I will find a place for the other two after all.

title: Not a bad camera but not full proof
text:
I have several dash cams at this point in life. Because trust is getting a little more difficult these days especially with the cars I have.

This dash cam basically does everything I need it do to. I've used this on several trips now and fortunately have never really needed it other than one road rage incident.

The picture quality is pretty good! Not great but good. Has some settings to adjust the angle and exposure. You're not going to catch a plate number if the conditions are bad (low light to headlight white out on plates ect) so I wouldn't recommend this if you're looking for a serious rig.

The mics are astounding. You can really hear almost everything with these!

The front and rear cameras were easy to setup. I tucked the cables into my headliner. I did not choose to hardwire it although I may in the future.

Then UI on the app is.... terrible. The wifi doesn't reach very far.. its slow... so don't plan on checking your car while in a store or restaurant like I can with an LTE cam. The motion detection works great! When it wants to. I tested it on my neighborhood one day and left it on the most sensitive setting. The rear camera caught my trees swaying in the wind a lot, "major motion" events but failed to capture a few joggers. This is disconcerting. I'm worried about the people not the trees. I kept having an issue with the app timing out before I could download a "trip" video that the give was 1.1GB. I could only get to about 700 MB before it would freeze up and stop. I restarted several times and still had the same issue. Ive found its best to just SCREEN RECORD your events while streaming the video through the app. Its impossible to download a file over a certain size it will just time out forever.

Other than that it does as it should. Good features for a fair price.

Please keep in mind ANYTHING is better than nothing. If you have the cheapest cam possible in your window it's still a deterrent! I have dash cams in all my vehicles and I've had people comment on that over time. Even recently someone thought this VIO was a radar detector.

title: Updated:
text:
Update:
I will leave my review below, but I did update it to 5 stars. Anker is an amazing company that really supports its products and strives to make its customers happy. They went above and beyond to ensure I was happy with their product. I did not think companies like this really existed; they even went out of their way to contact me about my review.

If you're looking for at purchasing a speaker like this, I would recommend their sound core 3 - it sounds better. The only issue is that they removed the 3.5mm audio jack. So my intended purchase of using it with my steam deck doesn't work well due to audio delay. The speaker itself sounds great, and I will use it for music.

________________________________
I usually love Anker products, but this speaker is not for me. I bought it to use with my steam deck / pc for general sound use (I use headphones for gaming).
- The device sounded static/cracky. Almost like it was just too loud, or the speakers were blown. I tried it with my phone, and the sound quality was the same.
- I had issues with the volume. The speaker has its own volume, but you can also increase the volume on the device paired or connected to it. I was hoping to set the speaker to 100% and then use the paired device to fine-tune the controls, but this only worked sometimes. Most of the time, the speaker sounded blown unless I lowered one the two volumes. This could have been user error idk.
- Finally, audio delay. I had a delay with audio on both Bluetooth and, oddly enough, 3.5mm jack which is strange. I tried to update the firmware (which I read was a solution), but I could not get their android app to find the device. I followed all the instructions, the device was paired to my phone, yet still, their app would not find the device.
-- I even busted out my old windows laptop to download their windows app to update. That wouldn't find the device, either.

Eventually I gave up. I am going to return the device and purchase another set of speakers.

Anker is a great company who typically have wonderful products. I will continue to buy their products in the future.

title: They're ok with a ton of minor inconveniences
text:
They're ok.

Reviews of headphones usually revolve around sound quality. These sound great, and my biggest worry, fit and comfort, with no ear/wingtips was actually it's best feature. After a few minutes, these were nice and secure inside my ear.

The issues comes with everything else. First, the case is a bit bulky and cumbersome. The texture is nice and the light indication is ok when it works, but the size makes it less practical to carry compared to something like the Earfun Pro 2.

Second, the controls are there, but they are not included in the manual and it's not guaranteed they'll work out of the box. When I first used my headphones, only the volume control worked. I had to charge the headphones in their case and resync them before the controls worked. They also included little indication beeps for hold controls, which include:

1 second hold and 1 beep and release: assistant activation
2 beeps and release: ambient mode/transparency mode
3 beeps and release: turn off manually
4 beeps and release: I still have no idea

I like that all the controls are there, but the I didn't think I'd prefer touch controls when having to do all the different commands (I just wish touch controls had a disable feature when putting in and taking out the earphones so you didn't get accidental touches.

Third, the app. This is something that I've learned using Soundpeats, Fiil, Soundcore, Earfun, and now Lypertek. A good universal app is nice. There is an app, specifically for this earphone. Don't make the mistake I did and get the Z5 app. I didn't get the connection issues other people got, but the app is light and it didn't really add much outside of light equalizer controls and a manual ambient button

Fourth, weird things like charging indications and the headphones not turning off when I put them in the case just kept popping up. There are also complaints about the glue on them falling off after a few months, which has me worried. I was excited by these but the software inconveniences are the most between the other TWS headphones I've used under $100

title: Samsung TV is garbage. Samsung product support is worse.
text:
First, to be clear: the soundbar is still working, so no complaints there.

The television, however, is garbage. We started getting full-width lines of stuck pixels about a year and a half in. Then the entire panel died at two years.

This is a $700 TV, I expect way better longevity than that.

Worse than that: Samsung seems to go out of their way to obfuscate their warranty. Some sources say two years, some say one. Either is too cheap a warranty for a $700 piece of equipment.

And then we get to Samsung customer support. They led us on a merry wild goose chase for more than two weeks. First we had to get a diagnostic from their singular authorized repair shop in a 100 mile radius, which we paid $60 out of pocket for. Turns out the part costs more than the whole TV. Then they agreed to a one-time repair and said the shop would contact us when the part came in. Almost a week later with no contact, we called the shop only to be told the part wasn't available. Why did no one call us to tell us that?

Then we had to deal with a dozen calls to a dozen different reps AND supervisors who: hung up on us, transferred us to a dead line, lied to us (told us IN WRITING that we already had a support ticket for an exchange, then the supervisor responsible for said exchange denied that the ticket existed), continuously passed the buck. We were told to call another department so many times I lost count.

Naturally, not only did Samsung not make any of this right, but they KEPT TRYING to waste our time. They never even just said "No we won't help you" but kept insisting that we call back to get another department (that just so happened to be closed at that moment, but we can call back tomorrow!)

I.... don't even understand the point of all that. Wasting our time is wasting their own time. Lying to us doesn't even serve them. But Samsung is so dysfunctional that they would have KEPT GOING until the end of time, apparently.

We will never buy Samsung again. Their products are junk and their customer service is worse.

title: Lightweight and lots of pockets for organization
text:
I've been in need of a new backpack to take to work commuting on bus and train. I wasn't sure what to expect in person, but I really like this backpack! First of all, the fabric seems to be nylon, but it's a bit stiff so it feels more sturdy and not flimsy. There is a bit of sheen to it, but it's not a tacky or cheap shiny look. I think it will do great in the rain, and when I did get a little bit of water dripping on it from my water bottle, it wiped right off. The straps are nice and padded and comfortable and there's a top handle for easy carrying. There is a luggage strap that you can use to loop over your suitcase handle for traveling. The zippers being a gold/coppery color is a nice touch and I like that the brand logo is rather subtle, just printed near the bottom of the bag rather than a huge emblem at the top.

And the POCKETS!! I was impressed by how many compartments and pockets, including several zipped pockets there are in this bag! There are 4 main compartments, with the padded laptop area being at the very back. Within the 3 largest compartments there are zipped pockets. The smallest one in front has a key strap clasp. And I love the "hidden" zipped pocket at the back of the bag that is perfect for a wallet or phone. Little details like being able to lock together the zippers at the largest compartment and able to tuck the zipper in at the smallest front compartment are nice. I do wish they had locking zippers in the 2 middle compartments.

Now for the slight drawbacks. Like some others have mentioned, the adjusting straps need constant adjusting. They remind me of a seat belt material but are really smooth so I think the buckle doesn't have enough grip to hold the strap in place. I'll have to see if I can figure out a diy hack for this. Also, the side pockets are rather small and would probably only hold a small water bottle.

But overall I like this bag and it's a good value. It's got a lot of room and pockets to help keep you organized, but overall not bulky. I think it'll be great as a personal item or carry on when traveling. Hopefully it will be sturdy enough to last me years.

title: 8 PoE Gigabit PoE ports at a good price and it works!
text:
This is my second SODALA switch. My first one (a 4 port model) has been running the several of the security cameras around my house since January and has worked quite well. This is basically identical to it, except with 8 port rather than 4, which I really like as that will let me get rid of three additional PoE injectors and consolidate them to one switch. So far, I did a bit of quick testing on this with a few phones (Grandstream, Fanvil, Vtech/SNOM) and a couple of security cameras (Reolink and Foscam). All worked fine (which is good, as the Vtech/SNOM is known for being quite picky and won't work with some of my PoE sources).

That being said, the one device that did not work QUITE properly with this switch is a Netgear WAX615 access point from work, which I just plugged in out of curiosity. While the WAX615 fired up and works, it only detected this as a lower power 802.3af switch rather than 802.3at, so it operates in a reduced bandwidth mode. However, I am not going to knock any points off this review based on that, as, so far, the only PoE switch I have found that the WAX615 seems to work at full speed with is specifically one built by Netgear (go figure). As that is the only 802.3at device I have at the moment, I can't say for sure if that is an issue with the access point or with the 802.3at implementation in this switch (and several others).

The VLAN and extend modes I have not tested, as they are not particularly useful for my own setup.

The only criticism I have of this switch is that LEDs are all at the bottom and not very visible nor very informative (all they show is activity, not PoE status nor link speed). While I would really prefer them to be a bit better on this, for the price, I'm still not complaining.

Overall though, I like this switch, it seems to work well for the devices I actually need it to work with, I like that it has dual uplink ports, I like that it has 8 PoE ports and a large power budget, and I like the price!

title: Good amount of connections, multi-monitor, inconveniently short cable
text:
I am using the Fairikabe USB-C Docking Station to allow multiple users with laptops to connect to a workstation with dual monitors, keyboard, and mouse to easily connect to these devices without having to unplug and replug all the various devices in.

The dock provides 3 USB-A Ports, which I consider the minimum needed to be acceptable. If you have a wired keyboard and mouse, you take up 2 of those ports already and have only 1 available for something like a camera. The USB-C port on this dock is usable as another USB port, but I am using this to deliver power.

All of the ports on the device appear to work as expected. The 3 USB 3.0 ports deliver data transfer at the speeds expected. The card readers are able to read and write data to my SD cards. The location of the card reader port is mildly inconvenient though, as they are on the back of the dock and would have preferred something on the side, as the back is generally closer to something like a wall. I was able to achieve acceptable gigabit speeds via the connected ethernet port, measured through iperf. The dual HDMI connectors were each able to produce video at 1080.

The most frustrating thing about this dock is the short USB-C cable that is built into the dock. The Fairikabe USB-C Docking Station is a wedge shaped dock, with rubber pads for your laptop on one side and rubber feet to maintain contact with a surface. With the USB-C cable coming out of the left side of the dock, you are not able to reach the right side of your laptop with the cable if your USB-C port is on the right side. I find this to be an odd oversight given the design of this dock has a specific orientation.

Overall, I find that this dock is pretty useful. I would consider this to be an affordable dock that could be used similarly to a commercial level dock, but for a more consumer setting. My biggest gripe with this device is that the USB-C cable that is built-in is just too short and prevents me from connecting the dock to my laptop that has a right side USB-C port without purchasing a USB-C extender, which means it's not quite ready out of the box..

title: If you are conatantly having to buy new ear buds....
text: I have put ear buds through  the ringer in my life time. Most ear buds i have bougnt in the past have lasted me around 2 months tops. I have tried taking extreme caution  with my ear buds and I have also  definitely  have been very hard on my ear buds.... doing stupid things like go running in the rain with them on/in.  I have tried el cheapos and i have tried more expensive buds....2 months top and they are done. These soundpeats have survived extreme abuse by me and live on despite it all.  I just looked at the date when I bought these earbuds and they are coming up on 2 years .... which is way way way longer than any ear buds have ever  lasted me. I have been meaning to write a review on these for some time but something finally drove me to stop being lazy and finally do it. Yesterday  it appeared as if my Right ear bud was finally kicking the bucket. I noticed that it was seeming to not want to charge. I fiddled with it and could make it start charging with a little voodoo but i was sure that these ear buds were finally at their end.....until i decided to actually clean the metal connector pieces where it charges. Presto .....they are charging just fine and STILL going strong. I have half joked that when these finally die i will make them into a trophy on my wall and i really may end up doing this. Realistically..i have blught over 100 ear bud sets in the past decade and i can remember  being suppppper frustrated when pair after pair would go out for seemingly no reason after a month or two.  With these soundpeats I have been .....running countless times in the rain..dropped the ear buds all over my warehouse at work...stepped on them...i even wear them in the shower if i am not washing my hair...the gnarliest story ever is when i was showering and  one ear bud popped out and rolled down the tub INTO THE DRAIN....and was in there for a solid 3 to 5 seconds with water just gushing onto it....i pulled the ear bud out  and it mini-glitched for like 2 mins and has been perfectly fine since. I am assuming not everyone has had the same excellent  experience with these ear buds as me but.. man....bravo soundpeats..bravo

title: Easy to Use, High Quality Video
text:
This camera is one of the easiest to set up, and I've had several kinds from different companies (Samsung, Wyze, etc.). Overall its a great little device that has amazing battery life and can be controlled anywhere with the app on your phone.

Set up:
Camera instructions are clear and most of the set up is through the VicoHome app. From there you add the Wifi (2.4 gz only - if you don't know what type of WiFi you have, then is 99% likely 2.4 gz)

After setting up the camera through the app (and an initial firmware update), you are good to go. You could put the camera right on your table and it'll work! On my first night I put it in my basement and it only dropped 1% for the whole night!

Installation:
The bracket is firm and easy to put the camera onto it with just a twist. The bracket can be screwed into the wall, but I used a couple zip ties to attach it to my pergola metal bars-- works perfectly and I can move it if I wanted. The WiFi antenna seems to be great, as my router is on the other side of my house and its picking up "Strong" signal outside on my deck. The solar panel is just as easy to install and you plug it into the back of the camera and the charge is automatic and always keeps my camera up at 100%.

Use:
The app is super easy to use to connect and view the live feed. You can install a 128gb microSD card to save movement videos to it. The app will alert you to movements within its viewing range; you can edit the sensitivity from Low to High, and with High sensitivity, it was alerting me when a squirrel ran by 20 feet away, so its nice. Those motion activated videos are stored in the cloud for a couple days or your SD card if you use one too. The app does offer longer storage and higher volume if needed, but free plan is good for me. You can move the lens so you can check on multiple areas and it has a wide angle lens so you see more in 1 area too.

I highly recommend this camera, just a couple years ago this level of camera would be $300+.

title: Good basic dash cam
text:
Since I don't have a dash cam, I decided this one was a good place to start. I haven't had a chance to try out all the features yet, but I can tell you how I feel about it so far. I ordered this for two reasons, but I wasn't as interested in the rear camera feature.

First, I wanted a dash camera for when I'm out traveling in town for safety reasons and legal proof. Since this camera automatically begins recording as soon as you start your car as long as it is plugged in to charge, this seemed like a good fit for a beginner like myself. Basically, I flipped through the instruction booklet quickly and ran to plug it into my car. It started recording as soon as it was plugged in and my car was running, and it picked up the audio very well so, if you need a plug-and-go dash cam, this is definitely an option.

The second reason I bought it was to record some basic travel videos for my local area. I was curious if I could record video and audio totally hands-free as I drove, and it worked pretty well. I still need to fasten the attached set up onto my window where I want it, but the recordings were pretty good with my own setup. One thing I learned is that I should have read all the instructions first! Ha! I say this because my camera recorded a bunch of one minute videos during my short trip because that's what it was set to do -- record and save every minute as a separate video. Be sure to change those settings so you have fewer videos to deal with, and be certain to set your dates and times because I realized that after the fact as well.

Overall, this is a pretty good little camera for an inexperienced dash cam person, but you will want to read the user manual first. I normally do, but this time I just wanted to get out and take a drive while filming. Don't forget that the memory card is set to record until it is full, and then it will record over the existing footage. If you want to use it for extended footage, be sure to keep some spare memory cards with you. I drove for about 90 minutes, and it used about one-third of the memory which I thought was pretty good. I look forward to putting this little camera through its paces as I make more videos.

title: A Budget-Friendly Cable That Works as Advertised
text:
A few years ago when I first upgraded my home theater with an HDMI 2.1 compliant OLED TV, I decided to proactively run HDMI 2.1 compliant cables to all four inputs, since I knew it would be a challenge to add or replace any cables after installation. I purchased four identical cables from a well known brand that in the past, had always offered good value-for-money products. Big mistake.

I've had numerous issues with my old cables over the last few years - primarily with 4K 120Hz VRR output from both PC and PS5 alike. While they did work, they'd often flicker or display a black screen until power cycled. I'm not sure if it was just bad luck -- i.e. I got four defective cables -- or I was paying the early adopter tax but regardless, enough was enough and I finally decided to rip everything apart and run some new cables.

Rather than buy a new set of matched cables I suppressed my OCD tendencies and used cables that I've collected along the way along with a couple new ones including the TCNEWCL 8K@60Hz HDMI Cable. I used the TCNEWCL cable to connect my PS5 and after many hours of testing at 4K HDR 120Hz VRR, I'm happy to report that it works perfectly. No flickering, no black screens, no issues of any kind - it just works.

There's nothing exceptional nor concerning about the exterior construction - it's as basic as they come and that's just fine because what matters is not what you can see rather, the internals you cannot. With regards to the internal quality, I can only make a determination based upon the TCNEWCL cable's performance and since it performs perfectly, I have to assume that the internals are of sufficient quality.

Wrapping this up, the TCNEWCL 8K@60Hz HDMI Cable is exactly what it should be, an affordable cable that fully supports the HDMI 2.1 spec. With that in mind however, I am knocking a half point off my rating for one reason that is unrelated to the product itself - the price. As much as I consider the asking price to be fair, there are cables of a similar length that perform identically and are 50% (or more) less expensive. 4.5 out of 5 rounded up. Highly recommended.

title: Great cable with proof of official certification to "Ultra High Speed HDMI Cable" standards
text:
This cable is certified by the HDMI organization as an "Ultra High Speed HDMI Cable" and it includes proof on the package with a holographic label that includes a QR code which can be checked with a mobile phone app (see screenshot). That certification means that it passsed independent HDMI lab testing so insure that it fully supports "ALL HDMI 2.1a features including uncompressed 8k@60 and 4K@120 and up to 48Gbps bandwidth." (Note: I had to black out the HDMI ORG URL as well as the QR code as reviews with either shown in photos are rejected.)

That's a big deal. It means that you cannot improve on the performance of this cable at any price. If you pay hundreds, or even thousands, of dollars for one of those "videophile" cables, it won't improve any aspect of television picture or sound. As we engineers say, bits are bits and HDMI is a digital format.

Inside of the bag is a cable packaged with care. It includes two hook & loop cable ties, one at each connector. They are just wrapped around and can be removed and reused. Each connector shell is a handsome brushed aluminum imprinted with the company name and the cable use rating (8K ultra high speed). These are protected from damage in shipping with yellow covers, insuring that they will arrive in pristine condition. Each gold connector end is further protected with plastic HDMI connector covers; again, to prevent damage in transit.

Once out of the packaging, the cable has good flexibility, especially considering the diameter and number of individual conductors. I could live without the Scottish kilt color scheme, preferring black cables that blend in with the black equipment and smoked glass shelving, but that's just a personal preference thing.

I'm using this cable between my Apple TV 4K and my Denon AV receiver. It replaced an older cable not guaranteed to the current Ultra High Speed HDMI Cable standards. This cable has performed flawlessly throughout rigorous testing (input switching, rebooting, and power cycling).

I am happy to recommend this. But whatever cable you buy, insist on the label with proof of HDMI standards testing. I may be buying more of these to replace some other, older cables in my setup.

title: A little too much hassle for me
text:
I am always in need of power strips and surge protectors because I own every electrical device known to man and those things are hungry for power! I ordered this because I wanted a power strip with a small footprint. While this definitely fits that bill, other quirks about it make me reluctant to recommend it.

The positives:

- There are three outlets on the strip and each outlet can be set up as a smart plug
- It’s very compact, so it will fit in a small place
- Six foot cord is much more versatile than other strips with three foot cords

The negatives:

- Setting up smart functions is way too much trouble
- Smart plug use requires installing another application on your phone
- Plugs are way too close together, making it unlikely to be able to use all three at once
- Because of the aforementioned negatives, the value of this product relative to cost is low

I really was excited to read the description of this power strip because it looked like just the thing I needed. I wanted something small that I could use with a smart light and to charge my phones. This does that, but it took way more time and effort to set up initially than I wanted to spend.

When I realized that there was no way to avoid installing yet one more app in order to use the smart features of this strip, my enthusiasm waned considerably. Instead of integrating with Amazon Alexa or Google Home directly via AP, you have to install the BN-Live app and THEN connect the plug to Alexa or Google via the BN-Live app. Ridiculous - especially since the app and/or device itself is super buggy. It took me almost an hour to get the app to recognize the power strip. I eventually had to turn off my 5GHz network completely (which caused me to reset a bunch of other devices). I also had to take the power strip and move it right next to my router before the app would see it. Now that it is set up, the power strip no longer has to be next to the router, but it wouldn’t work initially unless the things were side by side. And this is not inexpensive, so look carefully for options that might be a better value for your money.

title: Very Impressive Signal Strength and Range for a Budget Price
text:
I have tested many budget wireless routers trying to find one with good 2.4ghz wifi in the $40-80 range. I have used Linksys, Asus, Netgear, TPLink and many other home grade routers. My house is not even very big, but wifi signal was close to -70dbm on the second floor in one bedroom and also the bathroom. Had been thinking about going to a Unifi setup and almost pulled the trigger on a U6 Lite. But the price and needing a Unifi controller to get the most out of the setup made me hesitate.

Saw reviews on the TPLink Omada and APs and many positive reviews. For half the price of a U6 Lite with POE included it seemed worth a try. I have a Proxnox server running 24/7 with OPNSense VM as my firewall/router so adding a VM to run the Omada SDN controller software was easy. I had all the WLAN settings configured before the EAP225 even arrived at my door. Once I had it plugged in and adopted, it only took a few minutes to be fully up and running. Running speedtests on laptop and cell phone and right off the bat download and upload speeds were very impressive over anything I had before. The real test would be the bedroom upstairs and the bathroom and it didn't disappoint. Wifi signal was about -60dbm. The signal strength and range was really good. Before I bought the EAP225 I had thought I would need to run two in mesh, but after testing for a few days now, just one EAP225 is working for all that I needed.

Almost all the reviews for the EAP225 are for the V3 version and that is what i thought I would be receiving. However I was sent the V4. I didn't notice any downsides to this. So probably not a big deal.

Overall very satisfied with the EAP225V4 so far. I'm really liking the Omada ecosystem and who knows, I may get the itch to get another EAP225 or a EAP245 in the future to try a mesh setup. Definitely looking forward to see if I can get even more improvement out of the TPLink Omada products.

title: Great value for money and good support.
text:
I took a chance with these recertified drives (bought directly from water panther, a little cheaper than on Amazon) based on the price. Last summer I rebuilt my NAS and after shopping around for options decided to try 12tb drives. Ordered four, tested them for about a month, found a few odd things (the serial number on the drive did not match the serial reported by smart for instance) but otherwise no major issues. Ordered 4 more, tested those then set up a ZFS RAIDZ2 array and started moving my data over.

Recently during my weekly long smart test one drive made a horrible grinding noise and I knew immediately it was bad. Checked TrueNas and sure enough "array degraded" and though the system still saw the drive I couldn't get any smart info from it. Contacted customer support, got an RMA#, shipped the drive back and have the replacement resilvering now in about a week.

I'll admit to a bit of laziness, I was supposed to buy 2 more drives as spares but never got around to it. I'll be doing that but the RMA process was painless and fast which is a very good thing.
