While I couldn't be sure what the original drives were initially (an arsenal label covered the top of the drive) the replacement was a recertified Seagate EXOS x14 and this time the serial on the drive matches what is reported by smart.

These particular drives do run on the louder side but I'm in the process of virtualizing my NAS and the drives will soon be in a fractal R5 case which should help with the noise. Before I purchased these drives I tried to find out if these were worth the price savings and the results were mixed. After going through the RMA process I'm satisfied, having worked in the IT drives going bad is just a fact of life, I don't hold that against anyone.

If I were buying for a business/enterprise I'd go with new retail drives for the longer warranty but for my home lab paying half the cost of a retail drive with a reliable 2 year warranty backing it is kind of a no brainer. This is of course assuming WP stays reliable with RMA's but only the future will tell on that one.

title: Decent First Projector If Expectations Are Realistic
text:
This projector is okay if expectations are realistic about what one is getting for something in this price range. It is a budget projector with budget specs, so don’t expect to be dazzled by a sharp, bright picture. The brightness is listed as 9000 lumens, and I think it’s safe to assume they mean “light source lumens” and not the more accurate method to measure brightness, which is ANSI lumens. The 9000 lumens calculate to 300 ANSI lumens, which looks pretty washed out if there is any degree of ambient light in the room. I did understand the limitations of this projector when I ordered it, and my intended use is in a “garage theater” in which I can create a completely light-free environment. Again, I have realistic expectations about the performance of this projector, and it was never intended to be my primary source for viewing movies or sports, but rather for a bit of family fun time in which I am willing to make quite a few concessions. Setup is simple and both the Bluetooth and WiFi connected quickly and without any issues. Control-wise, there is nothing fancy going on with manual keystone correction and focus. The audio is expectedly low quality, but it was always my intention to use an external amplified audio source anyway. Something that is only mentioned kind of in passing in the manual is that this projector can’t process (or passthrough) Dolby audio, which I’m sure is a licensing issue. I wanted to connect a PC to this projector and stream through my Plex server, but all of my nearly 900 movies are in Dolby Digital, so there is no audio. My available workarounds are to use a Roku which downmixes to stereo, or convert my audio to AAC on an “as needed” basis. The Roku is the easier option, even if I don’t get the snappier response like I do from my more powerful PC. My biggest complaint is the noisy fan, and, if it is at all possible, I may take a stab at replacing it with something quieter.

It’s decent for a first projector if it can be set up in a very dark room and if the use is more about the get-together with family and friends versus expecting an incredible cinematic experience.

title: beast of a cable
text:
I mean, wow. 10' braided cord. usb-c on one end, with a usb-a adapter. microusb, usb-c, and Lightning on the other. handled my QC and PD chargers perfectly. I didn't test to see if it charged multiple devices as it claims but you'd need a decent charger on the other end and it's going to make some tradeoffs. I put this on a 25W PD charger and my phone loved it. I tried it with a USB-A quick charge too, no problem. I mostly want one at a time, just pick the right end. Nice to know they can share if needed though, and this makes it a great solution for travel. This is a good excuse to buy one of those 100W usb-c chargers :)

UPDATE: I got a bigger PD charger. This cable does NOT do the right handshake to enable "super fast charging" (USBC -> USBC) that the included cable does. I'm not too worried about it, the extra juice really only benefits the first part of charging from a completely empty battery. It DOES power my laptop that requires 65W. It still does fast charging and it works with multiple devices but this shows me it can't replace some of my existing cables.

Apparently this does data on one connection, either USB-C or Lightning. But let's not call this high speed data! They say it is 480MBps, so that's USB-2 speed (USB-3 starts at 5GBps) and nothing to get too excited about. Still, could work for a limited connection with something downstream if you just need to transfer a few files or something. Otherwise, use it for what it is designed: charging!

2 year warranty is frosting on this cake. I hope this cable is as tough as the last one I bought with a braided jacket.

My favorite cord with multiple heads has breathing LED illumination. But the charger end is USB-A only so it can't handle PD from a USB-C charger. This new cord doesn't have lights but promises to be a real workhorse and even with some minor limitations, it can serve most travel charging requirements quite well.

title: Great sound, solid isolation; Maybe lacks connection
text:
I bought these a while back to replace Jaybird Vistas that started to die. I'll try to keep it short and simple:

Pros:
-Comfortable for regular use. I wear them 8-10 hours per day, no issues unless I wear a tight beanie.
-Great sound. Listen to mostly rock, but have everything from jazz, blues, hardbass, house, and hip-hop. I don't feel like it lacks in sound.
-Great noise cancellation. I work near an airport and in a factory and the isolation mode does cover up a good chunk of that sound to way more tolerable levels.
-Solid battery life. Not much to say here. 8-10 hours of use per day. Usually use one at a time for 8 hours. Alternate every 4 hours, charge while going home/gym and full charge by the time I get there.
-Good fit. Doesn't slip on its own unless profusely sweating and pressing buttons at the same time, which I've done on longer runs, but they didn't fall out.

Cons:
-The case shape sucks. The oval/rounded shape makes it real easy to fall out of pockets on top of being kind of bulky. There's nothing really holding the case closed either. If you drop the case, be prepared for your buds to spill out.
-Poor connection at times. This is were I bounce around whether I want to replace these or not. I have Moto G Power phone and sometimes the connection to my music is interrupted just putting my phone back in my pocket. Can't walk away more than 10-12 ft. without the connection dropping. Vistas I replaced could maintain connection 20-30 feet away inside a metal-filled factory before dropping.

That's about it. The connection thing might be me? I hear and read mixed messages on that. I'd love to know or hear back if that's a defect or something that I could get fixed.

Oh wait, I forgot one thing: Dropped in the (clean) toilet, case and all. A day in rice later, no difference made. I blame the smooth, oval case. It shwooped out of my hoodie's pocket as I patted my pockets to look for keys.

title: Incredible Value Smartwatch At An Incredible Pricepoint
text:
I have purchased everything from kids smart watches, right up to the high-end name brands, and I have to say, this may be one of my favorites. In fact I love it so much, I bought a second.

Right out of the box, this watch, exudes quality, intuitiveness, familiarity, and it’s jam-packed with feature-rich apps and functionality. I would even go as far to say, as it has a near exact look, feel, and function of its higher priced name-brand counterpart.

It does come mostly charged out of the box, but it will also charge from a “dead state” in just a couple hours, and offers multiple days of use (depending on how much you use the apps.). It pairs easily with the iOS devices in my house, and offers all the functionality that you would want for sports, call and message connection, as well as media play. My favorite is being able to check the weather without digging out my phone. You can even set up the apps to look and function just like the big brands.

The price point may be the most incredible part. To be able to get the delux functionality, and quality of the higher price counterpart at an affordable rate, is a massive win

Pros: I personally feel that this is a great smart watch for anyone who may be looking for an entry-level smart watch. The functionality is awesome, the battery life is outstanding (I’ve been getting about 4-5 days on a single charge), and it has nearly all of the feature rich functions that you would want in a smart watch.

Cons: At this point, I haven’t found any accessories for this watch, such as different bands, and face guards, but I’m sure they’re out there. I also don’t care for the charging method. While I’d love to have wireless charging or even a USB-C connection, it uses a proprietary magnetic cable which if not positioned carefully, doesn’t stay on well. (But it’s a small gripe).

Final Thoughts: This is a wonderfully fantastic deal for a smart watch, and I am glad I was able to pick this one up.

title: The specs are correct, RGB lighting much dimmer than pictured
text:
As some have noted, Amazon has the wrong model number listed which might create an issue if you needed to return, but the specs as shown are correct. The difference is the 12UHS has twice the RAM and hard drive space than the 12UGS. Otherwise these are the same laptop. For the $400 price increase for the 12UHS, is it cheaper to upgrade the RAM and SSD yourself.

This thing is a gaming beast and you will not be disappointed in it's performance. Testing the CPU speed shows it goes to 4.2 Ghz under load.

The screen is a true 240hz monitor with no significant motion ghosting and is bright with no obvious dark zones or flash lighting. The UFO screen test shows crisp graphics at the promised refresh rate.

The speakers are above average for a laptop. There are two tweeter/mids on each side of the keyboard top and two side firing subs which go down to about 100hz. The result is a good clear sound stage with warm sound. The highest volume level might not cut it in a noisy environment tho.

Start up is fast and applications load very quickly.

The bad which soured my over all rating:

Disappointed in the RGB lighting. Controlling it is not easy even with the software needed to change per key or whole lighting effects. No where in the app is a control for keyboard brightness and the supposed short cut key combo has no effect on the brightness level. Pretty much useless unless you are playing in the dark. Out of the box they keys are dim as is the front bar that is shown to be glowing brightly in the product images. I was able to adjust the bar brightness successfully, but the brightest setting isn't bright at all. Definitely a case of false advertising by MSI. Now of course you don't buy a gaming laptop for the bling, but is a sin to over promise and under deliver especially at the 2k price point. If you are choosing this over other gaming laptops for the RGB lighting, choose something else.

Windows 11 is horrible. It took a lot of work to get it to look like I wanted to, especially the taskbar, but was worth it, mostly. This isn't MSI's fault, but Windows 10 would have been better as it is more customizable.

title: Excellent amazon based tablet with some amazon centric issues
text:
I got this tablet after trying an apple ipad and the microsoft surface go 3. So, I can say from my standpoint I like this fire hd 10 better than the other two tablets for a couple of different reasons. First of all the cost is a significant difference from the Surface Go 3, and if you are not a member of the apple community the apple ipad is extremely difficult to integrate into your android based ecosystrm.

The fire tablet has much similar form factor to the surface go 3. The screen is very colorful, detailed and bright. It is responsive and logical to get around on. The one little issue with the tablet is it's amazon centric software and apps that are difficult to work around. So, if you like the amazon web browser and are happy with it's email and other apps you will be very happy with it as it comes to you. BUT, if you are one of millions who prefer Google Chrome as your browser and associated apps like gmail and google drive you will have some work to do to get those apps on this tablet. It's not impossible but it is not for someone to do that does not have some comfort in downloading some apk files and executing them to get chrome on the tablet. There are a couple good tutorials on the web that explain how to do this. So, if it wasn't for this hassle to get other apps on the Fire HD 10 I would give this product a solid 5 star rating.

Another very positive factor in liking this tablet is the ability to add internal storage space with an sdhc card slot. Great! This was another factor in my preference for this tablet over the other two. One small issue with this tablet is the apps screen on startup. Amazon will not let you get rid of many of the apps or even hide them if you don't want them on the tablet. There is one small workaround to this if you don't want them cluttering up your screen and that is to put them in the "Utility" group on the front page. Some of the decisions these makers of tablets make continue to amaze me with their shortsightedness and selfish behavior when it would be so much better for the customer and hence sales of the product to design it for the customer's benefit, ease of use, etc.

title: Too big for one-handed use, hair-trigger power button, though warm screen is nice
text:
This is my 3rd kindle over ten years, and I've been a long time fan/user. In short - if you carry your kindle everywhere with you like I do then the bigger size of this unit and the hair-trigger power buttons are both net problems.

For size: this is constantly falling out of my pockets and is uncomfortable when holding with one hand. The smaller legacy devices for the Paperwhite/Voyage/etc. all comfortably fit into the back pocket of my (men's) pants. That's out the window now. Best case I get about 2/3 of this unit and then it feels like I'm carrying around textbook wedged in there. It also no longer fits entirely into most of my coat pockets (side or breast pockets), so I have it hanging out on pockets where my old devices fit fine. As a result - I've had this for about two weeks and have dropped it a dozen times just sitting on a chair or in the car.

For the power button: this is constantly turning on in my pocket despite my efforts to not press the button. The screen sensitivity is also such that I have had to walk back 10-20 pages in whatever book I'm reading. I've been reading a book or two per month on kindle for 10 years and, though this has happened to me once in a while, it is frustratingly common so far with this new one.

Lastly - both of these issues combine to make single handed reading for right-handed folks a cramp-inducing mess. For better or worse there's not much bezel area to pinch to hold the device up without accidental page turns. The side effect is that I naturally start to prop up the device with my pinky finger, which then hits the power button and turns off the screen. I have to hold much of the weight of the device on just the tip of my pinky finger (which gets painful) or otherwise use it two handed / propped up.

I really wanted to like this device for the warm light, and that feature is a great relief, but I'm having trouble overcoming the discomfort/inconvenience of not being able to throw it in my back pocket and then pull it out to read one handed while waiting in line or laying on the couch. I don't know if I'll keep it.

title: very bad picture quality and not UHD, very bad user experience from Amazon service centor
text:
do not buy this one, this is very bad picture quality , it is not a UHD.
and taking too longer time to get my refund, 60 days !!!!!!
the Amzon service centor just told us, you have to wating for 60 days and no any update information for tracking the device and updagte the refund staus, it was horible user experence !!!!!
no people want to buy this anymore again !

I add tother custmer user edxperince from Amazon, I had same now as below, do not buy from Amazon , this is very bad quality and user service experience
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

mazon sent me a broken screen and I thought return should be straightforward but it is a nightmare with Amazon currently saying no refund.

When I first initiated the return, Amazon provided me the RMA number and asked me to fill a form on Pilot freight services website. But nothing happened for days as Amazon system is broken and can’t talk to Pilot, as confirmed by an Amazon and Pilot representative. After multiple calls to Amazon customer service, an agent said he has to send an internal note to a heavy and bulk department to manually ask Pilot to initiate the pickup.

The next day, I get an email from Pilot to schedule a pick up and the TV was picked up, returned to Amazon warehouse as per Pilot tracking.

Now another round of calls to Amazon to process the refund and was finally said someone will contact me over email as the refund team is not available on phone. Why would Pilot freight services take a TV from me without Amazon authorization? Who paid Pilot for transportation of that TV? Given this is a bulk item, there was no prepaid shipping label like one would get for UPS returns.

I am clueless how to get refund but may have to try and escalate within Amazon or contact FTC or my credit card company

title: Updated review
text:
I have never updated a review. I want to in this case. This PC is awesome. I left a negative review. I want to change my review. I wish to state I I copied my first review and plan to paste it in at the end of this updated review. I no longer place blame on jack's shop or Minisforum. I now have had 3 PC's that failed because of Windows 11 updates. In each of those incidents this same thing occurred. As most of you know when installing a Windows update restarting the PC is part of the installation. My 3 PC's that got messed up all did the same thing. Windows update appeared to be installing normally during the shutting down phase. However, during the starting back up phase all I got was a black screen. So I now blame Microsoft. I read news yesterday. Many others besides myself has had the same thing happen. My advice is to use Windows 10 until this issue is resolved. Also many people have successfully installed this update I don't know how a person is to know in advance if their PC will install the update successfully. I do know nobody wants to deal with this. This was my original review:

I connected it and used it for awhile (2 weeks) a short while then I was told Windows had an update. I thought sure update windows. The PC has never booted since. Before that update I used this PC and was so happy with it. When that update occurred I contacted Minisforum. They replied that I failed to update the BIOS. They were saying in a nutshell that it was my fault for not updating the BIOS. I had it only 2 weeks. I have updated a BIOS before. Straight out of the box it needs a BIOS update or it will crash because of Windows update. Really how was I to know it needed to have a BIOS update or Windows update will crash it. When it worked it was totally awesome. I am posting this to inform new buyers, the very first thing they should do is find out if they need to update the BIOS or they may have the same thing happen them. They sold me a Windows PC with a BIOS that can't handle a windows update. Then said it was my fault for not updating the BIOS. It wasn't my fault like they (Minisforum) says they sold me a new PC with a flawed BIOS. They didn't want to backup their product so they blamed me.

title: Finally A Motherboard that works!
text:
Long story short, this was my fourth motherboard in a string of three others (other brands and models but all x570s) that were DOA. I have this up and running for over a week and it is performing as it should. It is the only one of the group that is WiFi capable which is a feature I do not need/use. Irony, right?

It has the features I was looking for, but it would have been better if it had two 3-pin addressable headers for RGB devices. The second NVMe slot comes with a heat spreader/sink but since my drives already have their own, I had to leave it off the build. Not a big deal.

I use air cooling so the thoughtful headers for AIO type cooling are nice to have if I ever decide to make the switch.

Compared to the other three fails (2 MSI and 1 other ASUS) this is a solid performer and handles my Ryzen 7 5800X with 32 Gigs of Corsair Vengeance RAM with no problems. The BIOS is easy enough to navigate and allowed me to set things as I wanted them. I am not an overclocker.

It does have a small RGB light on the back of the board which makes for a subtle display inside my all white case. I have not yet explored if that can be turned off. It does stay on with the PC off. I have to switch the power supply off to have these lights off. But again, I have not explored other options, such as in the BIOS, to have them turn off when the PC shuts off. It is no big deal for me, but perhaps it might be for you. I am just happy to have a board that actually works!

It is the heart of my new gaming rig. I went with a MSI RX6700XT and paired it all with a nice LG 32" 165Hz 2K monitor and I never knew how great my games looked until this setup was operational. I upgraded from a 10+ year-old rig running a FX6100 and a 1050Ti - I know, a museum piece. I love the new speed and power this board affords me. I am a happy gamer. I hope you are as well!

title: Marine Radio it is not
text:
This product is depicted as being used on a open speedboat.
1) The display on the one I have is so dim it is unreadable until dusk.
2) The sensitivity of the radio is not very good. As radio transmitter towers don’t line our coasts I assumed it would excel in sensitivity but it doesn’t.
3). None of the settings or saved radio stations are stored in non-volatile memory. So every time the 12v is lost, it forgets everything and you have to start again with an awkward setup procedure.
4) The gasket. I contacted Pyle Tech support on this issue and they were very underwhelming in response. The radio comes with a sleeve. The sleeve fitted nicely into the double Din opening of the metal panel I was mounting it in. There are bend back tabs on the sleeve that, combined with a front flange, hold it rock solid. The radio slides into the sleeve quite smoothly. It also has flanges on each side that sit on top of the sleeve flanges, to stop it from being pushed in too far. That’s all good. But then there is a plastic rectangular trim that slides over the front of the radio to finish off the look and hide the flanges. It sits on top of the flanges and has no features to wrap around them and provide a seal to the panel. So it sits nearly a quarter inch proud of the panel and makes a great opening for water ingress. And looks bad at the same time.
5). The Bluetooth has a range of about 2 feet, although it does stay connected.
I’m not impressed with either the product or their technical support.
UPDATE: I finally did something good with this product. I threw it away. I found the radio was being swamped by rf emissions by an adjacent digital voltmeter on the same panel, and when I powered that off could receive twice as many radio broadcast stations. I finally replaced it with another manufacturers product at twice the price. That was the first good decision I have made with this radio. I now get 4 times the number of radio stations I could get from this thing on a good day. I can read the display in daylight. The trim for the radio actually fits snug to the panel. And the voltmeter is powered up again as is doesn’t affect reception.

title: A perplexing device, could be great if not for deal-killer annoyances
text:
On paper, this is one of the best (and one of only a very few) smaller tablets still available. And by "smaller" I mean hold-in-one-hand size, with a screen in the 8 inch realm. An iPad mini is the other obvious option, but it's pretty expensive for what it is, and has its own drawbacks. So I opted to give a Fire a try.
Many things to like: it seems solidly built, has good resolution, and reasonable performance. It's a pretty lightweight device, too -- light enough for one-handed use, and isn't awkward to handle for super casual use.
From there, though, are so many negative factors. First and foremost: I really wish Amazon and Google would work things out such that their devices and services worked together. I get that they each have to protect certain aspects of their respective marketing domains, but not allowing the Google Play store for an Android device is frankly ridiculous. It's just too limiting. (To be fair, Google not allowing one to make in-app purchases from Amazon is equally limiting.) I think very few people live exclusively in the Google or Amazon ecosphere. Making it overly inconvenient to access one, from the other, works against consumers and -- ironically -- makes certain devices or services a non-starter (at least for me).
Then there's the issue of the Kindle app -- on the Kindle device. How on earth is the Kindle app, on the Kindle device, so much worse than the Kindle app on any other Android device? Why, on my phone for example, can I adjust font sizes, type faces, colors, spacing, et al., with about twice as many different options as on the Kindle-based Kindle app? How does this make any sense?
The limitations on customizing the home screen are maddening. I paid for an ad-free device, but the "recommendations" banner on the home screen seemingly can't be dispensed with.
I returned the Kindle Fire; replaced it with a Samsung A7 Lite, and couldn't be happier with the switch. About the same price, but the Samsung is agnostically Android-native. The Kindle app is the same I've become used to on my phone, and the device overall is simply better. I won't buy such a heavily brand-specific device again, that's for sure.

title: Opinion; On PC Monitors overall
text:
For me, it's LG then everything else as it relates to quality. PC Monitors are just terrible. I'm not saying that PC Monitors can barely be made out, but it just really sad that out of all the budget monitors, this is probably the best. Now I'm not saying that there aren't any 4k monitors are good, but really 1440p monitors w/high refresh monitors are really gaming monitors. 1440p is highly efficient with high refresh rate. To me if you're going 4K, you really need to get an LG monitor. Getting a 4K LCD really doesn't make sense. So since I don't have OLED LG money right now, I'm going for the 1440p ultra wide. I make and build content for youtube on transformational gaming. So Ultra wide is what I'm looking for. Sadly, this is the best 1440p wide monitor there is as far as budget. This has a high refresh rate and all the bells and whistles with gSync. But the bad news is that the color and picture are terrible. And when I say terrible I mean compared to OLED. I have the CX 65 inch in my living room. When I come back to this monitor, it just looks that much worse. I wish they can do updates to this tv like the LG. I'm sure there are some calibration they can do to make it better. But wow... if you want a wide screen with high refresh rates at 1440, you have to settles for this monitor. You can go for a 2400x1440 if you play games but again I need ultra wide at 3440x1440p for content creation. So eventually I'm going to get a 4K OLED monitor but right now to me it's this one that has everything I need and it's the only brand that has it. So it's almost like a monopoly at least at this price point. I'll make a video about this product soon.
Lastly, if you're moving from one place to another, my advice is to keep the box that it came with and put the monitor back in the box while moving. Anything else and you're going to end like me and have to replace it. That's right, this thing cracks like an egg. I'll talk about this more on the channel.

title: Nice to have if you’re used to using a trackpad
text:
My mouse recently quit working and refused to get repaired, and when I saw this, I decided to get it instead of another mouse. I had used laptops quite a bit and got to the point where I preferred the trackpad to using an external mouse, mostly because the mouse required finding more room to work in. And that is why I thought this might be a good idea. The same holds true on a desktop.

It did take some getting used to again, but the images on the pad itself are a huge help to mimic anything you’d do with a regular mouse, and they’re handy, so you don’t have to hunting for how to do some of the basic clicks, like a right click. But even looking up the function isn’t all that onerous because the instruction booklet contains a little chart that I just kept next to my monitor for the first couple of weeks using this.

In Windows 11 (I can’t speak for any other version), the sensitivity is just one of many things you can personalize, but I found the default medium senitivity setting to be perfect. I can hover my fingers over the pad without it interpreting that as a click of some sort. In fact, the default settings were all pretty intuitive, so I didn’t change anything other than the pointer speed, which I like faster than normal. I think this is a good product, and I certainly recommend it, whether or not you’ve used trackpads in the past. Just know that if you haven’t, it will take some time to get used to using this instead of a mouse, but you may find it worth the effort.

The overall score had one star knocked off because it’s not the best ergonomics. Indeed, after using only the trackpad for a couple of weeks, I had to get a new ergonomic mouse because my carpal tunnel was threatening to act up again. Note, however, that has everything to do with individual setup in terms of things like height of your chair versus height of where the trackpad is located. My computer desk is such that I had to bend my wrist too much using the trackpad. But if it had been set up where I was higher than normal with respect to the trackpad, I doubt I would’ve had a problem.

title: a lot of good features, but over priced
text:
I bought this because of some of the features which are unique. I like to build small efficient computers, but some cases are just too small. This one is just right. I have two NVme drives and a SATA SSD and it still runs cool. I'm using a Gigabyte Aorus B550i with a Ryzen 5 5600G. I don't play games but do some design and photo work.
Things I like:
4 USB3.0 ports in front.
Tall enough to allow decent airflow and space for easy assembly. I have used smaller cases which are a real pain to assemble.
The side/top cover could easily be replaced with acrylic instead, or even add a spacer to raise lid for more space.
You can use it horizontally or vertically.
Plenty of ventilation.

Things that need improvement:
The red drive LED is not visible as it arrived. The red led can be bent so the tip is near the flange of the white power switch ring, about 45 degrees away from the circuit board. Then you will at least see some flashing though the white outer ring--kind of dim but visible. They could have drilled a tiny hole for the red led and it would have shown through the front panel. Or used a dimmer LED for power on, perhaps just using a larger resistor or lower lumen LED. What were they thinking (if even)?
My cover had a ding near one of the countersunk screws. It must have been hit with a drill chuck or other tool. The corner was slight bent because of that. However, it was not something I would return it over. I just accepted it. Nevertheless, the pricing does not fit with manufacturing errors of this sort.
What are all those 9 pin delta cutouts on the back for? I did use an XT60 male connector near the PCIe slot for mounting a high amperage DC connector for my Geetech 250W PSU and external 250W LED driver. So that was okay. But that area could have had a slot for a low profile PCIe single slot video card. There is no way I would have used a two slot card mounted overhead. That would have added a lot of heat and may have required more power.

title: Huge upgrade from last projector
text:
Me and my wife bought a $40 project to use in our bedroom since we couldn't hang a TV up. It was the little yellow and white box one that you see most commonly marketed as a mini projector. It did the job but we had some complaints. It was noisy, the picture quality was ok at best and the system did not come with any integration, only phone mirroring. We quickly found out that phone mirroring didn't work with Netflix as it would block the picture, so we were forced to use an old Roku that we had. After about 9 months that ones fan finally gave out and we threw the system out.

I decided since we were getting a new one and we had been using it a lot that this would be a nice upgrade, but I am so happy with this. Some things to take into mind: I was upgrading from a $40 projector so I might be biased since this is leaps and bounds better.

Picture Quality: great, the projection size is very large, and the picture quality is crisp. Most the time we are watching in a dark room so I can't say much about the brightness, but from my experience I have no issues there. It does say it comes with autofocus, I never really got it to work but I can focus it fine without it.

Noise: Very good. My last one was very noisy, and we had to keep the volume of the speaker we hooked up to it at 100% to overcome this noise consistently. This one we keep the speaker about 50-60% and are more than happy with it. Even when running it for 3-4 hours at a time we will forget the noise is even there.

Android integration: This is the only place where this system might lose a point. To be fair there isn't many projectors with integration within this price range, so the choices are limited. But this one is a little laggy on response time. Some apps are worse than others for sure. Netflix has about a 1/2 sec delay on the remote where Crunchyroll has about 1.5-2 sec delay. Overall, it doesn't make it unusable, but it can be annoying at times.

TLDR: Good picture quality, good brightness, relatively quite fan, android integration is usable but can be laggy.

title: Amazing Earbuds
text:
These Are Amazing Earbuds!

Now, I've had a few earbuds in the past, but these are Hands Down the Best I've ever had. Let's start with the sound quality. You can get some pretty decent sound from a cheap set of earbuds. But what you can't get is sound that seems to track your movement giving you a True feeling of 360 degree sound. Meaning, not only does your music sound better, but if you have them connected to a TV or other movie watching device You'll have an Excellent movie watching experience.

Speaking of that... While watching a YouTube video, I got a phone call. Usually, my other headphones or buds would stop the sound from the video in favor of the call. But with These, the video sound kept playing, but at a lower volume that my call, meaning I could enjoy both without any loss of quality.

Speaking of quality... Let's discuss fit. For Me... Fit is very important. So much so, I went back to headphones because I couldn't get a good fit on previous earbuds. It gets really frustrating when you have to spend so much time trying to keep an earbud in place. They fall out, lose sound quality because they won't stay in right and just didn't seem to work well for me.

With These earbuds, that's a thing of the past. Once you get them in right, they Stay right! I mean, you can jump, twist and shake your head all you want, they just stay put. No more adjusting and readjusting, they stay right there. Not only That, but they are Comfortable! After a short while, you hardly feel them anymore, meaning you can go the whole day long without discomfort.

Speaking of the whole day. The battery life is just as amazing. You wouldn't expect something this small, that sounds this good to last so long. But you should be able to get 5 hours or more out of them, not to mention that (some Samsung phone users) can charge these with their phone.

There's also the ability to locate lost buds as well.

All N All, I'd have to say that these are an Amazing pair of Earbuds, Well worth the price.

title: Doesn't work with Mac Studio Ultra computer
text:
I bought this "avedio links 8K HDMI 2.1 Switch, Ultra HD 4K@120Hz Bi-Directional Switcher 2 in 1 Out, HDMI Splitter 1 in 2 Out (Single Display) Support High Speed 48Gbps 8K@60Hz for PS4/PS5, Xbox Series X".

I tried using this with my Apple Mac Studio Ultra computer. I have Monoprice Premium Certified cables, 4K@60Hz/HDR/18Gbps/28AWG/YUV4:4:4. One plugs into my Mac, the other into my Denon AVR-X3600H 4K receiver, the third into my LG 4K monitor. The cables are short.

However, this HDMI switch doesn't quite work; it *almost* works. It will produce an image on the monitor and from the Denon, but both have scan line problems. Especially if I move the mouse around on the screen quickly. So the little box is struggling. All of the cables work fine connected directly to the computer.

The HDMI switch itself is very small, with 2 HDMI ports on one side, 1 HDMI port on the other side, and a USB-A to USB-C cable for power. The switch has the USB-C connector. The push button switches between "1" and "2" as indicated with little lights.

I have tried another unit previously (GANA) that didn't have power and it didn't produce an image. At least this Avedio unit produces *an* image. So I think that having the power port is indeed important for this kind of switch with Macs.

I really wanted this unit to work but it isn't quite up to the task.

Scott

Edit: I received several email messages from the company and they were very eager to assist in addressing the problem. We weren't able to get it to work with my Mac and in googling around I suspect that the problem is with the Mac. Regardless, the company indicated that they are releasing a new produce soon which might address the problem. I was very happy with the willingness and responsiveness of the company and I look forward to their updated product.

title: Packs a lot of features at an entry price. Some bugs at release but the WiiM Team is working on it.
text:
So i may be oversimplifying but if you need an Audio Streaming Platform at a reasonable price that support most, if not all the services both paid, free and from local/private file hosting this unit most likely does it.

I could list all the features and inputs, outputs but you already know about that as its listed on the product description, i can say that the experience is near perfect within the limitations of the product and what i mean by that is that if you enjoy music, and need it to stream it to an amplifier and whatever is beyond there, you can expect a very good audio quality and a seamless streaming experience this will do it very well.

You may notice that i put some minor hesitation on every one of my statements, but it's not because i am not happy with the equipment, once they stomp on all the bugs it'll be exactly what i need, but by saying that is what i need doesn't mean it's the best available.

The DAC chip (Burr-Brown PCM5121) has 106 dB SNR, not very good for today's standards in paper, but to be honest more than enough for my, and probably 85% of entry, mid level audiophiles.

The software interface is very easy and intuitive to use, but the firmware has a couple of issues. There is crackling/noise sometimes while using the SPDIF out when a song starts, and the Chromecast over bluetooth doesn't work (WiFi, from YouTube Music to Chromecast then Paired Bluetooth Speakers) but WiiM responded quackly over their forums to let me know they were aware and added to the Known Issues and promised to fix it in future firmware updates.

Overall, i know that it may sound that i had a cautious review, but i think it's a 5 star product and that once the couple of bugs are polished (i know that the crackling is firmware fixable as it's a digital output, and the chromecast over bluetooth pairing is as well) then this would be exactly what i've been asking for, i have a set of 2 amplified speakers and a subwoofer plugged to it and it's a joy to use and listen, also that the dev. team is responsive and fixing the issues means that this is a company with future, recommended!

title: Comfortable and Full-Sized with Nice Features
text:
This is a full-sized keyboard and I find it more comfortable to type on than a laptop keyboard. The design reminds me of an Apple product. This was plug and play with my Linux system as any keyboard should be. The bluetooth option connected very quickly on an Android tablet. The 'Alt' key doubles as a 'Cmd' key for Mac users and there is an Option key that doubles as a 'Win' (or menu) key for Windows, Linux, BSD, etc.

What I Like:
1. Full Sized
2. Wireless
3. Large Backspace key. This makes it easy to correct my mistakes without having to look at the keyboard.
4. The lights go off after a period of time of non use. An example is the Num Lock light doesn't stay on if the keyboard hasn't been used for few minutes and will turn back on when a button is pressed. This is a nice battery saving feature.
5. Can be connected to 2 different Bluetooth devices. Switching back and forth is as easy as pushing one of the 2 Bluetooth buttons on the keyboard. This allowed me to type on 2 different devices without having to disconnect from one device to allow the other to connect. For example: BT1 -> Android Device, BT2 -> PC. Depending on which device I wanted to type on, I press the corresponding BT button to autoconnect then just start typing.

What Could Be Improved:
1. No angle adjustment. I prefer more angle to my keyboard when typing. This has some but not as much as I am accustomed to. It is definitely better than a laptop keyboard that has no angle at all.

Some Things to Note:
1. I have the media keys set up as secondary in my laptop's BIOS with the F1-F12 given primary selection. This keyboard didn't honor those settings and used the media keys as the primary option.

Final Thoughts:

I like the feel of this keyboard, the size and the colors. I find I am able to focus more quickly on the letters on this keyboard with white keys and black text than on my other keyboard that is black with white letters.

title: Kinda spendy but awfully pretty, can work on 96%/1800 style layout keyboards
text:
Looks wise they're fantastic to me. Colors, text, feel, etc are all very personal but to me they're fantastic for the most part.

The pics are pretty much spot on for how they look.

Feel wise they have a fairly smooth but still some how soft touch to them. You can very clearly feel the edges but they're not sharp on my fingertips at least. They have a relatively muted sound when typing too for some reason. I like that but not everyone will.

The lighting through the sides of the keycaps is pretty decent. There is some minor tint shift going on but its something I have to closely look at while at typing distance to notice so it doesn't bother me.

I can't speak to their durability long term but to echo others the outer material is indeed soft compared to other keycaps. I don't have long fingernails so I don't think it'll be issue for me but it could be for others. I was able to put a scratch in one with my finger nail by pressing moderately hard on it.

All the keycaps are of the proper height and appear to be identical in terms of shape.

I have a 96%/1800 style keyboard (Keychron Q5) and this set does indeed fill all the holes size wise. I did have to put 2 different color keycaps on different rows though (the PAGE UP and HOME keys) which is a minor bummer to me. But finding a keycap set like this at all for 1800 layout is tough so I was willing to put up with it. Nothing else out there at the time of this review comes even close looks and feature wise to what this keycap set will for the money.

The softness combined with the high-ish price of near $40 at the time of this review are why I knocked a star off. For that price they should be pretty much perfect in everyway IMO.

There are some $100+ keycap sets that appear to be slightly better in terms of durability, lighting tint, and 96%/1800 comparability with similar looks and features to this one floating around the web but that is waay too much for me to justify buying. YMMV

title: Goodbye, Dust! Hello, Electric Dust Mover!
text:
You can't actually say "Goodbye, Dust" with an electric dust blower, because it just moves the dust to somewhere else. Fortunately, this Musotica Electric Air Duster offers the option of using a tiny vacuum to scoop it up for proper disposal. But you can say "goodbye" to those compressed air dusters in a can with the little plastic straw at the top. The type that gets crazy cold in your hand before you've finished using it.
I took the opportunity of looking at other reviews for this product. At least two of them are immensely thorough. What's the saying? They took the words right out of my my mouth.
The duster had been partially charged when I received it. I assume it retained a charge after quality control testing. I charged it to full capacity before using it to clean around my electrical equipment, under my keypad (of course), and various other areas around the house that are difficult to access for dusting. This is where a power duster such as this comes in handy, because vacuuming isn't really possible. I tried testing the little vacuum in my car and garage and concluded that it's probably not intended for that; besides, we have other wired vacuums that far more powerful, with a much larger capacity and unlimited running time.
I do like the dust blower. Not so much the vacuum, although some potential buyers may have a better use for it than I do.
I included a photo of the instruction "manual," front and back, which could definitely be improved by the seller. I also included a photo of the back of the box, which provides some technical information.
I know I'll be using this product in the days to come, and I am pleased to have it. At its highest air-blowing setting, it began to hurt my ears. Obviously, it's not as loud as a leaf blower, but I felt I should warn you if you have sensitive hearing. Wear ear plugs. This dust blower is worth the mild inconvenience.
If you scroll down on the Amazon page for this product, you'll find dozens more blowers and combo duster/vacuums similar to this one. Look under "4 Stars and Above" and "More From Frequently Bought Brands." The price on this one seems competitive. Nevertheless, be sure to comparison shop.

title: Defective/Sketchy build quality for the price.
text:
I've had my pair for maybe 6 months or so. They got regular use, but handled with care. For whatever reason though lately I have a hard time triggering the right side to activate when getting pulled from the charger box and placed on my ear, which has become a more frequent issue with time.

Really aggravating when I go out of my way to make sure both sides are on the charger prongs correctly. And often the earbud will be fully charged, but for some reason it simply will not activate on the first attempt out of the box. I don't get it. Pressing the buttons on it won't shock it awake either. Not sure if there's any other way to wake them up besides pulling them from the charger prongs in the charger box, but if that's the case also very annoying.

I haven't even used them to work out with (over the ear is better for the noise), so no issue of sweat build up despite them supposedly being sweat resistant. So there's no way they've been damaged by moisture or really anything else.

A couple of days ago, they simply refused to do their jobs despite the fact that I knew they were fully charged, and I could hear what sounded like faint static in place of where my music was supposed to be coming from my 4 month old iphone.

The sound is just okay. In a lot of noisy environments it feels like it could have more oomph.

I think they're relatively comfortable and sturdy for extended wear over the span of a day. Probably the best aspect along with the battery life, which can probably get the average person through an entire day without a charge. Only all-day/heavy listeners would need a charging break. And they charge at a decent speed, although I've never paid close attention. They just always seem ready to go when I need them (well... the battery anyway).

Overall, for the price (I got mine when they were indeed $250, ugh) I kinda regret the purchase. Could maybe expect these kind of behaviors after a year and a half of frequent, heavy-handed/careless handling or from a sub $100 set, but just half a year handled with care and they're acting like this... either defective or cheap parts. Be warned.

title: Nice upgrade for older Fire Sticks
text:
I recently got a new Fire TV Stick 4K that came with one of the new third gen remotes. When I saw this new remote, I really wanted to try it with my older Fire Stick, since it has the extra buttons that I really like. This replacement remote is slightly longer and thicker than the original Amazon remote. A red silicone cover is included that fits perfectly, but it is hard to get on and off, making the changing of batteries a challenge. Every button is the same, except for the bottom 2 streaming services. The new remote has Disney + and Hulu instead of Direct TV and Peacock that is on the original. I actually prefer Disney and Hulu, and the buttons are not programmable, at least not easily. The plastic used in the new remote is not as good as the original, but the fit and finish are good, and there are no sharp corners or misalignments. The batteries go in separate compartments, as opposed to the single compartment in the original.
To pair with my Fire Stick, I went into the setup menu and navigated to the Controllers and Bluetooth Devices, Amazon TV Remote, then Add New Remote. From there, I pressed the home button on the new remote for 10 seconds until a yellow LED on the new remote started flashing. The Fire Stick found the new remote, and asked to press the Select button on the old remote to confirm. After that the new remote was connected, and I tried every button, which all worked perfectly. There doesn’t seem to be any lag between the button presses and command execution on the Fire Stick. I also have a Fire TV Recast, so the button to access the guide is a must have. The voice feature also works as advertised, and there are no differences in functionality between the replacement and original remotes. The included cover for the remote is handy, but it does change the feel of the buttons, making them go from raised to sunken. It takes some getting used to, and since it is red, it makes finding the remote somewhat easier.
Overall, this is a great replacement for any Fire Stick owner, especially the ones with the older style remotes. It is pricey though, since you can practically get a whole Fire Stick with the remote, like during Prime Day, for what is being charged here. It will not work with the first gen Fire Sticks, so make sure you check before ordering.

title: Holy Molyyyyyy!
text:
For under 50 bux? I don't know how they do it. I consider myself a budget audiophile. I've owned/own countless amps, AVRs, DACs, amps, speakers, subs, etc. I'm always experimenting, swapping EQ and speakers always chasing the perfect sound (to my wife's disdain). When I opened the brown box and saw the Kguss box, my first impression was wow, that's impressive. Well, it didn't stop there.
Let me digress and state that I'm using this little beauty connected to my PC via aux port in a nearfield application.
Upon opening the Kguss box, I was also impressed with the packing and presentation. The attention to detail is top notch. Build quality is superb. Aluminum body with aluminum KNURLED knobs. The knurling on the knobs is perfect, rougher on the volume, finer on the bass/treble controls. Large rubber feet on the bottom. The power supply is even labeled with the brand. These details add to manufacture cost. Knobs turn smoothly and very nice binding posts on the back.
Lets get to the sound. Well, to make a long story short, this thing kicks booty. Highs are airy and bright, mids pack a nice punch and bass is clean and ample. Detail and clarity are remarkable. I was a bit concerned since my previous amps that I was using were connected via optical cable, and going to analog, I was thinking I would lose some fidelity. Boy, was I wrong. Icing on the cake is that this amp is 4ohm stable. Bluetooth connected easily and sounded just as good as analog.
The only improvement I could suggest to make this little beast better would be to add a subwoofer pre-out. But no worries, if your subwoofer has high level inputs, then you're golden.
Performing an amazon search for Kguss, it looks like, Kguss is a sister company of another VERY highly rated audio company, which then made sense regarding the quality is this amp. Again, for under 50 bux, I don't know how they do it. I have a feeling that once word gets out on these, they will sell out, or the price will go up, so get this while you can at this price. You will not be sorry.

title: The unit itself is excellent mounted on the cheapest made holder.
text:
The unit components are excellent, but the body mount is TRASH AND CHEAP.
I've owned the unit now for 9 month I've had to replace the batteries already 3 times.
every time you unmount the unit and mounted there are 4 plastic l shape post that holds the unit.
This Sunday I change the batteries and surprise after a grand total of 8 times. using 4 new batteries and the unit would not relink to the system I deleted the camera three times during the times and nothing.
I called the so call 24/7 customer service and after 10 MINUTES of waiting and no one coming online I filled the customer service e form for assistance, I received back an email with the hours the individual worked and he would need my camera name and serial number, this had been already provided on my request with PICTURE I was also told to set the privacy and security to allow him to get in the system.
Late the next day I had not been recontacted and I needed the system on as I need a doorbell, so I remounted it and notice the one of the L shape pones cracked and three left.
the next day I took a multimeter and checked my batteries (NEW) voltage:
4 were 1.49V
1 was 1.5V
1 was 1.48V
I took my batteries case and took one also that was 1.5V now with those two I went ahead unmounted the unit and placed the 1.5 batteries, surprise after re resetting to factory specs it came online.
the unit then read on the app REPLACE BATTTERIES, the "instructions" tell you to remove the batteres and rein install them which h I did 5 times to no effect.
I wrote again to customer service and of course no answer.
Now my camera is hold by 2 plastic lacking straps as the holders were junk and broke, and no I worked in the Air Force with MICRO devices and know how to care for weak IE: plastic mount.
Of course, they don't have it, but I would give the customer service a zero star.
The mount ZERO star.
The requirement of batteries to be exactly 1.5Volts Zero stars.
Battery consumption no even 1 star

title: Great headphones, as described.
text:
[[VIDEOID:876c0b51b546ebcd9e5b9c41119649b3]] There headphones are great overall, they function and look as described on the listing.

They have all the features typical of this design with two variations: 1) they have physical volume buttons on each headphone, which is nice because you don't have to remember as many cues for the main button, but it is hard to grab the out of the case without pressing the vol buttons.
2) the case has a USB output so you can actually charge your phone from it, in addition to having the normal USB-C input to charge it with.

Other than that, they fit my ear the same way all of the over-ear types do. I have small ears, so they are a little bit big, but they still feel very secure. Also, they come with three sizes of ear cushions, a USB to USB-C cable, and an instruction manual. The smallest ear cushion (is that what they are called?) fit in my ears well, and feels a bit smaller and more comfortable than some other brands I've tried. So when I wore these for a couple of hours my ears didn't hurt which is a great plus.

These survived my workout pretty well and seem to handle sweat well, and felt very secure through my jumping and running around. The sound quality is great, they play much louder than other earbuds I have bought before, and the noise cancelling works well.

The case shows it's charge and the charge of each headphone when you put them back in it, which is nice. They did position them opposite in the case though, so you have to grab the left ear's earbud out of the right side of the case. This is mildly annoying to me, but other people might not mind it at all. Also, the case itself is bigger than some other brands, possibly because of the USB output, but it has a nice velvety texture that is common and still fits in the pocket of my leggings, so it doesn't bother me at all.

So overall, getting them out of the case can feel a little bit clumsy sometimes, but they are great headphones and worth it for the sound quality. Looking forward to more color options!

title: Excellent for hands-free calling
text:
Lately I've been on the phone a lot more than I want to be, and I needed a better solution for hands-free calling. I have an assortment of headsets, but they all have issues with mic quality and lack of comfort. With these Ankbit E600 headphones, I've finally found a workable solution.

These softly-padded over-the-ear headphones are comfortable, even over my glasses. The cups are a good size for my ears, and present a lower profile than some over-the-ear headphones. The instructions advise taking them off "every 1-2 hrs to get your ears to relax and protect them from the muggy environment," which I do instinctively. It does get "muggy" in there.

The mic is fantastic! It's the best headset mic I've used. Callers say my voice sounds very natural. It's bendable so I can place it where it captures my voice without being in the way. The only negative thing is that it sometimes picks up surrounding sounds that my phone mic doesn't, like when someone asked if I was filing my nails. (Yes, I was.) I like that the mic is detachable, but I'm careful where I leave it because it's small and easy to lose.

I'm not using it for music, so sound-wise all I can judge is how it works for phone calls. The answer is: great! Callers sound natural, like they're in the room with me. Actually, it's better than when they're in the room with me, because the headphones minimize outside noises so all I hear is the voice, without distractions. That's a good thing for aging ears like mine.

The Bluetooth paired easily with my Pixel phone (no dongle), and connects quickly when I get a call. The range is good - I can set my phone down and walk anywhere in the house or outside within 40' and still get signal.

The battery life is adequate. Using the headphones for a few hours a week brings them down to 80%. The only way I've found to keep tabs on how much juice is left is on my phone's Bluetooth connection message.

Small issues like that aside, I'm very happy with these Ankbit Pro Bluetooth headphones for my hands-free calling.

title: Surprisingly Good. Battery Lasts, Easy to Hand Charge, Radio/Flashlight Work Well.
text:
This replaces an old RadioShack emergency radio we had. Remember RadioShack? Yea, that's how old it was plus 10 years more. A replacement was in order.

I tested this several ways:
A) Battery.
1) Does NOT charge with a PD charger. You need a non-PD, 5V 1A charger
2) It takes several hours to charge fully (all 4 light solid on) from empty - it is shipped mostly charged.
3) There are 4 charge indicator lights. They go from 1 to 3 lights lit in a few minutes: the 4th light flashes for a long time before stopping
4) The battery will power the flash light about ~5 hours before it's too faint to be of any use
5) 10 manual cranks will charge it so that you have flashlight for about ~3 minutes.
6) USB A Charging port for other devices is 5V 1A only (tested working)

B) Radio:
1) Solid pickup of local AM, FM and Weather-band stations for the area.
2) Stronger stations didn't need the antenna, but the antenna does increase station strength
3) Sounds like a transistor radio so don't look for audiophile frequency response
4) Volume turns on/off radio; volume can go very loud

C) Flash Light:
1) Very bright, blueish white.
2) On/Off only, no dimming function

D) Alarm:
1) Actually pretty loud and annoying.

Pros:
+ light and compact
+ Crank charging works very well
+ good overall functionality (flashlight, radio, alarm signal)
+ good battery life
+ Radio works well

Cons:
- Charging lights are at best misleading. Shouldn't go from empty to 3 lights in a few minutes then take hours for the 4th light to stop flashing
- Would be so much better with PD charging

Overall, it's a very good emergency flashlight/radio that seems to be reliable.

title: Silly Great NearField Desktop Speakers
text: Yes I have these literally 2' to 3' in front of my face at my desk. Mainly because I have no space in my office/bedroom. I'm breaking these in from 50 to 500 hours as some have suggested. What paper cones do, and JBL uses them almost exclusively, is for purity of tone. Why use synthetic but some like that muddy sound for a more relaxing experience. This speaker separates everything and with the air suspension design I think it's more nimble and less boomy bass. It's a rock and roll east coast sound in the bas department however it's well defined like most modern speakers and monitors provide. It's a hybrid old school with a touch of modern refinement.  I wonder because all the original reviews said these were $2,000 retail so why are they all now $2,500? That's a massive jump. I bought mine like new used likely tested and returned but I couldn't tell they had ever been opened. Someone literally stated that without 500 hours of breakin you wouldn't even know how they sound. Well if they get better that's awesome. You have to admit that after a while boomy bass is the most annoying thing on the planet. It's fun for a moment but gets old fast. Accurate bass is really pleasing for hours or listening. Smooth, clean, toneful an accurate. This can do both but it's not going to rattle the windows. I listen to music as I work near my face so my head is almost inside the 10" cone but also at low volume most of the time. It's really nice but might be even better back about 8'. I probably have the largest desktop speakers in history with these. I only have an Ican pre-amp and main amp Cambridge 80 watts. I can switch to tube inside the Ican if I want a little less clean energy but it seems to prefer clean solid state energy. Many people have commented concerning which amp but I don't have an amp collection. 80 Watts seems to drive it fine. UPDATED: Here's a cool thing I discovered. I order a different KLH grille and you can add additional grilles directly over each other whatever matches the season or decor. So these speakers are toms/guitar/voice brilliant without bloated bass. Put on some Fogerty "Centerfield" and sit back and drool.  Sounds like the band is in your room.

title: I love this keyboard A Normal Amount™️
text:
I was admittedly feeling a bit dubious in getting a foldable keyboard at first, but it has been fantastic! I'll be real honest; I got this lil' baby keyboard so I can write erotica at work without using work machines, and it's been frankly impressive!
This keyboard has a fantastic battery life; I haven't had it die on me yet, and I work 11h shifts. The size is very convenient, and since it folds, I don't have to worry about the keys catching on something in my bag and pulling off. The scissor switches feel nice enough. I don't prefer scissor switches in general, so I'm a little biased in that aspect, but they feel like a high quality laptop keyboard. They're pretty quiet as well, which is great.
It is real damn sturdy too! I accidentally spilled hot tea on it a couple weeks ago, and I let it air dry for a few days before turning it back on-- it works as if I never doused it in pu'erh! I was so worried the tea would do it in, but this little keyboard keeps on going!!
Since it's so much smaller than a standard keyboard, it does take some getting used to when typing on it, but I adjusted pretty quick. I added my iPad & a pen for scale in the photos, and in the background you can see a standard size keyboard for comparison as well.
It connects quickly and smoothly to my iPad, Pixel 6a, and Windows desktop with ease. There was one small blip where it wasn't connecting with my iPad after the accidental tea-drowning, but it connected to my other devices just fine, and after forgetting & re-pairing the keyboard, it hasn't had a single issue since. My iPad has had some intermittent connectivity issues as well, so it very well could have been my old iPad acting up instead of the keyboard.
My one and only very, *very* minor complaint would be that it goes to sleep pretty quickly-- which I'm sure is great for battery life retention but can be a little annoying when I'm editing and it falls asleep on me often. A quick tap on any key wakes it up immediately though, so like I said, a very insignificant, nitpicky complaint.
Overall, it's not flashy, but I've been sincerely impressed by it!

title: Front bezel broke off
text:
First impression was that this was really well made.
Second impression- not so well made.
When I tightened the back nut down the front bezel plate came off. The glue that holds it on just wasn't very strong.
I returned and opted for a replacement, but the replacement is like a month off for delivery.
Will update when I get the replacement.

UPDATE: When I put in for a replacement it showed that the replacement was over a month away from delivery, but I needed the part so I had to order it. In the meantime I searched for the same type of part and finally found one that I could get in a few days instead of a month away so I ordered it. There was no option to cancel the replacement so I figured I would return both the original and the replacement when it got here. Shouldn't be a problem, right? The original was to be returned to Whole Foods so the replacement was going to go to the same place, right? Nope.
The replacement came in a week earlier than expected so I submitted for a return. I had already set up for the original to be returned to Whole Foods, but Amazon wanted the replacement to be returned to a UPS drop off center which meant that I would have to drive across town to a UPS drop off center, then drive to a whole foods which isn't near a drop off center to return this part. What a pain. Called Amazon and, even though these were from the exact same place, Amazon wouldn't budge on the return. Had a very long discussion and waited on hold but Amazon decided that it was better to have a UPS driver come out and pick up the part (sometime within the week but not a definite day or time because UPS doesn't do that) instead of letting me take both parts (that are being returned to the same people at the same place) to Whole Foods.
So, overall, the replacement does look like it would have worked but I decided to not leave my truck dismantled for weeks on end and found a better option. I wish I could have used this in a different project to avoid the hastle, but it is what it is. Wish Amazon would have let me return it to Whole Foods, then this would have been easily completed. Now I have to put this out on my porch each day and hope UPS comes to pick it up.

title: An interesting product
text:
An interesting product, so I gave a try since the price would be ok if it works as advertised. Actually, I like it and it does the job advertised. it boots up faster than expected, connect and tied well with my phone using apple car play. didn't notice any audio delay and Netflix, youTube, etc.. all good but becomes unstable time to time. Maybe this is only for my own experiences but a few problems I encountered are...
1. comes with a manual but not user-friendly at all. However, there are good YouTube reviews explaining how to xxx like mirroring your phone, split screen, app icon arrangement, even language and time format settings.
2. no gps signal from built-in waze/google map. sometimes waze app got stuck with this message even in downtown LA area. After changing GPS from BOX to Car, it's still happening but less than BOX setting. Also randomly stuck at updating traffic info xx% frequently. If changed to apple carplay, it just works.
3. forced switching between Wi-Fi hotspot and cellphone connection while using built in AA and ACP. initially I thought this was broken feature but only one connection is allowed unless you use network sim card with the box.
4. some of built-in APP like netflix is not updatable through google playstore; I believe OTTOCast advertised like you can install any app from app store. hmm... OTTOCAST support said the box needs to be factory-reset when the built-in app needs to be reinstalled/refreshed. Not sure if this applies to all built-in apps or just some of them.
5. Apps freeze intermittently when switching one from the others in split screen mode. Hopefully this will be fixed either my replacement or next firmware update if there's any.

Anyway, the problems still happen after recommended factory reset, so I requested a replacement through amazon. Why didn't I just go with return? Hmm, I still like its features. But if my replacement has the same problems, I don't think that is fair for its price tag. one more thing, after factory reset you will see an message liek 'Device not activated'. I don't know what it means but it was gone either completing initial setup or running waze after connecting wifi. good luck!

title: small size, adequate cooling
text:
Two 120mm fans will only push as much air as 2 120mm fans, and these aren't amazing fans to begin with. most laptop coolers just stuff more fans in, but the LIENS doesn't have that luxury--at half the cost of other coolers and the form factor of a chubby 14-inch laptop, a lot of sacrifices had to be made. considering this, is it still a compelling product? Yes.

I bought one of these years ago to cool the infamously spicy Razer Blade 15. I wanted something cheap and small enough to fit in a backpack with the laptop for travel. The LIENS has survived 3 Razers now and continues to do its job well.
Cooling is adequate. It never prevented throttling but roughly tripled the time it took for each laptop to heat soak, enough for top-level performance in a short gaming session. During sustained productivity loads, the LIENS was able to keep up with each laptop's i7--without it, they would eventually throttle.
Noise has been minimal. these aren't silent fans but they're quieter than many laptop fans, and I can't imagine most people having an issue with them. there's a moderate amount of soft blue lighting on the chasse that can be turned down with a scroll wheel, but as far as RGB goes, it's pretty unobtrusive.
Durability has been a bit of an issue. the manufacturing was fine, especially at this price point, but the plastic used is simply not as strong as my partner's foot. the LIENS uses a U-shaped foot with a metal prop, but the foot is particularly thin. on one occasion, the foot snapped in the middle and on another, the pegs that hold the foot to the chasse sheared off on one side. in both cases I was able to repair it with superglue, but this simply isn't a product you can beat up. Outside of that, nothing has gone wrong.

The cost is minimal, cooling is good enough for most uses, and durability is just adequate. if you need a no-nonsense cooler for a small laptop but don't want to spend much or haul around one of the RGB monstrosities that are larger then 17in laptops, the LIENS has you covered.

title: Installed without a hitch and bumped up my wifi speeds
text:
Quick background, I used this on an ancient 12 year old Windows 7 machine with USB 2.0 ports -- this is a machine so old it doesn't even have the ability to recognize 5GHz signals. Wifi speeds on this relic hovered around 4 mbps up and down -- SLOWWWW -- when my phone hits over 300 mbps right next to it. On the bright side, my ancient PC....being as old as it is....has a CD to install the TP-Link driver software, which I think would be a big problem for using these external wifi adapters on newer machines. Who has a CD drive anymore?

I tried this and the slightly less expensive TP-Link AC1300 USB WiFi Adapter(Archer T3U). This one gives about 80 mbps down and 20 mbps up, and the less expensive T3U gave about 50 down and 15-18 mbps up. For the nominal extra cost, I went with this one.

So, what to make of this. On the one hand, the speeds with these wifi adapters are nowhere close to what's being pumped out. However, the fault is almost certainly the creaky USB 2.0 and not the adapters, which are still yielding vastly faster connections than I had before.

Again, installation was a breeze that took all of 3 minutes -- I hooked up the adapter, popped in the CD, ran the driver, and voila. Actually, one additional step I did that you'll probably also have to, I went into the device driver and disabled the internal wifi card or the system would have continued defaulting to that. So, add another minute -- 4 minutes total. Easy. So far, connections have been stable.

If space is an issue you might go with the T3U, the performance difference.... at least on my system.... was negligible. But when your speeds are as slow as mine, any increase is worth it.

UPDATE: I don't know why because I have changed no settings anywhere, but download speeds have consistently increased to about 200 mbps down and 30-40 mbps up. Also worth noting is that wifi connects instantly when PC wakes up from sleep mode. All in all, very pleased -- zero glitches, fast speeds given the limits of my system, painless install. Highly recommend.

title: Great monitor with some headaches
text:
pros: As responsive as IPS can get (for now), good colors, decent HDR, bright, the only 1440p 360 hz monitor (for now), overall good build quality, nvidia reflex latency analyzer and dedicated g-sync module

cons: Price, strange bugs, gamer design on the back is lame. 360hz is great, but you really need to look at the games you play to figure out if you can utilize it.

Reasons I bought this monitor: I was upgrading from the first rog swift (pg278q). I considered the M27Q-X which is 1440p 240hz but those are mostly out of stock at the moment and the only options were used with inflated prices. I considered the pg27aqdm, but OLED burn in is a deal breaker for me considering I will also be working on this computer and many of the games I play have static huds that will 100% burn in less than a year. The Alienware 27 AW2721D was another consideration, but I really despised the outward appearance of the monitor. Finally considered the Neo g8 odyssey for $200 more, but I would rather have 360hz 1440p than 240hz 4k personally, and the g8 has even more reported bugs and issues.

That being said, this monitor does have bugs too. I've gotten it stable again so far, but turning on HDR in games or on windows sometimes makes the monitor turn off and on again occasionally. I experience this maybe once every couple of hours at most, but if HDR is off it never happens at all. Another strange bug happened with HDR when windows turned off the monitor due to inactivity, and when I came back the screen was stuck extremely dim. No settings I changed while it was dim could fix it, but unplugging and replugging the power brick fixed it. Once again, this has only happened once so far and it was when HDR was on. Others have also said disabling G-Sync will fix this problem. As far as I can tell from my research and what others have discussed, it is "an issue with Nvidia's display engine which struggles with DSC".
Overall, your mileage may vary. I have no dead pixels, very little backlight bleed and fairly limited bugs. I would say its otherwise perfect with some driver updates and a price decrease.

title: Great way to start your child out with a smart watch
text:
My daughter has been asking me for both a smartwatch and a phone since she was 6 - she's 9 now. I wanted to make sure she was ready for having something like that, so seeing this watch, I decided to get it for her. This is a great way to start your child out with the responsibility of having a device like this. She would lose her head if it wasn't attached, so getting her a smartphone wouldn't be something she could handle at the moment, but having a watch that is attached to her wrist, could give her the practice she would need to keep track of what she has and, hopefully, help her become prepared for a phone. I got the one that wasn't data ready. The other option would allow you to get a sim card for $6/month to allow for texting and calling features.

Without having the calling and texting features, this little thing still packs a good punch with what it has to offer. There are games, a camera with filter options and the ability to take a selfie or take a picture with the lens that is on the side of the watch, a video feature that does the same as the camera, ability to add and listen to music, an alarm, a flashlight, calculator, and a calendar as well. It's very similar to having a smartwatch that you'd purchase as an adult. The only thing that bothered my kid was the band made her wrist itch, but that's due to the metal of the clasp on the band. I fixed that up for her and she was good to go. If your child is sensitive to metals, you can use clear nail polish and it'll act as a barrier between the metal and the skin. The battery life is contingent upon how often your child plays with the different features. If they're on the games a lot, listen to music, taking pictures/videos, etc., then the battery will last about 6-ish hours. I charge hers every night and it's ready to go in the morning.

For the price, you get quite a bit, especially with the calling and texting features. For $6/month, that isn't a bad deal at all. Overall, this is a great starter smartwatch and it's at a great price. Sure beats the $100+ watches that aren't too kid friendly and may not have all the features that are offered like this one.

title: Alterative to a raspberry pi pc
text:
With the shortage of inexpensive computer options these days ie. Raspbetry Pi's . This comes in as a decent alternative with more potential.

PC seems well built it's compact and small enough to stash on a desk or use the supplied bracket to mount on the back of a monitor. It doesn't have alot for ports, which makes sense for the size. Has 2 usb ports on the front with the power and the rest 2 hdmi, 2 usb, power and audio out back. I do wish that it had at least one usb c since more devices are moving this standard.

Performance is ok and expected for this price range, it's on the lighter side of specs with minimal ram (8gb) and hard drive (256gb) which makes this ok for the basics. I could see this being an ok for a family pc if it's shared for basic stuff.
