The nice thing is that when you take the bottom panel off, you do have the option to swap out hard drive and ram so you can swap for something larger or faster down the road. It has an additional m2 sata slot so but no documentation on it but like that there is option to add some space.

While using it and running updates it seemed responsive maybe not as smooth as a higher end pc but something you won't really notice unless you've had a faster pc. I can see over time this needing a good wipe of the OS as Windows typically does. It does have a fan that tends to want to kick in at random and often, it's not loud almost not noticeable. But the fan profile could use some tuning.

As for the raspberry pi statement. With shortage of cheap pc alternatives and scalping that is on going. For a lil bit more this offer more potential and a full fledge OS.

Overall this is a good inexpensive pc option. If you plan to play video games or more resource intensive programs I would say this probably isn't the best option for that purpose. But if your going for a basics machine or something to have as a research pc in a hobby room or shop this would work great. I'll be swapping out my raspberry pi I currently am using to run Home Assistant with this pc as it allows me to do some other times I plan on doing. And freeing up my raspberry pi for fun projects.

title: All the basic features in a well made easy to use Walkie Talkie!
text:
I got a set to use for communication between our home and a lake about a mile away. It's much easier and more convenient to use walkie talkies than a mobile phone. It's also less painful if stolen while swimming. This set works extremely well for the application. It has all of the basic featuress and adequate range. The basic functions are effective and extremely easy to use. It has the full range of 22 FRS channels and provides for secure call alerts and multiple call tones. The scan feature works well and I like the fact that while scanning you have the ability to instantly change scan direction using the channel up/down buttons. Sound is clear and volume range is more than adequate for outdoor use. The battery can be charged using the AC power supply provided or via a USB-C cable that plugs into the housing. For my application the battery lasts all day (it's mostly in standby). i keep the walkie talkies in the charger when not in use so I'm not certain how long the battery will last on a single charge. The walkie talkies seem well made and durable

As you might expect at such a low price, there are limitations with certain features. For example, Squelch is automatic and not adjustable. There is a monitor button that turns off squech completely while pressed. The weather radio feature is nice, supporting 11 channels. However, I found that reception was a bit spotty and extremely sensitive to antenna orientation. Keeping the monitor button pressed while listening to weather reports does resolve the problem. I also found the weather channel scan feature was extremely difficult to use effectively. It did not stop at active weather channels. You need to press scan at exactly the right time to get it to stop at a desired channel. There doesn't seem to be any way to manually scroll through or select a particular channel. Once you've found a preferred channel and are able to tune to it, there is a memory function so you can return to that channel at any time. It would have been nice to have the Channel Up and Channel Down buttons enable you to select a weather channel but those two buttons are inoperative when listening to weather channels.

In summary, if you're looking for a basic, reasonably priced, well built and durable form of communication, I believe this is a great choice. Nothing fancy, no frills, just reliable and easy so use.

title: Inside was a [bad] Micro SD card
text:
Short version:
It didn't really work until I broke it open and replaced a bad Micro SD card inside.
Long version:
1st - this 128 GB photo stick USB flash drive drive worked when tested with an Android phone, but it was a small file and a short test. No additional app was needed.
2nd - Plugged into an an iPhone which immediately recognized that a drive was inserted and needed an app to navigate the files. The iPhone automatically recommended the "Files" app from Apple. I did not / would not bother with the third party app suggested on the instructions. I did not install any app or perform any more testing on the iPhone for unrelated reasons.
3rd - Connected the USB drive to a Windows 11 computer to test the rated capacity of 128 GB. FWIW, the transfer rates were around 20MB/s.
This is where the failure began. The USB flash drive would consistently lock up after transferring 1+ GB of data. It would lock up hard, and killing the process via task manager didn't always work. I reformatted the drive multiple times, both quick formatting and slow formatting. Tested with the USB-C port, as well as USB-A via the included adapter. I reboot Windows, etc. etc. The flash drive didn't work.
4th - Since it was useless at that point, I took it apart to see what was inside. The housing is a nice metal case and I thought about repurposing it. (if you care, I pressed on the USB-C end and the guts popped out the iPhone end. It took some prying too. Attempt at your own risk.)
5th - Inside was a Micro-SD card labeled 128GB. I replaced the card with an old 8GB card and now it works. ...the case is scratched up from my attempts to open it, but appears to work now with a different SD card inside.
6th - For what it's worth, it also works with Linux.

Summary:
* This appears to work as a very small, overpriced SD card reader with connections for most devices including Mac, Windows, iPhone & Android.
* It did not work out of the box, nor did it function as it was labeled.

Hope this helps!

title: Sufficiently cools Pixelbook
text: Granted my i7 Pixelbook is several years old since it was released in 2017 but I still really enjoy using it and it's still up to the task so until that changes I'll continue keeping it in rotation however one thing that always bothered me was how hot it runs. It's borderline too hot to even touch for more than a second or two without any kind of cooling however this item drastically improves this situation to the point where it's almost not even warm. Granted I modified it slightly so that it sits up higher and isn't sitting flush on top of the fans which I believe helps improve circulation but the end result is nothing short of impressive. The only reason I deducted one star is that my unit came without any kind of power switch and it's very difficult to turn on and off with some sort of crude instrument but if that can be addressed I would gladly change my rating to five stars. To be perfectly honest I may do so anyway because this is such a drastic improvement. I also very much like the aesthetic and the LED lighting is quite nice and much more varied in terms of the RGB output as compared to most of my RGB devices. The other thing that I would have liked to have seen is even a small amount of inability to change the angle but as it's stands and its current form it is completely fixed with zero ability to make any adjustments unless you change the surface that you place it on but this is not always able to be done. Also because of the aforementioned lack of a power switch in the event that My pixelbook is not sitting on the stand the fan slots are pretty exposed and could easily be damaged by something entering into the fan housing area and coming into contact with a fan that's in motion so you really need to be cognizant of that as I would imagine the moment any one of the fans becomes compromised the entire unit would be unusable since if you ever had a fan blade break off of any kind of fan be a PC cooling fan or otherwise you know that it's essentially useless from that point forward and any attempts to fix it only potentially make the situation worse. Most of these besides I mentioned only for the benefit of the manufacturer in case they want to improve the products for future release / updates but I am very happy with it even in its current form without a power switch. Also, the quality of the USB-C to USB-C cable and the USB-C to USB-A adapter is very good.

title: Technically functional, but not what I'd want in a real emegency
text:
The radio works and I can get reception on two NOAA stations and a bare handful of FM. But the features are all just not great. I'd rather have an emergency radio with one or two really functional backup power sources than several that are awful.

Pros:
- It powers on reliably and it does in fact receive weather, SW, FM, and AM. Not well, but I can get a few stations.
- The lights work.
- It can use AA batteries. Which is good since the other power options are terrible.
- The micro USB port means I can charge it off a power bank. Which I'll likely be doing constantly if I don't have AA batteries available.

Cons:
- The lights are barrely worth using. I mean, I have tiny pen lights running on a single AAA that put out more light.
- The solar charger is garbage. It's terrible. I need to hold it up nearly touching a 65 watt flood light before it indicates it's charging at all. Taking it outside on anything but a bright sunny day will be unlikely to get you any real power. How many emergency or disaster scenarios are accompanied by bright sunny days?
- The hand crank is horrible and flimsy. It does charge, but it feels like the handle is going to snap off during each rotation and you literally get fewer minutes of use than you've put in minutes of cranking.
- The built-in battery is TINY. It's 600 mah. I tried leaving the radio running on low volume and only got maybe two hours out of it. In a real emergency you'll likely want your radio to last more than two hours.
- The battery drains almost as fast in NOAA Alert mode as it does in normal operation. Tried it, got just under 3 hours before it died. I thought the alert mode was supposed to conserve power and only kick on if an alert went out. This maybe saves a bit, but not enough to be truly useful.

Overall this is just a toy product that pretends it can do lots of things, but does them all so poorly it's not worth buying. Get yourself a decent rechargable radio with weather functions and a separate power bank with a solar panel on it. That'll be WAY more functional than this thing.

title: decent air blower/vaccum
text:
It's not bad. it can be just annoying to use. and the attachments are not the greatest.

First starting with the positives, its can do a lot of things but it just can't do a lot well. I bought this mainly for cleaning my office and my computer from all the dust that is around in my house. and with all the attachments it was able to get the job done.

Now the things I don't like, first is theirs to many attachments and none of them a great at picking up a single layer of dust, you would think that the tip with the brush on it would work great until you find out that the suction power is reduced a lot once it gets past all those long bristle so all you doing is pushing the dirt.

For the first time if you want to vacuum with it then you will be confused and the instructions are not to clear but there's this plastic cover that get pulled off on the back by 1/4 twist counter clock wise and then you put the vacuum filter on it. All that you are doing is basically operating it backwards and adding a replaceable filter.

I do like the filter unlike other hand vacuums it has a aluminum shell around the filter so bigger particles are stopped. This increase's the life of the filter, but this also kills its efficiency at moving air and makes a restriction inside of it.

I will have to say this is more of an air blower does have design flaws. Like when operating in vacuum mode the air will sometimes blow right to your face. That was driving me nuts.

I do wish that the speed control was a dedicated switch instead of throught quick button/trigger presses so there's less confusion and/or put lights on the back to show speed and battery information.

Final Thoughts
It's not bad blower but its defiantly not a good vacuum. this 2 in one didn't hit all the needs as well as I wanted it will still get the job done but I feel like I could get it done faster if I just had the right attachments and if I wasn't getting blown on by the other side. but for a vacuum I don't recommend it but as a blower it isn't bad not as good as compressed air but can get a lot accomplished.

title: Great for Watchmaking
text:
This microscope exceeded my expectations, especially given the price. I picked up watchmaking as a hobby and was really struggling with loupes/magnifiers. When I saw that affordable digital microscopes were available, I did a bit of research. I ended up choosing this one in particular because it solves the issue most of these cheaper microscopes seem to have. That is, most do not allow you to move the camera far enough away to see the entire object. By lengthening the rail the camera rides on, this microscope is much more useful for my purposes.
As far as the features go, I've been getting a lot of use from the photo/video function. Basically, I record the disassembly of the watch movement. This gives me something to reference in the event I forget how to put it back together. That's been extremely useful while learning the hobby. Beyond that, there are a lot of settings and such for the camera (contrast, sharpness, etc.) but the defaults have worked well enough so far.
In my opinion, the only cons are the built in lights and charging time. The base has two lights built in, with their brightness controlled by a touch bar thing. In order to use them, you have to run an included cable from the screen unit into the base (because the battery is in the screen unit). The issue I have is that I kept activating the touch pad by accident. And, for whatever reason, the lights make an electric humming sound (but only when the brightness is set lower than full, which is weird). I ended up just leaving the base unplugged, because I didn't find it worth the trouble. The other built-in light is a ring light around the lens. This one works fairly well and has four brightness levels (or completely off). A minor problem is that the lights can sometimes be seen on reflective metal parts, but it's not a big deal. For some reason, they included a plastic doo-hickey you can install to completely cover the light. I'm not really sure why since you can just turn the light off. Finally, it takes quite awhile to full charge.
Overall, I'm really happy with my purchase. This scope makes examining parts very simple and a lot more comfortable (as compared to hunching over with a loupe). So, I would definitely recommend this to watchmakers or other hobbyists.

title: superior music delivery device
text:
I own about a half dozen Mp3 players and this one is the priciest.
Compact (about 2 X 4 in.) and comprised of a metal housing, it weighs a little less than my Samsung Galaxy phone. It fits comfortably into shirt or pants pocket. Navigation is very simple with various icons displayed on the full-touch screen. There is a jack for connecting to phones (not provided) or to an external speaker via an Aux cable (not included). Bluetooth pairing is easy, and I was especially glad to link effortlessly to my wireless earbuds. Works well in the car using either Bluetooth or cable.
Sound quality is excellent. There is an equalizer feature that adjusts to music genre, although I’m not convinced that this makes much difference. I play exclusively opera, orchestral and chamber music, and lots of piano recitals, so I chose the “classical” equalizer option. No problems. When the device is linked to my good Bose speaker, the sound, to my ears, is slightly better than that produced by any of my less expensive players. Similarly outstanding results when using high quality headphones.
Comes with 32 gigs of capacity, with the ability to add a TF card (not included). I loaded it with a bunch of full-length operas and there was still lots of room left for more. There is also an Ebook function that produces good readable text.
Oddly enough, the H2 lacks many of the features available from some of the cheaper competition. There is no FM radio connection, no speaker on the device and no WiFi access to things like You-tube or Amazon Music. Admittedly, many Mp3 players lack some or all of these things, but there are those that do indeed come “fully loaded.”
A modest instruction sheet included in the box with directions for accessing online a full user manual. Admirable customer service—I did not get the small velvet carrying bag that should have been included in the package. When I wrote to inquire about this, I got an apology and a free upgraded carrying case—no questions asked!
Overall, a very good player but not inexpensive. While I wish it had some of the missing features listed above, overall it is a handy and superior product that delivers as advertised.

title: Solid Blu-Ray Burner from Pioneer
text:
I have been using this Pioneer BDR-XD08UMB burner for some time now. I love that it is compact, lightweight and ready to use straight away.

Included:
-Manual w/ Cyberlink Media Suite Serial and link where you can download the application
-Burner [duh]
-USB A male to USB C cable male
-USB C male to USB A female

This burner supports CD-R/W DVR-R/W to BD-R [25 GB & 50 GB] and BD-XL [100 GB] discs. I tested a 25 GB and 100 GB discs with this unit and I found that it detected them properly. The suite is very user friendly too. I used the Cyberlink Desktop Burning Gadget application the most. This was super simple to use. All you do is you drag/drop the files you want to back up and rename the disc. Once you are happy with the contents of said disk, you select burn. I was able to create 20+ GB discs very quickly. As you can imagine, the 100 GB discs did take longer to create, but finished and worked well afterwards when tested.

I also enjoyed how quiet this burner is compared to some others ones I have owned in the past. It's never going to be whiper quiet, but I was pleasantly surprised how quiet this burner performed. I like that it has a matté finished in the outer door of this unit. This burner is super light and can easily been thrown into messenger bag or your backpack of choice.

I guess if I had to nit pick, I would have loved to have received longer USB cables [the included ones are short] and the Cyberlink programs do annoyingly solicit at you. Their apps will constanly offer discounts towards upgrade to their newest version. It does not hinder the process, but I wish you could turn this off. The Cyberlink suite is super comprehensive though. You get everything you could possibly want from a media creation standpoint, from video files /data files /label creation /image /video editing and much more.

If you are looking for a reliable burner for home or on the go, then look no further and check out already!

I hope this was helpful!

title: Has Android 12 installed but it is SLOW.  PAINFULLY SLOW.  I CAN’T BROWSE THE INTERNET SLOW.
text:
2Q]\

I will admit that I didn’t expect a lot from this tablet. At this price point, it would be much more surprising to get a good tablet than a bad one. So what is good about it? It looks nice. The bezels are small, it is similar in thickness to an older iPad. It feels like a pretty decent tablet in your hand. But that is before you turn it on and try to use it. It is painfully slow. I had expected it to be useable for surfing the web. At this point I will say it is not. I have 5 year old tablets that are smoother scrolling than this one. It struggles to load a common news website. There is a terrible lag when scrolling an article. When you go back, the screen blanks for what seems like an eternity.

It does have the Google Play store installed and I was able to download an app from the store and install it. I downloaded the Amazon Blink app for use with their Blink cameras. The app works but there is so little headroom that when looking at a live view, the sound cuts in and out constantly. At this point I would say that I can’t really imagine a credible use case for this tablet. Maybe if you have a small child and you want to give them a tablet but you don’t really care how well it works, maybe then. But if you have to load the apps on it or help them with anything, you will be regretting your choice soon. I really can’t envision a scenario where I would say this is good enough for any particular task.

Other important tidbits: It seems to say in the details that it works with both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz Wi-Fi. It does not as best I can tell. I have dual band Wi-Fi router in my home. Only the 2.4 GHz band shows up as available networks. Another nagging little issue is that you cannot tap the screen to wake up the tablet. You have to press the lock key to wake up the tablet. Overall, my experience with this tablet is completely sub-par. Keep looking, this is not the tablet you are looking for.

title: Quality keyboard w/a great feel.  Supports multiple systems!
text:
I mainly got this wireless ultra-slim keyboard to use in my office with multiple computers. I can switch between numerous systems using my monitor inputs, but I hated having multiple keyboards on my desk. This one fixed those issues by supporting various machines. I wanted a quality keyboard for everyday use.

I have been using this keyboard for several months and am very impressed! The keyboard is very slim with a low profile. That said, it is still a full-sized keyboard. This is perfect for my use case. I'm super happy with it!

This device works with either 2.4 GHz (with a dongle) or Bluetooth. It can also easily switch between multiple devices using Bluetooth with the press of a button. I use this with various devices frequently, so easy switching with no hassles is very lovely. It has worked flawlessly.

The keyboard is extremely quiet. The keys feel like they have a very soft click. I was looking for a quiet keyboard as my office is quiet and my old keyboard was very loud. This one did the trick! It is almost silent, yet still has a light, tactile click feeling when typing. It's just enough to feel confident and type quickly without noise.

It has a nice tray for holding phones and tablets, which works well. I tested it with multiple devices. Depending on the thickness, some devices fit better than others, but all worked with the device. I have one cellphone with a thick case that didn't fit the best. Taking the case off fixes the problem but is a hassle. That said, it's super nice for smaller phones since they don't flop around as much.

I could switch between my Mac and Windows laptops just by pressing the command key. The keyboard switched, and I could use "the other" laptop. It's effortless to operate.

I love that the keyboard is full-width. I use this with a portable PC most of the time and have room to store it in my bag. It's a great option I prefer over lugging a heavy keyboard around. It's perfectly set up to be my main "workhorse" keyboard, yet it is light and quiet.

title: Pretty OK large capacity SSD drive for storage
text:
I've been waiting for large-capacity SSDs to come down in price for a long time. I saw this 2TB for $60 on sale and figured I'd give it a try.

I'm looking to replace my RAID of spinning disks in my my long-term home storage with a few SSDs. In theory, if you primarily read from them, SSDs should last an extremely long time - even QLC drives like this one. This should make them perfect for long term archival storage with few writes. and lots of reads. And since they shouldn't fail ever year or two like mechanical drives, they won't need to be in a RAID, which means I won't need to buy twice as much storage as I need either.

I'm testing this one out as my media drive and using it to store my movie collection.

- The drive isn't screaming fast like the more expensive drives. However, the read speed has been consistently "fast enough."

- Writes are fast, until they're not. Once its internal cache fills up, the drive's write falls pretty fast. Sustained write performance can drop to 10 MB/s or less. This is a bit frustrating when I'm filling up a new archival drive - 1 TB all at once is likely the worst-case workload for write performance. But now that I've done that, I don't notice write problems much. I also think I'd probably notice less if I were writing smaller files.

I've been using the drive for about 3 months now. While I wouldn't recommend this as the boot drive on a high end gaming system or developer workstation, I think it would be great in a game console, in a media server, for archival storage, or even as the boot drive in a typical home user's PC or laptop.

Quibble:

Two of the threaded screw holes for mounting the drive from below weren't machined correctly. The screws only go in about half as far as they should. My drive trays mount from below, and two of the screws didn't sit flush with the tray, which made the tray not fit in my drive enclosure. I left those screws out (not a big deal - two screws is plenty to hold this drive in place).

title: Front bezel broke off
text:
First impression was that this was really well made.
Second impression- not so well made.
When I tightened the back nut down the front bezel plate came off. The glue that holds it on just wasn't very strong.
I returned and opted for a replacement, but the replacement is like a month off for delivery.
Will update when I get the replacement.

UPDATE: When I put in for a replacement it showed that the replacement was over a month away from delivery, but I needed the part so I had to order it. In the meantime I searched for the same type of part and finally found one that I could get in a few days instead of a month away so I ordered it. There was no option to cancel the replacement so I figured I would return both the original and the replacement when it got here. Shouldn't be a problem, right? The original was to be returned to Whole Foods so the replacement was going to go to the same place, right? Nope.
The replacement came in a week earlier than expected so I submitted for a return. I had already set up for the original to be returned to Whole Foods, but Amazon wanted the replacement to be returned to a UPS drop off center which meant that I would have to drive across town to a UPS drop off center, then drive to a whole foods which isn't near a drop off center to return this part. What a pain. Called Amazon and, even though these were from the exact same place, Amazon wouldn't budge on the return. Had a very long discussion and waited on hold but Amazon decided that it was better to have a UPS driver come out and pick up the part (sometime within the week but not a definite day or time because UPS doesn't do that) instead of letting me take both parts (that are being returned to the same people at the same place) to Whole Foods.
So, overall, the replacement does look like it would have worked but I decided to not leave my truck dismantled for weeks on end and found a better option. I wish I could have used this in a different project to avoid the hastle, but it is what it is. Wish Amazon would have let me return it to Whole Foods, then this would have been easily completed. Now I have to put this out on my porch each day and hope UPS comes to pick it up.

title: Great remote, but lots of room for improvement
text:
I started using my Nvidia Shield (2017) and I got reminded how much I don't like using the original remote it came with. So when I saw this listed, it was interested by the fact it was advertised that you can use it as a mouse by waving it. So I ordered it just for that.

This remote is pretty basic. It comes with two different ways to connect to your supported device: the USB receiver or Bluetooth 5.0. Since I got this for using with my Nvidia Shield, I was able to try both options. The USB receiver works as intended, but there must be a line of sight from the remote to the receiver even though I'm not that far away from my Shield. I ended up pulling out a USB extension cable and it seems to work fine. The only thing is that the mic for using voice commands does not work when using the USB receiver. It only works in Bluetooth mode. Speaking of which, the bluetooth mode works really good. Once I paired it with the Shield, it works instantly. The mic works for one thing and it works pretty good. However the one issue I have is trying to wake up the Shield over Bluetooth hours later. It doesn't work unless you tell it to enter 'repairing' mode by holding 'OK' and the 'Return' keys and only then it connects over Bluetooth again. This doesn't seem to happen when using USB, but I really wish this wasn't so bad because I perfer to use it over Bluetooth.

As for the mouse pointer, it works great! You push the button to activate it and it feels very smooth. I would compare this to using the cursor on the LG TVs with their magic remote. They both feel the same! You are also able to adjust the speed of the cursor to your liking.

The only other thing I hate is that if you choose to use bluetooth, there is no spot in the remote to store your USB receiver (see picture). When you open the box, the receiver is stored in the battery compartment. But when you put your batteries in it, you no longer have a spot for it. I wish they made some room in the remote so I won't lose the receiver.

I perfer using this remote over the original Shield remote and I'm hoping that there will be a new revision of this soon.

title: Recommened but previous version was better
text:
First, this is an MPOW Gen 5 headset, they come in an MPOW-branded box and have MPOW printed on the device. This fact might be a pro to some and a con to others, search for MPOW on the internet to learn more.

• Battery life: Excellent. All day of continous music, multiple days in standby
Ergonomics/convenience: Excellent
• Sound quality: Good
• Volume: Good, can even hear them over a lawnmower (but I'm sure that's not recommended)
• Microphone quality: Acceptable
• Build quality: Acceptable
• Controls: Barely acceptable. Only 3 buttons, each with multiple uses depending on push time/multi-press.
• Noise Canceling: No
• Waterproof: No
• Connect to multiple devices at the same time: Yes, supports 2 device connections
• Connection stability: Poor. These disconnect multiple times per day when paired to 2 devices. Unknown if this happens when using a single device.
• Phone app: No

Final thoughts: Recommended but not perfect. I use them as a headset for meetings/calls as well as listening to music/podcasts, I even occasionally wear them while sleeping. I also normally have them connected to 2 devices at the same time. In other words, I'm a very heavy user. I have also had older versions of this same MPOWS headset in the past that I have loved. In my opinion this new version is a step backwards, the biggest issue is that it disconnects from my devices by itself if left in standby for a while. Its very annoying because you need to cycle power by long-pressing a button to turn it off then long-press the button again to turn it back on. This has caused me to miss phone calls.
In addition, the audio clue (beep) has been eliminated when the pause/reconnect button is pressed. This makes it impossible to tell if the power is on or off while wearing them without actually cycling power. I would still buy them again but I really miss the older versions of this headset, they were the best bargain out there. These are acceptable for under $40USD but difficult to recommend if more expensive.

title: Very good video resolution
text:
I have a blind spot where there is no power available. This should solve that problem. For now, I have it mounted next to a wired camera to test it before installing permanently. So far, I am impressed with its functioning. After three days, the camera has functioned 24/7 on Solar only and, the battery consumption is good.

Installation and linking to my WIFI was easy but, you will need their proprietary, separate app. When I tried to link to "Alexa" it requires you to download an Alexa Skill. this App was "funky". At one point, trying to put in my credentials, It would not accept them. With frustration, I deleted the app and thought I would have to use the camera app only. However, on a whim I asked ALEXA to show me Solar Cam and it does it.

So far I have not found a way to store 24/7 recording on the SD card but, it does store all ALERTS of detected motion selectable from 6 seconds to 30 seconds (longer recording will drain battery more)

While I am not a fan of some unknown cloud service but, it does allow you 6 second video of all alerts for up to 7 days. If you want longer videos stored it costs 2.99/month and, it also costs to get AI, which distinguishes between human, animals and vehicles. But it does a very good job of motion detection.

Pro: very good build, worked all night on power charge provided by solar panel. Good picture and video quality with less than a second delay when viewing on App. included are screen shots from this camera and my wired camera. Ability to set/restrict areas of the picture that will detect motion to specific area.

Cons. While the price point for a product is an individual decision, this is a little pricey (IMO) compared to other similar products available. The speaker is not very loud and, is a bit muffled but, the microphone is very clear and loud for recording/listening to outside noise with about a one second delay. While it does link to ALEXA, it will not link to "Tiny CAM" which I use to monitor multiple installed cameras.

overall, though, I am happy with this Solar camera.

title: Very comfortable and an excellent value.
text:
This is an interesting trackball. I'm a longtime trackball user and have been using them for CAD software since the late 80s. This design is a cross between two industry favorites the big L's MX Ergo and the big K's Pro Fit Vertical. It isn't really like either one but shares basic elements. Also, these both cost considerably more than this offering from Nulea.
At 55°, it has a steeper tilt then the Ergo (which is adjustable from 0° to 20° and is about 5° degrees less than the Pro Fit's 60° of tilt. I like their description of saying it's at the natural handshake position. It really is. I find this equal to the Pro Fit, I really don't notice the difference between the two hand positions.
The big change is in the position of the ball on the mouse. As stated throughout the product page, this is a trackball for large hands. And that is really the big thing for me. On both the Ergo and the Pro Fit the ball is just a little too close to the resting position of the rest of the hand. To manipulate the mouse on either I have to bend my thumb in. On the Nulea, the ball is considerably lower down the side of the body. This allows me to manipulate the wheel with almost minimal thumb movement. Really this is a pleasure to use overall, but there are a few cons.
DPI: There is no DPI indicator so you can't at a glance tell what your current setting it. So it takes a while to click, test, click... Also the DPI range isn't a nice curve.. +300 then +200 then +200 and finally +400. I would like also have preferred a starting DPI of less than 500 for true precision work. I use a trackball specifically for precision and 500 is good, but not great.
Software: There isn't any. At all. So other than using some third party options you would need to investigate on your own, there are no settings, no storing of profile or programmability to the buttons. Not a huge deal, and at this price point, maybe I'm expecting too much. Afterall, we're only talking about the two thumb buttons which are set to Forward and Back.

title: Skeptical and Disappointed at first
text:
Right now, I must own at least four different kinds of earbuds, ranging from Samsung Earbuds Pro to Sennheiser Momentum to Soundcore Life P3, and so on.

I am in the airline business, and frequent travel is a must. My go-to headphones for travel are the Sony WH-1000XM4. They are over-the-ear and excellent in ANC and battery life.

However, I also wanted in-ear buds with decent ANC for workouts and airplane rides when my over-the-ear phones got tiresome or on shorter trips.

Here is my problem: the creator decided to bless me with ear canals, the size you can stick your thumb in. So none of the before-mentioned buds, with their included silicone tips, fit and sealed my ear canals. The result was hardly any ANC and a tiny sound with no bass. The only thing that would work for me is to purchase the largest Comply Foam Tips. They would work better, but now the Earbuds would not fit in their charging case, having me take the foam tips on and off every time I used them, making it a constant pain.

The Bose from the start sounded way better than the rest, and after trying out all the options of buds and bands, with all sorts of different insert techniques (frustration city), I found a combination with the large buds and small bands to get a somewhat decent seal. The test in the app showed green on both buds, but the ANC still had no "wow" factor. Running the vacuum was way louder compared to my Sony over-the-ears.

When I ordered the Bose Quiet Comfort II, I also had the foresight to order the separate XS and XL earbud kit. It arrived today, and after installing the XL Ear Buds, it has become a game changer. "WOW" all the way. Super ANC (the noise running the vacuum is almost not present) and a vast improvement in the sound quality. These are now right up there with my Sony WH-1000XM4.

There finally is peace, and the search is over.

If you have similar issues, buy these earphones and get the additional earplugs kit.

title: The Best Flash Drive Value Deal
text:
[[VIDEOID:2125dff72e85567828a6f9f1bf29f04c]] These are an excellent variety pack of USB Flash Drives that work just as well as a traditional Hard Drive. Each drive comes with 64GB of storage (59 usable), and they work instantly from the moment you connect them to your PC. Just plug it in, select your files, and you can have them transfer in seconds to minutes depending on their size. Using CDM, the drives average 133MB/s Read and 78MB/s Write Speeds on average, but according to the Windows Dialog Box that opens when transferring files, I was averaging closer to a 42MB/s Write Speed.

Each drive also has a protective sliding mechanism that makes protecting the drives and using them a painless experience. These drives are unique in that they don't have any locking mechanism or push tab like some other flash drives- you simply just slide it. Even other sliding drives I’ve used would have a noticeable locking click sound when extended all the way, but this was not the case here. I was originally concerned about this, because I thought since it didn't require a push tab or a locking mechanism to keep the housing in place, I thought it would surely close back up once I tried to use it. Luckily, that did not happen, and in my video demo I even show that as soon as you slide it out, you can push all you want on the top of the USB and it will stay in place perfectly. I was very impressed by this.

The drives perform mostly like a traditional HDD in my opinion. Yes, they can have some occasional slow downs, but so can mechanical drives as well. These flash drives are definitely faster than the other ones I have, and for the cost, you get an excellent variety pack of them. Not only do you get 3 of these drives, but you are also getting a total of 192GB in total storage (177 Usable) when you take all 3 into account. So, this makes it easy to use each drive for a specific use- one could be for work documents or student projects, another could be used for photo and video storage, and another could be used as a Windows boot drive. The possibilities are endless, and I would highly recommend these flash drives to anyone who uses lots of them for various tasks.

title: Good sound isolation (not cancelling) work headphones.
text:
I work in construction, sell woodworking projects in my own business, and have worked on oil and gas rigs for years. Point being I have worked in a lot of high noise environments, and have a lot of experience with hearing protection.

These work well at blocking/isolating sound. But, I doubt they are at the 30dbr rating in actual use, they seem closer to 22-24 to me compared to my 30dbr muffs or 26dbr isolating headphones. This is just a guess, but a guess based on a lot of experience. In any case, this is enough for most people - just not for sustained high decibel sound levels.

The sound quality is surprisingly good, and with the large batteries the battery life is great. They lasted me for a week long project, and true to claim I didn't need to charge them and they didn't die during that time. They remained comfortable the whole time in use.

Phone calls were made and received with ease, and the people on the other side of the conversation didn't say anything about the sound quality. I answer on these types of devices a fair amount, so that doesn't mean I sounded perfect - but enough it didn't elicit complaints or difficulty conversing.

This type of sound blocking headphones reduce situational awareness, especially with music on - so as a caution they aren't great for areas that require it.

The only two complaints I would have with this set of headphones are the multifunction button, and the way the foam inserts attach by sliding over a stub. The multifunction button attempts to control too many things at once, and I almost always activated "game mode" when attempting to shut them off. Small issue but irritating.

The more pressing issue is the foam plugs (which you need to use for the best, safest sound blocking) are slid over a plastic post. From experience with other brands like this - the foam plugs wear out regularly. They tend to split as the primary mode of failure - and this post attachment is probably going to aggravate that. I didn't search for the replacement tips, but make sure to factor in multiple sets a year (minimum 6) when considering the cost.

Overall really good sound blocking headphones, not perfect, but good for most uses and users.

title: Maalox by the Quart
text:
The device came neatly packaged, with an instruction guide inside which is a good touch. Except.

The instruction guide text is written in lettering so small that one with 20/20 vision is going to need a magnifying glass to read it accurately.

Next, plug this device into a power socket, and it lights right up, and immediately starts rapidly flashing, which I've come to understand is the "pairing" or "discoverable" mode. Using the Alexa ap, and initiating discovery comes up empty. When you attempt to manaully add the device, by the manufacturer, in this case Amysen, I'm instructed to download and install the "Amysen ap." Great! Tremendous advice. Except.

The ap I'm told to install - DOESN'T EXIST. When I search for this ap, I get "Smart Life", which supposedly will automatically link up with Alexa. Good to know, and perhaps Amysen didn't bother creating their own ap, and went with Smart Life and forgot to tell Alexa. Pretty crummy for software, really.

Next, using Smart Life, I could find the device (Hooray!), and operate it on and off, and set up a timer for it. (Hooray x 2!)

Next comes trying to get Alexa to discover the device so it can be controlled by her. Epic fail. Tried speaking with a live human being from Amazon to resolve this issue, twice, once for almost an hour, and the second time just now for almost 20 minutes and the results were zero.

I don't have any idea what in the world is wrong with what I'm doing, or this device. There are multiple others in my home which Alexa manages to operate very easily.

So, my take on this is that while your experience may be quite smooth, mine was not, frustratingly so.

When attempting to link this device to her, I recommend having a quart of Maalox or some other antacid nearby. You're going to need it.

Color me disgusted.

Ken Wagoner
Harrisonville, Missouri

title: My first security camera...a solid purchase!
text:
I've had this camera for about a week now and I'm pretty happy with it. I don't know much about cameras like these but have been on the lookout for a decently priced camera that did not break the bank. I only purchased one to test it out and if I liked it, I'd buy another one and well... I want another one of these! I feel this is a great deal! I cannot speak on the battery life as I have my camera plugged into an outlet at all times but it's rained, snowed, been sunny, windy... the camera has stayed recording. I bought an SD card to put into the camera but it's not entirely necessary as you can save motion detected clips right from the app to your advice. I'm assuming the sd card function is more so if the wifi goes out or you want the clips transferred to a computer/laptop. It was easy to set up as well. I can't tell you if you'd need a wifi extender or anything like that as my camera is close by my wifi router. The wifi has to be 2g not 5g. Picture quality is good and you can view the camera stream away from home!

Now the only con I'd say is the motion detection. Yes, you can pay a monthly fee to pick what kind of things you want to be detected, which the subscription isn't that crazy of an amount but... this camera only records clips when there's motion detected or you manually go into the VicoHome app and click record. You can adjust the sensitivity to motion detection and whatnot in the app but if you place this camera at a house facing somewhat of a busy road, it's going to give you a notification on the VicoHome app every time. It records the motion for about 10-20 seconds depending on what you choose. Overall, I'm happy with this camera. It's a good first camera for people who are looking to get one and the price is great. I will say, I did have to buy an SD card with this and it is recommended but I'm not sure it's exactly needed if you plan to do the subscription cloud service through VicoHome. The camera holder that you drill into could be a better material as it's plasticky so be careful with that but other than these things, I'm happy to have a camera that gets the job done.

title: Poor software, hard to get photos to frame, unstable
text:
Update 5/8/2033:
The set schedule is unstable. After a few days after setting the frame to turn off at 10p.m., it wouldn't turn off, keeping waking me up in the middle of the night (my moving legs trigger the motion sensor). I reset it, and after a couple of days the same behavior returned. In the trash it goes, one star down for this!
Original review:
This digital picture frame is a great way to display your favorite pictures. I ordered it for our bedroom.
The motion sensor is a great feature, automatically turning on the display when someone is nearby, and you can set the time it will turn off after no motion is detected (minimum is 2 minutes). You can set the frame to turn automatically on/off based on a schedule, which is good for nighttime.
The quality of the display is average, it does not have FHD resolution. The 16GB of internal storage provides enough space to store your favorite memories, but in the features description is stated it has 32GB. The touchscreen is not very responsive, do not expect the same responsiveness as for a mobile phone.
The setup was straightforward, but uploading the photos requires downloading an awkward app. I do not like the app, it is not intuitive at all, and it only lets you select 50 photos at once for upload. There is also the option to send photos by e-mail. Really? In 2023? What a joke! I do not feel comfortable sharing my photos or email address with a shady app.
I tried to plug in a memory stick in the USB port, but the space is so tight it will only fit a standard USB connector. My memory stick is maybe 2 mm thicker than the USB connector, so I was disappointed that I was forced to use a cable to plug in the stick into the frame. I managed only once to get it connected, and it took like forever to search and load the stored photos from USB drive. It only shows the photos, you cannot browse any folders you have. Any other attempts were unsuccessful, resulting in Vphoto app errors.
There are no proper user instructions for the frame or the app.
To conclude: for this price tag, I would look elsewhere. This is a poor product, with great features only on paper. I would not order it again.

title: Exactly what I wanted
text:
[[VIDEOID:cbb0b6303fbc4d6c8d7a9482085c0e2f]] I already had a laptop stand that I used at home, but it was a solid one-piece design that was very bulky to transfer to the office or a cafe/coffee shop.

I was looking for a second laptop stand that I could adjust AND that would fold to be mostly flat so it would easily fit in my laptop bag. The abilty to fold this stand makes it really worth the value.

I can't stress that enough.

As a college student, a designer, and an artist, who carries their work with them almost EVERYWHERE, this stand is my bestfriend since it elevates my monitor so I do not have to look down for hours and incur back/neck pains, while also very light and easy to stash.

I love that I can adjust the stand with a lot of precision to fit any display style like for drawing on my iPad, or using my laptop to type, watching movies, etc.

My laptop is actually bigger than the stand, it's 17in and this stand does not budge or buckle under the weight. It can handle a laptop much bigger than it but only at certain angles. Just don't angle the stand too far forward or too far back and it will carry a larger laptop just fine.

Also, boy is it stable! The only time I found this stand to not be stable is when it's on an uneven surface like a mattress, or if you angle it too far forward/backward. This happens because the stand is very light, if it were heavier then it would not fall forward/backward because of the weight of your laptop forcing it to. But that is a strength in my opinion since it makes the stand very convenient to carry in a messenger bag, satchel, or laptop bag.

Overall I really love this stand, so much so that I don't even use the original one I bought for home use anymore 😅! The pink is really nice, very much like the photos and it's a super convenient buy for any student, artist, or anyone who doesn't want neck/back pain while using their laptop or equivalent device while on the go.

title: Fangore has provided amazing Specs for a Good Price!
text:
[[VIDEOID:a54adb9c8c213e09ea6ec37264af74ea]] One of the first things you will notice when you remove the projector from the box is that it comes in a heavy duty carry bag which is unbelievably useful because it comes with a handle and it can contain all of your components including third party components like media sticks from Amazon or Roku.

This is a big time serious projector & it is more than enough to use as a permanent home theater projector for parties and events at your home.

You can control it using Miracast or Aircast depending on whether you have an Android or Apple device. You can just wirelessly control it using your phone....it's great.

You can also utilize the HDMI cord which comes in the box to connect this to your PC or laptop, or even a PlayStation or Xbox. So you could theoretically get on your PC, connect the projector using the HDMI cable that it comes with, sign into your Netflix or Hulu account, or YouTube, ESPN+, Disney+, etc and the projector will screen your content directly onto any white wall or projector screen.

Getting a projector tripod for about $30 is not necessarily but I recommend it.

Lastly, I recommend buying a media stick unless you already have one. Two popular models are the Amazon Firestick or the Roku HD 4k... Both run about $40 and will make your life incredibly easier because you don't have to use your phone or the HDMI cord. You can sit and mess with your phone without worrying about screwing up the movie you were trying to watch.

The maximum display size is 300" which equates to 25 ft from corner to corner.

It also has Bluetooth 5.0 so you can set up a bunch of speakers all around the room and have true surround sound.

This projector truly recreates an IMAX theater. It is able to utilize 12 million color variations, and they will be amazingly bright because it has 450 ANSI lumens which is incredible.

What you get for the price in this case is a complete steal.

Watch my video where I discuss things further.

A+ Device....great price for what you get.

title: One hella of an upgrade!
text:
I've been playing around with the webcam and it's one hella of an upgrade in comparison to the Nexigo N60. Overall a great camera but it may a bit overkill if you are not planning to use it a lot.

Pros
*The image quality is amazing
*Being able to set the angles with a control
*The software for the webcam is very easy to comprehend and the control can do most of those things too!
*USB connection; it doesn't need to be connected directly to the pc to work properly. I use a USB tower and there's no lag nor any other problem
*Wide lens!! Or well, I can see way more of my room with this new webcam than the previous one I have. And then you just adjust the zoom and angle w the control and your set.
*You can mount it on the wall or ceiling and with the control, you can still make the image look good.
*If you're not happy with the setting you applied it's easy to back to the default settings by pressing Home.
*Mute bottom!! The controller has a mute button and also a camera-blocking function. You can use both at the same time too. The screen will just go black but the webcam will still be on.

Cons
*I've hopped in calls to test out the built-in mic and I've been told more than once to go back to my normal mic lol
*You can't pop it on your monitor like smaller webcams, and if you just put it on your desk it will 1) give a nice view of your double chin and 2)block your view on the monitor (not by a lot but it's there).
*Had to put a small floating shelf so I can set the camera there and point it to myself. This also adds the effect that I'm always looking down although I'm looking at my monitors.
*On my laptop I can see a nice image, but sometimes the people you are calling won't appreciate the same quality.
*Sometimes in calls, when you are already using zoom, the camera won't go up/down/left/right for whatever reason. So you have to unzoom, change the position and then zoom in again.

title: It's quite loud
text:
As a duster, it's pretty loud, but it seems to be more powerful than other dusters I've used. Much like the other duster I tried, this one charges via USB, but it has USB A and USB C on it. The USB ports are behind a rubber cover to prevent water from getting in, but the cover is actually flush with the rest of the handle and thus it's hard to get it to open when you want it open. I wind up having to get something like a toothpick to dig at the corner until it comes off.

The included attachments fit into the recessed area on the front and are held in entirely by friction. At the moment it's fine but I feel like eventually it'll start to wear down and the parts might slip out. I suppose at that point I'll have to tape around the end of the attachments to ensure they have enough friction to stay on. It hasn't happened yet though.

The device also has a small LED light in the front which I don't really find that useful. I'm not dusting my computer at night, though I suppose it might help. The unusual thing is that it also flashes red and white. I guess if you carry this with you in the car then it might help as a roadside warning flasher, but I'm not sure why I'd keep this in the car. It's not like I'm going to inflate my tires with it. I'm not even sure it's powerful enough to do that.

The side panel has an indicator to show it's on (which shows battery level) as well as which power level you're on at the moment. P1 blows at about 12 MPH, P2 blows at about 20 MPH, and P3 blows at about 25 MPH. The high-pitched whine is not quite as loud as your leaf blower, but it's close. I'd say if you're going to use this for extended periods, you might want some ear plugs.

The included attachments are fine for dusting, and it also came with some brushes to help remove dust from cracks and crevices. Overall, it's a good duster, though I question the value of the "HD digital screen" and the flashing red/white lights.

title: Gets the job done nicely, but there are a few things I don't like
text:
Other reviewers have done a great summarizing features, so I won't repeat. Below are my impressions of this case, including what I like, and what could be better.

The good:
* This is a sturdily built case that will provide excellent protection
* The trackpad is a nice feature not found on all keyboard cases, and it works well
* The keyboard attaches magnetically to the case, and there's little chance of it falling out
* I like the keyboard's cool blue backlight feature
* The included instructions are good, and I needed them to pair manually when Bluetooth didn't automatically recognize the keyboard as it usually does

What could be better:
* The first thing I noticed is that this case is REALLY heavy, even without the keyboard. It's because of the magnetic plate sandwiched between the case's vinyl. With the keyboard, the case weighs the same as my iPad, so with the iPad and case combined, total weight is more than a slim 13" laptop. For me, this is reason enough to use this case only when I need the keyboard, and not for every day use.
* Because of the trackpad, the keyboard feels slightly cramped compared to other case keyboards. I'm willing to accept this tradeoff because I like the trackpad, but you should keep this in mind when deciding what's important to you in a case.
* The keyboard itself feels incredibly light, and not in a good way. I'm not confident it will stand up to heavy use, and when typing there's a cheap creaking sound that comes from the keyboard body flexing, not from the keys.
* In my opinion, the keys feel slightly stiff and harder to press than they should be. Some people might like a firmer touch, but I'm the opposite.
* This case doesn't include the Auto-shutoff/Turn on feature. I thought most iPad cases include the feature where the iPad turned on when the cover opens, and shuts off when the cover is closed. Perhaps I'm wrong.

The bottom line: If you aren't bothered by the things I mentioned above that I don't like, this is a great case and will meet your needs nicely. For me, I'll keep searching for another case.

title: Seemingly standard
text:
I've wondered what bone conduction headphones were like. It's interesting how it works. There are two square shaped pieces that vibrate and rest on the zygomatic bones in your skull. The sound is transmitted to your ear bones and drums from there.

These sound good too. It's not studio or audiophile grade, but they are decent. It has a good bass response, and the mids and highs are clear.

It takes a little being used to, but I like these better than earbuds. It does this weird vibration, sometimes, when the audio starts. It feels like someone flicked me lightly on the zygo. I first joked that my headphones assaulted me. It felt a bit uncountable at first, but, now, I barely notice it.

These wrap around the ear and the back of the head when worn. I really dislike the part that wraps around the head, because when I put my head back on a chair it will bump them, and I have to set my head back awkwardly when sitting.

They're fine for sports and other activities. They stay on good. No problems there. They are waterproof but I'm not sure they're submersible. They are made with good materials and components.

I can hear things around me better due to the open ear design. It's not foolproof, but it allows one to be a little more aware of their surroundings. They come with ear plugs, because you can hear with these better if you plug your ears. Weird, right? It's a trip.

I wear these a lot. Sometimes, I forget I'm even wearing them. I love that they're Bluetooth. No more wires. The battery lasts a good while, and it doesn't take too long to charge.

I'm not sure what the price is at the time you're reading this. They were over $100 when I received them, but it seems they may be available for much less now. I think that's a high price. I hope they're still reduced price.

I think these are good though. I like wearing these when watching videos and listening to music. Many times I'm cleaning out working out too. They are good for these activities. Not a bad grab.

title: Great Keyboard & Mouse Combo - Bluetooth + RF Connectivity
text:
I really like this combo a lot, keyboard is so thin and elegant, mouse is elegant too. I purchased this to use with my Gigabyte Aero 16 Laptop and it looks and works great. It's certainly the very best wireless set up I have ever used.

I tested connected both with Bluetooth and the included RF dongle. Both methods of connection work flawlessly but I found both to be of very slightly less range than a Logitech combo connected via a universal dongle, but not enough to be problematic. Since my laptop has no USB-A ports the Bluetooth connection is very welcome. Both mouse and keyboard have a 3 position switch with Off/Bluetooth/RF positions. This allows you to use both with two different PC's if you wanted, but it's a little inconvenient to have to switch both on a regular basis. Both charge via the included USB-C cable.

The keyboard has all the usual keys and a numeric keypad. The finish on the keyboard is a pleasing matt black that doesn't attract fingerprints. The keys are relatively light to use and are almost silent in use but have enough tactile feedback to be nice to use. Indicator lights are provided for num lock and caps lock which extinguish after a second or so of inactivity presumably to save battery. There is no backlighting on the keyboard which is a normal thing for wireless keyboards. The keyboard is quite heavy, rigid and just has a quality feel to it. There is also an included kickstand that magnetically attaches to raise the rear of the keyboard.

The mouse top is a slightly shiny black grained finish with a pleasing grey tactile panel where your thumb sits. The button next to the mouse wheel selects different DPI for the mouse pointer, there are 4 settings. The mouse is accurate in use and fits my hand perfectly. The two side buttons work as next and previous page in Chrome as you would expect. These have a slightly imprecise feel to them but other than that they work well.

The quality of this combo is evident from the moment you unpack them. The keyboard comes wrapped in black tissue paper and it's weight, thinness and finish making it feel quite exquisite. The mouse is also relatively heavy and looks and feels like a quality item. I really can't think of any way they could have made these any better.

title: No SD card will fit, terrible instructions
text:
You know how people make fun of Google translate for inaccurate and weird translations? I wish the people who made this camera had used Google translate so the instructions would be SOMEWHAT readable.

This also came with a rear camera despite not mentioning it in the listing, which was a fun surprise, but the instructions don't mention the rear camera *at all* so there's no way to tel how to set it up, even with the instructions essentially being gibberish.

The instructions do say something about connecting the camera to the PC, but there's no way to do that with the included hardware - the camera, the rear camera, the mount, and the cord that plugs the camera into your car. There's no camera-to-PC cord included and no indication of what sort of cord you would even need (the plug on the camera is not like the plug you see on Apple or Android devices).

The dashboard mount is useless. It flatout just does not work. It screws into the camera just fine, but it doesn't adhere to the glass at all.

And finally, no SD card works with this thing. It doesn't include an SD card, the instructions don't make it clear what exactly you need beyond "32 GB capacity" (seems really bizarre to me that the camera can't use a memory card that holds more than 32 GB but whatever). You need a micro-sd card, but the trouble is there's at least 4 kinds of micro-sd card and the instructions don't specify WHICH. I've bought two different micro-sd cards and neither of them work - they won't go into the slot, the camera won't read them. Both were SD-HC micro cards, so I thought perhaps I just needed the very basic oldest version that's just Micro-SD. But those have the capacity of up to 2 GB, when the instructions say "capacity 32 GB". So I have no idea. I'm irritated enough at now spending extra money on micro-sd cards that don't work PLUS a separate dashboard mount that I realize I could've just bought an entirely different dashcam at this point.

But it's pretty and the picture quality was good from what I could see when it was plugged in - it couldn't record anything but it still showed stuff on the screen.

title: Must have and so much better then what Blink supplies
text: I own a number of Blink cameras, and all the outdoor cameras are attached to trees. I quickly discovered this can be an issue if you have curious squirrels, raccoons, crows or neighborhood cats (my property is frequented by all four) as the mounts Blink supplies with their cameras are simply pathetic. Just a slight nudge by critter or strong gust of wind and the camera is dislodged--and trying to adjust where the camera points while it's "attached" to the original Blink mount is a massive aggravation. These replacement mounts are hands down worth every penny. In truth you don't need directions as it's obvious how to mount them. They are certainly no more difficult to mount than those awful little ones that come with the cameras, the visor above the camera does in fact protect it from rain and, to a lesser degree dust/pollen and it will clearly add an extra layer of protection against moisture getting into the battery compartment as long as you have the camera pointing slightly downwards. The mount itself screws securely into the housing that surrounds the camera, so no more cameras popping off the mount by a gentle nudge or a blast of wind--which could damage your camera, assuming you could locate it afterwards. Once mounted and the camera oriented the way you want (which is a breeze) and all the adjustments tightened, it's rock steady. A squirrel happily demonstrated that it won't budge when he sat on it, then he and a friend raced up and down the tree the camera was mounted on, sometimes using the camera as a launching pad and the camera did not move. We also had a pretty decent windstorm a few days ago and while I'd always been worried for my cameras in really bad weather, as all are fully exposed to whatever Mother Nature throws at my property, these new mounts held fast--no issues. It also does not in ANY way interfere with night vision These new mounts might also stump any would-be or opportunistic thieves, or at least make them work for their ill-gotten gains (in the process allowing the camera time to get good mug shot) as it might not be obvious how to remove the camera to anyone unfamiliar with this mount. That's another plus: if you need to remove the camera, to replace the batteries, the mount/camera housing will remain precisely the way you wanted it--no more repositioning once you replace the camera in its housing.

title: Works well for my needs
text:
I like to listen to rain sounds as a sleep aid. The earbuds I use have been working better for me than quite a few I’ve tried, except that the cord is way too short. I’ve lost count of how many times my phone has slipped off the nightstand while I tried to change positions or make an adjustment to the cord.

I measured the cable itself (not including the hardware on either end) at just under 38”, so the cord gives you a little over 3 feet of extra length. It’s essentially doubled the length of the earbuds I will be using with the extender. The cable has a rubbery covering that has a soft texture to it.

When I plugged my headphone jack in for the first time, I thought for a moment that the female connector was the wrong size since the jack wasn’t holding, but it turned out you have to push it in a little harder until it snaps into place. I assume they wanted to ensure a firm connection between the two cables so you don’t accidentally disconnect them with incidental movements. It gives a good hold, and I don’t have trouble unplugging them from each other either.

I have to use a dongle to connect my headphones to my phone, so I was a little worried that two connections would not work out so well. I was pleased to see that it worked as expected, and gave me plenty of extra length to lie comfortably in bed with my earbuds in. I tapped along the length of the extension cord and moved it around to see if it created any disturbances to the audio, and didn’t find any issues.

The product description mentions that the cord won’t be compatible with a microphone. This isn’t an issue for me since I specifically use earbuds with no microphone or controller for bedtime. I tested the extender with another set of earbuds that includes a microphone and a controller, since I wasn’t sure from the description if the controller would be affected in addition to the microphone. For anyone else who might be wondering, the extender does not have the necessary hardware to handle the button controls, so if that’s a requirement for you then you’ll want to look for something different.

title: You better read this if you are thinking about buying
text:
I am going to give this camera a solid 1 star for lots of reasons. Here they are:
1. if you want to view events, you have to have subscription. In fact, if you want to camera to do anything legit you need subscription. Even then I'm not sure it would work right.
2. software is full of bugs. Rules do not function correctly. If you set certain rules, they simply do not function. Example: you set the camera to not detect motion and send notification during certain times, it will still do it.
3. waypoints (individual quick pan views) just get deleted randomly. you have no idea what the default will be either. apparently it's the last waypoint you set but who knows how true that is. no way to set defaut.
4. sensitivy setting is all over the place. There's no way to tell what the range is and it will take forever to figure out what setting makes sense. They have no range specified not can they give you one. talked to support multiple times.
5. camera will record all kinds of junk on storage card and good look sorting through it to identify anything valuable. it's hard to navigate through the card and the camera will fill up the card with junk. all you can do is format the card to erase everything, you cannot select items, view them individually and erase them. what a stupid design!
6. tech support is sort of half-lame. they seem to not really know their own product either. as if this was just designed and everyone's in beta mode and counting.

What a piece of junk that will have to tinkering with it for days to no avail. All it's good for is live view and that's it. Image is OK but good luck if you think this will be some cool setup that allows you to monitor things properly and to get valid notifications. it will ring like crazy all day long despite of you messing around with settings and sensitivity levels.

they have a loooooong way to go to get this app to work well and software to behave correctly.
this was designed to lure people into subscribing but the basic sniff test without subscription is a total fail.

absolutely frustrating product. needless to say I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND.

title: I use this for work and I talk to clients all day sound is amazing
text: They connected super easy to my Bluetooth. I can charge it overnight and won’t have to charge it for maybe three days. I’m on the phones for about six hours a day. They can’t hear any background noise and with this headset they hear me very clearly I can walk around my house washing dishes while I’m talking to a client and they have no idea that I’m doing house work and they can still hear me very clearly and I can hear them extremely clearly as well. The meet button is on the side with the microphone by your ear. You just tap it really quick, so like if I need to call for something, I’ll tap it really fast and with most headsets whenever you press the mute button that robotic voice will say microphone muted, this one does not do that which I love because I don’t miss anything that they’ve said, it’s just click of a button to mute it  And then click it again and it’s as if you never click mute or anything. I love this headset Bluetooth range for it being wireless it’s pretty amazing. My desk is way by my kitchen and I go to the back of my house on my balcony and I could still hear them very clearly no problems no static  Battery life is A1 which it obviously is very important in the car. Clarity is amazing as well order it it’s great for the price. Actually it should be more pricey but it isn’t this. It’s it is wonderful doesn’t feel cheap. It doesn’t come with a headset bag for you to put it in but that’s not really an issue for me , it does come with the charging wire so you need one of those charger boxes that you plug into the wall and then input the charging cable to connect to the headset just to let it charge to get a full charge maybe an hour but I always just plug it in at night before I go to bed and when you do plug it in and connect it will tell you when you turn it on  if the battery is full medium or low when you first turn it on so you already know where you’re at with the battery life which is cool so my advice is to go ahead and added to go especially if you work from home and I just talk to clients or customers or guests

title: Tozo does it again
text:
Full disclosure I am a big fan of Apple air pod pros. I use my AirPod pros pretty consistently, however lately they have been glitchy when I’m working from home in a teams meeting or zoom meeting. I work from home and almost exclusively use headphones during my meetings on a daily basis. My wife and children are home some of those days and I need noise cancellation to drown out their sound sometimes.

When my AirPods started glitching, I bought a pair of Tozo clear earbuds however, they were not noise cancellation . These headphones are spectacular. The active noise cancellation functionality works great for a pair of in ear buds. Noise, cancellation, and sound quality is on par with the first generation AirPod pros. I couldn’t compare them to the second GEN AirPod pros because I don’t have them.

Pros:
-Sound quality is great
-Battery display on the case makes it easy to read and know how much battery you have left.
-The battery lasts a very long time. I charge the case once and use my earbuds about two hours every day and the case is at 43%.
-The earbuds do not slip out. They fit ergonomically in my ear and come with several different tips to customize for you and user.
-please connect to my phone automatically via Bluetooth every time without any issues.

Cons:
-earwax or oil, for my skin shows up easily in the case, and on the earbuds themselves. Strictly aesthetically speaking does not affect the performance of the earbuds at all.
-The case is super slick, and there is no loophole to attach any sort of lanyard or clip. I’m nervous about them slipping out of my pocket easily.
-additional application to change the settings of the earbuds is required. I have not downloaded the application to try it. and functionality are accessible by touching the earbuds.

For the price I don’t think there’s a better set of earbuds out there with the sound quality and features. These earbuds are truly worth the price. I would highly recommend them to anybody looking for an alternative to AirPods.

title: Doesn't provide the results I was hoping for
text:
I was hoping this docking station would be an avenue to add ports to my Dell laptop which only has two built-in USB-C ports.

The first thing I noticed when I plugged my laptop into the PD charging port was a continuous little caution symbol over the battery symbol in the taskbar. I have the Dell AC adapter connected to the PD charging port but the symbol is alerting to reduced battery charging speeds. After research, I discovered that the100W PD is undersized for the XPS 15 9500. This PD charging port supports 100W/87W/61W (20V and 5A) but my 9500 takes 90W at exactly 20V and 4.5A. Since the PD charging port doesn't support 90W this means that my XPS is only charging at 60 or 65w - thus reduced charging speeds.

I then went on to read the "manual" which points out the USB 3 ports are intended for data transfer and not recommended for charging iPads, tablets or smartphones. The manual also states that this device is not intended to support an external hard drive which I use daily. It will also not support wireless mouse/keyboard receivers which I currently use. So I am not able to free up those two USB C ports on my laptop.

Another issue I have is the cable from the docking station to the laptop is just too short. Like many people, I have my laptop on a riser and because of that, the docking station just dangles from the USB-C port on my laptop so I currently have it sitting on a box. I would think there would be even more issues with the cord for those with a full size desktop.

I did test the data transfer from my phone to my laptop and from an SD card and I had no issues. Also, my monitor is plugged into one of the HDMI ports and is working with no lag.

So I'm on the fence about recommending this. 1. I'm not sure if there will be long-term issues with it slow-charging my computer and 2. I'm not sure how much use I will get from this product based on my specific needs/peripherals . For now I will continue to monitor and may update my review at a later date.

title: WELL BUILT – WEBCAM / TABLET ARM – STIFF JOINTS (good) – NO LOCKING SCREWS
text:
PRODUCT VERSION REVIEWED

JUSMO LS31 IPAD TABLET DESK MOUNT, ALUMINUM ANGLE HEIGHT ADJUSTABLE FLEXIBLE ARM

QUICK REVIEW [TL;DR]

WELL BUILT – WEBCAM / TABLET ARM – STIFF JOINTS (good) – NO LOCKING SCREWS

REVIEW:

I noticed when I am on video calls, it always seems I am looking off the to the side or up or down, instead of at the person(s), I’m speaking with. My idea was to mount my webcam on a flexible arm that I could move directly in the middle of my screen when I’m using it, so it looks like I am watching the person.

This desk mounted stand has a traditional camera screw mount, which I was able to use to mount to my camera.

Initially, it was shorter than I needed to reach the center of my monitor, but due to the included camera screw mount, I was able to extending it using my standard camera accessories. Now it is perfectly centered on my screen for my video conferences. As a bonus, it folds up out my way, when not in use.

NOTE:

Because there are no locking screws on the joints, you are entirely dependent on the stiffness of the joints for supporting whatever you attach.

At first, the webcam weight was too much and it kept drooping down. Eventually, once I changed the ending orientation of the ball joint, I was able to get the camera to stay upright. Between the webcam, and my extension arm I added, I was probably exceeding the ending weight capacity.

PROS
- Stiff Joints to support devices
