- Flexible Orientation W/ Rotating main arm
- Included Camera Mount
- Cable Holders

CONS
- No Screws on Joints to Hold in Place
- No Instructions

I recommend the mount for light equipment. Nothing heavier than a small webcam.

title: Good Floodlight Camera But...
text: After one month of service, I feel as though I can give an honest assessment of the overall performance of this camera. Admittedly I had high hopes for this device but over the last month, my hopes went from impressed to just OK. The install was fairly easy and it did set up perfectly the first time. The video quality  is very good and the motion detection is very sensitive but after adjustments, works pretty good. The lights are bright at their brightest setting and can be dimmed to your preferred light level. About a week later, without warning, when I manually tried to turn the floodlight on or off, it would turn back on even with the motion detection turned off. The lights were basically on all-the-time. I ultimately had to perform a soft reset of the device by holding the button down for 20-seconds and subsequently had to reset the network settings. Worked good for another week before  it started losing connection to the network. My second Ring device, which is located about 10-feet from this one, was working fine so I knew it wasn't due to the Wi-Fi quality. It lost connection and it would not reconnect, no matter what I did, even after performing the soft reset. What fixed it this time was having to turn off the circuit breaker for about a minute removing all power from the device an turning it back on. We will call this a hard reset. After setting everything back up again, It has been working pretty well. That was a week ago. What's funny is that the arm/disarm schedule did not work right after the initial installation but after the hard reset has been working fine. Software issue? Hardware issue? Not sure. My advice to you if you should decide to purchase this device is to install in in-line on/off switch if it is not already set up that way. That way you don't have to hit the breaker when you need to do a hard reset. You will just be resetting the Ring floodlight and not everything else on the circuit. That is what I did. The issues you are reading about in the other reviews are very much legit and I can attest to that. However, it is a pretty good security device and it works well when it works. We will see how long it works after the hard reset and perhaps, if everything works right,  I might upgrade this review to a four-star rating. Stay tuned.

title: Fantastic "Prosumer" Switch
text:
Summary:
Everything most home lab or SOHO users need in a switch at an attractive price.

Details:
Prior to my current career, I was studying for my Cisco networking certifications which left me somewhat dismissive of consumer-level gear. In particular, I've always felt the need for a nice managed switch. Unfortunately it is just hard to justify buying a $1,000 infrastructure switch or even a $500 Ubiquity, and a lot of the other "managed" switches for home users are light on features. After all, if I am honest I just need a couple of VLANs and a few PoE ports.

This piece of Aruba kit perfectly balances price and features. It provides you with 24 ports (12 Power-over-Ethernet), 2 SFP to provide interface options, and all the features most people need. Even better it has an easy to access, local web-interface that makes setting VLANs and debugging problems exceedingly easy. In particular, I really like the PoE interface which clearly explains how many watts each device is using and can even prioritize shutdowns in the case of an overly large power demand. It even has a well documented CLI interface if you prefer that.

In addition to the basics it has most of the options I could see needing in a SOHO setup like spanning tree protocol and port mirroring. And all of this is clearly exposed, if not explained, in the web interface. I haven't tried their remote interface and I probably will not as I prefer to run things locally, but it is a nice option to have.

In addition, the hardware is solid and has a fan that changes speed depending on load. In my rack I think it is off most of the time... or at least is quieter than the other fans in the system.

The only downside I see to it, ironically given its name, is that it takes a bit longer to come up after being turned on and off than I would prefer. It isn't a huge deal because this will likely be restarted once every six months or so!

If you know enough about networks to need a managed switch, this will be easy to operate and setup. Plus I think it hits a real sweet spot between price and performance.

title: Good camera for the price, but needs a few improvements
text:
This is a decent camera for the price-point, but there are two, possibly three, improvements that need to be made.

1. Privacy shutter is hard to see.
There is a tiny slider switch on the camera itself that you can move in order to engage the privacy cover. This switch, and the privacy cover itself, are difficult to see. This makes it hard to tell if the privacy shutter is covering the lens or not.

I think they should paint the switch and the cover (or even just the cover) a much lighter color in order to let you easily tell whether it is engaged or not. It's a small change, but would greatly improve the camera.

2. The ring light switch lacks a stopper. You rotate it and it goes from off to dim to fully lit to off to dim...etc... This means that if you are trying to turn the light off, you can't really tell if you've turned it off or just dimmed it. It also means if you try to turn it off, you are very likely to rotate past off and into fully bright light blasting you in the face when you least expect it.

There should be a full stopper or even just something that provides tactile feedback letting you know the light is off. It's another small change, but would really improve the product

3. Autofocus. Don't get me wrong, the autofocus works decently, but depending on the room lighting, it may constantly refocus. I found I have to have a decent amount of room lighting and not just the camera's ring light, in order to avoid it continuously refocusing.

Those are just my three suggestions on how this product could be easily improved (well, the first two at least).

Don't get me wrong though. It's a good camera for the price. You get a built-in light that is dimmable (with a lot of flexibility and not just two or three stages of dimming). You also get a remote that will allow you to zoom in. The remote even lets you temporarily shut off the video, sort of like a software privacy shutter that resets whenever you restart your recording/web conf session.

title: Very convenient for cars that don't have Android Auto or Apple Car play
text:
I was very skeptical over plenty of these standalone units that say they offer Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, but I purchased this one just to try one out because I wanted to have one in my 2015 Nissan Altima. First impressions were pretty good actually everything was in the box packed very neatly, however I could tell the film on the suction cup was replaced there were a ton of air pockets under the film, I was going to wait to put it in my car, but now I needed to check and made sure it wasn't used before.

I turn on the unit and check Bluetooth settings and it was connected to someone else's phone. I am not happy with paying full price for something that was used, but everything was in perfect condition, so for now I'm fine with it because its like new.

Took a little bit to get it to work, the instructions are very vague and not well put together. It does work and it's running nicely. It is a bit slow here and there, but if you let it run for around 15 - 20 minutes it'll run smoothly. First day of using it was pretty good, but I will update this review if anything comes up with the device.

PROS
Car charger has 2 USB ports.
Has both Android Auto and Apple CarPlay.
Can do wired and wireless connections.
Has compatibility with USB Flashdrives and MircoSD cards for music.
Has a mic for Google Assistant or Siri.
Has its own volume and home buttons.
Can act as a Bluetooth receiver for cars that don't have Bluetooth.
Comes with 1 cable management clip.
CONS
Arrived used.
Suction cup is not strong enough to hold on the dashboard.
Is slow when it starts up for the first 15 minutes.
Sometimes has trouble connecting to my phone.
UI doesn't look modern.
Aux Cord is cheaply made.
Made in China. (You get the picture.)

All in all it's a very convenient option if you have a car that doesn't have Android Auto or Apple CarPlay built in. If you are like me constantly looking at products like this with very little insight from reviews, I hope this will help with your decision.

title: almost perfect!
text:
This is a really nice bag. I have a 16" MacBook Pro and it fits in here perfectly. The padding is soft and thick to protect my Mac and it slides easily in and out of its little pocket. Speaking of pockets - there are plenty of them. I really like the zippered outside pockets where I can keep things handy and better organized than my last bag. They are also within easy reach. I keep pens and business cards in one and a baggy filled with cables in the other. I'm sure this may change over time as I use this more. there are also inside mesh pockets which work great to hold my mouse, a video adapter, and my USB converter attachment. The main inside pocket is where my power cable goes and there's still room for more. There are also outside pockets on each side that do not zip down, but you can slide in books or other things that you need ready access to and don't need secured.

I like that it comes with both handles and a carry strap. The thing about the shoulder carry strap, though, is that it attaches on the flat sides of the bag rather than the ends, which I find odd. I did know this when I ordered it, because it's shown in the photos, of course. So far that hasn't been an issue, but I've not taken this on a airplane trip yet, so we'll see how that goes. Oh, the strap on the one side to slide this onto the handle of a carry-on suitcase is great. It is just slightly too small for my REI carry-on suitcase handle, though. I did manage to get it on there, but it is a really tight fit over the handle and then slides easily once its on the bars.

I have not tried the power adapter yet, but the inside USB came damaged - it somehow got squished. Also as noted in the product description, you need to have your own power supply, this is just the adapter cables. One thing the description states is that the cables are removable from the inside - but they are not - at least not that I can figure out how without getting a tiny screwdriver out and removing the entire thing.

Bottom line is that it is a nice bag with plenty of storage and a padding. If I can repair the USB cable it just might be a 5-star bag.

title: A fantastic pair of headphones- GREAT VALUE
text: [[VIDEOID:ed37edc384541d51266e51e751494e86]] I love these headphones!  I’ll start with the case, I love that it is smaller than other cases I’ve seen in this style of head phone, the USB C charging is a huge plus for me as I can’t stand the devices I still have with the mini USB.  I also really like that the display is on the inside of the case cover – I prefer it that way as sometimes in can be annoying to have the display flashing.  As far as the headphones are concerned themselves, they are just perfect at this price point.  Very sleek from a design standpoint.  They fit me very comfortably, but also come with additional pads so you can adjust to fit.  They stay on when I workout and not only that, they also stay in – I’ve had other headphone that stay on your ear, but wiggle free as you exercise – that is not the case with these in my experience.  I love the controls, it’s easy to play/pause and adjust volume on the headphones themselves, for me it’s very frustrating to have to go to my device to pause or adjust volume – so good functionality is a must here me.  These connect very quickly to my device and have great range.  With other headphones I would be able to tell which room in the house I left my device in based on when the Bluetooth started cutting out.  With these headphones I often have no idea where I left my device because the Bluetooth doesn’t stop working, definitely a good problem to have!  The battery life is fantastic – I have them running all day when I work from home listening to the radio while I work or on standby as I use them for calls too.  I’ve never had to charge them out of necessity, I just throw them on the charger every couple of days overnight.  The sound quality is great too – I love that they get very quiet when I’m in a quiet setting and don’t need them very loud, a vast difference from other headphones I’ve had that just don’t have those lower volume settings.  I would highly recommend these for about any use as they’ve passed the test for me for any situation I’ve used them in.

title: This Watch Uses The FitCloud Pro App
text:
I'm new to smart watches but wanted to try one with my Android phone. I wasn't looking for a lot of features as even with pricier smart watches, I would take all the health data with a big grain of salt (i.e. heart rate, blood pressure, blood oxygen). I wanted a smart watch for more simple things like date/time and select push notifications.

I'm not using any of the sport trackers but it also tracks steps and has a drink water or 'move' reminders. There's also a camera integration feature to let you shake the watch to take selfies (on a 3 second timer).

The sleep tracker is interesting to me to see that data.

Of course, one that's nice looking with lots of digital faces that can be swapped in was also important. I chose Lige as they had multiple models on Amazon and seem to be a reputable smart watch manufacturer.

This watch exceeded my expectations. Battery life is good but the charger could be better designed so it stays put better.

The watch uses a 22mm wide strap so my photo has an aftermarket strap but the two that this came with the watch are fine and can do the job.

From the product photos on Amazon, it looked like the bezel was its own physical object but it's really the numbers under the glass. The glass edge is angled but it's a solid smooth surface. I was hoping it was its own bezel but it looks fine.

I also tried another smart watch from Lige using the DaFit app. There are way more watches that use DaFit over FitCloud Pro. On Android, DaFit is 10MM+ downloads and FitCloud Pro is 1MM+ but for me, I find FitCloud Pro to be better as I could select each app that I wanted push notifications for on the watch whereas with DaFit, they had a list of popular apps but I wasn't able to select specific apps like Teams or Slack.

So, besides looking at the hardware, do some homework on the app that the watch will use. Sadly, not all watch listings disclose the app that the watch uses or you have to read the entire description to find the name of the app.

title: Lasted one month... (update) but failed for an unexpected reason.
text:
Ok, decided to tear it open as it was "heavier" on one side. It had two dummy plastic spacers in place of some actual cells. Now this isn't a problem as the pack is stated 2200 mah and should have been 14.8 volts so 4 cells is correct. (edit) The cell voltages were tested and I suspected them being of very low quality. I tested each one and the voltages were all over the place (the BMS obviously gave up trying and failed the pack). I had one at 1.9v, one at 2.3v, another at 3.6v and one at a flat 1 volt. Anything below 3 volts is basically dead for a lithium ion battery. 2.5 volts is considered over discharge-cutout. Maybe I got a bad one.

(update a few days later)... ok, had some free time and was looking for a battery to replace a failed 18650 in a wine opener. So decided maybe one of the cells in this month old laptop battery may suffice so cleaned them off and put them in my Cadex battery analyzer... oops - I may have jumped the gun on the quality of the cells specifically in my review above. These were in a severally mismatched and overdischarged state when I opened the battery pack, I assumed that like most of these cheap packs online, the cells were "C" grade at best. It really is rare that a BMS fails since they are far cheaper to make than the batteries so, tend to be commodities. In this case, the pack did fail due to the BMS, it simply failed and let the cells go out of balance and overcharge/discharge. The cells, very surprisingly, were apparently good quality. They came back from the dead (a feat in itself), and conservatively passed their ratings. Low ESR, averaged over 2350mah (2200 rated) each, with two over 2400mah, all tested at IEEE .2c rates. So, the batteries were good, the failure was electronic. Honestly I am surprised, as it is "almost always" the batteries/cells that get cheaped out on. I changed my rating, increased as it appears this was a manufacturing defect, not a quality control or fake advertised, issue.

title: Solid tube on a budget
text:
I'm a photographer with gear acquisition syndrome for lights, especially RGB ones. I've been eyeing some of the brand name tubes for a while, but ordered this one hoping it would perform similarly. And I've been pleasantly surprised. In the hand, it is very well built and does feel like one of those "premium" brands. And there are nice little touches that, to me, make it stand out from similar products at a similar price point. Things like magnetic mounts, rubber ends (rather than just plastic), the aluminum housing, etc. The battery remaining estimate seems to be pretty spot on and is a feature I can't believe I lived without; all of my other lights just say "60% remaining", this one says "2hr 11min".

For output, it's about what you'd expect. I'd love to say it blows me away with the amount of light it produces, but that wouldn't be accurate. It's not dim by any means, but really does need to be right next to whatever you're shooting to really be effective as more than an accent. For those folks using it for models and product photography, this will really hit the mark. For those of us that shoot portraits, the 1' version of this product is just enough to act as an accent or fill, not a key. Especially at fully saturated colors where you're only using one or two of the emitter sets inside.

Control from the onboard menu is super intuitive and after only a couple weeks of use, I'm almost getting to the point where I don't even need to look at the buttons to get where I want. The multiple parameters per preset (HSI for colors, as an example, rather than just output and color) are really powerful. I don't use the app because I don't like too many 3rd party apps on my phone, but have never felt lacking without.

I will complain that I miss the days of removable batteries so you can charge and use at the same time. The USB-C input does allow for, essentially, continuous use, but it's not truely wireless

Absolutely no diode imaging in the lens. I have been considering ordering a couple of the 2' lengths to use in photos/video as special effects. If they come out in a 3' version, let me know.

title: Way cheaper than Bose! Try them!!
text:
I recently purchased these sunglasses. I removed everything from the box and they powered on quickly. 0HO Sunshine popped up in my Bluetooth. There was nothing else I needed to do to connect them.

Right away I listened to some music and it sounded pretty good. As other reviewers have said the base is not strong but I don’t particularly like a strong base anyways.

Then I put on a podcast. You can tell when a professional podcaster are speaking directly into the microphone. You can hear very well. When they are talking to a “guest” who may be calling into the show, the guest’s voice sounded a little bit softer. I also tried them while I had a fan on in my home to see if I could hear over the noise of the fan. I could.

Here’s what I will say about the volume and other people hearing what you’re listening to… At about 25% volume I can hear faintly (but not exact words) across the room. I have to crank it up to over 75% to really hear it as someone else would say of you were walking down the street. I don’t think anybody could really hear all of the lyrics and exactly what you are listening to.

As for a phone call, I would feel comfortable taking a phone call, but I would not have the volume all the way up so others could hear what I was saying… of course if I was walking by myself, no one could really hear anyway, but for example, if you were around a lot of people, and you want to complete 100% privacy than that would not be guaranteed wearing the sunglasses.

All in all I think they are a great purchase for $32! I could literally by 10 pair of these sunglasses for the price of one pair of Bose sunglasses. The frame is a lightweight plastic I think if you were very rough or dropped them you would have a problem. But at this price point, I am not concerned about them lasting longer than a year. These are definitely worth a shot! I am excited to wear them as I live in a warm climate and it gets so hot and humid and sweaty here esp with AirPods slipping out (even the pro!)I feel like the glasses will stay on and deal!! Buy them!

title: AIWORTHLESS for podcasts
text:
I use MP3 players to listen to podcasts while I work or at the gym. This thing is USELESS to me

1. It's not touchscreen, even though it says it is. It has buttons that guide navigation, and the buttons are on the screen

2. The buttons are alternatively far too sensitive (forward and back) or almost completely dead (play/pause, on/off), making navigation and unending nightmare

3. The above two points are pretty much moot because the ultra shiny reflective screen makes it impossible to read the screen unless you're literally in the dark

4. If someone is talking to you while you're listening, good luck. Can't just hit one button to pause...need to hit on/off several times to illuminate the buttons, then it takes usually 5 or 6 taps at play/pause to make it actually pause.

5. most of the time, it doesn't bookmark, meaning if you're midway through a podcast, if you stop and this sack of crap turns off, you need to fast forward back to where you were

6. for no reason at all, when user unplugs aux jack, the screen will illuminate, usually resulting in an unwanted skip to the prior or next song due to the extremely sensitive nature of those buttons

7. despite what they say, YOU CANNOT IMPORT PLAYLISTS. have to assemble playlists within the device, which is a very slow and clunky process. also you are stuck with their laughably useless names playlist 1, playlist 2 and playlist 3, which cannot be changed.

8. volume maxes out at an absurdly low level.

9. good luck getting the bluetooth to work at all

10. sometimes it just wont power on unless you depress on/off for 30 seconds

11. instructions are useless and nothing more than circular prose translating to haha i got your money, sucker

and i consider myself lucky because the battery life of my unit is pretty good

I FEEL SCAMMED BY AMAZON as they featured this piece of trash as a "TOP SELLER".

title: It is not usb c.
text:
To preface I bought 6.6ft usb C cables with the device since it says in the info section that it comes with its own usb c cables.

But that had to be a typo on their behalf, it uses micro usb, so wasted my money on those cables.

I'm using the screen as a secondary monitor, it does, support 1920x1080, but it's native resolution is much better since you can still read text. I put discord full screen at native and it's perfect size, easy to read.

The lack of color range shows on static images
But it still looks decent enough, and on youtube videos or other casual viewing it doesn't bother me. The color settings work well to get a desired white. I was able to get close to my other monitor as to not be jarring when looking at whites between both screens.

Blacks are probably some of the worst I've seen on an IPS, but that's expected with its low contrast ratio.

There is, what I assume is the backlight bleeding through the top of the shell, but it's not distracting. But on the viewing area of the screen it's a uniform dark Grey.

This stand only has one angle, but it fits for my purpose. But if you have a weird arrangement or want more control you'll need a third party tablet mount, a Vesa mount would probably be a bit overkill.

The review might sound negative, but it's more to temper expectations, but it's otherwise a good small monitor, if you prefer to have a smaller screen on your desk to watch youtube while doing other tasks or have a program like discord in constant view so you don't miss anything. I personally don't need a 15-24in screen to benefit from the second display. It's built for a purpose and it satisfies those conditions.

edit:

I setup the touch screen with Windows 11 and its really awesome, it works like a smart phone touch screen and you can use its touch screen to interact with windows or apps on the monitor while keeping your mouse cursor where it is on your main monitor. So you can tap on the chat box in discord to type without having to move your cursor over to it.

title: Best lap desk on the market!
text:
I’ve spent over a decade trying to find the perfect products for a laptop lap desk and a book stand so I can do my homework in comfort. This product does both and it’s better than any other lap desk or book stand I’ve ever bought. I bought a black Mind Reader lap desk a couple years ago to keep in my car for use wherever I went without worrying about it getting dirty. It’s held up great and still looks exactly the same. It’s got a set of cushions on the bottom that angle the lap desk towards you without the usual legs most other lap desks have (which can dig into your thighs after a while). The surface lifts opens like a trash can lid, and underneath it adjusts so you can hold whatever you’re reading at a specific angle. This is nice when you’re positioning a laptop to be more ergonomic. It also has a ledge so whatever you’re reading doesn’t fall off. The ledge is sturdy enough to hold just about anything you might want to read. As you can see in my pictures, you can use it to hold small books if you have a book clip so you don’t have to tire your hands out holding it (especially important if you’re also typing), but it also holds dense thousand-page books, large hardcover textbooks, and 2-inch filled binders. I only have two sizes of laptops, so I can only confirm for sure that it can handle up to 15-inch laptops. I absolutely love this product and use it regularly. I highly recommend it for college students and those who work from home. I do wish is that the cushions and the base they’re attached to came in different colors (just like the surface lid does). I also wish the cushions were removable, machine washable, and replaceable as I know that some day they will get dirty or start to fall apart and you can’t put this in the washing machine or switch them out for new ones. Once they go bad, I’ll just have to toss the whole product. Who knows if this seller will still have these in stock by then. I hope so as I’d like to always keep at least one in my office.

Don’t bother with other lap desks. This is the one to buy.

title: Extraordinarily Extravagant
text:
[[VIDEOID:84a4036d9b8a0ad99d2e1e6b9f7c0a6f]] I had the older SL120s installed previously before these were released since the Lian Li Galahad AIO came with them so I ordered 3 more to fill up the case. My rear exhaust fan started dying so I decided to replace all of them with the infinity fans.

As far as performance specs go, the numbers are out there for your own viewing pleasure if you want to get into specifics but I won't bother doing so. There are many fans out there that would be better bang for your buck if you wanted pure performance. While these are no slouch in the cooling department, the main reason you're even thinking of buying these is how nice they look and how easy they are to install.

Looks are great, as expected from the amount of visuals they crammed into 1 fan. If you're not wanting the gaudiness of it then you have the option of turning off lights or choosing the SL120s or something to keep the ease of daisychain.

The fans themselves come packaged with peel off covers over all mirrored sections to protect them during shipping. The connection/daisychain method is just as easy as the SL120 though in a different location on the fan(centered instead of to the side).

The fan hubs for these are NOT the same as the ones for the SL120 so if you're replacing those in your system you will have to remove the old hubs to install the ones that come with the infinity fans. In a fresh build this isn't a problem but if caught unaware, replacing these in an older build may take more time than anticipated. The fan hub also requires 2 15pin SATA connections so make sure you have the space for it.

These are definitely not a mandatory item for your build as the main appeal is aesthetics but it is nice that they also do not skimp on performance. The price tag is also fairly substantial; you could buy other fans that perform the same for less money but I knew what I was getting into before purchase.

Overall I'd give it more like a 4.5/5 but that's really only because I wish the Lconnect3 software had more LED pattern options.

title: Good little camera
text:
Upon package opening...
-Packaging was very nice, I appreciated the foam used to ensure that the camera was held in place and protected from impact damage.
-The USB plug I think could use modification. As it is right now, it sticks directly out from the wall. It would be nice if there was an option for the cord to be set at a 90 degree angle, which would save space if the plug is placed behind an item of furniture. This would also allow better integration with a cord hiding system that would be flush with the wall.
-I am not a fan of the USB micro cable. It would be a good upgrade to have the camera's attached via USB-C.

Setup
-I decided that I would mount this camera to the ceiling for this test. The included mounting plate was very nice and appreciated, as were the extra screws and plugs.
-I experienced no issues setting the camera up on my wifi, the application worked well in this.
-The usb cable was long enough to reach, but as I mentioned before, a usb plug that allows a 90 degree input so that the cable starts flush with the wall would be a great boon.

Operation
-The camera functioned well. I found no issues with the baby monitoring system, nor the night vision upon my testing.
-The talk through function worked as expected
-The listening function worked well.
-The biggest issue I had was with the pan/tilt function.
-There is a noticeable lag when utilizing this function, which makes it hard to set up exactly where you want the camera to point to. My suggestion would be to put in two "scroll wheels" within the app, one for vertical movement and one for horizontal movement, for fine tuning the turning. It would be nice to have markers on the scroll wheels (like degrees of turning) to remember settings in the future.
-The camera itself worked well when moving about. It was smooth and experienced no issues.

Overall Impression
-It is a good little camera that just needs a few adjustments. I would definitely modify the ubs plug adapter, and switch the cable for a USB-C. I was not able to test the micro-sd capabilities of this camera at this time.

title: TOTALLY WORTH IT - 'online ESL teacher'
text:
I teach online and have for years. I used to use a multi head light and diffused and spent hours a day being blinded...

I got the "monitor light" and one of these to test for my second teaching set up ... and loved it.. I ended up getting
2 monitor lights (square) for my 27" monitor (only need one if you aren't old or don't have a green screen)
2 desk (long) for side lights for my green screen
1 more desk (long) light for an up-light on my green screen to prevent shadows when using a white board.

I look way better ... I don't even need a zoom filter to look younger!

In my "second" classroom I have 1 square "monitor light" and use the room light in the background (no green screen)... I'm using it with a cheap document camera that I use when I teach cooking classes and suddenly my cheap camera looks amazing (I have a logitech brio in my main classroom and this looks as good)

OVERVIEW
They are pretty (for lights)
The stand is heavy and supports the light well
The desk (long) light attached to a tripod with a screw top if you need them taller
The monitor lights are sturdy and adjust angle and height
many colors and brightness adjustments without software... (you can download software too I didn't bother)

they remember the last setting used when turning them on

**note you can not use a switched outlet to turn them on you need to press the power button.. not a deal breaker but good to know.. they do remember the last setting**

can use a USB c to USB B cord (included) or USB c to USB c cord (not included) and any brick they are low power. (I'm using OLD OLD iPhone bricks - like from an iPhone 4)

I tried these and cheaper ones.. my husband said 'THERE IS A HUGE DIFFERENCE GET THE BETTER LIGHT' with my second set up.. when I showed him my main set up he said "WORTH EVERY PENNY !! WOW!!"

title: Interesting but disappointing as well
text:
It's a great concept. It's basically a high end laptop without a display or keyboard/trackpad.

The instructions are sparse. They show tiny BIOS screens you can't read and provide minimal information. They show you the BIOS, but don't tell you how to access it. The BIOS itself is a cluttered mess and doesn't really provide much guidance compared to modern BIOS's I've used on other platforms.

It's got shiny, in the form of LED lights under the top cover and a bit of software is included that will allow you to configure those lights to some degree. The software indicates it can control a keyboard, but there's no indication of which brand of keyboard you may need for this.

Benchmarking leads to the conclusion that it's not making the most of the ram. There is no XMP mode in the bios. The system does report there are two extra ram slots available.

Interestingly, it included additional SSD drive mounting hardware indicating you could put an 2.5" SSD into it for extra storage. However, there is absolutely no instruction on what what to do with this hardware. I did attempt to open the unit by removing the four visible and very tiny screws on the bottom, but got no further in getting the unit apart to look inside.

The fan is loud. 46db loud. You'd want this mounted under a desk so as to minimize that noise.

The lack of any USB ports on the front of the unit means it's not for anyone that regularly needs to plug in thumb drives or other peripherals. You'll need to install a separate hub if you want convenience.

It's responsive to use, snappy, and seems to do a fine job, but the noise, inconvenience factors, and lack of instructions make this a very questionable product.

The two sticks of ram currently sell for $42 each as I write this and the internal NVME card can be found on Alibaba for $18.

For what it offers, it seems overpriced and inconvenient. I also really expect XMP to be available for any modern computer people will be using for gaming.

I'd give this one a pass.

title: These swabs make sensor cleaning easy and safe.
text:
I found that using these sensor cleaning sticks to clean my Canon 70D sensor was a lot less stressful than my previous technique of using a piece of lens cleaning pad folded over the end of a plastic paddle. While some may consider these to be somewhat expensive, cleaning your sensor is probably not something you should need to do very often and anything that makes the process go smoothly is worth the price.

It's important to make sure that a DSLR has a charged battery to prevent the mirror from attempting to close during lockup while you are in the middle of the cleaning procedure. And before using the swabs to do any wiping the sensor should be vigorously blown off with a rubber bulb blower. It will also help to have very good lighting on the face of the sensor before proceeding.

The instructions say that you should apply 1-2 drops of fluid to the swab. Waiting a few seconds will allow the entire edge of the swab to become wet. Then gently drag the swab from one edge to the other (I always use left to right) and in doing so you should see that the sensor face is wetted but then dries almost immediately as you drag the swab.

After this first pass I do deviate from the instructions a little however. Instead of making a reverse pass over the sensor I flip the swab and make another left to right pass (or the same direction as the first pass). This way any dust that is pulled off the surface either comes off with the swab or worst case stays on the right edge of the sensor.

Cleanliness of the sensor can be confirmed by taking the normal diffused light frames to look for dark spots, and repeating the procedure if necessary.

To maximize the use out of a pad I sometimes take the opportunity to use it over again to clean any filters (a much less critical use) before disposing of the swab. I have used this on expensive 2" narrowband astronomical filters by re-wetting any unused edge of the swab and wiping the filter in a circular spiral starting at the center and working outward.

These are not at all expensive considering that the proper pads and fluids for cleaning by other methods add up in price as well. These swabs make the job easy and safe. Recommended with 5 stars.

title: Disappointed
text:
I had high hopes. I bought this tv because I have a PS5 and because I trust Sony quality. I was upgrading from a $400 LG I had bought back in 2018. When you first set it up there's definitely a wow factor, but once you realize most of that is from the over saturation, over sharpening, ai processing, etc, and you actually calibrate the TV the wow is kind of just a "nice". Then the sound quality... Obviously if I want good sound I should have actual speakers, but the sound was just so... underwhelming from the TV. Muffled, no bass, flat. I played around with the settings and the best i could get it at was metallic sounding. The software is terrible. I love Google TV. I used a Chromecast with Google TV on my LG. However, that $50 Chromecast running Android 12 could run circles around this $1700 TV running Android 10. The tv software was slowly as can be. Slow to get from menu to menu. Slow to launch apps. And yes I was running the most up to date firmware. Then there's the apps. You have the play store which is great. Apple TV comes preloaded but the app doesn't work. You can't uninstall it, only uninstall updates and disable it. Tried that, followed by enabling. Tried clearing it's cache and data. Nothing. The only way I could get apple tv was by side loading the apk, then it worked. Then there are the weird quirks like not wanting to turn on. Sometimes the TV just refuses to turn on. No response from the remote, no response from the power button on the TV. The light is on, and it registers that a button is being pushed on the remote, but nothing happens. You have to unplug it from the power for a few seconds and plug it back in and then it lets you turn it on. Sometimes it turns on, in it's own, in the middle of the night. We've been woken up by a YouTube video resuming out of nowhere on the TV after we've turned the TV off. Creepy to say the least.

Just... Don't buy this TV. Even with all this said the TV is "fine". But I couldn't deal with all of it and ended up returning the TV because i didn't pay all the money for fine.

title: Exactly what I wanted/needed
text:
For a couple of years I've been on a quest to find an small, light, ultra portable computer that I would actually take with me. I wanted to avoid that subconscious bias that it would be too bulky and I wouldn't be using it that day anyway. I tried a few and settled on a Surface Go because it runs MS:Word and Scrivener and I couldn't play games on it.

Now I had to find a bag. Something just big enough to carry the computer and the various cords and accessories, but not big enough that I would weigh it down with extra junk that would trigger that subconscious bias and make it too bulky.

This bag fits the bill perfectly. It fits the Surface Go with plenty of room left over so it will work with a slightly bigger ultra portable.

In the main pocket I have enough room for the Surface Arc Mouse, Moleskin notepad, various pens, ear pods, power cable, hub, various other cables, a pack of tissues and some cinnamon gum. There is a special pocket for a thumb drive so you don't have to dig down under all those cables to find it. I also wrote my name in phone number on the lining inside the pocket with a sharpie in case someone finds it. There is some padding on the front of the main pocket as well so all that junk is a little protected too.

There is another pocket small pocket on the front, with enough room to put a small instruction manual and an Apple Air Tag. That is everything I would need to have with me under pretty much any circumstance except a portable battery which I wouldn't include because of heavy they are. YOU could put a portable battery in there if you didn't have as many misc. cables as I have. Again, for me it's the art of keeping it light.

In conclusion the bag is small, but big enough to carry what you'd need to have with your ultra portable. It's light and well made. The cons are, the 'Case Logic look' is a bit dated, but some of that is form following function. Also the strap doesn't have one of those padded bits on it, but to be fair its so light you don't need one. Note: I took the tissues and gum out for the picture so you could see the rest better.

title: First headphones with a bass (like the fish) EQ setting
text:
Right out of the package, these headphones are beautiful. I love the rose gold & white color combination.

I was able to pair the headphones with my iPhone 14 Pro quickly and easily. That’s when the problems started. Specifically:

1. The headphones are NOT comfortable. I have big ears, but I can usually find a comfortable setting with any of the almost 20 pairs of headphones I own. My ears kept hitting the inside mesh. The ear cup cushions didn’t maintain any distance between my ears and the plastic speaker cover.

2. The headphones feel really light and cheap. The plastic creaks and groans incessantly. I’m afraid to touch them for fear of breaking the cheap plastic.

3. The headphones come with a 3 foot long cable with 1/8” jacks on each end in case you wanted to use them in wired mode (without Bluetooth). This is not long enough to connect to a laptop on a desk or a handheld device unless you plan to hold it or keep it in a shirt pocket.

4. The controls don’t work correctly. The + and - buttons are dual function, controlling either the volume or the Prev / Next function. Controlling the volume works. The Prev function also works. But the Next (+) button only pauses the music. Even worse, hitting the next button again doesn’t restart the music. I was never able to find any combinations of button pushes that would skip to the next track.

5. The EQ button runs through a list of EQ settings, including Pop, Rock, Vocal, Jazz, Bass and Classic. The voice that announces the EQ setting pronounces “Bass” like the fish instead of the lower sound register. Frustratingly, there’s no “flat” EQ setting.

6. The sound quality of the headphones is poor. The bass is mushy, midrange is not clear, and the high end is non-existent.

Overall, I can’t recommend these headphones. Too many issues that even basic quality control should have easily caught.

title: A very good mid-class laptop with some interesting compromises
text:
The HP 17-cn2099nr is a very good mid-class laptop that is powerful enough to tackle most of your computing needs.

PROS:
- Intel i5-1235u processor
- 17.3" screen
- Backlit keyboard
- Fingerprint scanner
- 512GB SSD
- iRISxe graphics processor
- Lightweight for its size
- Decent quality built-in speakers
- Windows 11

CONS:
- 1600 x 900 screen resolution
- No ethernet port
- USB-C doesn't support video or charging
- 8MB ram

The 10 core 12 thread processor coupled with the 512GB SSD provides a snappy computing experience. While the 17-cn2099nr is not a gaming powerhouse, I found that it handled most of the games in my Steam library well enough to provide for a decent gaming environment. The limiting factor with games that I experienced was with 8MB ram, at least 16MB would have been more welcome. The 17.3" monitor has plenty of real estate for browsing and viewing media. The disappointing aspect of this monitor is that its limited to 1600 x 900 resolution. In today's environment of 4K gaming and media, this is a bit of a let down that we don't even get 1080p. In practical application, I only occasionally notice that the image is not quite as sharp as my laptop that has a 1080p screen.

Other than the monitor resolution, there was one other thing that was disappointing about the 17-cn2099nr. That is the USB-C port. The port does not support monitors or charging. This limits the utility of a docking station. A docking station will give you an ethernet port and additional USB ports, but you will not be able charge the laptop or use it to connect to an additional monitor.

The two negatives aside, overall, this is a great value laptop. It hits a nice compromise of features and price. If you are looking for a good mid-class laptop, you couldn't go wrong putting the 17-cn2099nr on your short list.

title: Actually holds up my ultrawide curved OLED pretty dang well!
text:
Now, the single "negative" before I get more into it. My ultrawide (AW3423DW, a very overpriced monitor I was very nervous about mounting the entire time because boy I don't think warranty covers "screwed up attaching an arm mount") does tilt down ever so slightly with this, even with tightening it the tension as tight as I physically could with both arms while wearing gloves and getting as much leverage as I could.

That said, the "tilt" is maybe a couple of degrees and I literally can't even tell while I'm looking at the screen. We're not talking those cheap mounts where your monitor is looking at the floor or something. It's VERY slight. But I know it might bother someone so I'm noting it. The only reason I even notice is because I can tell my second monitor is slightly straighter as they sit next to each other.

I'd have included images, but my desk is still such a mess (I have a very unusual desk with no back lip, luckily this comes with clamps AND grommet options so I was able to spend 5 seconds drilling a hole!) due to me being kind of unprepared to rearrange my entire desk. But I have a 34 inch Ultrawide curved display and a standard 16:9, 27-inch, which for the record doesn't tilt even a bit.

Setup was super easy. You attach it bit by bit instead of all at once (not sure how other arms do it, I've seen mounts in person but this is the first I've owned), so finding the perfect spot is very easy. They've got a wide range of motion, both horizontally, vertically, they tilt easily, etc. The tension adjustments worked great.

This has freed up an ENORMOUS amount of desk space! While modern monitor stands are... kind of low profile, they often come with two long prongs that, despite not taking up a lot of space per prong, just make a large portion of your desk unusable for much of anything. This is much lower profile, and the ability to just push both my monitors up and out of the way so I can use my desk as a desk is something I never knew I needed.

I highly recommend these arms, I'm very pleased with them.

title: They do the job for what I needed
text:
I'll be honest, I loose technology....often. As a result I never bought expensive earbuds. I would always buy the $30 and under option because inevitably I was going to misplace them and could not stomach the idea of loosing a $100 item within a few weeks of purchase. However after 3 years of COVID required zoom calls my coworkers chipped in and bought me the Google pixel buds. There was an immediate difference for me in regards to what I could hear and the experience for anyone talking to me on the other side. Here are the highlights

1. The noise cancellation works well. In the past people would complain they can't hear me clearly because of all the background noise. As if I were at a construction site when I simply was opening a bag of chips!

2. Sound quality is perfect. Can't tell you how many times with other earbuds I would be told can you get closer to the phone, or that I sounded far away, or was I underwater etc etc. But with these it's Crystal clear no issues at all.

3. Battery lasts long enough. I find that these last most of my work day. I tend to average about five hours of meetings a day and in that capacity they last.

4. Charge speed is quick. When I do need to charge these for from 0-100% in like 20mins. To be fair I don't think I have ever let them get to 0. Overall I don't find myself charging them often and the charging case really does do a good job of charging the actual buds quickly if I do run into a problem.

5. Ear buds do slip out. I have found an occasion that a slight tap will accidentally send the earbuds falling out of my ear. I've changed the size of the ear cushion but doesn't really seem to lock in well like other earbuds I have tried. So that is one point off for them but nothing insurmountable that would detract from the overall score.

Overall for the price I think these are great. So much so that I did in fact lose the ones my coworker bought me within about 6 weeks and ended up buying my own pair thankfully they were on sale. We'll see how long these last before I lose them!

title: Garbage Prebuilt
text:
I rarely leave reviews for products, but I felt I needed to for this one. I bought a relatively high spec Omen (30l, RTX 3080, i9-10900K) back in November 2021 and it was great until reliability issues started to creep up late last year. The system would freeze (no blue screen but the screen would freeze and audio would hang) which would require a hard reboot. This happened when playing current gen demanding games. I talked to their support rep. and they had me ship it back for repairs under warranty.

The repair procedure went smoothly and was quick, so no complaints there. HP replaced the GPU and everything seemed to be working fine. That was up until last night when playing The Last of US Part 1. This game is like a GPU/CPU stress test as all fans are very audible while playing. After starting from a saved game the power to the system just shut off like it was unplugged all of a sudden. I checked all cables and nothing had shifted or had moved (I have the tower sitting on my desktop). Tried unplugging the power cable, holding the power button for 10 seconds, and plugging it back in. Nothing. The system is effectively dead and I am out of warranty. I am almost positive the PSU died.

I have built many PCs over the years but bought this prebuilt as it was very difficult to find a 3-series Nvidia GPU at the time of purchase, so I went for this Omen. I am very disappointed as two major components had issues in the <1.5 years I have owned the system: GPU and PSU. The GPU was replaced under warranty but I'll have to pay for a replacement PSU out of pocket. Based on my experience, these are not reliable. I'll have to wait until later this week to see if the new power supply fixes it.

**UPDATE**
I received the new power supply and installed it today. Nothing. It's still dead. No lights, clicking, or buzzing. I can hear the power supply click after turning it on using the physical switch but nothing from the rest of the PC. I would give this no stars if I could. Will be returning the power supply and contacting HP to see what they can do for me. Do not buy this PC. The reliability is horrendous.

title: Sounds Great - Easy to Use
text:
I use the wi-fi connection & mostly Airplay.

When I first connected the device to wi-fi it worked the first time. Setup took less than 5 minutes!
It connects to my Apple Airplay devices easily. I haven't experienced any glitches connecting. I'm using the "All in One" setting.

I also plugged a USB memory stick into the back. It plays these FLAC files easily. It also finds the files on my Windows 10 computer. If I leave the computer "on", it'll play music from my computer. (for these 2 uses, I'm using the iFi App and iFi Web Browser page (ifi.local) .
BTW, updating the firmware via the App is simple.

I never power the unit "off" - it virtually never loses connection. I've only had to reboot it twice in over a year.

I stream Deezer HiFi (CD Quality, losless) and Apple Music (losless) files through the native Deezer and Apple Music Apps. I can't hear any difference between streaming services and the local FLAC files.
I'm using a Topping linear power supply with the unit. (it's slightly better than the iPower unit that it came with). Someday I may buy a more expensive linear power supply.

I have another streamer -- Mono Ultra MkII - made in Holland. It cost $1,100. It has a little more clarity and a little better instrument separation, but it sounds brighter. I prefer the warmer (more "musical" tone of the iFi) for 80% of the music that I play.

I listen to: Jazz, Pop and Classical mostly.
My system after the streamer is:
HoloAudio Spring 2 KTE DAC
Luxman SQ-N150 integrated amp (EL-84 tube amp)
Tekton Perfect Set Speakers &
Triangle Genese Trio Speakers.

Overall, I like this streamer a lot. Especially the "tone", which is on the warm side -- smooth and not digital sounding.

title: NOT 6FT LONG
text:
This cord is not even close to 6FT long. It will maybe reach 3 feet, but it has significant tension at any length past the 12 inch length of the coiled cord. I wanted to like it, I’ve given it a chance, but I LOATHE these chargers.
I cannot stand using these unless I am not using my phone with them. Having something constantly pulling my phone out of my hands, making me have a death grip on my phone just to use it, is absolute torture, and makes my hands and wrists cramp. If you have any health issues with your hands or wrists, I would highly discourage using these.
I don’t even like using this in the car because the cord is tight and pulls even when I’m sitting in the passenger seat right beside the charger.

They seem to charge at a good rate, but I would say above average charging speed rather than lightning charge.

If you have sensory issues with sound, or you are able to hear the whine of electronics, this charger very often emits a loud high pitched whining sound (a lot of people don’t hear it) while charging. Most phone chargers only make this sound when the device is fully charged, this cord emits the sound about 5 minutes after being plugged in, and continues until being unplugged. It‘s very annoying.

These cords have the normal USB end (instead of the usb-c) and can plug into the normal USB ports, so that’s a bonus.

I did find a charger that doesn’t make the whining sound when fully charged, and that is: https://www.amazon.com/Certified-Charger-GEONAV-Lightning-Charging/dp/B0B5L6QHMZ?
It has two cords and one USB-C charging block that both cords can plug into. The cords are USB-C instead of the usual USB cord that can plug into your pc, but that’s the only drawback. They also charge fast.

TL:DR
These chargers are annoying and keep pulling my phone out of my hands and they make an annoying whining sound while charging, but they charge ok. Do not recommend.

title: Good safe chargers.
text:
I own an iPhone 13 Pro and an older iPad. I am always looking for chargers that will charge them faster and at the same time be safe. I saw these and asked Amazon to test them.

There are sites on the internet that speak about the possible dangers of rapid chargers for iPhones. From what I read it appears that some can overheat your battery, which degrades it faster. I am not an expert and some may disagree. I tend to believe it based on some of the sources I have read.

My wife has a Puregear charger. It is faster than these chargers but it really heats up the phone in a short time. I used the Puregear charger for this review and it added about 20% more battery power than these chargers in a 9-minute time period. It varied a little depending on how low a charge the phone had. I tested them several times. The phone does not seem to heat up much with these chargers. Although, the converter box that plugs into the electrical outlet does get a little warm.

The website says that when the phone is charged at 80% these chargers automatically go into something it calls "smart stack tickle mode." It says it prolongs the battery on your phone. I am guessing that it slows down the charging process as it nears charging the phone, which the site says is to prevent "overcharging."

There is one minor problem with the USB-C connector on the connecting cord. See photo. When I travel abroad I like to take as few chargers and converters as possible. I have a universal adapter that will accommodate up to 3 USB plugs. See photo. I can't bring this cord unless I bring the converter itself because my adapter doesn't have a USB-C slot. This is certainly not something major but you need to keep it in mind when packing.

Overall I like these converters. It is great that they are MFI certified. I had no problem hooking them up to either my phone or iPad. They charged both quickly compared to just using a USB slot. Looking at prices they are a little bit more expensive than some of the other similar chargers but the difference is not much.

title: Sad I Am
text:
This is Coool! Fits in the palm of your hand and really has a couple needed attribute, if I could get it to work.

Several great aspects puts this one ahead of the other, that is currently available.
Namely a "Safe" Off button. MOL 10 second press on the button before it then safe to power off. Factually, it powers Off on it's own. A momentary press of the same button powers ON or wakes the OLED from sleep mode.
Secondly is the micro SDHC card remote insertion slot.

The SSD DB has a few assigned tasks other than simply SSD place holder.
Sustem Power supply by way of the DB is naturally attached to the Safe Off button, the OLED input is by way of the DB as are Fan and LED power as well.

Assembly is somewhat tedious but following the instructions for the order is the way of it. As Founder and Chairman of Save and Preserve tiny Screws Foundation I was thankful these weren't the smallest I've had to deal with; with perhaps exception of the SSD attachment screw.

This is not to say assembly didn't require a couple do overs, after full assembly and particial disassembly to redo or verify direction of FFC (ribbon) insertion. Only in sod planting is it intuitive that the green side goes up.
Only once in the instructions did the writers find it needed to point out which direction for the Blue strip. The only occurrence when it wasn't intuitive, to the writer, or me.

There has been a remark a time or two about the wires from the fan to power pins being too short. It depends on your approach. Don't install the fan onto the more distant plexiglass. One side is 13mm from the Ice Cooler, which is very close placing the fan nearly directly above to the pin connectors, while the other plexi plastic is 28mm distant.

They are currently unavailable both here and on there website; perhaps working on DB bug. The Daughter Board was T.U. on arrival. Nearly 3 three weeks and no response from seller, until today.
I'm torn between how Coool this case is and carp customer service.

title: Works great but be mindful you may have to trim a third party skin or case at the USB port
text:
Pros:
Able to play apps and games on the Steamdeck on a HDTV of various sizes and ultrawide curved computer monitors. Don't expect anything out of the deck effectively over 75hz for refresh rate. Keep your expectations low and your resolutions medium to low and enjoy a great framerate! ( 4k gaming is heavily overrated as framerate, neteork speed and input latency are way more important)

Wired internet gets the job done solidly for game downloads and video streaming in Game and Desktop modes.

Accepts various USB-A mice, keyboards, amd gamepads (up to 3 without an additional hub. ) Had success with Nintendo Switch HORI and Power A wired controllers. PS4 HORI dogbone wired controllers work. PS4 wired dualshock is maybe the best as the touchpad surface can act as a cursor movement and as a click.

Audio and video are amazing. If your display does not have speakers, the Steamdeck's (2023) speakers are pretty good.

These docks may barely fit a case on it, so be careful. But when it does fit, it does good.

Dock helps make the $399 Steamdeck the best student, creative tablet/PC or daily driver computer AND gaming/entertainment machine for the cost. The Desktop Mode with the Proton software layer may help tou be able to run some Win apps/tools ans games.

Feels solid and grips surface.

Cons:
Depending on the skin or case you add to the Steamdeck, you may have to trim them with a fine tiny blade or scissors to get its power/ data plug to fit in flush with actual surface of the deck. Only use the Valve/Steamdeck charger adapter that comes with it, so that it charges properly and won't overcharge your Steamdeck.

Maybe a Steamdeck issue or a dock one, or even a game by game technical issue, beware of changing a gamepad type mid game and/or going from monitor/TV to the Steamdeck screen. Your game may become unresponsive until you restart the game. It is not as smooth and reliable as the Nintendo Switch's screen and controller type switching flow bouncing between controller types and external displays.

title: Definitely easier to crimp than average, but a bit fiddly and wildly expensive
text:
I had a build project where I needed to crimp a ton of connectors in short notice, so the promise of a faster solution held a lot of appeal. This isn't a bad product, but I see it as designed for a very specific purpose: rapidly crimping keystone jacks when you don't have a solid surface to work with. The crimping tool is nicely made and can crimp these while held in your hand. But the process is a little fiddly, still.

To crimp, you need to:

1- strip the wire and untwist all the ends. So far, the same as a regular jack. You also need to add some metal shielding tape, included.
2- Pull the wires out and nestle them in the various channels. There's a color guide for A and B, which is nice. What's not nice is the cables fall out of their channels unless you use the included punchdown tool or your fingernail or something. So much for "easier" - twisting them into their channels was an exercise in frustration.
3- Crimp. You'll need to remove the top metal shield for this - the instructions make it super non-obvious and it isn't immediately apparent that it's removable and not hinged. On the plus side, rad blades come up from the sides to cut off the excess wire in one step, so that's cool.
4 - Put a termination block over top of your wires, then cover it with the metal shell you set aside.
5 - IMHO, the worst part of this whole kit: add a zip tie to hold the cover on. Why is this not a snap-to-fit piece? Having to get out my nippy cutters to cut off the ziptie end defeats the whole purpose of a rapid tool, and the zip tie makes the finished product look unprofessional and amateurish.

So... it's a bit shorter than a normal keystone jack, but only by a few moments. For that time savings, you pay a huge cost premium - make sure to look at the consumable costs before springing for this tool set, because I don't find the costs to be reasonable given the modest time savings involved.

title: Solid mid-market camera security setup!
text:
There's so much to this I fully suggest reading all the listing content, watch the video and head to the manufacturer's website to get a full grip on how extensive this is. It can easily be a one-stop solution for security because the cam can be rotated in all directions and do so thru the Wifi app. Now being 2K is more than enough for most applications and FHD (1080p) really gives a ton of detail. So the 2K here is nice to use and doesn't seem to overload the bandwidth but with the SD card slot you could easily store high quality video that way when needed. The App can leave a little bit to be desired, Engerish in places and weak QA/QC can get on your nerves but you can make it all work in the end. Doesn't seem to crash like other china-based cam systems around which is a plus.

The housing is waterproof and weather-resistant, I'm in NE Ohio and there is no such thing as weather-proof because I've seen stuff claiming "proof" that was taught a new lesson. But the cam and the solar unit are very tough and will last you for awhile.

Nice portion is the solar panel large enough to store up a charge and run the cam continually so you don't have to put this where you could get some power wired in or have an external outlet. This is great for anti-theft, you can mount this up in the air where it's not easily seen nor grabbed by thieves. I don't know how many anti-theft mounts I see for the video doorbell stuff because people simply rip them out and walk with them. Motion detection is solid, Night vision is crisp in almost any light and all round it's not bad for the buck.

There is a service you can use is nice but as always - at a cost. The 2.4G Wifi means no 5Ghz but then again the 2.4G is the most deployed out in the wild so you should be able to install it easily. Now allowing others to see your cam feed isn't ever a fantastic idea in general, but if you have seniors or handicapped family you want to be able to keep a remote eye on their surroundings, etc. this work perfectly for all that.

title: This USB-A Format Drive Handles Large Backups Fast
text:
This review is for the ORICO USB 3.2 Gen 2 standard (USSD) Flash Drive, advertised to have read and write speed up to 520MB/s.

As anyone who has been looking can tell you, the specs for USB 3.x connectors (and therefore drives with these connectors) can be really confusing. The packaging for this drive is labelled as a 256GB USB 3.1 Gen 2 version of a USB Solid State Flash Drive (USSD) and claims 520MB/S speed. I tested the drive in the USB 3.1 port of my (circa 2017) Dell XPS 8930 Desktop by copying 42.7GB of backup files from the internal hard drive to the Orico Flash Drive. This task was completed in 2.5 minutes (= 150 seconds), which equates to an average write speed of ~285MB/sec. The fastest USB 3.0 Flash Drives I’ve tested in the last 6 months have reached peak write speeds of just 36MB/sec, so this is a noticeable improvement. Windows 10 Task Manager showed peak write speed during this task of 365MB/sec (see photo), but this was not a constant rate; the speed throttling is likely due to the read-speed being limited by the source hard drive.

Like most fast flash drive, Orico’s drive heats up under continuous use; their temperature graph (see photo) shows a temperature of about 35C / 95F after 2.5 minutes of operation. They claim that this is significantly cooler than comparable USSD drives which is certainly possible. Using a Thermal Camera, I checked my Orico drive during the 42.7GB transfer. I found the drive to heat up to about 97F at the USB connection point while the opposite end warmed to about 82F – Noticeable heating but not too-hot-to-touch by any means and consistent with their graph.

CONCLUSION: This Orico drive’s performance is reasonably close to what is claimed. Even in an older desktop machine, this USB-A format Flash Drive was fast, making it a plausible choice for those who need to store larger size file backups. At its current price point, you are paying a premium for this speed and so it will not be for everyone.

title: Sleek Simple but Tinny
text:
For what I was looking for this was perfect, the only reason for less than 5 stars is that the audio down button doesn't work. But, I don't plan to use the volume controls (the controls on the keyboard & mouse work fine with it), so for my purposes that wasn't an issue. Just makes you wonder what else might fail.

SLEEK: My wife wanted speakers that looked clean and took up no real estate on her desk. These are perfect - they almost look like they are part of the monitor. I love the way it snugs up to the bottom of the monitor, doesn't cut into the screen at all, and leaves the DELL logo on the center bottom of the monitor unaffected.

SIMPLE: plug in the USB, it works. The system is running Windows 11.

OTHER:

- MONITOR THICKNESS: I almost didn't buy this because one reviewer said the monitor couldn't be thicker than 1/2". But the manufacturer said it would work on up to 1". I took a chance. This monitor is 3/4". It attached with no problems and a tiny bit of room to spare.

- SOUND QUALITY: Personally, I wouldn't be happy with these speakers because of the tinny, shallow audio. But that's not an issue for my wife - she doesn't listen to anything where quality audio is important to her. For her, the sleekness and simplicity were top of her want list. Personally I'd say they were a very small step up from laptop speakers. When I travel, I carry a JBL Flip which connects by Bluetooth.

- USB cable: it's probably long enough for most people but our setup needed a USB extension. That worked as it ought.

- THE "ON" LIGHT: There's a little green light that's on all the time. If that becomes an issue I'll cover it with some black electric tape. We've done that on other devices. (Update: the light was a bother, so a tiny bit of electric tape did the trick - against the black plastic of the speaker you don't see it.)

title: Buy it
text:
I recently had to shoot a music video and the venue would not allow us to use haze (even canned haze “Atmosphere Aerosol”, which doesn’t set off smoke alarms). I planned on only getting the Smoque 1 to give the appearance of haze in the room, but I needed next day delivery and this Smoque 2 was the only option. It was about $20 or $30 more and not the correct filter size for my lens (not if I wanted next day delivery). I almost didn’t get it. I found two filter step down rings for between $8 and $11 each, and ordered the filter. I used the filter with a cine lens and also a Canon 50mm.

The effect is subtle, you won’t lose any clarity or sharpness in most areas, it doesn’t color the image in any way. It does smooth out some contrast slightly, but you’ll mostly notice the change in lighting. Much like how haze will catch light and make it bloom, this really does that. So depending on how strong you want the bloom, that’s going to decide on how strong of the filter to buy: 1, 2 or 3. I’m actually very happy with the 2, and glad I didn’t get the 1.

The light bloom can be overwhelming if you have too much light in a dark scene: we had stage lights from left and right and they would wash out 2/3s of the frame with colored glowing light. But we actually liked the effect, it was almost like using light leaks. As the lights were moving around and this wasn’t constant, it wasn’t a problem for our shoot, it added a lot of interest to the shot. What I really like is when things reflect light such as dust particles in the air or furniture, the bloom is small and makes them kind of glow without making them too obvious. Gives it a real film feel.

This is pretty similar in effect to a black pro mist filter, but probably a bit stronger in how much glow you get from light sources. But considering I thought for sure it would be too strong and would have to return it, I was surprised to how perfect for me it is and how excited I am to use it again.

title: Great battery life and very, very loud!
text:
Picked these up to primarily use to talk with our little who is finally start to sleep in their own bed. A few things we noticed over the past few weeks:

1. The volume goes up VERY high, to an uncomfortable level.
2. They pick up conversations of the maintenance staff in our complex which means they can also pick up on our transmissions -- thankfully there are a bunch of channels to choose from.
3. So far, the batteries have lasted over a month with seldom use a few times each week. Power meter still shows full bars, that's some great standby time considering my apprehension once I realized these units require 4 AAA batteries each.
4. The battery cover was difficult to remove on one of the units but not the other one. I had to remove the clip first, and even then, I thought the battery door was going to break from all of the pressure required to remove it. The photo shows how the battery door "grooves" that are meant to provide grip for the user while removing the cover, are blocked by the clip. This is silly design flaw IMO and the grooves should be extended laterally so I could grip both sides with both thumbs WITHOUT having to remove the clip.
5. The 3.5mm headphone jack is super convenient for middle of the night bedtime stories (kiddo often wakes ~0100 and requests a bedtime story to get back to sleep), this way we can whisper to each other without waking others in the rooms.
6. The bright color themes are perfect for locating the units in piles of toys or stuffies!
7. The "lamp" isn't very bright BUT that's great for battery life retention and provides enough light to check the room for monsters.
8. The plastic housing feels relatively weak/cheap and I doubt these would survive a drop onto concrete or similar hard surfaces.
9. Sounds quality and reception are perfect at 40 ft. passing through 4 standard framed & drywalled walls. (We seem to pick up other transmission from as far as 100ft. away through inside walls, outside stucco wall, windows, thick foliage, and vehicles).

These were a great buy and we plan to try them on the road in May while we caravan a 1000 mile road trip--updates to follow!

title: Solid 3rd party control ring adapter
text:
YKEASU makes some very solid and functioning adapters. I've been using one of their standard EF-RF adapters with the optional tripod connector and it has been great. So when I saw their control ring EF-RF adapter, I had to get one. Obviously due to the design it doesn't have a threaded hole on the bottom for a tripod connector, but instead it has a very functional fully rotatable control ring. The adapter has metal connections and the ring is knurled metal. There is a rubber gasket for some weather sealing on the RF side. Build quality is great, as expected from YKEASU. This adapter also has a painted red marker to line up with my EOS R6m2 (a small gripe I had with the standard adapter was it had a painted white marker, which is typically reserved for crop sensor cameras, as opposed to the red marker which is for full-frame cameras). The adapter works well with all of my EF lenses I've tried (16-35 f2.8 L II, 24-70 f2.8L, 70-200 f2.8L II, 85 f1.2L II) and the control ring does what it's supposed to do.

I knocked a star off though because I feel like the control ring is a little stiffer than it should be at times. I contacted CS and they advised rotating the dial a couple of dozen times to help loosen the internal lubrication, in case it thickened up from cold weather. It definitely improved compared to when I first pulled it out of the box, but I still feel it could be tuned a bit better. Yes, it's easy to turn the ring when you've got all your fingers on it in a perpendicular fashion, but when you've got a lens and body attached to both ends, you're rotating the ring with your thumb and a finger or two in a parallel fashion. While shooting and holding the lens and trying to rotate the ring, the stiffness becomes even more apparent.

All in all, YKEASU has a solid 3rd party EF-RF control ring adapter. The adapter part works well and the control ring works with the RF body (whatever you set it to do). The adapter is much more cost-effective compared to the Canon brand, but this time the tradeoff is a little more noticeable in use.

title: Lightweight, compact, and sturdy!
text:
[[VIDEOID:69f27d97659ca5c45649187fa876e355]] Very impressed with this mono pod, it is small and compact, though when extended gives you plenty of reach. The wide feet on it make it very stable and the fluid head on the top is nice and smooth on all axis. Given that it is carbon fiber, it is nice and lightweight. has a nice grip material around the top and a wrist strap for extra security. The feet have a little twist lock that allows you to lock the monopod in a standing up position. Not that I would trust the monopod to stay standing on its own with my camera on it, but it’s a nice extra feature.

The listing shows that you’re able to make a high hat out of the feet and the fluid head by removing them both from the main body of the monopod and then attaching them together. This is definitely doable, but it’s not quick as there is no fast way of detaching the fluid head and the feet other than unscrewing them… but you can do it if you need to which is nice in a pinch. The problem with this is feature is that the feet tend to come loose from the base of the monopod easily. Not sure what to do about this, maybe put a little Loctite on it. That would fix the issue, but then it’ll be a pain to unscrew the feet if I ever need to.🤷🏽‍♂️

One other little annoyance about the monopod is that because it’s so compact, it has five stages of height adjustment to it, but each stage is only about 14 inches long, so to make any major height adjustments, you have to loosen, and then re-tighten multiple stages. When filming running-n-gun broll, and you need to be able to quickly adjust your angle for different shots, this can be a bit of a pain. I am using this monopod primarily for travel, where weight and size is at a premium, but for work around town, I’m keeping my other monopod with only three stages.

A couple of small annoyances, but overall a great monopod and a solid buy.💪🏼

title: Great looking case at a great price
text:
The good
- The box came with installation directions. Seems obvious for a case but instructions are always nice.
Clear transparent case that's virtually impossible to notice from a distance. Lets the natural good looks of the MacBook shine through.
- I thought the glossy finish would be a fingerprint magnet but so far I haven't noticed a lot of smudges yet.
- Came with keyboard cover. I generally don't like them as typing on them kills the little tactile feedback that's present on a laptop chiclet keyboard but this one is a little less annoying than other silicone ones I've had. It's a bit counterintuitive but I think it's because it's firmer than the other ones I've had that are squishier. Keep in mind the #1 killer of MacBooks is probably liquid damage so I really appreciate the keyboard cover even if I don't like it that much. The only key not covered is the fingerprint reader so if you spill soda or coffee don't do it over that key.
- Top cover tolerance was pretty tight so I have no worries about it coming off.
- Lowest price of any case I've had.
- It came with a nonslip microfiber cloth/mousepad

Things I wasn't impressed with
- The bottom cover fit wasn't as good as the top. A light nudging of the corner would unclip a corner of the case, not enough for the case to fall off though.
