- Some of the alignment looks a little weird but the lid closed normally. See the photos and judge for yourself.

Keep in mind that this case is hard plastic. There is no give or cushioning anywhere, except for the 4 feet on the bottom of the case. This case would definitely protect from scuffs and scratches from going through security at the airport and being stored in a backback with a bunch of other stuff. It won't, however, protect it from repeated drops and abuse from a teenager. Whatever corner the laptop lands on will destroy the plastic for that corner but it probably will prevent your laptop from being dented. Just keep in mind that you'll likely have to get another case after that. But it's current pricing is so low that you can probably buy 2-3 spares for this eventuality at what some other cases cost.

title: Great value! Not perfect...
text:
For the price, this is a great great value.
Sturdiness and ruggedness in a stand involve the total package, not just pole diameter. These stands have economical extension clamps and leg spread setting clamp. They are hinged with rivets and use economical spreader arms. So these are very usable, but not for heavy use and by no means 'professional' if I'm being the judge. They're fine here.
The power switch on the cord is on/off only. It does not control any brightness or color temp but the listing doesn't claim that so we're okay as long as you know that "control by switch" means off/on only.
The color temp and brightness are controlled by a remote control. Each light in the package comes with a remote but they're using the same frequencies so you can control both bulbs with one remote. That's the other thing, it's the -bulb- that is controllable, and only by remote. You do get the three advertised temperatures, and you can set brightness from off to full with up/down controls. There are some hotkeys on the remote to get you to certain settings as far as brightness and temperature quickly. They say that they are 135w draw bulbs, and therefore yielding way more than that compared to what an incandescent would. Yeah they're pretty darned bright but I don't have the meters needed to confirm any of their claims. Also... if/when these bulbs fail I have no idea what flexible replacement options might fill their role, if any...? I suppose that's no different than other LED lights where you have to replace the whole thing. At least when these fail the rest of the kit is still there.
This all comes in a reasonable carrying bag. The bulbs are in packing boxes so you might want to get a nice bag or something to put them in rather than a plain white cardboard box. The reflectors each come in their own separate slip bag. So once you fold them and fold their detachable front cover screens, you can stuff them in there and they stay compacted and protected.
I think you've got the info you need now along with what the listing says. As long as you understand that these are not for high volume handling, rough or heavy duty applications, they'll do a great job for you.
~Cheers!

title: Feature rich fitness/smart watch
text: There are already many reviews for this generation of Samsung fitness/smart watch so I'll just hit the highlights of why I like it. First, I find the S3 to be a feature rich and stylish watch.  I very much like being able to access the watch's features using the bezel wheel.  No tapping the screen or swiping to see information if I don't choose to.  I have a Samsung phone so the watch and App were easy for me to set up and understand.  The watch's screen is bright, sharp, colorful, and there are many modifiable watch faces available.  I don't keep the GPS feature turned on so my battery life is a good 2 days.  I have tried a couple of other fitness watches over the years, some with much longer battery life, but I have mostly used a version of Fitbit watch since 2015.  Because I wanted to try something new and after watching/reading a number of reviews for this watch, I purchased a renewed one for around $100.  I have been having fun with the watch and have nothing bad to say about it except step counts and some fitness info does not match up with my Fitbit watch results. I guess I will have to calculate a fudge factor in my head for the difference.  Anyway, I liked the watch enough to buy a renewed S4 {next gen} watch that offers a few more features over the S3 such as an important new OS.  Luckily, the Samsung App allows me to enable 2 watches so I can keep 1 watch charged all the time and switch back and forth between them. Samsung has promised 4 years of software updates so I will have plenty of time with these watches to try out the Samsung ecosystem before I have to decide to move on {or not} to their next gen watch. I believe S3 support updates end the Fall of 2023.  The last thing I will say is that the $399 Samsung wanted for these premium watches brand new is way out of my cost to value price range so I was happy to be able to purchase them renewed.  The good news is that their 5th gen fitness watch is more reasonably priced.  But if you want to kick the tires on a premium Samsung fitness/smart watch without it costing an arm and a leg, I'd recommend you buy it renewed {excellent condition} to see if it just might become your new favorite watch.

title: Probably won't be using Asurion any longer. Keeps getting worse!
text:
I have used Asurion in the past for cell phones and always gotten stellar service and happy with it.

Now comes using it for my laptop.

Did the claim online. Didn't get any type of confirmation or anything until it finally shipped. Then I noticed the shipment was going to someone I have no idea who they are and on the opposite side of the country. I didn't find this out till I got a message it was delivered and it was not there.

I reached out to support in chat. I was told that there was an error with the shipment of the box and they have to REDO THE WHOLE CLAIM! I was so puzzled, all of my information was correct but it was in their system there was this error. This was beyond frustrating as I had already waited countless days to get a box that never showed up. Now I was being told I had to wait another 3-5 business days for another box. I demanded it be next day shipped, this should have been a reasonable request. I am unemployed and looking for work and this laptop was all I had to do this. I was told the standard is 3-5 days.

So here I am waiting on a box that has not taken two weeks and no closer to getting my laptop fixed. I have never had this unprofessionalism in any other claim with Asurion.

I will update on how they handle the repair whenever it inevitably happens. Apparently the customers are now at the will of Asurion and their mistakes and have no interest in making things right.

Update 3/18/23
Well it just keeps getting worse. This week I got a call they are sending me back my HP laptop because it’s not the right one. Guess what my laptop isn’t an HP and nor have I sent anything in to them. So I wonder now if I’ll get some random strangers laptop. I’ve received two return boxes and every single one the claim number and my zip code do not match. I’m beyond infuriated. They have wasted two weeks and I’m honestly skeptical to even send my laptop in because I’m worried it will never honestly come back. This is a complete joke I’ll never buy Asurion insurance again.

title: Exactly what I was looking for, and more!
text:
I have spent hours looking for just the right product only to come up bust. This is not one of those times. I was looking for 3 things in a case/cover for my Microsoft Surface Pro 8, and I found all three in this one. And here they are:

1. The back of the MSP8 is very slippery, and I was in constant fear of dropping it. Fixed! The back cover of the case (mine is clear) is grippy without being spongy, plus the substantial edge gives it a second line of defense against it slipping out of my hands.

2. That edge also checked the box for making it more difficult to accidentally hit the Off/On switch when changing orientation. The button is still quite accessible but not as vulnerable. I haven't hit it accidentally since I got this cover.

3. Finally, I can fold the keyboard back and use the kick stand without an unneeded front cover getting in the way like with many other cases out there.

4. And fourth…. I know, I said three, but I hadn't even considered that I'd be able can detach the keyboard and walk around without clutching my MSP8 like a newborn.

5. Finally, along with that, it has another feature I didn't think I would use and that is the pen holder. Now that I feel secure detaching the keyboard, I actually ended up using the pen holder.

6. Okay, last unexpected benefit, honestly! The keyboard is no longer wobbly as is without the case, even when it is on my lap.

It does add a bit of bulk and weight but that's the price of protection, isn't it? I wasn't looking for military grade protection as I don't intend to drop it out of an airplane. But I think it is plenty sturdy for my needs. Too be honest, the MSP8 has already survived one drop without a cover, but I don't want to take that chance again. If you really need a military grade cover, you're going to have to pay a lot more for it.

BTW, I bought it directly from the company's store, and it was delivered quickly. I even got a discount for signing up for email.

title: Awesome tuner to get interested in radio again
text: Awesome portable wifi radio tuner. Claims it will support 99 presets but I’ve currently got 147 presets programmed in so I’m curious how many it will actually hold. Speaker sounds great and fills a room pretty decently. Tunecast website makes it easy to search for stations from around the world. You can send  and play a station link directly to the radio by sending it to the radio’s IP address. If you enjoy the station you can save it to the radio preset. As well you can use the radio interface to search and store presets but is easier to use the web interface. The skytune web interface also allows yo to organize the order of your presets and also add stations that are not found in the skytune database. Simply type in the stream url and save it to your presets. The trick is to figure out how to find the stream url address which is different than the station website. Search YouTube to learn how to find a stream url. When organizing the order of your stations start your order with preset #4. The reason is presets 1-3 are tied to the 3 favorite push buttons on top of the radio. If you keep presets 1-3 dynamic then you can change the presets programmable to the buttons without upsetting the order of your preset list. The radio will also receive Bluetooth ( but not send) signals so you can play your favorite Apple Music, Spotify service from your phone and hear it on the radio. I use a Bluetooth transmitter plugged in to the 3.5 mm headphone port to send to a large by speaker to play in my home. It truly is a portable radio because you can link it to your phone’s hotspot for use outside your home. Battery lasts ~5 hours on a charge. I recharge it by using a portable battery pack like you use for recharging your phone.  I am so impressed with this portable unit I am considering getting one of Ocean Digital’s table top units for home use. I’m extremely happy with this product and highly recommend buying it if you are considering one. It is very refreshing to get away from the corporate radio repetition of the same top 40 songs that have made modern radio so dull and boring. There are some really great stations out there that have playlists generated by humans with great tastes in music. I’ve found myself truly enjoying radio again with such varied sources of news and music.

title: Wow!
text: This camera comes with everything you need but a memory card.  The manual is professionally written and easy to understand even though there are a few spelling mistakes.  Setting the camera up physically in the car is the easy part.  The suction cup holding it to the window keeps working in extreme cold and extreme heat.  It comes with a little blue tool normally used to open laptops and phones.  I don't know why unless it is to help get the memory card in and out.  There are too many options to go in to here.  Suffice it to say that it works during the day and at night.  It takes video, pictures, and records voice.  You can playback on the camera or use a provided USB cable to playback on your computer, alternatively you can remove the memory card and use a provided micro-SD to USB-A adaptor also provided to see and hear everything on your computer. In video settings you can adjust the resolution to save memory, set it to loop, oldest out newest in.  You can have the camera automatically set the light exposure settings or do it yourself.  You set the time and date the first time you turn it on and then you can have time and date stamps on your videos and pictures.  You can set a motion sensor so it can record a loop when someone gets near your car such as when you are parked somewhere.  It has a G sensor so sudden shocks of a user defined level will trigger it to take a loop of video.  It has night vision mode.  In photo mode you can set the resolution and turn Anti-shaking on.  There are several menu options so you can set about anything.  The pictures and videos are truly clear, and the sound is good although it does pick up some road and car noise.  It comes with a power cable that plugs to the cigarette lighter socket and has a USB-A plug on the end so you can still plug other things in.  It is limited to 3 Amps.  It has an internal battery that will keep it going for a few hours but not for a day.  The instructions say not to leave it in direct sunlight or let it get above 170 degrees Fahrenheit.  I just checked and the national weather service says a car can get up to 120 degrees in the summer.  This camera can do about anything you would need a camera in your car to do.

title: Very good for the price
text:
It has Bluetooth 5.2, Qualcomm 3040 chip, noise canceling, two microphones which most only have one, 9 hrs playtime with 40 in total, alternate between the two earbuds, simple and durable leather case, and more.

While playing music the sound is amazing just as good as $100 plus earbuds. I didn't realize that you can pause music and adjust the volume on the earbud itself which I've never experienced. It has the most updated Bluetooth which I can go far away with no hiccups or lag. Switch to another song by holding down the right earbud for a few seconds and releasing, do the same with the left earbud for the previous song, Double tap to pause a song, and tap on the right earbud to increase sound and tap the left to decrease volume. (there's a control button on the earbud). I've never experienced so much control on an earbud it's pretty cool how they included this.

In terms of calling audio sounds clear, audio picks up regardless of whether you're using one or two earbuds to speak, and features two microphones which are nice. they give good enough noise canceling so you are not completely oblivious to your surrounding.

The Earbuds are comfortable and haven't had any ear pain, which some other earbuds have given me. They happen to give 7 different earbuds just in case which is nice.

If you are gonna just use one earbud make sure you take both out in which they will connect and put one back in the case to rock a solo bud.

You can also manually turn on and turn off each earbud, they give instructions.

All in all, everything you get in these earbuds for this price and the many features you get from more expensive earbuds is really good. This company seems to know how to make the perfect earbud hopefully they won't jack up the price of these ill be curious to see if they release more earbuds in the future because I'm pretty impressed with them. I've previously had earbuds such as sabbats which are more expensive and I would consider these earbuds better, they're cheaper and have a wider variety of features.

title: This is a simple solution for either of two common problems. This switch goes both ways.
text:
If you’ve got a TV/monitor that is one HDMI port short, this will get you by. This switch will in effect turn that one port into two, letting you swap between what’s displayed through that port, at the press of a button. Albeit a button that is on the other side of the room, in my case. It’s working well for having adding both a desktop PC and game console to a TV with only one empty HDMI port left. There’s no remote, so if you’re not sitting nearby, and will be switching sources regularly, keep that in mind. Also no extra HDMI cables are included, so also know that you need 3 HDMI cables.

One oddity in this setup is that switching to have the PC displayed on screen always takes several seconds for Windows to adjust its resolution (in this case, to the 4k of the TV). During this time, there’s a little black screen flash and/or the desktop resizing. It’s only a few seconds, but it is a minor annoyance. This is likely a computer/Windows issue, not an issue with the device.

As a bi-directional switch, you could instead use this in the opposite manner, having just one video source output to two displays. I don’t know what the most common use case is for this, but you would again be simply pressing the physical button on the switch to change which TV/monitor was receiving the signal. IMPORTANT: note that you can not have one source display to both monitors at the same time. It’s not a splitter, but rather a switch. So one display would show the video and the other would be blank (or likely display a message about having no signal, or go into power save mode, etc).

Conclusion:
Works well, small, simple, seems to be of slightly above average build quality for the price. Not the most elegant solution, as you have the extra dongle and cable in your setup. And if you decided you later needed to add another device, you would have to replace this with a switch that had more than 2 ports. But if you want a quick, functional, cheap Made in China solution, this gets the job done happily. And it comes in purple.

title: Great starter telescope for kids and adults
text:
I bought this knowing nothing about telescopes and not knowing what I could expect to see through this thing.
Now I know more, I think this is a decent value. In telescopes, the aperture size matters much more than magnification. The bigger the aperture, the better the image will be. This is a 70mm aperture (2.75 inches), which is about as small as you can get. It's typical for an "entry-level" telescope, and a decent value for the money if you want to get into stargazing without dropping 500 bucks or more on a bigger scope.

First, as with all beginner telescopes, it is actually much harder to use than a more intermediate level one.
Because most kids like looking "AT" stuff more than looking "FOR" it. And with this telescope, far more time is spent hunting for objects than actually looking at them.
This is made for kids. As such, the stand is very short. Which means that all the time you spend hunting for things, you'll having to be hunched over, crouched down, or kneeling on the ground. And if you live in a place with a lot of light pollution, you won't be able to see much more than stars, the Moon, or the brightest planets. I could make out Mars and some faint detail on Jupiter. Venus, on the other hand, is very easy to see. so we've been looking at it every night. Galaxies, most nebulas, and many star clusters are beyond the ability of this telescope.
For perspective, we've had a few weeks of use and practice, and feel comfortable with the telescope, and have a number of apps, charts, and star maps to help me find things. It's cool and the kid loved it. I consider it worth the effort, but my back is killing me today from the kids sized stand it comes with.

Don't get me wrong, for an entry-level telescope, this is good. It'll serve our needs. But, like all entry-level telescopes, this is harder to use and not powerful enough to see the furthers planets and galaxies.
If you get an entry-level telescope, this is a good choice at an extremely affordable price. But if at all possible, save up (4x the price) and get a larger aperture.

title: Very Impressive
text:
This is a really powerful little device. The size, however, has nothing to do with how capable it is to perform any tasks you ask it to do. I was REALLY, and I mean REALLY impressed by it.

I purchased it primarily for playing VR games on it, and it has not disappointed. Furthermore, I also plan on running ProxMox on it to be able to run multiple virtual machines simultaneously. Preliminary tests have shown that it can also do this without issue.

This MiniPC is also capable of running different flavors of Linux, though I haven't tested that yet. Super impressed with the network speed as well. I have it connected to 2.5Gbps switch and the connection is rock solid and stable. Wireless is also very good. Please be aware that it has a Wi-Fi 6E (Yes, not just WiFi6, but E, which is the latest and greatest).

The HX90G is also extremely quiet, you can barely hear it, even when being pushed to the max. Any gaming PC would definitely make more noise than this little wonder. If your room is cold, trust me you'll need to get your ear very near it to hear it at all.

The only thing negative I can say so far about the HX90G is about the Baseplate. It can certainly be somewhat cumbersome to install. At first, I genuinely thought it was defective. It almost looked to me like the holes on the plate (the little piece you attach to the unit itself) would not align properly. But after several tries, I was able to successfully attach it the way it was supposed to go. Please beware that you have to screw in one of the screws on each end first, then make your way one by one on each end. If you screw all the ones on side first and then go to the other side. It will be almost impossible to screw them in without damaging the screws and probably the unit's chassis.

Other than that, I'm super happy with my purchase, this is my first ever MiniPC and if it continues to perform the way it is, it'll probably won't the last either. MinisForum is a brand I had never heard of before. But they are making a great name for themselves for what I can see.

title: Pretty good
text:
I spend frivolously on speakers, lol, and I own WAY too many… That being said, I decided to try something new as I usually do every few months. I clicked on these because of the lights, the price, and I thought the shape was cool. I saw some reviews mentioned that these are very light. I felt differently, as they had a nice weight to them. They aren’t overly heavy or large, but they fit perfectly next to my 27” monitor OR below it if I turn them sideways.
I like that the knob isn’t infinite, meaning that it has a start 0% and stop 100% for volume. It took me a minute to realize the lights are controlled by a touch button on the top of the right speaker. There are 4 modes, but my favorite is the one that goes to the music. It works surprisingly well and it sort of starts central and expands outwards like an old school equalizer. You can turn the lights off if they distract, just hold the button. RGB mode is the second coolest.
The side buttons don’t bother me as I saw for some. I like that they blend in because it makes it clean looking. The USB wires are thick and braided. The USB almost spanned two monitors, it’s a good size. The top button is power. I wish that it tapped to turn on, but you have to hold it. Not a big deal. The middle is “mode” between Bluetooth and aux. I’m using aux. The third is the bass or balance mode. This is the only thing on these speakers that makes me laugh. The voice saying “balanced” is bad, lol. Not a big deal though. You can use any eq you want.
I leave it on balanced mode and adjust it with a software eq. The natural sound is clean. It’s not overly muddy with typical pc bass or anything. I didn’t notice a huge difference in bass mode, but it’s cool to have. Each song and genre will sound different with any eq. These aren’t overbearingly loud at all, but the nice part is that they don’t distort no matter how high you turn them. They stay clean, even with eq and volume max. I’m pretty happy with the buy.

title: For the PRICE! It cannot be beat!
text:
There are many portable monitors on the market. Each one has a particular use case. Some are great for CAD / Graphics Arts, while some are more suited for movies. This bad boy is geared towards gaming with it's high 144hz refresh rate. After countless YouTube video review research I settled on this one as it was a GREAT price at $139+tax after a coupon. Shipping was fast and the item was packaged very well.

Inside the box you will find all the accessories you need to get up and running. I am a cable snob and ordered a fancy mini-HDMI to HDMI cable I liked. The included one works perfectly fine. I hooked it up to my PS5 using the USB-A to USB-C for power and the mini-HDMI to HDMI cable for video and audio. Enabling the HDR mode on the device gives you a faux HDR look. It is not true HDR. While in this mode adjustment to brightness and contrast is disabled. You have to turn it completely off in the OSD to adjust.

I just got the PS5 so I'm waiting one some games to test 120hz 1080P. I did confirm one YouTube video got it working. I booted up Astro's Playroom and it looked fantastic. While at only 60hz there was some noticable smearing as the response rate is not as crisp as my Viewsonic XG2431 in 60hz with custom PureXP+ preset. It was playable and bright enough. I did test the video playback with a 1080P Blu-Ray and colors look as good as it gets on an IPS panel. I do feel the raw contrast is not 1000:1 but more inbetween 800:1-900:1 That being said, if you enable Dynamic Contrast it does help with the black bars in movies. The 3.5mm headphone output is clear and has decent dynamic range but sounds compressed slightly. It gets loud enough.

Full 144hz works great over HDMI on my Macbook Pro 14" and a desktop Nvidia RTX 3080ti. I really love the 15.6 size, it fits under my 24" main gaming monitor perfectly. Overall a great buy and economical alternative to the portable OLED monitors. If you need ultimate contrast levels for movies by all means go OLED. If you care more about input lag do not hesitate to pick up this sweet tech.

title: Does what is claims to do
text:
I've had the Y20GTA watch for about a week now and have explored all of the features. What I can say is it does what it says it will do. It's not flashy and you shouldn't expect flashy at this price point. The watch is mostly a health and fitness tracker which isn't what I was looking for in a smart watch but it does seem to do those things well. I purchased the watch mostly for notifications and business related alerts. It is very good at handling SMS text messages and a few other common messaging apps. The biggest disappointment for me is the fact that it doesn't have an interface for MS Office apps. The only way to get meeting alerts, for instance, is to enable "other" messages which passes through EVERY message that your phone generates, even ones that you never see on the phone. I asked technical support if there was a work around for this but learned there is not. Since I mentioned tech support, let me explain that a bit. Within the app that controls the watch there is a chat tab with direct contact to tech support. The chat support has been very responsive and helpful even when providing answers other than what I had hoped to hear. The watch has a few built in watch faces, only one of which I really like. There are additional watch faces to choose from but most are very gimmicky and seem to be targeted at a younger audience (cartoonish). You can only download one additional watch face at a time which is a bit of a pain since browsing through all the silly faces to find the one you like is tedious process. Regarding battery life, out of the box it seems to be quite excellent! I have charged it every night and by the end of the day I have not seen it below 85%. Surely that will degrade over time but my last smartwatch barely gave me a day on one charge and, when it got old, did not even do that.

All that being said, the watch is a good purchase for the price. If you are looking for a full functioned smart watch to use for business you'll need to invest a bit more. That said I am satisfied with my purchase and have enjoyed having and wearing it, however, I would not buy this watch again if it was lost or stolen. I hope this is helpful.

title: Expensive, but capable
text:
The TP-Link AXE16000 Quad-Band WiFi 6E Router (aka Archer AXE300) is one of the more expensive routers on the market, but is has the capability and features to justify the price. If you are looking for a router to blend in with your furniture....forget about it. If you want to make a statement that you are a power user, this is the router you want.

My ISP plan is 800 mpbs, but I am running around 930 mpbs using a DOCSYS 3.1 cable modem. If I decide to upgrade even further, this router can handle it. If you Internet plan is 400 mbps or slower, you can easily use a WiFi 5 (AC) or WiFi 6 (AX) router which will be considerably less expensive.

This is a WiFi 6e modem which includes a 6 MHz band in addition to the more common 2.4 gHz and 5 gHz bands. Furthermore, there are two 5 gHz bands. Please note that there are very few devices that currently support the 6 gHz band. My Samsung Galaxy 22 Ultra phones do have that capability. Some Windowsx 11 computers support 6 gHz; currently Windows 10 does not support 6 gHz, even if you install the proper adapter; Microsoft has chosen to block 6 gHz on Windows 10. There are workarounds if you insist.

Using a chanel width of 160 mHz on one of the two 5 gtHz bands, I am getting upload and download speeds of 1815/2402 mbps. That gives me Speedtest rates of 400 mpbs over WiFI which is half my Internet band plan. That is excellent as you cannot ever get the same speed over WiFi that you can achieve over wired Ethernet.

I am using a 2.5 gb Ethernet connection from my router to my primary computers. The router compes with two 10 gbe ports and one 2.5 gbe port allowing you to get around the speed limitations of routers that only employ 1 gbe ports.

Thus, if you are a power user and can afford this device, you will be pleased.

Please be aware that WFi 7 routers will be introduced over the coming year. However, few homes will need the capability of WiFi 7 anytime soon

title: Nice little player with good sound ....
text:
This MP3 audio player is very capable with good sound quality. It offers a host of nice audio features such as MP3 player, lossless audio playback, FM radio, blue tooth, equalizer, sound recording. It also has an external micro USB slot to add plenty of storage. It can even play video clips and function as an eBook reader; I have not tested those features since my only interest is for audio playback.

It is small and lightweight. Some might argue a plastic type of feel but I don't think it is too bad. It has an old fashioned power slider switch at the bottom which I like. The counter intuitive thing may be the navigation wheel inside a selected menu item. In order not to have the typical separate "return" or "back" button outside the wheel, the manufacturer has opted to put the"return" or "back" function at the bottom spot of the wheel this only applies when you are inside one of the apps. So, on the main screen the wheel is a full navigation wheel (up/down, left/right). Inside a selected app (function menu) the bottom spot on the wheel is your back button. Up/down are accomplished via the left/right spots. After a bit, you get used to it. It is not a big deal, just pointing it out; it is the price for having fewer buttons, I suppose.

Pros: good sound quality which is what really matters most. I used it with earphones and via Bluetooth and the sound quality was good. Rechargeable battery. Small and lightweight; fits in many places.

Cons: none really. It might have been nice to maybe have a protective carry case (sleeve), with a clip, for it included?

For the price point of this unit, you won't be disappointed with the full feature set and the sound quality. If you are looking for a high end "feeling" brushed aluminum case and nice metal tactile buttons, this is not it. I have one of those as well and they cost a bit more :-). If you are looking for a lightweight player for on the go this unit is hard to beat for features, sound quality and price. Highly recommended. A+++++

title: An Enterprise Solution for Small Business and Home Users
text:
There is a lot to like about this NAS. It comes ready to handle most tasks out of the box. I went with 6x Seagate EXOS 16X 16TB drives. They do work with this model and give me 80TB raw storage RAID 5. I added 2x 400 GB Synology NVMe drives to ensure that the unit keeps up with the 10GbE network since 6 SATA III drives barely maintain that speed with sequential transfers. This setup allows fast connectivity for most tasks. Hard wired with 10GbE hardware, switch, and cables, it is possible to achieve 1.4 GB / s transfers. That is as fast as USB C or single drive Thunderbolt 3/4 direct attached storage.

PROS:

4 core Xeon Processor

8GB RAM

1 x 10GbE built in 2 x 1GbE for backup or bonded connection

6 SATA III bays with expansion for up to 10 more

NVMe cache expansion for faster reads / writes / transfers

PCI 3 x 8 expansion slot for 25 GbE or 2 x 10GbE

Excellent DSM package with many packages to cover most tasks

CONS:

Price

Not PLEX compatible.

Expansion units run on eSATA limiting you to about 600 megabytes per second max per unit.

Synology steering towards extra pricey in house only RAM, drives, NVMe, and expansion cards is frustrating.

Every hardware requirement is enterprise grade. Enterprise switch, enterprise cables, enterprise RAM, enterprise HDDs, enterprise NVMe. It really adds up. You could try to install NAS grade or lower at the expense of stability and perhaps your warranty or at least support.

The DSM works so hard to keep you from making any mistakes that if you stray out of the narrow box or have a package freeze, you are forced to SSH into the system and work you way past their passive aggressive warnings via Linux commands to override or fix the DSM error. This is supposed to be enterprise grade, let me do what I want.

title: Like a wind tunnel in your hand
text:
Frankly I was blown away by this little (pun intended) tool. It's a bit smaller than a hair dryer and it's battery powered so I was expecting something that had the power of a typical hand fan, but this thing really surprised me with the huge amount of air it puts out.

I have a number of cans of compressed air that I use to clean my computer, keyboard and my garage workspace. I typically by a six-pack. I was hoping that this could replace those and offer me a little more control because those blast a lot of air and they are either 100% or 0%. This blower has a knob that lets you choose how much air you want. The lowest setting is still harder than I could blow with my mouth, but it's not too strong. The highest setting is like a tornado!

Since it's battery powered, I had figured that the highest output would still be well below the canned air level and I would still need an extra boost for some situations but I was wrong. This thing throws out a huge amount of air. It may not be as strong through a narrow opening as a can of air, but I can't see much difference and this thing is able to move a much larger volume of air so it can clear off a larger area faster.

It's really more than I had hoped for and I will use it a lot more often than the can of air because I don't have to worry about running out. I've yet to recharge it since charging it right after I unpacked it and I haven't noticed any reduction in the air flow. It's reasonably heavy so I suspect it has a nice sized battery. The instructions claim it will run for 20 minutes to 3 hours so I'm not worried that I will run out in the middle of a job.

It comes with several different nozzles and brushes along with a nice quality braided charging cable (that I'll probably used for other things as well). I find that I mainly use the long nozzle because that seems to proved the best for blowing stuff off. I will post a video showing the strength of the blower.

Bottom line is that I recommend this without reservation. I plan to buy another for my office at work.

title: Left ear occasionally drops
text:
I mostly listen to metal or podcasts so the sonic capabilities of high end earbuds are probably not fully realized for me. That said, I have been using various wireless earbuds for about a decade. The best earbuds I have to compare these against are the Sony WF-1000XM3 which are also noise canceling. Sony's WFs cost $149 against the hefty price tag of these at $395. Frankly, I can't explain why these cost so much. They ARE lighter than Sony's (even the case) and the noise cancellation seems better. Both are bulky in the ear, but that probably comes with the noise canceling technology built in. I also think these Bowers & Wilkins earbuds sound better but that can be a subjective thing since you can always play with the sound settings.

Setup was a bit confusing as there are 2 different Bowers & Wilkins apps. The one that said "headphones" was not correct and needed the music app downloaded. Go figure. One of the main things I look for in Bluetooth capable items is the reliability in connectivity. The WFs are more reliable for me. I can pull them out of the case, put them back in, pull one earbud out, etc. and they regularly connect. On the other hand, the B&W earbuds sometimes take a long time to connect, or the left earphone won't connect or drops while listening. It seems the only way to reconnect it is to restart my phone. Sometimes it's hard to know if these issues stem from the phone or item connecting, but since I have few problems with the Sony earbuds, I'm going to blame the connection issues on the B&W earbuds. Besides, at this price point, I expected NO issues. Each earbud requires a little more effort to pull out of the case due to the low profile and smooth surface so it's easy to lose grip and have it pop back into the case.

I will probably continue using these B&W earbuds as my go-to's unless the dropouts get really frustrating. They are lighter which makes them more comfortable and thus stay in the ear better, and the noise cancellation is better in my opinion. However, for what these headphones cost, I believe the casual user can get similar performance at even half the price.

title: Motorola technical support unresponsive via phone or chat; totally unacceptable!!
text: At Xfinity's suggestion, I tried to upgrade an old cable modem with a new "recommended" Motorola modem, MB7621. The process SHOULD be simple. You move the cable connection from the old modem to the new modem. You move the Ethernet cable from the old modem to the new modem. You turn the power on and call Xfinity. Very simple, but after days of calls, I still have no internet. Xfinity says to call Motorola, but Motorola can't be reached by phone or by their chat support feature. Ridiculous. Motorola advertises this modem as Xfinity compatible, but clearly there are problems, at least in some cases. Now Xfinity is forcing me to accept a technician visit, for which I will undoubtedly be charged. Customer service is a joke these days and has been turned into a new money-making opportunity for companies like Xfinity. Too expensive to retain experienced phone support people, I guess.  UPDATE: Xfinity tech came and was able to "modify some internal modem settings" and provision the modem. But ASUS router gave an ISP DHCP error, so no internet. Grrr. After hours of searching the Xfinity forum I was able to connect by manually changing the router MAC address. Way too complicated a fix (esp. if the Xfinity technician had no idea how to do it)! Motorola did respond to my chat question after two days. Too late. Sad.  UPDATE-2: Internet connection failed about 15 hours later. Was finally able to reach Motorola chat support. They said to reset the modem. That didn't work, but that was also their only solution. They said to call Xfinity. Xfinity couldn't do anything except send a technician again (at my expense). I ordered a new modem from the Xfinity list: Motorola MB7420. When it arrived, I switched the cables from the new modem to the old (less than one-week) modem, and instantly I had internet. I used the Xfinity app to activate the modem and it worked immediately. This is how it's supposed to happen. I give a big fail to Motorola for poor customer support and a big fail to Xfinity for not standing behind products they recommend. To go a week without internet was a major problem. Oh, and Xfinity offered me a $5 credit. What a joke.

title: Love this generation of KZ IEM, but why memory foam ear tips?
text:
I have tested many KZ IEMs including KZ ZS Pro X, KZ ZSN Pro X and this one KZ ZVX. Overall, I am very happy with all of them although they are not perfect. In fact, all of them are better than my airpod pros. Many times better. Unless you have to have wireless earbuds, there is no reason not to try one of these budget IEM to listen to music.

One thing I don’t like about KZ IEMs is that their sound signature is a bit too bright for me. While it is fun to listen to, it becomes shouty after a long listening session.

KZ ZVX is a new generation of IEM offered by KZ. While it maintains its fun signature, the highs are definitely toned down a bit although it still has a V shape sound signature with strong bass.

The mids are thick and comfortable. It gives you the sense of weight but not overwhelming.

As I mentioned earlier, the high is a bit more natural. It is no longer shouty but the details is there. I can now listen to my music for hours without feeling fatigue. It is perfect for working out and gaming.

Soundstage and Image are surprisingly good for the price. The Instrument separation is capable. I have no problem pinpointing the position of different instruments.

My biggest complaint is the memory foam ear tips come with the IEM. I never like memory fam ear tips. I never find them fit my ears well. Does not do anything to improve sound isolation while taking away all the bass. If you try this IEM and think the bass is lacking. I think it is more to do with the memory foam ear tips than the IEM itself. Try silicone ear tips instead. If you don’t have extra ear tips around, I highly recommend you to get SpinFit ear tips. The improvement is nights and days.

Overall, this is a great little IEM. Sound super engaging. Although I hate the memory foam ear tips, It is still a great IEM and 5 star to me.

title: PERFECT FOR MULTI DISPLAY MEDIA ROOM 1080P PROJECTOR and 4K TV
text:
PRODUCT VERSION REVIEWED

ROFAVEZCO HDMI SPLITTER 1X2 4K 120HZ MODEL NUMBER EZ-SP12H28S

QUICK REVIEW [TL;DR]

PERFECT FOR MULTI DISPLAY MEDIA ROOM 1080P PROJECTOR and 4K TV

REVIEW:

Expensive, but good working device to split signals between multiple resolutions monitors, TVs or Projectors. In my case, I have a 4K TV and a 1080P projector in my recreation room. Sometimes I want to watch the TV, but for family movie night, I want to watch movies on the big 100 inch screen.

Now, with the splitter, I can “play” each device at its own resolution without having to reconfigure my streamer each time. Additionally, it makes it so the rest of family does not have to worry about which button to push or cables to move make the TV or Projector work. They both just work.

SETUP:

The setup is very easy. Just plug in your source, then decide what output you want for monitor #2 (1080p or 4K). Monitor #1 is always the same as the input device. For me the EDID button only works on COPY.

PRO’s
- Compact Size
- Supports different resolution (downsync) on port#2
- Screw in Power Adapter to prevent power cord from pulling out.

There is a port to allow for firmware upgrades, but there is no easy way to do the upgrade without installing lots of Chinese software, and vague instructions. I gave up after about an hour trying to upgrade the firmware. I don’t need it for now, but it looks like it might be need for VRR support in the future.

RECOMMENDATION:

I recommend the splitter if you need the convenience of projecting the same image at 2 different resolutions, it seems to do a good job.

I do recommend it.

title: Has issues with NVIDIA gpus Don't buy unless you're up for some issues
text:
I had gotten this some time ago, I still have it cause i haven't been able to find an afordable solution. It does work sort of. I have a Cintiq 21ux. ThIs adapter doesn't seem to have a valid edid, so there for NVIDIA drivers recognize this device as Fail-safe which means it decides to only allow a resolution that the driver thinks is safe for the monitor which is often much lower resolution than the monitor can handle. You can not change this resolution normally, If you know enough information about your monitor you can force settings with the nvidia application however this can cause windows to malfunction in a strange way. Sometimes I can not play games unless i use my cintiq as the monitor the game plays on, SOMETIMES games wont play AT ALL unless i go in to the nvidia application and turn off the display port monitor from there, so gaming with both monitors up is touchy and iffy. It also causes my mouse pointer to vanish. I have to go in to the mouse pointers options and make sure trails is on in order to know where my mouse pointer is.

This appears to ONLY be a nvidia issue as windows default generic drivers before you install nvidia drivers seems to be just fine with the adapter. Nvidia drivers causes issues with it though if you try to force it out of the fail safe low resolutions. I do not reccomend this if you have a Nvidia gpu.

The adapter appears to work better in Linux than it does in Windows. Though it still has issues within linux. It also has the same fail-safe default that windows has however you have to force the drivers via xconfig file to not use any kind of check system. So no edid checks, no resolution checks no refresh checks.. nothing. You have to then set both your monitors if you dual like i do manually because this will also cause your other screen to not be auto detected for resolutions and refresh rates. Doing this also makes it to where both screens must have matching hz. My Cintiq hz is 60 so my HDMI LG monitor must also use 60hz. Linux mouse pointer doesn't vanish like windows does and doesn't have the game issues like windows does. Needless to say i spend most my time in Linux now.

title: I couldn't detect any ANC, and the sound quality was only OK.
text:
I bought these to replace a pair of Tozo NC2 earbuds that I lost after using them daily for about 6 months. I also bought the QRO Classics at the same time, also for about $20. It took little time to realize that the QRO's were the better choice, so I have sent these (Wilbur NO5's) back for a refund. The differences were clear:

1) Sound: the QRO's have a MUCH richer sound with a fuller base, excellent mid- and upper-range sounds, and it gets more volume. These Wilbur's were very average in sound quality, by comparison. I suspect that these have only 10mm drivers (speakers), while the QRO's have 12mm drivers. No comparison!
2) Active Noise Cancellation (ANC): These are advertised as having ANC, but I tried them repeatedly and couldn't find even slight noise cancellation with just the sound of a microwave oven. The QRO's have what I would consider average ANC, while the Tozo NC2's I used to have had incredible ANC - it was like walking into a sound-proofed room! I don't know if I just got a broken pair of earbuds, but I couldn't detect any ANC with the Wilbur's and didn't want to hassle with replacing them.
3) Battery life: average (6 hours) and on a par with the QRO's. Again, the Tozo's were much better, giving 11 hours of battery life before needing a recharge.
4) Controls: again, average. About the same ease of use as the QRO's, but the QRO's make a slight "click" sound every time they are touched making it much easier to determine if you touched them 1, 2, or 3 times. One the other hand, the Tozo's were so sensitive that anything coming close to them would turn the sound off or hang up on a call. This includes putting on glasses! That was a pain.
5) Price: at about $20, these are among the cheapest with (allegedly) ANC. On the other hand, the QRO's are also about $20 and give so much more bang for the bucks. Before you think that maybe the Tozo's sound tempting, remember that they are more like $40.

title: Triggers on every car driving by at night.  "Smart AI" is anything but.
text:
I bought this camera to replace an old blink camera that wasn't cutting it for me anymore. I wanted something with better picture and better motion detection and this one was advertising built-in smart AI motion detection so I pulled the trigger.

The good: 2k video looked good and was sufficient for my needs. The spotlight was a nice feature and being able to use local storage for an expandable SD card was one of the main things that attracted me to this over other more popular brands.

The bad: The camera was completely unusable for my front porch. I had it pointed at my front sidewalk, yard, and driveway. The street was barely in view but I made sure to set the detection zones to just my area. The first night I was getting constant motion notifications. I watched them and realized that it was detecting the car lights flashing across my yard and cars as motion. I tried pulling the motion sensor back to only half my yard and the first half of my cars in the driveway but it was no help, the headlights just kept triggering it. I turned the sensitivity down all the way and it was still triggering all night and every time it triggered on motion it turned on the spotlights so the battery was draining rapidly. I tried to set it to only detect persons but it doesn't have that option. It's either 'all motion & persons' or just 'all motion.' What's the point of having a 'smart-AI' if I can't tell it to limit the motion to just people? Even then, it occasionally detected a car headlight and even bugs as 'people' because it's that 'smart.'

I had to send it back as I couldn't be charging the batteries weekly and setting the motion zone to something so small that it wouldn't be triggered meant I was giving up on all motion except the patio stairs which is worthless to me. Don't believe the 'smart AI' feature as it's anything but smart. Also if you have this issue with the Tapo camera, don't buy a Kasa (same company) wired camera to replace it. I did that because I am on the Kasa ecosystem and found out it's the exact same software with the same AI and the same headlight detection problem. Lesson learned.

title: Great Sound. Strong bass.
text:
Let me start out by saying this is an early review, I've only had this Soundbar for about a week. So any long term issues would be marked with an *update*.

The sound is incredible. The settings have a lot of options for tweeking the sound to your liking. I found the installation very simple. I chose to walk mount and the screw guide was very useful. Also useful was the fact that the wall mount holes (plug holes) are spaced 16.5 inches apart so it was possible to hit two wall studs for mounting. I don't know if it was better to hit studs or if it would be better to use some sheet rock anchors due to the extreme bass. I am dueley mounted to studs and I have to have my bass turned all the way down because it's so deep it rattles the whole wall. Some people like the bass, and maybe it's not so bad when resting on a platform or entertainment center. I don't find this to be a reason to write a poor review, I turn the bass down all the way and everything is fine. The VRT:X button makes a really big difference in sound as does the TVOL. The Soundbar indicates when these features are on with 5 or so lights, off with zero lights. When I turn them off the sound is still fine but it is nowhere near as "high def" or "3D" we will call it. It just sounds so much better. If I turn off these features, I don't have the bass issues, but I'd rather have it on and turn the bass all the way down. I have it installed using the HDMI (arc) input on my TV with my NVIDIA Shield hooked to the TV. Some content will play in Dolby Atmos, that content is briefly displayed on the Soundbar with one single light for about 5 seconds to indicate it will be playing the sound for that content in Atmos.

Overall I am very satisfied with the Soundbar. Didn't seem to have any issues. Some of the reviews I have seen are not for the Vizio sound bar that is for sale, be sure to follow reviews that are correct. I've seen some negative reviews for this product but are for a Soundbar that is not this product. I am very happy with it. 4 stars for the super deep bass issues.

title: Nice heavy keyboard, slim mouse - works with Android/iOs or PC/Mac 2.4G
text: Got this on a whim. Glad I did. Keyboard is heavy, stays where you put it, doesn't slide around. (that's a big deal for me). The keys themselves are transparent, and you can change the backlit color (several options for color and several for brightness level-including off). There are so many great features! FIRST: There are TWO BlueTooth connection/pairings possible. SUPER. I've got it set up for both my iMac and my laptop PC. A quick Function+key press changes the keyboard from OS to PC set up. I can use ONE keyboard for both machines as I need, switching back and forth. Aside from 2 bluetooth connections, it also has a receiver (2.4G connection). Because of my home internet situation, the mouse has to use the 2.4G and the keyboard uses BT. That's on me. KEYBOARD: nice full size, has a built in angle for typing ease and feels good when you type. The keys soft click when you press them (I like) the sound is not obnoxious. There are little lights on the top edge for pairing Bluetooth 1 and 2, 2.4G, battery. They do not stay lit, just function when you need them to. The keyboard and mouse were easy to pair (follow instructions if you need). Only thing I wish it had that I don't see: an indicator light showing if you've got the number lock engaged or not. When the caps lock is on the A/battery light will show green, so you can see that easy enough. Both mouse and keyboard charge with a usb type c port - and important! So you can charge and use them at the same time. It doesn't say anything about how to change out the keyboard's rechargeable 800 mAh lithium battery and there are no visible entry points into the keyboard. Mouse uses a "size 14500" rechargeable battery (there is a small screw under the receiver). Batteries could be an issue down the road. The mouse is super slim (not high profile). It has different colored LED light effects, haven't figured those out yet. The instructions with the keyboard are a bit sparse, but all the important things are on there. I set this up in less than 5 minutes...it's working great, feels great, keypad spacing feels good. Functionality is fantastic. A winner.

title: A nice huge bag to take everything with you!
text:
Got this bag the other day and my first impression is that this is a pretty well made bag with lots of pocket and sections to keep things organized. It has two big compartment with each able to carry a fairly big size laptop. I had no issue fitting both my Inspiron 15 5000 which is a 15.5” and my Asus 14” Chromebook and most probably can also handle a 17” laptop as well but it will be tight. With that said, here are some of my early observations.

1) Lots of space & many pockets including two very large compartment to keep your laptops, chargers, or books and even some cloths with you on short trips.
2) Includes a USB charging port so you won’t have to dig into your bag trying to find that charger in this huge bag. However there is no pocket on the inside to hold that battery so when opening the bag you have to be mind-full of the charging wire.
3) Comfortable to carry (to a point). If you fill it to the max, especially since it has the room, your stuff will protrude from the back, making it awkward & uncomfortable to carry.
4) Looks durable & well made. Even when stuffed full, I never got the feeling that it would come apart.
5) Water resistant – Before risking my laptops & cloths, I did a test run to make sure it was water-resistant and it was and so no worry there.
6) The bag is rigid as you can see from the photos. Even when empty, it is standing up on its own.
7) There are no inside restraints to hold your laptop or sensitive electronics like camera in place so the laptop or camera can move around inside & move side to side especially if it’s small.
8) The side mesh pockets are mostly good only for water bottles & or storing some tissues or cloth but not for anything else and especially not for cables or chargers as they can get entangled in there.

Overall, I recommend this bag even though it’s a little too big for my taste. But if you need something roomy to take to the beach, camping or even to class, this is your bag and most importantly its a good value for what you're getting.

title: Attractive, syncs to Google Photos, well thought-out options
text:
My wife wanted a digital photo frame which looks like a real picture frame and not like a smart assistant. I wanted to make sure it could sync to Google Photos rather than relying on yet another cloud repository, in the very likely possibility that the company no longer exists in 20 years.

This review is based on syncing to Google Photos. I did not try Aura's support for uploading photos directly to their servers or syncing with other photo services.

Pros
-----
* We picked the version with a white mat, which looks like a desktop picture frame
* Aura does have its own cloud repository, but you can simply point it at your Google Photos library or a single Google Photos Album and it will automatically update your Aura photos to keep them in sync
* The frame will automatically place pairs of portrait-orientation images side by side, or you can disable this so only a single image is shown at a time
* The frame will automatically turn off when the room lights are out, or you can instead set it to turn on and off based on time of day
* The frame automatically brightens/dims based on ambient light level
* Other options: set image timing from 15 sec to 24 hours, shuffle-play photos, enable or disable autoplaying videos, enable/disable notifications, etc
* Images have good contrast, brightness, and colors
* App-based setup is pretty easy

Cons
------
* Viewing angles are not as good as I would have expected, so images look washed out if you're looking at the frame from - say - 45 degrees
* Not wall-mountable
* Google Photos does not upload videos to the frame (I think they appear as stills?)

Using Google Face Recognition
------------------------------------
I created an album of our granddaughter using Google's automatic face recognition. So now when our daughter in law texts my wife a photo, she simply saves it to her Photo Library on her iPhone. Next Google Photos automatically uploads it to her Google Photos library where the face recognition adds it to our granddaughter's album. Then a few minutes later the image syncs to Aura's servers and finally appears in the photo frame.

title: Way Better than any Arc Mouse - Spectacular
text: So, I know that it sounds odd to rave so much about a "simple computer mouse".  But that's not what this is.  It IS what I expected to receive, particularly at the outstanding price.  I have been a loyal fan of the ARC-shaped mice for well over a decade, choosing them over the very sleek Apple mouse options.  I love great design, and thus, I am an Apple devotee as well.  I will admit that with several design (imitations), Microsoft too, has come quite far in this area.  So, that said, it seems natural to want to spend lots of money on a "great mouse".  Well, if you are looking at this TECKNET mouse and are giving it serious consideration, end your search and buy this.  I swear that I have four black ARC mice near my computer, one of them the expensive Microsoft original.  And they ARE beautiful.  But the feel, the responsiveness, overall performance, and the look right out of the box have ALL made this the authentic PERFECT FIVE STARS that I gave it.  If I had to find a fault with it I would have to say that it's the fact that this one still uses the very small-sized standard USB connector for a Bluetooth signal to the mouse.  However, the most recent ARC mouse I have been using still worked and still felt good ergonomically.  BUT... when I say that it worked, I mean about half of the time.  It didn't use the little USB piece for a signal, which I initially loved and was impressed by.  It connects directly from mouse to computer by Bluetooth.  WHILE and WHEN working.  When you're working on anything that's giving you deadline anxiety or that you just want to work smoothly through, those without the USB connector piece WILL soon drive you entirely MAD CRAZY.  This not only feels good in the hand and works flawlessly and with instant responsiveness.  It doesn't EVER (yet) lose it's strong connection.  Out of fear that it could 'come and go' and wind up disappearing, I bought a second one - especially at such a great price.  In addition to this being SUCH an exceptional computer mouse, this is also a great seller to get it from, who will promptly follow-up with you to make sure you are pleased with your purchase.

title: Very lightweight, dongle will be lost
text:
This mouse is going into my laptop bag, to replace an old Logitech Unifying travel mouse.

This mouse is super lightweight. When I unpacked it, I wondered if it even had a battery inside it! In despite of the light weight, it does have a battery and a magnetic holder for the dongle.

Now, I am not a fan of most magnetic holders, and the one that holds the dongle in place is ad bad as it gets. It is nice that there is a place for the dongle on the bottom of the mouse, but the magnet is too weak to properly hold it in place. A bit of shaking and the dongle falls right out! This is not good for a travel mouse, and I am sure that I will loose the dongle quickly on one of my trips. For the next iteration of the design, I would suggest a mechanical 'lock' to keep the dongle in place.

The good part is that the dongle is only needed on devices that do not have Bluetooth, and since my laptop does have that, I will be using it primarily as a bluetooth mouse..

Pairing was super easy, I did not even need to use the manual: Turn the mouse to bluetooth mode, and let Windows scan. It shows up as a Bluetooth Mouse and connects right away. The mouse-wheel had an LED behind it that stays on while the mouse is powered on, so it is easy to remember to turn the mouse off before putting it away. I am not a fan of blue LED's in electronics, but this one is not bright nor intrusive.

The ergonomic shape is OK, if not a bit small for my large hands. It has the standard 3 buttons (left, middle, right) and the scroll wheel. All buttons function out of the box. The additional DPI button has a dramatic effect, and the effect is immediate. Works well!

A big one for me is that this uses a USB-C charging port. Good job here - There are still too many new devices on the market that use older standards.

Overall, this is a decent travel mouse that works as advertised, with the dongle holder as it's greatest flaw.

title: Jury is out on this one on rated for 2000 hours non continuous use?
text:
I will adjust this review as time goes on.

They changed the power from 12V to 5V which might not be enough Flow vs my old 12volt (discontinued)
It uses a USB adapter which sticks out further than the wall wart 12v did.

Price seems a bit skewed for what you get. Its just a $3.00 PC fan not even sure it has ball bearings. But unlike a PC fan it has a temp probe. Not sure that is really worth the price vs a fixed or adjustable fan.

Time will tell.

I just check these two new USB fans vs the original 2006 coralvue fans (12volt .5amp)
Mind you these fans were full of salt from 2006 they were caked. They had run over 14 years non stop. I only oiled the bearings.

Watts -
Old fans(CV-Fan4) - 3.9 watts (probes are broken no low speed but still quite)
New Fans (USB 5v) - 1.7 to 3 watts. Probe on one works better than other. One fan is faster at same temp drawing 1.7 watts other fan draws .9 watts with much slower speed. If you heat the probes to 98f with hand they ramp up to 3watts and feel about as fast as the old fans but.........

They are louder than old fans, they have high pitched whine. I looked at the blades and the old fans are rounded while need fan blades have sharp squared off corners. Not a huge deal but not as quite and they vibrate more.

- This is almost a showstopper for me - The website says the fans cant be run 24/7 they rated for 2000 hours? That is only 83 days. I ran the old ones 14 years. They are just PC 120mm fans with a temp probe on them. New one probably is not ball bearing. You have to run them 24/7 there is not switch they don't auto turn off and they are for a sump or canopy. Has to be a typo on their site or a cleaver way to avoid returns.

title: works for my usb-c monitor!
text:
The usb-c cable that came with my monitor is dying and I need a replacement fast. I've tried a few cables that I have lying at home but none of those worked. That is when I start to research and realize there are different standards and throughput involved in cables as well. So armed with this new knowledge, I start my hunt on a cable that fits my needs. Turns out, the search is way easier once I stumbled upon this cable.

Pros:
- rated at 100W PD, you can charge your devices quickly. This cable can even support charging heavy demand devices like macbook pro (given you have a 85W+ charging adapter as well, as just the cable won't do)

- 8K video - This is the main reason I get this cable for is the video capability. Connecting usb-c monitor w/ laptop is easy. As long as your laptop supports USB video (I think it's called DP Alt Mode? Honestly not too sure what that means), it will work. My macbook pro is quite old, and my laptop has "Thunderbolt 3. According to online, thunderbolt 3 is capable of 40Gb/s throughput. However, this cable works well with it, outputting video to my usb-c monitor without issues.

- thick braided cable - even though it's not as flexible, it's more sturdy for my setup, which is a portable setup that I wrap and unwrap the cables alot.

Cons:
- USB 3.2 Gen 2 standard (NOT thunderbolt) - Note that this is not USB 3.2 Gen 2x2 (which is multi-lane operation thus double the total throughput) or thunderbolt 3 or 4, so it caps at 10Gb/s. It's definitely not the fastest but fast enough for most operations that I need it for. Also to note that older devices will probably be cap at 5Gb/s or lower if they don't support USB3.2 Gen 2 standard. That's not the fault of the cable but rather limitation of the device itself.
- price tag - there are some thunderbolt 4 cables out there around the same price (or slightly more). However, those cables are thinner and are not braided. So quality purpose, I would prefer this cable more.

title: performs like a pro mic. these other reviews are misinformed. please read.
text:
[[VIDEOID:213770b423fe2955cc63ce95779fd877]] Originally I'd tested an $80 Rode Lavalier Go microphone on the Zoom H1n and it was terrible. The noise floor was way too high and the mic required too much gain to capture my voice whilst fastened to my chest. I promptly returned that microphone and bought this one...

I took a chance on this since it delivered same day and it was so cheap and it just performed beautifully. I own six different lav mics from several top brands, and this one is easily comparable to them (better than some). I only added about 3 notches of gain and I could hear myself clearly with very little white noise. I could easily gate out the noise floor...

We'll see how it fairs in the long term, as I've only just received it, but so far this lav mic has left a very good impression. Especially considering all of the extra kit included with the mic. (replacement filters, extension cable, and TRRS to TRS converter)

"noise cancellation is on your phone, not the mic"
just fyi... these reviewers complaining about "noise cancellation" need to educate themselves on audio gear. I don't think they understand that acoustical noise cancellation is a software algorithm installed on their smart phones, the microphone is merely built to support it. You can turn it off on your smartphone. It is not a feature of the microphone.

If I don't take care to keep my gain down, this microphone will pickup everything in the area with no problem, that's because my zoom recorder has no acoustical noise cancellation. You can hear this in my recording. (if amazon will ever allow me to post it.)

"the mic survives minor bumps and drops just fine."
furthermore, there is another review complaining their microphone died after dropping it 3 feet. I was concerned about that so I gave mine a few test drops 5ft and light smacks onto a marble floor. works fine. I think they're either downplaying the severity of their abuse or got a defective model and should've filed a warranty claim rather than whining on amazon.

hope this helps!

title: Early review. Solves audio connectivity problems with 2012-2018 Audi MMI.
text:
I have had the 9" Carpuride display for 3 days and so far it seems to be working okay. I drive a 2016 Audi A3 e-Tron which has a notoriously horrible audio system and screen called MMI. MMI is especially bad when paired with an iPhone, so I decided to go Carpuride and just forget the whole built-in screen aside from the backup camera.

The Carpuride is surprisingly well built and has a great looking screen. It is a little laggy but it is just as fast as any other Carplay screen I have used. It was really complicated getting it to work seamlessly with the Audi MMI, but that is the MMI's fault. If you own an Audi and are having trouble check out the AudiWorld forums. I have a tutorial over there.

The built-in speaker sucks, the first thing I recommend is going into settings and muting it. The FM transmitter isn't much better but it is a nice touch. The aux output is satisfactory, but if you are using Carplay you can actually get your phone to send data to the screen and audio to your car's bluetooth. This is where this device really shines. The description doesn't list bluetooth output as an option because it is really your phone that is routing the audio. It is kind of complicated to get it to work but once you do this thing rocks. I assume you can do this with android too, but I am not sure.

Using bluetooth audio direct to your car gives you a one cord system (just the power cable into 12V) and if you set it up right it looks like it is part of your car. So many cars from the 2010s don't have touchscreens so this really updates any car from that era providing a vibrant touchscreen and enhancing the functionality of your stereo. It would be even better for a car that doesn't have a screen. I just got rid of a 2011 CR-V and I REALLY wish I would have had this thing before I sold it, I may have kept it.

I will report back after living with this thing for a few weeks but if somebody would have told me I could add Carplay to my dated Audi for less than $250, I would have paid it immediately. This does just that and so far so good...

title: Works great so far, replaced YL1200500 AC adapter.
text:
This YL1200500 cable amplifier originally powered a 9-port Cable TV splitter amplifier that Time Warner Cable (now Spectrum) had installed at our house 9 years ago. We later "cut the cord" and got rid of our cable TV subscription and I mounted an outside over the air TV antenna and connected it to this same TV splitter, which distributed OTA TV throughout our house cable wiring. Everything worked fine until late last year when two channels from the furthest broadcast TV tower channels started cutting in an out intermittently. I initially blamed it on the Winegard preamplifier attached to the outdoor TV antenna and replaced it, but the problem continued.

Eventually I figured out that it was really the power supply to the TV splitter amplifier, this YingJiao YL1200500. It was running really hot, and taking it off and letting it cool could bring it back to life. The thing is pretty heavy, indicating it has a pretty heavy duty iron core transformer inside. I was going to get another one of these on eBay, but then I saw this model on Amazon. Another review had indicated that this one was much lighter, which I didn't think was necessarily a good thing, until I saw the High Efficiency Level VI energy rating. That actually turns out to mean something! Less wasted power draw when the adapter is not being used!

It turns out that these newer High Efficiency AC power adapters use the high frequency Switched Mode Power Supply (SMPS). Instead of sending the high voltage low frequency (60Hz) first into a heavy duty transformer to step down into a low voltage low frequency current, the SMPS uses a transistor switch to convert the house AC current into a high frequency high voltage current that can then be run through a much more efficient low mass transformer to do the step down into a low voltage high frequency current. This is then converted into low voltage DC current. This is why these newer AC power adapters are so light, because they no longer need these big heavy transformers. These efficient SMPS power supplies were first used for computer power supplies, and now they are pretty standard circuitry for the multitude of small AC adapter bricks that we use for all our personal electronics.

Anyway, so far so good. The TV channels are all back again.

title: Not expandable nor does it have an App Store
text:
TLDR: An excellent smartwatch that does 60% of that other famous watch brand at 15% of the cost.

FULL REVIEW:
This smartwatch looks very similar to that other famous brand and even has many similar features. However, it is limited to the apps and features that are pre-installed. That being said, it has a lot going for it as a daily activity tracker that can track many health and exercise features. On the iPhone, the data can be transferred to the Apple Health app.

One area that is expandable are watch faces, you can have one custom installed watch face and three built-in watch faces that are not removable. There are lots of choices available through an accessory app called VeryFit (see photos). Unlike Apple’s customizable complications (data info), this smart watch can only display what is predesigned into the watch face. For example, you cannot show the weather or stock market data on a watch face. That data is available but you need to swipe left or right through different screens.

I noticed that the watchbands are easily removable by pulling back a small pin on the back of the band (see photo) however, I’m not aware of any other watch bands that can be purchased for this watch.

It does lack an always-on display so you need to lift and twist your wrist to turn on the screen. There’s about a half second delay before it turns on. Touching the display does not work either but you can press the crown to activate the display. The crown can rotate but doesn’t seem to be utilized in software, instead, you must swipe up on the screen to scroll long lists.

When using the touch display, it is not as quick and responsive as I like. Sometimes I have trouble on the press and hold feature which doesn’t always seem to work. There is some haptic feedback but it’s not always used.

Thanks for sticking with me on this long review but I wanted to make sure you got the info you were looking for.

For the price, this smart watch offers a lot of features but don’t expect it to compete on the same level as that other very famous brand of smart watches.

title: Worst Setup Experience I Have Ever Had - Horrible Performance - Horrible App - Total Junk
text:
This is, by far, the worst Arris experience I have ever had. The modem part (Arris's real expertise) is fine but the router part is junk. The app & customer support are beyond bizarre. I regret this purchase.

1) The smart phone app is a disaster. It hangs up in the middle of installation, it somehow can't find connection to the service. Once installed, it continues to regularly drop connection to the network when everything else on your network remains connected. It makes configuring and setting up your router a nightmare.
2) Phone support for installation support is beyond bizarre. I was connected to what sounded like an artifical intelligence robot with a very thick Latin American accent. While the AI robot-sounding humanoid did finally get me basically connected, the end of the call was just him sending me back into that nightmare app to finish setup. That went well. (/s)
3) The router is a joke. It supposedly can satisfy a 4500 sft home but the signal cannot even acceptably travel 9 feet through traditional plaster walls. No setup or configuration instructions come with the equipment and what the company provides online is minimal and incomprehensible. The band sharing management features between 2.5 and 5 ghz don't work. And I have received the slowest wifi speeds I have EVER seen. While the signal is blazing fast in the room where the modem is (4 feet away), I was literally seeing 2.1 mbps upload and .5 download 9 feet away. Once you configure a feature (such as band sharing) in the app it is next to impossible to turn it back off due to the constant "lost network connections." Configuration, again, is a nightmare.

This is just about the worst installation experience of any kind I've had in the past 20 years purchasing from a reputable company. Arris doesn't know squat about bringing routers or smart phone apps to consumers and it shows with this poor product. Whoever within the company brought this to market deserves to be stripped of all dignity and walk in shame a la Game of Thrones. At least that's how I felt yesterday.

So now I have a (very expensive) modem and will have to buy a mesh router system to pair with it. Do not go into this purchase expecting the router to be adequate or easy in the least. Buy something else.

title: This adapter is great, but it also makes me hate macOS
text:
First thing about this thing is that it's pretty massive. You can reduce the size by removing the protective rubber sleeve. With the rubber sleeve it kind of almost feels like a USB-C dock in some sort of way. I couldn't test behavior w/ all 3 display outputs connected, nor when connecting to 2 4K monitors. However, single 4K monitor works fine, and 2 1440p monitor worked fine when connected to either HDMI+DP or over only the DP (the monitors were DP daisy chained in this case) in extended mode. Keep in mind though that this is only possible on Windows (and probably Linux), because macOS doesn't support DP MST, connecting either daisy-chained monitors (over DP) or connecting 2 monitors with this hub only works in mirrored mode, not extended. There's no way around this because Apple is stupid, if you needed this functionality you'll need either a DisplayLink or Thunderbolt dock instead.
