The 100W charging seems to work okay, although when I say okay it means that it reported 92W when I connected it to my Macbook Pro A2485. This is to be expected in my past experiences; I didn't get a chance test this on laptops w/ more temperamental USB-C power delivery, such as the XPS 17, so keep some of these things in mind.

So overall, this hub works great if you're on Windows, and it's large enough to actually be used as a dock. The multitude of connectors gives you a lot of connectivity if say, you're constantly on the move and debugging hardware/connecting to a variety of monitors. The VGA helps too. If you're on macOS though, unless if you're say, going around and having to connect to a variety of monitors w/ different display inputs, this thing becomes less practical, because of macOS's lack of DP MST support, meaning you can only connect to 1 monitor in extended mode (connecting 2 or more will cause them to be mirrored). It's also quite pricy (at the time of this review, it's $70 w/ a 5% discount coupon) to the point where you might want to investigate used Thunderbolt 3 dock options if you're looking for a more stationary dock approach. Overall though, if you're on Windows, and you need to connect to a variety of different monitor outputs, then this thing is great.

title: Definitely NOT waterproof! Challenging to learn all the features. Nice looking.
text:
Bottom Line: This watch (which is advertised as 'Waterproof') is NOT waterproof. My husband had been wearing it for a week or two, trying to learn it's features. Then one day he reached into the hot tub without thinking, since he has always worn waterproof watches, and this watch died. It was only under water for 1-2 seconds, but it never worked again. :(( So then he tried to take it apart to allow it to dry out, but taking it apart ruined it and it was already corroded inside anyway. Big disappointment, as this watch was nice-looking, the rubber watch band was very comfortable, and it apparently had a lot of features.

But I will try to review what he learned in the short 1-2 weeks of wearing it.

*First, as already stated, it's a nice-looking watch. My husband received multiple compliments from friends.
*The user gets 2 watch bands to choose from -- a black metal band and a black rubber/silicone band. He chose to use the black rubber watch band, as his arm is too hairy for metal bands which pinch. He liked the mechanism to attach the bands, with tool included, and thinks the band may even work with another watch face he owns.
*It has a very solid feel.
*The instructions provided are for using the associated app rather than for using the watch. And the instructions AND app were clearly written/designed by someone (or people) for whom English is not their first language.
*The charge cord connects to the watch via a somewhat weak magnetic contact on the back of the watch. It requires a specific orientation, so the watch and cord have to be set up and handled delicately to ensure the connection does not separate.
*A limited number of underwhelming watch faces are built in, but supposedly more options are available through the app.
*When the watch is connected to a phone via bluetooth, the watch annoyingly takes over as the primary speaker and microphone for all phone calls.
*Used the heartrate monitor only one time, and it seemed to be accurate.

Again, my husband did not get to really explore the many features offered by this watch and the app, as he quickly discovered this watch has no tolerance for getting wet. Thank you!

title: Well rounded watch.
text:
HYDZXINGW 2-in-1 Smart Watch with Earbuds - $82.99
This is my first time owning a smartwatch, so take my review accordingly.
First impressions are that it is well made and doesn't feel cheap in the hand.
-Easy to attach the band to the watch face.
-There is one tactile button on the side of the watch and the rest is touch UI.
-The touchscreen is responsive but does take a while to get used to navigating all the different screens and menus.
-There are a lot of different watch faces to choose from. More than what I've shown in the attached picture. Can upload and customize your own.
-Checks heart rate, blood oxygen level, counts steps, calories burned, and measures blood pressure. All of these are just general calculations and should not replace accurate medical equipment.
-Monitors sleep activities.
-Syncs with your weather.
-Earbuds are SMALL. Sound isn't that great and are a little tinny sounding. However, if I physically hold them a certain angle they sound better with a lot of bass. But just staying in my ears as is no matter how I orient them doesn't produce great audio. I got used to it.
-You can put bigger tips on the earbuds, but only slightly. Otherwise the watch face won't close properly.
-Earbuds last about 4 hours listening to music.
-Watch takes about 1-1.5 hours to charge.
-Does all the usual things smart watches do: Displays text msgs, alarm clock, timer, stop watch, find your phone.
-The app is easy to navigate and syncs with any changes to the watch and vice versa.

Note: Bluetooth connectivity between the watch or earbuds and phone or mobile device are separate. You have to connect the watch and the earbuds as separate devices. The earbuds don't pair through the watch.

Overall I am pleased with this. I wish the buds were better sounding and this would be a home run. 4.5-4.75 stars. Comes with charging cable and a spare set of tips.

title: A great alternative to a popular version, but at half the cost...
text:
THE GOOD:
---------------
* In terms of movement, and smoothness, it's just as good as the popular "L" brand version.
* Perfect for browsing your laptop or notebook while laying down.
* This is great for desktop as well if you don't have a lot of desk space.
* Compared to the popular L brand version, I do feel an improvement in ergonomics. There was a longer "getting use to it" time with the L brand version because my hands wouldn't completely rest on the mouse, and it created this tense feeling, when the objective is to make you feel less stressed and more relaxed. With this MicroPack version, due to a taller design, it took less time to get used to.
* The scroll wheel is perfectly placed.
* There is also one more button, it's the DPI sensitivity switch button.
* The track ball/marble size of the MicroPack is the same size as the L brand blue version, but they ARE NOT interchangeable.
* Battery compartment also has a magnetic compartment to house the 2.4 receiver.

THE BAD:
------------
* No bluetooth, then again, the L brand doesn't have bluetooth either and it cost twice as much.
* Now, I've gone through many L brand ones in my life. They all eventually go bad because the trackball collects debris, and no matter how often you clean the mouse, they eventually go bad. If you don't believe me, look at the picture I uploaded with the 5 blue marbles. That's 5 L brand versions that have gone bad, but I saved the marbles. So I'm anticipating the same sort of life span for this Micropack version, which is about 1 to 2 yrs.
* The L brand also beats the Micropack with it's unifying receiver system, as well as a dedicated software. This Micropack mouse simply uses your windows software for configuration.
* The L brand also has 2 more buttons next to the scroll wheel that you can customize.

Ultimately, I still rate this Micropack vesion 5-Stars! Because though it lacks some features compared to the L brand, it is half the cost. 5-Stars... for now.

title: Decent quality for the price
text:
I haven't really used this yet, but my initial overview of it resulted in choosing to keep it. I ordered a few different tripods, looking for a decent compact travel tripod, and this is the winner.
I know that there are better travel tripods, but they are much higher priced (think Peak Design, 3 Legged Thing, etc.). This is not intended to be my primary tripod, so can get away with a bit more in the way of shortcomings.
The build quality is adequate and doesn't seem overly flimsy.
The flip locks on the legs are quick and convenient. They are made of plastic, so I'm hoping that they will hold up.
The ball head is very small, but seems to be sturdy enough to hold the camera. Biggest issue is the width of the Arca clamp as it seems narrow, meaning less area to grip. I think I've got that figure out so that it won't be a problem, but I'll need to be mindful of it.
Stability is questionable with the center column extended, so that will generally be a last resort. It seems stable enough for what it is when relying on the legs alone.
Detachable leg monopod is a nice extra, and it doesn't feel like it will come off on it's own. This was an issue I had with another tripod. I don't know how much I will use that feature, but it's great to have.
Carrying case is adequate, but is very cheap compared to some other. Just an observation, and not really a complaint at this price point. It will likely be used very little regardless.
The tripod also came with a smartphone adapter. This is probably the lowest quality item included. It's seems to be a very cheap plastic, and just barely large enough to hold my phone. I look forward to using it, as it's an item that I've had multiple used for in the past, but I will always be cautious of it breaking.
Do I recommend this tripod? Yes, as long as you know that it's not a top quality tripod. You really are getting what you are paying for, maybe a bit more. The other tripods that I opted against were more expensive than this one and just didn't quite meet the mark. Judge your usage appropriately to determine if it will work for you.

title: Great Camera, still many issues.
text: Update 2: Finally found someone helpful at Red Tiger. They recommended another dash cam software. However, that software didn’t offer Geotagging, so they offered a $50 refund so I could purchase my own 3rd party software. Update: I removed a star, because their customer service is not as awesome as some have stated when dealing with a return. Apparently I ordered the newer version with a in vehicle rear camera. All the instructions were for out of vehicle placement. Needless to say camera got wet and moisture got into it, and it became cloudy. Additionally, their software for PC is atrocious. It’s not even downloadable from their website. It points you to a very shady download site, that throws up virus warnings on your PC. I have a very powerful gaming laptop, their pc app crashes my computer within minutes of opening. Their answer is to run in compatibility mode. That doesn’t work either. Be willing to shell out another $35-$75 on dash cam viewing software, if you want geotagging. Wasn’t sure what to expect for the price, but it’s a great camera. Video is clear from front and rear, day & night. The App makes setup easier, than setting up on the camera unit. I added a 256GB micro SD, that’s the max the unit can use, and should be plenty. The instructions are not well written, you can tell they’ve been translated to English from Chinese. The manual is very small, and hard to read with the very small fonts. However, it’s available online. I opted to hardwire the unit over using the 12V accessory, for the added features, and cosmetics of the car. I purchased a hardwire kit on my own, but it does state in the manual, they will send you one for free (wish I’d have read that part first). Hardwiring to the vehicle was simple enough, only 3 wires BAT/ACC/Ground. Your mileage may vary from vehicle to vehicle however. I purchased the double fuse wiring kit, because it has fuse taps for all fuse sizes, and you can tap into another fuse if your fuse box is full. I can’t comment on customer support yet, I just purchased, so no need to contact them yet. This is probably one of the best cameras out there under $200

title: My 11 yr old making moves with this
text: I had orders this to review for my 11 year old son . When I pick things to review I try really hard to pick items that are worth the retail price because even tho it is sent to me at no cost , the retail cost is reported as income to the Tax man and I do have to pay income taxes on the item . If something sucks I will say so . I get the items even if I wrote a bad review if it sucks so when I say this was a great item to review for us I mean it . My 11 year old plays Kerbal space program on PlayStation network and he is all about space . He constantly tells me random space facts and brings up events regarding space . Sounds , sights , facts , we even tasted space flavored coke . It’s like raspberry rum . So he started asking for a telescope and m all for buying him one but I wanted to start small and go from there . This was offered for review and I requested it , it didn’t look like much when it came . It’s kinda little compared to a regular telescope. It’s portable in a pocket kinda sized . It’s been a good month or 2 since we got it . My kid takes it EVERYWhERE ! It wasn’t until about a week ago that I realized how awesome this this is , he had asked me to show him how to print photos of things he captured using this little tool. We printed it up and I was shocked to see Saturn . I can see the planet and the rings in the photo . My kid used an old iPhone 7 to take photos thru the eye piece of this little telescope . I gotta admit I was not expecting to see Saturn . I will find the photo he printed . My 11 year old is getting up at 6 AM voluntarily to look at the sky with this . It’s fueling the fire in my son for space . I couldn’t be happier . It came with lens cover caps for both ends . The only thing I dislike is the lenses come off with his carting it around but that’s probably more on him being 11 then anything . I’d give it 10 stars if I could . This for our needs so well . It’s a love for us . I’d recommend it , order it again and buy it for a loved one if they wanted to look at the stars and space .

title: DRIVES ME NUTS!!
text:
Review is for Drivesmart 65 with Alexa unit but not including the use of Alexa.
The Good:
Driving instructions at intersections have always been good, and they still are. And, Garmin support when you call them is and always has been supurb. Altogether I and wife have several non-auto Garmin units, for cycling specific, triathlon wrist units, backcountry off-grid hiking. I wish all companies had such support.

The Mixed:
This Alexa unit recognizes speech very well, compared to previous auto models (I have 3 Garmin auto navigators). But, have been unable to access many many carefully marked sites on other models with with specific site names I've assigned, IN SPITE OF GARMIN EXPRESS showing it still has the ability to move saved sites from one model to another. Maybe the site names have been transferred, but I cannot find them under the names I've given.

The company Garmin uses for updating maps is super slow in being current (It took almost 3 years to change exit numbers to the mileage based ones on the Massachusetts Turnpike!). That company also uses local names taken from official maps of localities and counties -- unfortunately when everyone local refers to a road by its highway name, e.g. Route 146, Garmin maps will show the politically-nice name, like Clifton Park Highway, or Halfmoon Blvd for US Route 9. Google maps is up to date and uses Highway Route numbers. Imagine going on a trip, following a map on what at one point is called Rt 67 and suddenly have it change every time you go through a small town, leading you to wonder if you missed a turn somewhere and are lost.

Frequently I have to rely on WAZE to find something or something near where I want to go; then I can on my phone or car display tap on the specific location close to what in the past I carefully named on previous navigators and then get driving specifics.
Unless I know the very VERY SPECIFIC COMMERCIAL NAME for a place I want to go, the place does not exist on this model! Sometimes when I go to the separate app imbedded in the unit, the app will find what I want. But using WAZE is faster.

title: Great for Recording thoughts or video
text:
I use this for times when I am brainstorming ideas for my business in terms of video content or marketing. Usually, my go-to method is to walk around and record myself as I come up with ideas, and then I transcribe them later using the software. It's a quick and easy way for me to get all my thoughts out as they flow, and then I go back and organize them.

When I am walking around, I usually hold my phone up and talk into it, but I like talking with my hands and holding my phone; it sometimes causes the recording to go in and out regarding the volume of my voice, which can mess with the transcription software. So I bought this microphone because it was a great price. The cable is a great length for being able to clip it onto my shirt and have it plugged into my phone, and I still have a decent amount of slack in the cord. The clip keeps the microphone in its place, and the foam windshield does a great job of canceling out my pop sounds while at the same time not adding a lot of rustling noises from my shirt.

The sound pickup is great for the microphone and it is very clear. My transcription software was able to transcribe my thoughts a little more clearly than just hand-holding the phone. the microphone is also directional, so it picks up my voice but drowns out a lot of the background noise, which is always a great benefit. I did not notice any static or hissing when I plugged it into my audio interface to do a test comparison, but I noticed a slight amount when I had it plugged into my phone, but that may have been my phone or the case preventing it from going in 100%.

These will also work as lapel microphones to plug into a wireless transmitter that accepts 3.5mm microphones. I have a few Rode Go Wireless IIs, but these would be great for being more discreet or even as a backup, so I may be picking up a few more of these soon.

Overall, I think this microphone serves its purpose very well; I think it is a great price for the quality of the microphone and its value. I may look crazy walking around and talking to myself, but it's worth it for the time it saves me sitting in front of a computer trying to organize my thoughts.

title: This Review Will Tell You Everything...
text:
Summary: If you use Elgato and Large External Storage Drives then "PASS". All others consider this Hub if you know that you need USB 3.2 otherwise, get something more affordable.

Computers
Main System - MacBook Pro 16" M1 Max 64GB / 1TB
Secondary System - Lenovo ThinkPad P16 i9 vPro and RTX 128GB / 2TB

Pro:
* 3x Thunderbolt Ports and 1 is used to power your laptop so you get only 2 which is ok.
* MacBook Pro M1 uses USB 3.1 on its ports, but this HUB allows you to take advantage of USB 3.2 to get the max speeds on your devices that support USB 3.2. The hub then sends the data down the Thunderbolt 4.
* The HUB is able to power your MacBook Pro perfectly.
* DisplayPort 1.4 on the Hub allows you to use HDR, VRR and at least with my monitor 144hz

Negative:
* Sleep Mode Nightmares. Even on the latest firmware 39.1 you get all your external drives ejected. You have to physically reconnect the drives.
* CalDigit Support? UPDATE: [3/8/23] Finally for with support. But after many exchanges, they had no idea what caused the problem. They blamed all of the different brands of storage I would test from Western Digital to Seagate or SanDisk Extreme SSD. Maybe I have a defective unit? Will I don't think so it is easier for them to blame the customers and anything you decide to plug in the hub? I think it would have been better not to get them to reply.
[Original] Doesn't exist... Going for weeks without a reply other than their auto reply that asks you to provide information regardless of whether you already provided the information. Don't think Support exists and if they do, they clearly do not know how to do Customer Service.

Conclusion:
This is an excellent choice for Windows-based workstations and for macOS Power Users comfortable with higher levels of technical knowledge. Everyone else looking for a carefree plug n play experience should consider other more affordable options. You WILL NOT get any technical support from CalDigit in a timely fashion.

title: We LOVE these headphones!
text:
We got these headphones to use with a TV that doesn’t have Bluetooth, and it works perfect! Not only that, but it was extremely easy to set up. After plugging in the digital optical cable (included) to the back of the TV and the back of the headphone controller, and plugging in the controller to a power source, there was nothing more to do except to turn on the headphones. And in case you were curious, the speakers on your TV will continue to broadcast the sound, even though the headphones are also broadcasting it. You can turn off your TV’s speakers if you want, and the headphones will still play the sound.

A few things about these headphones that I didn’t expect (but really like):
1. The quality of the sound is excellent!
2. The volume control allows you to turn it up to an almost uncomfortable level.
3. The earphones are extremely comfortable – even after hours of wearing them.
4. The volume and power controls on the side of the right side are simple and easy to use.

Because I was so impressed with the things I mentioned I didn’t expect, I decided to plug it into my laptop to see if they were better than the Bluetooth headphones or earbuds that I usually use with it. Bottom line – YES! These headphones are MUCH better than any Bluetooth headphones or earbuds for all the same reasons I mentioned above. And it’s easier to connect to my laptop than my TV. Just plug the controller in using the USB cable and that’s it! Turn on the headphones and you’re connected.

For anyone who wants to know how far you can go before losing connectivity, I’ve managed to go over 100 feet. That may not sound impressive, but that 100+ feet includes going down 2 flights of stairs and through a 2 car garage on the opposite side of the house than the controller was sitting. This is as good as the best Bluetooth connection I’ve tested, so I’m satisfied with the distance it provides.

On a fully charged battery, we got a total of 46 hours 38 minutes of “on” time.
Charging a completely depleted battery took 2 hours 25 minutes.

title: Wait! This can't be happening.
text:
Quick delivery...check!
Good packaging...check!
Plug and go...check!
Set up...a miracle! No yelling or cursing. No trips to the liquor store. No threats to toss the darn thing in the trash. No tears!
Connecting to the internet...my first really scary moment. Suddenly a list of available networks pops up. I seIect mine, enter the password, hold my breath for a few seconds and voila...network connection established. Then I hit the sync button and before my eyes my old computer magically inhabited my new (far less expensive) companion. This couldn't be true! There were all my favorites, right where I left them. There was the obvious, of course. Documents and programs hadn't transferred, which was to be expected. Wait...Office 365 can't be installed? Run to Chrome support. It's true (takes up too much room and RAM), but there's a handy-dandy extension that let's you create, edit and save new and existing files. And it's FREE!
Oh, no...printing. I do a lot of that. It's a must have. Open the printer file, search for available printers, and, oh look, there it is. Hit connect and OMG--another miracle.
In less than an hour, my tech life has been fully restored and I'm thrilled. This little machine is amazing! It's fast (even with just 8GB), it's compact and lightweight, the display is quite good according to my 75-year-old eyes, easy to use (and answers to questions are readily available and are easy to understand language (no geek talk or superlative information), and the price point made me cry.
Now all those positive reviews make sense and seem real. Remember, we're talking the basics here. I'm no gaming, no photo or video editing, no high wire acts. I can even have multiple windows open at the same time without any negative impact. The analytics tell me I have a very weak wi-fi connection, which is a forgone conclusion--never buy a concrete block house.
I'm still discovering new things and constantly marveling at the performance and ease of use. But I've never made a tech purchase that was so exciting. If anything changes, I'll post an update.

title: Please read my review
text: So first off unfortunately I returned this projector but gave it a five star and I'll tell you why because for the price range in the dark it's literally just like watching a normal TV it's really bright really Crisp and I'm really happy with it just get to know the settings set the color how you like it set the size and really go into everything and know what it does because it's the first projector that I've seen where you can actually zoom in and out digitally it actually will make it fit your screen it's pretty cool the reason I returned it is because I like to hook up my Roku to projectors and unfortunately on this particular model you have to use both controllers you have to turn on the projector with the remote that it comes with and also you control the volume with that remote now the way it usually works is you should be able to turn on and off the projector with the Roku remote and do the volume with the Roku remote but since I cannot do either one of those that means you have to use two remotes and I definitely do not like doing that it's annoying especially if you're on the treadmill and you just want to get up and go. But if you don't mind using two remotes then I must say this is a really awesome projector but it's not for the daytime it should be completely dark your room cannot have any light in it it can have a little bit of light but it's only going to be for using at night time. I hope this review helped everybody out I'm sure if you're reading this you have a lot of questions and trust me if you don't mind to remotes this is a really nice one also it's got a USB port and I believe only one HDMI for the price point you can't beat it if there's only one more annoying thing about this unit is when you power it on and off I think you have to hit the power button twice it's kind of finicky and touchy just remember if you're going to buy a projector make sure that it's LED and not the old school regular bulbs with a filament. And I cannot stress this enough please read reviews you have to read the reviews if you just buy something without reading reviews it could be all bad and it's nice because you can go back and look at people's videos see what they say in the videos go back and look at pictures all right enough blabbering on here have a great night

title: Nice idea but solar panels don’t work… or take an extremely long time if they do
text:
With so many people losing power during the recent winter weather, I thought it would be good to have some way to charge our phones in case of lost power, and I thought this device was especially great because it has solar panels.

Well, the solar panels would be great if they actually charged the power bank, and maybe it does, in a few days or so. I had it sitting outside in the bright sun, panel lifted and pointing directly at the sun, for 5 and half hours today. The battery is still at the 2nd charge, which is what it was at when I took it out of the box.

There are 2 sets of instructions but they're both in German, which I can't read, so perhaps I'm doing something incorrectly.

There’s also a hand crank for charging. I did it a little while but if it’s as slow charging as the solar panels, I’ll be at it for days and might actually prefer to go without my phone for all that work. (I hope I never have to put that to the test.)

Luckily you can also use 3 AA batteries so be sure to have some on hand if the power goes out.

Now that that’s out of the way, how does the rest of it work? Well, I’m happy to note that it really does charge my phone. It’s slow but not too slow (1 hour, 4 minutes to get from 69% to 100).

The radio works well and there’s even a pull-out antenna. This is not a 2-way radio but if you need to find out what’s happening or if the wind is going to keep blowing, at least you can listen to the weather forecast.

I like the flashlight because it has 3 levels of brightness and the bright is very bright. There’s also an SOS alarm, though it’s not very loud. There’s a lanyard to hold the device on your wrist.

I’m glad I got this in case of an emergency but I’m really bummed about those solar panels, thus only 3 stars.

(Made in China)

title: Great sound and Quality!
text:
[[VIDEOID:a24c501f21992b3e956bd1774f9723e1]] First of all let me say; it definitely is not a 500w system. I think someone added an extra 0.

Am I the only one with this problem?

title: Surprisingly useful outside a Surface Pro case
text:
So, tablets. Great for watching Netflix, terrible for writing. Yet people keep trying to write on tablets, so of course the machinery of enterprise cranks round and round and comes up with...keyboards for tablets.

I usually don't use my tablet for writing unless I'm traveling somewhere. Now, yes, I do bring a laptop, but when you fly cheap, you're resigned to spending hours in a narrow chair with your knees in your nose, and in those circumstances a laptop can seem an extravagant waste of space inconceivable to any of us poor proles denied the comparative luxury of first class.

Tablet keyboards tend, as a rule, to be pretty terrible. They usually have a squishy Chicklet keyboard or a cheap keyboard with the tactile feel of a six-day-dead weasel, so imagine my surprise when I found a tablet keyboard that was (comparatively; I mean, it is what it is) pleasant to type on, and had a light-up keyboard. That alone put it far enough ahead of my old tablet keyboard case to be worth getting.

As a case, it's surprisingly attractive. As a keyboard, it is, unbelievably, useful enough that when I'm not traveling I use it as the keyboard for my server, which lives on a very cramped desk without enough room for a full-sized keyboard or a mouse. And it's useful enough it does admirably in that role.

Yes, the keyboard is detachable. Yes, it's not just for tablets; you can use it with any desktop or smartphone with Bluetooth. The touchpad kinda feels like an old-school plastic touchpad from a low-end laptop circa 2002, but the fact it even HAS a touchpad is a blesing, so I'm not going to pick that particular nit.

The fact that the keyboard lights up is a HUGE plus when traveling, since I don't have to risk the ire of my seat-mate by turning on that weird little overhead light that never quite lights up what you want it to anyway.

I honestly didn't expect to end up using it the way I'm using it, but then again, I didn't expect the keyboard to be as useful as it is, either. It's nice to be pleasantly surprised sometimes.

title: Nice Camcorder with all the accessories but
text:
I could only give it a 4-star rating and here's why. I am not a professional photographer or videographer but giving my honest opinion as a consumer.
First of all, this is a great video camcorder with just about every accessory you could want. It does a great job and does not feel cheap. The frame rate is good and it captures nice looking video and images. the 2 images you see in my review are taken directly from the Sd card that is provided. this comes with a 32GB SD card.
I feel the quality of the pics are good however the 1 picture at dusk does suffer from some graininess and pixelation. I actually did not expect it to be this good, so I am quite pleased.

When playing back the video on the camcorder itself I feel the video quality lacks some and the sound coming from the camcorder is not real clear.
Now with that said once this is uploaded to the Tv or computer the sound comes out great and the video quality is so much better.
Also only giving it a 4-star rating because of the battery life. It does come with 2 batteries and they do charge up rather quickly but I feel like the camcorder drains them pretty fast, especially if you are into doing time lapses and using a lot of the different features this camera has.

This WIKICO 4K Video Camera Camcorder deserves the 4 star rating that I am giving it because it is great for the first time vlogger, hobbyist, or just catching family moments. Also it comes with everything for you to get started right down to the 32Gb SD card, the external mike, the remote control and the lens hood, which really is a nice feature.
Speaking of the remote control I would highly recommend using this for all the functions, it really makes it easy and has a great range. Overall the zoom on the camera is good but does start to get grainy towards the 18X most likely because it is a digital zoom and not a completely smooth transition.
So overall this is a really nice camcorder, a complete package and a strong 4-star rating, it really is going to come down to the cost and what you want to use it for. For me it works just fine and does everything I need it to.

title: Great sounding budget BlueTooth headphones
text:
I've had these for about a week. The sound quality is quite good, which is to be expected from Sennheiser. I prefer over-the-ear headphones because earbuds fall out of my ears and just don't feel comfortable. These are quite light and comfortable to wear for hours at a time. The cups are small enough to fit under the warm comfy hat I wear in cold weather when walking outdoors. The battery life seems pretty spectacular. I've charged them once and used them for a total of perhaps 4 hours and the battery is still at 80% They quickly and easily paired with my Windows PC, Android phone, and Android tablet. I have used them for phone calls and Teams calls and people can't tell I'm using a BT headset. No one has complained about the microphone quality. The BlueTooth is smart enough to handle listening to music from one device and mute the audio when a call comes in from a second device, at least until you answer it.

Now for the things I find annoying:

-The Sennheiser app you must use to adjust the built-in equalizer. The app itself is okay, but I don't like having to register just to use it. Use a fake name and disposable email address.
-I wish these folded for travel or came with a hard case. Not really a complaint for the price paid.
-Noise cancelling would be nice. (again, not really a complaint for the price)
-An option to connect with a cord would be nice. (again not a complaint - I knew what I was buying)
-My only real, relevant complaint: If you're connected to multiple devices and you go out of range of one, the headphones will remind you incessantly every 30 seconds or so that you've "lost connection", even if the device is miles in your rear view mirror at that point. I wish there was a way to turn this reminder off, though turning the headphones off and back on again and letting them pair again with the remaining device(s) makes the nag go away.
-Oh, and the fake British voice that this and so many BT audio devices seem to use to report information is not terrible, but mildly annoying.

title: Kind of disappointed
text: First: If you buy the LTE version-your provider will charge an activation fee and a monthly fee. I bring this up as I was unaware and kind of shocked. Big rip off from the provider, should work with your current phone number and not be charged extra. Mine came with a grey colored band, rubber, that will probably not be good in the summer in the deep south. It is M/L-adjustable, guessing up to approx. 8-8.3 wrist. but not sure if ok for someone with a small wrist. I had the gear 3 classic previously, I'd still have it if my house was not robbed. This one was advertised as smaller in size. It is not. More of a bump on the back and still is very bulky and big. even at 45mm, it seems just like my old watch at 46mm. The front ring that moved on the top is now only available on the 4 model. Instead of the ring moving-you just slide your finger around the top and that does the same as the moveable ring. This does not have as many faces as my old watch and you cannot use most of the old ones on this new watch, which I am not really happy about. Seems they have eliminated the free ones to make you pay. I REALLY do like the function that you can change the orientation which was not available on the 3, but is now available on the 4 and 5. I don't wear my watch like the traditional way, so this is great for me. Not sure about the battery life yet. Been playing with it for 2 days now getting everything set up. Seems like this is geared more to the excercise world than the just plain watch world that just wants cool functions. I picked this one as they show the battery life is better than the 4. LAST BUT NOT LEAST: It comes with a charger, but not complete. The round magnetic peice that sits on the back of your watch on one end of the cable and a USB C plug on the other. So unless you have a laptop that has a USB C plug on it, you have to buy an adapter that the USB C plugs into and then into a wall outlet or USB C F to USB A adapter converter.  Which should come with it, but does not.  I had to buy one as my laptop does not have usb c. Hope some of this helps someone.

title: It promises but fails sometimes on the delivery
text: Product arrived on time and in good condition.  It came with good directions with all words spelled correctly and in good proper composed English.  It comes with the main remote controller rounded square thing hub (I don’t really know what to call it, it’s a remote but looks like a hub) and a USB power cable.  Set their app up on your phone and it then walks you through the whole set up process to get all your devices linked, it’s fairly easy.  If it doesn’t have your device, it will learn from your old remote or you can input its specific frequency, pretty cool.  It has a nice user face and easy to understand system.  You can set up scenes and have them function at warranted times and on specified day(s).  It has a lot of flexibility.  You can also now use Sari with HomeKit, works well.  I use my controller to turn on/off my TV scenes, light scenes and automatic roller blinds.  Everything works well most of the times, Sometimes I have to repeat a scene a few times to get everything working correctly, and often for my automatic roller blinds.  I had them closing at 9pm but 50% of the blinds will be closed, I would have to send the “close blind” scene a few times to get them all closed.  I know have the blinds closing at 9pm, 9:01pm, 9:02pm and 9:03pm. That way the signal would be sent 4 times and it closes all the roller blinds 90% of the time now.  I’m to bothered to set more times up at this moment, like 9:05pm, 9:06pm, etc. (plus I shouldn’t have to), so I just deal with the 90% success rate for now.  A few other devices I have the same problem with but less frequently.  So, it’s nice product over all, but getting your linked devices to all properly line up and function correctly when needed, is a hit or miss.  For now, it hits enough we’re I and my non-electronic understanding family actually don’t mind, so I’m giving my recommendation for this product to my family, friends and all who read this review.  Happy shopping!!

title: Low cost switch, but don't believe the feature set in the listing.
text:
While this may be a reasonable, low-cost GbE switch, I find the specs and documentation a bit lacking. Here's a list of my issues with it:
1) The box indicates "Smart Switch", and the front label indicates "Intelligent Switch", but yet it is an unmanaged switch. I am not sure when "unmanaged" became "smart", but this seems misleading to me. If you are looking for a managed switch, look elsewhere.
2) Both the description and the docs indicate "PoE", and the manual specifically states "it also provides direct current power to the equipment" -- yet the unit cannot receive power over the Ethernet line (I checked it with my own PoE switch) and the power adapter included is surely not capable of providing PoE to any downstream devices. Another possibly-deceptive, or at least unclear, indication. If you need PoE, look elsewhere.
3) High latency. While I did not measure it, this switch purports to have latency under 150us. This is relatively high for a GbE switch, which is typically in the 50-125us range. Again, the average person may not care, but if low latency is important to you, then look elsewhere.
4) The power input transformer provides 5V 1A (5W) through a standard 2.1x5.5mm barrel plug. I suppose it MIGHT be possible to use a PoE to USB power adapter and use PoE to power this unit, but the use of a barrel connector instead of a standard USB port would make this more tricky.
5) The online listing shows "5-16V input power", but the documentation makes NO mention of this. If this piece of data is accurate, then I would expect that a 12V transformer with standard barrel connector, or a PoE->12V adapter could work to power this switch. However, given all of the other misleading text, I cannot say whether such a configuration would work or not, and I wasn't about to test it on my own unit.

All is not lost, though -- if you are in a small home or apartment and just need to add a few more devices at a very low price point, then this may be what you want. Caveat emptor.

title: Small and promising
text:
Updated 2023-04-23

I swapped out the Kaming unit that started giving my wife issues with this and so far it’s showing promise. It took both of us a couple tries to do the initial pairing with the unit but after that it’s been quick to pair when getting back into the car. The real test is how well it does after the car has been off for a while (several hours to days) as this is where the other unit has issues.

I’ll continue testing this and update as we get more use with it. I’ve moved it up to 4 stars for now.

Also note that the seller has contacted me several times about my original review. I have asked for nothing and taken nothing from them. But it does show me that they are genuinely interested in customer success with their product.

—— Original review ——-

I got this through Amazon Vine to compare with a Kamang unit (it looks suspiciously like the Carlinkit unit) that my wife has been using with mixed results in her 2021 Toyota RAV4 XLS Hybrid.

I’m not sure what to think about it now that it’s gone unavailable, so I’m sorta leary to try it at this point. I may try it in one of my kids cars that has carplay (2019 Honda Civic or 2016 Mazda 3) and see how it does. For now, it sits in the box and this is just a first impression/unboxing review:

1) The unit is very small and light. There are no obvious means for heat reduction, which is strange give that this is a wireless radio and antenna.
2) It comes with both USB-A to USB-C and USB-C to USB-C cables, which is nice. And they are sufficiently short to not leave you with a bundle of extra cable.
3) The instructions are small, but readable.

Future updates to this review will focus on actual use, but given that it’s unavailable, I wasn’t too worried about the review being complete at this time. You can’t buy it anyway.

title: Warning: ROKU Does NOT PROVIDE Key Remote Recharging Cable & There are NO BROWSER Options
text:
The product has some great features.

#1 But after using the item for only 3 months the lightly used remote stopped working--only to discover it ran out of battery power. I actually planned to watch a very important TV show that was ONLY being shown around the time when my remote died. I then tried to open up the remote to change the batteries which was impossible since this battery-less model remote must be recharged for 3 hours after it dies before reuse. On top of that after contacting Roku technical support I discovered even though they even provide everything else you need including private listening ear buds, they DO NOT INCLUDE the remote recharger cable. The tech support person said, it's ok sir you can use "ANY" cell phone charge cable. FALSE, the device only uses an ANDROID connection so if you are in the sizeable iPhone user population then you are screwed. When I mentioned this to their tech support agent, he says "sir you can buy a Android charger cable at any store." But that particular day was the LA Marathon race with gridlocked sidestreets so by the time I got a cable that important one time show telecast I wanted to see was overwith. ROKU could have probably had a short recharger cable manufactured in China for pennies, but due to their company's CHEAPNESS they instead inconvenience many iPhone user customers like me who may be so frustrated and aggravated they might not buy a future ROKU product because of this. I will instead buy and Amazon or Apple product next time. So that extra 5-10 cents saving by NOT INCLUDING the required charger cord has cost them my lack of brand loyalty. When will corporations ever learn common business sense--especially in 2023? Ridiculous!

#2 Amazon Firestick products allow for the option of using a Firefox WEB BROWSER and services such as Facebook Live which despite all the ballyhoo of Roku Ultra being supposedly better and offering more features than any similar product. Sometimes from my living room flatscreen TV (not my laptop or cell phone) I want to check a website or watch service from my church on Facebook Live and I can't. There is a Bluetooth option for AUDIO streaming, but apparently NOT VIDEO. To me this is a HUGE OVERSIGHT and INCONVENIENCE on behalf of Roku.

title: My Experience with Samsung 970 EVO Plus SSD: Pros, Cons, and Lessons Learned
text:
I recently upgraded my Lenovo P15 with a Samsung 970 EVO Plus NVMe SSD and I must say, the experience has been life-changing. Before I made this purchase, my life was in shambles and I was on the verge of losing my job. But all that changed when I discovered this SSD.

It all started when I was playing a casual round of Rainbow Six and my teammates started making fun of my slow load times. Out of curiosity, I started researching about SSDs and eventually found the Samsung 970 EVO Plus. I took a leap of faith and invested $200 in it, and it was one of the best decisions I've ever made.

As soon as the SSD was installed, I felt a change in my life. I was invigorated and felt like I was at a complete balance. I took charge of my life, joined a gym, and started eating better. I even made significant progress in my physique and social life. My dog was no longer sick, and I felt like a new person.

The installation process was incredibly easy, and I was able to clone my HDD onto the SSD with ease. When I booted my PC through the SSD, everything went dark, and I felt like I was transported to a different world. It was a surreal experience, and I was left wondering why I didn't get an SSD sooner.

A week after installing the SSD, I quit my job and invested in cryptocurrency, which made me millions overnight. I no longer have to deal with slow load times, and my life has completely changed for the better.

However, I did face a few challenges during the installation process. The Lenovo site didn't provide complete instructions on how to install the SSD, and I had to do a lot of searching on the web to figure out how to get it to work. I had to disable the battery, go into BIOS, and change the boot sequence. It was a bit of a hassle, but it was worth it in the end.

In conclusion, the Samsung 970 EVO Plus NVMe SSD has been a game-changer for me, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking to upgrade their PC. Just be prepared to face a few challenges during the installation process, but it's well worth it in the end.

title: Quality budget dock that I recommend. Mostly does what I want it to do.
text:
This is the second dock I've tried for the Steam Deck. The first one was a bit of a disaster (although the aluminum case part was really nice on the competitor). So I'm mostly going to ignore the things that work great. I recommend this dock. Whether it's desktop mode or gaming mode, it almost always does what I want it to.

So what did I have issues with? Getting it to run at higher than 60hz. I tried numerous HDMI cables. Some new and some old. All of which work flawlessly on my PC running 4k @ 120hz. I don't know why 1080p/1440p @ 120hz were giving me issues, since it's within the bandwidth specs of this dock.

I could get it to recognize 1080p @ 120hz in the gaming mode. And I could even select 120hz in game settings. But it just would never run at 120fps. Gamescope would always lock to 60fps. This is with V-sync turned off. Allow tearing turned on. 120fps/off caps selected.

In desktop mode I could get it to engage 120hz and you'd have the telltale mouse icons being super smooth. But for whatever reason, I could not get anything to actually run at 120fps in gaming mode. And 1440p was just off the table. Maybe it's because the shortest cable I used was 10 feet. IDK. As I said, these cables all work flawlessly on my PC at 4k @120hz. So they're getting the full 48Gps there.

Now is this important? I don't think so. How important is this really? The Deck doesn't have power to spare. I would recommend running at a higher resolution over hz in the Deck's case. And BTW, running older emulators @ 4k @ 60hz with the CRT Royale shader looks amazing on a 4K OLED TV.

I generally prefer the CRT-lottes-multipass-glow shader when playing in handheld mode, but CRT Royale is built for 4K displays. It's also a pretty expensive shader. Yet the Deck could run older emulated 2D games at 4K with the CRT Royale shader and they look amazing on an OLED. So thumbs up on that.

title: Worked better than I expected
text:
Having tried two other cameras this one worked as expected. Without having the best camera out there, which is anyone's guess with the endless variety's to make a comparison to, this one works very well. I researched dozens of cameras, read reviews and watched Utube reviews, as we all do and settled on this product

Pros: Easy to set up with the included instructions. Included cables to initially charge the internal batteries and all the hardware needed to mount. Solidly built. The IR has a roughly 25 foot coverage and the motion detection, after it trains itself is pretty good at around 35 to 40 feet. Internet connection remotely is very good with only a short delay to start downloading live feed or recorded segments. Notifications take about 30 seconds to a minute after detecting motion to hit my phone. Overall the remote function is very good. I initially bought 2 cameras to evaluate the quality. I was satisfied enough to buy two more. The solar panels kept these cameras charged sufficiently even after 4 days of cloudy weather and none of them went below two bars on the charging indicator.
Install micro SD cards in all the cameras and the hub if purchased. this will save you money not having to sign up with cloud storage service. 64 Gig video specific cards have plenty of storage and they are cheap.

Cons:
Although the set up instructions get you through the start up well, they lack almost anything about how to navigate the features of the cameras and the hub if it comes with that. This is typical of any Chinese made product. A lot of trial and error eventually cements your learning curve.
There is no explanation what the SD card does that is inserted into the hub. That would be nice to know!
Although these cameras seem solidly built the adjustment screws and access cover screws can be easily stripped on the head. A Phillips head screw driver is included and works OK but someone in china over torqued the screws in a few locations and it took a regular size screw driver to get several screws loose stripping the heads in the process. I had to replace them with similar more robust screws. Caution here is recommended.
The only other complaint would be rain water running across the lenses. Makes the camera useless. Mounting under an over hang of some sort seems better. A better cover over the top of the lenses would be an improvement.

title: Solid T4 dock if you don't already use a T3 dock
text:
1. I am a big fan of Accell and there is nothing wrong with their product at all.
2. I recently picked up an Accell TB3 and TB4 to compare and I would have definitely kept the T4 if I had a good use case. For me, I run an MBP 14 M1 with a large single curved monitor, so the dual monitor thing is not a huge deal. I am what you would call a power business user. For me, the T3 works fine and I could not tell any difference in performance. My monitor is at best 4k, so pushing to 8k (something the T4 does for single) was not a deal maker or breaker. All this said, if you are a power gamer with a 6+ to 8k monitor, you'd want the T4. The T4 has an advanced SD card reader, the T3 does not. The MBP has an SD card reader + I have an external one, no real upside to that. Also, the MBP 14 has 2 other Thunderbolt ports, so that helps, if really needed. The T4 has 1 extra Thunderbolt port if needed (I don't). The T4 has slightly better video performance on paper. (DisplayPort 1.2 on the T3, can support up to 4K resolution at 60Hz, while DisplayPort 1.4 can support up to 8K resolution at 60Hz and 4K resolution at 120Hz.) While that is the case, I could not see any difference in my application use. It might matter in a super-high res monitor, or photo editing, yet for standard 4K, no real dif.

Again no issue with the TB4 product, it is solid and the price is right considering other offerings for TB4. That said, at over $100 less for TB3 it is a much better value. I am simply not getting much extra bang for the buck on TB4. However, for a more standard MBA or 13-inch MBP users would be better suited by the TB4 for obvious reasons.

TB3 - Accell Thunderbolt 3 Dock - Dual 4K at 60Hz, 70W Charging
TB4 - Accell Thunderbolt 4 Dock - Dual 4K or Single 8K, Max 96W, UHS-II Card Reader 2 x TB4 Ports

title: Not really undetectable
text:
I’ve seen DIY projects to build mouse jigglers yourself, but they are cumbersome and really only practical for hobbyists. When I saw that they miniaturized this into a USB dongle, I knew I had to try it. So what are these useful for? Most work computers have a preset time limit as far as how long a user can be away from the computer before it goes to sleep and locks. And if the company uses MS Teams or any similar app, the user’s status will be set to “Away”. My work computer is set to a very short 5 minutes and cannot be changed. It is frustrating to go get a cup of coffee or take a bathroom break to come back to a locked computer that I have to log back into again. A mouse jiggler solves this by moving the mouse for me, so the computer doesn’t go to sleep. This particular device has a power button and a movement mode button. The first 2 modes are not practical since the movement range is too great, but the last one moves the mouse cursor very slightly and is sufficient for keeping the computer awake. There is a series of LEDs that light up in a circular fashion, which rather annoying to me. You really don’t want to attract any attention to this device and people asking what it is for.
Some comments on this device being “undetectable”. Plugging this dongle into a USB port will automatically trigger Windows to install a generic optical mouse driver. Be aware that this does not make the jiggler “undetectable”. There are mouse loggers that can detect repetitive and sustained movements, so if you have this thing on and take a 2 hour lunch, you will be docked for taking the 2 hour lunch. There are truly undetectable jigglers out there (Eaxbux makes these as well) – they don’t even connect to your computer, and you just set your mouse on top of them. The movement is randomized, so just about impossible to detect. The only thing is, if someone walks by your desk and sees this, bingo, busted.
Overall, this is a useful little device to keep your computer awake, and there are some legitimate uses for it. It’s not a device for the truly paranoid though.

title: Great sound quality and perfect for parties.
text:
[[VIDEOID:28740d9f4602e20aa7b0ab74ad80001b]] I am speechless.This speaker blew me away. I was really surprised at how great this speaker sounds. I knew it was a cool speaker, but I didn't realize that it sounded this good. We recently had a big party during the holidays and I got so many compliments on this speaker. Everyone wanted to know where I got it.

This is the first large party speaker that I have ever owned that came with a remote control. The remote is simple and easy to use. I can pretty much control every function with the remote. It's packed with features.

The RGB lights look so cool. The lights are nice and bright and colorful. It has several different light modes. My favorite is the music mode where the lights move to the music.

The build quality is great. I will say that this speaker is kinda heavy. It has a carrying handle built-in to the back of it. Now, it would have been nice if it had wheels and a telescopic handle for moving it from place to place.

Now for the sound quality. The sound quality is awesome. The bass sounds great and clear with no distortion. It has extra bass modes. To be honest, the speaker right out of the box sounds good even without the extra bass boost on. The mids and highs sound great as well. This speaker really gets loud. It has 160 watts of pure power.

Battery life is pretty good. We had a New Years Eve party, and I had it playing at about 50% power with all the lights on, and when the party was over, it still had a battery left. I noticed that It has a battery saving feature. If it doesn't detect any sound, it will automatically shut down to save battery life.

It also has dj effects. I really didn't use them because they didn't sound that good to me. But the sound quality makes up for the poor dj effects.

Overall, this speaker is AWESOME! If you're looking for a party speaker, look no further. This is all you will need. So far me and my wife and I are really enjoying it. I definitely recommend this speaker.

title: Beautiful colors, nice sound and feel, great key attachment
text:
[[VIDEOID:193fa4441e7d9509f14d2c6cb41f3da4]] Guiheng Wireless mini keyboard/mouse combo (white and aqua)

Beautiful color! White and Aqua! Styled to look a lot like Apple mouse and keyboard. This makes it a nice compliment to a MAC setup.

Price: At $15.00 as of March 2023, a great price!!

In the box:
Just a keyboard and mouse. USB mini receiver is inside the keyboard battery compartment. No paperwork (we all know how to work a keyboard and mouse by now). Keyboard and mouse each require 2 AAA batteries (not included). Wireless is 2.4 GHz only. No Bluetooth.

Mouse has scroll wheel and DPI button, which lets you change DPI (Dots Per Inch) with just a click of that button. There are 3 levels of DPI settings ranging from 800 DPI to 1600 DPI. DPI affects how far the mouse cursor moves on the screen in relation to how far you physically move the mouse itself. For my use the middle setting (1200 DPI) works well.

Keyboard has rubber feet on bottom to help keep it from sliding around. Keys have nice springy feel. Instead of a scissor mechanism, the keys are capacitive (somewhat similar to mechanical keys in how they attach). The keys can be removed easily (to clean accidental spills) and put back on. If you have ever removed a scissor style key (or had one come off accidentally) you know how difficult it is to put it back on without breaking it. So this is a real plus to me! My only criticism is that this keyboard is not backlit. But for the price, that is a little much to expect.

Sound: This keyboard is not silent. But it has a nice level of "clickiness" that I believe most people will like. It is quieter than my mechanical keyboard, which has Gateron brown switches (medium clickiness).

Works well with my Panasonic ToughBook CF31 (Windows 10), FZ-55 (Windows 11), MacBook Pro (Monterey), Chromebook, and Raspberry Pi 4B.

title: Buggy, poor performance, missing basic features
text:
"Pro," "AI," "Smart" -- D-Link managed to throw all the buzzwords they could think of at this router, but didn't bother to actually make a product worthy of them.

Upon plugging it in and connecting, the devicesetup website the instructions tell you to use didn't work. I was able to access the website, but the website did not recognize the router's hardware ID and such couldn't log me into the router. Not a great start. I'm experienced in home networking, so I was able to manually get the IP address of the router via the command line and connect into it that way, but your average consumer would've been stuck calling support at this point.

Once logged into the router, I applied the firmware update it prompted me for, which seemingly didn't go over well. Speeds slowed to a crawl for downstream traffic, and I was forced to do a factory reset and go through the setup process again. This got the router working again, but the maximum performance it offered was unbelievably weak for an AX (Wi-Fi 6) router, actually slower than AC routers I've used.

As the only device connected to the router, my system with an Intel AX wifi chipset ten feet away from the router maxed out at 340 Mbps down. For reference, the not-so-great Netgear router I've had for a few years and was hoping to replace manages 670 Mbps with literally over a dozen other devices connected to the network. That's nearly double the D-Link.

Even if the performance were acceptable, the router is missing the incredibly basic feature of having separate SSIDs for the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz networks. Also missing is the ability to manually select channels if you're trying to avoid interference. The firewall page is very vague on what protection is being offered and there's no help manual on the box and if it's offered through the web interface, it's not easy to find.

I guess technically this thing does work as a router so it's worth more than the 1 star rating it would get if it did absolutely nothing, but it really deserves a 1.5 star rating instead of the 2 that I'm giving it. Save yourself the money and get a $50 wireless AC router instead with the same performance and more features.

title: Cute little laptop bag!
text: This bag is for small laptops and tablets. I have an asus flipbook and it fits perfectly. But my HP won’t fit. I like that this is a compact bag, as I already have a couple laptop bags that hold tons of stuff. This one is perfect for your tablet or laptop, plus a couple notebooks, magazines, books, or files. Room for the charger and maybe a bottle of water, some pens, and has an internal pocket that will hold your phone and/or sunglasses. There’s a divider inside and one side has a little Velcro tan to hold it closed, which I assume to be the device section, but my laptop didn’t really fit in there. An iPad would fit in that part perfectly. It’s fake leather but it actually looks really nice and could pass for a much pricier brand. Except of course for the fairly large brand tag on the front. I’ve never heard of this brand before so honestly I’d rather not have the tag on the front at all but you’d have to be close to read it and I think the way I carry it my arm will cover it anyway. I love the quilted design, it gives it a classy look. And the green/silver stripe adds a touch of fancy also. There are external pockets on both sides and all of the zippers are high quality and move smoothly and quietly. This bag can be carried either by handles or as a messenger/crossbody bag. I do have one complaint about the strap, and that’s the shoulder pad. You can only slide it as far as the size adjuster, and because they have the slits cut small and not the width of the strap, you cannot side the pad over the metal size adjuster piece no matter how hard you try. So that really limits how long you can make the strap. (It also has the brand imprinted largely on the shoulder pad-this is unnecessary and detracts from the classy look). You can see what I’m referring to in my last photo. And that’s why I deducted one star. You could also use this as a purse or even throw some diapers and wipes in it for a classy daily use diaper bag. Overall it feels and looks like a high quality bag and I think I will get a lot of use out of it.

title: Great quality, affordable headphones, fits larger heads, accommodates ear piercings
text:
These are the most comfortable, affordable headphones I've owned. For years, I've used a pair of Sony WH-1000 headphones, and now that they are quite worn, I decided to find a new option that was less expensive than top brand Sony. I've only had these for a week, so I can't comment on the longevity of the headphones yet. But otherwise, here are my pros and cons after 1 week of use.

Pros:
- These have really good sound quality. I was not expecting sound to be so clear at this price point, so I'm very pleased about this!
- These are extremely comfortable for people with larger heads/ears, specifically, they fully cover my ears and have enough space around them to accommodate my many ear piercings.
- The case is slim and can be attached to a backpack, which I'm thrilled about, especially since I'll be travelling often with these.
- I really like the look/style of these headphones, and they look exactly as pictured.

Cons:
- The ANC isn't good, especially when wearing these but not listening to music. It is noticeable, low-grade white noise, which isn't the case for other, more expensive brands. So if you're looking for noise cancelling headphones while not listening to music, these are probably not the right option for you.
- I've tested the mic/voice quality, and it is not good; I won't be using these for phone calls and gaming without an external mic, which is fairly common with many over ear headphones anyways, so I'm not too upset by this.
- Although these can connect to 2 devices simultaneously, switching between devices leads to some poorer sound quality issues, like 1 second pauses mid-song, inconsistent switching between devices, etc. I have moved back to 1 device connection because of these issues and don't plan to connect 2 devices simultaneously in the future.
- Upon opening these, there is a strong, unpleasant plastic smell. Thankfully, it has mostly gone away by now.

Overall, I'm pleased with this purchase, since it checks most of my requirements for headphones without the price tag of Sony, Bose, or Sennheiser. I would definitely buy these again, as long as they have decent longevity.

title: Faster than EERO 6
text:
Have both EERO 6 system and this Google system which does not have WIFI 6. Oddly this one (the Google Nest) is faster by quite a bit than the EERO 6. Have not had it long enough to speak to it's tech support quality, or it's stability. But, when the EERO 6 was installed it was blazing fast for maybe a day (over 300 meg down and full 30 meg up). But within a day or 2 the system would slow to 160 or so down and 20+ up. Not terrible but this is where it would stay. Very stable but not the speed promised overall
The Google Nest however is a little slower at very top speeds depending on where I am receiving signal. So like the EERO 6 I would see fastest speeds (450/30) when device is closest to the Gateway. However the Google Nest Access Points show stronger/faster speeds 300+/25+ unlike the EERO 6 with 150+/20+ at the access points. So my informal conclusion is the Google Nest access points are faster and stronger than the EERO 6 while the "base" or Gateway unit of Google is a little slower than the EERO 6. But here to not by a lot. Topping out at 375+/30+ vs the EERO 6 Gateway topping out at 475+/30+ These results are based on an installation with the Gateway located in my basement oriented to the rear of my home and approximate center of the rear wall, one AP in a front bedroom at another end of the (long ranch style) home on main floor and the 2nd access point located at opposite end of home main floor toward rear of home.
Sadly after only about 3 weeks of use things went haywire. Not sure if it is a fault of the product itself or perhaps the reason it was a "reconditioned" product. They caused constant interruptions to service. Even knocking the modem itself offline. Leading me to believe the issue was Comcast. A tech came out, he checked signal at my cable end. Said it seemed to be weak. Installed a whole new line, confirmed a good strong signal. Modem, and router(s) were all reset and seemed well until about 10 minutes after he left. Down AGAIN!. Connected my old Unifi WAP and while slower everything is operating normally. These things will be going back
