title: Easy, but use the right code!
text:
Easy Startup when you use the correct code.

The smart watch for men by Atevense is perfect for someone looking for an easy link-up to your phone.

While I was doing the initial charging of the phone I read through the instruction book. The instructions were fairly simple – scan the QR code and follow the prompts. I scanned the code inside the instruction book and to finish the registration too the app/website it wanted my credit card information! No way I was going to give them my credit card info. I thought I'd have to give away my brand new smart watch.

I'm glad I didn't give up right then. I was browsing around the watch menus and noticed on the opening menu an arrow that wanted me to scroll down. So, I swiped up and low & behold there was a QR Code on the digital watch display. Yaay, I was finally in business.
Don't make my mistake and scan the code inside the instruction book. Scan the code under the main menu on the phone!

After I scanned the code from my phone and was taken to the Google app store (no credit card info needed there). Once I installed the app on my phone it immediately vibrated the watch on my wrist. The vibration reminded me of an an old controller rumble-pack. From there it wanted some basic information; height, weight, gender, age. It was that easy. From there I could use my phone or new watch to check my blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygen level, how I'm sleeping, and how much exercise I've done including a calorie counter.

Some more features on the watch allow you to access the weather and move through your phone's music playlist.

There are also a bunch of different ways to set your screen. You can view just the time, or all of your health information, or time and weather – I'm guessing you can set up the screen any way you want. There are basic backgrounds, funky backgrounds, futuristic looking ones. You could have a new/different looking watch everyday for quite awhile.

Bonus: The page for the ATEVENSE watch lists the color as Black – but the tan/fatigue watchband was also included in the box.

title: Lack of volume makes this a dismal choice for hearing impaired
text:
First, my unit arrived obviously previously opened. The package tape was already cut, and the power supply cord was poorly re-wrapped and tied. This unit has obviously been returned and resold. The top of the unit is worn, and the bottom is very scratched and obviously used. This item should not have been sent back out as "New," but it was.

This puts the whole transmitter under suspicion because it was obviously returned after being used for a reason. One of the Amazon user comments is that the unit's volume diminishes over time. This is the case with this used transmitter. The broadcast volume is, at what I would rate as an older person with slight hearing deficiency, at 40%. It needs a lot more oomph.

Is it their matched receiver? No. Turn the transmitter off and the matching FM radios emit white noise at such a volume level that it hurts my hearing-deficient ears. The receivers are not the problem.

The broadcast sound (Bluetooth) is of good quality. It just cannot be made loud enough.

The second problem is that the Retekess transmitter/receivers start to break up within 10 feet, if there is an unobstructed sheetrock wall between them. At 20 feet with 2 sheetrock walls, it fails to work entirely. The setting on the power switch on the back makes no difference. The combination behaves the same. This transmitter has no volume and no power -- this compared to other offerings on Amazon that we own that broadcast 1-5 miles at similar stated power levels.

The indicated matching frequencies of the paired Retekess broadcaster and receivers sometimes do not match. Sometimes a .5 MZH difference will provide a noisy, but much higher volume response when the combination should not work at all. Obviously, the internal electronics are not purely tuned.

Since this unit is obviously a used, returned, item so, we have ordered a replacement. Hopefully, it will be new, and work as advertised. We don't mind getting scratched return items like this IF they work properly. Simply put, this unit does not meet our expectations or our needs for communicating with hearing-impaired people in our church.

title: The ant shown is not an ANT145 but an ANT130(NEVER OWNED ANYTHING LIKE THE ANT130)
text:
The RCA ANT145 has a dish center that looks like a small sat dish and a 2nd ring around that dish; this ANT130 only has a ring center. And, the ANT145 has more positions for the center knob to turn as well. I've owned a very similar RCA model to the ANT145 in the past: the only differences were it had no 2nd ring, it plugged into the wall(didn't pay any attention at the time but this probably meant it had a built-in amplifier), and you could choose the back coax cable for it(allowing there to be far less inference if you decided to use an average length cord of your own choosing than most soldered on cords or a very, very long coax if you wanted to move the antenna around[had a 25 ft cable]). Differences aside, my version worked well in a tree-infested area that was also 30-100 miles from almost all of the towers.

We had no local stations(in the tiny town where I used to live): Macon, MS to Columbus, MS(WCBI--CBS), Macon, MS to Tupelo, MS(WTVA--NBC), Macon, MS to West Point, MS(WLOV--FOX). In addition, the PBS station was around 150 miles away: Macon, MS to Jackson, MS. It must have been a very strong signal, because it came in as clear as you could get before digital and as clear as the 30 mile away station(WCBI). You can check those ranges out to see that I am not lying. For some reason, we could not get the WTOK--ABC station in Meridian, MS(about 60 miles away from us then) with this antenna. The only time I remember ever picking up this channel was with an outdoor antenna setup and turning the pole manually or by using a special box that did the turning for you. Keep in mind, this was in the days before the many OTA channels you can access today(I am guessing that it was sometime within the 2000s decade) and you could only get the major networks at this time. Granted, I did own a very similar one to the ANT145(not the ANT130 that is shown), but 30-100 miles and 150 miles out for one station is not bad in the woods for an indoor antenna!

title: Tjis camera is packed with features that allow it to surpass my other security cameras
text:
This camera is packed with numerous advanced features as outlined in the description...fantastic picture quality, three choices of night vision with a spot lighting option, free recording to and playback from up to 128 GB SD card in lieu of a paid cloud subscription, two-way talk communication, multiple user sharing capability, linking to Alexa, ONVIF Conformity with Blue Iris and iSpy, and more.

I have a couple other brands of security cameras and here is what I found in this camera that set is above the others.
-The user manual is excellent with very concise and very detailed setup and user instructions. (I found setup to be easy.)
-The video plays immediately as soon as the camera icon in the app is tapped.
-Playback of video captured and saved to the SD card is also immediate...so much faster than some other brands of cameras.
-Quality of the video is excellent even when the camera is positioned to monitor a large area from a long distance. See photos included with this review.
-Access to photo screenshots or video manually recorded by tapping the Screenshot or Video icons is super easy to view and immediately accessible by tapping the Album icon....much easier to navigate to than my other cameras.
-Detection at night can include spotlight activation. (There are actually three night recording options to choose from in the app.)
-Nighttime detection and image quality are superb.
-Free recording to a Micro SD card is up to a whopping 128 GB. (My other cams only record 32 or 64 GB.)
- The camera is very dependable at staying online. (Two of my cameras mysteriously go offline at times and require being reset.)
- The fantastic high quality picture surpasses my other cams.
My only minor negative comment concerns the first step of setup whereby the app asks the user to choose his camera from a list. I couldn't really find a camera to choose that was labeled SV3C camera, so I just chose from one that seemed to be an SV3C. This was a minor concern. The camera wound up being very easy to pair with my Wi-Fi system and easy to get up and running. Overall, I am very impressed with the camera and all of its features.

title: after a lot of finagling it works!
text:
[[VIDEOID:5ab5535944c8ebd720dd458aad815d57]] Update 2: the vendor sent a new camera and connector. Better quality. Unfortunately we already have the prev installed and aren’t about to take it all apart to redo. We appreciate their customer service. But as you know when you have your dash all pulled apart, there isn’t time to wait for a few weeks for a part to be sent. You need to use your vehicle! But I do appreciate them standing by their product and trying to make it right.

Update: re camera not working— after hours of troubleshooting and doing a ton of electronics testing found it was the cheap cable (see first image yellow) that was cheap crap. Fortunately I was about to build this for use with my own components.

Took all day for the install and a ton of finagling to get it all to work. Some
Soldering. The reversing camera is super wide angle.

See my photos for what else I ordered that was needed to install this in my 2010
Dodge Challenger.

It works now! Sound is very good with my speaker system. I hooked up via Bluetooth and CarPlay so I could use Siri to control volume or just say “Siri directions to such and such” and it shows up.

Hands free texting and calling.

Ask Siri to play my music and she does.

Ask Siri volume down and she does. There are buttons along the bottom with an audible beep you can click or use the touch screen.

The resolution is very good. Haven’t tried to mirror to play a video yet.

See my photos - the dash install kit I ordered twice before finding the right one and then had to shave it down to fit.

At this time now the camera isn’t working- but as mentioned we are trying to get the setting right. Just installed this afternoon.

Updated at top, so if you don’t know electronics I would not recommend installing yourself. If I had to pay someone to install this I would be in the red!

title: Clear Diffusion Filter with No Noticeable Color Cast
text:
[[VIDEOID:6a0c20a2c7224d943fbed3f07d451a79]] In a world where we chase the ultimate sharpness in images and video, diffusion filters are a fun getaway from that rat race. This particular filter is, in my opinion, fairly "low power" in most situations, so you can safely add it without causing an overpowering effect like many other filters, especially in the budget section. This can be used for portraits to give a slight glowing effect and soften up some of that sharpness while maintaining image detail, or for landscapes to add some glow to any light sources in the scene, along with any variety of scenarios you might come up with. If you have the time, I'd recommend trying it out any chance you have and seeing if you like what it adds to the image. These filters are very subjective and what may work for one person may not for another, and in reverse as well of course.

I found this to be most effective when there is some contrast and drama to the light. In the flat midday sun, it was actually difficult in my case to find any difference at all other than some mild softening of the image. However, in my night test, it added a wonderful glow to the various light sources, making the image much more appealing and less harsh.

One of the best things I noted about this filter is what it DIDN'T do. I didn't notice any color cast or discoloration caused by this filter. Many other filters struggle with this issue but in anything from midday sun to nighttime darkness, I didn't notice any color shifting (and to clarify, I'm reviewing these on my calibrated BenQ monitor).

Two side notes to mention:

I now own several different items from K&F and I've been increasingly impressed with this brand of photography products. This filter is definitely going in the camera bag and I will be trying it out as often as possible.

Additionally, this filter is packaged in one of the nicest hard cases I've seen. The smoke gray circular case stands amount amongst a sea of white square cases for my other filters, and includes a really neat rubber "mount" inside to hold a variety of filter sizes without it flopping around in the case.

title: Be careful of speed claims
text:
You will NOT get 10Gb/s on any of these ports although you MAY get close to 9Gb/s if you only use two carefully selected ports. Please read on to understand the limitations of these external ports.

This card uses a single ASM3142 which supports (in theory) a maximum of two USB3.1 Gen-II (confusing numbering, but these are 10Gb/s) ports - I'll call these internal ports. On the board, each of these two internal ports are shared between 4 of the external ports. The 10Gb/s of the internal port is roughly divided equally between each of the 4 shared external ports (for that particular internal port) that are in use. Thus, if there are three (of 4) external ports in use, each will get roughly 3.3 Gb/s bandwidth. In practical use, there is bandwidth lost in the division process so each port actually works at less than 3Gb/s. Even with only one external port in use, you only approach 9Gb/s. When fully loaded (all 8 external ports across both internal ports), I only got ~2Gb/s on each device. Refer to the manual for which physical external connectors are connected to the same internal 10Gb/s port.

I found the card easy to install, physically. Windows 11 recognized it immediately and installed the native Windows driver (the date on this driver is misleading but it is the correct driver). I first tested the speed of each port with nothing else connected to the card. Then I tested the speeds with various combinations of ports in use simultaneously. Regardless of the combination, I found a fair amount of bandwidth loss (10-20%) at the external ports which is probably typical of this chipset.

A much bigger issue is the stability of the USB ports. Although the system never lost communication with the ASM3142, it frequently dropped the external USB connections. This did not happen with the same devices connected to ports on a card with an ASM3242 (different card). Sometimes the dropped connections reset, sometimes they didn't. Eventually (within 10 minutes) everything connected to this card just stopped working and was no longer recognized by Windows.

After much tinkering, I gave up. I found this card much too unreliable in any configuration. YMMV.

title: Larger than expected and solid build
text:
I have a small business that specializes in destruct testing. We use Mac computers for our engineering group and Windows for the regular business side. We wanted to add a computer on a kiosk in the waiting room where customers could come in and look at films of some of our testing over the years. So, it was important to have Wireless capability for the network and for the keyboard/mouse and that the form factor be small.

When this became available, I decided to give it a try. Here is what I found:

1. This is larger than I expected and much better build. Guess I was expecting a cheap plastic box but was surprised by the build of this one.

2. It includes a VESA mount that allows you to mount this to the monitor. We used a 4K 28 inch TV as it was the perfect size and it was inexpensive. It was easy to bolt on and to run the short HDMI cable. The only cable leaving the monitor was the power cord. We used a wireless keyboard and mouse.

3. We did not put it into a case yet because we wanted to test it out first and then give the guys in the machine shop a lunch time project.

4. Now, comes the dreaded UPDATE cycle!!! As is typical, you run a full update to only find out that there is then another update that needs to be run. Three updates later, we were done!!!

5. The hard drive if fast and quite. Videos run smoothly and are great for detail. Office and Quickbooks loaded with no issues and we were up and running in a short time. We were checking to see if we wanted to expand our computers if this would work and the answer is, YES!!

6. To give you a feel for this, if you have ever used an iMac, it feels about the same way, just certainly not as eloquent.

We will be running tests for the next several weeks. If there are any issues, I will come back here and report them. But, at this point in time, this is a very solid device and I would recommend it if your requirements fit.

title: Provides a solid base for mounting a dot sight to A7iv
text:
I have been been trying to mount a Nikon dot sight to my A7iv for awhile, and tried all kinds of adapters and coldshoe adapters, etc., but none really worked with the Sony hotshoe. Regardless of how tightly I turned the screws, the shoe would "twist" whenver it was touched, so it made using the dot sight a pain, because I'd have to re-align it often.

Then I saw this Smallrig half-cage, and when it is attached to the A7iv, it has an area in front of the normal A7iv viewfinder that has one 3/8" hole in the center and a 1/4" hole on each side of trhe center 3/8" hole. It was a bit unfortunate that the center hole was 1/4", but I found a 1/4"-to-3/8" adapter (it was Camvate) so I used that to mount a Smallrig cold shoe, and then the Nikon dot sight mounts on teh cold shoe.

Works perfectly, and the dot sight is not too much off the camera compared to if the dot sight was mounted directly into the A7iv hot shoe, and it is stable now.

The cage screw into the tripod mount on the bottom plate of the A7iv, but it also is designed so that it has a 2nd attachment point to the left side camera strap lug. You have to remove the triangular ring from the left lug, and then remove the rearmost 2.5mm screw that is screwed into the cage side. Then loosen the front 2.5mm screw and slide that part back until it contacts the front of the left lug and take the screw that you removed through the lug. The whole thing is very stable. You can then attach your strap through a slot that is on the left side of the camera, instead of through the left lug.

It also comes with a tool that is magnetically attached to the bottom of the cage.

Since this is half-cage, the door for the memory cards is accessible. Same thing for the battery door on the bottom.

The main "con" is that you have to remove the ring from the left lug.

title: Good headset, with some quirks
text:
Ordered this headset as a replacement for one my microphone broke on. I don't game much, but I am on a LOT of Zoom calls throughout the work day.

The first thing I noticed was the long cord, with a cable wrap included. It offers plenty of length and I love that it is able to be organized well. The cord is heavy duty and seems to be well designed.

The headset seems to be of a good build quality. The microphone comes in loud enough to hear and is easily configured to fit you. The best part is people don't complain when I talk during meetings anymore...it's good at isolating sound out. I work in an office with 7 other people and have customers come in and out during the time and the microphone has done fantastic at keeping it to only my voice for the most part. The fit for the headset works well for my head and requires no time to get setup as it customizes automatically for your head. My one complaint is the ear pads are a bit stiff and take some getting used to/breaking in. I've had others that are much quicker to adapt to my ears, but these aren't as large so my ears aren't always fully covered which may be the reason they don't fit so comfortably.

This headset claims full 7.1 surround sound....hard to believe since it only has 2 speakers. It does appear to have better sound quality than others I have used, and some surround sound effects to some degree. One thing that is cool is you can adjust the front, back, side, center, and sub levels with the provided inline control. Here you can also mute the mic and/or adjust the volume as a whole.

Overall, I think these headphones fit the bill for a good set for Zoom calls and even gaming. The cord could be an issue potentially if you don't plan for it...but if you want wireless headsets then it's not fair to compare it to a wired pair. I do recommend making sure the fit works well for you....I'm not sure I could wear these all day long but have easily worn it for 3-4 hours in a day without issue. For the price, you won't find a better set. I recommend these headphones to anyone looking to get something of good quality but doesn't want to spend a lot of money.

title: Misleading Information in Production Description
text:
While the device was easy to setup and connect to my wireless network, it doesn't correctly match the description - WiFi to Ethernet Adapter - at least not without other baggage. Let me explain.

There are two operating modes of the device:
1) WiFi extender
2) WiFi access point

In the extender mode, it attaches to your existing WiFi network wirelessly and then re-broadcasts its own network. While in this mode, you can attach a wired device to the ethernet port. That's fine, but I really ONLY wanted to attach a wired device and not broadcast another network on both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz which adds more congestion to the airwaves. You can "hide" the SSID for both of the re-broadcasted extended networks but there is no option to turn them off. Furthermore, there are no adjustments allowed for channel selection or channel width - I guess it just picks whatever it wants.

In the access point mode, the ethernet port is connected to your existing wired network and then it acts like another access point in your house. OK, that might be helpful for some people but I already have multiple access points so that doesn't help me and is not why I purchased it based on the description.

But the biggest issue is that the wired ethernet port is limited to the older "Fast Ethernet" standard of 10/100 Mbps. That is fine for a printer, and even for a TV, but not for other devices where you might actually want to take advantage of the fast WiFi speeds. So whether you use this as an access point or as an extender just know that any network traffic going over the wired port will be capped at 100 Mbps. Doesn't make sense to support the AC1200 standard on the WiFi side of things and then create a bottleneck at the wired port. It really makes no sense as Gigabit ethernet chipsets for wired connections have been around for years and cost next to nothing.

PROS: Easy setup. Affordable price.

CONS: No controls in the web interface to adjust how the device is working to disable unused/unwanted features. Wired port is limited to 100 Mbps of throughput.

title: OVERRATED
text:
Thought I was upgrading from my 8 year old Sena SMH-10 system. What a massive disappointment!

We Snowmobile as a family of 4. We have an 8 year old and 12 year old so reliable communication is absolutely necessary.

First: the range is a complete lie. We were lucky to maintain 4 way communication up to 300 feet. The 1.6 kilometer claim is simply absurd. Maybe in a desert, with a clear line of sight, but not in a forested region with hills.

Next, one of the fixed microphones failed completely after only 3 days of use. What the heck? I'm on a snowmobiling vacation and I have one helmet with no Mic.

Next, there was never a time when all of us could hear each other with saying. "What?" "Say that again" "Did you hear me?!!"

My old Sena suffered from crackling sound and refused to update, and the majority of reviews suggested that Cardo was the best. NO WAY. In real world use, on the trail, in snowstorms, I can say that all four of us were very disappointed, and that's putting it mildly. keep in mind, that's just for the 4 way Digital Mesh Communication, which is all we care about. Listening to music and taking calls, etc., mean nothing when the most basic function fails.

I've had to factory reset 3 times in 4 days just to keep a semblance of communication, and my finger-tips are sore from how harsh the buttons are to press trying to achieve the factory reset.

I feel I was completely duped out of nearly $1000.00.

Anyone that wrote a story, a review, or magazine column extolling the virtues of these communicators for snowmobiling either never used them for that purpose for more than a few minutes under perfect conditions, or is was simply disingenuous. Either way, their journalistic license should be suspended and or revoked!

I should have followed my gut and upgraded with the latest Sena, or maybe Uclear.

I would absolutely NOT recommend these communicators to anyone, even the people I don't like.

title: This head unit totally destroy all other head units!
text:
Why choose the Atoto S8 Ultra Gen 2? Well if you want a head unit in your car/truck that work like an android tablet then this is the one you want! The Atoto S8 Ultra Gen 2 is pack with a lot of features and the touch screen display is very responsive. This is the best of the best car stereo out there folk!! You can spend up to $1,000 - $2,000 on a known brand car stereo like Sony, Pioneer, Kenwood, Boss, etc. but you won't find anything like what the Atoto S8 Ultra Gen 2 has. What make this unit quite unique is that you have the ability to access to the internet and you have the ability to download pretty much anything you wanted! You can download app like Netflix, HBO Max, Disney+, Amazon Prime Video & so much more. You can even play game on this thing! This unit will make your old/new car act like a smart car.

This stereo + the CA-AEC02 was a gife for my father's truck. My father said he loved it. That great which is what i wanted to hear =). I also love it and now my sister also wanted one for her car. I will start recommending it to more friends and family members. I think it is better than a lot of top quality known brand car stereos out there. You're pretty much restricted to what you can do with them but with the Atoto S8 Ultra Gen 2 they gave you the freedom to fully download/customize what you want on it which is what I really like. If you want a head unit that act like a smart car then you got to go with ATOTO! You won't be disappointed!

Now I heard the S8 Gen 3 will be release. I'm excited. I hope it packs with a lot more ram, better cpu & gpu. If the S8 Ultra Gen 3 come out with an Oled 4k display than it is an instant buy for me. I believe this could be the #1 brand car stereo for the foreseeable future. Atoto deserve more recognition!

If you have any questions or problems with your unit you can head over to ATOTO Android Head Unit Owners OFFICIAL on facebook or r/ATOTO on reddit the community over there are very helpful.

title: Lot's of handy pockets in front and back.  Lot's of room inside for long weekend or flights.
text:
I really love this backpack, but it's not the perfect laptop travel backpack. It is a larger backpack that would serve many purposes for someone needing to carry a lot of things comfortably. They have really designed this for the regular traveler. It is perfect for a long weekend away or plane, train, bus trip.

The front panel has 3 very nice sized pockets designed for travel documents, books, medicine, hand sanitizer, etc. Each side has a pocket for cold or warm drinks that are lined with silver insulation material. (Genius!) The front zip open section folds out flat and is an open section for clothing, etc. It also has an elastic cross-strap to hold all of your clothes down securely.

There is a nice sized pocket for a USB Powerbank in the front section which you can connect to on the outside via a USB cable. Unfortunately, it only has a USB-A connection on the inside by the Powerbank and a USB-A connection on the outside. Oddly, it looks like the outside connection has a location for a USB-C port, but it hasn't been installed. (See photo.)

Unfortunately, the smaller back section, which is designed for your laptop, does not zip all the way down and open up flat like the front. I think the TSA requires you to have a backpack open up all the way with the laptop visible. Otherwise, you have to remove your laptop when going through scanners now. (I could be wrong, I haven't flown since pre-Covid.) This section though is very large and easily fits my 15" laptop, my 12" tablet, my headphones, and some of my accessories. I'm sure it would fit a 17" laptop like the description states.

Overall, I still like this backpack, even with its faults. It's the perfect size, comfortable, and holds a lot of things for a trip. It appears to be very well made of quality materials. I also think it is priced well when compared to some of the others out in Amazonland. I hope to see them come out with a newer model in the near future that has USB-A and USB-C connections and the laptop section can lay out flat when opened.

title: Great Security Monitor for the Price
text:
[[VIDEOID:6d3560b5ffaf0381bb53f82c4a96484b]] I like this bulb security camera (2-pack) because it was super easy to setup, install and operate. I like the app -- even though it is a bit rough at times -- because I was able to figure it out without any documentation. Setting up the camera was pretty much a no-brainer and I've been running it for couple of days with zero issues (except for those of my own making via the MANY settings in the app).

I was able to get it on my home wifi (I have blended 2.4 & 5 gHz, so not sure which band it is on at any time) and downloading photos and videos from the app is seamless and fast (they reside on the 128gb micro-SD TF card I had laying around (the max size it accepts) and these download very quickly from the camera on the back porch to the other side of my house where I am typing this.

I will say when I opened the rubber waterproof hatch to insert the TF card, it looked like I was doing brain surgery in there as there were visible circuit boards, which I didn't want to see -- and it was not clear how to insert the TF card, but I figured it out eventually.

So far the only thing I do not like is that it does not integrate with my smart home (we have Apple, Alexa and Google), so I have to use the app to access photos/video...but as mentioned above, the app works okay for that, as we are really only interested in what has happened (e.g., people at the pool) rather than receiving *urgent* alerts, which the app does not provide (as far as I have found so far).

I also like how the camera tracks movement very well (there are yellow boxes around people it is tracking -- see video) and seems to have almost infinite ability to see/record up, down, and around.

I am currently using only one of the two cameras, but like it well enough to be thinking where to install the other.

UPDATE: It does do alerts on my iPhone...it pays to keep playing with those settings in the app!

title: Don't make upgrades to a computer that can't handle them.
text:
*Sigh*
On paper this computer looks great. I am not a super tech savvy person, but there are little things that I look for in a computer. I want it to be touchscreen, have a keypad, have a backlit keyboard, and enough speed and memory that I am not dealing with having to delete things all the time or dealing with crashes. That is what I thought this computer would be. I have bought 3 laptops off of Amazon and never had an issue like this.
Main cons-
- Who thought of putting the charging port there? The cord is constantly slipping out and I have to do weird maneuvers for the laptop to even charge. This is an HP design flaw and it is awful. I can't blame this on the third party who did the upgrades, but it is an issue with my purchase.
- It constantly freezes and I have to shut it down and restart it.
- Constantly needs to update and these updates take forever.
- The battery has no life. Once unplugged it lasts about an hour. I am sure before the upgrades it was better. This is one of my main issues for upgrading a computer past its ability.
- If it dies, it takes forever to turn on. I have had a black screen multiple times and have to keep shutting of and restarting to get it to eventually come on.

This leads me to the seller who performed these upgrades. Why? Why make these upgrades that you as a professional should know that a computer like this cannot handle. It is honestly shameful and I can't imagine a lot of people are happy with your company. It's one thing to make upgrades that actually enhance the computer, it is another to make it seem like more of a machine than it is possible to be.

I am returning this and I have gone to the HP site and built my own with the current config of this one and only paid $100 more. SO WORTH IT.
I will not buy a computer of off Amazon again and I think Amazon should really look into some of their third party sellers.
Look at the ratings for this and that should answer you question.
Also, yes, I know I should have read the reviews. I hope someone is reading this and runs far, far away from this computer.

title: Works As Advertised
text: As a part-time podcaster, I sometimes work "on-location". I needed an internet connection for a remote production... but of course, the closest ethernet jack was across the street! Adalov's 5.8G wireless bridge solved my dilemma. Adalov says this bridge has a range of up to almost a mile. That's much farther than I was prepared to test. But in all cases, the transmitter and receiver work best "line of sight"- meaning they should be able to "see" each other, with no obstructions in between. For my setup, that simply meant second-floor windows. This kit is 'plug-n-play', right out of the box- the two transceivers come already paired. I say transceivers because each unit in Adalov's kit can be the transmitter, or the receiver- with just the flip of a switch. The bridge components get power via PoE (Power over Ethernet), and in-line power injectors are included- but each needs an AC outlet. An important note: There are two specs provided, regarding data/throughput speed over the bridge. The transmitter and receiver can "talk" to each other at up to 450mbps, but at the ethernet ports which complete the bridge- on either side, max data speed is 100mbps. So, your data speed using the bridge is 100mbps. However, that's enough bandwidth for streaming at 4K... on as many as four devices- simultaneously! For my operation, I connected each end of the bridge to ethernet switches- one supplying my internet connection, the other allowing me to connect several devices at the receiving end. Everything worked flawlessly. As I mentioned previously, the bridge is 'plug-n-play', out of the box. If signal strength appears low, there are 8-channels the bridge can operate on- each easily selected via a simple button push, on each device. Of course for "power users", the bridge is configurable for IP address, network domain, user name and passwords as well. Lastly, the transmitter and the receiver are weather-resistant, however the power injectors are not- so for permanent installs, longer ethernet cables than the ones supplied with the kit (for use between the transceivers and the injectors) will likely be needed. To sum up, this bridge works as advertised!

title: Excellent wireless bluetooth headphones
text:
I regularly used wired headphones when I wanted to privately listen to music on my phone or tablet, and since I've done so for ages, back to my days long ago on a portable radio, cassette player, or digital audio (MP3) player, the dangling wire never bothered me. As such, I'll honestly admit that I viewed these kind of wireless devices as frivolous devices of extravagance. Especially considering the ridiculous prices certain brands are marketed as. However, I like gadgets, so when the opportunity came to try these out, I certainly seized the chance. So, what can I say now? I'm a huge fan, these are fantastic, and at the price point these sell at, it proves you don't need to spend ridiculous amounts of money for a good pair of wireless headphones. Actually, for the price of a really good pair of wired headphones, these are very impressive for what you get.

The sound quality is very good. Of course, you have to trade-off something to get this kind of portability and freedom of movement, so you are not going to get the kind of broad sound you can get from an excellent pair of wired over the ear headphones. But considering the size of these, wow, you come surprisingly close. Despite the claims of excellent bass response, I have to temper that with while they sound great, excellent bass you can feel, not just hear. That's the one area where headphones this small just are not going to bend the laws of physics, no matter what the price or marketing department tells you. But for zoning out to your tunes while working, well, these are top notch.

My only complaints with these so far are that the controls are a little overly sensitive. I see other have made the same comments and maybe this is something they will be able to correct over time. I find the controls are intuitive, but it sometimes misinterprets a single, double, or triple touch. Given the small size, I know this must of been quite an engineering challenge to build these and get the good performance and nearly invisible controls all into this package. The tiny little instruction booklet will certainly get lost, so I reformatted a copy from their website, along with the missing instructions for the ear-tips (pads), and uploaded a copy here.

I'm now a convert, and these are highly recommended!

title: out with the old and in with the NUU!
text:
I should start out with, I love my over the ear big Sony and Bose headphones. I love the sound and the lack there of (Noise cancellation!) I have tried numerous brands of headsets... wireless, in the ear, over the ear, bone conducting, over the ear wired, pods...etc. Nothing fit ME just right. Even after all that, I still ordered this set. Hoping that just maybe, they would work in a pinch.

Well, let me tell you I am sure glad that I did!!!

Right out of the box, you can tell you are holding in your hands a high quality product. I unpacked the entire little box of goodies and quickly read the directions. I read about an app on google play and I have an iPhone.. YIKES! I started to get a little disappointed. That frustration began to quickly fade as I was able to set up the bluetooth connection so easily.

I placed the buds into my ear and turned on my music. WOW! I was seriously impressed. In addition to hearing my music beautifully, I didn't even hear my husband return from dropping off our children. It is usually quite easy to know when that happens as my three dogs bark their heads off as if we were under attack!

I used the buds the next morning when I was listening to my Bible reading. It was so easy to just pop them in and my phone automatically switched to the buds. I listened to several chapters as I was walking around my house getting the day going. I am in LOVE with these little guys.

I should also mention that I have a tragus piercing which makes most ear things uncomfortable for me. These buds didn't phase me one bit with my piercing.

My husband who detests ear buds, tried them and was like WHOA! These sound great and feel so good!

So, if you have ever struggled with trying to find the perfect listening device, I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND you give these NUU Buds B a try. I am hopeful you will find them super comfy and sound great and for those budget conscious, these do NOT break the bank!

title: The item sent to me had noticable signs of use and the watch charger is a little too weak.
text:
I received this item today, and upon opening and inspecting the item, it had notiable signs of use. It's difficult to show the lighting and usb cable blemishes in a photo (both were scratched, noticable to the naked eye), and so I'm only uploading a photo of the watch charger, as it clearly shows the scratches and blemishes, consistent with a used/returned/resent item.

The item comes packaged in a simple box. Once opened, the item is coiled around the center of a basic plastic tray, with a twist tie keeping it bound. Based on the simplicity of the packaging, it would be incredibly easy for the company to repackage and resend already used and returned products.

I was able to plug the item into a usb-c fast charger, and it worked on both my phone and watch, simultaneously. It took about 1.5 seconds to start charging. This is about 3x longer than any other charger I own, including 3rd party manufactered ones. I cannot attest to the long term reliability of the item. The fact that it worked for the 5 minutes I tested, as well as the general functional useful nature of a single cable to charge both my phone and watch while travelling, are the only pros of this charging cable.

The magnet in the watch charging pod is weak, I would say about half the strength of the standard apple charger. If used while travelling, and if the cable is required to fight gravity while plugged into an available outlet location at whatever location you're staying, it seemed to me incredibly likely it could become dislodged.

The length of the cable is technically 6', from the absolute tip of the usb-c charger, to the absolute tip of the watch charger. However, the lighting cable end is only 71.5 inches in total length, because the magnetic watch pod extends a half inch past the end of the lightning cable. As a comparison, when you buy an apple cable, and they advertise that it's 1 meter in length, that doesn't include the connectors. You actually get just over a meter in actual, usable, cable length.

Overall, because I received a clearly used item, and due to the lack of strength of the magnet in the watch charger, I wouldn't recommend buying this item.

title: Don't be discouraged by relative lack of reviews
text:
I'm not actually sure how many reviews there are currently, but when I bought it there was only like one review. This computer is wonderful!!! I've been using it for a bit longer than a month now, and It was a great purchase. I didn't figure out how to turn on the lights, but it wouldn't matter for my specific setup anyway. I believe there is a way to, though. Just look it up on YouTube. The computer is great for beginners that want to eventually be able to replace parts when the parts get older. It is also VERY well ventilated!! Holy crap, so much airflow.

Also, I saw some others having issues with it turning on- it would light up for a few seconds then the fans would slowly stop spinning and it wouldn't turn on. This happened to me, but it turns out I was a complete idiot and I didn't plug in all of the cables I needed to. If it helps, this is what you need to make sure that you have:

1) plug from the tower to the wall outlet/multi plug extensions (comes with computer)

2) wire from the tower to the monitor (comes with computer)

3) wire from the monitor to the outlet/multi plug extensions (does not come with computer!)

This seems obvious, but it could be a possible solution to this problem. It was a little frustrating to figure out because the instructions just said that the computer requires just those first two cables to turn on, without mentioning that critical third cable. I called a tech support place for Lenovo before I realized there was a missing cable and once I confirmed that I bought this from Amazon they said "oh.. that might be a problem". I'm Not saying that you shouldn't buy it for a slightly cheaper price here, but just keep that in mind. The keyboard and mouse are pretty ok. They are usable and work fine, but they aren't super high quality. I still use the keyboard, it's nice and smooth enough for me, but the mouse is quite clicky.

It is a 5/5 in every other way, through! Great for smooth gaming and beginner upgradability. If you find that it is a cheaper price here than on the Lenovo website, go for it!

title: Looking for a Raspberry Pi?
text:
I found some software that fills a personal need, and which recommends 4 cores and 4GB memory, and decided to build a small system using a Raspberry Pi. But if you're here, I'm sure you know what the market is like for Pis.
Renegade is comparable to a Pi, and possibly even better in some regards, as a tiny home server. I paired it with a 128GB Samsung MicroSD (a bit overkill for the application; Raspbian Lite OS image is under 1.5GB), a 5.25V / 3.5A micro USB power supply (a bit overkill for this board, but I wasn't going to wait to find out later if there are power stability issues), and a compatible case.
From unboxing to first Raspbian Lite boot took around 30 minutes, and most of that time was spent getting the board installed correctly in the case - and also getting the board out of the anti-static bag without breaking a pin. Connected with ethernet, an initial "sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade" took only a few minutes, and I was able to install Docker from its repo without any issues.

As others have mentioned, it's recommended to have a good working knowledge of Linux because the official OSes are all Linux distros and you can do a lot with that knowledge alone. The website and general support seem to have improved a bit since some of the reviews here but it is still subpar to Raspberry Pi, and there is still definitely not as large of a community behind it.

I have more to do with this project but so far I'm very satisfied with my purchase of the Renegade at 1/4 the current price of a Raspberry Pi 4B. I've also bought another board to tinker with and am already planning to buy a few more for running a k8s cluster on dedicated small hardware at home, rather than just tinkering with kind on my gaming PC. But having 1 or 2 of those 8GB models would be pretty nice, too.

P.S. Amazon: The "Touch Screen" feature rating is a very poor choice for this product. It is a SBC with GPIO, not an integrated user environment. You can definitely connect a touch screen to it, but it alone has no touch screen.
