title: Worked for 11 Months, made a zapping noise when plugged in and burning smell followed
text:
I had this for adapter for 11 months. I’ve been using it for a Hollywood styled make up mirror. I was very happy with it’s performance and the length of the cable for my setup. The adapter worked well up until recently.

I had been rearranging some cords around my desk when the mirror the adapter was hooked up to began to flicker like a strobe light. I did some trouble shooting to determine if it was the cable or the mirror malfunctioning. When I didn’t touch the square, ribbed area of the cord coming out of the unit, the mirror lights worked fine. When moving it slightly, a metal clipping noise can be heard (and felt) and the mirror lights began to flicker again. Trying to move the cable around and the ribbed area didn’t fix the lights while they were strobe-like; I had to unplug the adapter and replug it back it to test it more.

I speculated if the wiring to the circuit board was knocked loose. This unit doesn’t come with screws so opening it up isn’t easy. While still troubleshooting, I tried plugging it into a different outlet. When I plugged it into the mirror, I heard a subtle “zap” noise and could smell plastic burning. I freaked out and turned off the outlet from my breaker box before approaching it. I threw it away because it was making my house smell bad. I tried searching for a way to contact the company to see if they’d send me a new one for free but I couldn’t find anything. Amazon makes it pretty difficult to contact sellers unless it’s from a fairly recent order.

I’d say this might be one of those “you get what you paid for” moments. It was a cheap adapter for a small amount of usage. I’d expect a cord like this to last a lifetime with proper care which it was given. The construction of the housing could use some work along with accessibility to the components. I guess it would make sense for a cheap product to never be opened and only closed once upon manufacture. It was working fine up until recently and I was hoping I wouldn’t have to make a yearly $10 purchase to keep my make mirror functional.

title: Great Keyboard - Nice Connectivity Options
text:
I have to say first impressions of this keyboard were not great. It comes in a flimsy cardboard box with some thin plastic end caps for protection. The included cable and dongle were in a smaller flimsy box inside, no manual was included. The box got a little squished in transit and the dongle was just rattling around inside and could easily have exited the box and become lost! I'm all for minimalist eco friendly packaging but this keyboard and it's accessories were not adequately packaged.

Having extracted it from the poor packaging the keyboard is quite delightful. The white keys and silver metal looks great and match the metal case of my Gigabytes Aero laptop perfectly. Connecting was super easy, just plug in the included dongle and it just gets recognized by Windows and just works. To connect via Bluetooth you just press the #1 or #2 Bluetooth key and it goes straight into pairing mode. Switching devices (you can connect 3) is really easy, you just press the appropriate key at the top right of the keyboard.

The construction is sturdy, the keyboard has some weight to it but not excessively so. The scissor type keys are light and positive, it's a nice keyboard to type on. Backlighting is nice, it lights up the legend and the outline of the keys. It took me a while of trial and error to discover that you can change the backlight color by pressing the "Fn" key and the dedicated backlight key. Backlighting can be off or one of three levels. After 30 sec of inactivity the backlighting turns off to save battery.

The keyboard is charged from a USB-C connection, a USB-A to USB-C cable is provided.

One little word of warning, I had to re-type this review after accidentally pressing the key on the top right hand side of the keyboard. This sent the page to a new blank tab... hitting back didn't recover my text! I'm not quite sure of what this key is supposed to do since it didn't open a new tab. This was really quite annoying.

I very nearly deducted a star from my review due to the inadequate packaging and the lack of any instructions (I searched the web and didn't find any either). But this is really nice keyboard for the price.

title: 10 months... still satisfied
text:
I bought my first R3 camera almost 10 months ago now, right after they came out and not long after a driver backed into my new car at a red light (and ignored my horn because, as she said, "People honk all the time so I just didn't pay any attention to it"). In that case, the at-fault driver admitted fault, but I realized how easy it would have been for her to lie and make me look like the guilty party. So I ordered my first Rove dashcam the next day and have since installed them in each of our family vehicles: two R3s and two R2-4Ks.

I've been very satisfied with this camera system. I've rewired a couple of times to get the wiring path I'm most comfortable with in my car. Our other R3 even wired nicely into our old Honda Odyssey with sufficient cable to find a hidden path from back to front. All the cameras have stayed in place well through very hot and very cold weather. The video quality is pretty good. I mean, it's a tiny dashcam, but it's good for what it is. Recently, a truck going the opposite direction on a 2-lane highway dropped a rock on my windshield, and I was able to pull the footage just fine except...I couldn't get my phone's app to connect to the dashcam's Wi-Fi. I ended up having to pull the SD card and get the file from it with my laptop.

I emailed the company earlier this week for help and heard back within 24 hours. Alphie was very helpful. He asked for a screen recording of the problem I was having, was able to diagnose the problem right away, and helped me fix it (turns out, I was using the old app, not the new one--not a difficult problem to fix but certainly was not obvious to me). He continued the conversation through to its completion, even responding to my final email where I gave him feedback on the product.

So far, I'm glad I chose Rove dashcams for our cars. These devices are worlds better than the old dashcam I tried to use years ago and finally gave up on it. I started with an R2-4K to make sure I was happy with the brand, then added three more Roves to the fleet.

title: Nothing but problems, problems, problems.
text:
I knew what I was getting into with this watch. I didn’t want a full smart watch—I’ve had an Apple Watch in the past and it just wasn’t for me. I wanted a fitness tracker that could accurately track heart rate, sleep, and my heart health. In theory this watch should be perfect, but I’m four months into owning this, and it’s been nothing but problems from day one.

First of all, as many others had noted, the heart rate tracking is unbelievably off. My personal trainer actually laughs at some of the numbers it gives me. 10 minutes on the stair master? 72 bpm. Driving in the car on an empty road? 190bpm. 15 minutes on the rowing machine? 82 bpm. Lying down reading a book? 145bpm. A set of PR squats? 68 bpm. I’ve tried wearing it on the other arm, wearing it on different spots on my arm, cleaning the sensor, changing the tightness—nothing but incredibly inaccurate readings. This inaccuracy on a simple measurement like heart rate makes me question the accuracy of the ECG—which was a real selling point for me.

The other infuriating thing is how buggy the connectivity to the app is. This isn’t my first FitBit, and I’ve grown to really appreciate the app over the years, but I can only use it if my watch actually syncs—which it almost never does! I lose connectivity to the app every 2-3 days, and it just sticks on “Sync is taking a while. Sit tight” for literally ever. Days if I let it. The only way to reconnect it is to remove the device from the app and my phone’s Bluetooth, and then do a factory reset on the watch itself—less than ideal, obviously.

Because my watch almost never syncs, I can’t see any of my sleep data. So all the reasons I purchased this watch aren’t functioning for me, which means I’m basically just wearing it now as a $300 “dumb” watch and that really grinds my gears.

After many loyal years, I think I’m done with FitBit after this one.

title: This fancy new ATX 3.0 PSU was dead on arrival
text:
I was excited to finally get my hands on this unit as it was one of the first ATX 3.0 PSUs with the 12VHPWR port to power the 4000-series Nvidia GPUs without the clutter of adapter dongles, to come to market from a normally very trusted brand in the PC component world (MSI). I've had MSI motherboards, graphics cards, laptops, and they've always been well made and reliable after years of use, so I expected the same from this PSU. Sadly, this was not the case. Perhaps MSI quality control has gone down, or maybe I've finally struck some bad luck for once. This PSU would not even power on after installing it on a new build. I should've tested it before spending hours on the build but since I had so much faith in MSI as a brand, I didn't and that was my bad. I did not buy this from amazon but rather from a reputable b&m computer store who tested this PSU when I returned it and confirmed it was indeed dead out of the box. So sad. I had high hopes for this beast. On the positive side, I will say that this MSI MEG Ai1000p looked very well-built and was nicely packaged and included some decent cables including the 12VHPWR stamped with "600W" on the connectors. It was also dead silent when I turned it on, but that's probably because it was just dead :)

Anyhow, I didn't want to roll the dice with MSI on a PSU again so instead of getting a replacement of the same model, I decided to try Silverstone HELA1200R and beQuiet DarkPower 13 1000W. Both were in stock at amazon and delivered quickly so I got a chance to try both. Unlike this MSI unit, those other 2 PSUs worked like a champ out of the box. I decided to keep the DarkPower 13 over the HELA1200R simply because it seemed better built, was a lot quieter even under full load, and was slightly more efficient with a 80 Plus Titanium rating versus the 1200R's Platinum rating. The 1200R might have higher wattage capacity, but at 1000w the DarkPower 13 already seems to provide ample juice for my specific gaming build (7950x + 4090 with just mild overclocking).

title: I thought I made a mistake ordering this, but now I love it!
text:
[[VIDEOID:9518666ad4d8e42e4283407d03cf5a4a]] I originally ordered this little side monitor for a smaller laptop I have to get a little more screen real estate. After I received it, it dawned on me that the laptop I wanted to use is a 2-in-1 style that can fold up to be used as more of a tablet. The mounting plate for the back of the laptop would interfere with closing the laptop up for use as a tablet. It still closed mostly on a test fit, but felt odd being partway open. Oops, I thought.

Then I realized this little monitor can be used as a self-standing monitor, making it very useful for me. I can use it with several different computer setups I have whenever I need some extra screen. Since it's USB powered, I can even use it in my campervan.

One issue I had is that for the life of me, I can't remove the baseplate (has the double sided tape) from the monitor arm. I see how it slides in, but it won't come loose even with a pretty good amount of force. I don't want to really force it since I don't think the hinge would take it. If it's some sort of intelligence test, I failed miserably. There's even a video on how to remove it, and it slides right off and back on again in the video. Mine won't budge. I'll look at it again with fresh eyes later. Fortunately it doesn't matter anymore now that I'll be using the mount/hinge assembly as a stand.

The angle of the monitor can be changed by moving the mount/hinge in or out as desired. Pretty slick! If the monitor is flipped/rotated over to move the ports to the other side, the image flips automatically. It comes with excellent documentation and instructions but nothing about removing that darn baseplate.

This monitor will come in very handy in my little photo studio and can be set on table next to a client so they can see what I see in my computer when shooting tethered (camera is controlled by the computer). Although I may be using it differently than its intended use, it's super helpful to me and I am really glad I got it.

title: Great bang for buck unless you want top production value
text:
The Nisheng 1080p camera comes with a monitor clip, mini tripod, USB cable, USB-A (female) to USB-C (male) adapter, adhesive privacy cover, and a paper manual. They're organized securely in a custom plastic frame in a white box with basic graphic of the camera and is attractive enough to give as a present.

Installation is plug and play, couldn't be easier. The camera delivers more than good enough picture quality. You can let it automatically manage the settings or you can dive in, disable it, and do it yourself. I opted for the latter as I fine-tune it better as lighting conditions change throughout the day. It can compensate for backlighting. Color reproduction/auto white balance is satisfactory. It is fixed focus so you have to move to where it is optimal if you want to look crisp. It has a pretty decent range from close to 5 feet from it. Surprisingly it's capable of 60 FPS. You'll want hardware encoding on your computer to take advantage of that (pretty much any Intel machine made after 2015, or if you have a gaming-oriented video card).

There is no way this has 80 degree angle of view; their own example meeting room picture shows no more than 35 degrees. I'm estimating it somewhere between 35 and 40 degrees. So it's fine for one or two people and possibly an intimate third, but get something else if you want to run larger group meetings.

The privacy cover is an adhesive affair. It's obviously not as good as if it were designed into the camera itself but it works well enough.

The microphone quality is surprisingly good. It's a condenser of course, and it picks up everything in the room. It's on the bright side. It's easy to exceed its range so keep the input setting low (it was on 22 by default).

The mini tripod has two height settings. It can support the webcam and it has a standard 1/8" mount but it can't support a contemporary phone. The clip is hinged to accommodate most monitor situations. The camera can pivot on two axes, pitch and yaw but not roll, enough to cover all but extreme situations.

For the price it's a solid value if you prioritize ease of use and results.

title: Great Dream Turned Into Nightmare
text:
Looking at this case you would think the thermals would be fantastic - not. Started with a i7-11700K in a MSI ITX B560 MB. Using 2 -120mm Noctua 1800rpm fans on top and 120-15mm on the bottom because that is all that would fit. Got the unit to post but at idle it wouldn't go below 55° C with fans at 80%. Changed the 2 Noctua 120mm on top to their Industrial versions which spin at 3000 rpm and that got it down to 51° C at idle. Only found 2 coolers that would fit because the PCIe 3.0 (why 3.0, that's a different subject) has to wrap around the 92mm 15mm thick fan which obviously blocked the airflow - but the be quite & Noctua gave same temps.

OK start over - ripped the unit apart and went to a i5-11600K processor. Completely reassembled and now it idled at 49°C. I should have prefaced this with the dictum we deliver our builds at - they cannot idle above 35° C because that will usually translate to an acceptable temp under heavy load. Now under moderate load, this unit shot up to 76° in a few minutes.

Obviously, this case will never leave our shop this way. So just for our own volition we ripped it down again and equipped it with a Thermaltake Ultra 240 Liquid unit. Leaving the i5 processor this got the thermals down to 38®C but by doing that we lost the two exhaust fans on top so there was only one 120mm 15mm thick fan intake. Now the processor temp was "acceptable" but the board temp went crazy.

We then took the same components and installed them in a Sugo Mini-Cube. Posted and immediately idle temps were under 33® C. So now we could change the noisy 3000 rpm fans for some reasonable 120mm's. The Sugo case only has 2 fans but they can be full width 120's.

Bottom line - they tout great German engineering - think they might try some simple German testing before releasing a product. Not worth sending it back as with all the in and out of components its got beat up and Amazon should not be penalized for that. Keep away if you value your sanity.

title: Very good sound at a value price
text:
I received the LARKSOUND 2.1 Sound Bar with Subwoofer

I was happy to receive this sound bar to improve the sound of my 43” TV in the bedroom. (see pic) The TV sound was OK, this sound bar is much better. To be clear, the sound is not audiophile quality, but not every TV requires audiophile sound and the price that they can cost. This sound bar is a good value.

Installation was easy. In my case, the sound bar sits neatly on the shelf below the TV and the subwoofer sits in the corner on the floor. Assembly of the sound bar is easy, it has two halves that connect by a single wire and then slide together with groves in the housing. The subwoofer connects via a single wire and RCA-type plug to the sound bar. No additional power is required for the subwoofer.

There are multiple input options available: Audio jack, USB-A, Bluetooth, optical and HDMI. I am using the HDMI ARC output from the TV to the HDMI input on the sound bar. This allows the sound bar volume to be controlled by the TV remote and the sound bar turns on and off automatically. I also connected the sound bar to my Amazon Echo via Bluetooth, and can easily switch between TV and Echo using the included sound bar remote to switch inputs. Input type is indicated on the sound bar with different color LED, for instance, Bluetooth is blue. There are different sound options, selectable by remote, including: Standard, Movie, Music, Night, 3D. (see pic)

Set up took less than five minutes, simply connect the parts and plug in. Wall mounting, of course, will take longer to drill holes if required.

The package includes the sound bar, the subwoofer, a remote control (see pic), an audio cable, an optical cable, two optional wall standoffs for extra space behind for wiring, mounting hardware and wall template and a user guide. The remote requires two AAA batteries, not included. An HDMI cable is not included.

I’m very happy with this sound bar and look forward to watching movies with it. I hope this information has been helpful

title: Really nice Bluetooth speaker for my PC
text:
I don't really like wearing headphones except when I'm on Zoom calls or gaming on Discord with friends. For that reason, I prefer watching videos and listening to music over speakers - but the onboard speakers for most monitors tend to be garbage.

Before I bought this sound bar, there were almost no reviews on here, but each one that *was* published was positive. So I took a bit of a chance and purchased this one, since the sound bar I had at the time which was USB-powered + Aux connection only was quickly fizzling out.

That was July last year. I've been nothing but impressed by this little sound bar since then! I'm no audiophile, but to me, the sound quality has been consistently good. I've used it while watching Netflix, playing casual games (I don't play shooters or games where the directional audio really matters), and listening to music while I work.

Easy to set up and use, with the volume knob right at my fingertips to turn sound up or down. It can get pretty loud; I keep it usually at 20%-30% volume, and turn it up to maybe 60% max. It also fits perfectly under both of my monitors, even the one which is a bit lower. Sometimes (like with any BT speaker) I need to manually reconnect it when I restart my PC, but oftentimes it automatically reconnects.

The one "con" I'll note is that when it starts up, it lets out this pretty jarring dial tone like a phone trying to call someone, which annoys or startles my partner every time. ** I did see on someone else's review, though, that you can just connect the USB to a power strip to eliminate this "wake-up" chime which is caused by turning the soundbar on - by plugging it directly to an outlet, it will always stay on. I've found this isn't true for me: My unit is always plugged into the USB port on a power strip, but connects via Bluetooth, and still sounds every time I turn on my PC. Might work if you connect via aux cable though!

For $60, I'm not sure you can get much more value for money with computer speakers/sound bars. It's a 10/10 recommendation from me!

title: Awesome portable projector
text:
[[VIDEOID:3932ee658c98b5c592f2afff099087a]] Taking it out of the box, I was surprised by the quality of the case. I love the faux suede material, and I really like that every accessory has its own place. It keeps everything organized and accessible. It also includes everything you need to get going right away.

The included power bank is really handy. I have actually used it to charge my other devices when traveling. It will power the projector for a while, but I noticed it seemed to drain quickly. It will easily charge my phone from a very low battery with charge to spare. If you’re planning to watch a movie, I would recommend plugging it directly into an outlet with the included power cable.

When I turned it on, my first impression was that it was really bright! Even with lights on in the room, I could still see the screen clearly. I didn’t apply any filters to my video or pictures so you can get a good idea of how the room lighting affects the projection. If you’re in a small and very dark room, there is a setting to dim the brightness. You can adjust the focus with a small dial on the side. It’s really clear, and the picture quality would be better if my walls were flat instead of textured. Connecting the projector to my FireTV with the mini HDMI cable was easy. There is a remote in the carrying case, but the touch-sensitive menu buttons on the projector are also handy in case the remote isn’t nearby or you lose it.

The audio is about what you would expect from a small device, but it’s really easy to connect it to a separate Bluetooth speaker. I actually prefer to set a speaker closer to where I am sitting.

I have another projector that I can use for fun movie nights outside to project on the side of the house, but it’s big enough that I was always worried about breaking it when we would travel. I don’t have these concerns with this one. I can put everything in the carrying case and toss it in my bag and go. It is also ideal if you’re wanting to project something in a smaller space. Definitely recommend!

title: Niche beats I pad
text:
There’s really 2 categories of competition when comparing this. 1. Ipads 2. e ink devices.

Vs iPad, the writing feel, eye strain, and battery life (4-5 days), and distractability are the main advantage the boox has over an I pad… essentially every other category from processing power to ux I pad wins…

Its more of a paper note pad/ book replacement with lots of enhanced features over a basic notebook. You can look at it all day without eye strain and use it in the dark with its front lit lights. It’s super nice. It really does feel like paper. It can do all android capable features but is not as snappy as you might as expect from an i pad. The user interface is not bad… it’s not great as there’s no apparent tutorial on how to use it within the tablet itself

Vs other ink tablets
Boox is the most robust in features over the other main competitors. Within the notes app you can input hyper links to websites, and voice recordings, video. It has a back light which I feel is necessary, a camera (which is pretty crappy actually in terms of resolution and focus ability) the fastest writing latency of all competitors at this time, I don’t find myself using the keyboard a ton nor the camera… with the camera theoretically if you take a picture with your phone and sync it with the tablet you can import a photo. The keyboard is very good but when you type, you might type 10 words and they don’t immediately show up, But then they all show up at once after you kind of take a half second break. It doesn’t bother me. It has also never failed to type what I have imputed on the keyboard but something to keep in mind.

It was a no brainier to go with boox primarily for the backlight. Between the note air 2 and ultra tab, I liked the idea of the keyboard and especially camera, but the main selling point was the fastest writing speed of the ultra tab. Looking back I really only use it for hand written notes so I likely could have gotten away with the note Air 2… but then again it’s only about $100 less so not a bad deal

title: Functional alternative to disposable air cans.  Accessories arrived damaged or missing.
text:
BLUF: Assuming you receive a truly new unit, this is an okay option at the mid-to-low end of the price range for this type of product. Forego this specific model and opt for one with a better suite of attachments and suction, which (IMO) is a must-have feature available in similarly sized products

**The unit I received appears to missing one attachment and another is cracked (see pictures).**

Between environmental impacts and the potential for abuse, I moved away from disposable, compressed air duster cans a long time ago. Since then I’ve used a combination of detailing attachments on vacuum cleaners, soft bristle brushes, and most recently cleaning gel to get the jobs done. I don't necessarily need the same force seen with compressed air cans, but it has to be enough to effectively clear debris from the nooks and crannies of my keyboard, computers, consoles, etc.

This PGROUP duster performs well enough most of the time. For scenarios in which it comes up short, one could argue that a different tool would be a better approach. I don’t think you’ll be disappointed if you choose this product, but better options exist.

This offering from pgroup is similar (and some cases effectively identical) to current products from Opwulo, Qindlkar *Amazon’s Choice*, ZLLOO, TriPole, Yomile, KENSOSO, etc.

Experience: The unit powers on with a long press of the single button and operates continuously at the lowest setting. Short press the button to cycle up to the next speed (three sppeds, low, medium, high). Turn the unit off with a long press or by cycling past the max speed setting. The led work light is on whenever the unit is operating and effectively illuminates the work area (if you're too far away for it to help, you're probably too far away for the duster to make a difference). The accessories snap into place (functionally, not so much audibly) and hold with friction; push or pull to attach or remove respectively. USB-C charging. More than enough power to get through numerous cleaning sessions.

title: Not a 3255 chip but still great.
text:
We have been using this amp to for dance parties and it's very good, very loud. I think it's the best under $100 2.1 available right now.
I do have two main comments that could be considered negatives. One, this one does get hot. In our warm environment, it sometimes shuts down when played loud. We first put a small 6" fan on it to cool the case and that works well, but you have to make sure the fan is on also. We now have drilled holes in the case and it can ventilate and release the heat better. Fosi should consider passive ventilation or even installing a small fan.
The other is the actual chip used. I believed the publicity that this amp came with TPA3255 chips. 3255 chips accept up to 48 volts though that also depends on the capacitors' rating. I had planned to get a higher voltage supply and power this at 42-46 volts for the full power of the 3255.

BUT this amp is strictly limited to 36 volts which is the power specification for the 3251 chip that is the lower wattage sibling to the 3255. It is still a very good chip and still more power than the other chips used in these class D amps except the 3255. To me, the power input ratings and the output specifications all point to the fact that this is a 3251 based amplifier.
In addition Fosi does have two other amps (at least) that it advertises as 3255 based amps and those ones are, in fact specified to work with their 46 volt power supply while this one is not. They also have the power output specifications of a full 3255 amp.
Again, nothing wrong with the 3251, it's a very very good amp. But I do not think wrong for Fosi to pretend that this is one chip when it is almost certainly the lower power version. I have asked on forums and also here and Fosi will not answer. The two chips are the same pin configuration so it's possible that Fosi designed the amp to work with either one but then kept the price lower (40+ v power supplies are expensive!) or the heat production lower. Please be honest Fosi! We love your products and want to trust you.

title: Intel Arc A770 4k@120hz 10bit HDR10
text:
After having some issues with HDMI and my LG OLED C1, I read that using the displayport is a better way to go. Since TV's don't have displayports I grabbed a DP to HDMI adapter I already had and gave it a try. After a few weeks with no issues I decided to find a better adapter that did 4k@120hz. I received it today(3/2/2023) but so far it seems to be working great.

With my LG OLED C1 I can get 4096x2160@120hz 10bit HDR10.

One thing I did notice when I tested using 2001: A Space Odyssey 4k remaster was that Plex is telling me I have 5.1 surround Bitrate-2197 kbps. While the TV only seemed to recognize 2 audio channels in the HDMI diagnostics hidden menu. I also confirmed this with Aliens (1986),5.1 24 bit DTS@1509kbps, installed on my pc and using VLC to playback. This could be windows shenanigans since I haven't paid for dolby, but without a proper surround setup I cannot confirm.

**Edit: Turns out the surround issue is due to windows NOT the adapter. You can think Microsoft for its extremely poor implementation of audio, although without testing I can't say that Linux does it any better. Also while playing around I did notice some audio skipping, I couldn't figure out what was causing the issue since it was intermittent. Then I remembered another review that mentioned the adapter getting hot, so I slapped a few raspberry pi heatsinks I had on the adapter. The skipping issue went away almost immediately. I also checked the firmware and found it to be up to date, the utility Cable Matters has on their website made checking/updating the firmware very easy. I still give this adapter 5 stars since it does everything its advertised to do, although it could do a better job of cooling.

Edit 03/20/2023: I'm now using this with the cable matters Active 8k HDMI Fiber Optic Cable 300047-BLK-15M. The adapter and cable are still getting 4k@120hz VRR 10bit HDR, but now with a 15m/49ft cable. (added 2 pictures to review showing LG hidden menu & windows 10 settings)

title: A good secondary monitor with minor problems
text:
Overall, I'm pretty happy with this monitor. I use it as a secondary monitor on my large desktop PC (I have an ultrawide as my primary). This sits conveniently next to the larger screen. Setting it up was as simple as plugging it in and extending my desktop in Windows.

I do wish the brightness was a little better. Sometimes it feels dim and could use better contrast (I have both set to max and it still needs more). I haven't tested the built-in speakers yet, but in my configuration I have little need of them.

Here's the odd thing... there's no power button. It seems to rely on your PCs power settings or on the fact you're going to shut the PC down. I virtually never shut down my desktop. There's simply no need unless I have to do a brief reboot. I just turn my primary monitor off physically before I go to bed. But, I can't do that with this monitor. I have to physically unplug it. Minor inconvenience. It comes right back when I plug it back in.

All in all, it's a great convenience to have this screen sitting off on the side when I'm playing a game on the big screen. It's nice to just be able to mouse over and read a document without having to alt-tab out (which many games aren't too happy about).

There's no real mounting solution for this monitor. I believe the expectation is that you're going to just use the magnetic case that came with it and stand it up like you would a tablet. I suspect that works for most applications, just don't expect to be able to stick this on a VESA mount or anything like that.

I received this for free through the Vine Voice program, but I can tell you I wouldn't pay the asking price for it ($189 as of this writing). It feels too expensive for what you actually get. There are similar products on the market right here on Amazon that also have IPS panels and are $60-70 cheaper.

I know that sounded like a lot of complaining, so I want to emphasize that I still believe this is a solid 4-star product. I wish they would reduce the price a bit, but I can definitely recommend this for certain configurations.

title: Occer Compact Binoculars
text:
I purchased these compact Occer binoculars on Amazon a while back. These particular binoculars have been the top selling binocular on Amazon for a very long period of time. That fact alone got me interested in buying them. I have a very large collection of binoculars at home. I live in the California high desert in a beautiful scenic valley with spectacular views. This dark sky area I live in is also ideal for astronomy.
These come with a very nice carry case and the two rubber eye cups that come with the binoculars are attached to each other, which is a good idea, less likelihood of them getting lost. These come with a thin economy style neck strap. These binoculars have these rotating eye cups that extend outwards as you twist them. I've never seen this feature before on binoculars, I think it's mainly for eyeglass wearers. The eye cups can be extended out for quite a distance from the binoculars body.
My first impression of these Occer binoculars is extreme disappointment with the magnification. The Chinese manufacturing companys love to exaggerate magnification claims on these economy binocular models. I'd say the true magnification on my binoculars is only about 7 1/2 power, nowhere near the stated 12 power placed in the Amazon ad. I make this claim judging from the magnification that my other binoculars provide. I bought another new pair of compact binoculars around the same time I bought these Occers. This other set was around the same price and are a bit smaller in size than the Occer brand. I prefer this other brand over the Occers set because of the increased magnification they provide. Sadly this model was discontinued right after I bought them.
The Chinese are so advanced now in binocular manufacturing that it's hard to go wrong buying an inexpensive set of binoculars with BAK4 prisms. All these BAK4 binoculars sold on Amazon provide excellent image clarity and detail. The image quality from one brand to another is negligible due to the high quality standards the Chinese now have in their manufacturing process. All these different binocular brands with BAK4 prisms provide excellent image quality that was not available on cheap binoculars many years ago. Now if they could only be a bit more honest on the true stated magnification in their ads, then they would hit a home run!

title: Great for keeping an eye on package deliveries and pickups
text:
I send out a lot of packages each week and usually I will schedule a pick up. This means that I will usually place my packages on the front porch so that they can be picked up during the day. Similarly, there are times when I receive a package, but have no idea it’s arrived for hours because the package delivery notification doesn’t update. So, I’ve always been worried about leaving packages for pick up or from delivery to me out on the porch for too long for fear that someone might take something. So, I was excited to get this wireless camera to be able to keep tabs on the front porch area.

This was very easy to install on the house and similarly it was easy to set up on the app. There are a bunch of customizable options on the app about how sensitive you want the motion sensor to be, notification options, etc. The motion sensor is very very sensitive!! I had to put it all the way down to the lowest sensitivity because I was getting motion notifications several times an hour in the beginning. As it is, I still get notifications whenever my neighbor’s car leaves the driveway or at nighttime when car lights pass by. However, I easily fixed this by positioning the camera a little differently so that I could customize the location of the sensor.

When I get a notification of motion, now I can go into the app and take a look at the picture that was snapped to see what the motion was. Very helpful in determining if there is an issue outside and in ensuring the safety of my packages. However, I do wish the picture would be taken faster. Sometimes I’m getting the tail end of someone leaving the front door. I can set up the app to allow for video storage but I haven’t done so.

One thing I really don’t like is that there is a bright light that will go on during motion sensing - it seems to only go on when it’s a certain level of darkness. I have not found a way to deactivate this but would love to. I assume it gets very annoying to my neighbors at night, and probably also disorienting to anyone coming up to the door.

Overall though, this is a great camera that provides exactly what I needed to keep tabs on the front porch area.

title: Xtrasaver Inc. is Selling These with Ancient Inputs --> D-Sub, DVI, only one HDMI
text:
Xtrasaver Inc. sent me a refurbished/"renewed" one of these - price was right...

What arrived looked new! Only, it had the wrong base, square instead of curved. Only, it had only one HDMI input (standard female), instead of 2. Only, it had a DVI input, and a D-Sub input.

Only, it didn't come with a Display Port input. None.

So, what if someone wanted to take advantage of the two HDMI inputs from two sources, and share them on the one screen - which is a feature for this monitor?

Easy, just time travel to when Fry's still existed everywhere, to when they carried connectors and cables of all types and many eras of electronics, and get yourself a D-Sub cable. Or, perhaps you're still running video cards with DVI connectors?

Then maybe you can use the dual input feature, maybe?

Otherwise, it ain't gonna happen. Because, Fry's is gone and Methuselah moved on from D-Sub decades ago.

So, I'm returning this. Am taking pictures, while at UPS so I have a witness, of the monitor and the accessories. Am also taking pictures using the packaging used to deliver it to me. So, if Xtrasaver tries to claim they got it with things missing and or damaged, from me or my packaging job, I got my evidence to counter.

Amazon has already stepped in on this and we're both waiting for them to get the return, and promptly refund me.

There's new one's available, with the correct inputs and features, for like 30 bucks more. I went for it. It ships from Amazon. Am confident all will be well with the new one. Am not so confident Xtrasaver will refund me without a hassle, but Amazon said they will be contacting them, to help make sure I get my money back...

D-Sub inputs... who here misses VGA graphics? How does a 4k 27" monitor ship in 2023 with D-sub inputs? They don't. Unless you order refurbs from Xtrasavers.

title: Shipped unprotected .. 2 legs indented .. did not fit my light .. no instructions.
text:
When I ordered this had a list price of $39.99 with $5 off (for a final cost of $34.99).

You’d think if the manufacturer had any pride they’d put some packing around this but they just put it into a plastic bag & stuck that into a thin cardboard box, & that’s how it shipped.

Once opened, some parts were rattling loose in the box, and there were no instructions or anything else to reach out or know what parts should be included — the box was not fully sealed by the time it got to me.

I pulled it out, & found where the parts fit, then upon extending the tubes noticed where there was a big indent on one of the tubular legs.

It still opened & did not seem to make it any more wobble or unsteady. Then I looked at the other two legs & another was less obviously indented — so 2 of 3 tube-legs were crushed in, I can suppose during shipping, but there were no obvious paint flecks — so possibly it was sent out that way?

I later tried to mount my streaming light, but the “dual” fitting on this tripod had “dual” male ends, unfortunately just like the tripod fitting on my light is male — so I can’t even use this without going somewhere else to find an adapter that fits the tripod mount to the light attachment.

This is lousy performance of this manufacturer to ship its product with no protection to speak of & not include any help or other info inside with the product. Not taking the obvious step of packing it to protect it is just tempting fate and the resulting suffering of the consumer who is then expected to re-pack, ship it back, order another.

Disappointed customer on this end.

I’d look for another tripod..
..from a manufacturer that tries to protect his product;
..tries to put sufficient adapters in to fit typical devices you’d expect it to attach to;
..and has the minimal sense of duty to put written materials in the box so you can know if everything is there (at least).

title: Disappointing
text:
I have so many Samsung devices, that when my fourth fitness tracker from another company died I decided to give Samsung a try. Here are the pros and cons.

Pros:
==============
-The Samsung name.

-It has many more features that I will every use.

-The design feels sturdy and I expect it to be durable.

-It is attractive enough for a smart watch.

Cons:
==============
-The battery life sucks. Even in battery saving mode, the watch gives you a maximum of a day and a half of charge. Mind you, I don't really do anything other than look at the clock, my heart rate, and steps. I do not answer the phone with it, or send messages, etc. My old fitness tracker, which granted had fewer features, would last upward of a week doing the same thing.

-Sleep tracking is a joke, because again the battery sucks.

-You cannot remove unused apps from the watch. Electronics manufactures love to load smart watches, phones, PCs with stuff you don't need and will never use. Considering these things often work in the background and use energy, it would make sense to be able to remove them.

-It is incredibly thick.

-There is no way to know by the packaging whether you are getting a US or international version. Found that out the hard way with the first one of these I bought. Try registering an international version in the US and you will see why this is an issue... though I would argue there should only be one global version for something like this anyway. There is no reason why the end-user could not just install the region specific software they need.

-The US version has a shorter warranty (1 year) than if you live in the EU (2 years). Hey, either your device will last two years or it won't. Give us the same guarantee you give others. Given the issues I have had with Samsung products over the years; washers that throw baskets through walls, Note phablets that catch fire, and a monitor that started black screening about a month after the warranty expired... I guess shame on me.

title: OK hub, very limited I/O offering
text:
I've used one of these side-mounted hubs on my Macbook Pro ever since they released the dual TB3 model. However, when I moved to the new M1 Macbook Pro, the old hubs covered my Magsafe charge port, making them much less useful.

This is the first hub I've used that gets around the Magsafe port with a cutout, in order to offer the same side-mount functionality. It passes through one USB4 port and uses the second to provide HDMI, ethernet, and USB-C -> USB-A conversion.

However: the overall experience is quite limited - it allows for 4k@60Hz HDMI, a single USB2.0 port, and a 1GbE link. That's 18Gbps+0.480Gbps+1Gbps, respectively, or ~20Gbps bandwidth usage while consuming a 40Gbps port. While it's expected that this hub runs at the USB 3.2 Gen2x2 20Gbps spec, the consumption on this hub is not appropriately maximizing the IO. 2/4 USB-C data pairs can be utilized to send a 4k@60Hz signal, offering the necessary 20Gbps of bandwidth via Alt Mode. That means 10Gbps of bandwidth is still available from the USB-C port, and it is allocated here for a USB2.0 port and an ethernet link. The USB2.0 port is connected directly to the USB-C dedicated USB2.0 pins, so the only thing connected to the 10Gbps link is a USB3->Ethernet adapter chip (the AX88179A).

All of that is to say: this is really *not* a "hub". There is no USB hub chip inside. It's simply taking one USB-C port and dividing its lanes into an ethernet chip, a HDMI, and a USB2.0 port with no hub controller. This means the overall bandwidth is very limited, and the functionality of the "hub" itself is minimal. For the price, I'd expect an integrated hub chip that exposes, at bare minimum, an additional USB3.0 port instead of a USB2.0 port. Instead, a 10Gbps USB3.2 lane is entirely being dedicated to a single, 1Gbps ethernet link.

title: Really nice folio slip case, but a tight fit even for an Air
text:
I have a lovely new MacBook Air and am not ready to hide it with a hard shell. But, in most briefcases or packs, without protection, it kind of slides around in the slot. Plus, it's really hard to get a good grip on it when taking it in and out of a bag. What I wanted was a slip case, one not too padded, because my briefcase has a padded slot, bu something protective w/out a lot of bulk. This is perfection.

These folks sent this product in one of the most impressive packaging I've seen. The folio even comes with its own drawstring pouch (which you can use to store it, cover it, or use alone for you Air). If the folio stands up as impressively as the first impression, they've made a customer for life.

It's zippered on 2 sides only and my Air slid in and was a nice tight fit. It's got a very nice feel to it without creating bulk. It also provides better gripping when moving the Air from case to desk. The felt inside is smooth and tight. Won't pill or shed. This is not a heavy duty padded slip case. It's a folio, meant for something you slip into something else. When you zip it up, it's a nice snug fit. It easily slipped into my briefcase slot and kept it from moving around.

Honestly don't know what I'd use the slots inside for. Things would need to be slim and not capable of denting the Air. But, it's a plus that they're there in case a need ever comes up.

WARNING!
If you have a MacBook Pro, get the next size up. My Air...without a shell or casing, was a snug fit. A Pro might be really tight in the 14 inch version. I have a shell for my Air that hasn't been installed yet and just putting the shell in this was a real stretch.

This folio is classy. Smart, practical, and having this makes me question even putting a shell on my Air.. My iPaid Air, with protective case fits in this, making it a safer way to tuck it into backpacks and briefcases. I'm actually keeping the box it came in, too.

title: SPECTACULAR travel monitor
text:
This review is based on my first impression, written within the first 30 minutes after connecting the monitor to my laptop.

I will update my review if the monitor develops issues in the future.
This is an amazing travel monitor.

The display is large and everything on the display is very easy to read.

The monitor can be powered by the included AC adapter’s USB-A to USB-C cable, or by plugging the USB-A to USB-C cable between the laptop and monitor, or by plugging the USB-C to USB-C cable between the laptop and monitor.

My monitor is currently powered by the USB-C to USB-C cable between the laptop and monitor, and in this configuration the AC adapter is not required.

I recommend purchasing a Mini HDMI Male to Standard HDMI Female adapter, just in case you decide to use it on another computer that does not have a Standard HDMI Female connector. Just be prepared.

As you can see, you have options.

Please note that I do not have a MAC or Desktop PC, I ONLY have a laptop.

I connect my monitor into an HP EliteBook 845 G8 Notebook PC (i.e., a laptop).

The monitor is larger than my laptop’s screen, and that is perfectly fine.

I like the fact that a magnetic leather is included with the monitor.

I wish the package included a screen protector, but that’s not a deal breaker and not a reason to take away any stars from my rating.

I have not tested the speakers.

I’m not a gamer so I am unable to give a review that relates to gaming.

The screen is a matte finish, not shiny, and I like that.

The colors displayed on the screen are magnificent.

That’s my review for now, perhaps I’ll append to this review in the future.

As for now, I HIGHLY recommend this product.

5-STARS!!!

title: A Great Value for the Money, Goes All Day, MP3 or WAV Sound Quality Choices
text:
​I don't play video games or have a fancy mobile phone, and ​I ​am one of the older technically challenged slow​ ​learners, but I am now proficient with this ​​​BrilliantHouse Voice Recorder. I purchased this recorder to record conversations so that I can replay and make sure I remember them correctly. For this price point, I feel this is a great value and I would recommend it to my friends. ​It came fully charged but has an extra long battery life.
​There ar​e three papers included with the recorder. To learn how to use this recorder, find the paper with the You​T​ube video to watch. Watch it and then check out any other videos for a recorder that looks like this ​​BrilliantHouse Voice Recorder. There are several videos for recorders with different memory sizes and makers that closely resemble this. Watch them if you need further help, I did and I finally got it!​ ​The instructions still need revisions or clarifications​. You get a "Recorder Instruction Manual" but you need a magnifying glass to read it. There is a​"BrilliantHouse Voice Recorder Operation Manual." printed on both sides of an
8-1/2"×11" paper so that it can be read easily without my magnifying glass. However it contains selections of information taken from the instruction manual that has been enlarged and randomly placed. Although I could read it, I found myself flipping the paper back and forth which confused me some more. ​The various YouTube videos really helped me. ​
A charging cord is included to charge into the computer​, but not a charging block.​ It comes with ​​earbuds but without soft connectors, just hard plastic for your ears. They are cheap but will be good to have on hand in case I forget my ​comfortable but large headphones.​ ​It comes with a plastic phone connector attachment for recording from a landline telephone hookup with the plastic connection that very few users have. I guess I'll hold on to this--maybe I will need it one day. After watching YouTube, I can operate the recorder and understand the cheat sheet.
​​
For a small portable audio recording device, this ​​BrilliantHouse Voice Recorder ​checks all the boxes and is worth the price.

title: Whole lot of space with a pretty good microphone.
text:
5 stars are usually reserved for products that go above and beyond or just do just one thing to me that makes them more then what I thought I needed out of the product. I knew I needed a voice recorder to make a journal. Didn't expect having a voice recorder with just having an idle shut off. Yes, the idle shut off is what's getting the five stars here.

I won't lie that I'm a very forgetful person. So I do forget I leave devices on and go out the next day to realize I have electronics ready to shut off. The idle shut off is just a nice feature for people like me. It's been 3 weeks since I gotten the device and so far it never needed a recharge thanks to this feature. So if you do finish recording, hit save and forget to turn it off or it turns on in your pocket it'll shut back off after a while.

Now, other then just one good feature the microphone is surprisingly good. It does catch a lot so if using in lessons it should pick up your instructor even at the middle of the class depending on the room. I also do like that it comes with a 48 gig card. With just voice data that will take a long time to fill up and honestly since it's just a microsd card holding all the data you can just buy a bigger card if you so happen to get this one full. The card even comes out easily.

As for playback, this device is actually decent if not a bit loud. You'll hear every bit of what you were trying to record and of course the background noise.

For the negatives. There will be white noise in your background but if you're going for a voice recorder at this price I feel it's sort of expected. This also can be remedied a bit with even free audio software and a few minutes of your time if you're willing to edit. In short, if you want 100% clear audio with none of that static noise in the background, this may not be for you. If you just need something to note things down, or use for lectures then this is fine.

In short, for 30 dollars this is a great voice recorder. And I havn't even scratched the surface with the features it has so it feels like a steal to have.

title: Oh BlueParrott
text:
I've used the BlueParrott B260-xt & xts since 2009 or so. I'm a trucker and I fell in love with the B250 because it was the 1st headset I wore where I could very clearly hear all phone calls as if I were on a landline phone. No matter how loud the truck was (for those who know, think PTO on and on high or check the engine with the RPMs high) I could hear the person on the other end with no problems and vice versa.

Now enter the B450-xt....
The earpiece is amazing, you can wear it all day long with no problems. The problem is that it's entirely too quiet. If you have the volume maxed out, the loudest your environment can be is that of the inside of a passenger car with the windows up, air on low, radio off, driving 50MPH. Anything more than that and you'll struggle to hear the person in the other end. Add to this, the fact that your mic volume is also low, so they'll struggle to hear you at times even when their sitting in a quiet house.

For truckers or anyone who works in loud environments, I cannot ever recommend this headset. Maybe it has something to do with Jabra buying out Vxi BlueParrott, I can't answer that, but Jabra has never been trucker friendly.

I will give the B450 credit where it is due....
The earpiece sits over the ear and is extremely comfortable.
The cushioning on the head strap is very comfortable as well.
The battery life is beyond amazing. Charged it to full and after almost a week it's still over 50%. I use my headset to talk about 5 hours per day, 5 days a week.

The bad....
The mic volume is too quiet and people can't hear you as well as other headsets.
The speaker volume is way too quiet to use in noisy settings.
The mic boom is rather short and only reaches the outside corner of your mouth. Which likely leads to you sounding more quiet to the people on the other end of the line.
It's very expensive for a device that is not honestly fully trucker friendly.

title: Good sounding earbuds
text:
I like these earbuds.
I like the fact that you can see the battery levels on each earbud to determine their battery levels and that you can see the percentage of the battery for the charging case separately!
The case can charge the earbuds up to 4 times (if fully charged).
It doesn't take long for the earbuds or case to charge. They were almost fully charged upon receipt and I haven't let the case go below 80% before charging it again.
The case is small and compact - not bulky in any way. I carry a medium/large sized bag at any given time and it would get lost inside it!
The sound quality is crazy for it being the price that they are. I'm pleasantly surprised with that. No static, very clear. I use them on phone calls/zoom from time to time and haven't heard any complaints which is weird because with my JBL headphones I get feedback from people that they can't hear me or it sounds very low on my end. Weird!
I do have two gripes with these earphones.
First, while it's not a huge issue, it's kind of annoying. How the earbuds are placed in the case is just odd to me. I'm used to most earbuds being placed with the long portion (where the connectors are that enables it to charge inside the case) inserting into the outermost part of the case with the part that goes into your ear toward the middle part of the case. Oftentimes I find myself inserting the earbuds in the wrong way once I'm done with them when they do NOT go into the case that way!
Second issue is that the sensors that allow you to change songs/end calls/answer calls/pause music just SUCKS. I hate to say it like that, however, it's true. The sensor should've been placed in a better location (like on the side of the earbud instead where it is placed (on the front of the earbud).
Overall, it's a pretty decent set of earbuds - I plan on using these as a back up. Besides the sensor not being placed in a better location and working about 50% of the time, these are good earbuds for the price.

title: Worked great to cool M2 NVMe enclosure
text:
Pros:
• Worked perfectly for cooling an M.2 NVMe drive enclosure
• Thermal tape adheres well and appears to have good thermal transfer

Cons:
• Fins could be a bit thicker, and not have slits to increase surface area

I am using this heatsink on the surface of an ACASIS TBU401E Thunderbolt M.2 NVMe external drive enclosure. This enclosure has a SK Hynix P41 NVMe SSD in it that gets quite warm. The ACASIS drive enclosure is generally excellent other than its thermal performance. It was getting rather hot with the high performance P41 SSD and was concerned with thermal throttling and degraded lifetime of the drive.

This heatsink has lowered the temperature considerably. I should have taken before and after temperatures, but I didn’t. It does feel considerably cooler now though. The heatsink is warm and so is the rest of the drive. This indicates the heatsink is doing exactly what was hoped for; it is efficiently removing heat. The thermal tape is working well transferring heat from the bottom cover to the heat sink, and physically retaining the heatsink as well.

The ACASIS drive enclosure has a thermal pad between the M.2 SSD and the bottom cover. This transfers heat from the drive to this cover modestly well, but that cover isn’t large and there is relatively poor thermal transfer from the cover to the rest of the enclosure housing. The result is that only the cover serves to remove heat from the drive. Adding this heat sink to the cover substantially increases the thermal mass and surface area.

The size of the heatsink matches the size of the SSD reasonably well, and fits easily and neatly on the cover of the enclosure. Overall, it is a good fit. I could have used a few more millimeters on each side and height, but this works well and looks relatively neat. This may reduce the portability of the drive, but for my application it is being used in a fixed location so not an issue.

This works very well with this M.2 drive enclosure, and will likely work well for other similar external M.2 NVMe external drive enclosures.

title: Awesome Thunderbolt Hub with a huge power supply
text:
Wow, thats a big power supply! But it does provide 60Watts of charging to your connected laptop.
I have been looking for a Thunderbolt hub for quite some time since I have added a TB card to my tower.
I was pretty concerned at first with this device as it provides 60 Watts of charging power to your connected laptop, Yet my TB card provides 90 Watts of power to connected devices. My concern was with both components pushing power towards each other, is something going to "spark", well short circuit. After a few emails with the seller, they confirmed I would be fine. Still being wary, I connected first to another system to make sure nothing would happen. Everything worked on all systems tested as speeds were not impacted by adding this hub. I was able to achieve 20-28Gb/s out of the 40b/s theoretical max speed. Not to bad, actually very great. The max I was able o achieve was 2972 MB/s which is screaming fast and about the max speed on the external NVME drive I had attached. When testing speeds this fast, your bottlenecks become the speeds of cables, physical hardware, NVME drive, external enclosure. Any one component can reduce your overall speed at Thunderbolt 40Gb/s. Hooking up 2 external NVME drives to 2 separate ports on this hub and doing my file test consisting of 25 gigs of data I was able to achieve the following: Copying to both external drives at the same time about 700-800 MBytes/s. Copying from both drives at the same time to my computer . up to 1800MB/s for one drive, and around 1200MB/s from both drives. So there was a little drop, but you have both drives dumping a total of 75 gig onto my one internal drive which can only write so fast. The copying from one external to the other external resulted in a max of 500MB/s with a low of around 200MB/s. So performance was slower transferring port to port on the hub. I would have liked to seen a bit better port to port speed but there could be multiple reasons for that. Only thing they could have changed would be to switch the locations of the power cord and On/Off Button, and maybe some holes in the bottom for mounting, Overall this is a great Thunderbolt Hub and works perfectly for my needs and performs very very good

title: Inaccurate on multiple functions; terrible battery life
text:
Okay, I gave this three weeks to win me over. Not impressed. I’ll give a rundown by function:

The step counter is terribly inaccurate. Usually it overestimates (by a lot), but at least once it underestimated. In my pictures, the pedometer I’m comparing it to is one I know is accurate, that I wear on my ankle at all times.

Blood pressure measurements are way off, and not in a consistent or predictable way.

It does receive text messages, but doesn’t make use of its huge screen to display them. The font is tiny—smaller than the font I have on a watch with a much smaller screen.

The battery barely lasts 2 days. 3 if you’re lucky. The first time it actually lasted only 1 day, until I changed some settings (made it dimmer, told it not to check my heart rate as frequently, told it to leave the screen on for shorter lengths of time). It doesn’t give you any warning that the battery is low, but turns off vibration mode, so any alarms you have set won’t do you any good. Then—unless you frequently check the battery specifically—one time you’ll look down and not be able to get the screen to turn on.

The charger itself is nice. It has a strong magnet, so it attaches easily and doesn’t get knocked loose.

The sleep tracker doesn’t match what other watches get, though I can’t be sure which one is right (as far as deep sleep goes). This watch always gave smaller amounts of deep sleep.

Scrolling is difficult enough to make the preset timers pretty useless, unless you only need one of them. Also, the lowest time it has is 20 minutes. I often need 5 minutes, or 1 minute.

Its shape, size, and the location of the buttons make it uncomfortable to wear, as the buttons dig into the back of your hand. It’s a little more comfortable if you wear it on your right wrist. Since most people wear watches on their left, this is a poor design.

title: Works great on the 2023 Subaru Crosstrek
text:
We had been using a standard USB-A cable to connect our iPhone to the vehicle so we could use Apple Car Play. It was a pain to deal with the excess cable. Also, when it was connected via USB-A, Apply Car play would often disconnect when we drove on bumpy roads. I think this was due to the weight of the excess cord and using the phone, each pulling on the cable while it was connected to the car. Could we use a shorter cord? Absolutely, but we didn't want to deal with multiple cords. Since switching over to wireless and using this wireless adapter, we have had no issues with Apple Car Play disconnecting.

We read review after review and were worried about the quality. We decided to try this CarPlay Wireless
Adapter and we have to say we have had great results with it. We use it with an iPhone 14 connected to a 2023 Subaru Crosstrek.

We use it mostly for the Apple Car play navigation feature. We primarily use Waze and Google Maps as our navigation apps. Both work exceptionally well. We also listen to podcasts and music. Both work great. We have not noticed any issue with a longer-than-expected wait period between songs. The fact that it is wireless also took care of our issue with what to do with the excess cable.

If we were to pick one negative comment about this adapter we wish it was a plug-it-in and forget-about-it type product. Our family has both Apple and Android users. You cannot leave this wireless adapter plugged into the car if you wish to connect an Android phone to the car at the same time. This adapter overrides any Android connection function. When we want to connect the Android phone to the car we need to unplug this adapter. Once the adapter is disconnected only then are we able to connect the Android phone to the car. You can leave it connected if you wish to connect different iPhones. It's a minor inconvenience but nothing that would change our minds about our purchase.

We have only had this for a short time so we gave a rating of four (4) since we have no idea if this adapter will last or not. However, if it performs as well as it has been we would not hesitate to give it a rating of five (5).

title: Decent enough mp3 player
text:
This little device delivers in some ways, but is lacking a bit in others. It is small and lightweight, thought it seems to be pretty sturdy and not too flimsy, so I’m hoping it will last a while. The instructions included are kind of minimal, so you need to have a basic knowledge of how to upload music from a computer. I simply slapped some mp3 files into the folder, so it was definitely easy enough. At first I didn’t think they came with headphones, but they were in the bottom of the box so I’m glad I checked. They are earbud style headphones that actually fit pretty good in my son’s ears. The sound isn’t exactly high quality, but for what you’re paying for, it’s decent enough. My son knows he’s not allowed to listen to this above a volume 10 as it does get quite loud, but I told him I prefer he keeps it at an 8. He uses this mainly for his workouts. He likes to run on the elliptical and usually uses his tablet for music. He is too young for a phone, so this was a great alternative for him.
The player comes with other options such as audio recording, which can be handy, or photos. Honestly, most of the menu seems quite pointless to me. And when you click between menus, what you think you should be pressing by intuition ends up being the wrong thing, so I find myself backing out of to the menu by accident quite often. This is probably the only real frustrating thing.
For what it is, it works just fine at this time. It is definitely not what you’d expect from a high end mp3 player, but I think it is great for kids or just someone looking for a cheap music player. Oh and be aware, it doesn’t play on any internal speaker or through Bluetooth, so you have to use an output source connected through the auxiliary jack. The radio also works surprisingly well and it’s nice to be able to preset my son’s favorite stations. I will also say, the device came fully charged and he’s been wearing them almost daily for a week and it still shows as full. I didn’t have high hopes for this mp3 player, but I am more than pleasantly surprised.

title: It should be called a balance maintainer and only used on previously-balanced packs.
text:
So if you have a string of eight cells and you're buying a balancer, the expectation is every cell in the pack will be at a very similar voltage than the rest of the cells in the pack. That's not what this does. In fact, the first cell relative to the second cell could be 0.1 volts lower and the second cell relative to the third cell could be 0.1v lower and so on all the way to the last cell. A pack that reads 2.79,2.88,2.97,3.06,3.15,3.24,3.33,3.42 won't trigger this balancer to even turn on! This balancer would work okay on a well-balanced pack to maintain it, but it absolutely will not balance a very out of balance pack. I will be returning it.

Update: after extensive experimentation and reading the data sheet for the IC that controls the voltage threshold for starting and stopping balancing, it became clear to me that this IC was developed and optimized for lithium ion, not lithium iron phosphate. As such, the triggering mechanism works better at slightly elevated voltages. Setting my BMS to terminate charge when the first cell hits 3.8 volts did two things. 1. It caused larger voltage differentials in my 8s pack. 2. It caused the IC in this balancer to trigger reliably at the end of charge and start balancing. The result is much more aggressive balancing and better performance overall. So, if you want this to work, try slightly overcharging your lithium iron phosphate cells to 3.8v for aggressive balancing then set your cell cut off back down to 3.60 volts after the pack is balanced for longevity.

I don't see this as a terrible thing, considering the absolute Max voltage on lithium iron phosphate is 4.2 volts and the cell only stays at 3.8 volts for perhaps one to two minutes at the end of charge.

I am adjusting my rating and considering keeping this. The chip manufacturer should consider altering the detection algorithm and threshold so it works better for lithium iron phosphate at the lower cell voltages. Also worth mentioning, this chip supports two amps. I don't know why they didn't enable it. Perhaps heat dissipation or reliability.

title: Solid, High Speed Splitter with Power Adapter!
text:
FIDECO 7-Port USB Hub, USB 3.2 Gen 1 Data Hub with Independent On/Off Switch

First I am going to start off and say, this is my favorite USB splitter to date! The product comes in a sturdy, weighted aluminum case. This weight allows it to sit neatly on your desk without flipping over if you bump a cable. The only thing that could make this case better is a rubber grip on the bottom to prevent it from sliding. The bottom surface is smooth, so it can easily slide with a finger push.

One great feature about this product is it comes with its own power adapter. I have gotten splitters that have a jack to connect to a power adapter, but they never actually came with one. I am very happy this is included in the package.

This was very easy to connect to my computer. I plugged it into the USB-C port on the front of my desktop and it was ready to go right away.

To test its functionality, I plugged in 6 USB thumb-drives and a set of desktop speakers. Like expected, each of the drives showed up on my computer and were fully functional. On top of the thumb drives being plugged in, I was playing music with the speakers. This handy device is also providing the power for them.

I really like the individual on/off buttons for each USB slot. Because I like to use these to power my speakers, I use the push button to turn off the speakers. That way the volume level is always set on my speakers and I just turn the power off to it.

One thing I have to note that you as the consumer MUST know about. I plugged the power adapter into the splitter, and then plugged my speakers into one of the ports. The speaker immediately responded by playing a buzzing sound. I then connected the USB-C cable to my computer and the buzzing almost went away and you can only hear it when there is nothing playing. To me, this indicates that there is possibly noise on the internal buck converter or maybe some grounding issues. I do not believe this will have an effect on your devices, but it does affect speakers when they are plugged into this product.

Overall, I really like this product and recommend it.

title: Complete background kit at a reasonable price.
text:
This is a nice background stand kit that comes complete with two stands, a sectional crossbar, 6-spring clips, two sandbags and a convenient carry case that can hold everything except the sandbags when they're filled with sand.

The medium-duty stands work fine for holding up a background and you can raise them as high as a little over 7'.

Because the cross bar contains individual sections, it can be configured to three different widths: 5', 7½', and 10' which is nice because sometimes when you go on location, there isn't room to set up a 10' wide background, especially when all you need is 7' or less for your backdrop.

The sandbags have a wide opening on the top which is very convenient for filling with sand, or water bottles, or rocks, etc.

Here's a sandbag tip if you want to fill them permanently with sand as opposed to filling them with rocks or water bottles when you get to your photo destination

Start by getting two Ziplock 1-gallon freezer bags and fill the bags up with as much sand as they will hold and still let you zipper them closed. You can then put the Ziplok bags into the sandbags and pull the drawstring closed. It makes for a much cleaner sandbag that is essentially double walled now and there is no chance of the sand ever leaking out of the bag through the seams or out of the top which doesn't close completely with that drawstring.

The sandbags are shown suspended from the lower sections of the light stands where the leg tightening knob is. To get them to work as shown, you will need to forcibly open the large metal O ring wide enough to get it around the lower pole section. Then you will have to bend it back perfectly into its original position - tight against the other side.

It takes quite a bit of fussing to get the two sections to mate up perfectly again but it's worth the time because you're going leave these rings on the stand permanently. Once you get the two sections to mate tightly together, secure the sections together with some gaffer tape. That is because the weight of the sandbags will have a tendency to separate the rings where the split is.

title: Pros and cons
text:
Pro: Nice bright vivid screen with great colors
Pro: pretty fair selection of faces
Pro: 24/7 customer service through the HuaWise app. Very fast response though the rep couldn't solve my issue.
Pro: a strange built-in blowdryer to dry the watch. How cool is that, right? But why is it necessary? Hmmm...
Pro: screen protector included

Con: I get a vibration about every 45 seconds telling me that I'm listening to music, though I can't control music from the watch. When I turn off the "other notifications" as suggested by customer service, I get nothing-not even texts. I don't use the text program that came with my phone, I use a much more robust program. It is included in the "other" notifications which don't work when I turn off the annoying music notification. Also included in "other notifications" is every app that I've chosen to receive silent notifications, like Next Door and news apps. It's all or nothing with this watch! With my other brand watch, the app gave me a list of all the apps on my phone in order to turn on or off notifications on the watch.

Con: I chose "enable phone" on the watch settings so I could control the music, and I got this message: "Please try again after pairing". The phone and watch are already paired, and I have received phone call notifications on the watch, as well as notifications from my music program, as already noted. I have tried to answer my phone from my watch, and it didn't work.

Con: When someone calls and I answer on my phone or earbuds, the watch keeps vibrating for quite a while after I answer.

Con: three times I tried to add favorite contacts. The watch showed that it was syncing, but then failed every time.

Con: When I tried to add favorite contacts, the search function didn't work, and the list to scroll through it not in any semblance of order, alphabetical or otherwise. It did finally work when I went to look at each contact on my phone and typed in their phone number on the app.

This watch/app was definitely NOT ready for rollout.
