title: An Extremely Durable, High Quality DisplayPort Cable
text:
This is a shockingly durable, rigid, high quality DisplayPort cable that will work great for whatever your needs may be. The cable is an adequately acceptable length that is able to easily reach from my wall mounted monitor all the way down to my Gaming PC that is sitting in a roller cart on the floor. The cable comes packaged using two velcro strap style cable organizers that you can remove and then use to organize the cables from your PC or elsewhere. The outer sleeve of the cable is a very durable, braided nylon that isn't loose at all and fits very snug against the cable itself. I tried scratching it and it was not able to tear up the nylon fibers which is good enough to me on that end. As far as the connectors go, it is a locking style DisplayPort cable, so if you prefer the ones that don't lock, then it may not be for you. The button to unlock the cable for removal is my only real complaint about the cable as the button sounds loose when you are setting it up for the first time, and you can't really feel it/notice when you press it in, so you can't always tell when the cable is ready to be removed or not. Aside from that, it does connect and lock easily, and it works well. The connectors also have a respectable amount of protective rubber that travels down the cable enough to where it should work incredibly well at preventing the connector ends from fraying, splitting, or snapping off from the rest of the cable.

From a performance point of view, the cable is easily able to deliver on everything it promises- up to 4K at least as I don't own any displays that are higher resolution than 4K to test. However, I was easily able to get the full 144Hz refresh rate out of my monitor, and there were no display issues, distortions, or intermittent disconnects like I was experiencing with my old cable. The cable just works. Additionally, the cable fully supports 10-bit color, and while this may be a placebo effect, I think my display actually looks more crisp and sharper than it did before.

Overall, I don't have any complaints about the cable other than what I previously mentioned about the locking tab button as the cable is extremely well made and works flawlessly for my needs. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a high quality DisplayPort cable.

title: Best Switch I've gotten, from the seller with the best customer service ever!
text:
Prior to buying this switch I've owned a handful of other switches.
My PC has had trouble with previous switches and disconnecting the USB (almost like the power saving mode turns on even when it's been disabled).
This switch does not have that problem. It also feels WAY more robust and sturdy.
I love the front facing number to let me know which computer is active at any time (vs LED's on the top of the switch that I may or may not be able to see).

The built in hot keys (which can be on mouse or keyboard) are really nice and allow you to mount the switch in a location that the button is not necessarily convenient to touch.

Be aware that default the switch has a hotkey of pressing right control twice to hotkey switch.
If you want to turn off the beep you hit rctrl rctrl b enter and the switch will stop beeping.
However... it's important to know that the command is really (and not listed in the instructions as)

Hotkey, Hotkey, [command button], enter.
So to stop the beeps if you did the command to switch the hotkey to scroll lock becomes:
scr lk, scr lk, b, enter.

I didn't know this and it was a cause for thinking my switch wasn't working.
Which brings me to the seller and their customer service!
Explaining the issue to the seller (and the lack of the instructions not mentioning it), I had just assumed my box was not registering the keyboard commands, and the seller I think wasn't understanding the hotkey switching worked but the keyboard commands weren't (not realizing I had switched the command to scroll lck.
so my ONLY critique would be to update the instructions a little to point out the commands are related to whatever your hotkey is currently set.

They pretty quickly responded to my questions and we were messaging through amazon.
The seller then said they would send me a new box because mine wasn't working.
They made a youtube video showing it working, they mailed it priority so it got here in two days.
Really the best customer service I ever had on amazon.

title: Disappointing product from CCA
text:
I’ve used cca iems for a long time and have fallen in love with how balanced and crisp their sound is. I use the CCA C10’s and they fit every need I have, expect one… Versatility.
I was stoaked to find out they had a new pair of truly wireless earbuds and I was confident that if they sounded remotely close to as good as their wired counterparts I would love them. Sadly that wasn’t the case.
These headphones are rough around the edges and you can tell they are still trying to figure things out. The way the headphones pair to eachother isn’t very smooth. There is a couple milliseconds of lag between the two ears. The right ear plays just slightly but noticeably louder.
The sound, is disappointing. It’s the sound you would expect from a pair of 20$ ear buds. Very lacking in the mid section and lacking depth and soundstage. The bass from the 10mm driver is fine and the armature driver designed to play the high end does a good job at playing the high end but that’s it. There should be at least one more driver to fill in the mids.
For any mainstream headphone at this price I wouldn’t be surprised with the sound being bad. But for this product to come from cca is surprising. When I first ordered a pair I was so let down with how they sounded that I thought that something was defective with the pair I had, so I sent them back and othered another pair. Sadly I was wrong and they’re was nothing abnormal or broken. That’s just how they sounded.
The one thing that I love about them is the comfort, extremely light and ergonomic. Designed to fit the shape of an actual ear instead of looking cool, and they do a great job of that. I can wear them for +8 hours and don’t experience any fatigue.
I have hope that cca will continue to improve them and smooth out the kinks. I think the concept they’re going for is phenomenal, and I know that CCA is capable of making an excellent sounding iem. This first attempt at a fully wireless design had the right concept, just poor execution.
I would wait for future models to come out before purchasing these.

title: Ideal for bedroom use
text:
I was in the market for a 32 inch television for my bedroom and discovered that TCL had two full HD tvs, a Roku and a google tv set. As I already had a Roku Streambar, which I was going to continue to use as a soundbar, It made sense to go for the Google TV. Adding weight to the decision, the Google set comes with an ethernet port and the Roku doesn't.

How does the TCL 32S356 perform?
Picture - The 32S356 comes with a full HD panel and the picture is sharp, clear and bright, I am very pleased with it. The tv is best viewed straight on as the colors are less bright at an angle. The tv also picked up when accessing an HDR10 source and informs you that it is running HDR.
Digital Tuner - Although this carries less weight on my part as I am using the tv for streaming, the digital tuner appears to be excellent. It picked up all the major channels and more subchannels than I was aware existed.
Streaming - I'm familiar with the Google TV service, my downstairs television has a Chromecast with Google TV streaming device. I knew that the TV would access every streaming channel I use. I find the TCL tv to be very responsive. Initial setup takes a while as you will have to download the current software and download any apps that you're installing. Once set up, the tv starts quickly and apps load very quickly.
Sound - As I had mentioned at the top, I was planning to use the Roku Streambar as a sound bar. Using the HDMI ARC port, setup was painless. The TV immediately sensed that it was connected to the Streambar. I then disabled the soundbar to try the internal speakers. It's here that the tv falls short. That said, the internal speakers are adequate, with sufficient volume and clear audio. The frequency response is where the speakers fall short, with no bottom end, the speakers sound a bit tinny. Without a soundbar, the tv would still be adequate for viewing, but the tv really benefits from an external soundbar.

Overall, I am very pleased with my TCL television. It does everything well and is the perfect fit for a bedroom.

title: Great Sound Bar for the price.  Great rear speaker flexibility.
text:
This is a great sound bar! The flexibility of the removable rear speakers helps this stand out from the rest of the Dolby Atmos sound bars out there. In addition, you can calibrate it to your room. This helps customize it to your room and helps make the sound even better

Sound - It is awesome. My home theater sounds like it is surrounded with speakers. The bass is powerful, and even at the default of 3 setting can be overwhelming at times. I don't know how it could be better. The rear speakers sound solid and can be charged via USBC cables or plugged in to the bar to charge. This offers great flexibility since you don't need to have an outlet near each one.

Connectivity - No issues whatsoever with the bluetooth connectivity. I love the way it powers on with the TV or streaming device, and can control the volume with any remote. All speakers, including the bass, connect via bluetooth. No need for wires.

JBL App - Very easy to use and helps make set up a breeze. You will be using this bar within minutes of installing. It also helps with any updates that are needed. You will probably have one when you first connect.

Remote Control - Kind of basic, but the truth is you don't really need it much. The App has a virtual remote as well.

Installation - Very easy and all of the brackets you need are included if you are mounting it. I had it attached to the wall within minutes. The JBL app makes the other parts of the installation a breeze.

Look - I think it looks great and makes for a clean and expensive look. No cloth covers over any of the speakers, which in my opinion look cheap and can get dirty or rip.

Overall - You will not be disappointed with this purchase. The JBL Bar 1300 or 9.1 are great as well. The downside on the 9.1 is no App connectivity. It is cheaper than this one, but you give up some of the better sound due the additional speakers. The 1300 is a bit of an upgrade to this one, but there is a cost for the upgrade.

Great sound bar for the price range Better than the others in this price range.

title: Good budget dash cam, but cable is too short for my vehicle
text:
This is a good budget dashcam that is pretty easy to use and install. Unfortunately for myself, the power cable (uses your cigarette lighter) isn't long enough for my vehicle. Measuring out the cable, it came in around 11'2". For most people, that is probably adequate in length. However, the car I am installing in only has the cigarette lighter power on the back of the console, and the cable length isn't long enough to be able to run it and hide it. That's why I'm knocking one star off of the review.

The app itself is pretty easy to use. You simply connect to the camera via WiFi on your phone, and you have access to live video, ability to change the resolution, and how long the video loop is (1, 2, or 3 minutes).

It comes with a sticker you place on your windshield that you can then mount the camera to. That way, you aren't attaching it directly to your windshield, so you avoid getting adhesive mess on your windshield.

On the top of the camera is an "open and close" option (a pic is included of it). That allows you to slide off the plastic piece that has the adhesive that sticks to the windshield. That's a neat feature in case you want to remove the camera and place the camera in another vehicle - however, that would require an additional plastic piece with the adhesive (extra adhesive pad is included, but not the plastic piece that would be needed to mount in another vehicle) and an additional power cable for it.

In testing the video, when viewing live, it's not as clear as when going and looking at the recordings themselves. The audio with the video picks up sounds really well. There is an option to turn off the audio in case you don't want it recording that.

In order to use the parking feature, you'll have to purchase an additional wiring kit to hook it up directly to your fuse box. So, no parking feature with what is included in the package.

Overall, good budget dash cam. I do recommend checking the length of cable that you'd need to make sure you can install it to where the cable is hidden. And, that length of the cable is the only reason I'm knocking one star off of it.

title: Great sounding earbuds to me
text: This was my second purchase of these buds because when on sale they beat out every other set that I have tried for volume/headroom and sound quality. The app is basic but these just sound great for a bluetooth set of earbuds imho. I bought a set last year and really like their volume and sound quality abilities. I never use any noise cancellation etc so that never matters to me only sound quality and volume/headroom level abilities. The first set are very reliable as far as quickly connecting to my phone and sound great. I wanted a second set for a new tablet that has low bluetooth volume with the earbuds and headphones that I tried with it and I prefer to use 1 set of buds or headphones per device just to keep things easy. I ordered this new set when it went on sale and connected them then did the update etc and noticed that the left bud was at 20% after around 15 minutes of use while the right bud was at 97%. I tried resetting them every different way that I could find on the Klipsch website but nothing fixed the problem. I contacted Nick from Klipsch support and he was very helpful and to keep this as short as possible ended up sending me a brand new left bud without asking me to return the one that I had. That was refreshing and it came in a few days so I connected it and it did the same thing. What are the odds of that? I contacted Nick again and again he was very helpful and sent me a brand new set including the box, case, cable etc. brand new, never opened. He said for me to try these and make sure that I had a fully functional set of earbuds then send back the original buds, case, box etc with a shipping label that Klipsch paid for. The new set came in a few days and to my delight works great!. I boxed up the defective left buds, the functional right bud, case etc. and shipped it back to Klipsch in Arkansas. When the first bud did not function properly I was dreading having to deal with customer service which I assumed would consist of someone in another country who could not comprehend what I was saying and vice versa, being ignored, put on hold for hours etc. but this experience was the exact opposite of that and I could not be happier with the result. Thanks again Nick, Debbie and Angela at Klipsch!

title: Great sound and very comfortable headphones
text:
I have a larger head and as you can see from the pictures of the comparison with my previous Bluetooth headphones, these are ½ inch wider so they are much more comfortable to wear over an extended period.

I liked that I was able to perform a firmware update on these using the app on my android phone.

I like that the Active Noise Cancelling works so well. (I find it odd that the bass gets richer with the ACN on)

I think the Audiodo personalization is very cool. (I wish it was available for PC)

For my PC, I looked in “Microsoft Store” and found a free utility called “FxSound” that is a “volume booster, bass booster, better sound quality, or an easy-to-use Windows EQ.” The music from my Amazon Music app, version 9.4.2.2420, is quite a bit richer with this on (using the “Music” preset). Bluetooth can be a little tricky so the other thing I like about “FxSound” is that it pops up any change to your sound output, so you know when these are connected correctly.

Besides my PC, I use these with my big screen TV using the Bluetooth built in to my “Fire TV Stick 4K Max”.

To switch back and forth successfully, I find that if I disable Bluetooth on my PC, have these powered off, get in to my home screen for my Fire TV, then turn these on, after a short delay it pops up that they are connected. When I want to go back to the PC, I send my Fire Stick to “Sleep”, turn off the headphones, enable Bluetooth again, click “Connect” beside the “PSB M4U 8 MKII 785R 5D70”, and while it is searching, turn on the headphones and after a short delay it says “Connected voice, music” (replacing the word Paired) and FxSound pops up on the lower right of the screen saying: “Output: Headphones (PSB M4U 8 MKII 785R 5D70)”.

title: Sturdy protection for the Kindle Scribe
text:
First part is on me, I saw "leather" and I didn't see "PU leather" not that I would know what "PU leather" anyhow. Now I know; the PU stands for polyurethane - or plastic to us non-chemists. I don't mind that it's not genuine leather, I feel like it may hold up even better than some leather I've seen. The only downfall is when I first got it, I had to air it outside for a day because it did have a strong odor to it, but it did dissipate.

If you're here, then you probably have a Kindle Scribe - don't you love it!? Unfortunately, I do feel as if one drop and it would be borked forever so a case is important to me for this device. As soon as I aired it out, I found my Scribe to fit very snugly in place - it's not going anywhere or falling out. That being said, it goes Kindle > this plastic > ground if you drop it. I'm not sure if it would protect from a drop, but definitely would from scratches on the screen, maybe even save the screen from a direct hit.

The outside plastic cover has a crosshatching pattern probably meant to replicate leather, good lighting, it looks kind of plastic. However, it does look like it is going to be easy to keep clean. The inside of the cover is a nice soft felt that rests against the glass screen. I really like the auto-wake when you open the lid and sleep when you close as I'm not the biggest fan of the side button that does the same. All in all it seems very durable and looks like it will last a very long time.

The plastic channel that holds the pen allows for the magnet to hold the pen in place well, however, there's only a small hole on the backside of this channel where you're supposed to "easily" pop the pen out. I have fat fingers so it's not that easy. I have found that I can get my fingertip in and roll the pen onto the screen with my thumb in one swoop. Maybe that's how it's supposed to work, but I'm not sure, I couldn't find any instructions.

title: They won’t stay in my ears
text:
On the surface, these seem like good earbuds. The build quality is nice enough- all the materials feel high quality and everything functions as advertised. Pairing with any device is easy and instantaneous, and it functions flawlessly with everything I have tried.

Sound quality is pretty good, not great and not terrible. There is a barebones app that gives you some basic EQ functions, and it has a game mode where it allegedly reduces latency (in exchange for what, they don’t say) but I can’t tell a difference from the regular mode.

Phone call quality is sub par. For some reason I have a lot of connection issues while trying to make a call, the audio quality is poor and the microphones are pretty weak.

So here’s the thing- no matter what I do, these simply won’t stay in my ears! If I put them in and even move a little, they fall right out, never mind coughing or trying to talk to someone on the phone. I genuinely don’t understand how these are expected to stay in place, they have no rubber canal inserts or clips or anything. I think the biggest culprit is that they have a satin finish, which is a lot more slippery. I’ve had better experiences with earbuds that have a glossy finish.

And when I try to adjust them, it activates one of the touch controls, so I’m always inadvertently skipping songs or changing something else. The touch controls themselves are ok, but when you constantly have to adjust the earbuds every five seconds to prevent them from falling out, the touch controls are a huge problem.

I think the biggest thing is that at $50, you’re in the same price range as earbuds from brands like JBL, JVC, Altec Lansing, Skull Candy etc, and within striking distance of earbuds from Sony, Beats, Belkin, Apple, and other recognizable brands that will deliver a better experience.

My personal advice would be to put this money towards another product, especially something from a more recognizable brand with better localization for the USA. You can definitely do better for the same price, and you can do significantly better if you spend another $20-30.

title: Ever wanted your own microscope?
text:
[[VIDEOID:fca47c7219df8e70095b7893b0b97edc]] Okay, so this isn't "laboratory grade" by any stretch, but for personal use and curiosity / exploration it's really great! I've been using it via USB on my PC mostly. It's accessible via WiFi and their app, but I really don't want a different app on my phone for every Wifi device that wants me to control with wifi =.=

Via USB it connected right to the Windows Camera app just like any plug and play webcam. The zoom is manually controlled by turning the zoom ring on the scope. It will wobble a lot when doing this, even carefully, but the included base and arm are actually fairly decent and have always gone back to where I was focusing if I displaced it a tad while adjusting it.
While I don't personally have much need/want (right now) for the cordless/wifi option, the fact it's there would be quite handy for folks trying to look at things in nature or checking for specific stuffs (so technical, I know...). The phone app based on the Play page seems similar to the Wifi Depstech endoscope I have. Boot up the app, change the Wifi your phone's using to the one being broadcast by the scope to see a feed and take videos or photos. Might be able to adjust zoom via the app, but I don't know for sure.
Pics and Vid attached... I need to clean my desk mat I guess haha

This is 100% NOT a toy - a good thing here. I mean, I love playing with it... but I wouldn't just hand this to a younger kid and expect to get it back in working order. It is digital enhancement (FINALLY that sci-fi trope of "enhance... enhance..." comes to life!) for better or worse. Still seems like a good resolution at fully zoomed in, but will still it the same walls cameras might for zooming when digital v. lenses.

I really did expect MUCH lower quality for $40. Thankfully it's fairly decent quality construction, casing, materials, and the digital zoom is nice. It'd be kinda nice to have some indication of what zoom% you're at.

title: WYZE App not working in Android 13
text:
READ THIS review and you'll see why I rate this camera 1 star.
Since WYZE created their first cam, I purchased 5 and liked them UNTIL several things happened:
1. Frequent app service outages which prevented viewing.
2. Now I am running latest Android 13 on a Pixel phone and the WYZE app won't even open. Did several searches for solution and found this (see my screen capture).
3. Despite using the protective shells/housings to use V1 and V2 cams outdoors, they didn’t last.
4. Purchased a V3 cam and by then WYZE had become a huge success. Good for WYZE but seemed to slow down their server(s) so viewing live images took longer.
5. Then the security breach exposed millions of users so hackers can see video feeds. Took 3 YEARS for WYZE to fix that known problem. Thus, I removed my remaining 3 working Wyze cams from service in 2022.
Decided to give WYZE a 2nd chance in 2023 and purchased this Pan V3. Here is why I will NOT use it for my home:
1. Design of the mounting bracket would force me to drill more/new holes in exterior wall.
2. Design of the plug (L shaped end) would force me to drill a wider diameter hole through an exterior wall.
3. Camera lacks internal rechargeable battery. My current DCT cameras can record 24/7.
4. Zoom range on my DCT and Hawkray cameras is better. I also tested Dzees which is virtually same as these 2.
See my photo comparing them.
5. Less motion detection “false alarms” with DCT and Hawkray cameras.
6. MOST IMPORTANTLY, VicoHome app for DCT and Hawkray cameras has NEVER had outage or security breach so I am sticking with these trusty cams for exterior security.
As I said above, can't even get the WYZE app to open on latest Android so unopened Cam Pan V3 is being returned to Amazon.
Hope this review helps someone so I’ll know I didn’t waste my time writing it.

title: Compatible with wide range of devices
text: I ordered this keyboard case for my iPad Air 11”.  The iPad slips into the cover’s rubber protective enclosure.  When my iPad is in place, there are some gaps where the rubber doesn’t completely enclose the ipad (ill fitting). Nevertheless, it seems to hold it in place firmly enough that it isn’t going to slip out.  They keyboard itself is removable and thin.  It attaches to the case magnetically with a firm grip.  The keyboard layout is pretty standard, but has some nice features like function keys that perform IOS functions like copy and paste, as well as audio controls: stop/play, forward/back, vol up and down.  It also has an escape key to exit an app, and a delete key that deletes characters forward (many keyboards only have a backspace key.  It also has arrow keys, but no touchpad for navigating around the document. The keyboard has a power switch to save battery life and a caps lock indicator, which is handy to know why your passwords aren’t working.  The keys are easy to type on, but some of the keys are a little finicky and don’t always register.  The keys are also a bit too noisy-the clacking sound would be distracting if taking notes in a meeting, for instance.  The keys are labeled with decals that look like they could peel or wear off over time.  Since the keyboard is removable, you can just use the case by itself, or take the keyboard along inside the case - it’s thin enough.  One issue is that the location to put the keyboard for closing the case isn’t the place where it needs to be to tilt up the screen and type, so you have to reposition the keyboard when you are ready to work, and move it again when you are ready to pack up.  That’s a little inconvenient.  Finally, there’s a storage spot for a stylus or Apple Pencil in the case, but it doesn’t allow the Apple Pencil 2 to recharge from the iPad when they are both in the case.  Overall, this is likely an adequate keyboard case solution for many folks.  I find some of the shortcomings listed here to be annoying and the case hasn’t yet won me over as a fan.

title: Jicjocy Wireless Earbuds Bluetooth Active Noise Cancelling Earbuds Good value Decent Sound.
text:
The Jicjocy Wireless Earbuds are a great option for those looking for a good value Bluetooth earbuds with active noise cancelling capabilities.

What is Jicjocy Wireless Earbuds?
The Jicjocy Wireless Earbuds are a set of Bluetooth earbuds that connect to your device wirelessly and allow you to listen to music, take calls, and more. They feature active noise cancelling technology that helps to reduce ambient noise for an immersive listening experience.

How does it work?
The earbuds connect to your device via Bluetooth and can be controlled using the touch controls on the earbuds themselves. The active noise cancelling works by using microphones on the earbuds to pick up ambient noise and then generating sound waves that cancel it out.

What's to like?
Fit and finish is nice, making them feel comfortable in your ears and stays in ear properly.
Sound quality is quite decent and it is good for listening to music and taking calls.
They fit comfortably and stay securely in your ears.

What's not to like?

Slight lag when watching videos, it can be frustrating if it happens when you want to enjoy something with no distraction.

Active noise cancelling, it can sometimes amplify or create unwanted rumbling every now and then due to how it works. They can be exhausting with ANC on, as you can't hear it, but your ear drums will feel it.

The touch control is different on each side of the ear piece, so if you lose one you might not be able to activate certain features.

The battery life during use could be a bit longer, at least you can charge one and still keeping use one on long chats.

Conclusion: I would give the Jicjocy Wireless Earbuds 4 stars. They offer a great value for their price and decent sound quality, but there are a few downsides, such as the slight lag when watching videos and the active noise cancelling can be a bit hit or miss. Despite these drawbacks, they are still a solid choice for anyone looking for a pair of wireless earbuds with active noise cancelling capabilities.

title: Not the best voice recorder out there...
text:
The included waveforms of the TenmaTec (3rd track in each picture) to compare against other competing recorders and to give you an idea of how it sounds.

Features:
Choice of Mp3 or wave file type
Bitrate are: 32kbps, 64kbps ,128kbps ,192kbps
It has a Voice Operated Recording (VOR mode) that can record when it detects sound.
There is also an "auto-record" feature that allows you to set a start time to begin recording, though I'm not sure why that's important.
It has a "monitor" feature where you can monitor the sound coming in from the input.
It has the capability to utilize better mics because it has a line-in, external mic.

This recorder is one of the slowest reaction times that I've experienced. Turning on the unit takes roughly 3 seconds to get to the home screen. Then once you hit the Record button, it takes 9 seconds before it starts to record. Subsequent recording after bootup and after the first recording drops down to 3 seconds.

The menus are hard to use because the controls are the up/down buttons on the right side, the play button is "OK", and the stop button is "BACK". The screen is not the best quality as the contrast of the screen is lacking, and the actual graphics used in the program are of lower quality. It's pretty ugly, honestly, compared to some of the other crisp OLED screens I've seen.

I like how the recorder feels in my hand, as it feels nice and solid. It is not a touch screen, so you are at the mercy of the annoying button assignments. I also constantly have to turn the unit around to find the on/off switch, as both sides of the recorder have the same three buttons and I can never remember which side it is on.

If you're looking for a quick and intuitive way to record meetings or your classes, this recorder is not for you. It is just too slow, and awkward, and the non-touchscreen is just plain ugly. I had high hopes when I began to review this recorder, but alas, it just was not meant to be.

title: Not really for music, but very comfortable.
text:
The Trucker Bluetooth Headset is a bit of a surprise. When I ordered it, I wasn't entirely sure what to expect. So, let me walk through what I discovered.

First, the Trucker headset is very comfortable to wear, even for an extended period. I have a big head, but the headband fits me well and is comfortable. The clamping pressure seems just right it is strong enough to keep the headset on your head, yet the sampling pressure isn't so great that it becomes uncomfortable. The ear pads are also very soft and comfortable. However, note that the ear pads do not cover your entire ear. That means two things. First, it is easy for this headset to fit your head. Second, they do not isolate you from your surroundings. For gamers, music listeners, or people working in a crowded office, these are not for you. However, if you say work from home and you want to maintain awareness of what is happening around you, these would work well.

This headset uses a current Bluetooth standard. That means they are easy to connect to your phone or computer. Moreover, I've never had them disconnect when I was using them. Very expensive earbuds and headsets can't say this.

The final thing that impresses me about this headset is that the controls are easy to reach and intuitively placed. For example, the volume controls are two buttons, one is placed on the earpiece in front of the headband mounting, and the other is placed on the earpiece behind the headband mounting. It is doubtful that you are going to engage the wrong control on this headset. Again, not all expensive headsets have all of their controls so carefully placed and easy to use.

These headbands are almost entirely plastic, so they are probably not the best choice for children or folks who can be rough on their hardware.

The sound quality of this headset is a bit disappointing for the price. Don't get me wrong, if you intend to use these for online conferences, classes, TV listening, or phone conversations, this headset will handle all those situations well. But they are not for music. I know several earbuds and headsets that sound much better at a lower price. I use them for teaching classes online all day, and I like them.

title: Solid when they work BUT..
text:
I got these for Christmas 2022 and have been using them since. The sound is above average to great - but you're used to that if you have any Bose products. I appreciate there are 2 removable attachments for each ear to configure to get a perfect fit. I live in a busy city so I don't use the noise cancelling very much (to be aware of my surroundings) but I have used the feature on flights and it's great.

OK, we're done with the positives.

From day 1 I've had connectivity issues with these. I think since they were a Christmas present I overlooked the shortcomings but 4 months later I can safely say they completely dropped the ball here. It's to the point where I have a mental Klondike bar if I can get both buds to connect on first try. The audio quality will falter randomly but too often even though my phone is mere feet away - simply unacceptable for the Bose name.

I already had to send them in for repair as the audio on the left bud just gave out and after hours of painstaking troubleshooting and frustration I sent them in - to be fair to Bose the process was pretty seamless and I was only without the earbuds for 7-8 days.

The app is buggy garbage - it's completely useless in trying to regain connection. One is better off toggling Bluetooth in the phone settings and trying to reconnect there. The app doesn't tell you how much battery the case has left so I just have to remember to charge the case every so often (I believe there's a physical light function to tell you how much battery is left, but c'mon for a premium product they can do better.) Did I mention the app is garbage? The features that are available to you are also pretty buggy but the absolute worst part is that the app does work a lot better when you have good data connection (think 5 bars 5G or good wifi) which leads me to believe that the app is too busy scraping data off your phone to be actually useful to your BLUETOOTH headphones.

I hate to say it, but looks like I'll be buying airpods next time I'm in the market which honestly might be sooner than later if Bose doesn't release significant firmware/product updates to these.

title: Read this if you are having issues with Bluetooth 2 disconnecting
text:
I love this head unit. I bought it to replace the stock nav that came in my 2007 Hummer H3. It is exceptionally priced and has given my 16 year old truck more features than a brand new car.

The only issue I had was with Bluetooth 2. Whenever I paired my phone (to get internet), or my OBD II dongle to use the torque app, it kept disconnecting. Everything would work if I unpaired / repaired the device, but the moment I restarted the car (and thus the head unit) Bluetooth 2 would refuse to connect to my already paired devices. To get them to work again, I would have to unpair and re-pair them, which was super annoying.

I should also say that Bluetooth 1, which is used by the head unit for phone calls, worked fine. So I could make calls and stuff, but any extended functionality that you would get from Bluetooth 2 wouldn't work.

I finally got fed up, and went to Atoto's website. I registered my head unit and figured I'd try to read a detailed manual about it in case I missed something.

Then I found that they have firmware updates on their website. Super easy to download and install, and they keep a whole change log of what fixes each update implemented.

So I downloaded the most recent update for my head unit, installed it, and that fixed everything. That is the solution here. Updating the firmware from the Atoto website.

I figured it must be software related because if it was the hardware, Bluetooth 2 wouldn't work at all. But it does work, it just doesn't reconnect. With the software update, it does reconnect now and all is well.

I can finally use Bluetooth for internet (not a hotspot like I was doing), I can finally connect to my OBD II, and I can finally start on other projects I had put on hold because of the Bluetooth issue. I plan on installing Bluetooth controlled LED cabin lights and a dashcam with Bluetooth event viewing. All possible now that Bluetooth 2 is working.

So if you're stuck like I was, go to the Atoto website and download and install a firmware update. Then you'll be good to go.

title: Very versatile... especially for Android devices
text:
Didn't know what to expect. Didn't know what it could really do.

Shortly after this arrived at my doorstep, I plugged it in to my Samsung Galaxy mobile phone. The phone acknowledged the device. I inserted a USB thumb drive and was able to view its contents. Then next thing I did was hook up an HDMI cable from this device to my TV while it was still connected to my phone... then the magic really happened.

On the TV screen was the Samsung DEX display!

What does this mean? It means that using this device through my phone gives me the ability to treat my phone as a desktop-based computer. All I needed to do was connect a USB mouse and keyboard to the device's USB ports, and I'm using my phone like a desktop computer. What an amazing capability! I then connected an active ethernet cable to the RJ-45 port to test network capabilities. Although I don't think you need to do the following, I put my phone into Airplane Mode to shut off all WiFi and carrier data, hoping to be sure I was only relying on the ethernet connection for my network connectivity for testing purposes.

IT WORKED!

What's more, I plugged my phone charger into the USB-C port provided on the hub, and my phone started to charge. So now, with a few added components, like a portable keyboard/touchpad combo, an HDMI cable, and my phone charger (if desired), I can turn my phone into basically a Chromebook. This works great for on-the-go presentations with Google Office, etc., or just to simply use my phone from the convenience of my TV screen.

I'm certainly going to take advantage of that feature in the future.

I then plugged the hub into the USB-C port on my Windows laptop. It gave me a notification about having an HDMI video port. I suppose that means in a pinch that I can use the adapter as a 4th video output other than the laptop's built in screen, built-in HDMI output, and built-in VGA output. It also reads SD and MicroSD cards along with USB drives.

This is a rather versatile USB-C device. I highly recommend it.

title: This product will be going straight into my junk box, or more likely, into the trash can.
text:
Back in the 1970s, when I was around 10 years old, I mail-ordered a miraculous TV antenna that plugged into your home's electrical wiring and converted it into a house-sized antenna. That was, of course, a gimmick product. It's sad to find out that those cons don't go away; they just get repackaged into a different form factor. This TV antenna is the current version of that whole-house antenna.

You need to know that I live only three miles away from the broadcast antenna tower of the local CBS affiliate and about six miles from a PBS repeater transmitter. These stations are so close that just putting a paperclip into the TV's coax antenna-in port is often all that is needed to get reception.

For testing, I put the antenna in a window on the top floor of my house. I connected it to my TV antenna-in port, plugged the "amplifier" into a USB power source, and set the TV to work scanning for digital channels. After the first scan was completed, it detected ZERO channels. I changed the orientation of the antenna and began the channel search again. After the second scan was completed, it again detected ZERO channels. As an experiment, I eliminated the "amplifier" and was finally able to get the stations to come in. What gives? Why does it work better WITHOUT the amplifier? The listing gives this warm tip: "Please switch the amplifier to "short range" if your house is very close to the broadcast tower (within 35 miles)." Sorry, but there is no switch or button anywhere on the amplifier module.

I decided to pry open the case of the "amplifier" just to see what's going on in there. This doodad is described in the listing as "SMART SIGNAL BOOSTER AMPLIFIER 450 MILES - This HD antenna built-in Smart IC Chip Powerful Amplifier Signal Booster." Sorry, but there are no integrated circuits at all in that little module. Just some surface-mount resistors, capacitors, and a few triodes. Furthermore, it says "Maximum Range 35 Miles" elsewhere in the listing. So which is it?

This product will be going straight into my junk box, or more likely, into the trash can.

title: Excellent radio!  Small frustrations  (tuning knob, external antennas)
text:
This radio is fantastic in so many ways! Build quality (other than tuning knob) is great. The user interface is well-designed: logical and sophisticated. Autoscan in each band, saving memory presets for all detectable stations (with just a few false signals bleeding over from other frequencies). It's easy to switch between memory recall ("VM" mode) and non-memory tuning ("VF" mode). Reception with internal antennas is great in all bands, though some signal overload is evident with external antennas. Sound quality is great: some bass, good clarity, fair treble. Selectable bandwidth setting in all but FM band (very useful for marginal signals). Stereo/Mono switch for FM (when using earphones; stays Mono with internal speaker). Displays signal strength and signal-to-noise ratio for all radio bands (and signal-to-noise responds nicely to bandwidth or Stereo/Mono settings). Bluetooth speaker mode works well. Haven't tested microSD card playback, but that's also a nice feature. Rechargeable 2000 mAh 18650 Lithium Ion battery provides hours and hours of use. USB-C charging. The amber display can be set for constant LED illumination without impacting battery life terribly.

My main disappointment is the tuning knob, which is too small in height and diameter (hard to grip and turn effectively) and rubs against the cabinet. It is programmed as a fast/slow tuning knob. Turn it slowly for fine-tuning, faster for standard radio band frequency increments. Given that it's hard to grip and turn smoothly, this fast/slow design is awkward. The backward / forward buttons on the 4-way controller also do fine-tuning and more effectively. I usually avoid standard tuning ("VF" mode) and instead let autoscan set memories, which in "VM" mode one can move between with the tuning knob or the backward / forward buttons. In "VM" memory preset mode, the awkwardness of the tuning knob is less critical.

This radio also lacks squelch, useful for shortwave and AM, as provided on more expensive XHDATA radios. There is no support for single-side-band, of course, in this price range.

title: LOVE THESE!
text:
I have a pair of Apple AirPods, but they never seem to have a long enough battery life. I think the ones that I have currently are second generation Apple AirPods. Just to have a Second pair of earbuds as back up I thought I would try these out. I was beyond pleasantly surprised.

First of all the case is awesome! It has an indicator on the front that will tell you how charged the case is or how charged each earbud is which is super handy. I have small ear canals and the skins that were on the earbuds originally fit perfectly which is a Nice, because I usually have a problem with earbuds being too big.

Another problem I usually have is that while talking to people on the phone they always seem to hear the background noise like the train or the street car or the street sounds when I’m walking down the street but not with these. The sound is great not only while listening to a conversation, but participating as well as those in the conversation say that they hear me perfectly.

Music sounds pretty good in these as well. If you’re a casual music listener who just likes to put on your favorite playlist and jam out while you’re working out or walking down the street I don’t think you’ll have any problems with the musical sound on these. If you are a musical connoisseur and like your music to be clear with a luxurious rounded sound and booming bass you might not like this so much. I find myself desiring more out of the music aspect of these earbuds, but for the price you really can’t complain at all. They do the job.

TLDR:
Great for phone calls
Grateful working out at the gym
Waterproof and durable
Plenty of earbud skins to fit different ear types
Battery life is long and charge is pretty quickly
Noise canceling works well
Not the best for music, but they will get the job done.
Great back up earbuds or great if you’re looking for a good pair of earbuds on the cheap.

Will update in time as usual!

title: amazing and highly recommended
text:
These are the best headphones that I had. I had the following headphones:
- Meze 99 Classics
- SENNHEISER HD 660 S
- SIVGA Oriole Rosewood Wooden Closed Back Wired Dynamic Headphone (Brown)
- JVC HASW01 Wood Series Hi-Res
- HIFIMAN SUNDARA Hi-Fi Headphone with 3.5mm Connectors, Planar Magnetic, Comfortable Fit with Updated Earpads-Black, 2020 Version
- Audio-Technica ATH-M50XGM Professional Monitor Headphones
- Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone
- beyerdynamic DT 700 PRO X Closed-Back Studio Headphones with Stellar.45 Driver
- beyerdynamic DT 770 Pro
- Apple AirPods Max
- Apple AirPods Pro

It was essential for me to find good closed headphones. I like listening to music and sound quality is very important to me.
Beyerdynamic DT 1770 Pro are the most enjoyable headphones among the closed headphones mentioned above and they have the best sound quality. I can listen to them for hours.
Other advantages of Beyerdynamic DT 1770 Pro:
- they are very comfy
- noise isolation is very good
- wide sound stage

Apple AirPods Max and Apple AirPods Pro are good wireless headphones for iPhones and they have balanced sound. I use them on the go.

SENNHEISER HD 660 S is a good pair of open headphones and enjoyable too. However, they are open and I still enjoy Beyerdynamic DT 1770 Pro more.

JVC HASW01 are surprisingly good but they cost more and don't have so wide an audio stage.
Meze 99 Classics impressed me with strong bass and overall good sound. However, I experience fatigue after listening to them for more than half an hour.

My search is over. Try Beyerdynamic DT 1770 Pro, I think you will enjoy them. Also, they are available with discounts now. I bought them for less than $400.

title: Right earbud battery is only good for 3 - 4 hours. See the update 2/27/23
text:
These things fit just fine and the sound is great. I don't usually mess with ANC and could care leass about the heart rate monitor. I get that from my watch or I can just take my pulse.

My problem is that the right earbud battery is very short lived - lasts for a little under four hours. The left earbud is good for 6 - 7 hours. I wanted to wear these to bed with Pandora playing to help with my tinnitus, but the right earbud dying usually wakes me up around 2AM.

I didn't even open the box until a month and a half after getting them, so I can return them. I guess I'll use them to watch videos on the laptop while the wife watches TV.

Actually, the best buds, I have found, that sound great and have good battery life are Samsung's Galaxy Bud+. Unfortunately Samsung doesn't make them anymore.

Update - I was contacted by a tech from Anker, who offered me a replacement set of earbuds. I accepted those and received them within a couple of days. There was a definite improvement as the new pair's right earbud lasted about 6.5 - 7 hours. I noted that once the right earbud died, the left earbud had almost a quarter of battery life left. I reported this back to Anker and came to find that was as it should be. They have tested the earbuds to 8-9 hours, more using the charger. But - the right earbud has the heart rate detector in it. So, it will eat battery faster than the left earbud. If you don't care about the heart rate monitor, don't use the LDAC sound/Spatial Audio/soundcore Wellness mode. Your earbuds will last longer.

While this was happening, the original pair of earbuds received a firmware update.

So, due to Anker's willingness to work with me on this issue, I'm adding a star, and since I have found the method for extending the battery life, I'll add another star. If I actually get the 8-10 hour life, after turning off the un-needed features, I'll probably kick it up to 5.

title: Best Zip Tie Tool That I Have Owned
text:
Over the years in my business, I have used thousands of wire ties. I have used other Zip Tie Tools with varying degrees of success. Many is the time that I have reverted back to my trusty needle nose pliers and wire cutters. After familiarizing myself with this Superun Zip Tie Tool, I really like the way that it functions. It is narrow and well designed to work in tight spaces. It works well on a number of widths, from tiny to large wide zip ties.

How to use the tool: This tool operates like a pair of pliers or wire cutters. There are 2 handles, a long and a short, on one side of the tool. The other side of the tool has a single long handle. To use the tool, first wrap the zip tie around the item. Then insert the zip tie in to the binding end of the tie and slightly hand tighten it. The 2 handle side of the tool, is the same side where the end of the zip tie, is inserted in to the tip opening in the tool. The tie end will slip through through the slit/opening, past the cam gear teeth that will grip the tie. Then squeeze the 2 long handles together, to tighten the zip tie to the desired amount. (Do not over tighten) Once tight, the remaining waste portion of the zip tie can be cut off by depressing the short handle. Note: The short handle moves the cut-off blade. Be careful not to accidentally squeeze the short handle while gripping the two long handles. If done, it will cut off the zip tie before it is tight.

I will offer a few other tips on using this tool: If your zip tie end is inserted in this tool correctly, it really locks on to the tie. It will in fact, hold it so tightly that one can stretch and break the zip tie. You have to get the feel for it to avoid over tightening. Also, whenever possible, insert the end of the zip tie in to the tip of the tool, as straight as you can. The cutter will of course cut off the zip tie at the same angle that it was inserted in to the tool. Angle cuts will leave a sharp point where the zip tie was cut. The sharp angle can be easily corrected with wire cutters or scissors.

I hope this is helpful.

title: Nice lightweight unit - tablet or keyboard mode
text: I have a couple of these keyboards for my iPad and they are all pretty good.  No one knocks it out of the park the way Apple does but then again, I can buy 6 of the reasonably priced ones or ONE Apple keyboard. Not everyone can afford a $300 keyboard so...I have two of these.  What I like about this, other than price, is that it's light.  My backpack already weighs a ton so I downsized from the 12.9 in Pro to a 10 in Air to save on weight.  Some of the keyboards I've tried almost bulk up the Air to the weight of a Pro which defeats the purpose. This one is light.  It was a no brainer to get connected to the air, charges using USB-C (believe it or not that's huge because so does the Air...and some companies are still using the very slow micro-USB which also requires another cable). I like that it has a tablet mode (i.e. turn, flip and lay flat) and also a keyboard mode (stands like a laptop) because I find myself needing both and the keyboards that lack this feature mean struggling the iPad out of the case...and then having to store the case...which is doubly annoying when traveling.  Anyone who has been on an airplane in the last 5 or so years gets it.  The seat in front of you is only "far enough" when you are in the Economy Plus section so this is great for the rest of the plane.  I have two complaints: first, unlike the other unit I have this one is likely going to scratch from being put in and out of the bag.  The other one I have has a coating that will prevent that.  The other one however also has a right shift key that is half the size of a normal one so thats why I replaced it with this one.  The second thing I dont care for are the little brackets they use to hold the iPad in place.  Typical cases use compression into a rubberized fitting.  This uses two little rotating brackets.  I dont think they will ever break (too small with too little exposure) but I would prefer compression only.  Overall I am glad I made the switch and will likely use this one going forward.  Its worth the price unless you really want to spend $300 with Apple.  It's a win.

title: Lots of issues with this TV
text:
I got this TV with such high hopes. I’m a huge Amazon fan and was excited to get a firetv and saw that the reviews were mostly positive.

Unfortunately— I started having issues upon setup. You are able to select your Amazon account as the account you will use during setup before you purchase the tv, so I was expecting an easy set up process. This was not the case. It kept telling me that an account was already connected, but when I went into the backend it said that Amazon account was my own. I ended up on live chat with Amazon customer service for around 1 hour troubleshooting the issue. I was told it was something that wasn’t accurately set up on their end. Either way— very frustrating.

Once the tv was set up, I started noticing more issues. The Home Screen often doesn’t load the preview images or app images (as seen in photo). Some of the apps have major issues that I never had with my Roku. I constantly try restarting the tv, making sure the apps are updated, the tv OS is updated, and have tried clearing the cache or the data for apps that aren’t working correctly. I’ve tried installing and reinstalling apps. I have Fios Wi-Fi and it works perfectly for streaming on other devices in my home and I have tested the speed multiple times before to make sure it’s fast enough.

Peacock buffers terribly to the point where I can’t watch episodes because it is so bothersome. On my Roku upstairs (connected to the same Wi-Fi) I have no buffering issues with Peacock. Paramount+ simply does not play any movie or tv episode, just attempts to load, and then gives an error message. HBO Max will crash occasionally, and sometimes has the same buffering issues as Peacock. Netflix, Prime Video, Disney+ and Hulu never have any buffering issues at all. Which is baffling.

Overall, I give the smart features 1 star because of the above experiences. I just want the tv to work and play the episodes on the streaming apps that I pay for.

The picture is the one thing I would give 5 stars. When it’s working— the 4K is stunning.

title: A fine cable for DIY jobs, but not much else.
text:
I'm going to start by saying that if you're planning on buying this cable just to extend a regular 9-pin USB header, don't even bother. There are plenty of proper 9-pin header cables that will just plug right in without any fuss. In fairness to the people who gave this thing one or two stars because they had to break a pin off in order to use it on a normal header: I don't know who would actually need a 10-pin header cable - unless the sole reason is to modify it.

What this cable is great for; is resolving issues caused by OEMs who like to use annoying proprietary components. For example, you want to connect a new motherboard to a pre-existing front-IO board with an old cable, but you can't because the pinout isn't standard, this will resolve it. However, it's going to take a little work. You're more than likely going to have remove and rearrange the pins to make it work. In my case, I used two of these cables to connect a new Gigabyte motherboard to the factory FIO board of an Alienware Area 51 R2. It was chore of popping the pins out with a small flathead screwdriver and triple-checking to make sure they were all lined up with the original female-to-female cables but in the end, it worked.

What I really dislike about these cables though, is the design. The manufacturer opted to separately jacket each half of the wires, with makes the cable unnecessarily bulky. I assume this was an attempt to make identifying both halves of the cable's wiring easier, since they are the same colors, but this was frankly a terrible solution. Also, the cable is just comically long. I know there's some people - like myself, who enjoy building out of really strange cases, but I've never found myself in a situation where I needed almost 4 feet of header cable. This all makes routing these cables needlessly messy. They could make it a third of the length and I'm sure it would be fine for most people.

In closing, if you deem it suitable for your project and aren't afraid to get your hands dirty, this cable will work for lack of a better solution. The build quality is fine and the price is decent, but the design could be a whole lot better.
