title: Truly impressed with this and at that price point, will be buying more!!
text:
I installed this over a week ago and have been using it daily... I looked up the price today so I can comment on it's "value" and I am genuinely surprised at how cheap it is! I've had cameras over $100 that didn't perform half as good as this!

To set it up, all you have to do is download their app, make a login, and have the camera scan the QR code in the app and it's setup! Super quick and painless! And putting the camera up on the porch consisted of drilling 4 screws in so that was super easy! Comes with a template to help you mount it perfectly straight or whatever but I didn't use that and it still looks good.

Functionality- this thing spins all the way left and right (wont spin in circles but it does reach all the way to each side.) Then it's range of looking up and down is really good too. I posted this on a porch post out front and I can turn the camera to the left and look down to see when Amazon delivers my packages now! Truly impressive the coverage this one camera has!

Night vision has like 3 different modes- one of them I think it keeps the spotlight on (which is BRIGHT) and I can see my car in full color/crystal clear from a few feet away! Another mode is just black and white with the IR lights on. And the other mode is black and white but it switches the spot light on and goes to full color when it sense motion.

I need to see if it has a sensitivity setting because the on bit of annoyances is that as is- it catches motion of bugs and everything under the sun so I look at my phone and have 30 alerts at any given time from the camera! Hopefully I can fix that but even if not, I am happy with the camera for the price point!

Picture- it auto starts off in standard def but you click that icon and it switches it to HD which is MUCH clearer!!

Overall I'm truly amazed by this and will be buying a few more to cover my current house and the house we're remodeling. I normally go with another company's cams but this one is far more impressive and I'm a convert for sure!

title: Awesome Speaker; I’d Give This 6 Stars, If I Could
text:
I’ve had the Marshall Stanmore III Bluetooth speaker for about a month and wanted to give it plenty of use before writing up a review. I gotta say, it’s awesome! By far the best Bluetooth speaker I’ve tested and reviewed. I have past experience with Marshall amplifiers, so I had certain expectations for this speaker - this speaker definitely lives up to the Marshall name.

The speaker is the perfect size for a bookshelf or a bedroom. According to manufacturer specs, it’s roughly 14”x8”x7” and weighs in at a hefty 9 pounds, holding one (1) 50W and two (2) 15W amplifiers. It appears to be well made and has the same look and feel as my Marshall amp. The exterior is a soft feel/touch plastic; the front has the fabric liner covered in a plastic mesh; and trimmed out tastefully in gold and the Marshall name. On top, the gold/brass dials and on/off switch look just like the Marshall amp toggles. The bottom has rubber “feet” which provide a nice sturdy base and prevent and rattle or vibration. Overall, this looks like a piece of art; truly well done.

So how does it sound? It’s perfectly balanced, with clear highs and mids. The bass has that punch that you can feel, without sounding harsh or distorted. Overall, it’s such a clean sound. Volume-wise, this speaker definitely has the juice to shake the walls. I truly have no complaints about this speaker.

There’s a Marshall app which connects to the speaker and provides some more finely tuned features; based on the speaker’s positioning, distance from the wall, etc. A cool feature, but I don’t really use it. Once you have your speaker set and tuned to your liking, I don’t really see for the app.

The speaker itself is a little more costly than other comparable Bluetooth speakers, but I’d say this lives up to the price tag. The sound is incredible and the look has a type of class and style that makes you want to show this speaker.

I think this a fantastic speaker and would definitely recommend it.

title: Affordable NOAA Radio and Flashlight, would not use phone charger
text:
I recently learned of NOAA radio and wanted to have one on hand for emergencies. This little device is great! Not only does it have a NOAA radio, it also has AM/FM radio and a flashlight. It can also be charged by sunlight or hand crank in addition to a standard USB C charger.

I've been using this flashlight when I walk my dog in the evening. The wrist strap is nice, it means I'm not too worried about it slipping out of my hands. However, buyer beware, it appears to be housed in cheap plastic and feels more like a kid's toy - I'm not convinced this device will last, particularly if it did drop. It's got three LEDs and they are bright enough. Only one mode too - it turns on and off, no modes or strobe lights, which I really appreciate. I used it two nights in a row as a flashlight without charging, but I'm not sure how long either the radio or flashlight would run in an emergency. Also the manual was a little unclear - it said something about using the hand crank 3-5 minutes before use. Like once? or every time I use it? Seems like a lot, but to be safe I hand crank for 30 seconds or so while leaving.

The battery charging indicator light is confusing too. If you're using a cable, the light flashes when charging, but the light remains solid when you use the crank or solar. I think most devices use a flashing light to indicate charging, so that just makes it confusing, but I suppose it it blinked, it might make it look like the solar/cranking is going on/off/on/off, so maybe that was intentional.

Left on a kitchen counter in sunlight, in charging indicator light was on. I fully charged with USB after I first received it and now am trying to rely on the crank/solar to get a better understanding of how it works/how long it takes to charge/run out.

I wouldn't rely on this device for charging other devices. The battery is 2000 mah, so not enough to charge all phones to 100%, it's good for an emergency like if you need a few % to send a text or place an emergency call. I have a much larger capacity, smaller frame battery that I keep charged for that instance.

title: Powerful, light; but keyboard wear
text:
Pros: 32GB RAM, 2TB SSD, powerful CPU, dedicated NVIDIA GeForce GPU make for a speedy, responsive laptop; screen is nice and bright; very lightweight for the size and power.

Neutrals: large touch pad; dedicated number keys; no fingerprint reader.

Cons: Fan runs more than other notebooks I've had; keyboard "feel" could be better; what seems like excessive key wear after four months; only comes with Windows 11.

I bought this notebook as a personal-for-work machine in September 2022. I do scientific computing and frankly this thing is as speedy as my previous desktop machine for some modeling work. The fan runs more often and a little louder than past laptops; then, this is, for a laptop of its size and weight, on the powerful side.

I use it daily as a complement to my desktop machine when I'm in my office at work, and all day when I'm on business travel (1 week out of 4, typically), mostly plugged in. The battery life seems fine under normal office use - using it for number-crunching simulations kills it quicky, as one would expect, so no real complaints there. The keyboard is a little firmer than I would like - I've been spoiled by IBM/Lenovo ThinkPad keyboards - but it's better than many laptops I've had or tried.

My biggest complaint, honestly, is that the keys I hit most often are starting to get that partly-polished, shiny look. It's not finger oils; I clean the keyboard every so often, and the polished portions remain and are getting larger. It's not yet a durability issue, but it's not a great look and I wish it weren't happening so fast.

Overall, there are other options that come, let's say, 70-80% of the way to this thing's capabilities at around half the price; but they probably weigh more. If you can do with less ram, storage space, and CPU and GPU power, you probably don't need this machine. But if you want or need those aspects, and want them in a lightweight frame that's not too annoying to travel with and carry, it's the best option I've found.

title: Good Working Binoculars with 8X Magnification and 9-10’ Close Focus Range
text:
One of our granddaughters is fascinated by our binoculars when we visit and birdwatch in her Florida back yard. She has a pair of toy binoculars, but they are probably more discouraging than helpful. These pink Boosigant Compact Binoculars are both cute and functional 8X magnification binoculars with a surprising close focus of 9-10 feet. They are lightweight, sized for small hands, and protected by a rubber coating. The eye pieces have wide and soft cups. The focus wheel is a little stiff, but will probably loosen with use; nonetheless, they are easy to adjust. Both focus and color look good. The accessories are less impressive, but still helpful. The strap is difficult to thread through the ring on the binoculars without unraveling it (I used tweezers) and it’s a thin strap all the way around, though the binoculars are so lightweight that a thin strap is probably fine. The barely-big-enough storage case is made of a thin and stiff neoprene-like material with a belt loop and a hook-and-loop closure that will keep dust from the lenses and focus mechanism. There are instructions for adjusting and focusing the binoculars, but none for attaching the strap. If you’ve not attached this type of strap before, see my instructions below and the photos. I think my granddaughter will love these binoculars and they work just like her grandmother’s.

Instructions for threading the strap onto the binoculars: 1) set the binoculars on a table with the eye cups up, 2) pull some slack in the part of the strap that is already threaded through the buckle so there’s a loop sticking out of the top of the buckle, 3) align the strap so that the bare crossbar of the buckle is facing toward the binoculars, the loop is facing away, and the loose end is hanging down 4) thread the loose end of the strap nearest that buckle through the bottom of the loop on the binoculars (i.e., up toward the eye cups), 5) thread the same end through the bottom of the buckle and over the crossbar, underneath the loop you made earlier, 6) leave a little of the loose end free and tighten the straps in the buckle, 7) repeat with the other side.

title: Worst key layout, possibly ever!
text:
[[VIDEOID:f2b9b298d48bfb703f84032799289f20]] I received the (grey) design keyboard/mouse combo for free in exchange for my honest review.

Keyboard:
✅ COLOR. grey/black contrast looks very sophisticated. Tons of compliments at the office are guaranteed (speaking from personal experience)
✅ NON-SLID. has 5 silicone “grips” at the bottom. anyone who says otherwise must’ve already lost theirs.
❌ SIZE. “full size” is referencing the numeric keypad, which would typically not be present on a compact size keyboard. While this not a tenkeyless keyboard, it is also NOT full size! Some alphanumeric keys have been dramatically reduced in size (Space bar, Shift, Caps Lock, Tab, Enter, and Backspace) and additional layout modifications will put this keyboard in the same range as “75% compact” but with a numberpad.
❌ LAYOUT. I don’t know what type of evil designer must you be to come up with the idea of placing the Delete key in exact location of where the Backspace key would located on any standard keyboard???
As someone who’s already had to go through the pain of relearning how type, I can tell you that muscle memory takes time and practice, and there is absolutely no reason why anyone should be forced it upon themselves to learn a new typing method when you can just buy a differed keyboard instead of this atrocity.
❌ STIFF KEYS. surprise mode sticky keys- all keys but at random times. expect the unexpected by pounding on each key you type.
❌ DELAYED RESPONSE. very bad for IM users or anyone who takes frequent breaks between sentences
(30 second or longer)

Mouse:
✅ REDUCED NOICE. not silent per se, but a muffled click is still better than “clicking” click.
❌ NON-ERGONOMIC. Very flat.
❌HYPERACTIVE SCROLL. Middle switch should be able to reduce mouse sensitivity. apparently scrolling wheel doesn’t qualify

title: A welcomed added sense of security
text:
The 2-pack of Aomeisi wi-fi security cameras and hardware arrived boxed securely nestled in form fitting foam. The instruction manual is extremely detailed making the set-up go a lot smoother than anticipated. Having QR Codes available also helped when it came time to synch the camera to both our Android phones. Aside from drilling the holes to mount the housing, the set-up of the first camera (with two phones) took approximately 40 minutes.

The housing to hold the camera is sturdy and durable. The camera attached easily to the fixture. It would have been appreciated if the cord was longer. As it is, it must drape across the wall to the only outlet by our front door. An extension cord will obviously solve the problem, but again, a longer cord will probably be warranted by most. Beside that issue, the device is sleek an unobtrusive in appearance.

As of this writing, the cameras have been exposed to the rain twice along with 35mph winds. On both occasions, service was not interrupted nor was the picture quality hampered. The security cameras switch from day to night mode automatically. In both settings, the images appear to be clear with no pixeling noted. At nigh time, it is a treat to see the animals that walk through our backyard. Who needs a trail camera when the Aomeisi camera does the trick.

Being able to talk with a visitor from inside the house is one of my favorite features. There are many other capabilities of this security device that I have not seen on others. The motion sensitivity levels are a plus especially with year-round insects. No more waking up to a false alarm caused by some creepy crawling pest. We haven’t had the need to use all of the bells and whistles of this system, but it nice to know that they are available when the occasion arises. This wi-fi security packages is definitely more than I was expecting.

Note: AS a Vine Voice, it is my intention to help sellers improve their product while highlighting the features of it. I also try to be as detailed as possible with my feedback so that prospective buyers have a more complete “view” of the product. Most reviews are completed within weeks of receiving the product, so if warranted, I will edit a review after some time has passed.

title: Amazing, very cool universal remote control with hub, all in one smart remote. Over my head.
text:
This SofaBaton universal remote comes with an app and is an all in one smart remote. It's definitely smarter about what it does than I'll ever be. My friend set this up for me, and it's great once it's all set up, but I'd still be trying; this isn't due to the SofaBaton being difficult to set up but is due to my lack of knowledge about such things.

The remote works with over 500,000 devices from over 6,000 brands, including TV, DVD, Blu-Ray, cable boxes, streaming players, etc. I have a Samsung smart TV and a small JVC regular TV, and it works very well with both of them.

The SofaBaton app works with iPhones and androids, and it's compatible with Alexa and Google Assistant. It does a wonderful job of changing between modes of watching television - from live TV to streaming to recordings. I just have no clue whatsoever as to how it does all the things it does.

I do understand the basic idea of the SofaBaton - you have one remote that controls everything and does everything but walk the dog. You can create customized activities for your home entertainment system, whatever that may be, and you can set it up to do anything you want it to do as far as recording, streaming, music, whatever. You can set it for starting and controlling devices in groups or individually, directly with a touch, or with custom schedules. Once you get the hang of it, it's really not that technical. If it was, I couldn't do it.

Excellent product, an amazing universal remote control for all your devices. How it works is entirely over my head, but it works very well. It comes with its recharging hub, and its app works on both iPhones and androids. It also works with Alexa or Google Assistant. This is a very, very smart remote that any man would love; the more gadgets, the better. Now that someone else set it up for me, I love it, too; it makes doing what you want to do with your TV, music, streaming, recording, you name it much easier. I'd highly recommend this to anyone who wants a universal remote, and this would make a fantastic Valentine's Day gift for anyone.

title: Great light blocking ability. Large, but slightly smaller than listed
text:
[[VIDEOID:683d55cbe7f09b1181abd001cb470c32]] Today I'm reviewing his black photo backdrop,

As you can see it comes in a nice very large, zippered bag that measures about 18x14x4 inches in size. Now I'll remove the backdrop and the four plastic clamps. The clamps have a pretty nice amount of spring tension so they should hold well. The ends have a hinge to ensure you get good contact. The clams are about 3 inches wide at the handle and 4.5 inches tall. You only receive four clamps, so that may not be enough depending on how you plan to hang this.

I'm seeing some green fluff on the backdrop. I don't know if it shipped this way or if the fluff came from my green screens. I'll have to open this up to take a picture. Let's get an idea of the thickness of this material. It seems pretty think, when I try to look through it the fabric seems to do a good job blocking light. This is fairly opaque. I'll open this up and measure it.

The fabric is smooth but does have some wrinkles.

You can see the comparison to my old black backdrop on top, which is actually doubled over. On the bottom is this new one (this item). You can easily see through my old one and even get a hint of the green screens. I'm very impressed with the thickness and light blocking ability.

The only downside I see is that it is not true to size and when measured it was just over 19 feet by 9.5 feet. So, a foot short in one dimension and half a foot in the other. Since I won't have to double up this backdrop, I'm fine with the slightly shorter than expected size.

I'm rating this five out of five stars

Pros
- Thick fabric blocks light well
- Has rod pocket on two sides
- Remaining 2 sides have a sewn edge

Cons
- Backdrop is undersized. Actual was 19 feet 1 inch, by 9 feet 6 inches.
- Minor sheen to the fabric

title: Great gaming motherboard, prices are higher on Amazon
text:
This is a great looking, stable motherboard with a lot of futureproof features built into it. I'm using it to run my new 13700KF and some 6400 speed DDR5 RAM, and I've had zero issues so far. There are lots of fan headers to help control airflow if you don't want to rely on buggy software, and the BIOS lets you set fan curves pretty easily. Overclocking is easy, and this has plenty of power phases to make sure that overclock will remain stable. TPM was enabled by default so I didn't have to worry about changing that to get my Windows 11 boot drive to fire right up, and even the basic BIOS menu that you see on first boot let me enable XMP for my RAM right away.

One thing that wasn't super clear until I RTFM was that installing an M.2 NVMe drive in the one marked "Blazing" would lower my GPU's PCIE lane allocation. When you remove the heat-sink that sits right above the primary GPU slot, there are actually 2 M.2 ports there, one to the left and one to the right. If you put a drive into the one on the left your GPU will run at full PCIE 5.0x16 and the M.2 drive will run at PCIE 4.0x4, but if you populate the M.2 drive on the right, even if it's just a PCIE 4.0 NVMe drive, it will automatically lower your GPU to only using 8 PCIE lanes because it assumes you've installed a PCIE 5.0x4 NVMe drive. It is called out in the manual, but it wasn't something I realized until after I'd booted everything up so it required a bit of rework.

My only real gripe is that prices on Amazon are about 10% higher than other competitors here in the USA. I still bought it here because I wanted the free shipping and I either don't trust or have had bad experiences with some of the competition (looking at you, egg company), but it would have been nice not to have to pay a premium to do so. 4.5/5 overall because the board itself is very nice, but the price increase drops it half a star when buying it on Amazon IMHO.

title: Nearly Impossible to Program Because of Cryptic Key Functions
text:
Like all cheap electronics this scanner has convoluted cryptic programming. It has those annoying multiple function keys that force you to do all manner of key pressing. You know the routine, press 1 then 4, then 5 which turns the 8 key into enter, but if you press 1 then 5, then 4, the 8 key becomes a delete key.

In this case, you have to press and hold the "HOLD" key, enter a channel number, then press "E" (for enter). There is no acknowledgement of your entry. If you make a mistake entering any data, your only option is to clear the entire entry and start over, so you had better get it right the first time. If you are lucky enough to program your channel, you cannot simply go on to the next, you have to exit, then start all over from scratch. By the way, the instruction manual does not tell you that the volume key is used to scroll through the menu, as well as scroll through the alphabet when you enter labels for the channels.

Speaking of the volume knob, it serves three separate functions depending on how many times you press it, and as usual there is no indication of what mode it is in, you just have to rotate it and see what happens.

I programmed a few channels to scan interesting frequencies at Fort Lauderdale Airport. When I was finished, I pushed the scan button, and nothing happened except for a message that said all channels were locked out. I returned to the set-up menu and scrolled down to the unlock all channels and selected it. Still nothing. In other words, I now have a $115 chunk of useless plastic cluttering my house.

This is definitely not a user-friendly device, so you had better keep the user manual within easy reach if you expect to use this scanner in the future. The only problem with that plan is that the user manual really sucks. It explains how to do the basic set up (sort of) But it offers no help if you want to change any settings once programmed, for that you are on our own using trial and error.

As for me, it is winging its way back to Amazon as I write this review. I am not looking to learn a whole new programming language just to use what should be a simple scanner.

title: Good sound but low volume
text: The TV we hooked this up to had a low volume issue; we would have to turn the volume all the way up to 100 to get what was normally a "normal" volume level for listening. We thought getting a sound bar would help us to be able to turn up the volume more and hear better; so this is the first attempt. The HDMI ARC connection worked easiest; unfortunately this resulted in the sound not being any louder than what the TV produced. I don't know if it's because of the TV's sound output limitations or this speaker's limitations. I was hoping the speaker could amplify the TV's sound better but it definitely didn't via the HDMI ARC cable. I tried using the included optical cable, and couldn't get it to work at all. I have used optical cables successfully in other applications, so I believe it was not user error. The optical cable was really thin. So either it's a bad cable, or a bad port on either the TV or speaker. The third try was using an aux cable. The TV only had a headphones out jack, which happened to be the only type of cable they didn't include. However, I found a spare laying around my house and hooked it up to this speaker using the aux to aux cable (think headphones jack on both sides of the cable). This worked. We could turn the speaker all the way up, and then still use the TV remote to control the volume because the TV out volume was still coming out of the headphones jack and was subjected to the TV's volume control. The sound though seems a bit distorted if it is turned all the way up; probably because the headphones jack isn't made for that type of output. However, essentially now the speaker is amplifying the 100 volume level of the TV, and so we get good volume. Overall I like the sound output by the speaker, I just wish it was higher volume. The front display on the speaker goes from 0 (or 1) to 30 for volume adjustment. The Bluetooth feature worked fine, I connected it to my iPhone easily. It played music from my phone and sounded great, but again, wasn't very loud. All in all, a nice speaker if you don't need anything loud. If you are wanting high volume to overcome other noise, then this speaker won't cut it. But if you are in a quiet setting and only need medium volume, this will work great.

title: Really nice microscope & Good Price
text:

CONS:

I ordered this for both my kids so that they can get interested in something other than electronics. This microscope is well built and really focuses nicely on the slides. It comes with everything you need. The 30 prepared slides really show that all things are made of multiple layers. My kids are so excited to disassemble items to see exactly what they are made of. It helps them focus on something more than just their electronics. Both of my children have shown interest in learning what layers things are made of. This microscope is well made and is easy to use. I would recommend this product to others. I feel it is a great price for the quality as well.

title: Read this if you're planning on using this for an industrial radio.
text:
I'm going to lead with the fact that I work as a millwright and bought these for my work radio. It's a Motorola CP200d. That's less important for compatibility than your handset though, make sure yours has an audio jack before buying, not all radio handsets do.

The sound dampening is good, they function as regular ear plugs and I don't feel like my hearing is in danger even in the loudest parts of the mill.

The fit is decent, I'm not normally a fan of the flanged silicone style ear plug, I've always found them painful in my ears by the end of the day, but these are made from a very soft silicone that's grippy but not uncomfortable.

The sound quality is decent but nothing to write home about. I would have rated higher, but there's a concussive burst at the start of each transmission that's distracting till you get used to it, which takes a few hours. Other than that I can hear pretty clearly and it's helping a lot with my ability to communicate when I'm working in high noise areas, particularly when I have to have muffs over my plugs.

My actual cons for this are in the pic. The plugs stuck straight out of my ears. A bend at the end of the plug would be a huge benefit because it bumps into things in close quarters which is distracting, and I can't wear a beanie over my hears. The latter is my biggest issue, we're in the actually cold part of winter out here on the Washington coast and I have to work outside in the rain and sleet a lot, and my ears are getting cold.

My other con is that the wire is super stiff, which makes it a little hard to route so that it stays out of the way and won't get snagged.

If I were to give feedback to Elgin, I would say to add a bend to the plug end and use a more flexible cord coating like a braided sheath, you could probably lose the nice storage case to keep the cost similar to what it is. Several guys I work with also bought these, and since we have personal radios we don't have much need for the storage because they stay plugged into our hand sets while they're charging.

title: Worth it for the price!
text:
I have a spouse that snores, and stumbled across these headband headphones. I already have a pair of over-the-ear headphones, and I love to fall asleep to non-snoring sounds or books on tape but I am a side sleeper, so I was bemoaning the fact that I couldn't get really comfortable AND drown out the human log machine. I also have quite sensitive ears, so I can only wear headphones, ear buds, and ear plugs for a short while before they start hurting, and headbands have to be a good size, not too tight, so I don't get headaches.

Pros:
--The tightness of this headband is practically perfect for me. My head is 21" circumference, and the band doesn't hurt after hours of wearing it. I did wake up with one ear hurting the first night, but I think that was because I fell asleep hard and didn't move a muscle for hours, and I consider that amazing, compared to all the not-sleep I had been getting recently.
--I can sleep on my side and listen to my book!
--I have adhd and find it very comforting to have some kind of background music or calming sounds going on at all times, but it can seem rude to others if I have my big headphones on. Not that that really matters, but it's nice to not have to worry about someone thinking I'm rude. At a glance, it looks like I'm just wearing a headband.
--It's pretty budget friendly
--The battery, so far, has been quite good, and it is easy to use

Cons:
--I wish I could turn the volume up little louder. Great for when I'm doing quiet crafts, but I couldn't wash dishes and catch everything if I was listening to a book. Also, not noise cancelling, but I didn't expect these to be for $15
--The warning that you've turned the volume up to max is a little jolting, to say the least. A loud double beep, but I try to make sure the volume is all the way up before I put them on, and then don't touch it.

All in all, I am super pleased with my headband headphones!

title: Unbelievable value
text: This is my second Vizio soundbar without a subwoofer. I was very happy with the quality for the price of that one, and over two and a half years later it is still running strong. However with the release of Dolby Atmos and many shows on Netflix including this upgraded feature, I wanted to enjoy this novel sound experience. So in Vizio released the soundbar, I was excited because they're one of the few companies that actually create an option without a subwoofer as they are some of the few that understand the practical challenges of owning an audio system. Honestly the technology's got so good now, that unless you live in a large space, the value of a subwoofer is really not justified it seems. The sound on this speaker is of excellent clarity. Voices come through clearly. Bass is excellent as it enhances the watching experience to have a more dramatic impact rather than just simply being punchy. The atmos orientation of the speakers is very effect. Watching shows like drive to survive which involves formula 1 drivers racing around, actually feels like cars are driving past you, not just on a television. For those who use an Amazon fire stick device, make sure you plug it directly into the soundbar HDMI in port. From there route the HDMI cable from the arc port into the TV. There's a slight delay in processing, which is most prominent in the lag of the closed captions to keep up with speech. The remote is well laid out and the same one used across many devices. It is not entirely intuitive, so I recommend you read the user manual to know how to adjust things like the treble and bass. Night mode is a useful function so as to not disturb folks sleeping by turning down the bass an appropriate amount. For some reason all the equalizer presets aren't available. I'm not sure if this is because I have an older Vizio TV, it is due to the Amazon fire stick, or some other reason. Also there is a true volume button which equals out the noise level across different media to prevent jarring differences from one channel or source to the next. This is really what I love most about Vizio, they are in some ways like the new generation of consumer electronic companies that understand is not just about the hardware, but also the user-friendly design of the units which actually allow optimal use and thus full extraction of its value. Good job fellas.

title: Random shutdowns under heavy CPU load
text:
I currently own an Asus Strix Z690 D4 but wanted to move to DDR5 and I was waiting for a decently priced open box 2-dimm board to become available when one popped up so I snagged it from Amazon Warehouse.

It arrived basically looking near brand new (few blemishes here and there) but I did notice the stickers had been removed and reapplied so it HAD been used sometime in the past. It was open box so that was to be expected.

The board is solidly constructed and pleasing to the eye. The sheer amount of pack-ins is astounding. If you're into flair and tchotchkes this has them in abundance. There was no manual included. I'm not sure if it was meant to have one or if MSI does the QR code route.

After updating the BIOS from a circa 2021 revision to the newest A.90 I outfitted it with my pre-existing components (12900k, Samsung 1TB SSD, MSI 4090, 1600w PSU) and away we go. It was also outfitted with a set of Trident 2x16GB 7600 DDR5 modules. I was able to dial in the memory to 7400 @ 34-43-43-34 rock solid (TM5 and WMD passed).

Everything seemed to work well from stress testing the GPU to the memory and more. Gaming was fine too. The problem was once placed under a meaningful CPU load the system would randomly shut down. No warnings, nothing...just complete power off.

CPU temps were fine along with VRM temps. It would just power off. I swapped in a 12400 and a 12100 and they ran fine under sustained load indicating an issue with much heavier loads being subject to a motherboard issue.

I swapped everything back to my Strix Z690 D4 and with the 12900k under the same heavy CPU load scenarios that caused random immediate shutdowns of the MSI Unify-X, it ran just fine for 30-60min stress tests.

Pity as it was a good price and I really liked the aesthetics of the board except for the BIOS indicator light which is ALWAYS on. One position is is a glaring white. The other is an even worse red.

title: Great Machine
text:
This tower comes with absolutely everything you need to get going with the exception of a monitor and a cable to connect the monitor. The correct model tower was shipped to me, however the video out ports weren't what I was expecting for this model, so I did end up needing to purchase an additional cable which is not the end of the world. The device I received came with 3 DisplayPort style ports, not 2 DisplayPort and 1 HDMI as I was expecting - I find DisplayPort to be a bit more secure and the cables more reliable (you can't just use and reuse and transfer them back and fourth to any old thing) so ultimately it was a nice little upgrade and a pleasant surprise. I also misunderstood what was meant by "accessories" and ended up buying a keyboard and mouse separately, so if you are wondering about the need to purchase those - you don't! In the box was also a WiFi adapter, as this particular model does not come equipped with WiFi capabilities out of the box. Setup and first-use went exactly as it should for a brand-new PC, and the drives appear to have been properly cleaned (wiped drive was overwritten to remove any trace of previously deleted data), so it essentially runs and behaves like a brand new out of the box PC.

I bought this for the sole purpose of running Revit23, so far I have not had any performance issues or other problematic encounters with the device. Revit is the only software that has been installed or used on the computer, but it is extremely resource heavy - especially with larger designs or more intricate planning. I can't imagine there being any issues with moderate or even the heavier side of moderate usage short of a hardware failure or misuse. The WiFi adapter it came with is extremely reliable and hasn't given me any connection issues when I use it (I tend to keep the device offline 90% of the time). For reference, my office is in an upstairs bedroom, with the router on the first floor (9 foot ceilings) and roughly 40 feet of linear distance between the where the desk and router would be if they were on the same floor. I also have abysmal internet service and speeds much of the time. Take from that what you will.
Overall this would be a great daily driver, especially at this price point, and has the capability to carry some really resource consuming programs with ease.

title: Convenient solution for modern PCs
text:
With modern PCs rarely coming with disk readers anymore, old PC users like myself that liked to archive things on CD/DVD media still need a way to read our old disks, play CD music, and sometimes write to new blank disks. There are several portable disk readers and writers available to resolve this issue.

This particular unit is very small and light and supports a current USB 3 interface (both type A and type C connectors) so it's a handy way to be able to give modern PCs a way to use that media. So far I've not had any issues; the player plugged in fine and was recognized by Windows 10 without any need to download drivers. I played music CDs, ripped a music CD, and read a photo disk. The drive isn't the fastest device but it was sufficient for my needs.

Pros:
- Supports both Type A and Type C connections.
- The interface cable is integrated into the unit. This is convenient as you're less likely to misplace a cable.
- Quiet
- Plays CD, DVD, and Blu-Ray disks
- Doesn't need an external power source, just runs off your PC's USB port

Cons:
- Integrated interface cable is very short, just a couple inches. You'll have to keep the drive close to the device using it
- No included software, but you should be able to find free utilities if you want to burn disks, and Windows comes with the ability to rip music disks built-in

Tips:
- If you don't need to use Blu-ray disks, step down to just a regular DVD reader/writer. It'll save you a bunch as there are plenty of those external drives and they are about half the price of a Blu-ray version
- This doesn't come with a carrying case. Some external drives do, so look around for other options if you plan to travel a lot with this and want something to help protect it

I haven't tried the disk burning feature on this one yet, so I'll report back later if it warrants mention. Also, I've had disk readers burn out on me after a year or two of use, will report back if this one does the same thing.

title: Good fitness watch, Great price, Bad App
text:
This watch is actually a very nice value for the cost. It seems well made and feels nice although a bit bulky. It has a bright display and about 100 various watch faces to choose from. Battery life seems great as I have been wearing it for three days at this point and it is still 50% charged.

The package watch comes nicely boxed with a charging cable and 2 additional watch bands should you not like the one that comes with the watch. I choose to stick with the watchband that came with it and find it to be stylish and comfortable.

The display shows the typical time and date but also shows your steps, calories burned, and heart rate. The watch will also track your oxygen level and blood pressure which is fantastic for those looking to monitor health. I am not sure I would use the reading to replace those that you would get from a high-quality medical device (blood pressure cuff, oxygen meter) but the watch is certainly close enough to keep you informed on a consistent basis.

The big letdown with this watch is the application. It really doesn't provide much in terms of data and while it does allow you to connect your watch and use it to make and receive calls, text, and other notifications, I am not sure that this is the best use of a watch. I use a good quality headset with noise cancellation and find that much more effective especially for business calls. The watch would certainly work in a pinch but if your phone is close then why not just use your phone as a phone?

The next major disappointment with the app is that while it will connect to the google fit app, it doesn't seem to pass any health data to the app. Given that this is the case, the only thing you are doing by connecting to the Fit app is giving the watch manufacturer access to your Google files. My recommendation is not to do that.

So, my overall opinion is that this is a really good option if you just want to track steps and heart rate and need to be able to do so inexpensively. It is a watch that provides most of the functionality of the much, much more expensive major brands and does so with style.

I would definitely recommend this watch if you looking for an inexpensive alternative to the major players who dominate the market.

title: Bought two of them.
text:
My man and I love to game together. Our PC's were getting old but we didn't have a lot of money. I've worked with computers since I was 17 and I'm 40 now. So I do have quite a bit of experience.

Gamers: Great for stuff like League of Legends, and I've been playing Path of Exile on it (lowered graphics) just fine. Seems to handle quite a bit despite it being integrated graphics. You can't play the new stuff with super graphics. But I don't have the dang money to buy those games anyways, so I won't be trying to play them. lol If you enjoy light gaming, this thing is perfect! Plenty of space too with the 500GB drive.

Browsers/Show Watchers: If you just like browsing around and watching shows, then this thing is perfect for that! Great all-around mini pc!

The things I like the most: Small and compact. No more moving a giant tower everywhere. Setup was extremely easy. Came with Windows 11 Pro. Runs all the games I play. Nice amount of RAM. I have been able to multitask without a hiccup. Example like I'm playing PoE, listening to music on Spotify, and then I look things up and keep tabbing in/out with my browser. Slower systems are gonna lag or even hiccup. But this one just keeps truckin. So it's pretty great for medium multitasking as well.

Do you dislike anything about it? Well I know I can't play the newest games that have intense graphics, but that's a sacrifice you have to make if you can't afford your own dedicated graphics card in a big system. But honestly that's the only downside at all. And I'm cool with that, it does exactly what I need.

I ended up enjoying this mini PC so much, that I have just gotten a second one for my guy. I freaking love technology, and I LOVE what a powerhouse this lil thing is for the price. Super recommend. (Also don't get the cheaper mini PC's that are around 100-200 unless you are strictly browsing online and watching youtube, you can't game on those, I've bought one before, they're not strong enough for it.)

title: Great value!
text:
I bought this on sale for $300 and liked it so much that I immediately ordered another!

I have no comment regarding the installed Windows OS; when I buy a machine with that OS installed, I boot into an installer for an alternative OS (Linux in the past, OpenBSD for the past several years)

The Mini PC package is pretty much identical in size and shape to an Intel NUC (which this unit replaced).

Other reviewers have noted that the fan is quiet even under load. I confirm this: although I don't run game software, other CPU intensive software warms up the air exhausted at the back of the unit. The only way I've been able to discern fan noise (in a quiet room) is with my ear close to the vented top grille of the enclosure.

Not only do I not run games, but I don't run a desktop environment (preferring an X11 window manager) or *any* GUI apps. I use lynx for the web, telescope for the "small" web, and alpine for IMAP/POP email. That said, I do run xlock or xview in the root window for decoration; my *impression* is that animations (particularly of busy xlock screens like that of the "scooter" mode) seem to render better than they did on the NUC that I ran previously.

OpenBSD 7.2 installed without issue; everything works. (NOTE: this does not include the built-in Bluetooth, which is unsupported by OpenBSD regardless of the hardware platform. If you really need to run a Bluetooth speaker or headset, buy a USB Bluetooth dongle; OpenBSD supports these.

This Mini PC has an AMI BIOS.

Performance is fine. (Remember, I'm not running Windows. YMMV...) Subjectively, this Mini PC is every bit as snappy as my former Mini-ITX desktop build with an 8th-gen 65W TDP CPU from Intel. In fact, I think that my days of custom builds are in the past; Mini PCs are just too convenient and are available in a broad-enough range of configurations for my applications (software dev't, email, servers, etc.).

title: Good router but with caveats
text:
The Good: It’s light and sits vertical which works for me. The user interface is terrific. You can really dig under the hood and see/learn what is happening. I live in an old home that makes reliable and as advertised by my provider speeds via Internet very difficult. I was shopping for a system that came from a trusted name and support that did not try to force a subscription model on me. After some struggle it runs well and even use their AIMesh with an ASUS Blue Cave device to help carry the signal throughout my home. Also, they have good customer support. The Wi-Fi signal is fast.

The Bad: The firmware was not working for me. I had to deal with a few weeks of intermittent Internet and a lot of time with customer support resetting the station and tweaking the optimal and recommended settings with them. In the meantime the wired connections worked but that was only a handful of devices connected to my entertainment center.

The Ugly: The culprit was the ASUS firmware. I had to think out of the box and install a third party firmware named Merlin (look it up) before every my Internet became reliable again.

Additional tips: If you have older devices like smart plugs and IOT appliances that use 2.4 GHz only, set up with separate 2.4 and 5.0 GHz channels. Do not use their Smart Connect because it’s truly not very smart.

If your 2.4 GHz alone ever goes down (not even visible while the 5.0 and wired devices are ok) and restarting the device doesn’t bring it back, dig into the admin interface and change to any another channel and hit the Apply button. Wait a few minutes and your 2.4 GHz magically reappears and reconnects with all of your old 2.4 GHz devices. I have had to do this only a few times in 3 months and it’s probably because I live in an area with a lot of Internet traffic/other users nearby.

Overall I am happier with this upgrade but unless you’re willing to spend a little time with a learning curve this might not be the best for you. If you like digging into your tech but don’t claim to be an engineer this can be an option for you.

title: Didn't expect too much and got what I expected
text:
For the price this camera is just OK. Here's what I've experienced:
Daylight performance is good enough. Good motion detection, perhaps just a bit too sensitive but that's something that can be adjusted through the VicoHome app. I'll write more about the app below. I tried both SD and HD quality but couldn't see any real difference in the recorded daylight when viewed on either my phone or tablet.
When set to higher motion detection sensitivity every car that drove by on my busy street 90 feet away triggered a recording. At night the b&w images are only good out to 20 feet or so.
The included mounting bracket is OK, seems sturdy enough though I have had trouble finding a good place to mount it on my house. That's my problem not the camera's though.
I have had it running outdoors for 24 hours and the camera still shows 99% battery. That's much better than expected.
I have Alexa in my home but have not found any way to pair the camera with Alexa. If it's possible it's not documented anyplace.
Now for the app:
PROS- It works and controls the camera well.Viewing the videos from the Internet is handy BUT that feature will only be available during the 30 day trial period. Watching videos recorded to an internal SD card is more cumbersome but it works.

CONS-The camera sends your images to a server somewhere in China! I hate that! After the 30 day trial I expect that I'll start getting requests from China for a credit card to keep the service active. That's not going to happen.
The app really eats battery power on my Android phone. Most power hungry app I've ever installed.

SUMMARY-
It's a plus that the camera can work with just an SD card and no subscription though without 100% functionality. Will I mount this camera permanently? That remains to be seen. Will I keep it? Probably, because it's OK for what I paid for it and it's not worth the hassle to return it but I can imagine a time in the future when it just ends up unused in a box with other failed high tech gadgets. Time will tell.
Would I buy more or recommend to a friend? No, probably not.

title: Sound is good, controls are cumbersome
text:
This is my first time using any earfun product. I’ve actually never heard of this brand before. I did some research on the brand before ordering, and read multiple glowing reviews about this product from tech magazines. I had no problem getting these earbuds to fit and stay in my ears. I appreciate that included are 3 extra sets of tips for a custom fit. I mainly use earbuds while I work out at the gym. These buds stayed in place through a few sweaty workouts so far, no problem. I’m no audiophile by any means, but I think the sound quality on these earfuns is great. The sound is crisp, and while listening to high energy hip-hop at the gym, I particularly enjoyed the level of bass these provided. As far as noise cancelling goes, I had these in when I first got them and my husband called my name 3 or 4 times and I didn’t hear a thing. I didn’t know he was trying to get my attention until I looked his way and saw his mouth moving.
I haven’t used these buds on a phone or video call yet. I’m a little nervous to do so, because the control functions are super tedious to me. Maybe I’ll get used to them over time, but as of now, I need to look at the instruction manual to do anything like control the volume, pause, or skip to another song. Once I feel more comfortable with the controls maybe I’ll try these out on a call.

I was able to connect these to Bluetooth and pair with my phone right away, through the Bluetooth setting on my iPhone. I haven’t downloaded the earfun app yet, that will be next. The earbuds themselves charge really quickly. I went for less than 10% charged to full charge in about 30 mins or so.

For the price, these earbuds sound amazing, stay connected, cancel noise, fit In my ears and charge quickly. The sound quality definitely far surpasses that of my other well-known brand of earbuds. I’d recommend these, with one main caveat: the controls are really tedious. If that is something you’re willing to be patient with and figure out, I’d recommend this set.

title: A few things that I wish I knew before I purchased
text:
My wife purchased these from Amazon from my Wishlist. I recently had a pair of wireless headphones that because of time and extensive use needed to be replaced. I purchased these because of good reviews, but have not been impressed by a few of the qualities that I wish I would have known before I purchased them. To be clear, the sound quality is great and noise canceling is good. The compatibility make this product not useable in my scenario.

First, you can not listen to the headphones and charge them at the same time. This is frustrating for me as I mainly use these headphones at work in front of my computer. I have to unplug them before I use them and remember to plug them in after I am done using them. If I do not turn them off manually, or I don't remember to plug them in, they will be out of charge the next day, and because you can not use them while charging, they can not be used until sufficient charge has been reached rendering them useless.

This leads to the second issue. I work on a Windows 11 machine, with a Bluetooth Dongle added. When you plug the headphones into a power source from an on state, the headphones automatically disconnect from the source. When you go to power the headphones back on, they do not automatically re connect when turned on. I have to manually remove the headphones from my Bluetooth settings, and re add them to be able to listen or use the mic, every day. I have a success rate of connecting the headphones to my bluetooth to my computer of about 50%.

These headphones only do this on my computer (I have tested on two and it doesn't work on both), and not my mobile phone, so if you plan on switching devices frequently, or only use them for a mobile phone, then they would work. If you plan on using them at a computer these features make it incredibly frustrating, so much so I have gone back to my broken headphones.

I reached out to support and they told me that my computer must be incompatible with the headphones and that they could not do anything but offer me a 15% discount to purchase another set of headphones. I am extremally disappointed especially being unable to listen while charging, and having to re connect my headphones to my computer every time I charge my them.

title: Impressive features that match many X670E motherboards.
text:
Received on January 27, 2023. Will update this review as needed.

I am currently using this with my Ryzen R9 7900X and have not experienced any issues. It boosts properly and its performance is stable with CL30 memory clocked at 6000Mhz.

It offers Gen5 PCIe and Gen5 m.2 so you can future proof your system if you ever intend to upgrade to a new GPU (current 40 and 7000 series GPUs are only Gen4 so don't worry about it for now). Likewise with the m.2 slots, it supports Gen5 so you can also upgrade your storage when needed.

It is an 8 layer board with excellent power delivery so it's got your basic overclocking needs covered as well.

Either this or the B650E AORUS MASTER which offers very similar features/specs at the same price point are great options, I highly recommend checking out the full specs of both and see which one offers what you want.

Also remember this, motherboards will not really make much of a difference for gaming so you can avoid overspending on this to increase your budget elsewhere. Buy them based on the features you want and if you are an avid overclocker who wants the absolute best, you should probably look at the X670E boards instead.

This board also has Clear and Reset CMOS options, which is an excellent feature if you ever mess up anything in the bios. You can always use that to go back to the base stable settings or install a fresh bios. It also has a Q-Code display for basic troubleshooting if your system is ever not booting properly.

Keep in mind that you can only use 3x m.2 drives if you want PCIe Gen5 on the first PCIe slot. Using other PCIe slots may also lower the bandwidth to Gen4 on the first one depending on the amount of lanes used.

Overall, with this board you are gonna get similar features to that of the mid-high X670E boards at a much lower price and not have any sort of performance issues, while at the same time, futureproofing your system so you can drop in a new gen5 GPU or gen5 m.2 storage in a few years.

title: it's a meh in my book. You Definitely get what you pay for.
text:
Well, it plugged in and powered up the device - so no complaints there.
The quality of the product is good with the respect the fit and finish is well executed.

What I liked.
1. It works
2. All of the plug in connections are solid.
3. I like the indicator light on the power supply showing there's power to the transformer. This is something that's missing from the OEM HP power supply. Personally, I think this is a really good thing!
4. Cable length is good at both ends - the power cord to the power supply and the cord coming out the other end that plugs into the computer.

What I don't like
1. The plastic incasing the transformer is less than desirable - it's hard and brittle. I can see a drop on a concrete floor would cause it to crack.
2. the cords are stiff out of the box - and isn't going to get better when cold. I'm hoping its just the insulation, and the wire isn't aluminum, or copper coated alumimum crap. My complaint stems around a pet peeve of mine. computer cabling that retains the packing shape - making it a challenge to get to lay flat.
3. Like the HP version, the power cord from the wall to the power supply uses a somewhat non standard type of end, that I call Mickey Mouse or bunny ears (connection). I'm sure there's a more technical name for it, but I have no idea what it is. A standard PC power supply cord would be a more desirable choice of power cable. Especially when I leave the power cord in a hotel somewhere; then try to find a replacement cable at my new location. It's a challenge - been there done that... Not fun. Especially when you've got a presentation the next day and 50% battery on the computer. Anxiety inducing!!

All in all it's OK especially for the price point. It most certainly is not a direct replacement for the power supply that came with my HP ZBook - but it's also about 75% less money. So you get what you pay for.

The materials are, in my mind, sub-par. The cord is

title: Waiting for 48 hours for support is for the birds
text:
While a lot of information is at the Blink.com website, I defy people new to Blink to actually FIND it. And you certainly don't want to wait for 48 hours to get an answer on how to set up your camera, do you? PLUS if your question is not specific enough expect to have to go back and ask again. This part of Blink really riles me. Even though Ring doesn't have the scheduling feature for camera on and off, at least they have decent support - probably wait in que for about 15 minutes at most.

Got the camera. Set it up with the help of friends, NOT Amazon. So then I buy a outdoor motion light with camera. Once again LITTLE to no instructions other than set your camera up. BUT it doesn't tell you how to now have BOTH cameras on the same scheduler with different names AND different schedules and perimeters. I know it's possible since I've seen friends that had front yard, back yard, etc. with their own schedules but I defy a new person to Blink to find HOW on the Blink site. I'm sure it's there but nothing I search on brings up what I'm looking for.

I then tried to set up the motion light with camera on it's own scheduler. They said, set up your camera, get the blue blinking light with a red light. I'll be damned if I can get a red light. I try to just set up the camera and it says I already have a camera set up - true enough. This is the SECOND camera. They also content that the motion lights will then be automatic. Don't know about that since it won't let me set up a second camera. Do I now have to have two accounts? WHY can't people provide DETAILED instructions 1) set up scheduler 1 2) set up camera 1 3) ADD a camera with motion lights (do I really need a second scheduler?).

I'll also mention that camera #1 (just a camera) is NOT good in the dark. Foggy and very difficult to see anything even changing the IR level.

I want to talk to a REAL person to address all the issues but apparently that's more than Amazon Blink is willing to do..

title: Useless during Texas 2021 Ice storm + more
text:
Bought this for my father, a construction worker, thinking he'll enjoy listening to music whenever he is outside or at a random job site back. Purchased in Nov. 2020 as a christmas present for him.

My family knew an ice storm was going to hit and I charged up all our power banks, phones, laptops and tablets so we can at least watch movies. This was one of the items I had charged up and these were the experiences we had during that storm:
-my father told me it had drained his phones battery (chalked it up to my magnetic charger so I gave the device the benefit of the doubt)
-Cranking the lever in hopes to get the radio to play (hours of cranking but for a few minutes of radio so it was useless)
-I didnt bother using the solar panel as I was disappointed in this device and we used other things. Pretty sure it was just a bad battery or something.

-------------------After the storm, I forgot about this device-------------------------------
I found it again and remembered it had a radio function. Started using this radio for our bird and he likes it. Thought it could just serve a purpose and we could use AAAs to power it (at this point I had no hope for the battery after this amount of time).
I charged up some batteries and insert them into the device. A few days later, thought I should see if they are still playing holiday music and turned it on. Dead. The batteries were already dead....... so guessing my unit was faulty or something.
Shame this cant be somewhat dependable for entertaining my bird....

---------------------------------------------conclusion----------------------------------------
1. If you buy this for emergencies... get a back up plan or something else...
2. Test it out, see if the battery, the lithium and AAAs, to see if it drains itself when OFF (cant believe this happens).
3. See how long you can have this working after using the crank.
3. Stay safe.
Apologies that I cannot give you the bare minimum to expect, my unit was just awful and feel like I should inform others to check theirs.

title: A LOT better than we ever expected.
text:
Amazon Glow was the device we never knew we wanted. We grew to love so much over the year plus we used it. We miss it terribly.

With this device, our boys could call their cousins and grandparents on their own, and have daily meaningful interactions. They had a blast with all the games! We all loved how they would use the Glow to stay connected with family that was out of state. Sure we could use phone and video calls to stay in touch, but it was the casual nature of the interactions like, "Hi Grandpa! Would you like to play a game?" that really made this platform shine!

The games were innovative, and the interfaces were really clever! How the Glow allowed them to see each other while playing on a shared gameboard was truly unique. A small video window wasn't fighting for screen space, and the "touchscreen" was so large and intuitive.

Other than long distance interactions, the Glow allowed brothers to play fun and challenging games with one another. One would get the Glow, and the other would get a tablet. This worked beautifully! They could play in different rooms, or at the same table. They were both entertained and played [relatively] peacefully with one another regularly. There were so many games! And new titles were ALWAYS being released! This was a unique platform that really provided truly unique opportunities.

We've used Osmo for years, and while that is a great platform for educational games, etc., but it is completely different from the Glow. The Glow allowed for real communication and connections, whereas Osmo is designed primarily for a single user at a single location.

There really isn't anything out there like the Glow for the regular consumer. I mean, sure, we could set up (2) devices, one for an online connected game, and another for a video call, but then you need two devices each, and getting all the connections to work reliably and consistently would be a bit of a pain and possibly a game of luck. Having everything in one consolidated and effective device made it so easy.

If they didn't wish to be the steward of this platform, for whatever reason, we wish Amazon would allow another private firm buy the technology and keep it going. We miss you Glow!

title: Airplane mode saves power
text:
First, I want to clear up some confusion about airplane mode. Looking at reviews, I see complaints about battery life and the assumption airplane mode uses power. Wrong! Airplane mode means wireless communication is OFF. When you drive a car, the overdrive off light comes ON to tell you that feature is OFF. On a Kindle or phone or any device with airplane mode, that means the WiFi and bluetooth are OFF. (With a phone that also turns off cellular communication.)

My previous Kindle was/ is the paperwhite 8th edition. That Kindle recently started having problems like light not coming on, random restarts. So I bought this to replace my old PW before it quit working. This rest of this review is comparing this 11 gen vs 8 gen.
This new model automatically puts books of same series into a folder. My 8gen simply showed all books in library. While reading there is an option to have a clock at top of screen, and time left to finish book at bottom. Time left is calculated from your reading speed. The adjustable light may be nice for some people, but for me I have it set to look like my old Kindle. There is a low power sleep option (device options, advanced). With this option enabled it takes a few seconds to wake up and use. I disabled that feature so I start reading when I want to. I have a third party ebook that takes about half a minute for 8gen to process, this new Kindle takes about 6 seconds. To transfer my content I plugged both Kindles into my PC. Both Kindles came up as external drives. I found the folders where content is stored, then copy and pasted. That is also how I load PDF and other third party content. My old kindle was bought December 2014 and got a lot of use. Battery life on old Kindle is still good, and I always use airplane mode except when downloading a new book.

Overall, this feels like a waste of money if old Kindle were reliable. The new features are not worth it otherwise. I was worried the smaller border would make it difficult to hold without touching the screen, but I have not had a problem. The border can be widened to reduce accidental touching. I am using my new Kindle with CoBak case. The one new feature i really like is the bigger screen with more text.

title: Great bluetooth adapter!
text:
When I first received this, I wasn't sure exactly how it could possibly work. How would you be able to pair with a device if this doesn't have a screen?

I guess, it was easier than I thought, from pairing mode, turn the speaker you want to connect to it on to pairing mode, and they just connect to each other. It was pretty simple.

Using it as a bluetooth receiver, it works great! Connect to it just like any other bluetooth speaker and it works exactly as you would expected.

As a nice bonus, it has TOSLink connectors for input and output.

They are nice enough to include a 3.5mm audio cable, a 3.5mm to rca adapter, a TOSLink cable, and a microUSB cable in the box.

For testing, I connected it to my computer speakers. I think I'm going to end up leaving it here!

I can now use my logitech desktop computer speakers over bluetooth! Works great!

I also tested bluetooth transmission to a bluetooth speaker. It transmitted my computer audio to the speaker quite easily.

Only downside that I don't like: It needs to be "on" for the bypass mode to work. The bypass mode allows you to connect the input directly to the output, so that you don't "lose" an existing connection by using this.

In bypass mode my computer speakers are directly connected to my speakers.

In rx mode, it turns my computer speakers into bluetooth speakers.

In tx mode, it adds bluetooth audio to my desktop, in hardware! No software bluetooth glitches!

Overall, this is a great little device that does exactly what it says it will do.

There is a light on the top that indicates it is "off" that is a battery "icon" but there does not appear to be a battery inside of this. A little bit of a strange design choice, but it doesn't change anything. At the time of this review it wasn't advertised as having a battery, so it's just an oddity.

title: Fantastic amp at a very reasonable price
text:
Based on numerous favorable reviews on YouTube, I bought this amp. The amp definitely lived up to the hype: it sounds amazing!

Douk Audio also manufactures the Aiyima T9 amp. The two amps are identical except for the name on the amp. Douk says they give priority to fixing issues on the units that bear the company name, so any issues mentioned in reviews for the Aiyima T9 are addressed first in the ST-01. Having seen the reviews for the T9, I can confirm that none of the issues mentioned by the reviewers showed up in my ST-01. In particular, there is no clicking noise, no problems with the remote, and no Bluetooth pairing issues.

The unit is solidly built with a sturdy metal chassis, quality knobs with no play or wiggle, and excellent inputs on the rear of the unit. I ran signals through the Bluetooth, RCA and USB inputs, and everything I ran through them sounded great.

The stock tubes sound really good, but I upgraded to the GE JAN 5654 tubes for a noticeable improvement. (See my separate review for these tubes.)

A couple of things to keep in mind:

* When powering on the unit, there's a scratching sound that lasts for 1-2 seconds and then goes away. I believe this is just the sound of the tubes lighting up. Again, the sound goes away almost immediately.
* The VU meter's needle might not move very much if the input signal is low. For example, if you're playing your iPhone through the Bluetooth connection, the VU meter needle barely moves unless the phone is fully cranked.
* Tip: Follow this suggestion when using the knob to turn the amp on and off: Press quickly to turn on the amp. Press and hold to turn off the amp. If you press and hold to turn on the amp, nothing happens. If you press quickly to turn off the amp, the input changes. When using the remote to turn on or off, no need to worry about quick or long press.

In summary, this is an excellent amp, especially at this reasonable price. Highly recommended.

(If you found my review helpful, please answer Yes below.)

title: Turning Head
text:
The Aomeisi 2K Security Camera is a 3MP 2.4G Wi-Fi security camera that is powered by a USB adapter. The power cord is a little over eight and a half feet long. That should be enough to feed the cord inside the house . It offers both cloud storage or local storage to a micro SD card. It can accept up to 128 GB cards. Be aware that if you choose to record to an SD card and the camera is outside, your SD card is also outside with the camera. The camera is PTZ, which means pan, tilt, zoom. The phone app allows you to rotate and tilt the camera, view live and recorded video, use it as an intercom, sound a siren and many other functions. The picture quality is pretty good and you can zoom the image 4X on your phone. You can also change the resolution through the app. This does affect how much storage is used for recordings. But the highest quality allows you to see better detail when you zoom in on a detail. I included a photo where I show the camera on the left, the resolution is set to QHD, which is the highest, there is a stuffed character 4'6" from the camera, the camera is zoomed all the way in on the character and the image is displaying on the phone in the rights side of the photo. This gives you some idea of the detail it is possible to achieve with this camera.
It also has night vision which is surprisingly clear. You can also set alerts up on your phone when it detects motion, but that was too much interruption for me.
The setup instructions are fairly straightforward, but some of the English is not translated well. I have to say they really tried to be complete and have mercy on folks with less than perfect vision. The booklet itself is 48 pages and the font is big and easy to read. There are lots of screen shots. And the App on your phone also can access "Quick Guide 1" which is 9 pages and "Quick Guide 2" which is 7 pages. So most of the instructions are right there on your phone. The process is simply following some prompts (many of which are full English voice prompts), scanning a few QR codes and enabling certain access to your phone resources.
I think this security camera offers a lot of functionality for the price

title: Amazing!!!
text:
At first, I was going to give this a four star rating because I was having connectivity issues but after some trial and error and experimenting I finally found a way of setting it up, so so that there are very little to no connectivity issues. (in case anyone with this system is interested once I plugged the LAN cable directly into the box all of the cutting out) Once I got that out of the way, the sound quality is absolutely unbelievable! It’s not just loud, but the clarity and different layers of sound that you can hear out of the speakers are unlike anything I’ve ever heard before! The only thing that could compare is the theater, the room I have my set up in is about 20 x 20 with flat walls in the acoustics are unbelievable so I would say it’s even better than the theater.

True home theater surround sound! I got the better subwoofer that they recommend and there is truly more sound and base that could come out of the speakers that I would want. The maximum I’ve ever turned it up to us about 67 out of 100. It just blows my mind that they could go so loud. I do not have the use of a center speaker, so I was worried about voice clarity not coming through. Just the speakers by themselves do not need a center speaker at all, no matter what the volume is the voice clarity of any show, sports, or movie is perfectly very easy to hear. My last sound bar sounded great, but I cannot make out the voices unless I had subtitles which is very inconvenient.

The only other thing I could possibly think of as a negative is the fact that you cannot control the volume of each speaker individually, which really is unnecessary if you’re sitting directly in the center of the room. But I am not sitting in the center of the room, my is just slightly to the left of center and there are some adjustments that you can make, but I can’t quite get it just right. Maybe with some updates down the road that might be a possibility but for now it’s still MUCH MUCH better than any sound bar or home theater surroundsound system I’ve ever owned, and I’ve owned several of the top-of-the-line home theater, surround sound systems, and nothing even comes close!!!

title: How to review perfection?
text:
I have been in search of the prefect IEM for a long time now, even giving up on the format for a while. My first real foray into the IEM world was with the ATH-CKW1000ANV and they were where I found the sound I was looking for but it had numerous issues and led to the JVC HA-FXZ200 and these were exceptional but required using the tipple flange tips to get a great seal and the bass that would dig into the basement. After looking at a ton of reviews I made a major investment into the FIIO fh7... and was thoroughly disappointed. While a technically accurate headphone it was not one I got much enjoyment out of as it became sibilant at moderate volumes. In short they were not the headphone for me despite being the flagship at the time. Looking back I should have picked up the FH5 as it seems to have the musicality I am looking for. So buyers remorse is kicking in hard but FIIO throughs me a bone and announces that there is yet a higher end model coming and I do my best *shut up and take my money* and picked these up on launch day.... The presentation is lovely and everything feels like money well spent. The interchangeable 1/8" 2.2mm and 4.4mm are a boon and must be praised. And speaking on the cable I give it full marks it looks lovely and feels good in the hand.

On to sound. These are it. This is what music should sound like to me when I put these on with no eq or trickery. They rock and crank up without any hint of sharpness or overdrive. One of my favorite test tracks is Finks live troubles what you are in. In this you get an acoustic performance that you can hear the strings plucked while the acoustic bass guitar vibrates your eardrums but never gets muddled and the box drum is clear. All summed it is the best experience I have had to date and I set the bar high here with the headphone corner defended by the meze elites and the speaker corner defended by my legacy signatures. The FIIO's pack all that fighting power in a manageable price tag.

Ear bliss with no down sides... would be a six out of five if I could but five or five stars will suffice.

title: Not durable
text:
I have owned many Bluetooth headphones of this style, and this set has begun to deteriorate much more quickly than the others. I can typically expect around 12 months of good use out of most of them, with some surprising me and lasting a few months longer than that. Typical failure mode is broken internal connections causing intermittent or total sounds loss in one or both sides. It seems to be a general flaw in the design across the board. However, this set has already started to show signs of malfunction within just 3 months. While wearing them, slight movements will cause the sound/signal to cut out or sound staticky. This is the normal precursor to failure of sound in one side. It's a sign that there is an internal connection coming loose, and movement can break/reestablish the connection.

Generally speaking these were not that great even when they worked. The sound quality, range, and battery life are all about average. It also suffers the same design flaw as all others of this style where the charging port cover gets in the way of the charging cable.

The biggest annoyance is the significant delay in "long press" functionality. Most of the headsets I have owned have had the same setup for long press, where it takes between half a second and 3/4 of a second for the headset to register the long press and send the command. However, this set takes about twice as long, somewhere between 1 and 1.5 seconds. If you are trying to fast-forward through a song or podcast or something, it's totally useless. Repeated long press commands take excruciatingly long. I almost always end up stopping what I'm doing, taking my phone out, and using the UI commands on the phone instead. It's a hassle, but way less of a hassle than trying to use the long press feature on this headset.

The one feature that I really loved was how quiet the button clicks are. Most headsets make a very loud clicking noise when you press the buttons, but this headset is very quiet. I really like that feature, and it's a hard feature to shop for or find in other products.

All in all, even if this hadn't started to break down so quickly, I would not consider buying them again.

title: Best $99 I’ve Spent
text:
I’ve been looking to upgrade my iBasso DC06 which I recently learned was a duo ESS Saber DAC. It actually sounds amazing with my LCD-XC, but then I don’t want to bring those to work with me. So, I’ve been using my modified Audeze Sine - I replaced the ear pads to over ear pads as well as the stock cable. So when I came across the Hiby FD3 and saw that it had duo ES9028Q2Ms for under a hundred dollars, I knew this might be worth a try

It’s a lot smaller than I thought and machined out of a single block aluminum from the looks of it. Perfect for hooking up to my iPad Pro when I travel. Unfortunately, my go to audio cable wouldn’t work. Bummer. I tried other cables, but you need to use a Apple certified mfi cable. The DAC needs it. Not the iPad.
