So, I used the supplied USB C to USB C cable. It’s nice and short which is perfect if you’re using a laptop, but not an iPad that sits on a Magic Keyboard or a magnetic stand

I’ll have to look around for a longer Apple mfi cable to remedy this

Short comings aside, the cable is fairly good albeit a tad short for my purposes. My LCD-XC didn’t sound great, but not bad either. However, my Audeze Sine sounded amazing! It’s what they call synergy and it’s perfect! At least for me. Wonderful clarity without harshness. Nice timbre. Digs low. And the best part is the seperation! Instruments are just layered and fully in their own space, much more than my LCD-XC which surprised me. My search for the perfect traveling DAC is finally over….sort of

One thing I noticed is that the FD3 seems a bit power hungry. I don’t use it for prolonged periods so it may not be a problem in the long run. But for now, I’m happy as a clam

title: Pitaka iPad Pro MagEZ Folio 2 offers some unique design features
text:
I've been using Pitaka cases for my iPhones for years, and consider them the best in the industry. The new MagEZ Folio 2 iPad Cover shows promise of being in the same league. It is well-engineered, has a fine fit & finish, and is highly functional.

Design:

It is easy to compare this to previous Origami-style cover for iPads or Kindles, but this has a number of significant differences. The design is simple and uncomplicated, unlike competing brands that have very involved folds and reticulations: the Pitaka has just four panels. Its camera cut-out will fit older iPad models that have a single camera lens or more modern ones that have three camera lenses.

Materials:

Inside is a soft microfiber surface that will not scratch the back or glass of the iPad. The outside cover is a polyurethane material that is not only sturdy and well built but has a leather-like surface that makes it easy to hold without that common slippery feel. The strong magnets hold the iPad securely in place.

Features:

The iPad enclosures you buy are usually divided into three styles: covers, cases, and keyboard combinations. Unique among cover-style iPad holders like this one: an Apple Pencil strap to hold it in securely. Without the Apple Pencil attached, it will keep the cover secure from accidentally opening. The cover provides instant-on/instant-off capabilities, expected of magnetic covers; the strap adds additional safety. There are four configurations of this cover for common uses of an iPad: 34° tilt for drawing or typing, 53° tilt for landscape streaming, 57° tilt for Facetime calls, and 62° tilt for portrait document reading.

Summary:

Pros:

- Well designed
- Quality material
- Highly functional

Cons:

- This is a nitpick: The QR code on the paper wrapping over the package shipping content does not take the user to the YouTube video for this product but to other Pitaka cover videos. But you don't need it, the wrapping has pictures to show you all the features.

title: Nice, light bag for tech essentials, but rather pricey
text:
I use this bag to transport a Surface Book and a 15.6" USB monitor. It holds them both, reasonably well protected, with just barely enough extra room for the Surface power supply, a few pens, and accoutrements such as cable and a slide clicker. That pretty much exhausts its room. It's not very thick front to back.

It makes up for that by not adding much weight. If you're trying to lighten your load as you carry your computer, this is a pretty good option. The pockets are sufficient for the sort of things you'll probably carry. The front has two zippered pockets, but no internal organization in either one (no pen loops or subpockets for things like business cards). When it arrived, that section also held the shoulder strap. The back has a snap pocket which is ideal for boarding passes, stowing a phone during airport security, etc. The photos for the product don't show that, so I included a picture of it.

The internal zippered section has two subsections. One is well padded and my Surface Book fits nicely there. The other is a bit wider, and holds my 15.6" monitor. That section also has a couple of subpockets, about 6"x8".

You'll probably need to install the shoulder strap, because this bag is missing one feature I would expect on a high end bag: a fixed strap on the back that fits over luggage handles. Since the bag is narrow and the bottom isn't particularly flat, it doesn't balance easily on top of a wheeled luggage piece.

Without that feature, and all things considered, I consider it somewhat pricey. It's in the territory of high-end designer bags, but it doesn't really fit in that league. The new version of my older Kenneth Cole polyester bag, for example, is significantly lower in price, while having more high-end features.

I won't be able to assess durability for awhile, but it seems sturdy and well put together. The ballistic nylon seems tough enough to last, I think. So I expect to use it for a while.

If weight is your primary concern, and you are sticking to the tech basics when you travel, this might be what you want.

title: If you want a billboard in your bedroom…
text:
About eight months ago, the Echo Show 5 was on sale, so I decided it might be nice to replace some of my Echo Dots with Shows. I mostly thought it would be cool to have a device that does everything an Echo does and also displays the time. I was so naive. As many others have commented, the Show’s display cycles continuously among a variety of suggestions, sponsored ads and other…b.s. If you go into settings and disable every last one of the “home screen content” types as well as “rotate continuously,” this reduces but does not eliminate such things from displaying periodically.

Also—and I should’ve seen this coming but didn’t—on an Echo device with a screen, every time you tell it to do anything, the screen changes to reflect your command; if you say, “Echo, turn on light,” the Show displays the light’s status for a brief period. And of course if you tell it to play audio of any kind (e.g., radio or your music provider), it displays what’s playing; then if you want to see what time it is, you have to say, “Echo, home.” Maybe that seems logical, but on the other hand, if, for example, I’m *hearing* NPR, I don’t need to *see* a screen telling me that NPR is playing.

On top of that, the Show 5 is very poor at doing the one essential Echo function—hearing. Similar to the experience of other commenters, I can be five feet from a Show 5, face it and say a command, and the Echo Dot located 20 feet away in another room will respond.

I’m sure many people aren’t bothered by the display issues, but they really bug me. Just not what I had in mind. Between that and the failure-to-respond issue, within a couple of months I wondered how long it might be before I unplugged the Shows and put back my Echo Dots. Well, that finally began yesterday. I’m looking forward to a restored sense of visual peace in the rooms in my home ;)

title: Huge improvement over a wired Android Auto connection
text:
I have a 2018 Subaru Legacy and no matter what cable I used, my AA either wouldn't connect or would disconnect often at the slightest tug or movement of the cable. I've wanted a wireless adapter like this and have been extremely happy so far. The device itself is a lot smaller than I thought it was from the pictures. It's about the size of a coaster and extremely light. It comes with a usb-a to usb-c and a usb-c to usb-c cable, so you have options depending on your car's inputs. Be mindful that the cables are short, but if you are plugging it in and tucking it into a compartment, it's fine. You never have to really unplug this device or access it, so it's not a big deal.

First time connecting it, the device needs to be connected to your phone via BT. It shows up as smartboxXXXX and pretty much after that, your phone should connect within a minute or so of entering the car. Make sure you aren't connecting to your car's BT. It's not instantaneous as others have said, as the device presumably is booting up when the car powers on... but for me, the time it would take to remove my phone from a pocket, connect it to the USB cable and then have it load up... its not much different. The big win here is that I haven't had it disconnect at all while driving. I can put my phone anywhere, even leave it in my pocket and the AA stays on. Be mindful if you have 2 primary drivers and you both BT connect to the device, when you both get in the car, one of your phones will connect to it first. You'd have to "disconnect" from the device and my assumption is that the other will then connect.

Updating the device was a little clunky, but following the instructions I did figure that part out within about 10 mins or so. I don't anticipate doing that often, as they say if its working not to worry about it. Customer Service is phenomenal. They emailed me within 24 hours of placing the order, and I joked that I hadn't even received it yet. I did write back to them about updating, and they send me detailed directions with pictures.

title: Might be 4 start if didn't advertise as Auto Wake/Sleep
text:
This is a good looking case. Fit is fine. Though "stand" is different than the kind which folds in 3 pieces to form a triangle, it does work and might even be better than the 3-fold kind because you get a bit more choice in angle. The surface you angle the bottom against is grippy enough to keep the ipad tilted up at several different angles.

The two biggest problems are:
1) it claims to have a feature it does NOT have - the Auto Wake/Sleep when cover shuts. There is not even the slightest bit of magnetic charge ANY where.
2) if you write to inquire, though the company, Aippdo, responded VERY quickly, and seems to want to do the right thing, they just don't express themselves well enough in English to really be able to provide good support.

I'll paste in my communications with them below: My recommendation is to pass on this if you care about the auto wake/sleep function:
My question:
This beautiful cover does not have the wake/sleep functionality that the title and description describe. The display does not wake up or go to sleep the cover doesn't have even a hint of magnetic attraction to hold it closed.
I would love a replacement if someone could assure me that they are going to get me one where they are SURE this functionality works. From the reviews it seems many others say it doesn't work but some say it does so maybe you just have a quality assurance problem and I got a bad one. But if you can't be sure you're going to send one that fixes it then I would rather not waste my valuable my time going around again with another one that doesn't have automatic sleep/wake.
Please let me know. Thank you!

Their answer:
Respect customers
hello
We have tested this product. There is no such problem at present. Thank you very much for your feedback. We will review the function of the product. Here, we solemnly apologize to you. You can pick up a new product. Or you have a better idea to offer us, we will actively take it. Thank you for your email. Let us find the deficiency. We will correct it immediately. Thank you very much.

title: Use on the Nikkor 200mm f/4 Micro ED Lens
text:
I am very pleased with the way that this diffuses the flash for Macro (Micro) photography--very simple and easy to use, and gets great results! I really like it, for getting great soft lighting that looks quite natural and beautiful.
This did not fit the 62mm threaded UV filter (65mm outside diameter) that I keep on the front of my Nikkor (Nikon) 200mm Micro ED lens--too small for the diffuser to grip it. It works fine on the barrel/focus ring of the lens, which is 76mm (or 3" OD.) And to angle it forward (which I prefer,) works well--to have the front of the opening of the diffuser grabbing the top of the UV filter, and the back of the opening grabbing the focus ring. The trouble with having it gripping the focus ring, (which is the majority of the front end of the lens,) is that the diffuser rotates with the focus ring, and has to be adjusted back to where it belongs. When it is angled forward, it doesn't take much force to keep it from rotating with the focus ring, but is a hassle. The filter on my lens doesn't rotate or move with focusing, (when I manually rotate the focus ring.) My solution was to put a little piece of adhesive-backed velcro at the top of the opening of the diffuser, and the other part of the velcro threaded into the UV filter, (I left the wax paper adhesive backing on it, and caught the overhanging wax paper into the filter threads.) That way it is easy to remove the diffuser when I don't want to use it, and it holds the diffuser from rotating as I manually focus.
BTW, on my Tokina 100mm ATX Pro macro lens, this fits fine on the focus ring, (75mm, and with the same rotation problem, and being back from the front of the lens as I do a close-focus,) but doesn't fit on the front of the lens, which is 65mm OD, (55mm filter threads... nor the extended barrel, which is 58mm.) To use this diffuser on my Tokina, I would use step-up rings, and maybe a 72mm UV filter for the diffuser to have a level surface to grab onto.

title: Almost perfect…ALMOST
text:
This hub stand is a versatile and convenient docking station that offers a range of useful features. With the 11 different ports, including HDMI 4K 60Hz, 1000M Ethernet, 100W PD, USB-C and 2 USB-A 5Gbps data ports, it provides plenty of options for connecting your devices. I used it with my Samsung Galaxy Note 20 (using DeX), my HP work laptop, my budget Acer laptop and an older Windows 10 tablet that I kept around. It worked very well with all of them. The tablet was a little laggy, but it’s older, with a USB 3.0 port (I used an adapter) and only 2GB of RAM. Still, even with the under-powered tablet it was usable.

One of the standouts features of this hub is its phone holder, which makes it easy to keep your phone or smaller tablet within reach while you work. The holder is adjustable and can accommodate a variety of phone sizes, making it a great addition to any workspace. I didn’t (and wouldn’t recommend) use the stand part with my laptops.

The HDMI 4K 60Hz output is another highlight of this hub. Using a variety of devices, I still found the picture quality to be excellent. The ethernet port is also a nice feature for those who need a reliable and fast internet connection, though I only tested this once for functionality as our home is pretty much entirely wireless.

However, one drawback of this hub is that it doesn't come with a power cable at its price point. This was a bit disappointing, as I had to purchase a separate adapter to supply overall power to the unit. It would have been nice if the manufacturer had included a cable to make it a more complete package, particularly at this price point. Still, I think the belief is that you’ll just use your USB-C laptop adapter (assuming you have one and that it’s USB-C).

Overall, the USB C Hub Stand is a great choice for anyone looking for a versatile and convenient docking station. It offers a wide range of useful ports and features, including a phone holder and HDMI 4K 60Hz output. The only downside is the lack of a power cable at its price point.

title: A Quality Mid-Range Webcam
text:
There are typically a couple national brands I look for when I consider a webcam, but when I stumbled across this webcam I decided to give it a try.

This webcam by GUSGU is a 1920x1080p High Def Cam that offers a beauty touch ring light, noise reduction microphone, built-in privacy cover, and is compatible with most major video apps including the ones I primarily use - Zoom, Facebook, and Teams. At this price-point, I was expecting a more mid-range experience and that's largely what the camera delivered. While you can definitely get better HD experiences, you're typically going to pay more for that experience.

While the webcam comes with a noise reduction microphone, I found the microphone to be the webcam's weakest point. While it's likely fine for conference calls or conversations, it's not what I would consider to be recording quality in any way. While most podcasters wouldn't dream of using a webcam microphone for a podcast, even entry-level recordings will likely sound a bit inferior here. This is true even when compared to similarly priced webcams from other brands.

On the flip side, I'm a fan of the beauty touch ring light. It's a nice feature and it works quite well here. It added a nice quality to my webcam experience. I live in a rather dark house and this really improved the quality of my video.

I was happy with video quality. I'll admit my needs tend to be rather basic. I would say, however, that even with this being an HD cam the quality wasn't that much higher than my several years old HP webcam. However, it is an improvement and I'm still overall pleased.

This webcam weighs about eight-ounces and is fairly easy to move around. It has a pretty solid base and I had no glitches with any of the video formats I tried.

Overall, I'd say this is a good but not great webcam. It's likely just fine for everyday use, however, those looking to do more professional video work may want to explore upper-range options. As I haven't had this camera for a long time, I can't speak to durability but I will definitely update my review if that becomes a concern. For now, 4-stars feels absolutely perfect.

title: Easy to use; works well for many applications!
text:
Summary: Good general purpose walkie talkies. Range is enough for typical use cases. The included rechargeable batteries have good longevity. Worth it, in my opinion.

I like their bright colors. The neon green and orange in particular are hard to lose. I've dropped the orange one twice and had no problem finding it.

These were very handy on an open campsite. It makes it quick and easy to reach family and friends without the need for a cell phone. In an area where cell signal can be hit or miss, these are a great replacement.

I've also used these on residential job sites as an easy way to coordinate wire pulls. They haven't had any issues with the signal dropping out across large homes, even if one is in a crawlspace or other enclosed space.

They're handy in airsoft as well. They have a simple interface so when I hand one to a new person they quickly know how to use it. It's easy to set them up and get going. I haven't had any issues with the range in a moderately wooded area over about a mile and a half. One of the radios sometimes gets more feedback than the others.

The battery life is good, a bit above what you'd expect. The rechargeable batteries are much appreciated; you'd be eating up a lot of AA batteries with each of these walkie-talkies taking three batteries at a time. And the charging port isn't some special or proprietary port; it's a normal micro USB (OTG) connection. This is the one before USB C started being used for all smartphones, so you probably have an old phone charger laying around that would work.

The included lanyards have a quick disconnect feature that was cool at first but seemed like a weakness when in use. The plastic quick-disconnect feels like it would break easily. Ultimately I preferred the clips as it keeps the radio at the ready and not flopping around when walking.

At the time of writing this review, the price of these walkie talkies was $59.49 including a 15% coupon. I think that price is good for what you're getting. Four handsets with rechargeable batteries, good range, good battery life, easy to use.

title: Decent but has one annoying problem
text:
[[VIDEOID:d1bf247d924dd2de137e6545efd76e18]] I use my laptop with external monitors and a bunch of accessories so I was looking for a solution that would let me attach all of my monitors and accessories through my single USB-C port. This RVP+ was almost the perfect solution but alas, it has at least one issue that I can’t get over.

Here’s what I like and don’t like about this USB hub:

****************************************************
LIKES

*Multiple Connections- This hub includes multiple connection ports for almost every accessory I can think of. It has two HDMI ports so I can plug in both of my monitors, a network port which I can run directly to my router, and multiple USB and USBC inputs for all of my accessories. All that goes through a single USB-C cable into the back of my laptop so it's nice and streamlined.

*Small Profile- this has a really small footprint so it doesn't take up a lot of space on my desk.

*Power Option- I like that this thing includes an additional USB-C port that accepts a power input so I can still charge my laptop while I'm using it.

*Simple Setup- everything was plug and play on this hub with no setup or additional software required. I didn't need to install any drivers and everything was automatically recognized as soon as I plug it into the hub.

****************************************************
DISLIKES

*Missing Monitor After Sleep- My only pet peeve with this hub is the fact that it seems to disconnect a monitor after going to sleep. Once my computer goes to sleep and I wake it back up, only one of my two monitors comes back up, no matter how long I wait. In order to get the second monitor to show back up I need to unplug it and plug it back in. I haven't found a way around this and that's a big enough annoyance for me to dock it a star.

****************************************************
Overall I’m pleased with this hub and its functionality even with the monitor issue.

title: Amazing paired! Jazz & electro rock bliss!
text:
[[VIDEOID:e50a8d626073f767b23ef78a0ddd0212]] Be sure to not have mono selected in your settings for stereo vs mono. There is a setting in Bluetooth that supposedly adjusts levels better for headphones vs. speakers as well. Theses things are great for the money and I expect them to bloom nicely with time. Stereo is the way to go for big room sound with these relatively small speakers. Pocket size, yet it fills up your large pockets for creative wearables. These have a well balanced sound and can get loud if needed. EQing is typically needed with any small speakers at higher levels. These can pass a bass heavy if placed in corners but are not quite sub levels. I bet these would be outstanding with a small sub for a bedroom to small studio entry level applications for people on a budget. Don’t underestimate a bunch of these hooked up with Alexa’s and a Alexa sub for whole home entry level yet deeper applications. It’s quality budget solutions of all kinds, like for office listening or therapeutic centers. These in stereophonic mode is where they will shine rather than mono applications. Theses are clean speakers so far with just a weekend amount of use. These have a full sound even at 50% levels without a EQ applied. These also sound pretty good at lower levels and with all kinds of different music or vocal listening. Fantastic for traveling and wanting a broad stereo sound field at a easy no brainer price. These are impressive for newcomers as well as for audiophiles if hooked up correctly. Can’t wait to try a vacuum tube preamp setup with a sub for the experience. These are fun speakers because they are easy to carry, yet loud enough to turn heads:

Get them before they Jack the price up! There that good just listening to Latin jazz and dub techno sounds amazing so far at moderate levels, it’s bathroom filling or any room I’m sure. Excellent Clean sound way above it’s asking price so, & not everything is meant to be cranked even though it can especially in closed quarters,. So be considerate to even yourself

Again Make sure u experience them in stereo with phone settings accurately set to stereo as well.

Enjoy! 🎶 !

title: For cloning and hard drive access
text:
Docking stations like The Wavlink Dual Bay Docking Station help me do TWO things easier and faster: duplicate existing drives and access drives not in an external casing (like hard drives removed from laptops and desktop machines) with an existing computer using an external USB interface.

GENERAL OPERATIONS: A power supply plus into a standard receptible and into the back of the red unit. There is an external on/off switch on the back of the unit which is important: the hard drives I have were formally the internal units of desktop and laptop machines with an active operating system. When connected to my computer, I want the computer to run off the op system on the hard drive inside my computer. So I let it boot up before turning on the Wavlink unit.

The area for inserting the hard drives can handle my 2.5 inch and 3.5inch hard drives. It takes more than a few tries to get that larger hard drive seated correctly which was a little frustrating but not unexpected. I got it eventually.

The connection on the back of the Wavlink is the old-style square USB connecter that printers and other accessories used when USB was first introduced.

This unit states USB3 to Sata BUT I've never seen a USB3 speed from a unit using the square USB connector. I believe you can interface with the USB3 using an adaptor but you will end up with USB 1 speeds when connected through USB to a computer.

Compact and fits easily next to the computer.

ACCESSING HARD DRIVES
Both hard drives plugged in were recognized and files accessible IF the drives were valid. I was able to transfer files to and from the hard drives, the purpose for which I wanted the unit. I tried an SSD drive and nothing showed. To be fair, I also couldn't access it or have it recognized through internal desktop connections either.

HARD DRIVE DUPLICATION
I was not able to test this function.

EVALUATION
For what I was able to test, this is a reasonable but not especially fast connection for a computer. Reliable and stable. It would just be nice to offer higher speed file transfer.

title: Excellent bundle of joy!
text:
Update 03-21-2023: When I went to register this camera with Canon I found out that even though it is an American model number (T8i vs 850D or Kiss...) it is still considered "Grey Market" and was sold from a non-authorized retailer. Because of this, it can not be registered with Canon. It also does not have any warranty protection from Canon. We did buy the extended warranty that Amazon offered, upon purchase, so it doesn't really matter to us, but it might matter to others. We still really like the camera and have had no problems with it, so far. Just want to give others a heads up on what to expect.

When we ordered this Canon EOS Rebel T8i camera bundle and there were no reviews. There was one spot in the item description that I didn’t see until after I ordered it that mentioned the camera was the “import model” and I didn’t want that. So I was nervous about what I would get. I took a chance and I am so glad I did. I received an actual T8i not the import model 850D. The amount of items that came in this kit is incredible. It will take me forever to learn how to use them. Everything seems to be good to great quality with the exception of the tripod. That feels lightweight, but chincy. It would be good if you were hiking or doing a ton of walking with it and wanted something easy to carry. It did come with a carrying backpack type bag. Over all I am very happy with this bundle.

I was also happy with the size of the T8i. The talk all over the internet is how much better the mirrorless cameras are and that they can be made smaller than DSLR cameras. This Rebel is the perfect size. I was afraid it was going to be a monster the way everyone talked about DSLR cameras, but it isn’t. I don’t know how you would handle a camera smaller with a big telephoto lens on it. I know this might not be the most up and coming camera, but I prefer DSLRs to the mirrorless fad that is happening now. They are tried and true and been around for decades. Can’t wait to learn how to use my new camera.

title: Literally worse than the A12 at everything, including radiator fan
text:
What is the point of these fans?

These are high static pressure fans, meaning they are good for radiators and bad for case fans. Yet these perform worse than the NF-A12 at both, even when restricted to the F12's lower RPM of 1500. These F12's perform slightly better at incredibly low (sub-500) RPM's but gets outclassed as soon as the RPM's ramp up. Not to mention the A12's also go to a higher RPM so they work even better if you're okay with the increased noise. If your case can fit 30mm width fans you can even get the T30's that are better than even the A12's.

So what's the point of these? Noctua themselves sell a fan that beats these in every category for the same price. These are old, outdated fan designs and Noctua's newer A12's just left these in the dust and then the T30's left all Noctua fans in the dust right after.

These were the cause of massive temps in my Dan H2O. Specifically, both my NVME drives (with heatsinks) were hitting 83c and my 4090 was thermal throttling at 83c constantly, even with a 70% power limit. In a small case like the H2O, a lot of the stagnant heat from the GPU is expected to be carried away by the radiator fans, but these just weren't up to the task. I swapped to the T30's and immediately lost 15c on my nvme drives and my GPU doesn't go pats 75c at 70% power. This test was done over a 3 hour gaming session btw, not just surface level tests. I have much lower 53c idle temps on my 7700x as well and at 90w limit I max out at 75c. My CPU temps went down slightly, they weren't much worse with the F12's, but all of my other parts dropped by ~10c.

These are just a nonsensical buy. I wish I knew that before wasting $50 on a pair and being outside the return window. I don't even know what to do with these. My advice is to either get A12's like everyone else, or better yet T30's if you can fit them.

title: Bright picture, but fails in several other areas
text:
At first glance, this is a nice package with positives such as, included projector screen and built in Bluetooth. The included screen is nice, the picture is bright, the built in speakers work fairly well, and it's not too noisy for this price of projector at about 45 dB. So what's the problem? There's 4 for me that really disappoint.
1. The first one I quickly found was adjusting the screen size. Depending on how far the projector is placed from the projected surface, the size of the picture changes. These projectors have a feature that allow you to adjust the picture size so you don't have to physically move the projector back and forth. This has that feature, but it requires you to go into a menu to adjust the size percentage. Unfortunately, you cannot see the results of the percentage change without backing out of menus and going into others. As you adjust the percentage, the screen size does not change. Exiting to the main screen, nothing has changed either. This change has no impact on the main home screen. The only way to see if the percentage you selected is correct is to basically start watching a movie, which requires a few clicks through the menus. This is frustrating and inefficient.
2. The second thing, and likely the biggest issue, is you cannot focus the entire screen. You can get one area focused, say the center, but as you move away from the center everything becomes out of focus.
3. Thirdly, this does not work with all portable USB drives. It worked with an older Western Digital drive, but not a newer Seagate drive. I verified that both worked on another, older, projector I own.
4. No case included. This is not a problem or an issue, but it would have been nice to include a case for this price.

The picture quality is decent, the colors are good, and the picture is bright, but I cannot recommend this projector due to the above mentioned issues. The biggest issue is probably the focus. When watching movies it's not too noticeable if you try to average out the focus across the screen. However, if you're using this projector for something like PowerPoint presentations, then it's unusable as you cannot focus text very well.

title: Just fine for my use
text:
Purchased this unit for my 2004 Silverado. Had no issues installing it and was happy the wire color codes were the same as my adapter. Helped speed up the install. Fit into a standard car stereo opening with ease (had chevy face adapter from older CD stereo). Operation was a different story.

The unit has a display that is always active. If playing a MP3 it wants to scroll the song data continuously. If you press clock it will stay there unless you press forward/backward then back to scrolling. I find this irritating. It wont just show you the song number or time, has to give the folder name it found the song in "ROOT" followed by MP3 name. Also requires FAT32 where my other Chevy radio's work with NTFS. Not major deal breaker there. I did have some MP3's that were glitchy when playing, changing to another MP3 and back made it play correctly (software issue?) The volume using good speakers is very sufficient for the truck (I also have a small 8" sub). While the volume is good there is no default volume so if your MP3's are weak and you turn it up to compensate and then return to the radio you can be blasted out of the truck. Bluetooth does work, connect my phone with ease and streamed music without issue. Then upon returning to the vehicle it was no longer connected and required me to reconnect the phone. Bit aggravating there. I have not tried any of the speaker phone/voice capabilities.

Pros:
Price (considered in this review)
Easy Install (about as easy as you can get)
Wires properly color coded
Good power to speakers
Does play from a FAT32 file system
FM and AM Reception was very good!

Cons:
Volume does not compensate for the input (watch out)
Some minor issues so far with some MP3's files
Bluetooth required reconnecting upon return to vehicle (not automatic)
Display continually scrolling data
Not NTFS comnpatable

Overall, considering the price and performance, a good deal.

title: I love these headphones
text:
These headphones really have exceeded my expectations. What I like about them is that they fit over and in my ear well, have great sound, and the case shows actual battery life.

The fit is nice, although not perfect. I have small ears, so I've been looking for headphones that will fit snugly into my ear and not fall out easily. These headphones fit that bill. The over-the-ear part is soft and not too tight (I would actually say very loose), so it doesn't push against the back of my ear and cause any discomfort. For me, it's just enough to do the job it was designed for. Inside the ear, it's not perfect. I do feel a little discomfort after wearing them for a while, but not enough that would make me hate them. I can adjust them from time to time to relieve the little discomfort there is.

As for the sound quality, I would say it's really good. It has a good range from the treble to the bass. I adjusted my phone's equalizer to see how the sound quality pairs against the different options and I like what I hear. The bass hits deep enough for headphones, better than others I have used. The treble is good and helps balance out the bass in the music. I was impressed by the sound quality of these headphones.

The case is a little bigger than other headphone cases, but not overbearingly big. If you were to carry it in your pocket, it would be noticeable. What I love about the case though, is that it displays an actual number to show the battery life. You don't have to guess based on some lines, you know when it needs to be recharged. When you place the headphones in their "pocket" within the case, they fall right into place. With other headphone cases, you sometimes have to adjust the headphones in position to charge correctly.

All in all, I do love these headphones! They have good battery life, in the headphones and the case, so they will last a long time. I have been using mine, on average, a couple of hours a day and I've had them for 4 days now. I would definitely recommend them!

title: Not worth the amount it selling for
text: The frame arrive within two days. They shipped it without a cover box. It was shipped in the regular frame box. Just like you buy out the store. It came with the frame , remote control with batteries, extra frame (brown), warranty card, cable, wall mount, stand with screws, jump drive with preload stuff, and power cord. A person has to download SSA Wi-Fi Frame App. This app is easy to download but some what hard to figure out. You have to use the remote control to do anything dealing with the frame. Hate that it’s not touch screen. It would go much quicker and easier if it was. Trust me I know. I have a 10.1 digit frame. I had a hard time getting my hometown setup on the frame. It was a huge problem with getting my wifi to stay connected to it. I just use my hotspot from my cellphone to connect to the frame. Finally get account from phone and frame connected together it was a task uploading pictures. The app sometimes won’t send the pictures to the frame. It only load 50 pictures at one time. Some pictures I had to try three to four times. After working with the setting in how you want the pictures to scroll and how fast you want them to come and go; it was okay. This frame again isn’t touch screen, not motion sensor, it won’t allow you to zoom on one picture. It will zoom all the pictures. You can change the angles on the screen. However, you can’t crop any pictures. All in all it’s can be a headache and still I wasn’t satisfied with the settings of the frame. My 10.1 $159 did more than the 21.5 $299 frame. The most things I love about this frame is it’s big, has the ability to play music with or without the pictures, you got an alert, and calendar. The calendar screen is beautiful. So if you want something that feel like a dinosaur and make you work to put pictures on it and love using the remote than this frame is for you. Time is what you will need to use this frame. I still had to use my iPad to send the pictures to the frame because my phone using the app would freeze up or automatically log me out or be super slow in sending the pictures.

title: My 4 year review
text:
I’ve been using this strap for for years now & on two different cameras. It’s made very sturdily, but in my opinion too much so as I’ll describe. A few revisions could & should be made by Peak Design, especially at this price point. When I first got this strap I would‘ve quickly given it 5 stars, but after a few years of use it pretty much annoys me every time I use it.

I like the width of the strap & it’s a very good material (similar to a seatbelt, but not as wide). The anchor tags need to be longer because when the strap is installed, its overly bulky clips interfere too much with camera operation. Granted I have XL hands, but I’ve read this same critique from others as well. Even without the strap installed, the anchor tags always flop around & get in my way way too. The non-slip material that rests behind your neck is unfortunately on the outside of the strap as you wear it, so it’s basically useless unless you enjoy the feeling of a twisted strap. I certainly don’t, & I think it is the stupidest idea Peak Design has developed with this strap.

Speaking of a twisted strap, it somehow seems to always be oriented incorrectly when it’s not on your body. Set it on a table and the anchors twist the wrong way. Put it in your camera bag & it never lays down well. On that note, when I place my camera in its bag the anchor connectors & adjustment buckles always want to lay right on top of my rear LCD screen. I have a screen protector, but that’s beside the point bc I don’t want it getting scratched up by my strap of all things. Trying to place the strap any other way in the bag is more cumbersome than it should be due to the stiffness of all of the components.

So what do I like about the strap? Adjustability. The adjustability is great. Literally everything else has a drawback & is annoying. I will say though, Peak Design is very close to perfection with this strap. Resolve the issues above & it certainly would be the perfect camera strap & worth the $60 price tag.

title: Comfortable and Adjustable
text:
I needed a side handle to add some comfort to my camera rig. I chose this one from SmallRig due to the versatility of its ambidextrous design and the low weight and high durability of carbon fiber.

As far as side handles and grips go, this thing is beautiful; the magnesium alloy and carbon fiber construction looks and feels premium, and will blend nicely with any rig, whether it cost you hundreds or thousands of dollars.

The handle fits great in the hand -- while it's not as ergonomic as some dedicated left or right handles, comfort does not suffer due to its dual-use design; its size should be good for average and large hands alike, but it may feel a bit bulky for people with smaller hands. Even with extended use, I have not had an issue with it becoming slippery as other reviewers have noted. Since I have only used it indoors in a climate-controlled environment, I decided to replicate the potential sweat of more demanding use by misting some water onto my hand; with moisture introduced, the handle does become a bit slick, and I can see how it would be a problem for heavier rigs. Since I'm not a professional photographer/videographer (and I'm not prone to having sweaty palms), sweat is unlikely to ever be a big issue for me, and if it ever is, the handle can be wiped dry with a cloth (or even my shirt if nothing else is available). I also would have no problem temporarily wrapping a black rubber band around the handle for added grip.

The 360-degree adjustment works beautifully, and there are no detents -- you can rotate the handle to the precise position you need. The NATO interfaces (both the rail to rig and handle to rail) are rock solid. Another reviewer described the fit as "sloppy," but I suspect that's a problem with the rig rather than the handle, since I can't replicate the issue with my equipment.

I think the reduced grip in sweaty conditions was an oversight on SmallRig's part, and something as simple as a removable rubberized overgrip may have been a great benefit for those that will be using the grip in outdoor/hot environments. As for me and my amateur indoor use, the grip is near-perfect and I'm glad to have it in my arsenal.

title: Amazing microscope for beginners / class
text:
[[VIDEOID:a391ddd9a86a918ae0b763c248790713]] I'm quite surprised as to the good quality of this microscope for the price. I was expecting a bit less but pleased with what was received. The body is cast, heavy and solid, no toque issues during focus. The stage is also solidly built, if it's plastic it doesn't feel like it, it feels like metal with a powder coating or something. The stage clip could use a bit of work but it holds the slides in place well enough. All adjustments, stage and focus (coarse and fine) are well built and offer smooth movement. The condenser and aperture surprised me on this one, again for the price range I really assumed they would have skimped on the quality here but they actually pulled through and included some decent hardware that offers good lighting distribution and contrast adjustments. The LED itself, however, could use some work as the brightness levels aren't the best. Obviously it can dim down to off, but it doesn't seem to want to get bright enough when the aperture is closed all the way for higher contrast, it could use a bit more brightness, especially if using the 100/1.25 objective lens.
The video in this review shows the blood sample provided with the microscope at 3 stages, recorded with my phone with the included phone mount atop the 2x & 25x lenses. The 1st part is 4/0.1 (200x), 2nd part is with 10/0.25 (500x), and 3rd / final part is with the 40/0.65 (2,000x).
The phone mount is cheap plastic and wobbles around on the eyepiece, but locks to the phone quite well and offers adequate adjustments for your phone camera lens placement.
Power supply is via a USB plug but the microscope itself doesn't have a USB plug (see picture of plug type). Power output of provided adapter states it's 1,000mA, so 1 amp, so keep that in mind in case you plan on using this with a USB power bank. Possible as long as it can output enough current.
No broken or missing parts and overall very pleased. This will provide an amazing learning experience for the kids, with adult supervision and guidance. Highly recommend for any young aspiring scientists out there.

title: Light it up!
text:
I haven't done much underwater video or stills work, mostly because I'm not much of a diver. But we have trips coming up where not only will we be in the water, a waterproof light will be helpful.

My son-in-law worked with me to test it out and he was surprised how bright it was compared to the OEM light.

Pros:

- BRIGHT! This little thing puts out some light.
- Nicely made, just feels sturdy. The accessories are mostly plastic but there is a lot of metal (aluminum alloy) in the construction of the light itself, plastic only where it really needs to be.
- Comes with everything you need to attach it and your GoPro to the also included mount. And a cold shoe adapter if you want to use it on a stand or DSLR. Love that flexibility to use it in or out of the water!
- Three different light modes. Each with two levels of brightness. Easy to switch between modes.
- easily available USB charging, cable included.

Cons:
- Well, my son in law and I may disagree on this. He thinks maybe it's heaviness relative to the OEM light is a con, I think it's not "that" heavy and in the water that's a pro. You're not going to feel the weight in the water, it may even help with stability (need to test that out still!) and the extra brightness over the OEM makes the extra weight worth it. You'll have to decide for yourself as to whether that's a pro or con for you.

This light is definitely waterproof although my test of that has been limited to the bathtub. (Don't ask. THAT test was NOT with my son in law.) As much as I like reviewing products for other Amazon shoppers I don't love y'all enough to test it in the ocean during winter.

I'm not a super techie person, I review based on how I use things and what's important to me in that use. If you want to know lumens, etc., they're in the product description.

I'm happy with this light and will be packing it with me on my upcoming trips.

title: I got these primarily for my cats, and…
text: [[VIDEOID:9fc3a9f8ef3e8a20c415efa9d032b8a4]] So, I got this mainly for one of my cats who seems to be the only one that loves to be outside all day. I’m definitely a little over protective cat mom, I don’t like to let my cat out without a leash because you just never know. BUT I’ve had my cat escape a harness twice and has darted outside while someone was opening the door several times. Being so, I wanted something that just in case he wanted to get loose, I can locate him easily. The AirTag is okay. Here’s what I do like about it: makes a sound to help you find it, trackable using the iPhone, real-time location when nearby, a better sense of safety. Here’s what I don’t like: at night, it will tell me that I need more light to locate him, “more light required.”. He can be somewhere in my neighborhood or a couple houses down, but even that close most of the time his location will not show. It primarily only shows the location when my phone is in range (I would say it’s the range of a normal sized house, which is the 30ft listed on the AirTag specs), when I’m gone it will update but sometimes it won’t update for hours, you can only add the AirTag to one iPhone/iCloud account, and the biggest con is that it won’t locate him while he’s moving (it will sometimes only show approximately how many feet he’s away while he’s moving, IF within the 30ft) I added a screen recorded video of the AirTag in “Find” mode, with this review so you can see with that looks like. With all that being said; a lot of other reviews for trackers say that it’s not accurate or updated real time either. I do feel safer that he has the AirTag on. I would recommend as maybe an extra security BUT NOT TO BE RELIED ON COMPLETELY for pets! If you just want this for items being misplaced in your own home or rental location then this would be 100% spot on and most definitely recommend.

title: Once again, another great find in the Tozo lineup of wireless earbuds
text:
My family owns almost every model of Tozo earbuds, along with the newest addition, a Bluetooth wireless portable speaker (Amazing speaker I highly recommend).

We all have our favorite models, mine is still the T10s, our young adult daughter who has really really small ears has struggled to find one's that work for her until we discovered the A3, my husband has two different models he uses throughout the day(I'll try to update later with his exact model #s). I'm still keeping my first purchase many years ago, the T6 in regular rotation as well(I love the size of it's case)

As you can see, we didn't really need another pair, but here we are now trying to decide who gets to keep this pair. I didn't expect to like the larger size of the external part, but I found it very comfortable and it feels more secure than even my favorite T10s. I feel they're a netter fit for times when I'm being very active, like hiking, gardening, etc... It took me a minute to play around with the settings and learn how they function, but once I did, I realozed I really like this model.

I honestly don't think you can go wrong with any of the Tozo models. My husband has his preference for the model he uses to watch movies and listen to music on, and he has a model he prefers to use for talking on the phone on his commute home and for work(a noise canceling model). He feels these NC9 are versatile enough he could use them for everything. I like having a pair that are noise canceling. I now see why my husband likes his other noise canceling pair so well.

I think these would be a pair I would also buy as a gift. I feel like they tick a lot of boxes and most people would really like them. Don't be thrown off my the larger external design, unless you have really small ears that even the T6s/T10s won't work for you like our daughter's situation. These do not work for her small ears. She cannot get them to stay in at all due to the external size & shape(go for A3 if you have this issue or are buying for a younger person).

title: It keeps your computer awake; but there are issues
text: The Vcnoeo Mouse jiggler does what it says it will do. It appears sturdy and well built. This USB device will keep your curser moving (more than you want) and will keep your computer awake. Install it into a USB port, and push and hold the the small button for a second or two to turn it on.  A very small blue light on the device shows that it is on. I like the fact that there is an on-off button. There are three settings: random movement over a small area, random movement over a large area, and very small jittery movement. You can cycle thru these by pushing the on-off button. I think the movement is two fast and if someone looks at your monitor they will see your curser jumping around quickly. Other units that I have had have very small movements every few seconds, and you can still use your computer and do work with the jiggler active. Because the movements are so large with this unit, you need to push the small button  and turn it off each time you want to get back to work. It is inconvenient to  remember to turn on or off this unit when you need your computer to stay awake; and to search to see where it left my curser. So overall, I do not like the way this unit functions.  If an IT Dept was searching to see if employees are using mouse jigglers, any competent IT Department would discover this unit. The product description states that it installs as: USB Composite Device.  However, it installed on my computer as: TEST MOSUE. Yes, mouse is spelled MOSUE when installed. If my IT Dept searched my computer for installed devices, they would wonder what a test mosue is, and look into the matter further. First, the device would be questioned because it is a test unit, and then they would question the validity of the unit because the device type is spelled incorrectly. This would prompt my IT Dept to inspect my computer to determine what is connected to it.  If you can get over the stated problems, this device may be for you. However, there are too many issues with this product for me to like it. If the curser movements were slowed down to once every few seconds, and if the identification of the device was corrected to MOUSE, then this product would be useable.

title: The included “extras” make these inexpensive glasses worthwhile.
text:
Hi. I have a variety of bird feeders set up in my backyard and my family enjoys using binoculars to watch the birds who visit. The binoculars we use most often (and keep “quick grab” handy in a kitchen cabinet above the fridge) include 8x30mm and 8x42mm compacts. Adding this pair of high(er) pair of 12x glasses to the group has been positive experience and there is much to like about them. The following is a quick take on what I’ve learned about them so far …

* The kit I received arrived with no visible defects to the binoculars, the included soft sided nylon case, mini-tripod or the phone-to-eyepiece holder and bracket;
* The included mini-tripod, although mostly plastic, has an easy to adjust metal ball head and is, overall, surprisingly well made. It scores extra points for having “press to adjust” sliders on each leg with detents and easy to read adjustment measurement lines. The tripod attaches to the front of the binocular’s center column quickly, and without fuss. It is a surprisingly nice little ‘pod …
* The “eyepiece to phone camera” attachment is/was a fun thing to play with for a bit. It was, however, a novelty that, at my house, went back into the box soon after it was tried; and, lastly;
* These binoculars have contours molded into the body that help to make them secure to grip and comfortable to hold. Once adjusted for the user, they focus quickly and are easy to control for 12x glasses. They exhibit far less noticeable (hand)shake than I anticipated for their magnification power. Sharpness, resolution, and image color is on par for their price. Simply put, these are inexpensive, but decent, optics that do the job.

The verdict: These are capable binoculars that are packaged with a surprisingly nice little tabletop tripod, an eyepiece to cellphone bracket, and a sturdy nylon case with strap. This value priced package is currently being offered on Amazon at a sale price that makes them even more attractive.

title: My favorite IPad accessory !!
text:
[[VIDEOID:e4f3ddd722a370815c521c2de754314b]] I’ve had this protector about four months now and all I can say is…. GET IT!!

Overall, this protector has exceeded my expectations and I love it. I didn’t want to commit to a paperlike screen protector for two main reasons, cost and permanence. The name brand paperlike screen protectors are expensive! Also, I didn’t want to commit to a grainy screen because I enjoy watching things on my iPad. I didn’t want to sacrifice my visual quality just for drawing purposes. While considering these two main things, I stumbled upon this protector. It has a low cost and it’s not permanent?? Sign me up. So I took the chance on this item considering there aren’t many reviews. The magnet is strong and stays in place for drawing. The texture is just like paper and has the resistance. I enjoy the ease of popping this on when I want to draw and taking it off to watch videos. This is also very easy to take around and travel with. I have a magnetic iPad case which allows me to attach it to the IPad case and put it in my bag with me ready to go. I really do love this product.

So about the downsides: Although it’s called a screen protector, is not meant to actually protect your screen. Considering it’s a magnet, it will more than likely not protect your screen. This is meant for a paperlike feel only. Also, due to it being a paperlike feel, it does wear down your Apple Pencil nib. This problem is not exclusive to this product considering all the brands that carry paperfeel protectors have this issue. So after about four months of consistent usage, I will soon need to purchase a pack of replacement nibs. (Which can be found here on Amazon for about $11). My only other issue is that this gets dirty quite fast. It picks up cat hairs and lint easily. HOWEVER, this screen protector comes with a cleaning cloth so just be sure to stay up on keeping it clean.

Overall: For the price and the quality of this product, this an amazing steal. GET IT!!

title: This is the bag
text: Hi.  I am a backpack addict.  I have about 10 backpacks more or less and not counting the sling bag I recently got.  My go-to bag is my eBags Professional Slim.  It's a 9/10 but it doesn't have space if I want to take off my hoodie. It's not designed to do that.  I have eBags motherlode carry-on that works well with the slim but I am not taking it with me when I go to Europe and Asia in three weeks.  So I need something that looks good, I can put it on my back but also carry a change of clothes if I want to be fresh when I land.  I reviewed a lot of bags of 40L type and a lot of them are about half the price of this bag but I have the Tomtoc sling and love it so it only made sense for me to get the big brother. It arrived today in style.  I was impressed with the inner box, sleeve, and tags.  I immediately took everything out of the eBags Slim and started to fill the Tomtoc.  Obviously, the change of clothes for the 14-hour flight will wait but my MacBook Air fit snugly and the zippered pouch for the cables and plugs was a no-brainer.  There are two zippered areas, one on the top and one on the front.  The one on the top was for my EDC flashlight, gum, toothpicks, wipes, and sanitizer.  The front zippered area holds my passports and an EDC multi-tool.  I struggled to find a place for my pens, extra batteries, USB C adapters, and such. I haven't found the right spot or perhaps it doesn't exist, ( I hope that's not the case ) If there's a small inside pocket or small zippered pouch inside, it would be ideal for such things.  The backup plan would be to use a small ziplock bag for those things and keep them in the front zippered pouch near the passports.  We depart in three weeks and return in 9, I'll provide an update then but super impressed with everything.  One more thing, a lot of the other bags at half the price have their brand name plastered on the front and I just didn't want that.

title: Airpods vs Sony WF-1000XM4
text:
I'm not an audiophile, but I was looking for great sound, noise cancellation, and fit. I got these Airpods which are my first ever and was impressed with the noise cancellation right away.

Sound-I bought the Sony's (WF-1000XM4) second for one main reason, SOUND! I have the Sony WH-1000XM4 headphones which are amazing. The Sony earbuds sound very close to the headphones. The Airpods didn't quite have the same sound although they sound great. I was actually surprised that the Airpods sounded very close to a pair of Mpow M30 earbuds that I got in 2020 for $30. The Sony's seem a bit louder with richer sound. Also, the Sony buds have the ability to change the sound profile using the equalizer app. The Airpods rank second to Sony in my opinion.

Noise cancellation- Both Sony and Airpods do an amazing job, but I think the Airpods beat out the Sony but a hair. The noise cancellation does not disappoint on either one.

Fit- The Airpods are way more comfortable for my small ears. The Sony feel big and like they are going to pop out. I find both comfortable, but the Airpods feel more natural in my ears. The Sony's take a little getting use to.

Controls- I prefer the Sony controls. The Airpod controls still feel a little awkward to me. Matter of preference.

Voice/Calls- LOVE the Airpods!!! I haven't tried the Sony's on calls yet simply because I automatically go for my Airpods. They connect quicker. The calls are clean like the person is in the room with you.

Battery Life- Airpods lasted a bit longer.

Overall, if you mainly make calls or workout, I would go with the Airpods. If you are looking more for music listening, then the Sony's are way better. Noise cancellation...either one, but because of the better fit of the Airpods on small ears, I would default to the Airpods...although the Sony headphones beat out both. If you can afford both, then I'd say go for it!

title: Decent volume, but not for the audiophile
text:
[[VIDEOID:1df41d8f0f8b55d4dfab1aa6b7e6ea13]] LENRUE's computer speaker bar come in at just shy of $20, putting it squarely in the "budget" category. Viewed through that lens, it performs quite well.

If you're very picky about your sound quality, you might want to pass on this. It performs very well with vocals and mids, so if you're usually listening to pop or rock this will suit your needs quite well. Without a dedicated subwoofer or tweeter, I wasn't expecting it to be great in the lower and upper ranges, but the drop-off in quality is stark. I don't consider myself an audiophile by any means, but even I could notice that orchestral/symphonic arrangements sounded decidedly worse.

The volume on this has a decent range for most applications. I'm not sure it would be loud enough for a frat party, but for a guy in his 30s who occasionally has people over for dinner and games it's good enough. Vocal quality stays pretty consistent through the entire volume spectrum; instrumentals fall off at the low end but retain their quality at the higher volumes.

The lights on the speakers do a slow cycle through colors. They start out synced but very quickly fall out of sync, first noticeable between the lower light bar and the side light bars, but eventually even the six light sources on the lower bar drift from each other so that there's no rhyme or reason to the lights. Unlike other products I've used with features like this, you can only have the lights on this disjointed multicolor slow pulse or turned completely off; there is no option to have, say, a solid color. The touch on/off button is responsive to even light touches.

I do like that the unit is self-contained with a minimum of cords: just one that comes out of the back that splits at the end, a USB plug for power and an aux plug for audio. It's truly as portable as you can get without it being wireless.

Overall, it's an improvement on most stock laptop speakers, but definitely doesn't do better than its $20 price tag.

title: The best keyboard case for my 12.9" iPad Pro 6th generation
text:
I bought myself a 12.9" iPad Pro for Christmas 2022 and am so happy that I ended up with this keyboard case. I have had several iPads over the years and have purchased a keyboard case for everyone of them, but I had never experienced the floating cantilever design before. I first saw this feature on The Apple Magic keyboard, but I refuse to pay $350 for something that should be half the price!
This keyboard case has many great features beyond the floating cantilever stand. The keyboard is backlit and has a good feel to it making it easy to type. The most important feature of the keyboard for me is that it is almost always awake and ready to type when you start typing. My other keyboards would go to sleep fast and wake up slow, which was a major distraction!
The iPad attaches to the case via magnetic attachment, meaning that you don't need to squeeze the iPad into a rim or lip, you just attach and detach it at will by pulling it off of the magnets, but it stays securely in place if that's what you prefer. The case edge protrudes about 1/16" all around to protect the iPad's edges, and give a little bit of an edge to hold the Apple Pencil in place on the magnetic mount.
The vegan leather case is well constructed and has a good feel. The softer texture helps it stay on my lap when I'm playing games or surfing the web while sitting on the couch at night.
This is my second keyboard case for this new iPad. I immediately ordered a keyboard case with a 360º swivel and 180º flip case when I bought the 12.9" iPad Pro. That case sounded good on paper, but it failed in many ways. As mentioned above, the keyboard would go to sleep even during a brief pause, and would take several keystrokes to wake up. It was heavy and made of hard-smooth texture plastic so it would slide off of my lap. The 360º swivel and 180º flip hinge mechanism was very stiff and required 2 hands to open/close the case.
Thanks to Amazon's return policy, I was able to return it and immediately order this Magnetic Keyboard Case with Cantilever Stand. I can honestly say that of the many keyboard cases that I have owned over the years, this is the best ever!

title: bright, configurable, but pricey
text:
A solid, heavy, and expensive "connected" LED panel. It's very bright, going up to 2800lumens. The light is very quick to change & consistent once set. The panel is configurable via app.

While the panel is marketed for streamers and gamers, it would work for anything that needs a configurable direct lighting set up.
I tried it out for product photo lighting and portrait lighting. For these use cases you'd have to adjust your shooting environment-- for close-up use, a softbox or something else softening the light would be better. The bare panel would otherwise need to be mounted at some distance from the subject to avoid glare. I'd assume that to be the case for video conferencing as well.

The android app has a distressingly low number of downloads, and the app itself is a bit clunky-- not following modern Android design guidelines. Tapping and dragging the sliders, back-and-forward screen actions don't quite work as I'd expect.
The app offered a firmware update for the light initially. That update failed, and there's no way to check or re-trigger the update. Buggy or broken. But the lighting controls work.

Other thoughts: The minimum height of the mounting rod makes it hard to put this panel on the same level as the subject. It's more likely to be shining somewhat downwards, although it does support side positions that lower the height of the bottom of the panel (by positioning it vertically). It would be nice if it would fit a light stand or tripod mount, to provide options other than clamping it to a desk.

I like Razer products a lot. This one is typically well-made, but a bit too expensive for a multi-range LED light panel.
I don't think the app / smart-interface adds much over physical onboard controls-- and that lack of physical controls could be problematic if you need the same mobile devices for whatever activity you're lighting. Maybe if you have a bunch of these panels to set up identically, but at this pricing and pictured use-cases, it's hard to imagine somebody having more than two.

Recommended if you game or need auto-color-changing features., but mind the price.

title: It could be a great except for the Blink Module
text:
After an incident that occurred with my neighbor where he had more than a couple of drinks, I decided to have a Smart doorbell with motion detection for mild security on my home. I was not planning to spend too much, and I'm quite a fan of Amazon products. So I decided to get a Blink Doorbell bundle with the Sync Module 2, additionally I pair my purchase with a Blink exterior camera. The process to connect everything was pretty easy and simple, only my chime was not compatible and was buzzing if I wired the Doorbell. So I left this connected only with notifications through my Echoes.

A few months later, the Sync Module starts to lose connection and no matter what steps to resolve the issue I performed, always prompted a message that my Wi-Fi or Password was incorrect, when in reality was not. Eventually, after several attempts on its own was back online and a few months later again the same issue keep repeating over and over. So I contacted customer support to seek a replacement. Which is the worst by all means, regardless of what you described of the steps performed on your own, they always reply with the same scripted troubleshooting steps like if you were talking with a bot. In a thread of 18 emails, instead of replacing my module, they decided to blame my internet connection. As always the module a couple of weeks ago decided to get back online, clearly I have a defective product that Blink support did not want to replace or recognized.

A few months ago, I upgraded my Wi-Fi connection to a Mesh system. I was afraid to switch the connection, but I went through and luckily there were no issues, or at least I thought so. It turns out my echoes does no longer starts the live view. At the end the culprit was, as always, the Sync module This time, thinking I have fixed the Wi-Fi issue, I restarted the connection of the module. To my surprise it does not connect anymore and always shows the same error message that my password is incorrect and lights on red and from there I have not found solution. Now my Doorbell and the camera are useless without the module.

In conclusion, the doorbell is great, unfortunately the Sync Module 2 does not work. I found online through several forums, the same experience that I have and Blink Support does not resolve anything.

title: UNREAL AUDIO!!!! 1000/100!! YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED
text:
Got it the Between Pros yesterday. Thought it was another set of regular earbuds. I kept seeing on my feeds on FB and Instagram. They weren't lying. So let's start off with
Packaging - it comes in a nice black box. Opened up pretty easy. Getting it out was a little rough from the foam. Nice design.
The unit itself - opened it, had a little difficulty with getting the earbuds out. Realized the magnets are pretty strong, so I had to tap them out forcefully them out of their box. Easy set up without the instructions. But read them afterwards.
Audio - INSANELY UNREAL, I didn't expect these to be that unreal. I feel like I'm in a concert or a club. I checked my volume on my phone and it was only at half unlike my Samsung earbuds I have. Noise cancellation is WAY too good. I can't hear anything else, you'll get shoulder taps in the gym for sure when you are focused. Sounds quality is easy too good. I can hear every beat, tremble and bass. It's honestly too good. Volume controls are easy to use: double press on right earbud for increase, and left earbud to decrease volume.
Range - I walk out my bedroom to test out for before it loses its connection to my phone. It's a good 20 ft or more. So best not to lose the case or even it entirely.
Connecting to devices - can connect to anything that is Bluetooth capable. Laptop, Steam Deck, Samsung, Apple, etc... I am, so far, a dedicated user to these earbuds. I don't think ever buy another set of earbud brands except these. Well worth the price and knowing what matters to the user.
Battery life - is left to be known. Because I didn't test it out that far yet.
Overall quality 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟
No exaggeration it's that good!
Apple and Samsung earbuds users , I challenge you to try them out. YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED!!

title: Good but, misses with the back zipper
text:
[[VIDEOID:6aed27f522d46d9a28965b45f19ad3a4]] The Chargella Waterproof PU [faux] Leather Laptop Messenger Shoulder Bag has quite a few positive. It has handles along with a detachable shoulder strap to give you the option of wearing the bag on one shoulder or as a crossbody bag. Overall, the outside of the bag is approximately 11 inches tall, approximately 13 inches long from bottom outside corner to bottom outside corner. The deepest section within the bag is about 11 inches deep. The back pocket is about 5 1/2 inches deep while the front pocket is about 7 1/2 inches deep. The material is very soft.

I unloaded my everyday crossbody bag and found that everything from it fit inside this bag. I also easily found room for my iPad Pro and had room to spare.

The negative is about 1 issue only: zippers. Specifically, 2 of the outer zippers are problematic. The top zipper is meant to open beyond the length of the bag but, even when I straighten out the end of the zipper tag, the zipper itself struggles to reach the end of the track. That is more of a minor annoyance to me because I had no problem fitting my things inside the bag. Another person might need the zipper to open fully and then it would be a  bigger problem for them.

The back zipper gets stuck in one place over and over. In the video, you'll see me using one hand (the other hand was holding my phone to film). But, prior to the video, I used both hands a few times to try to get the zipper not to stick. I double checked to make sure that the fabric onto which the zipper is sewn was not getting in the way - it wasn't. There is no visible impediment. But, maybe the cause is related to the seam that brings together the two back panels. The upper part of the seam meets just under the zipper.  It's possible that the extra material depth right there is the culprit.

I would be concerned with putting anything important in that pocket, anything to which I'd need frequent access. I intended to put hand wipes, gum and a few other things in the pocket but, I think I'll leave it empty.

title: Exactly what I was looking for!
text:
I'm honestly not sure why thus has such bad ratings. It's exactly what I needed.

My car is 1 model year before Apple Car play was added by my manufacturer, and a few years before Android auto (don't know exactly when Android Auto became a thing)... My GF has an iPhone, and I have a Samsung Galaxy...

Her car is 3 years newer and has both already... But my car will only play music off of an iPhone almost like connecting a hard drive or something.

I saw this and had to have it.

I haven't mounted it yet, so no pics, but I hooked it up to test it, and it's amazing!

I can connect my galaxy using Bluetooth, but the sound isn't great... This connects with Bluetooth as well... Ehhh... It can also connect through the FM transmitter which doesn't sound great either...

What's a person (that wants quality audio) to do? Connect it to your stereo using the provided aux cord.

Sounds pretty dam* good...

I don't like the GPS that came with my car, and shows on my original screen, so this allows me to use Google maps on my newer secondary screen that will be mounted just above...

Honestly, the only drawbacks I can think of is that since it's connected using the aux cord, I can't control the music with my steering wheel controls (but a quick tap of the screen works, or saying "Hey Google, Next song")... And the other is finding the best way to route the cables so they aren't just dangling down my dash and center console... Which is why I haven't taken the time to mount it yet... But there are a couple of easy suggestions right in the manual on how best to do it (and it comes with some cable clips for just that purpose), so I'll mess with it more this weekend.

All in all, it looks great, and it sounds great.

If your car already has carplay, and Android auto built in to your system, this adds nothing. If your car is a couple years older, this is exactly what you're looking for.

title: Worth the Price for My Needs
text: [[VIDEOID:d0c907314d7659f36f8231c05b2dc849]] I've been looking at digital pens for a long time and could not make up my mind on which was best for my needs. I simply needed a way to take notes in meetings and transfer them into text fast. The pen does that and more. First unboxing and setting up the pen was as simple as pressing a button and writing (once fully charged). I went with the Neo Studio app after comparing it with others. I don't need productivity and/or task management support so the Neo Studio offered the easiest and best option to simply take notes and convert to text or upload to my designated storage platform or send via email. The Neo Studio app was fairly simple to download on to my very old Samsung tablet and it works seamlessly with the pen. I did not give it 5 starts because one feature appears not to work and I don't know if it is the pen, the app or user error. The pen is supposed to activate simply by beginning to write on the Neo paper. But I have to press the on button to activate the pen before it stores information (when using without the app activated). I learned this the hard way after taking a full page of notes (I didn't have my tablet with me at the time) and then attempting to upload to the app later, there was nothing stored in the pen memory. Lesson learned make sure LED light is lit when taking notes. The Neo paper is required to use with pen. The pen recognizes multiple different notebooks and keeps the notes sorted by the color of the note book. I purchased the pack of 3 books with blue, purple and grey. I use one color for each topic and the pen automatically recognizes which notebook is being used and stores the uploaded notes under that appropriate notebook. The handwriting to text transcribe feature has been about 95% accurate with minor missed letters (mostly due to my handwriting). I was able to improve the transcribe accuracy by slowing down as I write (slightly). One note that I didn't find in the instructions is that when I delete notes in the app it deletes from the pens memory storage as well. So there is no way to retrieve past notes if I haven't saved them elsewhere. I have recommended this to everyone one of my friends that prefer handwriting their notes or keeping a paper calendar.

title: Love the built-in DVD player, but the projector needs more fine-tuning adjustments.
text:
[[VIDEOID:c7ead6d2286a0c61fcc0e6e22ee1d6d5]] The Big Asou DVD projector with Wi-Fi is a great idea having the DVD player built into the projector. Would’ve been nice if it was Blu-ray, but still have plenty of standard definition dvds to play on it.

The projector itself is nice and compact and comes with a sturdy little tripod to make it easy to adjust the angle of the projector on a table. Brightness wise, you’re not gonna be using this during the daylight time or in any sort of direct light. Definitely needs to be after the sun is gone down or night time to be able to see it clearly.

The projector does have built-in speakers which you can use in a pinch, but you definitely want to connect it to some other speakers to run the audio through. It’s nice that it includes Bluetooth, so you can connect Bluetooth speakers to it quite easily an issue is though that there audio when playing via Bluetooth lags behind the video). The app functionality works fine as well as being able to play movies off of a USB drive, if you don’t wanna use the DVD player.

However, a big issue with the projector is how loud the fan is. It is quite annoying and and turns on right away, regardless of how long we’ve had the projector on for. Also when angling the projector up at a wall or screen, which is what most of us are going to be doing, the keystone setting on the back, which adjust the picture on the wall to make it look square, only goes 15° one way or the other, which is not anywhere near enough to get the picture square on the wall. This project really needs to be close to level and projecting straight ahead for the image to look correct. Also, with focusing, if the project is setup and angled more than a few degrees up or down, you’ll have either the top edge or the bottom edge of the screen noticeably out of focus.
