I really wanted to like this projector, but given the issues with focusing and squaring up the image on the wall plus the loud fan noise, I wouldn’t recommend it.

title: Great stabilization in a compact form, perfect for travel with small DSLR cameras
text:
[[VIDEOID:5635179b36cad0b30da9ef54e55debb]] I have experience with gimbals and this is my 3rd Zhiyun. Overall the quality seems decent, and I absolutely love the compactness of this gimbal. it's a solid, lightweight, compact unit. It's perfect for travel using a lightweight DSLR or mirrorless camera. The Stabilization is very good. I ran some quick test and it performed very well. Even more impressive is I wasn't even trying to be steady with my holding and walking which you can see in my video.

The unit comes with 3 cables, and I did test the one for my Sony and it worked fine. I was able to trigger the camera from the gimbal. That's a great feature and it's great that Zhiyun includes that! My Ronin did not include that cable and the one I purchased from Ronin is sketchy at best.

The light is a nice feature/option to have. If you're in a dark area it's better to have something than nothing at all. It triggers right from the gimbal so you can use it in a pinch. It also comes with color correction filters that snap on.

I took one star off for balancing issues. I could not make super fine adjustments and this resulted in it taking longer than usual to get a perfect balance. I did however achieve perfect balance but I think there's room for improvement with adjustability.

Adding to my adjustability comment, I was unable to balance my iPhone 13 pro max using my Manfrotto phone clamp/mount. The mount is a little back heavy and the crane did not have enough adjustability for me to properly balance it. So if you want to use your phone you may want to consider using Zhiyun's phone mount. I'll have to get that as well and I'll report back on its compatibility.

With all this said, the unit is a compact little powerhouse. I would recommend checking Zhiyuns's compatibility website because some of my lenses were not compatible. I think if your using a small DSLR or mirrorless camera, you'll need to stick to lightweight lenses otherwise you'll have some balancing issues.

title: Good enough for my basic needs
text:
I don't use my desktop computer for much by way of sound output (not really using it for streaming music or videos, and not a heavy use for gaming - that's what I do on my laptop). My desktop fills more utilitarian needs, but it's speakers were dying so I bought these.

They are quite basic and work well enough in that regard. I appreciate they are USB powered, though why they don't also do sound through the USB is weird. You have to plug in a USB cable for the power and an audio cable for the sound output.

A few downsides:

(1) The physical volume control is a rotating switch attached to the audio line. This means that to access it once everything is connected, you have to reach behind one of the speakers to use it. Since my speakers are placed to the back edge of my desk, this means that this switch is dangling off the back of my desk and inconvenient if not nearly impossible to reach -- so, I just set it to full volume and then use the system's software volume control. I'd much prefer for this sort of physical control to be ON the front of the speaker.

(2) The length of the wire connecting the two speakers is rather short. My desk isn't the largest, and yet I can't place the speakers to each back corner of the desk to put them the potential maximum distant apart that I'd like. The wiring is about a foot shorter than I'd like. My prior speakers had much longer wiring, though they were a much higher price when originally acquired than these.

(3) Being as these are so basic, there's no headphone jack on the speakers themselves (as I had on the speakers they are replacing). So if you want to use headphones, you'll need another solution and then, likely, software switch the output through your system controls to toggle between speaker or headphones. For me, not a big deal overall because I have a separate USB headset already for use in video conferencing though it's annoying to have to manually switch between the two in system settings.

Anyway, for the price there a reasonably good deal with generally good sound output for basic needs. Would NOT recommend if you wanted a solid surround-sound experience.

title: Love it!
text:
The Fidioto USB Hub is a versatile and convenient solution for expanding your USB connectivity on your laptop, Windows PC, Mac, or other devices. This USB hub features 4 USB 3.0 ports and 1 USB 2.0 port, providing you with multiple options for connecting various USB devices, such as printers, flash drives, mobile HDDs, and notebook PCs.

One of the standout features of this USB hub is its high-speed data transfer capability. The USB 3.0 ports offer super-fast data transfer speeds of up to 5Gbps, allowing you to transfer large files quickly and efficiently. The USB 2.0 port also provides decent data transfer speeds of up to 480Mbps, which is ideal for connecting devices that don't require high-speed data transfer.

The compact and sleek design of this USB hub makes it easy to carry and perfect for use with laptops or other devices that have limited USB ports. It comes with a built-in USB cable that can be easily tucked away when not in use, keeping your workspace tidy and organized. The hub is also plug-and-play, requiring no additional drivers or software installation, making it user-friendly and hassle-free to use.

The Fidioto USB Hub is compatible with various operating systems, including Windows, Mac, and Linux, making it versatile for use with different devices. It also has a wide range of compatibility with USB devices, including printers, flash drives, mobile HDDs, and notebook PCs, making it a versatile option for expanding your USB connectivity.

One potential consideration is that the USB 2.0 ports may have slower data transfer speeds compared to the USB 3.0 ports. If you require high-speed data transfer for multiple devices simultaneously, you may need to prioritize the USB 3.0 ports for faster performance.

In conclusion, the Fidioto USB Hub is a reliable and convenient solution for expanding your USB connectivity on your laptop, Windows PC, Mac, or other devices. With its high-speed data transfer capability, compact design, and wide compatibility, this USB hub offers a convenient and efficient way to connect multiple USB devices to your computer. Whether you need to connect printers, flash drives, mobile HDDs, or notebook PCs, this USB hub is a practical choice for enhancing your USB connectivity.

title: Great little amp to run passive speakers from my desktop computer
text:
I've had many sets of PC speakers over the years. I always thought I should be able to have the speakers I really wanted to listen to, instead of the speakers I had to settle for. I was all set to drag out one of my older Onkyo receivers to do the job, but I really didn't want to use a full blown receiver to do this and I didn't want a full size receiver taking up valuable office space.

I stumbled across these small Fosi Audio amps in one of my searches. I picked the BT30D for several reasons. First was the compact size. This is exactly what I imagined when it came to a small powerful office sized amp. It fits perfectly and conveniently under my desktop. It's out of the way, doesn't add clutter to my desk and at the same time, it's always within reach.

I don't use or need the BlueTooth capabilities that this guy offers because I was only interested in connecting it to my computer. It has RCA line inputs that I connect my computer to, left and right speaker binding posts, passive subwoofer RCA jacks and a powered subwoofer RCA jack. There's also the BlueTooth antenna jack and the DC power supply input. Because of the small format of this amplifier, I would recommend also spending a few extra bucks and getting some banana plugs that you can add to your speaker cables. You don't “need” them, but it makes connecting up your speakers a ton easier. You would need very small fingers to be able to screw down the binding posts.

So, my system has a pair of Bowers & Wilkins bookshelf speakers and an Elac subwoofer. This amp powers these all very well. One of the main purposes I had for buying this amp was so I could listen to music (which I usually enjoy very loud). So far, I haven't been able to turn it up all the way, it really has good power. The frequency and volume knobs for the subwoofer work really well too. Plenty of power all around. The sound is clean and my desktop system has never sounded anywhere near this good. For the price, I was really blown away.

title: Battery is pretty powerful and lasts longer than some other tablets I have had
text:
Pros, Likes, and Features
*Comparable to other tablets on the market this is about the same except it can also connect to 4g lte internet service with a sim card and data plan through your wireless carrier.
*This has the capability of dual sim so you can have 2 lines of service on this tablet. Handy if you travel a lot and need phone or data service in areas where one or another is available and you need to be able to go back and forth
*Mine came mostly charged, I didn't have to charge it to use it for quite a while out of the box
*Audio and mic pickup is good. Had no issue video chatting on it through zoom and Facebook messenger for testing. Colors and brightness are acceptable and I have no complaints there.

Cons, Dislikes
*Where can I get a rubberized protective case and screen protector for this? Only options I see so far are the universal ones. I would like to see some more dedicated products for devices like this. What if I want a rugged case and a glass screen protector? This should be something that could be ordered or provided or even included by the manufacturer but I don't have any option but with universal products here..

I don't have any cons for this device. It is a lower end tablet with dual sim card capability for connecting to cellular services. Can connect to Verizon and ATT both so if you travel it works in areas where one or the other would work better or when one isn't available at all. I have good comparable signal to that of my cellphone with it and have tried it on the ATT network and everything tested good. I have yet to try others but I don't anticipate any issues being this is unlocked it should work with all of them. The Audio and Video are clear and sound good and I don't have any issues with the touch capability and it charges fairly quick with the included charging cable and adapter. I don't know if this can be charged wirelessly as I never tried and the charging cable with take a few hours to fully charge so it would be best with an overnight charge when needed. I think it is a pretty decent tablet with connectivity most tablets do not have for this price. Because of that I think this stands out from most other tablets apart from name brand tablets.

title: Handy Light, Built to Last
text:
I love this little light for quick-shooting situations where I don’t want to set up my larger light panels.

PROS:

It is very light, and it is still easy to handle my phone or tablet even when the light is mounted. And the small form-factor fits easily in a pocket when not in use.

Very simple to use. Just 3 buttons control everything.

Choice of 3 Color Renditions, 3000k to 6500k for household warmth to daylight cool.

Choice of 10 light levels by short presses of the +/- buttons, or continuously variable by long press.

Although it is small, the light is nice and even, and considerably softer and more flattering than the led ‘flash’ built into phones.

The versatile spring-clip allows you to direct the light where you want, and I felt the mounting clip was safe for my devices.

Although light-weight, it is designed to last, with a threaded metal socket for the mounting bracket, and an all-metal, locking, mounting foot included for use with a cold shoe.

I tested the run-time from a full charge, and it was about 1:53 to shut-down at full output. Recharging time was about 1 hour.

Comes with a C Type charging cable, but no charger.

CONS:

Although the mounting clip seems gentle and safe for my devices, it needs to be said that the attachment COULD be more secure. Be careful not to wave your device around with this light clipped on, or you might inadvertently crash-test this light as it is flung off. Good for use with mindful handling only.

Although the product page shows 360 degrees of rotation, this is only done by loosening the clip attachment. It will have to be re-tightened to secure the light. Not as convenient as a mount that ACTUALLY rotates.

CONCLUSION: A very handy light for many uses, for both people and objects. Allows me to be lazy (and not do a studio setup) when I just want a quick photo.

title: Inexpensive, Good Sound Quality. Otherwise....
text:
This MP3 Player sort of reminds me of a Creative Labs MP3 Player I had decades back. But worse.

The OS takes some getting used to because the buttons/clicks work in ways that are annoying. For instance, you press the circle control to the Right to get the menu to go Down. Pressing the Down button is the Go-Back function. And so on.

What is absolutely most annoying is the transfer method and speed. Silly me, I thought I could load up a micro SD card with MP3 files, stick it in the device, and play. But no, the SD card is not recognized. So you have to stick the SD card in first and then connect the player to your computer to transfer. Then it will worked just fine.

But I have two issues with this. First, I know absolutely nothing about this company other than it is made in China. How can I be sure there isn't some sort of malware embedded in the firmware? I can't and I'm betting the average user would be able to be sure either. So connecting this device directly to my PC is a real problem. Fortunately, I had one of those cheap mini-PCs on-hand for just this type of use.

Second, the transfer speed is ridiculously slow. It took over 40 minutes to transfer about 1.5 GB. That's ridiculous. Imagine how long it would take to fill up a 64GB card...?

So these two issues are what's meriting a 1-star rating from me. So annoyed by this was I that I didn't bother to check out the radio or Bluetooth feature (the ebook reader function is an artifact from the old days; I didn't even consider looking into it).

Yes, it's very inexpensive. Ridiculously so. That's good. And, to be honest, the speaker sound is incredible. I was amazed how good it was.

But the direct-connect requirement (with its attendant PC security concerns) and the ridiculously slow transfer speed are two huge impediments. Hence, my 1-star rating.

Fun, yes. Cheap, yes. Worth it, I don't think so.

1 star.

title: Can't Go Wrong W/ H5 Flow
text:
Let me start by saying that this is a great case. The build quality is excellent. I had no intentions of ever doing any kind of liquid cooling. Although a custom cooling solution can be placed here, I don’t think the case is suitable for a full-fledged liquid solution due to the closed off bottom, limiting space.

All the fans were from NZXT, until I updated 3 of them with a Corsair LL120 RGB 3-pack kit. The toilet 120mm, and front 140mm fans remain as I didn’t want too much lighting. (See before and after pics).

The only real gripe I had was actually my fault. Although the case is rated for a max GPU length of 360mm (approx. 14.17 in.), and the GPU I bought is 344mm (approx. 13.5 in). I failed to account for the measurements for the Z bar that the XFX Radeon 7900 XT included for support. I do suggest an alternate solution for support for the big GPUs as one, it is absolutely necessary, and two, there are solutions that will easily fit in this case. (see Z bar pics and alt. support bracket I very quickly swapped to). I also included a pic with my old Radeon 5500 XT, which easily fits and doesn’t require support.

The spacing for cable management is excellent, although due to the toilet (gpu) fan, you don’t get the entire bottom for cables, hence using cable extensions can cause cluttering quickly. There are lots of “paths” for cables which help organize, as well as lots of velcro straps attached to the case, and loops for adding more of your own as needed.

Nothing much else to say, overall, I am very happy with the case. Looks great, and in my opinion, it is very versatile and best for an air cooling solution. It does only come with the toilet and rear fans. I do highly recommend adding the maximum amount of fans for the best air-flow. Furthermore, I would only use 140mm front fans for best intake.

If I had the space, I would’ve gone with an H7, but you can’t go wrong with the H5 Flow.

title: Excellent value for a big ball head
text:
This is a big 55mm low profile ball head that can handle 88 pounds of load, so it will most likely handle pretty much any camera/lens combination you'll have. In fact, it might be a little overkill for most camera rigs, but when you want a big ball head, this is a great choice, especially if you're on a bit of a budget.

I tried it with a few of my zoom lenses, including a 150-600mm, and the ball head felt very secure and will lock down tight. I will say that the movement isn't quite as smooth as some higher priced ball heads I have, but for the price, I don't think it's worth complaining about. If you want super-smooth, spend another $100 for a higher end ball head like the Leofoto LH-55 (https://amzn.to/3X43mmf), which is still considered a value brand, but produces a very high end product. Or if you want the very best and can pop for $520, get the Really Right Stuff BH-55 Head (https://amzn.to/3YoQEzE).

I think the reason this Weyllan head isn't as smooth is due to the ball itself, which has a bit of texture (see my pictures) compared to the more expensive brands. If you look at the more expensive heads, their ball is extremally smooth, which would make sense that it would translate into a more smooth action. I am assuming this is where the money saving comes in. The panning action is also less smooth/fluid than the higher end heads, but again, that's to be expected at this price level. Frankly, super smoothness isn't that big of a deal for most still photographers anyway.

Minor smoothness observations aside, this is a very capable ball head, with great features and load capabilities that is also an excellent value. I appreciate the size of the main knob, which is heavily knurled and can be adjusted while wearing winter gloves, which is important to me when shooting in the Colorado Rockies. This CH55 head comes with two Arca-Swiss style quick release plates and a nicely padded case. I think for the money, this head is tough to beat and offers a fantastic value.

title: portable
text:
As boomboxes go this model has lots that’s recommendable. It is easily portable (although a bit heavy) with a foldable handle on the top. Sound quality is very good, even rich. An equalizer function adjusts to music genre--I used the “classical” setting but I’m not sure how much of difference this made. Nevertheless, the sound was fine for the operas and classical music that I play. Good volume for a device of this size.
Mode settings allow for various formats: cds, radio, and Mp3 hookup with an Aux cable (not provided). Especially welcome is the flash drive port that allowed access to my extensive list of downloaded music files. The Bluetooth function pairs easily. But there is no cassette player, a disappointment for collectors like me who have large (admittedly old) tape collections.
Controls are all over the unit. An illuminated blue screen on the top front clearly displays what is playing. Manual controls are on the top—volume, cd operation—but this can be bypassed by using the remote that is provided.
But other parts of the operation are problematic. There is a power button on the remote and on the top of the device. But there is also another on/off button on the bottom back that must be engaged. This is awkward for me since I usually place my boombox on the top of a bookcase in my study. Moreover, the unit has a power cord for the re-chargable battery, as well as operation. Yet it is recommended that this wire be disconnected if the unit is not being used over an extended period of time. For me this is inconvenient. I prefer to leave my radios and other players plugged in and ready to go. I suspect that the makers of this device want users to rely on the battery for power. This is fine for those who wish to carry the unit around but not for those who intend to leave it one place.
The Klim is a bit larger than your typical boombox. It also has a flat, squareish design. Valuable instruction manual with customer support contact information.
Overall, a worthwhile product that could be better. OK for those who mainly want a portable device.

title: This is a great router, especially when used as one half of a mesh pair.
text:
This is a handsome looking router, which does not have to be hidden out-of-sight. The antenna are neatly hidden inside. That is, it's great looking if you like a minimalist, business-tech look; if don't like that aesthetic, it may look like a black toaster which has no place in your living room. (However, I put mine sideways on a bookshelf where it blends in easily.)

I have looked at a good number of wi-fi routers. The main point about this particular one is that it is a great mesh router for persons who live in large homes, or a homes with thick plaster, brick, or steel-framed walls or walls with metal pipes (which all interfere with wi-fi radio transmissions). It has three radio bands, one 2.4 gHz frequency band, one lower 6 gHz band, and one upper 6 gHz band. When used as a two (or three or more) unit mesh system, the upper 6 gHz band keeps each individual unit synchronized wirelessly. In some other three-band mesh systems, the synchronization needs to be done with ethernet cables installed between each unit.

If this router is installed as a single, non-mesh, system the two 6 gHz bands can be re-united in the system settings to get up to a 160 gHz wide (very fast) broad wi-fi channel. Otherwise, the 6 gHz band cannot be wider than 80 gHz, which is still fast. (And given all the possible things which can interfere with a radio signals, it is sometimes impossible to get a full 160 gHz wide band, anyway.)

The other thing which I really like about this and other Asus routers is that it, and they, come with a free-for-life software firewall. Most other big router companies make you buy an annual software firewall subscription, or do without.

This is a good, stand-alone, single unit wi-fi router, with a neat, tech look. However, for the money, there are other decent single unit wifi routers, if you don't mind antenna sticking out or subscribing to software firewalls. But as a part of a two or three unit mesh system, it's hard to beat this router for the price.

title: A great monitor with 2 minor issues.
text:
I have used multiple oled monitors in the last couple of months and each of them had their own issues. Including this one. But in this case the positives outweigh the negative. The picture quality with its contrast, inky blacks and motion clarity is the best you can get. Absolutely stunning. In comparison to aw3423dw (which uses the same panel), in my experience the Samsung takes the cake with less issues and noises. It has no fans or loud coil whine noise with an external power supply. My unit didn’t have dead pixels unlike other monitors I have had. Flicker is also non existent. The firmware updates through WiFi automatically when you turn your screen on after there has been an update. All in all a perfect screen. Now, there are 2 issues:

1. The bigger issue out of the two is that the monitor sometimes does not want to connect to the pc even though the pc is outputting a signal. You will have to either restart the pc or reply the display cable in the back of the monitor. I already tried contacting Samsung about this issue but it’s useless because they are blaming my own pc for this issue. Keep in mind this is a known issue and you can find people talking about it on the internet. I’m sure this issue can be fixed with a firmware update and that is the only reason why I would give this 5 stars instead of 4. The aw3423dw does not support firmware updates and if this was the case with that monitor then you’d be dead in the water. But there is hope with this one.

2. The monitor comes with a remote to change your settings, and it has been confirmed that the next issue is not related to the remote. Sometimes (very rarely) the volume on the monitor itself changes automatically one up and you will have the volume indicator popping up on the left side (like a tv). This can be annoying if you are immersed into a game or movie and then have to look at the volume indicator until it disappears. Not a big deal for me because I don’t use the monitor speakers. It also happens very rarely. The tv feature seem a bit gimmicky sometimes but it’s acceptable.

Otherwise, great monitor. Definitely the best ultrawide monitor in this format.

title: Spendy but gets the job done
text:
I used this vertical mount solve several issues in my AM4 refresh.

I have an Asus ROG Strix-E Gaming X570 board in a Cooler Master H500M case. Which has worked great for a long time. When I moved away from the GTX 1070 and upgraded to a Asus TUF 4070 Ti, the card would no longer fit in the vertical location built into the case (max 2 slot).

The new card is 3.5 or so wide... x570 chipsets have active cooling on most boards, and when plugged into the mobo - the 4070 TI completely blocked the chipset cooling solution.

Enter the Cooler Master V3 mount!
This mount is not the sturdiness award winner of the world. No, your GPU will not fall out. But it will wiggle around and that's by design. I wouldn't want anything particularly rigid here since we're using a riser cable that needs some flexibility to keep from breaking things. Furthermore there is adjustability front to back to accommodate length as well as side to side to accommodate width and monitor cabling. Your mileage may vary here as there's not going to be gobs of room to work with on every case. If your case has a fully open expansion slot area, you'll probably be okay. If it has beams between each slot where the knock out plates are, you may need to remove them to make this work - especially if you're running multi monitor or bulky aftermarket cables.

This mount allowed me to roughly center my GPU so there's equal cooling on all sides. I added an additional 140mm fan up front right behind the 200mm fans that come with the case, and curved it with the GPU temp sensor to give it a little boost when things get warm. A slight curve here is less noise than a 60% curve off the triple GPU fan. I found this was overall more efficient!

If you have a GPU with minimal RGB, you'll be a little unimpressed I'm sure. If you have a big beautiful thicc boi GPU with flashy RGB, this is how you get it visible in your case.

(Who's idea was it to design a beautiful GPU and then spend eleven cents developing a backplate?)

title: Phenomenal sound for the price!
text:
I'm not going to lie, I didn't have a ton of hope for the quality of this Bluetooth speaker. They're typically tinny, easy to blow out, have problems connecting, and are generally overpriced for what they are. In addition, I'd gotten this for my husband to use with his computer as he can be the biggest of audio snobs with things like speakers and headphones. I wanted to see what he'd think of it.

He did some of the testing for this, and I did some (we were both together for the entirety of it, so I saw everything, as a side-note). He used the speaker with several devices, from laptops, tablets, phones, to his computer (a desktop). He purposely tried to distort the sound and put the volume up to maximum to test the integrity. He couldn't get it to distort or blow out with even his best efforts, aside from ONE time with a specific small range of sound from a device that doesn't communicate the file as clearly as most do today (regarding the coding). That was it. He couldn't make it behave poorly despite his best efforts.

Since then, he's carried it around everywhere, between rooms and used it for all kinds of things. He was gloating about it the same night we'd tested it. He loves it. For the price that it is, it's an absolutely amazing deal. This is highly recommended. It has had almost no trouble connecting, it's immediate, and it even has an almost separate range for the volume, which is rare these days. So if you've already maxed out the volume on your device, you can sometimes boost the volume even more with the speaker, as the easiest way to describe this. It has an analog-style dial on the side of the bar for volume, and if you turn it completely "down", it will turn off.

Overall, we are super happy with this. It's a small little sound bar, easily carried, and sounds amazing, and is very affordable. There isn't much more you could ask for.

As a note, the remote hasn't been used as much, but it's there if you need it. Seems to have average range of communication to other remotes of similar quality. Nothing special or abnormal there.

title: Very good product rich in featurea and cables
text:
Biggest reason to buy THIS system is the seller. Crazy good service. I asked for an extra camera (free promotion?), and they verified everything else was fine. They mailed extra parts, and called several times with latest shipping and tracking info.
Now to the hardware.... Large screen with 2 inputs. Switches automatically to 2nd input when I go into reverse, or will automatically turn on the screen if set to off. Pretty smart.
The other camera can be used for various things. I have one in my horse trailer above the divider to make sure all is good back there. The wide angle lens sees it all and is very clear. Most would put it as a rear view for the trailer of course.
Easy to disable the bright white camera lights which I did to use the license plate camera as a rear view mirror. Didn't want it on upsetting drivers behind me and I have bright LED backing lights already It's not great at night as headlights tend to show as big white areas with no detail. But, for hitching, it's GREAT. Way better than my old one.
Another great thing, the kit comes with 3 long cables for almost any run length, and the seller would sell or send more.
The only very small issue is that the extension cable is meant to connect to a trailer when In use, but when not in use, there is no tethered cap, so it'll get dirty up in there eventually.
Installation is what you make of it. Could be fairly easy with the power plug adapter. I hard wired everything on mine and made a custom bracket to hang from the ceiling. Solid install and clean looking. Again, plenty of cable for even an overhead install on a large Super Duty truck.
Images can flip and invert for any need, but it's funny that the camera ID which is displayed for a couple of seconds also flips and inverts. Oops. No biggie.
Also recommend the manufacturer set the contrast to 1-10. It is 1-100 now and there is no need to have that fine of an adjustment for the brightness. It would be nice to set night/day mode faster, as going 50 or so counts takes a while.
Summary, great system and I'm VERY HAPPY I bought this one from this seller.

title: Do NOT BE TRICKED INTO GIVING A POSITIVE TEVIEW BEFORE YOU RECEIVE REPLACEMENT ITEMS.
text:
I received a keyboard and mouse that was nothing like what I bought. Upon contacting customer service, I was promised a shipment of new ones. I was also told what I purchased was not in stock at the time and so they sent whatever they had. Which were non working- dirty used items. Assured a new replacement for the items I ordered would be sent I cancelled the return. The replacements never arrived. I used supplements to get the system up and going. Screen is grainy, and the system buzzes at a ridiculous volume. CS told me this was normal?? This isn’t white noise this is a constant disturbing buzzing that has a volume louder than anything you are trying to hear through the trash provided speakers. For the speakers. The appear as what I ordered. They do not function as so. A rep did call me to check on the system. This was much appreciated. She stated the og replacement must have been “lost” in the mail and that she would issue another that should arrive in a few days. We have been unable to use the system in this wait. So I cannot give a review of the actual working system accurately.
They will however beg you almost to leave a great review of their customer service. Then send you links as the review applies to the actual equipment.
I felt a need to distinguish these 2. The system thus far has been trash. Promises made to replace and not kept.
However I appreciate them calling me instead of me having to track them down. They are very friendly although a language barrier. If I receive the replacement items this time, I will come back to update this review. Until then, if you can avoid this purchase do so.
Item was ordered I. December for Christmas. We’re near end of January and product is still non functional. I’m giving them until mid feb. to make it right. At that point if it’s still in operational,I will send it back for a full refund. I know the risk when buying refurb equipment. This isn’t that. It’s worse.

Edit to add- the keyboard and mouse were received. They are wired. What I purchased was shown as wireless. Wanted to update as I said I would.
I would not purchase from this seller again.

title: GREAT SOUND & AWESOME CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!
text:
This cd player is really complete. The sound is impeccable. It comes with earbuds which have excellent foam ear tips. (When using the tips properly, you should roll them around
your index and thumb then insert them into your ear canal for best quality sound) Even comes with extra sized tips.

This unit has bluetooth which requires patience on your part for recognition setup however I find bluetooth on any bluetooth device sometimes requires patience. Just read the excellent manual that comes in the box and is produced top notch. It's not one of those chinsy fold ups. Great care was put into it's layout.

The player comes with a charging cable, (USB-C type) . Latest tech. Also included, a 3.5 male to male wire to use headphones with wire which sound wise is better especially with cds, as they are recorded at 1,411 kbps which is not compared to streaming services which mostly have only 320 kbps for the highest point.

This player has two sound outputs so two users can enjoy your cds. The secondary output acts also as an antenna for the excellently programmed FM radio which is included in the decice,

There are 5 eq settings so when playing, remember to select the appropriate setting, ie rock for rock sound, classic etc.

Before I forget to mention, you can select random play, intro, straight play and other modes. Random is my fav.

No battery's needed. Built in with aprox 12-14 hours playtime depending on usage.

If you have an sd card or tf card, then there is a slot but your limited to size. I tried mine which I think is larger and I had no issues. Read the manual. Also random is available for the cards.

Btw, the unit recognizes mp3 disks or cdr home made disks etc, even folder handling of them.

There is a 5 year limited warranty. Awesome, and as mentioned at the top, EXCELLENT Customer Service.

Get this toy... It will NOT, accumulate dust,

A favor....use your best headphones for maximum pleasure.

title: Good basic trackball mouse
text: I've tried a number of trackball mice after deciding to forgo yet another Logitech tb mouse - when they were wired they'd last for years but now that they are Bluetooth they last 2 years or less. For the $60 to $80 price tag, it's just not worth it. So far, this is my favorite, the Lizprot. For half the price, you get a close facsimile of the original. My only complaints: it's much larger than the Logitech - and many of you know the Logitech is actually now larger than prior incarnations; it keeps getting bigger and therefore less comfortable for smaller hands. I'm not sure if there was a surge of construction workers becoming techies or why they have chosen to make these so much larger. The second complaint is that the ball, while precise, is not as easy to move as other trackball mice. While it's smooth and rolls appropriately, it does not speed across the page with a flick of your thumb. So, if you're someone who needs to slide it across a long Excel spreadsheet, or a gamer who needs to fly across the screen, you might not appreciate it the way someone who is doing detailed special effects. And third, I don't like that it goes to sleep quickly. You'll start rolling the track ball after 3-5 min pause & it's disengaged - feels like a glitch. it does wake up pretty quickly but you very often have to depress the left mouse key before it does so and it's a little disconcerting because you're never sure if that left click is going to engage on the screen or just wake up the mouse. For that reason I would not buy this again, but for the price I paid I am keeping it until I resolve or exhaust my search for the perfect new trackball mouse after Logitech let us all down. The colored lights is pretty, the mouse itself is attractive and easy to use, easy to connect to Bluetooth and will connect up to three devices which is a plus. God battery life and can be used during charging. So it's a pretty nice little package for the price of it lasts a year. I think I am going to break down and try that expensive brand and hope for the best. Once you've had track you can't go back. And if you have or trying to prevent carpal tunnel, I highly recommend trackball.

title: Great cover for the new Kindle Signature & the corners won’t crack because the back is silicone
text:
I got this cover for my new Kindle Signature. It’s a great cover. It fits like a glove and is very sturdy and well-made. I especially loved the cat on the cover, looks just like my Willow. The BEST thing about it is the silicone backing. I had gone through several hard plastic backed covers with my 2018 10th Generation Paperwhite Kindle in the last four years, because for some reason every one of them has cracked in the corners within months, and sometimes weeks, of having it, regardless of the manufacturer. This was never a problem with previous Kindles and hard plastic covers, but for some reason it always was with the 2018 model. The silicone backing on this Kindle Signature cover hugs the Kindle well, and still protects it without any fear of corners breaking at any time. I have been able to find a silicone backed version of it made by the same company for my 2018 Kindle but the choices for covers aren’t as cute. It’s a shame there aren’t more whimsical choices for the 2018 model with silicone backings like the multitude of choices available for the Kindle Signature version. There are some really fun covers for the 2018 model, but they all have hard plastic backings.

Unfortunately, I have to return this cover because the new Kindle Signature I purchased it for was a POS and constantly froze from day one, then started having some other major software issues within the first week. I kept hoping the glitches would work themselves out, but they have only gotten progressively worse. After reading many other negative reviews from people who had the same issues with the new Kindle Signature, I don’t want to exchange it, and chance getting another dud sent to me, then be past my window to return it and be stuck with an expensive and useless e-reader that I have already been tempted to throw against the wall on too many occasions in just a few weeks of having it.

If it would have fit my 2018 Paperwhite Kindle, I would keep this cover when I return my Kindle Signature. But unfortunately I have no use for it since it’s larger than what will fit my old Kindle. This cover is of a much higher quality than the taped up cracked corners of the hard plastic one currently on my old Kindle, and I will mourn the loss of such a well designed protective cover.

title: Very solid board.
text:
The MSI z790i is probably the best ITX Z board money can buy. It helps overclocking your cpu and ram really well. The shortcuts to UV and OC are really handy especially for those less technologically saavy and want the best efficiency or performance with a few clicks. There is a small fan and it is not obnoxious like other motherboards. The temps for components on the board are well within spec and the worst is the PCH usually in the 60s and 70s. I definitely recommend this board over the ROG strix z790 due to the daughterboard issues, the clunky hive module many do not like and the price of it is clearly not competitive for the features presented. OTOH the MSI z790i is priced very nice and will get you going where you need to go quick.

If I had one gripe with this board is I wished the connections were placed different or at least a little more easily accessible. ITX boards can be challenging in a SFF build and say having all the fan headers placed close together AND in a spot where it's easy to reach all 3 would have been much nicer but that is the price paid for ITX. Also, XMP has had no problems or hiccups whatsoever. Once trained boot is quick especially if you're using a high quality gen 4 drive. You'll be asking yourself what sorcery is this when it boots in ~15 seconds or games where you used to have to wait about 15-20 seconds will load in less than 5 seconds. The other minor grip I have is I wished the theme of this board more closely resembled that of the MSI z690i. That board looks very nice. The silvery whiteness of this board can throw a big wrench into your black themed build.

Nonetheless, if you're on the fence about a Z series board this is the one to get, especially if you don't know how to UV. If you're on the fence between this and a B series board, MSI or Asus might be up your alley if you want to save some money so you can get a better gpu. Mind you, B boards cannot OC and UV'ing will have to be done manually and most of the guides are for the Asus B boards. Thanks for reading.

title: Good Smart Watch But With Issues
text:
[[VIDEOID:68c63cccf148eb628cd690bf0303956f]] This smart watch is stylish and comes with two bands included - one brown and one black.

What I Like:
--The watch is bright enough to see in the daylight.
--The accompanying app (I use the iOS version) paired easily with the watch (after a bit of a problem described below in "What I Don't Like".
--The app has several different watch face styles that you can download. I'm a minimalist in that regard, so I appreciated having some options.
--Great battery life. I have been using it for two days now and the battery is at 94%. Based on that, I think I can expect to get at least a week per charge.
--Tracks sleep, steps, heart rate, blood oxygen, etc. and syncs this information to the app.
--The app has an option to have a "free" account without registration - I opted for this, so I do not know if there are other benefits with registering.

What I Don't Like:
--Out of the box, the watch was unresponsive. It was charged and the display illuminated faintly (see pics and video) but it would not respond to the app or to the buttons on the watch. There appears to be no way to manually reset or restart the watch (nothing in the instructions, and I tried multiple button combinations). Charging the watch did not resolve the issue. I ended up letting it sit with the backlight stuck on for a couple of days until it finally ran out of battery and shut down. After it shut down, it started behaving normally and I've had no issues since. However, I almost gave it a one-star review and shipped it back before deciding to let the battery run out so it would be forced to restart. To the manufacturer: Include a restart/reboot function that can be done without accessing the watch menu!!!
--The connections for the band are snug, but the buttons are difficult to press (takes some pressure) and this usually pushes the band out of place a few millimeters.

Overall, this seems to be a good watch.

title: Quality Performance and Affordibility
text:
The sound quality of the X1 Sports Edition “over the ear” earbuds, Tranya’s latest release, is impossible to match. Especially at this price level. These earbuds provide long lasting wear-ability and comfort as well as practical new features like wireless charging and a digital state-of-charge display. I’m always glad to see a device that doesn’t require a unique set of charging cables to add “even more” clutter on my desk. Like most users, my two main considerations when buying audio devices is affordability and sound quality. Pretty much in that order. I’ve discovered over past years, Tranya consistently does not disappoint in either category. On more than one occasion I’ve inadvertently forgotten my earbuds in my clothes following a vigorous workout and thus put them through the wash. I’ve determined this experience to be largely disadvantageous. But, can’t stress how impactful this can be with earbuds costing $200+. At this cost and performance level it almost makes sense to buy an extra pair for emergencies.

Having owned (and lost) my share of expensive Samsung, Bose and, Apple earbuds, I can fully appreciate the value of Tranya’s products. If you consider, for around $50 you can enjoy the “best of best” and you haven’t had to make a major investment. It just doesn’t seem to make good (dollars) and sense to decide otherwise. From a technical point of view, the pure audio fidelity, noise cancelation and professional level sound quality are, in most cases, better than competing higher priced offerings. I hasten to add, the clever new “4 mic” feature has significantly improved understandability when making and answering calls. Perhaps a minor attribute to others but, I particularly like the size and accessibility of the mode control buttons. From personal experience, I’ll share, sweaty large fingers do not lend themselves well to the finesse required of typical (petite) earbud controls. Also worthy of mention, the X1 affords ease of setup and operation.

I own and highly recommend the Tranya X1 over-the-ear Sports Earbuds. Great product! Great customer support!

title: Very nice cover
text:
Trying to get more habitual with digital art this year over traditional so needed something to carry my surface around in a bag like my sketchbook, this fits the bill perfectly, it looks stylish and is well made and fit my Surface Pro 7 exactly, it does add a little bulk to my tablet but that's not unexpected, I only had a few things I was a little meh on outlined below, but overall very happy with my purchase

Pros:

-Feels very nice
-Magnetic closure in front and on the pocket
-Fit my Surface Pro 7 perfect with the Microsoft type cover it came with
-Has a pen holder
-There is a hole for the back facing camera which I don't use but thought was nice

Cons:

-The straps to hold it in on the inside at the bottom, I came to complain about them being on the screen/having to be removed to make the computer stand or charge and thankfully read a couple reviews before I finally got it, the straps go on the fold out stand under the main screen not over the whole computer, while this is probably common sense I would've liked a little card with a diagram to show me how it fits, this solved my issues with stand compatibility/straps over the screen etc. Which were most of my complaint with this product (and looks like a similar complaint with other reviewers) -- see my photos of straps on the correct way and computer standing/charging port clear

-The pocket is nice, but made very slim, this isn't a deal breaker but it cannot fit my charging block laying flat without puffing out/pressing against the back of the surface (see photo), it does hold my small items like drawing glove, papers etc. That are thin and flat

-The way the pen holder is sewn it causes the pen to hang out on the outer side of the case which makes me nervous about it snagging (see photo) it would've been nice if the pen holder had been stitched a little closer in so the pen sat under the lip of the case against the tablet (in fact my pen would've been able to magnet to the side of the computer and keep itself still in the holder)

title: The Perfect Addition to Your Entertainment System!
text:
I recently got my hands on the HOMATICS Smart TV Box and I'm here to share my experience with this Android 11.0 TV box.

First of all, the setup was very easy and straightforward. It was quick and simple to connect the TV box to my TV and get it up and running. I was impressed by the speed and efficiency of the box when I started using it. The 2GB + 16GB memory provides ample space for downloading all the movies, games, or files you want without any issues. The voice control remote is also a great feature, which made navigating the interface much easier and faster. You can quickly and easily access different apps like Netflix, YouTube, and Google Play with just the press of a button.

The picture quality is also impressive. This 4K streaming TV box is optimized for 4K playback, which delivers an amazing processing power (Up to 4Kp@60) to deliver the best content and super smooth interface experience. The HDR10+ support provides high-quality video codecs on the market, including hevc, vp9, and av1. The content looks bright and clear, and the colors are vibrant.

The device also has excellent connectivity, including HD port, AV port, SPDIF port, network port, and 2 x USB port, which allow you to establish a high-quality connection for the best visual and audio performance. It also features 2 x 2 MINO Wi-Fi 2.4GHz/5GHz 802.11a/b/g/n/ac along with a 100M Ethernet connection.

However, the device does have one drawback. I wish it was a bit more durable. The plastic casing feels a bit flimsy and I'm not sure how long it will last with daily use.

In summary, the HOMATICS Smart TV Box is a great addition to your entertainment system. It is easy to set up, has impressive picture quality, and a voice control remote that makes navigating the interface much easier. The device also has excellent connectivity, allowing you to establish a high-quality connection for the best visual and audio performance. If you're looking for a high-quality TV box that can handle all your streaming needs, the HOMATICS Smart TV Box is an excellent choice.

title: Great little dashcam
text:
I do a lot of driving with my business and family. I had always had a plan to purchase a dashcam, but delayed in pulling the trigger. I just wasn't sure what I wanted, and I found it hard to justify the cost.
Then one day I got side swiped by a kid on the phone. I said I was definitely getting one then. Still didn't do it. It wasn't until I had a police officer tell me that I made a right on red, when I know for a fact that I hadn't, that I said decided it was time.
I spent several days looking at all the different cams. I didn't want a screen, or some big bulky thing on my windshield. I just wanted a high res camera with a memory card. I also didn't want to spend a small fortune on one, as I figured that may actually entice thieves rather than deter.
After my exhaustive search I settled on this one, and I couldn't have been happier. It's so low profile that I forget it's even there sometimes. The features are great, and the software is pretty easy to use. I do wish it were a little easier to get the videos off of it when need be. I'm sure there probably is, but I just don't know it. It still isn't too bad to do while sitting in the vehicle though.
I have mine hardwired and that is awesome. The camera was installed for two days when I came out of Costco to a large dent in the side of my truck. Hopped on the camera, was able to see the lady who didn't properly put her cart away, watch as it came flying across the parking lot, and bounce off the side of my truck. I'll never be able to find her, but I know what she looks like.
Now, to the reason this is only 4 stars. The SD card that they provided with the camera died. I don't know for how long it hasn't worked either. It's only a few months old, and that's a real bummer. I haven't looked at the warranty yet, but I doubt it's covered. So I'll be purchasing a new one.
Overall, I definitely recommend this camera if you want something low profile that takes high quality video. Just keep an eye on the SD card.

title: not easy to install
text:
first off im a professional installer and have been for 23 years. i got this for my commuter car. wanted something cheap and even at dealer cost, the name brands are a lot more expensive. my truck is the vehicle with the expensive sound system. just wanted something super cheap for my commuter car. so heres my take on this radio.

this unit takes a lot of work to install if you using iso mount (oem factory brackets and no dash kit). meaning most toyota, subaru, older honda, etc. the face is larger than pioneer, sony, kenwood, and alpine radios. i just spent few hours installing in my 01 subaru forester. uses isomount. sincs the face is slightly larger i had to drill new holes in the oem bracket to recess the radio back about 1/2 inch so the dash bezel could go back on. the touch screen is not the best. the corners especially, so if you have big hands, its cumbersome. the screen does not have adjustments to alter the image for position. the radio is a little lower in the dash of the subaru and when you look at the radio from the top down angle the screen washes out. looking at the screen dead on straight is ok, but from the angle im looking at it from the drivers position its got a white haze to it. the rear view camera is reversed. meaning left is right and right is left. it basically means the camera is a front camera. no way to switch the image for back up camera. will wait to hear what the manufacturer says about it. there is no way to turn the led lights on the camera off. slightly annoying there too. they say its a wide angle camera but it clearly is not. the image is so narrow i cant see the corners of the bumper. the camera is mounted up high right next to the washer fluid nozzle for the back window. so from almost 3 ft down i have about 3 ft of width. any camera at my shop would see far past the bumper corners. so it looks like im taking this camera out and replacing with one of mine. the android auto is ok though. from what i have tried. not sure if i want to return this or not, but heavily leaning towards it and spend the extra money on a pioneer or alpine.

title: Very good for the price
text:
I am very fond of the Maven C series binoculars, and I own several of them. There is a wow factor that this series has that is very appealing. Color rendition, is fantastic. Sharpness at focus is very good, although this larger C4 with it's 18x magnification, is not quite as sharp, as say my C1 10x42. This makes sense, since higher magnification, will bring out the shortcomings of any glass more readily.

The one downside, as is the case with most of the C series, is the short depth of field at focus. This means that you will have to focus more often, as you move from object to object. Even with a large tree, some branches will clearly be out of focus, while others are in focus. The C2 compacts also have this issue, but to a much lesser extent.

Field flatness is very good, and eye relief is also very good. Much like another reviewer stated, I plan on using this binocular on a tripod, instead of my spotting scope at low power, when low power is the preferred option. I have been frustrated in obtaining replicates of quick release plates for my tripod, but I discovered that by taking off the quick release plate, I could simply rest the binocular on the flat plate underneath, and that actually worked out very well. You do have to hold onto the binocular, but just to ensure that it doesn't slip off the tripod, but I found that very easy to accomplish.

Two potential concerns, depending upon your requirements - one, the diopter adjustment is a little tricky, and two, the IPD range, is not very good for those with narrow set eyes. The only way that I could reach collimation with both eyes, was to cut off the objective lens cover from the binocular body. The straps holding the objective lens covers, were preventing me from obtaining the required setting for collimation. Now for me, this isn't a big deal, because I don't plan on using these except on a tripod, so losing the covers, is less of a concern for me, because I will be relatively stationary while using the binoculars. But if you plan on taking these out into the field using a harness, then you might have a problem, if you have narrow set eyes.

title: I LOVE this speaker!
text:
Holy cow! This speaker is amazing! I don't even know where to begin with reviewing this because I love every feature so much! I'll try to quell my excitement long enough to get some order here.
Without further ado, here's a rundown of why this is now my new favorite portable speaker and will likely remain so for a long while.

- Sound quality. The sound quality of this speaker is so clean and crisp, I swear I'm hearing lyrics in old songs I never heard before. When you use the fancy SoundPulse button and let the speaker take over the equalizing, your music really comes alive!

-BASS. What a thumper! This thing cranks out true bass that HITS. The best part is, the bass doesn't pull power from the highs and mids, so you get a truly full sound.

-Battery life. The battery on this lasts long for me because even at 50% volume it is usually plenty loud for most working situations. According to the manual, at 50% with no lights, it'll last for 24 hours. So far I haven't killed my battery yet in use.

-Stereo speaker pairing ability. I'll fully agree that one amazing-sounding 40-watt speaker is more than enough for any personal music-listening situation, but what could be better than two in perfect stereo for a total of 80 watts of power? Well, I liked my first one so much, I bought a second one just for this purpose and I can't see needing any sort of home stereo system for a while. I don't even turn it up to 100% volume anymore because it is usually too much for my small space!

I don't really see any cons with these speakers. It's not even a "get what you pay for" deal. These are actual, good-quality speakers at a reasonable price point. I'm interested in seeing what else Tronsmart will offer in the future because I'm not kidding when I say I'd put these guys on the level as serious competitors with JBL or Sony. If you love your music more than just a little, or you'd like a nice sounding portable to take to a picnic or the beach, you really can't go wrong buying this.

title: Piece of Junk!
text:
Don't waste your money on this item - notice now the price has been jacked up from other reviews (which stated it was around $30 - now priced between $126 and $135 or so, probably to make it appear a high quality product, which it isn't!).

I received mine at a gift exchange party, in a nice gift bag and still sealed in the original container. It didn't work from the day I opened the package: some CDs played for maybe 22 - 24 seconds, then nothing and some not at all (all retail CDs, not W or RWs!). Earphones very uncomfortable (and I have a small head!). Also, the many of the written controls were so small that, after reading (then re-reading) the manual when it didn't work, just to be sure I was following all directions, which I was) I had to use a powerful magnifier just to read many of the tiny buttons!

I first contacted Amazon, since it was the only place I found it online (Bsaw that BestBuy had discontinued selling it), but was told it was not exchangeable for another one without the order number, which I did not have. I did locate the person who brought it to the gift exchange/"steal" party, who assured me it was purchased from Amazon!

I then contacted Insignia, who only told me the very same thing, even when I reminded them that this was shortly after Christmas and most stores/manufacturers would at least replace a defective item, but Insignia would not make any exceptions.

I have now read MANY bad Amazon reviews stating that it either didn't work as it should or stopped working after a very short period of time, and also notice that the price keeps going up and down - have seen a new one at around $60 up to $135 on Amazon alone.

My guess is that it's now an outdated product - and probably a cheap bulk purchase by sellers who are trying to just make as much profit from it as they can. Even the manufacturing company, Insignia, won't stand behind replacing it (I didn't insist on a refund - just asked for one that works!).

Buyer beware on this!

title: A pretty nice bag with just a few caveats - See Review:
text:
[[VIDEOID:8d0ef6ef3a0e08d827b667e40f8af110]] This review is part of Amazons Vine program. That out of he way, I have to say this bag is actually pretty nice. The bag does hold a 15.6' Mac or Windows laptop with no issues and probably could get away with two, however I wouldn't recommend it which I'll get to why. The bag had 3 colors and I ended up going for the yellow ,which I am glad I did as its a really nice color. It has a lot of pockets and is pretty much as advertised in the ad showing.
Honestly there isn't a lot to complain about its a pretty good computer bag that is indeed water resistant, I got caught in heavy rain and while being concerned my laptop was drowning in rain water , to my surprise it held well. The only reason I am giving this bag a 3 star or average rating is just that, its pretty average. Some of the material used to make the bag and the faux pockets give it a cheap feel, however it doesn't look cheap at all, and there is absolutely nothing wrong with a good sturdy average bag. The packaging as you can see was very nice and well presented, the look of the bag as I said has a really premium look to it, the space and individual pockets are very convenient and spacious. I like that it has a top handle on the top is almost like a purse type handle which is great if its holding a bunch of my electronics. That and the back strap that allows you to strap onto luggage when traveling for extra support is a win as well.
This bag is great, it's a middle of the road, average computer bag for a fair price and will do the job well. It has a very nice finished premium look or a designer look, really other than the 2 faux pockets I mentioned and some material feeling a tad under par, thus far it has proven to be a sturdy bag that is a steal and I would definitely recommend. For those that follow my reviews on other social platforms know I give straight up honest reviews good or bad. This bag gets a pass from me and thus far I am enjoying it on a daily basis in travels for business. I hope this review helps someone make a decision on this item and as always best wishes!

title: pretty cool keyboard and mouse set
text:
Are you tired of the same old boring computer keyboard and mouse? If you want to add a splash of color and personality to your desk, you might want to check out the MOFII Wireless Keyboard and Mouse. This product boasts a retro typewriter design with gorgeous blue colorful keys, making it a fun and stylish option. Let's take a look at the pros and cons of this product.
Starting with the positives, this wireless keyboard and mouse combo is incredibly easy to use, with a stable 35ft working range and a 2.4GHz wireless USB receiver that's easy to plug and play. Additionally, the keyboard features floating bubble keys that are flexible and removable, making it easy to clean any waste that accumulates. The inner concave round key design fits your fingertips perfectly, providing a comfortable typing touch. Plus, the soft click sound is not harsh on the ears.
The keyboard also has several shortcut functions and auto sleep mode to save power, including media hotkeys for quick control of player, volume, web home, email, and keyboard lock. The wireless keyboard and mouse will also auto-sleep after 5 minutes of inactivity, helping you to conserve power.
The product is also widely compatible with a variety of operating systems and devices, including Windows 11/10/8/7/XP/Vista/98/2000/ME and PC, Laptop, Desktop, Notebook, Chromebook, Smart TV, and more.
The only potential downside of this product is its durability. While the keyboard and mouse combo is well-built and functional, it may not be as durable as other keyboards and mice on the market. That said, the 1-year warranty offered by the manufacturer provides some reassurance and support for customers.
Overall, the MOFII Wireless Keyboard and Mouse is a fun and stylish option for anyone looking to add a pop of color to their desk. It's easy to use, comfortable to type on, and has some great features like shortcut functions and auto sleep mode. If you're looking for a unique and affordable keyboard and mouse combo that will help you stand out from the crowd, this product might be a great option. As Elle Woods said in Legally Blonde, "Whoever said orange is the new pink was seriously disturbed." But with this blue colorful keyboard and mouse combo, you can prove that blue is the new black.

title: A great intro to planar magnetic phones.
text:
Prior to owning these, my best benchmark for headphone quality would be the ATH-M50X, which I'm sure is the case for many going into the world of open-back headphones for the first time. They did the job with their dynamic drivers and closed back design, but now that i never go full-can outside the office, I knew something like these open-back headphones would be ideal for a desktop setup, given they don't get hot or uncomfortable, and i was definitely right about that. I can tell these will last long just from the lack of ear sweat, not to mention solid build quality. I get no creaking or extraneous noises when i put these on, which i love.

I was cautious going in to the planar magnetic side of things due to their iffy reputation among fans of bass, but i can say this is a speaker type definitely worth considering as open back headphones, and I'm now in love with this style. Now the bass is present and satisfying, but less pronounced than I'm used to, since these are balanced for accuracy. I have a FiiO A3 as my amp, which has a bass booster that doesn't compromise clarity from what i can hear, and does add a satisfying punch to my bass heavy stuff. Combining this type of speaker with an open back design doubles down on width and clarity since you don't have a speaker enclosure trapping and reflecting sound all over the place, but rather a magnetic coil / membrane that is more evenly distributed and allows sound to vent more evenly. These are the only planars i've owned, and they are pretty mid in terms of price range, yet they are the clearest sounding headphones i've ever heard. When it comes to dialing in volume, i was never a numbers guy, now I need to remember my settings so i don't risk pushing the volume, which is a good problem for these headphones because you'd need to deafen yourself just to find any distortion on these. The instrumental separation is unreal, lyrics will POP! Your ears will get drawn into melodic lines getting passed around that were previously almost inaudible. Headphones like this will change how you hear music.

If you're ready to drop a significant buck on your first quality pair of accurate monitors for a room with low background noise, these will blow your mind!

title: Lightweight Big Sound rechargeable speaker system with handle - Bluetooth/Hardwire connectivity
text:
[[VIDEOID:90fb1e8c18cdf9d78f73437f7711b9b1]] TREBLAB Model: HD-FORCE OUTDOOR STEREO PORTABLE SPEAKER SYSTEM is rechargeable supplied with USB Charger Cable ( NO AC Power Module ), 3.5mm AUX Cable and User Manual. Product is manufactured in China with Warranty of one (1) year from company located in Florida. Warranty Card with Support Contact information included in kit.

For test I utilized the Bluetooth connection. Speaker can also be connected through 3.5 AUX Cable or music played by inserting SD CARD. Maximum data size of SD CARD is 512GB. SPEAKER System as received was pre charged with enough power for test Bluetooth connectivity and music playback. Controls located on speaker top. Pressing ON SWITCH activates Bluetooth Pairing Mode with blue light ring around speaker top.
Selection of speaker on my table resulted in instant connection with no issues. As music plays the light ring keeps time with music and changes colors.

MUSIC PLAYBACK…. Is clear with no variations of sound levels. In my opinion and observation the sound has good quality for speaker of this size. By my measure it is approximately nine inches (9”) high, with a square shape with each side approximately four inches (4”). There is good BASS resonance and midrange. Test included Rock, Classical, Jazz, Hip Hop and Country. I liked the sound quality from this small portable speaker system. Treble was no issue and good overall quality with BASS and Mid Range.

Manufacturer rates the speaker for outdoor use with Water Resistance Specification of IPX6. As part of the weather resistant protection the inputs and SD slot have a rubber cover that snaps into place over the connectors. After speaker is charged it can be used as charger for other devices but must be in ON condition.
Recommended…. Five ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ Star

Your time and interest looking at my Review is appreciated. Thank you ! Intent, you find Valuable, Informative, Useful and HELPFUL. 😃

title: No port isolation. Instructions are inadequate. Works as basic PoE switch (albeit slower than many).
text:
I bought this switch for the fact that it advertised "vlan isolation," PoE long distance transmission, and gigabit uplink. I haven't yet tested the PoE long distance capabilities yet, because the vlan isolation does not work.

I plugged my uplink and my client device into each of the uplink ports, expecting that the switch would offer simple unmanaged switching to send traffic from client to uplink. That worked fine. Then I plugged both the uplink and the the client device into the 100mbit ports on the left - none of them "uplink" ports - and discovered that traffic still went from client through uplink. Those ports should have been isolated - i.e. traffic should not be allowed between client ports. That's what I need, and it doesn't do that.

Since it isn't a managed switch I'd not expect any vlan port tagging and trunking and such at any rate, but I was certainly hoping for simple port isolation on the client ports.

The instruction manual included with the switch is generic, and the diagrams even include pictures of a rack-mount system. There are no instructions as to what the switch on the front does, which says that it toggles between regular PoE mode and long-distance 10mbit/s PoE mode. But the product description says that it auto senses the need for that. So what's the switch for? I have no idea.

The 2Gbit uplinks work fine. Why would you need a 2Gbit uplink with 8 100mbit client ports though? Other than switching between the two 2Gbit ports, I suppose, that doesn't seem to offer any benefit.

As it is, I can find a use for it, but will have to invest in a more expensive managed switch I think to get the true port isolation I need. Maybe its long distance PoE run will work - I do have a need for a 200m ethernet PoE run for a remote access point. If it doesn't, I can always try a PoE range extender.

If the seller offers some way to configure the port isolation, I'll certainly change my review!

title: Doesn't charge to 100 and call audio is distorted... Might return and switch to Sony.
text:
Out of the box, the headphones looked great. I have a small head and the headphones felt loose, which unfortunately can't be adjusted. The product case was black despite me ordering the white smoke headphones, which was a little disappointing, but what can you do? I bought the headphones for the sound and function, so as long as those work, it will be worth it, right?

The headphones themselves sounded okay and the noise cancelling did the trick, however this is where the good steeped off. I use Discord and Slack often, and bought these headphones to work and game at home. After one minute on a group call, the audio began distorting and gargling. This only happened to me on the call, so I can only assume it was the headphones causing this, as I've never had this issue in the past.

I had to mess around with the settings in the call a lot, but to no avail, as it would cause my audio to not be heard or cause me to not hear the others on the call. I had to quit and rejoin the call multiple times for all the issues to eventually fix itself, but in the end, the audio was worse than it had been in the first minute of the call the first time I joined.

As for the issue with battery, I can never get the headphones to charge past 80%. I've had the headphones for a few days now, so I've tried plugging it into different outlets, closely monitoring it, restarting the headphones, and resetting them. No matter what, the headphones never seem to charge past 80% and the light never turns green or solid white (it is always either blinking or orange).

I was really looking forward to using these headphones, as I've loved Bose products in the past (particularly my old QC 25s), so I am going to try to do what I can to fix these issues.

But if nothing works, I might have to return these headphones and maybe get the Sony wh-1000xm4s instead. Even though they are more expensive, they might be more worth it if the calls and audio functions better.

I will do my best to update if the headphones can be fixed.

title: Wow.
text:
To start, if you're even thinking about trying these can get these for $120 or under, just do it. These are the first iems that I have tried since I got into the hobby that actually blew me away.

DISCLAIMER: I have used these for only a couple of days but want to give my first impressions because I think these are that good. In the last year, I have tried the Moondrop chu, ssp, aria, kato, blessing 2 and s8 as well as truthear zero and hexa and more recently, the qkz x hbb khan. The only iems I have at the moment are the Moondrop S8 and the Letshuoer S12.
I also have a pretty small ear and found the blessing 2, truthear zero and qkz khan to be too large and uncomfortable.

THE GOOD
First, the accessories, apart from the case, are absolutely amazing. So many tip options and the nicest cable I have received of all the iems I have tried. The build and fit are also the best I have felt in a long time, super premium and I can wear these for hours with no issue.

Looking at the graphs, I was concerned when I saw the treble and upper mid-range spikes as I am pretty sensitive to treble, but I find the S12 to be manageable, and excellent. Compared to my S8, which are a $700 iem, these sound more intimate and upfront, but have a surprisingly similar tuning. I still prefer my S8 as far as tuning but these fell a little more lively and fun. Bass is great, mids are great, treble is great, no complaints.

THE BAD
The case is a little small. With the quality of the cable, I feel like I'm crushing the buds slightly when they are in the case. Maybe a little to much treble? But that's it, these are great.

CONCLUSION
These are so good, I have not tried the timeless which I know these are comparable to, but for under $150 I don't see how these can be beaten especially in terms of comfort and sound.

title: Great Value!
text:
Received today and installed on a 2023 iPad Air 5 with a glass screen protector. The case fits tightly - maybe because it’s so cold here today and it had been outside for awhile. I had to heat the edges with a hairdryer and use a thin blade around the edges to allow the iPad to slip into the case. Don’t believe there is any way the iPad is going to fall out and the edges of the iPad are well protected. Doesn’t seem to interfere with the screen protector. Case seems solid and a little heavy, but I expected that — with the keyboard removed my iPad stands nicely on my lap in my chair while watching YT videos which is a key reason I bought it. I got the grey tweed(ish) case and it looks nice. The pencil holder is perfect - fits nice and tight and connects and charges while in place. Couldn’t figure out how to easily get the pen out and then realized you just push from the slot underneath. Better than any pencil holder I’ve seen on any other case.

The keyboard is superb. Connected almost immediately. I am a touch typist and the adjustment period was zero! This is mostly a traditional QWERTY layout so if you’ve gotten used to the new iOS keyboard layout it’s going to be a little different. I kept pounding the ‘delete’ key and wondering why nothing was happening — it still has the ‘backspace’ key which you may or may not like. The function keys across the top are pretty handy.

I have not figured out exactly how the keyboard stores when you close the case, and can’t find any illustration of it. It doesn’t “fit” the screen well and I’m not sure how I feel about that. If I didn’t have the glass screen protector along with Apple Care+ I doubt I’d store the keyboard in the case, and in fact, may not. But it seems the keyboard will stay in place when the case is folded up.

I will update this review if anything changes or if I get clarity / comfort with the way the keyboard stores.

title: It's about damn time!
text:
I've been interested in these dash cams for quite some time, and every time I look at them online, they all look similar with similar features. I only cared for a few because of their software integration with your mobile device. They were usually not all that great. Some of them had great features, but installing these cameras took work. I didn't want wires leading to my center console for these cameras to be powered.

Then there's the Ring Car Cam, and I was immediately sold. I like the fact that the installation was simple. And when I mean simple, I mean REALLY simple! I was wise to pre-order directly from Ring once they announced it and could get this purchase for $199 to save some money. But on top of that, because I was already a Ring protect subscriber, they gave me an extra $20 off, which made my purchase $179.99!

I like the fact that I can connect this to my OBD-II port in my 2023 Land Rover Discovery. At first, I was afraid that the Car Cam would drain my battery, but it didn't. You can set the battery usage to Low (their recommendation) for the shortest active time. This is best for cold days and vehicles drove less than three days per week or with a battery over three years old. And because I work from home and park my car in my garage, it didn't matter to me. The camera is a perfect size and doesn't stick out like a sore thumb. It just blends with my dash.

The only thing I don't like about this camera is the Car Cam flap that covers the rear-facing camera. It's hard to grab hold of the flap in the open position because the space between the Car Cam and the dash is too small. I have big hands, and it's a tight squeeze. The ring team should create an adhesive or an extension attachment to extend the handle of the flap.
